Some spice, ginger and strong rosemary and black pepper. Nice hoppage and malt with a dusty tobacco and jacket potato finish. Odd but I like it.

name: Inveralmond Independence
review: Cask - various. Pours dark amber, nose is nutty, toffee, taste is sweet toffee, fruity.

name: Inveralmond Independence
review: Cask at the Blackfriars, Glasgow. Pours copper with an off-white head. Roasted caramel aroma. Toffee, some fruits, light hoppy.

name: Inveralmond Independence
review: On cask at JDW, Galashiels - Light copper body with a slight white head and lacing. Slightly malty in the nose but pretty bland otherwise. Nutty flavour with plenty of malt. Nothing special, but nothing offensive either.

name: Inveralmond Independence
review: Amber colour with a thin off-white head. Malty and light spices on the nose. Taste is light sweet and bitter. OK, not that inspiring.

name: Inveralmond Independence
review: Pint in Blackfriars. Dark, golden on the eye, with light head. Slight malty nose. Spicy, malt taste. Perfect accompaniment to crisps and nuts.

name: Inveralmond Independence
review: Hazy amber beer with a sweet initial flavour and a dry, tangy finish. Quite refreshing.

name: Inveralmond Independence
review: Cask by handpump at Blackfriars, Glasgow - clear deep golden, thin creamy off-white head, caramel malty aroma, excellent lacing, creamy texture, sweet malty, hint of apple, refreshing drink

name: Inveralmond Independence
review: Cask: This is a pretty average bitter with a nice sessionable ABV. Nothing special but not bad either.

name: Inveralmond Independence
review: Cask @ Golden Rule, Edinburgh Dark golden amber, creamy white head, some lacing. Aroma of fruity sweet caramel malts, not much on the nose Taste - sweet caramel malts, honey, light fruits, some herbal notes, vague hint of almond? (!) Palate - soft carb. medium body, oily, dryish. Some biscuit in the finish. Overall - Slightly unusual flavour - one of their better beers.

name: Inveralmond Independence
review: In tap at the Queen’s Arms. Pours dark amber with a proportionate head. Nose of raisins, apricots with the toffee and expected biscuit crunch at the end. Taste of more apricots and toffee. Palate medium with a fairly balanced finish. Overall, liked it enough to take another.

name: Inveralmond Ossian Ale (Bottled)
review: Ricky white head left a froth on a translucent pale golden still body. Light citrus, floral & pale malt aroma. Medium bodied, well carbonated, light on the tongue & cloying on the back. Zesty tasting with faint citrus, summer berry, faint malt & a pithy finish. Quaffable

name: Inveralmond Ossian Ale (Bottled)
review: Bottle, from Co-op, Orkney. Gold, thin short lived white head and gentle condition. Some melon fruitiness and a hint of esters in the nose, soft and slightly sweet in the mouth with hints of melon and a low chalky bitterness, finish is brief and slightly fruity.

name: Inveralmond Ossian Ale (Bottled)
review: Clear golden pour with lasting white head. Aroma mainly malty and soft. Taste also; lager malts, very light citric, small bitterness in finish. Ik carbo. Rather plain as blond als, but nice as a lager.

name: Inveralmond Ossian Ale (Bottled)
review: Clear dark golden colour, large dense white head; aroma of lemony, floral fruity and biscuity-malty notes; taste is the same with some metalloc bitterness; not bad

name: Inveralmond Ossian Ale (Bottled)
review: Bottle at Forthill Sports Centre. Can't believe I haven't already rated this. Appearance - blonde with a generous head. Nose - lemon and pale malt. Taste - lemon barley water. Lemon zest finish. Palate - light bodied and creamy. Refreshing finish. Overall - decent.

name: Inveralmond Ossian Ale (Bottled)
review: Cerveza bastante ligera, con notas frutales. Limpia y clara. Refrescante con alta gasificación.

name: Inveralmond Ossian Ale (Bottled)
review: Pours clear golden with white head, that won‘t stay for long. Fresh malty and gently bitter flavour. Easy to drink, yet not very intense in taste. Quenches your thirst well.

name: Inveralmond Ossian Ale (Bottled)
review: 14/20 used to love it, still really good, really fresh lager ,so easy drinking, with a big taste for 4.1%, lemon taste with the lager.

name: Inveralmond Ossian Ale (Bottled)
review: Hazy golden with a fair bit of carbonation running up the glass. Thin white head which quickly dissipates. Aroma of lemon, citrus, grass and malts. Taste is quite pleasant, with the bready biscuity malts balanced well with a lemon/citrus zest. Not too sweet, not too bitter. Not much to distinguish it from other decent golden ales though. Also a little too much carbonation for me. I definitely prefer the cask version.

name: Inveralmond Ossian Ale (Bottled)
review: 500ml bottle: BBE Dec 2018. Poured into an Abbot Ale glass tankard at home on 4th Nov 2017. Liked the cask version, let's see if this 'live tasting' comes up trumps too. Nice light amber/orange body, clean and clear; the head a foaming blanket of off-white bubbles. Aroma has both hints of hops and maltiness, nice blend in the nose. The taste is semi-sweet, slightly fruity and hop bitter. Decent, but the cask offering is better in my opinion, just a little too much carbonation in the bottle.

name: Inveralmond Thrappledouser
review: Cask @SRAF 2013, 11th-14th July [paper rating backlog]. Pours golden, white head. Nose is citrus fruits, grass, slight toffee. taste is more of the same with a sweet finish and a slight floral touch.

name: Inveralmond Thrappledouser
review: 500ml bottle. Pours slightly hazy orange copper with a small off white head. Biscuit malt with citrus and peppery spice on the nose. Taste is a nice balance of biscuit and toffee malt and lemon, grapefruit and orange peel bitterness. Hugely drinkable brew !

name: Inveralmond Thrappledouser
review: Cask Pint at Wibbas Down (JDW), Wimbledon, London in May 2010 - Golden-copper in colour. Fruity; citrus grapefruit/orange. Hoppy; spicy (peppery) and floral hops. Malty; toasty malts, buttery caramel, toffee. Nice fruit/hop/malty balance. Slightly bitter hop fruity throughout. Very drinkable. (2010-05)

name: Inveralmond Thrappledouser
review: nice beer with a golden amber color. The foam is low. The aroma of spices and fruits, but the taste is a little disappointed. Spices were, but fruits were replaced by wet bread and even some off-flavor. Still quite watery. Not bad, but I expected something more interesting.

name: Inveralmond Thrappledouser
review: On tap at Dirty Dick´s, Edinburgh. Pours golden color, white head. Aroma of malt, bit citrusy. Taste is bitter, malty, hoppy, bit citrusy.

name: Inveralmond Thrappledouser
review: Bottle from Asda. Clear amber. Nose is bitter, resin, sweet toasted malts. Tastes grainy malts, light bitterness, biscuit, light toffee.

name: Inveralmond Thrappledouser
review: Cask at The Railway, Putney as ’Inveralmond Thrappledouser’. Amber orange, still, translucent, small foamy white head, some thick lacing. Aroma is cheese powder and gummy sweets. Body is smooth with low carbonation. Taste is cheesy hop up front, then some suggestions of passionfruit and lime, bready malts, touches of soap and citrus. Not very bitter but dry into the finish. Definitely a grower not a show-er. Could easily drink a few pints of this as the cheesy first impression dies down quickly.

name: Inveralmond Thrappledouser
review: Aroma hint of spice. Flavour toffee toast . Unusual but nice. Appearance amber. Head laces well on glass. Overall another good one. Will try on its own again.

name: Inveralmond Thrappledouser
review: Sharzie from Rory Duncan watching rugby World Cup. Nice malty ale with fruity hop. Well balanced sessionable beer.

name: Inveralmond Thrappledouser
review: 500ml, brown bottle, co-op. Scent is grassy lager and zest. Taste is a delicious sweet grainy and grassy red ale. Finish is mild. Sessionable. Great

name: Inveralmond Lia Fail
review: Cask at The Moon Under Water (JDW), Watford in 2012. Bright ruby with an offwhite head. Aroma of lightly toasted malt, caramel and dried fruit. Fruity and malty sweet flavour.

name: Inveralmond Lia Fail
review: 0.5l bottle. Pours clear deep amber with off-white/beige head. Aroma of malt, caramel, british hops, subtle hints of citrus. Taste is quite malty, caramel, touch of bread and a slight citrus note. Bitter, refreshing, good stuff.

name: Inveralmond Lia Fail
review: 22-09-2019; bottle; at home (bought somewhere in Scotland). The looks of the beer are very nice. The beer has a nice copper colour, with some touches of nice caramel. The beer is crystal clear and bubbles nicely. On top there is a nice layer of frothy off-white foam. Foam retention is very good. A nice drape stays on top of the beer for quite some time. Nothing wrong with this. I like it. The aroma of the beer is also very nice. It is different from what I'd expect. The malts are delicious. They give the beer toast, roast, a hint of chocolate and some coffee. Nice smooth roasted bouquet. The hops are nice. Earthy and leaflike. They give the beer a nice touch, that goes well with the malts. Yeast gives a creamy fruity aroma, with a touch of banana. It is quite nice. The taste of the beer is also quite nice. The malts give the beer some very nice sweets, but also toasty bitters and roasty salty notes. The hops give more bitterness. For a bitter, it isn't that bitter. Well balanced though. The creamy yeast note makes it extra smooth and balanced. The palate of the beer is also nice. Smooth beer, medium body and medium carbonation. The finish is nice. It has some nice bitter roast, followed by the bitterness of the hops. This hop bitterness in the finish is clearly a Bitter feature, really nice. All in all, a very nice beer.

name: Inveralmond Lia Fail
review: Bottle, from Co-op, Orkney. Chestnut brown, thin but lasting white head and moderate condition. Gentle malty nose with some earthy hop notes and a hint of banana fruitiness, full bodied in the mouth with some burnt toffee, an earthy and a slight tang of fruitiness. Finish has a restrained roasted bitterness, some sweet toffee and a tingle of hop resin.

name: Inveralmond Lia Fail
review: Pint at the Red Lion Wetherspoons. Thick creamy beige head. Clear Amber pour. Light bitterness

name: Inveralmond Lia Fail
review: Clear castaign colour body with tan head; OK retention. Aroma indeed bit nutty and Chocolate. Taste same, starting moderate sweet and developing to mild bitter. OK carbo, slightly watery. Not bad.

name: Inveralmond Lia Fail
review: On cask at the ford madox brown reached out of the glass and gives you a great big hug malty and comforting

name: Inveralmond Lia Fail
review: On tap at JDW Plaza in Rugeley. Pours a very dark brown with a light frothy head. Aroma was a mixture of coffee, chocolate and burnt toast. Malty and sweet to taste with burnt toast, coffee and peaty overtones. A nice bitter aftertaste. A well balanced dark ale with plenty of flavours.

name: Inveralmond Lia Fail
review: Deep red brown colour. Light tan head. Sweet roasty rasin chocolate nutty firm aroma. Flavours of coca, loads of malt, dark fruits and earthy hops. Long dry spicy finish. Great ale.

name: Inveralmond Lia Fail
review: On draught as a guest beer. Dark amber and looses head quickly. Malty taste, strong beer. Very nice

name: Isle of Skye Red
review: Clear, copper colored, medium off white head. Malty, bit toffee and toasty, some fruity notes, medium sweet malt, moderate bitterness, dry finish, bit nutty. Medium- bodied, soft carbonation, oily.

name: Isle of Skye Red
review: 29Jun2019 Floral notes, fruit compote, bittersweet grain malts, resin, pine. Clear brown, small, creamy, off-white head. Light bitter. More floral notes, bitter marmalade, red berry compote, soft carbonation, medium bodied. Fairly decent for the style. Bottle from Co-op Food.

name: Isle of Skye Red
review: Bottle in Scotland, pouring clear brown with a tan head. Hardly any aroma; maybe in beginning indeed some faint nutty tones, but later away; not even malts. Taste is caramel and dried fruits; moderate sweet, soft bitter. This is an easy, well-balanced, but rather non-descript beer. Because of the name one would expect a reddish beer with red fruits, but nope...

name: Isle of Skye Red
review: Pours a brown-Amber with suds of white head. Toasted malt aroma and taste, not sweet but a bit of red apple notes. Notes: on cask at the Bosville, Portree Scotland, June ‘19

name: Isle of Skye Red
review: On cask at The Captain James Lang, Dumbarton. Pours a amber red with a white head. Aroma: biscuity malt, toffee, dried fruit, lemon, mild caramel and grainy notes. Taste: mild biscuity malt, mild toffee, mild dried fruit. This was thin and watery. It smelt better than it tasted. This was pretty average.

name: Isle of Skye Red
review: Aus der Flasche 2015-05 getrunken. Eine schöne Kombination aus Frucht und Hopfenbitterkeit mit leichte Malzaroma.

name: Isle of Skye Red
review: Bottle , smallish head, clear deep red color, aroma of caramel, biscuit and dark fruit, biscuity flavor with a light bitterness and a light pleasant sweetness. Nice but quite simple.

name: Isle of Skye Red
review: Cask at Westford Inn North Uist. Clear amber colour with off white head. Light caramel malts red hue beer

name: Isle of Skye Red
review: Clear dark redish brown, rich and creamy lacing, lasting foam. Caramel aroma and taste, malty too. (Portree 201806)

name: Isle of Skye Red
review: Bottle. Pours dark copper with thin head. Aroma of malts and roast. Taste is very mild and warm around malty and some fruity flavors. Very distant honey, without tasting too sweet. Has no bitter elements.

name: Isle of Skye Young Pretender
review: Cask at The Bothy, Fort Augustus in 2016. Clear deep golden with a white head. Aroma of pale malt, soft fruit and elderflower. Dried fruit, grain and biscuity malt flavours.

name: Isle of Skye Young Pretender
review: Clear, golden-orange colored, small off white head. Malty, some grain, medium sweetness and bitterness, bit toasty, quite light fruity and herbal hops, dry bitter finish. Medium bodied, soft- carbonation, bit oily. Could be fresher.

name: Isle of Skye Young Pretender
review: 02Jul2019 Grain and cereal malts, caramel, bread. Slightly hazy, medium, creamy, white head. Light bitter. More grain and cereal malts, wet straw, grass, dough, soft carbonation, medium bodied. A wee boring. Draft at Uig Hotel, Uig.

name: Isle of Skye Young Pretender
review: Bottle from Skye brewery, pouring beautifully clear deep golden with foamy white head; good retention. Aroma is rather weak; malty and bit grassy. Taste is rather dry, with a tiny, delicate bitterness and a moderate sweet finish (bit towards yellow fruits or honey). Smooth feel, with a firm body for a session ale. Not very specific but well done.

name: Isle of Skye Young Pretender
review: Pours golden in color with white head. Light fruity floral aroma and taste. Notes: bottle at Raasy House, Scotland Jun ‘19

name: Isle of Skye Young Pretender
review: Bottle. Nice head with goodduration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are grass, malt, caramel, notes of butter, fruits and hops. Sweet finish.

name: Isle of Skye Young Pretender
review: Tried at the Lincoln beer festival. Atoma is do light hints of citrus at damp. Taste isdlight four and sweet. Medium body.

name: Isle of Skye Young Pretender
review: Only had a sip of this beer around Hughes. Apart from an evening session this was definitely my favourite. I will market down as one to follow up in more details and will update this review accordingly.

name: Isle of Skye Young Pretender
review: 500ml bottle from the Aldi Scottish Ale festival. This is the bottled 3.8% ABV version, not cask. It starts of sweet with a grainy dryness to follow, the wheat is very noticeable and I like the balance of this one. Its a bit different to the run of the mill but hits the spot. Probably the best I have had of late.

name: Isle of Skye Young Pretender
review: Cask at Westford Inn North Uist. Clear gold with white head. Light malty wheat caramel notes

name: Isle of Skye Blaven
review: 01Jul2019 Yeasty grain and cereal malts, bread. Clear gold, medium, creamy, white head. Light bitter. More grain and cereal malts, bread, yeast, wet straw, soft carbonation, medium bodied. Boring. Bottle from Co-op Food.

name: Isle of Skye Blaven
review: Bottle in Scotland, pouring nice clear deep golden, with a near-white head. Aroma is very malty, bready. Taste is dry, bit yeasty, mild bitter & sweet; not bad. Not their best brew.

name: Isle of Skye Blaven
review: Pours a golden in color with white head. Fairly sweet malt aroma and taste with a balance. Notes: On cask at the Old Inn by Talisker.

name: Isle of Skye Blaven
review: Aus der Flasche 2015-05 getrunken. Ein sehr einfaches, aber süffiges Bitter. Etwas Langweilig, aber nicht schlecht!

name: Isle of Skye Blaven
review: Had a bottle while in Scotland. Fairly nice scent with a nice golden color. A bit sweet, the bartender said it was like an IPA and the description says it’s malty but it didn’t seem like either. Not bad though and a good local beer ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Isle of Skye Blaven
review: Bottle, from Gairloch Hotel. Hazy golden brown, thin but sustained white head and gentle condition. Slight yeasty sweetness and some grain notes in the nose, slightly earthy but dominantly yeasty in the mouth with a hint of smokiness and some sweet malt, before a faint chemical note emerges, finish has a lingering yeast bitterness with a hint of coconut.

name: Isle of Skye Blaven
review: Bottle at home in Hackney - cheers to the Nellzer for hauling back to London from the North. Pours totally clear burnished gold with a frothy, mostly white head. Reasonably well rounded, with bready malts, a touch of butter, bitter grass and sun-kissed hay, undertones of ripe citrus fruits. Light bodied, a little oily, with fine carbonation. Finishes with bready malts, some dough, mellow grassy bitterness, orange peel. A fairly basic ale, but entirely drinkable, to be fair.

name: Isle of Skye Blaven
review: Bottle from Coop in Portree, Isle of Skye, Scotland. Pours deep golden on the brink to amber with a decent head (one finger). Offers a surprising range of flavors beyond the regular Lager or Bitter. Has a lot of fruit and some element that I think could be peat (but not sure). A very gentle bitterness completes the comparably complex taste of this very good brew.

name: Isle of Skye Blaven
review: Bottle. Clear golden beer, thick white head. Very light aroma of grassy hop. Tastes of citrus, apple, a bit of caramel and malt. Not a strong taste but crisp and refreshing. Light, airy aftertaste with a bit of biscuit. Not great but not bad.

name: Isle of Skye Blaven
review: 500ml bottle. Pours a rusty gold with an off white head. Nose is grainy, toasted malt some caramel and green apple peel. Touch of citrus too. Fairly sweet toasted toffee green apple, with some cereal and lemon peel leading into a medium bitter finish. The bitter finish saves this one, as the beer starts out a little over sweet for me. Pretty good all things considered !

name: Isle of Skye Gold
review: Cask at The Bothy, Fort Augustus in 2016. Clear mid golden with a thin white head. Aroma of soft fruit, straw and malt. Malty, sweetish flavour.

name: Isle of Skye Gold
review: Bottle 50 cl. Pours a clear golden, with a lacing white head. Aroma so British it almost hurts. The description tries to make this something very special. But reality is: it's an archetype Golden Ale - and not a Bitter as it is listed here. 230819

name: Isle of Skye Gold
review: Clear, golden-orange colored, small white head, not too lasting. Mostly malty aroma, biscuity, medium- sweet, moderate- hoppy earthy, floral and spicy notes, some grainy notes, dry finish. Medium to light bodied, soft carbonation, bit oily.

name: Isle of Skye Gold
review: W aromacie s³odowe, trochê mydlane, ale te¿ kwiatowe. W smaku okej, odczucie trochê w stronê wytrawnego, w sumie doœæ czysty profil jak na brytyjskie ale. Konkret goryczka, nieco pio³unowa w charakterze. Nie jakaœ najprzyjemniejsza, ale sprawia, ¿e coœ siê tutaj dzieje. Oceniaj¹c w stylu, jest nawet spoko, dobra alternatywa dla jasnego lagera.

name: Isle of Skye Gold
review: 29Jun2019 Bread, grain and cereal malts, floral notes, straw, hay. Clear gold, small, creamy, white head. Light bitter. More bitter grain and cereal malts, wet straw, floral bitterness, soft carbonation, medium bodied. Alright. Bottle from Co-op Food.

name: Milton Minotaur
review: Cask 1/3 pint at the 46th Cambridge Beer Festival, 2019. ABV 3.3%. Very dark reddish brown colour, beige head. Aroma of dust, grain and a hint of chocolate. Light bodied. The flavour has notes of chocolate with a decent fruitiness.

name: Milton Minotaur
review: Cask @ Bricklayers at Arms, Luton. Nice head with good duration. Color is black. Aroma and taste are roast malt, hops, caramel, fruits and has a nice sweet finish.

name: Milton Minotaur
review: Cask @ The Bricklayers Arms, Luton. Clear dark brown with an offf-white head. Aroma is sweet, roasted malt and soy sauce. Flavor is medium sweet and light bitter. Sweet finish. 160218

name: Milton Minotaur
review: Cask at the 9th Elysian Winter Beer Festival. Pours ruby brown with a small off-white head. Aroma of chocolate and malt, with moderate roasting and a hint of coffee. Moderate sweetness, medium roasted bitterness, Light body, watery texture, soft carbonation.

name: Milton Minotaur
review: Cask. Dark Brown in colour. Roasty malts, chocolate, caramel, hint of coffee. Dark fruit notes. Lightly hopped. Sweet, malty & fruity mild. Tasty for low ABV but a bit thin. Not bad. (2008)

name: Milton Minotaur
review: Cask at the Pembury. It pours a clean dark copper color with a small beige head. Aroma is tangy soggy socks sole biscuit. Taste is also softly biscuity and grainy, mostly bollocksed. Soft bodied with soft carbonation. Overall, not good

name: Milton Minotaur
review: Cask handpull at The Pembury as Milton Minotaur. Dark brown, cola black in a certain light, slight red hue, foamy light brown head. Aroma is cardboard, chocolate. Body is light and smooth with soft carbonation. Taste is watery malts, ashtray, roast definitely lifts it from being overly watery, demerara.

name: Milton Minotaur
review: on tap ambrato carico noce quasi piatta discreta maltatura un po’ tostata crosta di pane non molto amara

name: Milton Minotaur
review: Cask at the Cambridge Winter Ales Festival 2016. Mid-brown, watery-looking and flat. Used coffee grounds and cereal in the scent,sweet taste with some bitter-sour nearer to the finish. Body is weak, it tastes a bit like beer-flavoured water. There are some decent flavours in here but when all is said and done, it’s not my kind of drink.

name: Milton Minotaur
review: Gravity cask@wirral beer festival, Port sunlight. Black beer with small head. Aroma of chocolate and dark malts. Taste is some dark fruit, chocolate and malts. A little sweetness. Good.

name: Milton Jupiter
review: Cask at the Pembury, 12/04/18. Clear golden with a decent off white covering. Nose is biscuit, crackers, faint sulphuric edge, hedgerow. Taste comprises biscuit, earthy, grains, straw, stale bread, caramel. Medium bodied, soft carbonation, semi drying close with a moderate bitter edge. Ok bitter.

name: Milton Jupiter
review: Cask handpull at the Pembury Tavern Hackney as Milton Jupiter, 3.5%. Pours a hazy orange, a vibrant shade in this light, still with a small froth atop. Aroma is airy, bready, worn socks, biscuits. Body is smooth with soft to tingly carbonation for cask. Taste is burnt crackers, little tobacco, biscuity, little chalky, leafy hop linger, pleasing bitterness. I think this is pretty decent. Almost a little smokey phenol. (6-4-6-4-14=3.4)

name: Milton Jupiter
review: Cask, gravity, Glasgow Real Ale Festival, The Briggait, caramel malt aroma, clear golden, thin white head, no lacing, creamy malty, harsh biscuit flavour, which mellows as it goes down, flavourful, sweet malty finish

name: Milton Jupiter
review: Cask at the Devonshire Arms, Cambridge. Light to mid-gold, little to no visible carbonation or head. Grainy aroma with a note of buttered toast and orange marmalade. Basic but enjoyable bittersweet taste with a sulphurous note gaining momentum toward the finish. Fuller, thicker mouthfeel than would normally be expected of this ABV and style. Tasty all in all.

name: Milton Jupiter
review: Cask, gravity, at Bedford Beer Festival ’10. Copper gold. Glorious aroma of biscuity sponge and lemon custard. Sweet crusty taste. Mid to sharp bitterness. Good as the winter sponge pudding they used to serve in some primary schools..

name: Milton Jupiter
review: Cask gravity @ Reading Beer Festival 2008. Clear medium yellow amber color with a small to average, frothy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toffee, buttery. Flavor is moderate sweet and light light bitter with a average duration. Body is medium to light, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is flat. (020508)

name: Milton Jupiter
review: (Cask at Oakdale Arms, Harringay, London, 24 April 2008) Dark amber colour with brief, white head. Suspiciously cloudy. Fruity nose with notes of orange peel and earthy, slightly citrussy hops. Fruity taste with citrus, nuts, toffee and balanced amounts of earthy hops in the moderately bitter finish. Light body. Decent session beer, but hardly exciting.

name: Milton Jupiter
review: This used to be my regular drink at the St. Radegund (Cambridge) before it was sadly taken off in early 2007. A medium-coloured bitter that, when on form, has a complex and refreshing flavour. For me, a mixture of fruits, barley and even slightly nutty - also quite strongly bitter. It does seem to be tricky to keep, probably due to the low APV. Probably most easily found at the Oakdale Arms (Harringay, London) or Coalheavers (Peterborough)?

name: Milton Jupiter
review: cask @ 2nd pembury festival. Light gold with a white head. Barely there aroma of hops and fruit with some sweet buttery brown sugar. Bitter hoppy taste. Quite dry. Rather boring.

name: Milton Jupiter
review: Cask handpull at Pembury Tavern March BF 07. Gold/copper colour with lasting beige head. Earthy hop, some toffeeish malt on aroma. Pleasant in mouth. Some crisp drying hop on finish. Pleasant drinkable session bitter. First of the day.

name: Milton Neptune
review: Cask at Castle, Chancery Lane, London, 24 Nov 2010) Amber colour with brief, off-white head. Malty nose with toast, dried fruit and dusty hops. Malty, slightly roasty taste with notes of dried fruit, citrus, toast and dusty hops in a dry finish. On the thin side. Decent.

name: Milton Neptune
review: Cask at cloisters ... amber ... sweet toffe hop nose... dry light toffee hop... low fruit ... low bitterness ... little earth. ook butnot my thing

name: Milton Neptune
review: cask @ kingston bf 08. aroma of wet cardboard, snails, a bit of glue, old stinging nettles and diesel, quite unpleasant really. Straw yellow in colour, thin white rim, little lace. Flavour wise not much to start with, not much more than malty water in the middle and a to finish a bit of dry bitterness. wholey dissappointing.

name: Milton Neptune
review: Cask, Cow and Plough, Stoughton. Golden/amber with an off-white head. Aromas are fruity and spicy with pepper and fresh hops. Not very malty. Flavours are soft malts with lemon and some roast character. A bit thin.

name: Milton Neptune
review: Cask gravity at Planet Thanet BF 2006, Ramsgate. Amber colour with bubbly beige head. Some malt, some hop on aroma. Fruits are along the red berry lines. Bit of coffee too. Dryish finish, bit earthy/muddy on the end.

name: Milton Neptune
review: [Cask at GBBF 2004] An orange beer with no head. The aroma is sweet caramelic combined with hints of diacethyl. The flavor is roasted combined with hints of flowers, and with a dry bitter end.

name: Milton Neptune
review: [Cask conditioned] Amber coloured. Fruity and hoppy aroma. Hoppy and fruity flavour with notes of caramel and nuts. Bitter finish.

name: Milton Neptune
review: Gravity Cask, Catford Beer Festival. Beautiful fruit aroma with a flash of steel. Some pleasant mustiness overall. Huge sweetness that tends to dominate. Oak notes. Pleasant, but a bit clingy.

name: Milton Pegasus
review: Gravity poured half-pint at the 23rd Codsall Station beer festival on 3rd May 2019. Light amber/copper body, off-white crown. The nose gives notice of semi-sweet caramel maltiness in the taste, some mild fruitiness from the hops too. Decent.

name: Milton Pegasus
review: From old notes: Cask @ Booze on the Ouse fest, St. Ives, 2000. Amber color. Really good bitter, without being overly bitter. I wonder what I would think of it now...

name: Milton Pegasus
review: Cask @ Devonshire Arms, Cambridge. Nice head with good duration. Color is amber. Aroma and taste are toffee, hops, caramel and malt. Light bitter finish.

name: Milton Pegasus
review: Cask @ Devonshire Arms, Cambridge. Clear amber with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel and toffee. Flavor is medium sweet. Sweet finish. No real bitterness. 151018

name: Milton Pegasus
review: Cask @ Calans, Hebden Bridge. Amber-brown with a creamy head. Has a well balanced malty-bitterness with some bready graininess.

name: Milton Pegasus
review: Cask at St Jude's Tavern, Ipswich. Pours dark amber/brown with a bubbly off-white head. Aroma of biscuit, malt, toffee and dark fruits. Moderate sweetness, medium bitterness. Medium body, slight oily texture, soft carbonation. A decent bitter.

name: Milton Pegasus
review: Cask. Pours light amber gold with white lace top. Aroma is hop fruits of the non-citric kind. Taste is medium bitter with light sweetness initially. Palate is medium to light body, average to soft carbonation, tacky feel (whatever the opposite of smooth is), finish is not short but not languid

name: Milton Pegasus
review: Cask handpull at The Pembury Tavern as Milton Pegasus, 4.1%. Pours a dark almost rose gold, still and almost clear with a small greyish head. Aroma is a little cheese powder and syrup, breads. Body is smooth and rounded with soft carbonation. Taste has more cheese powder, tiger bread, sugary with a soft bitterness and a muddled fruitiness throughout. Middling stuff. (5-4-5-4-13=3.1)

name: Milton Pegasus
review: On tap at The White Lion, Norwich. Amber with a small white head. Malty, caramel aroma with a touch of grassy note. Sweet malty flavour with a touch of grass.

name: Milton Pegasus
review: Cask at The Haymakers, Cambridge. Clear amber/dark gold colour with a thin white head. There is sweet grainy aromas with some malty undertones. Taste is bitter with a few fruity notes. Everything is OK, but Milton have done better.

name: Milton Cyclops
review: 5th July 2017 Chelmsford Beer Festival. Cask. Light haze on this gold beer, a few pale cream colour bubbles. Palate is light and smooth, modest fine carbonation. Smooth sweetish malts, a touch of honey. Mild marmalade and a little lemon. Some sweet floralness. Light spice. Light dry finish. A dry but pretty drinkable golden. This ain’t an English Strong.

name: Milton Cyclops
review: Cask at the Pembury Tavern in Hackney. Nicely balanced, enjoyable session beer with hints of citrus.

name: Milton Cyclops
review: Copper, quite clean. Dark peach. Good mouth feel, but short aftertaste. It’s okay. (Pint shared at Haymakers pub)

name: Milton Cyclops
review: 2015-09-21. Crisp yellow body with a small white head. 3+ Aroma is mild, lightly fruity throughout. Flavour is lightly bitter, mild citrus notes. Smooth average to light bodied palate, soft to low carbonation. 3+ Mild overall but lovely. Cask at Bag O Nails, Bristol. Overheard: "He’s not gonna be able to visit a farm again is he?" Re: David Cameron, #baeofpigs.

name: Milton Cyclops
review: Cask at the Devonshire Arms, Cambridge. Golden, clear with almost no head. Apricot, tropical fruit and seawater in the aroma. Strong alcoholic fruity taste. Unfortunately the aftertaste is astringent bordering on acrid so the whole package is brought down a notch.

name: Milton Cyclops
review: Cask at The Pembury Tavern. Deep golden color, tiny white head. Aroma has some ... aromatic hops and fruits. Medium-bodied. Sweetish, malty, English hops. Nicely balanced and feels lots of than its abv.

name: Milton Cyclops
review: Cask at the Pembury Tavern - London. Pours clear gold with a frothy, white head. The nose holds sugary malts, faint toffee, some berries. Medium sweet flavorbwith bready malts, some apricot and nectarine, dough, English yeast, faint leafy hops, orange peel. Medium bodied with fine carbonation; OK condition. Sweet finish with more bready, lightly doughy malts, faint butterscotch, ripe citrus fruits. Tasty beer.

name: Milton Cyclops
review: Cask at The Pembury Tavern, Hackney, London. A golden coloured pour with a medium white head on top. Fruity, malty aroma. Tastes fruity, floral, slightly malty.

name: Milton Cyclops
review: Cask (handpump) @ Pembury Tavern, 90 Amhurst Road, Hackney, London, Greater London, England E8 1JH. Clear medium yellow orange colour with a small to average, frothy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, pale malt, caramel, moderate hoppy, citrus, lemon. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration, hoppy, citrus. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is flat. [20120813]

name: Milton Cyclops
review: Cask (White Horse, Parson’s Green) Initial fleshy fruity aroma, nice sweet maltiness too. Smooth palate, sweetish. Luscious, even - so moreish. Great fruity hop aromatics in the mouth, and leaves a gentle bitter bite too. Classic pale ale, I could session this happily.

name: Milton Mammon
review: Cask @ The Pembury Tavern, Hackney. Very dark ruby with a bubbly head. It's strong tasting, but this is slightly offset by a heavy berry-fruit sweetness. Unsurprisingly it has a sweet berry-fruit nose too.

name: Milton Mammon
review: Cask at the 22nd Cambridge Winter Ale Festival. Pours mahogany brown with a small bubbly beige head. Aroma of chocolate, winter spice and Christmas cake. Medium sweetness, moderate bitterness. Medium to full bodied, slight oily texture, soft carbonation.

name: Milton Mammon
review: Cask at the Pembury. It pours a clear amber color with a small beige head. Aroma is quite sweet and fruity with notes of chocolate fudge, rum cherries, coconut. Taste is also seeet and fruity again with more notes of cherries, cola, licorice, rum. Medium bodied with soft carbonation. Overall, very nice

name: Milton Mammon
review: Cask at Pembury T. It pours clear reddish - brown with a tiny head. The aroma is sweet, treacle, cherry cola, Dr Pepper, candy, dried fruit, eccles cake and wood. The taste is bitter - sweet, slick sticky, oily, wood, leather, twig, cherry, cherry cola, Dr Pepper, boost, fruit compote and leather with a drying, woody finish. Medium body and soft carbonation. Pretty fruity and boosty.

name: Milton Mammon
review: Cask handpull at The Pembury as Milton Mammon, 7%. Dark brown red hue, foamy off white head. Aroma is rich chocolate malts, fruit n nut choc, plum, rum n raisin fudge. Body is smooth with soft carbonation. Taste is plummy, chocolate, more fruit n nut chocolate, soft bitterness. Deserves its rep.

name: Milton Mammon
review: Cask. Dark Brown in colour. Roasty malts, caramel, chocolate. Massively fruity. Dried fruits & spices. Hugely flavoursome, rich & warming. Very drinkable. Superb beer. (2008)

name: Milton Mammon
review: On cask @ Pembury Tavern, London - UK. Color: deep dark black beer with no carbonation and no foam. Smell: domination of roasted malt, caramel, chocolate. Taste: medium body. Very nice warm taste of caramel. Good roasted malt and brown sugar with chocolate finish. Good attenuation. Aftertaste: nice bitterness. Very nice balance. Easy drinkable for this ABV.

name: Milton Mammon
review: Gravity Cask at St Peters Ale House, Bedford. Dark ruby brown with some translucency, pretty much flat. Light aroma of liquorice and warming alcohol. Taste is yummy: sweet and warming with enough hop backbone to give it balance. Raisin, port and chocolate in the finish. Medium to full body, slick mouthfeel. Good stuff overall.

name: Milton Mammon
review: Cask at the Pembury Tavern, 03/01/15. Chestnut brown with a moderate light beige covering. Nose is dark fruits, breadt, spice, light malt, toffee. Taste comprises toffee, biscuit notes, light yeast, rich fruit cake. Medium bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close. Ok.

name: Milton Mammon
review: Cask at the NWAF, Derby, ’14. Reddish brown pour with a beige head. Toffee malt and orchard fruit aroma. Flavours of toffee apple and sultana. Quite a smooth texture. Nice.

name: Ringwood Razorback (Cask)
review: Clear light red brown beer with very short dark white head, smell is honey and very light grass, taste is light malty, light bitter, light watery, short finish, light body, thin texture, soft carbonation, no fruits, boring (I have 0.5l bottle with best-before 06 May 20 and batch LA9065 03:07)

name: Ringwood Razorback (Cask)
review: Third, cask ale, beer flight at Bargeman's Rest. Shared with Finn. Clear dark amber body, fair lacing from a mostly dissipating white head. Moderate smell of mid-sweet caramel and grass. Biscuit flavours followed by a bittersweet tail. Fair enough. (Newport, Isle of Wight 21.10.2019).

name: Riverhead Butterley Bitter
review: Cask-conditioned at the Swan, York 5/10/2018. Deep gold in colour, with a tight, white, head. Sweet orange fruit, leafy hops, chewy malts, and a moderately bitter finish. Good.

name: Riverhead Butterley Bitter
review: Cask @ The Jemmy Hirst, Rawcliffe, East Yorkshire. Light brown in colour, light mouthfeel, fruity for a bitter. Ok beer.

name: Riverhead Butterley Bitter
review: From cask at Riverhead Brewery Tap, Marsden, with JFE 19.01.18. Clea golden. Dense and persistent off-white head. Aroma of pale malt and marmalade. Lots ofpale malt, grains and marmalade in taste. Medium low bitterness.

name: Riverhead Butterley Bitter
review: Leeds Beer Festival 2017. Golden ale. There’s some toffee notes that are slightly more stated, and linger longer in its taste than aroma.

name: Riverhead Butterley Bitter
review: Cask, handpump at The Riverhead Brewery Tap, Marsden, West Yorkshire, 22.04.11 Pours warm gold with a white head there is a slight haze. There is a touch of cardboard at first but then some citrus shows. Bit dry at the end, little bit thin. Easy drinking and inoffensive. A6 A4 T6 P3 Ov12 3.1

name: Riverhead Butterley Bitter
review: Cask as Boatland Bitter. A dark golden beer with a dense orangey head. The aroma has notes of malt as well as lighter notes of sulphur. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt as well as lighter notes of caramel and straw, leading to a lightly bitter finish. The mouthfeel is smooth.

name: Riverhead Butterley Bitter
review: Cask handpump at The Wellington, Birmingham. Golden orange with hardly any head. Not much scent, just a slight hint of flowers. More sweet than I would expect from a bitter, with a dry end. Quite malty, biscuits and cream in there with some straw and pears, I think. Quite a thick mouthfeel. Nice.

name: Riverhead Butterley Bitter
review: Cask (handpump) @ Rat & Ratchet (Ossett), 40 Chapel Hill, West Yorkshire, Huddersfield Road, HD1 3EB. [ As Riverhead Boatland Bitter ]. Clear medium to light amber color with a average to large, frothy to creamy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white to off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, fruity, light to moderate hoppy. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20100119]

name: Riverhead Butterley Bitter
review: Cask. I took this down as "Boatland Bitter" but guess it’s this one. Slightly hazy pale amber with a creamy off-white head. A little fruit and butter in the nose. Thin and watery with lots of caramel and fruit with a subdued bitterness. 190110

name: Riverhead Butterley Bitter
review: Cask at Peterborough beer fest. Alround rating: Buttery(shock shock horror) nutty, almond paste, floural, like very floural which helps it all.

name: Ringwood Old Thumper (Bottle) (UK)
review: Bottle, from historic notes. Source not recorded. Poured dark amber with a creamy off-white head. Aroma of malt, caramel, hops, fruit and a hint of spice. Medium sweetness, moderate bitterness. Medium body, oily texture, soft carbonation.

name: Ringwood Old Thumper (Bottle) (UK)
review: 500ml bottle in 2013. Clear deep brown with an offwhite head. Aroma of toffee, toasted malt and raisins. Overreaching hoppy bitterness in the flavour with biscuity malt undertones.

name: Ringwood Old Thumper (Bottle) (UK)
review: Just a touch too bitter and the bitterness lingers. Apart from that a lovely pint.

name: Ringwood Old Thumper (Bottle) (UK)
review: Nice Amber ale, very fruity, almost sweet, malty with toffee and a lovely color. One of the better guest ales at the Spoons recently.

name: Ringwood Old Thumper (Bottle) (UK)
review: 0.5cl bottle. Pours deep golden brown. Aroma and taste malty. Medium bitterness. Lingering aftertaste of malt.

name: Ringwood Old Thumper (Bottle) (UK)
review: Clear brown ale with a deepish malty bouquet - sweet (toffee) and discreetly fruity (apple). Nice, solid bitterness that carries over into a strong finish with a neat dry edge. Pretty impressive! There‘s even a hint of aniseed in there somewhere - but it‘s very elusive.

name: Ringwood Old Thumper (Bottle) (UK)
review: Pours brown with small head. Aroma is malty and nuty. Taste is bitter and malty.

name: Ringwood Old Thumper (Bottle) (UK)
review: Bottle from Liz/Larry. Pours amber body with slight haze and a white head. Bitter with citrus, fruitiness, caramel. Not bad.

name: Ringwood Old Thumper (Bottle) (UK)
review: 0.5l bottle. Dark golden color with white head. Aroma is malty, herbal, floral and earthy with some caramel. Taste is malty with medium bitterness and light caramel notes.

name: Ringwood Old Thumper (Bottle) (UK)
review: Pivo u flaši. Ako proèitate na flaši ili u tvornièkom opisu da je za neko pivo korišten Goldings ili Progress hmelj , onda oèekujte pravo Englesko gorko pivo. Goldings se drži za jednim od najboljih Engleskih hmeljeva a i Progress je na vrhu. To se naravno osjeti i u u aromi koja je inaèe još i sladno biljna. Okus osim gorèine ima lagane slatkoæe, onak' vrlo malo na suho voæe. Ak' vam je lijep dan , pa si ga želite malo zagorèati , popijte si jedan ovakav Engleski Bitter :) imat æe te cijeli dan u ustima taj gorkasti "posljeokus" :)

name: Ringwood Boon Doggle (Cask)
review: Decent mild easy drinkable golden ale Nothing wrong, but nothing exciting either Plain malty, mild fruity and mild herbal stuff [Cask at Hole in The Wall in York, England]

name: Ringwood Boon Doggle (Cask)
review: Cask at The Kings Arms, Ombersley. Strong apple flavours. Actually pretty easy drinking.

name: Ringwood Boon Doggle (Cask)
review: A blond beer with a very fruity taste. Very nice, this is a beer I will recommend. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Ringwood Boon Doggle (Cask)
review: Cask at Railway Inn, Winchester. Only ordered this because a mate says it's one of his favourites so thought I'd check it out. Will have to challenge him!! Awful. Light gold. Bubbly white head. Thin watery stuff. Smells eggy and tastes eggy with a hint of citrus. Rank. Drank ot as I was at a gig and it was watery.

name: Ringwood Boon Doggle (Cask)
review: This beer used to be great but for the last few months it has been cloudy and slightly sour. It's not the pub because the rest of the real ales are usually bright and clean tasting. I have watched the pub put new barrels on and about 8 out of 10 are like this.

name: Ringwood Boon Doggle (Cask)
review: Dec 2018 - Cask handpull at the Britannia, Borough. As Ringwood Boon Doggle, 4.2%. Pours a clear golden orange, still with a foamy ring of off white head. Aroma is cereals, some mild cheddar, crackers with cheese, some lemongrass. Body is smooth with soft carbonation. Taste is a touch sweet for a golden ale, straw and lemongrass, some lemon boiled sweets. I like the hop character but it's hidden behind the chewy malts. Absolutely serviceable but just a touch off balance for my taste. Good warm-up for the whisky flight. (6-4-6-3-13=3.2)

name: Ringwood Boon Doggle (Cask)
review: Cask half pint at The Lamplighter, St. Helier. ABV was 4.2%. Golden colour, white head. Moderate aroma, some malts, a little fruit. Some fruit / berries and tingling hops in the flavour, much better than the bottled version.

name: Ringwood Boon Doggle (Cask)
review: Tap at Waterside, Imperial Wharf. Pours a clear amber body with barely any head. Aroma is sweet malts, yeast, honey notes, some light citrus. Taste is yeast, sweet malts, some citrus. Not great but drinkable.

name: Ringwood Boon Doggle (Cask)
review: Draught. Pours amber with a white head. Light citrus, floral and woody aroma. You can taste the hops since the very first sip, but the toasted malt flavour as well as some fruity and leather notes get progressively more dominant. Dry finish which is well coupled by a hoppy kick. Medium body and definitely oily. Though not very well rounded there's a good sense of complexity here. Plus, it is quite refreshing. Nice.

name: Ringwood Boon Doggle (Cask)
review: Draught at Three Tuns, York. Pours amber with a pale tan head. Floral aromas, slightly sweet, hops and caramel. A very distinct note of maple syrup. In mouth, aromatic hoppiness that leads to a malty flavour that dominates, which progressively gives way to a drier hoppy finish. Oak, leather, not perfectly rounded but certainly not one-dimensional. Medium body, oily and average length for finish. A typical ale.

name: Ringwood XXXX Porter
review: Bottle at PoW, Farnborough. Low key malty chocolate aroma with a berry edge. Dark kinda murky cola brown. Thin off-white head. Creamy with a bitter edge. Very creamy chocolate and berries. Medium bodied. Slick. Soft carbonation. Slightly astringent finish. Better than I was expecting. Pretty drinkable.

name: Ringwood XXXX Porter
review: Nice. Dark brown with caramel aroma. Cherry hints in taste and mild on palate. Very drinkable and good strength. Nutty hints.

name: Ringwood XXXX Porter
review: From cask at The Last Plantagenet, Leicester, Leicestershire, with OGJ 04.01.18. Dark mahogany. Pale brown head and lacing. Aroma and taste of dark caramel and dark crystal malt. Low bitterness. Good drinkability.

name: Ringwood XXXX Porter
review: Cask at The Last Plantagenet, Leicester. Pours black with a tiny tan head,aroma of sweet syrup, weak toast. Same goes for taste, sweet start with a weak toasty charry finish.

name: Ringwood XXXX Porter
review: Very quaffable porter, surprised that in appearance it seemed a dark brown rather than black colour. Very easy drinking, not too heavy.

name: Ringwood XXXX Porter
review: Very smooth and not a heavy taste like other stouts. Would recommend this to anyone.

name: Ringwood XXXX Porter
review: Cask at The Green Dragon, Leek (JDW) A deep brown colour with a medium beige head. Aroma of sherry, dark fruits, slight caramel and subtle liquorice. Taste of dark fruits, sherry, some liquorice, slight wet wood and subtle caramel. Medium bodied and an oily texture. A bittersweet, sherried fruit bitterness in the finish. Not my kind of porter. Sweet sherried fruits and spicy liquorice. Tastes a lot stronger than it says and quite acidic.

name: Ringwood XXXX Porter
review: Bottle. Reddish Brown. Roasty malts, caramel. Chocolate. Dark fruits. Smooth, sweet, porter. Thinish. Short dry slightly sour finish. (2008)

name: Ringwood XXXX Porter
review: Cask 1 Pint, The Porterhouse, Bournemouth, England, UK. Ciemnorubinowe piwo z puszyst¹ i trwa³¹ pian¹. W smaku kremowe, przyjemnie palone i lekko kawowe z ³agodnie wytrawnym finiszem.

name: Ringwood XXXX Porter
review: Clear yet deep dark red beer. Brief off white head. Light roast malt aroma. Thick smooth slightly powdery mouthfeel. Light toffee, roast malt. Lightly sweet. Lightly bitter.

name: Riverhead Black Moss Stout
review: Wakefield Beer Festival 2018. Black with a light roasted malt character allowing a fair sweetness through. The barrel ageing was not that obvious from this wooden cask offering.

name: Riverhead Black Moss Stout
review: On cask at the Guildford Arms. Appearance - opaque black with a lovely fawn head. Nose - molasses and smoke. A touch of chocolate. Taste - more molasses. Black jack sweets. Honeycomb. Like a dark Crunchie Bar. Roast on the finish. Palate - medium bodied with a crunchy texture and a long dry crunchy finish. Overall - nice and complex.

name: Riverhead Black Moss Stout
review: Cask@post office vaults, birmingham. Black beer with small bubbly tan head. Aroma of light roast malts. Taste it’s roast malts, chocolate and a hint of raisin. Decent.

name: Riverhead Black Moss Stout
review: Cask black bull liversidge. Black good tan head lacing. Nice choc roasted malt aroma. Taste is great sweet choc followed by earthy roasted malts long bitter finish. Nice body. Very good well rounded stout.

name: Riverhead Black Moss Stout
review: A quite dry stout. Pitch black in colour. Not a lot of aroma. The flavour is mainly burnt malt with hints of bitter chocolate. Bittersweet aftertaste. The mouthfeel is slightly ashy. A decent, fairly light, stout. Cask (handpump), Riverhead Brewery Tap, Marsden, May 2005. [5/4/7/3/13] Re-rate: Cask (handpump) at the Riverhead Brewery Tap, May 2009. Seems to have been beefed up considerably since I first rated it. Very dark with a creamy beige head. Lots of roasty chocolate malt. Distinctly bitter. Very smoky aroma. Almost medicinal, phenolic touches. Some licorice in the flavour. Good firm mouthfeel with plenty of weight. [7/4/7/4/15]

name: New Belgium 1554 Enlightened Dark Ale
brewery: New Belgium Brewing Company (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
review: Keg at 73 Enid Street. A clear nutty brown coloured pour with no head. Aroma is earthy twig, raw nutty malts, toast, apple. Flavour is composed of earthy twigs bark, toasted brown bread, earth. Palate is earthy, semi sweet, lowish carbonation. Meh.

name: New Belgium 1554 Enlightened Dark Ale
brewery: New Belgium Brewing Company (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
review: Bottle, picked up at brewery in Asheville so as fresh as it gets. Pours dark brown-red and clear. Nice fine head, doesn't appear filtered. Aroma of dark malt and light hop. Tastes crisp, dry, dark malts without bitterness (debittered malts methink). A little hop in the background. A nice easy drinking beer.

name: New Belgium 1554 Enlightened Dark Ale
brewery: New Belgium Brewing Company (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
review: On tap at Mali Medo Zagreb. Black coloured, medium sized brownish head, light caramel in the nose. Light roasted malt, mild chocolate, some fruits and caramel with light nutty touch in the finish. Nothing special here.

name: New Belgium 1554 Enlightened Dark Ale
brewery: New Belgium Brewing Company (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
review: On tap at Mali medo, Zagreb. Black, medium to large creamy tan head. Aroma is toasty, malty, lightly fruity. Flavour is toasty, nutty, roasted hazelnut, bready. Charred wood. Light caramel sweetness. Dry roasty finish. Kinda watery, moving towards creamy texture. Light body. Very light cardboard touch, could be from the malts. Also experienced light green apple, nothing too intense. Not bad.

name: New Belgium 1554 Enlightened Dark Ale
brewery: New Belgium Brewing Company (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
review: Pours clear black with a thick light creme head. Aroma of roasted malt. Taste has lightly toasted notes, creme elements. Creamy palate, nutty, light and well rounded. Good!

name: New Belgium 1554 Enlightened Dark Ale
brewery: New Belgium Brewing Company (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
review: I was surprised to find that this is a lager. It has the appearance of a stout ale, but with a milder flavor. It appears a very dark brown in the glass with a minimal head. Mild flavor and mild aroma. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: New Belgium 1554 Enlightened Dark Ale
brewery: New Belgium Brewing Company (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
review: Backlog, pours a cola colored reddish brown. Tan head with decent lacing. Notes are bread, dark fruit, light toast malts, grass, and chocolate. Light bodied black lager. Alright

name: New Belgium 1554 Enlightened Dark Ale
brewery: New Belgium Brewing Company (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
review: Black colour with luscious rocky head. Nice light coffee and choc flavour. Light body.

name: New Belgium 1554 Enlightened Dark Ale
brewery: New Belgium Brewing Company (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
review: Aroma is toasty, nutty, and chocolatey. Bready malt up front, which turns into caramel and roasted dark chocolate. The finish lingers with sweetness of caramel and cocoa. Clean flavors throughout and very even keeled with no spikes of hops, acidity, or fruitiness. Drinks like a 4.5 %abv brew, but it is slightly sneaky at 6%. Has a bit of a creamy mouthfeel, a little more creaminess than other shwarzbeers I've had. Roasted barley bitterness in the finish as well.

name: New Belgium 1554 Enlightened Dark Ale
brewery: New Belgium Brewing Company (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
review: Wednesday, December 12, 2018 10:10 PM 12 ounce bottle to wine glass Sight: Black/ very dark Brown small brown head, goes away quickly, lacing Smell: fragrant, roasted grains Taste: lightly bitter, some sweetness, light tasting Mouthfeel: lively carbonation lingers in roof of tongue, good followthrough, finish Overall: very good beer, ok to repeat, not to look for

name: Guinness Draught
review: Best beer known to man. Could drink for breakfast, lunch and dinner. Refreshing, able to get drunk. Love it

name: Guinness Draught
review: nie znalaz³em jeszcze piwa z lepsz¹ pian¹. Nie jest szczególnie intensywnym piwem , nadrabia smak swoj¹ tekstur¹.

name: Guinness Draught
review: Czarne, nieprzejrzyste, gêsta, kremowa piana. Aromaty chlebowe, lekko palone, bez sza³u. W smaku podobnie - kwaskowy chleb, kawa zbo¿owa i palonoœæ. Lekkie i niewymagaj¹ce.

name: Guinness Draught
review: Rich, creamy head with delicious coffee and chocolate notes. Delicious and smooth going down. Very drinkable

name: Guinness Draught
review: Wygl¹da œwietnie - czerñ ale nie zbytnio mêtna, piania œrednia be¿owa, drobno pêcherzykowata, d³ugo utrzymuje siê. W smaku ju¿ tak fajnie jest, czuæ kawê zbo¿ow¹ na pierwszym planie, a dalej pustka, nic wiêcej.

name: Guinness Draught
review: Z kranu w Ostrawie na rynku. Efekt nitro przepiêkny - piana sztywna jak bia³kowa, be¿owa. Piwo niestety bez wyrazu, wodniste, kawa zbo¿owa, bardzo niska intensywnoœæ. Odczucie w ustach œwietne, aksamitne, g³adkie, ale poza tym niewiele.

name: Guinness Draught
review: Gekocht bij de lokale Albert Heijn en gedronken in een BeerBattle tegen de 7 Deugden Stout + Moedig. Voor mij kwam de Guinness als winnaar uit de bus. Ik heb geen idee of onder invloed van de 'nitro-can' is, maar alleen het inschenken al is bijzonder. Het settlen van het bier is alleen al iets om naar te blijven kijken. De licht creme schuimkraag is niet fors, maar blijft komen met een donkerrode glinstering in het ogenschijnlijke zwarte bier. In de geur springen er voor mij vooral de gebrande mouten uit. De smaak is niet erg uitgesproken. Mogelijk ook vanwege het bijna ontbreken aan koolzuur. Maar, het moet gezegd worden, je drinkt dit bier bijna meer voor de beleving dan voor de smaak

name: Guinness Draught
review: Why am I only rating this now? Creamy, thick, dense head on top of a opaque Brown body. It smells of molasses, with a touch of coffee. It tastes watery, due to the lack of carbonation. It has good flavors, with a bit of the dry aftertaste. I like it better than I like the extra draft. I don't dislike this beer but I couldn't see drinking it all night long. After one or two I'd want to switch to something else

name: Guinness Draught
review: Just like a supermodel; so good looking that it’s doesn’t matter it’s a bit light on

name: Guinness Draught
review: sjedim ja u sobi i smorena sam kad ono meni poruku šalje èika paki. odem ja u rodu i kupim ginis umesto blue moon, doðen doma i popijem njam njam sfrpslfrp

name: Mad River John Barleycorn
review: Hazy amber colour with thin head. Aroma and flavour are packed with sweet caramel malts . Smooth and dangerously easy to drink.

name: Mad River John Barleycorn
review: Bottle 12fl.oz. @home poured into a tulip glass. Intense medium amber, small fizzy beige head, mostly diminishing, light lacing; aroma roasted malt, caramel, overripe fruits, treacle, alcohol; taste light heavy sweet and light bitter, very roasty, toffee, overripe fruits, grain, alcohol, spicy notes; malty sweetbitter aftertaste, grainy and earthy notes, boozy; full-bodied, oily texture, soft carbonation; heavy duty beer, not for the faint hearted, well-made but lacks smoothness, despite that a good brew.

name: Mad River John Barleycorn
review: Bottle. Pours hazy dark amber-brown with foamy beige head, caramel-coffee aroma, low carbonation, bitter caramel malt-coffee taste with alcohol undertones, thin body, long bitter finish. Good brew.

name: Aecht Schlenkerla Rauchbier Märzen
review: Smell- malt, fish, smoke Foam- thin, malty, acidic, bit of caramel and then smoke notes somehow ? Head is medium sized, medium dark, brown, creamy white color. Appearance- nice unique looking bottle cap, and interesting bottle design. Clear, medium dark, brown, red Taste- malt, caramel, some other taste, kind of roasted, kind of neutral. Bit weird, but drinkable and decent.

name: Aecht Schlenkerla Rauchbier Märzen
review: Piêkna piana. Miedziane klarowne. Aromat intensywny przykemna wedzonka z nutami marcowego. Smak pó³s³odki i tu rz¹dzi wêdzonka. Niska goryczka wysycenie œrednie do wysokiego. Dobre piwo polecam

name: Aecht Schlenkerla Rauchbier Märzen
review: Aromat: przyjemna wêdzonka, palone drewno Wygl¹d: barwa brunatna, klarowne, ³adna piana i lejsing Smak: przyjemna wêdzonka w stylu wêdlin, nuty drewna, przyjemna goryczka Podniebienie: cia³o œrednie, g³adkie

name: Aecht Schlenkerla Rauchbier Märzen
review: I love this beer. It's my favorite mass produced one by far. Very light but with intense flavor and aroma

name: Aecht Schlenkerla Rauchbier Märzen
review: 500ml bottle at We Brought Beer, Balham. Deep mahogany with a tan head. I love this beer. It’s pretty much the perfect Rauchbier. The smokiness is so full and well measured and just unrelenting from first whiff to lingering finish. Perfect amount of maltiness and great body. Classic.

name: Aecht Schlenkerla Rauchbier Märzen
review: Dark ruby color , aroma and taste of smoked meat , bacon. Very good beer overall , but it depends on your taste if you will love it or hate it. Full of flavor.

name: Aecht Schlenkerla Rauchbier Märzen
review: # 491; 10/2016. Vynikající, výrazný nakuøovaný pivo. Plný, výraznì uzený, uzený maso, lehce karamel.

name: City LaCrosse Lager
review: Can, shared by me... in my dining room... just now. Pours a pale straw color with a big but quickly falling head. The aroma is doughy, lightly sweet, a little corny, but mild & not uninviting. The flavor is lightly sweet and lightly bitter. It’s got the corniness well in check with a light hop zip. It’s doughy but not over sweet or especially yeasty. The palate is lively and light. In many ways this is a quintessential American Pale Lager, for what it’s worth most folks will not like it because of that, but I do like it. I don’t get enough chances to pick this one up.

name: City LaCrosse Lager
review: Pretty basic lager alcohol taste nothing stands out. Slightly watery. Not bad just not very good.

name: City LaCrosse Lager
review: Aroma is bread, fruit and a hint of spices/earthiness. The flavor is fruit, malts, bread and a tart finish.

name: City LaCrosse Lager
review: On tap at Bodega. Pours a clear light gold with a white head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has a good amount of sweet corn and straw with a touch of bread backing. Flavor is similar with corn and straw with some sweet grains underlying. Slightly crisp.

name: City LaCrosse Lager
review: 12 oz. can. Aroma of sweet malt and corn. Flavor is strongly on the sweet side with very mild corn and bitter notes. Light bodied, fizzy carbonation. Finishes sweet. Too sweet. Lots of sweetness in this one.

name: City LaCrosse Lager
review: Bottle poured into a shaker. Pours a clear dark gold with a half finger of white head. Aroma of corn and grain. Taste is light sweet. Meh, not bad.

name: City LaCrosse Lager
review: 12oz can (old notes ’03)-Pours a golden body with a small white head. Aroma of corn and sweetness. Taste of the same with a little grains coming thru. This light bodied brew is not bad as I was expecting worse.

name: City LaCrosse Lager
review: 12 oz can into 16 oz. snifter (yeah, I know, a snifter is overkill for a lawnmower beer). Light, slight grain/corn aroma. Pours perfectly clear, golden, with reasonable head. Flavor of malt and corn; minimal hops. Not as thin as other lawnmower beers. Pretty good for a beer that comes in 30-pack cans.

name: City LaCrosse Lager
review: Well LaCrosse used to be the home of Blatz and for that I salute them. For this I give them the FINGER! Who poured sugar and corn syrup into my beer!??? I thought I was drinking a corn flavored soda. NEVER AGAIN. NEVER. Hang tight with the Blatz and the bitches will be pounding down your door. Hang with this and expect a lot of digital oscillation (from yourself) of your male member. Shameful! Is this the treatment our boys in uniform deserve?

name: City LaCrosse Lager
review: A pour man’s MDG or Bud. I’m not a huge fan of lagers in general, but I found this to be skunky which is a bit odd as I had it poured from a can into a pint glass.

name: Smiles Golden Brew
review: Cask Handpump at the Penny Black, Northwich (JDW) 29/10/2003 Golden coloured with some sour fruit and hoppy aromas. Slightly bitter malt finish.

name: Smiles Golden Brew
review: It was a little strange, like the one from Insipiration. But it was a little sour, and sweet in aroma. Good foam and colour.

name: Smiles Golden Brew
review: Cask Conditioned at The Swan, Banbury. An orange golden beer with thin head. Strangely thin on first inspection, but then a reasonable dry bitterness with tangy hop flavours. Lasting fruitiness on a fresh finish.

name: Smiles Best
review: Cask 3 Judges. Aroma is bursting with caramel and toffee malts, also som green king apple character. Taste is similarly over malty caramel and toffee, raw apple sweetness and no hop character at all. Total caramel = overvented.

name: Smiles Best
review: Cask at Wellington Arms, Bedford. Mid to dark amber with a small. off-white head. Aroma of caramel malt. Taste sweet and malty with a citric sourness and slight, grassy bitterness.

name: Smiles Best
review: From bottle - Nice looking - clear golden brown, with a nice sized white head. Sourish aroma. Bready, toasty flavor, with a mellow but persistant hop bite. Enjoyable, once you get past the aroma.

name: Smiles Best
review: Bottle, from Rythym & Booze in Brigg. Amber bronze with thin but lasting creamy white head and gentle condition. Pleasant caramel, digestive biscuits and good solid English hops in the nose, chalky sweet yeast and fuggles? In the mouth with the caramel more muted. Finish is dry and chalky with some sweetness coming through at the end. Typical English bitter

name: Smiles Best
review: Bitter # 234,454 of this holiday. Bit fruity and hoppy. I don’t particularly like the style and this is no exception.

name: Smiles Best
review: Clear orange/red color, short head. Aroma is fruity, caramel malty, hoppy. Slightly bitter and sweet taste.

name: Smiles Best
review: Cask@The Fox, Twickenham. Pretty odd stuff. Buttery and lactic sourness. Some toffee and shortbread, quite flat and sweet.

name: Smiles Best
review: Tried in bottle form perhaps the cask version is more inspiring.Slight head and no dominating taste apart from a slight bitterness.Whilst not a bad drink it has nothing that makes it stand out.

name: Smiles Best
review: Cask Conditioned at The Anchor, Sidmouth. Red bronzed beer with no head, no matter how much the rather pretty bargirl tried! Not Smiles best I'm afraid, somewhat flat, lifeless and mouldy, ashy.

name: Smiles Best
review: Reddish amber color with a dissipating tan head. Somewhat of a sparkling/fruity aroma. Balanced malty/sweet flavor and nice finish. Not bad at all.

name: Smiles Heritage
review: Bottle. Deep red and brown with a beige head. Aromas are sweet weetabix with caramel malts. Flavours are swet malts with weetabix and chocolate. Malty and good.

name: Smiles Heritage
review: Handpulled half pint at The Cayo Arms, Cardiff. Dark mahogany body. Low level foam with some laceworks. Aroma of sweet berries. Flavour is a mix of malty sweetness and dark fruits. Vague bitter end. Rather anonymous for a premium bitter (02.02.2007).

name: Smiles Heritage
review: Cask, Gardener’s Arms, Oxford. Deep brown with a light tan cap of dense, sticky foam. Carameled apple aroma with a touch of lively tartness. Warm caramel flavor, round and malty. A bit of toasted marshmellow. Just a touch of earthy hops. A wholesome and satisfying pint, just the thing for sipping in front of the fire here at the snug Gardener’s Arms.

name: Smiles Heritage
review: [cask from The Three Judges] Dark brown, tight head. Caramel and some sweet, red berry notes and a dry finish.

name: Smiles Heritage
review: Mine just has the word Smiles in big letters and says "English Ale" and "Bottled Cask Ale" in small letters underneath. Its the same strength and have a similar description so I’m pretty sure its the same beer. That is farking annoying. Speakof of annoying, this is the kind of english beerr I don’t like: over the top fruity. The aroma and flavor are dominated by plumbs, raisin, pear, toffee, and caramel. You can’t even taste bit of hops. Its a flat, reddish brown with little head. This beer does nothing for me. Maybe if it were hand pumped in England or something.

name: Smiles Heritage
review: 1. Cask Handpump at the Penny Black, Northwich (JDW) 04/11/2001 Dark coloured with fruit and chocolate aromas. Strong in alcohol. Roast malt finish. 2. Cask Handpump at the Penny Black, Northwich 18/07/2002 Copper coloured with floral aroma. Fruity blackcurrant flavour. Dry malt finish.

name: Smiles Heritage
review: Cask conditioned @ Duke of Wellington, Soton. Fairly dark brown. Light roasty malt aromas. Some sweetness and tart fruity flavours and a roasty finish. Fairly interesting but not that great for me.

name: Smiles Heritage
review: cask at little gem aylesford ruby colour rich malt flavour plums and strawberries sweetish but pleasant good ruby some choc bitterish hops on end with more strawberry. nice

name: Smiles Heritage
review: Bottle. Poured a medium size tan head that was mostly lasting, sparse lacing, fine-small sized bubbles, softly carbonated, transparent, and a ruby hue. Aroma was malty, roasty and sweet. Sweet, malty, roasty, and thin flavor. Palate was thin and smooth. light body.

name: Smiles Heritage
review: This bottled brew marked best before HUG01 and labeled L09080G1 poured a large sized head of foamy off-white colored mostly diminishing bubbles that left behind a good lacing and a softly carbonated transparent caramel brown colored body. The aroma was mild and malty. The mouth feel was dry and semi sweet in the finish. It was OK brew but I didn’t enjoy it much.

name: Smiles Maiden Leg Over
review: Sampled on draft at the House of 1000 beers this beer poured a hazy apricot color with a medium sized foamy off white head that faded quickly and left no lacing. The aroma was sweet honey, bread, orange and clove. The flavor was sweet and tart bread, orange and clove with hints of honey and banana underneath. The finish was bitter, tart and somewhat astringent with lingering orange and banana. Medium body. Ok.

name: Smiles Maiden Leg Over
review: Cask at Comptons. Drinkable, and I had three, but two notable flaws. It was salty, perhaps they went overboard on the gypsum? And there was a distinct butterscotch taste, which could have been diacetyl. But at least it was much better than the London Pride!

name: Smiles Maiden Leg Over
review: Cask at The Eagle, Shepherdess Walk, Hackney. Hazy, deep golden with a small, frothy head. Toffee and fruit nose. Quite bitter throughout with some softening toffee. Light body.A standard bitter without too much character.

name: Smiles Maiden Leg Over
review: Cask Stillage at the Old Broken Cross, Rudheath 11/07/2002 Golden coloured smooth on the palate and hoppy. Lasting malt finish.

name: Smiles Maiden Leg Over
review: Cask. A soft summer beer that doesn’t stand up well to poor treatment. I’ve had this several times and it has never shone. This is either a boy’s bnitter or a pale mild.

name: Smiles Maiden Leg Over
review: Gravity cask at Lobster Pot, West Malling Pale gold, no head. Some citrus/acid/peach/hop going on. Quite sharp with a bit of hap but basically I didn’t like this very much.

name: Smiles Maiden Leg Over
review: On tap at Aston University sports complex. Bright yellow, with a creamy head and good lacing. Very smooth and creamy in the mouth. Good fresh, but light hoppiness, with a bitter, faintly malty finish. Very easy drinking, refreshing, quaffable. Very good I thought.

name: Smiles Maiden Leg Over
review: Cask at Crosse Key in London. Golden amber body. Small whitish head. Aroma is hops with a tea-like hint and fruit (peaches and pears??). Taste is lighter hops and more fruit notes with pears coming through as being more dominant. Light sweet malt flavors throughout. Mouthfeel is rather full while the finish is hoppy and allowing of more of the fruit to come out.

name: Smiles Maiden Leg Over
review: Cask Conditioned at Hook Norton Beer Festival 04. Pale straw coloured with no head. Thin dry unsubtle malt bitter, one dimensional with a sharp cereal note. Suffered with being sold too early.

name: Smiles Maiden Leg Over
review: Cask conditioned @ JDW, Soton. Citric, malt aroma. Refreshing with bitter flavour and long finish. Well balanced.

name: Smiles Old Tosser
review: Cask at Ship Centurion, Whitstable: Dark watery ale, very thin in mouth. A little bit of malt but nothing else to this beer. This is dishwater, very poor.

name: Smiles Old Tosser
review: Cask conditioned - Went to have this in a the Queens Head, Sedgeborough, Worcs yesterday but it ran dry as soon as they started serving it. Tried it in a pub in Prestbury, Glos today. Red amber colour, bit cloying malty aroma fairly inconspicous franky a bit dissapointed.

name: Smiles Old Tosser
review: Cask conditioned - served without sparkler. Reddish tint, with a malty aroma. Taste is also malty with a hint of fruit. Not particularly distinguished.

name: Smiles Old Tosser
review: Mid amber colour. Malty and sweetish, with toffee undertones and a hint of aromatic hop. Curranty dried fruit finish. Medium bodied and reasonably well balanced. Very palatable. Handpump, Lord Moon of the Mall, Whitehall, London SW1

name: Smiles Old Tosser
review: Cask Fresh @ JDW, Gravesend. Cask Marque. I tried this in a JDW pub in Forest Hill and got served the wrong beer, so it's good to have another chance at it. Dark sultry amber with assorted bubble head lingering seductively like the frothy lace of female underwear. Vaque fruit sweetness up front, slightly sticky, with a mild acidity, then some woody almost roasty notes come in. A tanginess rides along the top. Finishes dry, with tree bark flavours. Quite nice.

name: Smiles Old Tosser
review: Dark amber beer, tasting of very sweet, dark roasted malt. No appearance of hops evident in mouth. Overall; sweet and cloying.

name: Smiles March Hare
review: Cask Handpump at the Penny Black, Northwich (JDW) 08/03/2001 Smooth and sweet on the palate. Malt in the aftertaste.

name: Smiles March Hare
review: Cask Conditioned, Royal Standard, Wooburn Common, Bucks. Fairly pleasent, nothing really stood out, though.

name: Smiles March Hare
review: Cask Conditioned. Light brown colour with medium head. Thin malt flavour with a little hop body. Largely light with a slight zingy hop but unexeptional

name: Smiles May Fly
review: Cask Conditioned, at Hamilton Hall, London. Clear golden amber colour with a white head. Vanilla aroma and flavour. Supposed to be a delicate balance of malts but it’s a bit of slop really. Is all a bit washed out with no backbone.

name: Smiles May Fly
review: Gravity at the Briar Rose (JDW), Birmingham. Gold beer, no head. The absolute epitome of what Silk Tork speaks about as the freshness of British real ale. No fizz, no head. Just a zesty, lustrous quality in the mouth, ensconced by a subtlety of jostling flavours in the undercurrent. Fruity, hoppy, light, with a dryish, but friendly finish.

name: Smiles May Fly
review: Cask Conditioned at a Wetherspoons. Pale golden yellow beer with bubbly head. Full flavoured light beer with smooth but tangy floral notes. Light bitterness and apple notes in the finish.

name: Smiles May Fly
review: Cask, The Bull's Head, Pratt's Bottom. Good pub with bar billiards. Beer has a yeasty nose and a murky light amber colour. Rough edges with oaky notes lend interest and depth. There is some sour fruit with orange flower flavours and a light hop finish, slightly earthy. Some chocolate late in the finish. A splendid ale.

name: Smiles Zummer Vat Ale
review: Cask handpump at The Wellington, Birmingham. Copper, no head. Sugary malts in the scent with a hint of grapefruit. Thin. In the mouth there is berry fruit, then lots of hop, then a long malty / syrupy aftertaste. Not bad.

name: Smiles Zummer Vat Ale
review: Cask Handpump at the Beer House, Manchester 24/08/2002 Mid brown coloured with a slightly wheaty aroma. Malty with a dry lasting finish.

name: Smiles Zummer Vat Ale
review: Cask Conditioned at The Bell, Banbury. Pale brown with thin head. Light body with thin flavours, some sweetish tangy notes but mostly understated. An average summer ale.

name: Smiles Holly Hops
review: Cask pint: drank in the Brier Rose, Wetherspoons pub in Birmingham, on winters evening early 2007. Dark with an off white head, looked an OK winter warmer. Burnt malts, mushrooms and biscuits dominate the aroma. The beer tasted of burnt malt and nothing else, it was watery and had no depth, not at all what I was expecting, hence the low scores.

name: Smiles Holly Hops
review: aroma was of malt, and I think that I could detect the wheat. Has a stong matly flavor with some fruityness and some bitterness in the finish. Really nothing great. but not horrible

name: Smiles Holly Hops
review: Cask (Pillars of Hercules): Amber with a beige tight head. Mild fruits, spice, nutmeg? Sweet nutty fruity and spicy flavour. Medium bodied, perfectly drinkable.

name: Smiles Holly Hops
review: 1. Cask Handpump at the Penny Black, Northwich (JDW) 27/12/2002 Amber golden coloured and sweet on the palate. Slightly bitter malt finish. 2. Cask Handpump at the Penny Black, Northwich 15/01/2003 Copper coloured and malty. Strong in alcohol with a slightly dry finish.

name: Smiles Holly Hops
review: Cask handpull at Pillars of Hercules, London Xmas Pub Crawl. Well it has come out of retirement thanks to Highgate. Red/chestnut colour with thin beige head. Tarry fruit with good malts. Fruit is a little sour in the mouth with dark cherries. Again, I quite like this, bit of liquorice hiding in that sourness somewhere too.

name: Smiles Holly Hops
review: Cask at Royal Oak, Ockbrook. The Boxing Day pint; good chewy stuff to go with the hot pork rolls, hops struggled against the sweetness but managed to give it an overall feeling of control.

name: Smiles Holly Hops
review: Deep reddish brown colour. This year, I seem to hitting a lot of "Christmas" beers that are perfectly decent but, frankly, not very Christmassy. At least, not in the way I anticipated. This one was no exception. More like a strong autumnal bitter really. There’s a significant element of dry, chewy malt with quite a noticeable hop rush coming through on the palate. Can’t say I noticed the wheat. Cask (handpump), Penderels Oak (JDW), Holborn, London.

name: Smiles Holly Hops
review: This one was at the Carpenter’s Arms as opposed to the Masons. The latter must work harder because this one was not a bad drop but let down by a slight weakness in the beer. The wheat adds little I feel as opposed to the great partnership of the F&G hops. A pleasant seasonal beer that helps to make London at Christmas a great place to be.

name: Smiles Holly Hops
review: Cask Conditioned at The Bell, Banbuery. Deep golden colour with bubbly white head. A full malt and wheaty grain flavour, heavy base flavour with a sweetish light overnote. Plenty of alcohol on the nose, warming and insistent. There is a hoppy finish which doesn't quite overcome the sweetness of the base malt.

name: Sulwath Criffel Ale
review: Bottle. Amber coloured beer with a strong white head. The aroma is gently roasted with mild yeastiness, and the flavour is mildly bitter and roasted with a mellow finish. Overall a reasonable bitter.

name: Sulwath Criffel Ale
review: Bottle from Aldi Inverurie. If pours clear deep amber with a decent foamy white head. The aroma is earthy, wood, toasty, peanut, leather and some spice. The taste is dry, bitter, wood, leather, toasted nut, a bit chewy, spiced, dried florals and a touch of ash with a drying, slightly tannic finish. Medium body and fine, prickly carbonation. A bit chewy and woody. Fair.

name: Sulwath Criffel Ale
review: Cask at the Caley Sample Room. Pours clear amber with a thin white head. Aromas of faint toffee and sulphur. Taste is light malt sweet, toffee. Thin finish.

name: Sulwath Criffel Ale
review: Cask at JDW Standing Order. Clear ruby, creamy beige head. Nose is malts, berries, caramel. Soft mouthfeel, taste is bitter and somehow roasted, caramel, dark and dry fruits. Dont find it very nice.

name: Sulwath Criffel Ale
review: Drunk from 50cl bottle given as present by parents from their Scotland trip. Enjoyable Indian pale ale. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Sulwath Criffel Ale
review: Pint at Counting House in Glasgow. Clear amber beer with a thin creamy head. Light hoppy smell. Flavour is light bitter hop with a lemony twist. Unremarkable but fine.

name: Sulwath Criffel Ale
review: Keg tap from the Brewery Tap, Castle Douglas. Light brown/amber with a tiny wisplet of white head. Light scent of malt, berries. Taste is standard but enjoyable: a simple bittersweet taste which leads to a surprisingly dry finish. Light body. Not the greatest of beers, but thus would be a welcome alternative to bland Scottish pub bitters.

name: Sulwath Criffel Ale
review: Bottle BBE: 14/6/15. Well-chilled. Crystal clear amber body with a quickly-diminishing, creamy white head. Low intensity aroma with some biscuity character and gentle, sprucey hop notes. Very light sweetness and a gentle bitterness - overall a well-balanced taste. Light body, thin texture, low-to-medium carbonation and a short, bitter finish. A pleasant enough, standard drinkable bitter. Rather bland and unexceptional.

name: Sulwath Criffel Ale
review: Bottle at home. Pours golden amber, nose is malty, fruity, taste is similar, refreshing.

name: Sulwath Criffel Ale
