review: Bottle purchased at the brewery. Pours cloudy copper to bronze with a rocky white film. Gingerbread caramel malt and yeast aroma with cinnamon notes and a faint floral, fruit hop nose. Malt and yeast (dough) watery butterscotch flavor with fruity notes. Medium bodied and watery-oily and spicy palate.

name: Estes Park Pale Ale
review: Draught. Body is hazy dark yellow. Aroma is lightly malty (cookie), moderately hoppy (grapefruit, resin), lightly yeasty (dough). Flavor is moderately sweet, moderately acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, moderately acidic, moderately bitter. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. Very straightforward, simple, average APA, nothing wrong with it, easy-drinkin’. Patterned after SNPA for the most part.

name: Estes Park Pale Ale
review: I was going to skip this one, but the bartender told me that it would be hoppier than their IPA - Yup, he was right! Big citrus/grapefruit aroma. Body is light copper with good head and lacing. Malts are sweet and seem to add to the big juicy hop explosion. Finish is long and full of grapefruit and orange rind. Very good

name: Estes Park Pale Ale
review: Good bitterness. Nice color and head. All in all its a little above average but it needs more guts in the taste.

name: Estes Park Gold
review: Crisp clean golden with no head. Pale cereal grainy aroma. Thin golden malt flavor that’s grainy and bready and slightly sweet, kinda thin and clean.

name: Estes Park Gold
review: Sample. Low and quickly disappearing white head. Pale yellow body. Mild and weak straw malt grass aroma and flavor with little hops bitterness, low carbonation and a short finish.

name: Estes Park Gold
review: (Draught) Pours a clear pale yellow body with a medium white head. Aroma of earth, grain, and biscuit. Flavor of grain, biscuit, and light citrus.

name: Estes Park Gold
review: Pour on tap at the brewery, clear straw yellow pour with white head, aroma brought notes of biscuit, grain, cereal into a bit of slight grass or herbal hops, touch of minerality. Taste is a mix of biscuit, cereal, and some herbal hops, very slight sweet honey into a bit of grainy husk, finishing dry.

name: Estes Park Gold
review: yeah...EP is all over the map. lots of sub par beers and a few nice ones too, but this was crap. light in color (and everything else) for an amber. unpleasant generic aroma and flavor. nothing redeeming."

name: Estes Park Gold
review: October 2010. Sampled at the brewery. Golden color with a white head. Corn, fruit, malt and grassy aromas. Light body, light flavor.

name: Estes Park Gold
review: Sampled at the brewery on October 9, 2012 Clear dark golden color, white head. Sweet, light fruity scent. Malty mild taste. Smooth mouthfeel, low bitterness.

name: Estes Park Gold
review: Light crystal malt aroma. Smooth texture. A mild golden ale...just kinda middle of the road. Notes: Pub visit during ’09 GABF

name: Estes Park Gold
review: Sample at the brewery. Pours a thin, short lived white hed,, over a clear, gold (SRM 5) body....nose is light cereal....taste is thin cereal, thin floral tones....mouth feel light, carbonation low. This is very light overall. BJCP 6/3/10/4/5

name: Estes Park Gold
review: Light amber pour. Caramel, corn, pale hops. Flavor is grainy, light hops, rather typical and boring.

name: Estes Park Porter
review: Ar: palony slod, kawa, nieco czeko, rasowo, intensywnosc srednia. Wyg: czarne, nieprzejrzyste, piana bez, cienka, drobnoziarnista. Sm: wysycenie srednio-wysokie, masa kawy, nieco palonych slodow, wodniscie. Pos: palone ziarno kawy, nieco gorzkiej czeko. Ov: niezle, stylowo, ale czegos brakuje, zbyt pusto i wodniscie.

name: Estes Park Porter
review: Sample at the brewery. Pours black, with a big, frothy, khaki head. The aroma is syrup, walnuts, light coffee, peat, and pine. Sweet and roasted, with a pleasant bitterness. Medium body, with a velvety, syrupy feel. Surprisingly solid.

name: Estes Park Porter
review: Clear deep dark brown with a thin light beige head. Delightful nose that’s chocolate cake-like with a hint of coffee with a thin hint of caramel. Smooth roasty dark malt flavor that’s slightly cocoa’d and has a hint of coffee. Smooth and nutty and bready and roasty.

name: Estes Park Porter
review: Bottled. Near black, huge gushing head. Nice aroma of licorice and coffee. Bone dry with light-medium body and clean, spritzy mouthfeel. Chocolate and coffee, Resiny bitter finish.

name: Estes Park Porter
review: Sample at the brewery. Medium high fluffy pale brown head. Pitch black body. Mild but solid roasted malt coffee liquorice aroma and flavor with a fair hops bitterness, low carbonation and a long finish.

name: Estes Park Porter
review: Tasting at Matt’s Dark brown color, no head. Dark caramel aroma and flavor, very light roasty flavor too, a bit too dry and weak though. Luckily there is some chocolate too. Nice.

name: Estes Park Porter
review: 12 oz. bottle, pours a deep dark brown with an amber tinge with a small beige head. Aroma brings out toasted malt and dry cocoa. Flavour is fairly robust, with toasted malt, burnt crusty bread and toasted nuts. Somewhat robust in the flavours, but the body is quite weak making this underwhelming. Meh.

name: Estes Park Porter
review: Bottle - Nice toasty notes and some flowery notes. Deep brown with a light beige head. Light sweet toasty notes and some hop perfumy notes. Nice, light and sweet.

name: Estes Park Porter
review: (Draught) Pours a black body with a medium tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, graham cracker, coffee, and chocolate. Flavor of chocolate, graham cracker, caramel, marshmallow, and toasted grain.

name: Estes Park Porter
review: Pours dark red abd mostly opaque with an off-white head and little lacing. Aroma is a mix of sprucey hops and coffee beans. Tastes of roasted coffee and hops. Overall much more hoppy than expected.

name: Estes Park Barley Wine
review: From May 2007 Purchased from Wilbur's in Ft Collins This pours a deep amber/brown with little to no head of foam and has a tiny bit of lacing. The smell is spot on for a BWSA for me. Lots of yummy caramel malt and dark fruit hitting my nose. The taste on first sip is huge! I'm getting the big caramel that I mentioned in the smell along with some dark fruit, plum and black cherry,(light on the cherry) and a good roastiness and some grain. Further sips in and the flavours just won't quit and yeah, the 10% abv is obviously there but taking the small sips that I'm taking, it is no way near overwhelming. I'd say it's more of a soothing effect on my taste buds and I don't get a burn when it goes down. Yum. The finish is very tasty with a mix of fruit semi sweetness and a roasty bitterness. The aftertaste lingers on for what seems like forever and in this case, that's a good thing. ;^) The mouthfeel borders on thick, as in thick and chewy, where it *should* be, and the carbonation is light, also where it should be. I'm darned impressed with this BWSA, to say the least! Bottom line: This is the first brew I've tried from Estes Park Brewery and my hat is off to them for making a very true to style, abundantly flavourful, and oh so tasty sipping Barleywine Style Ale. I'd buy this again without hesitation.

name: Estes Park Barley Wine
review: Draft at the brewery in Estes Park. Pours opaque bronze. Aroma of stone fruit (figs with some apricot). Caramel with fig along with some subtle apricot notes. Sweet brown sugar with a hint of alcohol in the finish. A bit too much sweetness.

name: Estes Park Barley Wine
review: Clear dark ruby copper with no head. Big boozy sweet aroma with dates and sticky toffee malt and brown sugar. Good flavor featuring boozy caratoffee and dates and boozy sweet phenols. Nice. A good sipper.

name: Estes Park Barley Wine
review: Look: pours a dark copper. Off white head. Slight cloudiness. Smell: very sweet. Caramel or toffee. Raspberry fruit roll up. Berries. Malt. Taste: alcohol. Slight bitterness. On the back end. Sweet berries. Raspberry. Blueberry. Malt Feel: dry. Leaves a thick film on the mouth. Really makes the mouth salivate. Overall: nicely done beer. Goo flavor and mouth feel. Really like the sweet fruits and the slight bitterness. Very well balanced beer. Not what I would call a true barleywine but still a great beer. First Drank: home 10/13/14

name: Estes Park Barley Wine
review: "pretty dark pour...nice mahogony color, but also pretty flat. a smooth sipper. definitely on the sweet side...molasses, tobacco, dark fruits. definitely liked it and it could stand up to some of the big boys with some carbonation."

name: Estes Park Barley Wine
review: 12 oz. bottle. Pours a thin poorly retained ivory head, with some lacing, over a clear dark copper (SRM 20) body.....nose is pine, resin, citrus peel, dreid fruits....taste is malt sweetness, with dried fruits including, raisin, fig, plum tones, some light pineapple, finishing with a moderate pine citrus peel bitterness......mouth feel, chewy, with a heavy thick body, sticky, alcohol warmth, with slight fusel tones, carbonation low with a mild acid finish. This is obviously an American Barley Wine with American hops. It is hop forward, with almost balancing malt strength resulting in a near balance of strengths. BJCP 8/3/15/4/7

name: Estes Park Barley Wine
review: 10/10/2010. Sampled at the brewery. My favorite of the beers served there. Dark brown with a tan head. Malt, dried fruit, caramel aromas with hints of alcohol. Thick and buttery, dried fruit, alcohol with light hops.

name: Estes Park Barley Wine
review: On tap at the brewery. Brown and cloudy with a light tan head. The aroma is sweet and full of caramel malts and light alcohol. Similar flavor, malty and sweet with grass, herbal hops and a light earthiness. Full bodied malt bomb.

name: Estes Park Barley Wine
review: Aroma is caramel and malts with some vanilla. Pours a dark reddish brown with almost no head. Taste is caramel and malty sweet. Not as much alcohol taste as other barleywines. Very good.

name: Estes Park Barley Wine
review: Bottle from Ratman. Pours a hazy dark brown. Sweet with some dryness. Aromas of caramel and hints of roasted malts. Also notes of alcohol and residual sugars.

name: Estes Park Longs Peak Raspberry Wheat
review: Ar: bardzo intensywne maliny, nieco bananow i ziarna, dobra intenywnosc. Wyg: metnawe, zolto-zlote, piany prawie brak. Sm: konretne, ale nieco landrynkowe maliny, przejrzale banany. Pos: nieco lagery, niedobre przejrzale banany. Ov: ok, z potencjalem, ale z wadami.

name: Estes Park Longs Peak Raspberry Wheat
review: Sampled in a massive, multibeer taste test. Pours with a sparse head. Definite raspberry aroma. Fruity but weak palate. Cheerleader beer.

name: Estes Park Longs Peak Raspberry Wheat
review: Clear golden with a thin spotty white head. Bright Raspberry fruity jammy nose. Crisp clean pale golden flavor with a thin fleshy raspberryish crisp flavor.

name: Estes Park Longs Peak Raspberry Wheat
review: Translucent pale yellow with quickly dissipating head. Strong sweet smell of artificial raspberries. Strong taste of artificial raspberry flavoring. Similar to a wine cooler. Taste is sweet with a dry finish. Very fizzy.

name: Estes Park Longs Peak Raspberry Wheat
review: Raspberry beer that really tastes like the fruit, not fake. Light and refreshing for the summer, but beware the funky aftertaste. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Estes Park Longs Peak Raspberry Wheat
review: Sample at the brewery. Low fluffy white lasting head. Clear yellow body. Sweet raspberry aroma and flavor with little hops bitterness, low carbonation and a long finish.

name: Estes Park Longs Peak Raspberry Wheat
review: Pour on tap at the brewery, hazy golden pour with white head, aroma brought notes of grass, bread, some slight raspberry, watery smelling with a hint of mineral, slight wheat notes with a touch of fruit, no real yeast character. Taste is a mix of grass, bread, some grain and wheat into a slight watery raspberry/vanilla sweetness, some slight minerals, finishing sweet.

name: Estes Park Longs Peak Raspberry Wheat
review: thin weakish wheat beer base nothing to write home about, but the raspberry is done well, and it ends up being a refreshing brew. fruity beer lovers would like this. i thought it ok."

name: Estes Park Longs Peak Raspberry Wheat
review: A smooth beer. Pale malts throughout which covers most of the aroma and flavor. The raspberry tastes a little synthetic.

name: Estes Park Longs Peak Raspberry Wheat
review: 12oz bottle, purchased from Brennan’s in Madison during GTMW. Clear golden color. Some particles floating about in the body. Minimal ring of white head. Loose short ropes of lace. Nice wheat flavor, and good raspberry. I like it. Moderate sweet taste, light tart. Medium body. Smooth, kind of crisp, light soft, light carbonation. More slick finish. Solid raspberry wheat ale, I enjoyed it.

name: Estes Park Bear Lake Blueberry Wheat
review: Ar: mocne jagody, jezyny i borowki, nieco sztucznie, ziarno w tle, intensywne. Wyg: zolto-zlotawe, lekko zmetnione, piana gruba, rozna. Sm: wysycenie bardzo wysokie, lekkie przejrzale banany, za to jagody i jezyny wyrazne, w tle sycaca ziarnistosc. Pos: cierpko-kwasek czarnych owocow, nieco siary. Ov: pomysl dobry, slaba baza.

name: Estes Park Bear Lake Blueberry Wheat
review: How: Bottle. Where: Tasting at Björn, 2017-09-22. Appearance: Hazy golden colour with a white head. Aroma: Blueberries, sweet. Body: Light body, medium carbonation. Flavour: Blueberries, some malt.

name: Estes Park Bear Lake Blueberry Wheat
review: Bottled. Hazy golden, huge lively head. Aroma of blueberry jam. Sweetish with light body and clean mouthfeel. Blueberry jam and emptiness. Tinny and basic.

name: Estes Park Bear Lake Blueberry Wheat
review: Clear bright golden with a thin white spotty cap. Brisk blueberry flesh aroma with a slight pancake tone behind it, but in a beer-y way. Hard to explain. Brisk semidry flavor that’s golden malty and bright blueberry fleshy and slightly blue fruity.

name: Estes Park Bear Lake Blueberry Wheat
review: Sample at the brewery. High creamy lasting white head. Hazy pale yellow green body. Mild and sweet blueberry straw malt caramel flavor with little hops bitterness, low carbonation and a long sweet finish.

name: Estes Park Bear Lake Blueberry Wheat
review: (Draught) Pours a clear pale yellow body with a small white head. Aroma of blueberry, grain, and biscuit. Flavor of blueberry, muffin dough, and wheat.

name: Estes Park Bear Lake Blueberry Wheat
review: 12oz bottle, purchased from Brennan’s in Madison during GTMW. Mostly clear golden orange color. Thin ring of off-white head. Leaves a few bits of lace. Medium body. Smooth, kind of slick lighter carbonation. Moderate sweet taste. Wheat flavor, and decent blueberry. I much prefer the raspberry version, though.

name: Estes Park Bear Lake Blueberry Wheat
review: Reviewed from notes. Consumed last Summer. This was poured into a pint glass. The appearance had a nice hazy golden orange to amber color. The smell had a nice blend of sweet blueberry notes subtly combining with a decent wheat malt base. The taste was mainly sweet with a light wheat kick at the end. On the palate, this one sat about a medium on the body with a sessionability that could be slightly discerned. The carbonation was subdued and slightly smooth but yet the wheat that was in this one maintained a certain mildness that wasn’t necessarily expected. Overall flavorful sweet fruity Summer ale in the blueberry fashion, uh... heck yeah, definitely one of the better blueberry ales on the market these days.

name: Estes Park Bear Lake Blueberry Wheat
review: Had on draft at the brewery. Big blueberry aroma, some cracker as well.The flavor is all blueberry and doughy wheat notes. Not bad beer.

name: Estes Park Bear Lake Blueberry Wheat
review: Poured from tap to glass. Hazy straw hue with white head and fresh blueberries floating on top. Aroma is huge blueberry, straw, sugar, clove, yeast. Mouthfeel is smooth with a medium light body and soft carbonation. Taste is sweet wheat throughout with a mellow carbonic balance. Overall this is a fun seasonal brew.

name: Estes Park Staggering Elk
review: Taster at the brewery. Pours a clear, light brown color, with a small, beige film. The aroma is biscuit dough, rye, pine sap, and chalk. Sweet and malty, with a sharp bitterness. Light to medium body, with a sticky, malty, and hard palate.

name: Estes Park Staggering Elk
review: Slightly hazy golden with a thin white rocky cap. Thin biscuity pale malt nose. Crisp pale lagery flavor that’s clean and bready and quite German with no hop bitterness anywhere to be found. Cerealish and slightly corny but clean and light.

name: Estes Park Staggering Elk
review: 355ml bottle. California common style yeast makes it a bit fruity in the aroma, flavor is not great, but it is drinkable.

name: Estes Park Staggering Elk
review: Sample at the brewery. No head. Clear amber body. Mild and weak malt straw aroma and flavor with little hops bitterness, low caronation and a short finish.

name: Estes Park Staggering Elk
review: (Draught) Pours a clear yellow body with a medium white head. Aroma of grain, biscuit, and light citrus. Flavor of grain, earth, apple, and citrus.

name: Estes Park Staggering Elk
review: Now I know why the elk are staggering: they’re about to drop dead after sampling this horrid brew. "Harshly metallic" is the only way to describe the taste. Did I get a bad batch? After 1 1/2 sips we dumped the rest of the bottle down the sink.

name: Estes Park Staggering Elk
review: Look: pours a dark golden color. Slight cloudiness. Bright white head. Smell: heavy malt. Sourdough bread. Biscuit. Taste: bread. Crackers. Heavy malt. Noble hops, minimal pine flavor. Hint of bitterness on the back end. Feel: medium carbonation. Malt heavy. Very balanced and refreshing. Overall: ok beer. Not a Bad lager. Like the balance. Normally not s lager fan but the mouth feel flavor and aroma are all nicely balanced. First drank: home 11/5/14

name: Estes Park Staggering Elk
review: "my buddy said this was a great lager on tap, but i wasn’t feeling the bottle. light and fizzy are the keywords. flavor and aroma has cereal malt and light grassy hops, but not much else."

name: Estes Park Staggering Elk
review: 12 oz bottle shared by Huhzubendah’s mother in law, thanks Sue! Pours a clear copper brown with minimal head retention and virtually no lacing. Aroma is mild biscuit malt and a certain unbalanced oxidized note. Flavor is same with a thin mouthfeel and sweet sugary finish.

name: Estes Park Staggering Elk
review: Hilarious art work on the label and a great story behind this beer. Copper body, light chill haze with a bubbly tan head. Aromas of lager yeast, heavy fruity sweetness, caramel malt. Eh...mediocre flavor at best. Caramel malt and sweet fruity booze. Pass.

name: Cains Finest Bitter (Cask)
review: Bona cervesa molt equilibrada i gustosa. Buena cerveza muy equilibrada y sabrosa.

name: Cains Finest Bitter (Cask)
review: Appearance: Amber color with a finger thick white head. Fine lacing. Aroma: Slightly sweet caramel malty and fruity. Palate: Medium light body. Slightly sweet and a mild bitterness. Soft carbonation. Taste: Caramel malty, toffee, light hoppy and a fine fruity background. Overall impression: A bit thin. Otherwise ok. Personal stats: On tap at Doctor Duncan’s (Cains) in Liverpool, England.

name: Cains Finest Bitter (Cask)
review: Cask @ Doctor Duncans, Liverpool 040113 Light golden brown, clear, pillowy white head, good lacing Aroma - soft caramel, soft fruits, touch of red berry, subdued aroma Taste - caramel malts, hedgerow hops, very simple, not bad though, bit watery Palate - Thin body. Finish - more fruits come through here, red berries, touch of blackcurrant with bitter twig hops in the tail, Overall - Bit better than the average standard bitter

name: Cains Finest Bitter (Cask)
review: thin, watery, near flavourless beer had it at the brewery tap and even there it was cloudy and near undrinkable little bit of hop little bit of bready malt i keep giving cains a go and the only thing theyre consistant with is dissapointment.poor

name: Cains Finest Bitter (Cask)
review: Clear amber with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, caramel and fruity. Flavor is medium sweet almost without bitterness. Dryish finish. Thin bodied, flat and bland. 291010

name: Cains Finest Bitter (Cask)
review: A bit different from how I remember it last time I had it. Colour off brown, taste is of cereal and caramel.

name: Cains Finest Bitter (Cask)
review: Cask. Nose is a fine woody malt, copper, pours a small long lasting toffee head. Flavour is a lighter malt than the nose, nutty too. Light bodied, well balanced, fine bitterness. Very good.

name: Cains Finest Bitter (Cask)
review: Cask. Clear amber golden with a creamy off-white head leaving broad curtains of lacework. Sweet buttery nose. Thin and watery, completely flat with light notes of nuts and a massive fustiness. No bitterness. Poor. 200110

name: Cains Finest Bitter (Cask)
review: Cask at Charlies. Clear orange red coloured with a small off white head. Fruity aroma of caramel, hops and grass. Fruity flavour of malts, caramel, hops and grass. Dry hoppy finish.

name: Cains Finest Bitter (Cask)
review: From cask at Charlies. Pours clear and golden deep amber with a small tan and lacing head. Roasted malt aroma, light fruity. Smooth malty, breadish and fruity. Bitter and overripe fruity finish. Dry and malty lasting impression.

name: Cains Dark Mild (Keg/Can)
review: This is a backlog rating from 2012 from a can, from notes. When I had this beer it was average to below average for the style and not something I wanted to have again or I just didn't get back to my notes because of my technology at the time. Words to describe this beer are toasted, chocolate, earthy, I won't revisit this.

name: Cains Dark Mild (Keg/Can)
review: retrospective notes as i have just discovered this to be discontinued. always had cains canned, and found it to be smooth and refreshing for a mild british ale. that being said, this is far from my favourite form of beer and this - how can i put it "mildly" (haha) - is a fairly bland style sometimes. i always enjoyed my cans of cains; chocolatey and malty with a old style taste. ABV is incredibly low, though.

name: Cains Dark Mild (Keg/Can)
review: Poured into a perfect pint. 4.25 A: Clear dark brown color. Two and a half fingers of creamy/frothy tan head. Retention is very good and a short ring of lacing is left. 3.75 S: Roasty toasty graininess with a hint of ash. Overall quite dry with notes of chocolate, nuts, and caramel. Touch of mineral to round things off. Decently powerful for a beer of its size. 3.75 T: Like the nose, there’s a lot of toastiness with some roasty component. Dry with a moderate bitterness. Chocolate, nuttiness, mineral and caramel form a subtle complexity. Again, a lot going on given the ABV. 4.25 M: Lighter body. Good moderate carbonation with a surprising amount of creaminess. Super smooth, well done. 4.0 D: Pretty good beer to reach for if you are in the mood for a dark session beer. No real complaints. DavoleBomb, May 29, 2013

name: Cains Dark Mild (Keg/Can)
review: Can. Press an opaque dark brown with a thin layer of toffee colored head. Aroma is faint, some malts. Taste of subtle malts and hints of chocolate.

name: Cains Dark Mild (Keg/Can)
review: Pours black with creamy beige head. Smell is slight bandaid roasty malt. Taste is smooth creamy band aid and subtle roasted malt. Creamy body, soft carbonation

name: Cains Dark Mild (Keg/Can)
review: I had a bit of a heavy night of it last night and so as a consequence I wasn’t after anything too challenging today. I thought "Ooh, mild, that shouldn’t hurt me too much." Well, I was a little surprised at how dark it really was. It verges on black with some ruby port in the dimple and has a thick skim of head that looks creamy with a tinge of green. The aroma is of dark caramel, chocolate and cocoa with maybe just a niff of rum? Thickish and creamy texture with sweetness aplenty. It has its charms this beer, but in my current state it is a little heavy going, even for the laudable lower alcohol content. I don’t think my review does this beer a disservice though. On any other day I would still enjoy its flavour just as much.

name: Cains Dark Mild (Keg/Can)
review: 500 ml can I am a little disappointed in not getting to try something from the area while in England but that is a good reason to go back. In the meantime this county tick is a respectable beer if you still happen across it. It is nothing special and being transported across the ocean does it no favors. That said I have had worse mild ales. Aroma / Appearance - Velvety chocolate fluid pours easily into the pint glass. A mocha head remains from the vigorous pour. Chocolate cream pie, sweet malts, and gentle roasted notes accent a mostly balanced and low key mild. Flavor / Palate - The body is a trace thin even for a mild ale. Cool coffee and inexpensive chocolate alternate the primary focus before a soothing low key finish. Fading quickly there is not much left after the final sip. If you want a fair representation of the English mild style this does a good job. However there are certainly better offerings out there when on the other side of the ocean.

name: Cains Dark Mild (Keg/Can)
review: 500ml can from The Beer Cellar. Super black in colour with a big frothy head. Roast malt aroma with a thin mouthfeel. Big flavour for a small alcohol content.

name: Cains Dark Mild (Keg/Can)
review: 16oz can thanks to devman! Clear brown. Smaller creamy coffee head. Nose is fruit juice, cherry juice box, cinnamon perhaps. Taste is watery, metallic, apple skins, mild coffee. Pretty decent creaminess as it warms. Lactic dairy character, mild chocolate milk. Not so bad.

name: Cains Dark Mild (Keg/Can)
review: From a can, aroma is light roast, taste is nice and dark and mild... Nice pub style ale

name: Cains FA (Bottle/Can)
review: Bottle @ Home. Pours golden with a small white head. Aroma of malt,, light caramel, light hops. Flavor is sweet, malt, little caramel, light grass. Thin to medium body, lively carbonation. 220914

name: Cains FA (Bottle/Can)
review: Bona cervesa, bastant equilibrada i gustosa. Buena cerveza, bastante equilibrada y sabrosa.

name: Cains FA (Bottle/Can)
review: An odd earthlike flavor with some bitterness and a watery aftertaste. Color is amber with a white head.

name: Cains FA (Bottle/Can)
review: Golden ale, no head. It’s a typical premium bitter with a slight sweetness for its aroma and taste. Easily a session beer.

name: Cains FA (Bottle/Can)
review: Bottle: Nose is malt and cereal. Taste is cereal and slight lactose. Very little bitterness. Light hops. Passable bitter

name: Cains FA (Bottle/Can)
review: Bottle. Golden ale with a quickly dissipating head. Aroma is sweetish and a little metallic. Taste is malts, fruits maybe plum and caramel. Quite sweet. A little too carbonated. Quite nice if you fancy a sweet beer for a change.

name: Cains FA (Bottle/Can)
review: Dark golden coloured and clear. Has a white head. Sweet aroma, malty and light bread. Flavor starts moderate sweet and creamy, finish bitter and dry. Soft carbonation.

name: Cains FA (Bottle/Can)
review: Lovely smooth ale, nice caramel malty aroma, looks heavy but.is.surpsingly easy to drink,sweet and tasty.

name: Cains FA (Bottle/Can)
review: Can’t believe I’ve never reviewed this before: 500ml bottle best before the end of July 2012, poured into an Abbot Ale badged glass tankard two weeks before that date. The deep golden body had a slight hazy look but the perfectly formed head and aroma compensated for it completely. Malts all the way here with hops always trying to break even both in the smell and taste: this ensures the beer is semi-sweet and has a mini bitterness at all times as well. The 5.0% ABV suits it nicely and it sits well as the beer sinks down my tankard leaving some thick lacing after each gulp.

name: Cains FA (Bottle/Can)
review: Bottle, 5%. Slightly hazy deep golden/amber with small off-white head. Aroma is malt, hops, little fruit and a little caramel. Flavour is malt, hops, medium bitter, little sweet, high carbonation, fruit and a little grainy.

name: Granite Brewery Best Bitter Special
review: Cask at Barvolo. Pours a clear, copper caramel with a one finger, creamy cask head. Aroma has mild notes of caramel, bread, slight roast and dark fruits, and a slight nuttiness. Taste is balanced very well with notes of caramel, cola, nuts, bread, slight roast and darker malts, and a drawn out, dark caramel ending. Medium body with a low, Cask carbonation. Clean in the mouth with a dry finish. Overall a nice beer of cask.

name: Granite Brewery Best Bitter Special
review: On cask tap at The Henry House in Halifax. Unfiltered with 4.5% ABV. Clear copper body with a bubbly tan head. Looks like their regular bitter except that the head is a bit better and the copper colored body is slightly darker. Smooth thin body with light carbonation. Mild bitterness. Lingering, moderately hoppy aftertaste. Some bready malts in the background. Surprisingly weak aroma given the flavor.

name: Granite Brewery Best Bitter Special
review: cask at the brewpub. Coppery amber. Whiteish bubbly head. Very sweet, candy-like aroma, like sniffing a bag of jelly beans, plus floral hops. Tastes similar. It’s quite different from their regular Best Bitter. Very soft on the palate, even too much so - no liveliness whatsoever. Dry, somewhat grainy finish with a bit of grassy bitterness.

name: Granite Brewery Best Bitter Special
review: Well balanced British style bitter. Good floral hop nose backed with a great balance of toffee and 2 row. Lots of character from Ringwood yeast. One of the best ales in the maritimes.

name: Granite Brewery Best Bitter Special
review: Sampled on draft at the brewpub this beer poured a dark caramel color with a large soapy white head that lingered but left minimal lacing. The aroma was tart, fruity, a touch of perfume and leather. The flavor was tart and bitter with vague fruits, citrus perfume and a hint of leather. Medium length finish. Medium body but a bit flat. Not good.

name: Granite Brewery Best Bitter Special
review: Growler from brewer. Amber brown pour with moderate head. Caramel and hops aroma. Moderate palate. Peculiar flat aftertaste. A bit of a disappointment for me.

name: Granite Brewery Best Bitter Special
review: Draft - Caramel, grassy hops and a slight bitterness. Clear gold with a decent white head. Caramel, resinous hops and a mild long lasting bitterness that has some grains. Nice example of a casket ESB.

name: Granite Brewery Best Bitter Special
review: I enjoyed this Bitter beer. One of the better Bitters I have tasted. Was cool being able to take some home with me in big Growler bottles. Also the food at the brewery was very good, it is a nice little place to visit if anyone is in Younge and Eglinton area.

name: Granite Brewery Best Bitter Special
review: An old favourite of mine from when I lived nearby. Turns out it’s pretty much as good as I remember. Appearance: clear amber with foamy 3/4-inch head. Aroma: English hops and caramel. Taste: caramel, bread, with a big bitter finish. Great cask texture.

name: Granite Brewery Best Bitter Special
review: Grey Cup 2012. Sample tray. Had the Best Bitter on tap and the Best Bitter dry hopped cask. I prefered the tap. Nice copper body. Bubbly head and nice lace. Long comforting woody hops.

name: Granite Brewery IPA
review: Cask. Kind of tropical smelling, soapy head and very foamy, very round and smooth creamy palate, fresh grassy hops, easy drinking IPA, bitterness is moderate and hop flavour is the primary.

name: Granite Brewery IPA
review: Tap at Granite in Toronto. Slightly hazy golden with off-white head. Interesting and not at all IPA-ish fruitiness, a kind of passionfruit nose and flavour. Carbonation really mild, and not too surprisingly, watery on the palate. Really soft on the tongue, which is rather pleasant... Yet how it all comes together... Not exactly the kind of IPA I’d enjoy very much or write home about. Pleasant enough to finish the sample though.

name: Granite Brewery IPA
review: Can from the brewery. Pours a deep apricot with thin white head. Nose is fruity and floral, euro hops, overripe fruit. Taste follows the nose, fruity esters, firm bitterness, low carbonation, some citrus fruit. Very English, very tasty. Light for an IPA. I like it. Not at all in the west-coast style.

name: Granite Brewery IPA
review: Cask at Castro's Lounge. attractive colour and head. No odour. Unbalanced and watery on the palate. Little hops. Long finish but not enjoyable. Wouldn't order again. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Granite Brewery IPA
review: Sampled on draft at the brewpub this beer poured an orange-amber color with a medium sized soapy white head that left no lacing. The aroma was tangy, fruity and citric. The flavor was bitter, dryish and bitey with fruity and citric hops. Long finish. Light body and thin. Meh.

name: Granite Brewery IPA
review: Cask pour at Victory Cafe looks fantastic: butter yellow body with a plump & curvy one finger head. Clear case of nice legs, shame about her face. This is a mild tasting British style IPA, with a flaccid palate & far too flowery flavour. May go well for a quick pint before work, but other than that your other options have more pull.

name: Granite Brewery IPA
review: Cask - Earthy and a bit of grapefruit. Clear gold with a thin head. Grassy and resinous hops, perfume, mellow with a light malt backbone. Nice cask style session English IPA.

name: Granite Brewery IPA
review: On tap at Granite Brewery - golden with a soapy head. Far and away the worst IPA I have ever had. Taste is buttery and watered down. If you ever have the opportunity to drink one of these, get something else instead.

name: Granite Brewery IPA
review: Grey Cup 2012. Sample tray. Good head on cask. Nice hop delivery. Grapefruit with light malt gentleness. Nice finish and aftertaste.

name: Granite Brewery IPA
review: Cask @ Volo. Pours a cloudy orange with minimal head. Aroma of toasted malt, jam, apricot, toasted biscuit. Flavor of bready malt and bitterness up front, followed by spicy hops and tobacco. Light, drinkable, and tasty. 7/4/7/4/14 [3.6/5]

name: Granite Brewery Peculiar
review: If rum was hopped it would be Peculiar by Granite Brewery. It’s mahogany hue with modest head introduced dark fruit, butterscotch, graham cracker flavours. Had this strong English ale at Townhouse Pub, Antigonish, Nova Scotia onJuly 17, 2018

name: Granite Brewery Peculiar
review: Tap, Water & Bone, Halifax. Pours mahogany, low carbonation, zero haze. Taste is caramel, sweet malt, almost no hop. Well made if a tad light.

name: Granite Brewery Peculiar
review: Soft aroma of soya sauce, no head and a dark copper body. Flavour is soft hoppiness tempered by just a touch of malt character. Not too interesting but drinkable.

name: Granite Brewery Peculiar
review: Had this on tap as part of a sampler at Henry House in Halifax. It was my favourite of the 4 Granite products in w sampler. I prefer a malty ale to one with a lot of hops & Peculiar hit the spot

name: Granite Brewery Peculiar
review: Bottle from the LCBO. Clear dark copper under a fluffy off white head that fades slowly and leaves some sparse lace Nose is banana, dark fruit, spice toffee and some bread. Moderate brown sugar, plum and raisin sweetness with a light bitterness appearing in the middle and fading through the finish. Medium slick mouth with average carbonation, Bit on the sweet side. 7/4/6/3/14-

name: Granite Brewery Peculiar
review: On cask tap at The Henry House in Halifax. Copper body with good clarity topped by a durable, light tan head. Sweet and roasted grains with faint hops in the aroma. The flavor follows. A touch more bitter than sweet. Smooth, near medium body. Alcohol more obvious than it should be in both the taste and the feel; especially in the taste. Some toffee up front and again in the aftertaste.

name: Granite Brewery Peculiar
review: Right out of the bottle (650ml) lots of wet banana bread batter scents. Dark red tea water with a thick grayish off-white head that looks like frothy latte. Some spicy notes and a bit of cloves with a heavy yeasty base in the aroma. Wet or sweet taste and very fruity even dark raisin flavours. Upfront bold high gravity profile balance and refreshing.

name: Granite Brewery Peculiar
review: Tap at the brewpub. Dark, clear, coppery-mahogany brown with a nicely retaining off-whtite head. Roasty-toasty nose and flavour, sour red berries and nuts, prunes, somewhat citric. Feels more bitter and strong than it actually is. Crisp. Lemon drop kind of finish. It’s quite nice.

name: Granite Brewery Peculiar
review: Sampled on draft at the brewpub this beer poured a dark caramel color with a small soapy white head that left good lacing. The aroma was tart, bitter, fruity and had touches of honey and toffee. The flavor was tart, bitter, sour caramel, vague fruits and citrus. Medium length finish. Medium body but a bit flat. Meh.

name: Granite Brewery Peculiar
review: Pours dark brown with a small diminishing white head. Sweet aroma of light hops and caramel malt. Flavour starts off sweet and ends lightly bitter.

name: Granite Brewery Ringwood Ale
review: 12oz on tap at the Henry House. Pours a clear golden with light white head and light carbonation. Grainy with a little bit of a buttery flavour. Light and thin on the palate. Pretty bland.

name: Granite Brewery Ringwood Ale
review: On tap at the Henry House in Halifax... Very tasty. Somewhat light, with dissipating head, well carbonated but not exaggeratedly so. Great mouthfeel with subtle hops and a fresh aftertaste. By no means a flavour-bomb, but subtle and elegant.

name: Granite Brewery Ringwood Ale
review: Draft - Bready, yeast and pale malts. Pale gold with a rich creamy head. Bread, yeast and corn. No hops or bitterness and kind of flat. Not very good.

name: Granite Brewery Ringwood Ale
review: Clear brew with a light yellow amber colour. Muted aroma but shows yeast and earthy notes with a hint of sweet malts. Medium bodied at best. some almond and nuts on the uptake and a fast finish. boring beer.

name: Granite Brewery Ringwood Ale
review: Grey Cup 2012. Sample tray. This is was the most surprising sample. Great for style and the light beer every brewpub has. Lures you in then gets you with a very nice gentle hop bitterness. I could have used a couple of cases of this while working on my deck this month.

name: Granite Brewery Ringwood Ale
review: Draft sample at Henry House. Aroma was fruity, like sweet berries. Very little head and light lacing. Unfiltered gold colour. Taste was more light sweet fruit with a nice hop finish. Body was crisp with light carbonation. Overall, a decent lighter ale that actually had some hops.

name: Granite Brewery Ringwood Ale
review: Odd taste, certainly detect soft mouth feel they talk about which is nice. Touch of sour aftertaste.

name: Granite Brewery Ringwood Ale
review: On tap @ The Henry House in Halifax, enjoyed as part of a tasting tray. Very bright clear golden, medium white head. Aroma is cereal malt, quite buttery. Grainy sweet and buttery flavors with low key dried leafy hop in the finish.

name: Granite Brewery Ringwood Ale
review: Growler from the brewpub. Pours a hazy golden yellow with a tiny soapy white head. Aroma is grainy, somewhat sweet with a mild citrus note. Taste same although citrus a little more pronounced. Light earthy hoppiness in finish. Nothing special but solid all the same.

name: Granite Brewery Ringwood Ale
review: Draft, Granite Brewpub. Clean gold pour, small head. Decent carbonation here. Very mild aroma; grains, sweet malt, perhaps a little citrus. Average golden ale taste. First introduction to the term Fuggle, though, so I’ll give this one points there. Slight citrus taste, but there’s nothing here worth going back form, IMO. Was expecting more, especially being unfiltered, but it is average at best.

name: Granite Brewery Keefes Irish Stout
review: Tap (The Greater Good, Toronto). Black color. Medium size, brown head, stays. Sweet, milky, roast, chocolate, herbal in aroma/taste. Solid brew.

name: Granite Brewery Keefes Irish Stout
review: AROma is straight roast, coffee, caramel, maybe raspberry or something else tart. Solid black, minimal beige head. Medium bitterness, little bit of sweetness in the finish. Decent overall, probably wouldn’t get again though.

name: Granite Brewery Keefes Irish Stout
review: Soft coffee on the nose and a bit of head over a jet black body. Flavour is good coffee and roasted barley, filling on the mouth. Not exceptional but this stout hits all the notes.

name: Granite Brewery Keefes Irish Stout
review: Had this as part of a sampler on tap at Henry House in Halifax NS. Dark ruby, almost black. It stood up very well with fish and chips with loads of malt vinegar.

name: Granite Brewery Keefes Irish Stout
review: From tap. Pours pitch black with a small tan head. Aroma is roasted malty and slight breadish. Toasted malty. Sweet, toasted and caramelish. Malty and roasted finish. Dry and herbal far finish.

name: Granite Brewery Keefes Irish Stout
review: Nice roasted coffee scent with medium to full body, nice coffee taste and slight roast malt sweetness. Very smooth and a bit smoky in the finish, pretty tasty.

name: Granite Brewery Keefes Irish Stout
review: Draft to tulip Consummation: Coffee, cream, and hazelnut. Adjunct: Aroma is Baileys; thick black with thick creamy head

name: Granite Brewery Keefes Irish Stout
review: Keefe’s Irish Stout on tap at The Henry House in Halifax where it’s sometimes referred to as "Halifax Guinness". Medium-light body that’s smooth and well carbonated but seems a bit to thin. Clear but very dark ruby colored body with a creamy and very durable head. Hints of smoke and char. No fruit notes. Moderately bitter. Lasting aftertaste of very dark roasted grains.

name: Granite Brewery Keefes Irish Stout
review: Draught at The Craft Brasserie. Mostly roasted malt flavors with light smokey and nutty notes, bitter coffee finish. Meh quite simple and average brew, nothing memorable.

name: Granite Brewery Keefes Irish Stout
review: On tap @ The Craft TO. Pours an opaque brown with a large mocha head. Aroma is slightly acidic and metallic. Tastes are coffee and roasty malts. Full body, rich and creamy, medium bitter finish. Nice beer. ---Rated via Beer Buddy

name: Granite Brewery Summer Ale
review: The Oxley toronto. A bit bitter for me but ha s a a pretty full body to balance.

name: Granite Brewery Summer Ale
review: Tap at Granite in Toronto. Slightly hazy golden with off-white head. The aroma is grainy, floral, wheaty. Flavour’s similar, mellow sweet with little finishing bitterness. A bit watery but that’s expectable. A perfectly alright summer-time brew to down by the pint - I really did enjoy it!

name: Granite Brewery Summer Ale
review: Sampled on draft at the brewpub this beer poured a medium amber color with a large creamy white head that left incredible lacing. The aroma was malty, yeasty, bready and had a hint of vague fruits. The flavor was phenol, tangy, sweetish and had vague fruits. Long phenol finish. Medium body. Meh.

name: Granite Brewery Summer Ale
review: Growler. Pours golden with a fluffy white head. Nose is citrusy hops, spent apple, graham cracker and mild caramel. Lightly sweet with well balanced hop. Low carbonation and modest body. Crushable, a great British-y quaffer.

name: Granite Brewery Summer Ale
review: Cask handpull at a random Toronto bar while waiting for Bellwoods to open. Hazy amber color, fluffy tan head. Aroma of light straw and citrus. taste is bitter and lightly peppery. OK.

name: Granite Brewery Summer Ale
review: tap, golden pour, floral, honey nice and summery, a light hop bit and a nice finish.

name: Granite Brewery Summer Ale
review: #oncask at Dominion on Queen. Poured a nice light amber colour, very little carbonation - as expected. The waiter even asked if I knew what cask was before bringing me the beer. I liked the nuanced aromas and flavours oh malts and hop bitter. Quite refreshing on a hot day.

name: Granite Brewery Summer Ale
review: Smells sweet, honey-like. Fairly decent for a lager, no chemicals or ill aftertaste.

name: Granite Brewery Summer Ale
review: On tap at the Toronto location, yellow gold color, with a tiny ring of white head, faint floral hop citrus nose with a light honeyed pale malt aroma follows through on a light-bodied palate with a watery, juicy flowery hop leafy character with some faint grassy, citrusy flavours and with a subtle pale malt undertone accent, leading towards a lemony hop dry finish.

name: Granite Brewery Summer Ale
review: A fuzzy light amber, mild country hay aroma, taste light country barnyard and light fruit. Medium-light feel, not much to describe.

name: Panama City Lagoon Lite
review: Draft at the Brewery in 2003. Forgot this place existed but apparently it’s closed now. Basically carbonated water with a yellow tint from what I remember. Oysters Rockefeller were suberb though.

name: Panama City Lagoon Lite
review: Light american nasty, no flavor lite.Still better than anything AB can make.

name: Panama City Beach Blonde
review: Draft at the Brewery in 2003. Forgot this place existed but apparently it’s closed now. Even less taste than macro brewed ales from what I remember. Oysters Rockefeller were suberb though.

name: Panama City Beach Blonde
review: Great golden color, not much aroma, watery and weak.........................

name: Panama City Mullet Head Red
review: Not sure if this is the same beer, but mine says Flora Bama Mullet Head Red. Got it years ago at Flora Bama bar. Anyway, red color taste was with dry finish. Nothing great about this, but it was ok.

name: Panama City Mullet Head Red
review: Draft at the Brewery in 2003. Forgot this place existed but apparently it’s closed now. Slightly below average red from what I remember. Oysters Rockefeller were suberb though.

name: Panama City Mullet Head Red
review: Clear amber color, foamy light head, thin and a bit watery, pretty bland a below average amber.

name: Panama City Captain Barrows Tarpon Stout
review: Draft at the Brewery in 2003. Forgot this place existed but apparently it’s closed now. Best beer at the brewery from what I remember. Not enough memory to comment on its stout qualities but I remember the brewery well. Odd location on a busy highway unfortunately.

name: Panama City Captain Barrows Tarpon Stout
review: Not a bad dry stout, roasted aroma, nice black color, dry roasted coffee flavor.

name: Stepan Razin Porter
review: FTA: A simple example of Russian modern baltic porter. I was drinking it for the first time when I was 16, during December 2000 cold frozen starry night. This must be ticked and noted.

name: Stepan Razin Porter
review: 0.33 l bottle (vintage 2005) at Petalax Beer Festival. Dark brown color. Raisins, chocolate, perfumed alcohol and cherry in aroma. Raisiny, musty and vinous flavor with cocoa. Quite musty but still fairly good.

name: Stepan Razin Porter
review: Bottle 330ml. @ Petalax Beer Festival 2010 - the 4th. edition. [ Vintage BBF 07-2007 ]. Clear medium brown color with a average, frothy to creamy, good lacing, mostly lasting, beige head. Aroma is moderate to light heavy malty, raosted, caramel, raisin, oxidide malt. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration, alcohol, vintage, licorice, malty. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20100702]

name: Stepan Razin Porter
review: Bottled vintage 2005 Dark brown, amber color, small off-white head. Caramel and some licorice in the nose. Caramel. roasted malts, raisins and cellary notes. Wineous. Not in the perfect shape but has potential.

name: Stepan Razin Porter
review: Stepan Razin Brewery--Stepan Razin Porter--2003 16.9 oz. Bottle. 8.00% ABV. (3.75 / 5.0) Clear dark mahogany red black color. Thin lacy head. Malty mild floral hop front. Sweet thick rich body with mild roasted rich toffee mild cocoa flavor. Smooth mild hop mild hot EtOH end. Too sweet. Big. Sampled 6/8/2003.

name: Stepan Razin Porter
review: Pours dark brown with some copper tinges and a creamy tan head. Smells earthy with some decent sweet qualities. Tastes of sweet malt, some figs, hints of tea. Mouthfeel is thick. Finish is slightly watery.

name: Stepan Razin Porter
review: Bottle. Dark brown colour with average off-wgite head. Aroma of roasted malts, coffee, hops and some chocolate. Well roasted malty flavour along with some raisin, coffee and bitter-sweet chocolate. A quite good porter.

name: Stepan Razin Porter
review: sweet aroma of banana, hops, and some chocolate cereal. huge creamy tan head on a dark ruby colored beer. a very smooth beer with banana and hops in the finish. some milky chocolate as well. a little thin. i liked it better than baltika’s baltic porter.

name: Stepan Razin Porter
review: Bottled, thanks brunnsbe!. My beer 1300, and a good way to "celebrate" it. Dark ruby red colour, mediumsized slightly off-white head. Pleasant roasted malts in aroma, along with coffee, chocolate and burnt wood. The same things in flavour, along with a sting of alcohol and licorace. Very good, I would like to have some of this in my cellar...

name: Stepan Razin Porter
review: Very full flavour, with a complex aroma. Heavily roasted. A little sweet and sour, sour cherries. A pity that this is not brewed any more - this could have been a hit on the international market!

name: Stepan Razin Martovskoe
review: Make it or break it: One of my most loved Russian beers. Up till know I was sure it was always brews in Leningrad. A perfect beer all around - thirst quenching and malty. Had not had it for 2 years min.

name: Stepan Razin Martovskoe
review: 500ml bottle (?, Russia) - gift from Alexey - thanks! Slightly mashy sweet malty aroma, a bit bready, decent roast. Classic eastern european dunkel. Rich orangy red, large tan head which fades quickly. Taste as you’d expect from the aroma, it’s sweet and malty, again a nice roastiness to it in places. Tiny hint of hops in the finish, mostly the malts. Smooth palate, soft carbonation. Full, and a little sticky in places. Nice dark lager, clean but flavourful. (Bottle says it’s brewed at Obedinenni Pivovarni Heineken = Bochkarov on RB)

name: Stepan Razin Martovskoe
review: Very attractive amber beer. Purple on the edges white sticky head...very rocky for a lager. Bubblegum chemicals in the nose. Fruity for a lager. Like Juicy Fruit in a glass. Flvaors dive, however. Chemicals are the first thing that strike the palate. Ripe fruits and juicy fruit. Slick grapefruit flavors followed by a chemical bitterness. Crips like a lager but fruity nonetheless. In the end this beer is kind of gross. Dull flat corn ending. Gray.

name: Stepan Razin Martovskoe
review: Dark amber with foamy, quickly diminishing head - very malty aroma, with cookie dough, brown sugar, rolled oats - light enough in flavor to make a good session brew, which is good for the style - however, it’s flavorful enough to keep you wanting more - caramel, brown sugar and rolled oats from the aroma come back in the flavor - a unique oktoberfest - kind of tastes like a watered down barleywine, but still pretty good.

name: Stepan Razin Martovskoe
review: Umber color with a orange brilliance when held to the light. Diminished head to a dense tan lid. Simple sweet aromas of light caramel and brown sugar. Some hints of fresh cut birchwood and vanilla in the background. Flavors are also rather sweet and simple. Light toffee and caramel. A nice toasted malt linger though. The brews from the eastern bloc counties have improved significantly in the past few years. Still not great, but at least not the alcohol infused wood and infected flavors of the days of yore. So there is hope.

name: Stepan Razin Martovskoe
review: A dark amber beer with no head. The aroma is yeasty and malty. And so is the flavor. A good beer for a Russian beer.

name: Stepan Razin Martovskoe
review: Amber color. Well malty nose, with a hay note, and sweetish. Sweet taste, lacking any character.

name: Stepan Razin Martovskoe
review: Bottled. Ruby coloured. Aroma of plums. Sweet and clean, rounded and lightly roasty. A plain Russian take on the Märzen style.

name: Stepan Razin Martovskoe
review: Bottled. Chestnut colour with a blink-and-you-miss-it head and moderate condition. Toffee malt aromas like a pale dunkle, caramel in the mouth and a long, initialy malty finish that turns chalky and quite dry at the end. Not quite sure whether it wants to be a dunkle or a märzen.

name: Stepan Razin Martovskoe
review: Thinnish, carbonic amber lager. Called Martovskoye in Russian..............

name: Stepan Razin Temnoe
review: FTA: A simple example of Russian dark lager. I was drinking it for the first time when I was 16, during December 2000 cold frozen starry night. This must be ticked and noted. There are still several brews missing. Martovskoe?

name: Stepan Razin Spetsialnoe (Special)
review: FTA: A simple example of Russian lager. I actually have all of the Stepan Razin caps and some of the labels in my archive. Loved the brewery.

name: Stepan Razin Spetsialnoe (Special)
review: 500ml bottle from supermarket in Torfyanovka. Clear yellow colur, small fizzy white mostly dissipating head, little bit of lacing. Aroma of grain, grass and a hint of apple. Taste is initially fairly balanced and slightly acidic, turning into a short acidic finish with a hint of bitterness and a chalcky feel. Light body, dry texture, lively carbonation. A very inoffensive bulk lager that doesn’t taste very well made, better to avoid.

name: Stepan Razin Spetsialnoe (Special)
review: 0.5 bottle. Pale golden color, and a big, white, frothy head which even leaves some lacing. Obvious pale lager aroma: pale malts, some hops and barnyard aromas - very hackneyed. Taste is corny too, has a lot of cereals and a touch of malts, not hop at all. Light body, thin texture and average carbonation. Finish is rather short and has even more grain. Overall the beer like most Russian lagers I have tasted is good in respect that it’s not awful, drinkable too.

name: Stepan Razin Spetsialnoe (Special)
review: Bottle. 4.0% ABV. Golden color with a collapsing medium white head. Malty aroma with light notes of hops. Flavor is sweet and malty with some hop bitterness in the finish. Light to medium body.

name: Stepan Razin Spetsialnoe (Special)
review: (Bottled, 4.0% ABV) Paleish golden color with a quite small, lacy head. A sweetish aroma of honey-corny malt and some acidity. Corny-malty flavor with some added vegetables and very little hops. Light-bodied, somewhat foamy-carbonated palate. Definitely not interesting, but still a bearable brew. Lacks most of the good features of Petrovskoye and Admiralteyskoe.

name: Stepan Razin Spetsialnoe (Special)
review: A yellow beer with no head and no aroma. The flavor is malty with notes of honey and hops. A boring pilsener.

name: Stepan Razin Spetsialnoe (Special)
review: Golden coloured. Quite weak and boring The flavour is sweet with a dry finish. Thin.

name: Stepan Razin Spetsialnoe (Special)
review: Frothy head, diminishing slowly. Slightly hoppy, soapy aroma. Medium bodied. Malty with a firm hoppiness. Some caramel and diacetyl. Some dirtiness in the aftertaste.

name: Stepan Razin Spetsialnoe (Special)
review: A sweet, toffee-ish aroma. A golden beer with almost non-lasting head. Some bitterness.

name: Stepan Razin Spetsialnoe (Special)
review: On draught at Balsjoj Festival Piva, Moscow. Golden color. Slightly sweet in flavor. Some hens-food aroma with notes of toffee...I had hopes for worse...

name: Stepan Razin Admiralteyskoe
review: FTA: A strong, solid example of a good Russian pale lager. Not a Czech Pilsner, but rather a good Helles to my tongue.

name: Stepan Razin Admiralteyskoe
review: 0.5 bottle. Pale yellow color; medium, white head on top, quite dense and stays for a while too. Hop aroma of pines and grass with some yeasty notes of leather. Taste is slightly bitter, composed mostly of hops and yeasts - very trite. Light body, thin texture and lively carbonation. Finish is short and uneventful. Overall the beer is a cliche in its own style besides the unusual fact of lacing; nothing to describe.

name: Stepan Razin Admiralteyskoe
review: Bottled Golden colour, O.K. head. Buttery aroma. Thin and watery with a faint buttery flavour and a lingering grassy bitterness.

name: Stepan Razin Admiralteyskoe
review: Not a bad beer to drink, but a little light to be a German Pilsener. It looks fine, golden with a creamy white head-soon-halo. The aroma is faint, biscuity with a hint of eastern hop bitterness. This is very soft in the mouth and tastes of sweet malts, grassy, with too light of a hopping. Okay, not great, but as the commercial description says, it’s an Ideal beverage to accompany cheeses or flavourful meats like smoked ham. I’m sure. Bridgeview Liquors, Bridgeview, IL

name: Stepan Razin Admiralteyskoe
review: Yay! I finally retrieved the ratings I lost when I dropped my handheld... by getting another handheld. .5 L bottle, rated in St. Petersburg, 6/8/04. Sometimes I feel I’m overrating these Russian beers just because they don’t offend completely, are very cheap, or are kind of refreshing after a long walk. This one will not get that treatment, although it’s pretty much the same. Opens to another lager yeast smell (flash pasteurization?) that detracts from the rest of the beer experience. Color is closer to a pilsener style, so this is close to being okay. But I had a genuine Budweiser Budvar on draft at the St.P airport a week before, and I know what a pilsener should be. For one thing, it should have hops. This doesn’t.

name: Stepan Razin Admiralteyskoe
review: Pale gold color with a thin white head. The aroma is bread with some slight flowers and dust. The taste is a full corn with some green beans and honey. There is also a hint of corn. This is not a very good version of the style. I have enjoyed some other beers from this brewer.

name: Stepan Razin Admiralteyskoe
review: Golden color with a small white head. Dry malt aromas along with a hint of chalk and light floral hops. Grainy, bready, chalky flavors. Really not bad. Really just OK.

name: Stepan Razin Admiralteyskoe
review: Golden and disturbingly hazy--no infection though and no head either. This is pretty typical for pale Russian lagers which is to say it’s too far on the sweet side and just generally crappy. Notes of hay, grass, cereal grains and the unspeakable.

name: Stepan Razin Admiralteyskoe
review: 50 cL bottle, paper bag, snifter. Wet hay, grain, cereal malt (M); earthy hops (L); honey and light DMS aromas. Light gold body. Short, white, fizzy head is quickly diminishing. Moderately sweet, moderately acidic flavor becomes a lightly acidic, moderately bitter finish. Grainy flavor throughout. Medium light body, watery/chalky texture, lively carbonation. The bottom line is: well, it really does taste like a pilsener, just not a good one.

name: Stepan Razin Admiralteyskoe
review: (Bottled) Pale yellow color with a smallish head. Grassy, hoppy, slightly metallic aroma. Slightly sweet honey flavor with hints of metal, and a reasonable amount of malt and hops. Smooth-carbonated, light to medium-bodied palate. Quite nice, but somewhat metallic pilsener.

name: Stepan Razin Studencheskoye
review: Pale yellow. Terrible smell of burning rubber. Thin, metallic taste. Ovewhelming revolting, chemical, gassy aftertaste - artificial rotten eggs?. Definitely one of the worst beers in the world.

name: Stepan Razin Studencheskoye
review: Ah yes, Studencheskoye. The minute the rotten vegetable aroma jumped out of the glass, I knew I was on to something. The palate - like taking a bucket of industrial chemicals, dumping them on a compost heap, then burning the bucket.

name: SR Zenit 1984
review: Deep golden. Dryish with hints of apple and metal. Well hoppped and bitter.

name: SR Zenit 1984
review: This Vienna style is one of the more respectable of St. Petersburg's remarkably bland mainstream beers.

name: Stepan Razin Krepkoe
review: FTA: a decent fortified lager. I was drinking when I was 16 during December 2000 cold frozen starry night. This must be ticked and noted.

name: Stepan Razin Krepkoe
review: This beer is all about sweet and sour malt and alcohol. In every way horrible disgusting! I’d rather drink pure alcohol than this beer!

name: Stepan Razin Krepkoe
review: (br-btl br-lbl, "first Russian brewery 1795) lct-cpr, thin head, med-body, §co2. §dusty §malty §hoppy aroma, malty T1 §dusty T2 warm fruity T3.

name: Stepan Razin Krepkoe
review: I can see why this was $2 now. Clear golden colour, large head that carries a noticeably strong alcohol aroma. Taste is creamy, unbalanced malt character. and a taste that is strong in alcohol also.

name: Southend Bombay Pale Ale
review: Pours copper with an off white head. Smells earthy. Tastes dry and spicy with some floral hints.

name: Southend Bombay Pale Ale
review: Tap - not much head, medium amber color, nice hoppy flavor with decent malt backbone

name: Southend Bombay Pale Ale
review: This was called Castle Pale Ale. It looks like thier APA has nmany different names. The alcohol was slightly higher at 5.5%. Served in pint glass the head was small and dissapoated. I liked the deep copper color. Good bitterness with some light citrus. The finish was smooth with some bitterness. This was downtown Cahrleston in three stories..

name: Southend Bombay Pale Ale
review: Clear and yellow with no head. Faint aroma of nothing worth mentioning. Pretty boring and bland all around. Watery. Not good.

name: Southend Bombay Pale Ale
review: Draft at brewer. By far the best beer here tonight. Pours a copper with a thin white head. Malty/hoppy floral scent and a blanced taste.

name: Southend Bombay Pale Ale
review: Amber with light aromas of wet paint. Palate confirms nose. Light hoppiness and long finish. Too long--wet paint beer is not good.

name: Southend Bombay Pale Ale
review: On tap at Southend Brewpub in Charleston S.C. The aroma contains notes of floral hops and the flavor is extremely floral and fruity without. A little sweet but finishes with a moderate bitterness.

name: Southend Bombay Pale Ale
review: Lasting , minute-bubbled head provides a curtain of lace. Amber color and nearly clear. Good blend of light colored malts and floral hop. The taste is more hoppy than the smell. Bitter aftertaste. A solid pale ale whose only demerit is the thin body.

name: Southend Bombay Pale Ale
review: An.amber pour with a small head. Good mild hop aroma. Light but abundant lacing. Slight burnt walnut character. Pucker mouthfeel. That darned apllejuice bitter sweet backend. Shallow finish

name: Southend Bombay Pale Ale
review: This was the best of the lineup. There was ample head with excellent retention. A very fresh hop aroma. The hops come across with a bit of an orange smell. There is a lingering hop bite, but it’s only moderate at best. Still a standout in this lineup. It was a good pairing with the shrimp and grits on the menu.

name: Southend Carolina Blonde
review: Draught at the brewery. Pours light copper. Smells breaddy. Tastes watery with some floral hints.

name: Southend Carolina Blonde
review: tap. tangy pale malt flavors with a noble-like hop finish. slightly hazy gold color. clean finish with a smooth palate.

name: Southend Carolina Blonde
review: Tap - good size foamy head, light straw color, smooth light malty flavor , refreshing

name: Southend Carolina Blonde
review: Draft at brewer. Pours a deep yellow/gold with no head. Scent is sour and yeasty. Taste is yeast and malt.

name: Southend Carolina Blonde
review: The taste is a little weird and very thin. Definitely drinkable, but not much else.

name: Southend Carolina Blonde
review: On tap at the Charleston brewery. Pours a bright clear yellow with no head. Crisp clean sweet malt taste along with mild hoppiness. A decent American summer lager.

name: Southend Carolina Blonde
review: Light yellow with little aroma. Tastes like those Jelly Belly popcorn flavored beans--not good. Creamy palate. Not terrible, just a little weird overall.

name: Southend Carolina Blonde
review: No head, but there is Belgian lace on the glass. Straw color and nearly clear. Dry, light adjunct smell. This continues in the flavor which is strongly dry. Thin malt flavor and no hop. The aftertaste is odd, beyond my ability to describe. The body is very thin and highly carbonated.

name: Southend Carolina Blonde
review: Tasted at the Southend Brewery & Smokehouse in Charleston SC - pours a golden color with no head. Aroma of grass and wheat - like the light it tasted of corn and SLIGHTLY less of dirty sock. Still not a great beer but not quite as offensive as the light version.

name: Southend Carolina Blonde
review: A darker yellow pour with a small white head. Iron powder aroma. Dirty wood flavor. Tastes like amdro? Mild bite. Can’t even finish the sample.

name: Southend Oktoberfest
review: This was pretty good definitely one of the better tasting oktoberfest’ i’ve had lately.

name: Southend Oktoberfest
review: Crystal clear amber lager with good retention and decent lacing. The nose is of fruit, with notes of cat piss, honey, cinnamon and nutmet. I had a cold, so maybe, just maybe, that wasn't cat piss I smelled. Perfectly balanced flavor. It mirrors the aroma. Medium-bodied with a creamy mouthfeel and mild carbonation. Lengthy, lightly bitter finish.

name: Southend Oktoberfest
review: Draft at the Southend Brewery in Jacksonville. This beer had a small sized off-white head with fine-small sized bubbles that mostly diminished. The body was carbonated and transparent with an orange hue. The nose was hoppy and the flavor of this beer was that of mild-moderate hoppiness. The palate was tingly and a bit dry. This was a medium bodied beer with excellent lacing.

name: Southend Oktoberfest
review: TheDM and Hotstuff vacation brew 46. This draft brew was enjoyed at the brewery in Jacksonville Florida. This brew poured a small head of off-white colored mostly lasting bubbles that left behind a carbonated orange brown colored body and a very nice laceing. The aroma was also a nice one with a good caramel malt presence. The mouthfeel was tingly though it diminished in the finish where the mild hop bite took over. The flavor was nicely malted with a smattering of hops. Overall, it was quite nice and very enjoyable.

name: Southend Oktoberfest
review: Had at the brewpub in Jacksonville. Has a decent, light copper appearance and a sweet, slightly nutty aroma. The head is off-white with good lacing. Solid malty-sweet undertones in the flavor. Overall, a solid brewpub seasonal - noting to write home about.

name: Southend Oktoberfest
review: Dry. A little more orange than their pale ale. Very lightly hopped. No aroma to speak of. Palate thin. Lackluster. Rerate 2003 Grainy lager aroma. Dry, nutty, some notion of mayonnaise. Long woody finish. Decent hopping. An improvement over the 2002 batch.

name: Southend Ironman Wheat
review: Pours yellow with a white head. Smells of light citrus. Tastes of citrus, some grainy wheat.

name: Southend Ironman Wheat
review: Draft at brewer. Pours a cloudy yellow with a thin white head. Scent is sweet honey and wheaty. Taste is wheat.

name: Southend Ironman Wheat
review: A pretty average wheat beer with some hints of spice and orange - nothing special, but not bad either.

name: Southend Ironman Wheat
review: On tap at the charleston brewery. Pours a cloudy orange with no head. Sweet malt aroma; yeasty wheat malt taste. Very refreshing with a slice of orange.

name: Southend Ironman Wheat
review: This is a mild wheat beer--not much nose and light taste. The beer settles to have no head (just some bubbles along the rim). Leaves streaky lace. The color is orange-amber and predictably cloudy. The smell and taste are similar--light wheat background with notes of beery and citric sourness (very mild). The body was true to the style, although the carbonation was on the high side.

name: Southend Ironman Wheat
review: Tasted at the Southend Brewery & Smokehouse in Charleston SC - this brew poured a hazy orangish color - aroma was citrus (they stuck an orange in it so not sure if I smelled the beer or the orange), hops and wheat. Taste of orange, spice and wheat. Average brew.

name: Southend Ironman Wheat
review: This beer was a cloudy gold, but somehow managed to have no head, odd for a wheat beer. Despite having heard of problems with some of the Southend beers from raters who’d been there as recently as a month ago, this is the only beer that showed any signs of off flavors. It tasted like it could be a bit old.

name: Southend Ironman Wheat
review: Hazy straw light white head very smooth and not much clove or banana. Which is to my liking. Crisp finish with a slight medicinal tone.

name: Southend Ironman Wheat
review: Draft. Citrus, but almost no nose on this lighty hazy straw colored beer. Banana and apple flavors. Refreshing, decent enough flavor, but really watery. Seems to be the trend at this place.

name: Southend Ironman Wheat
review: One of the better brews I had at Southend, which seems to be quite the hit-or-miss place when it comes to their brews. I wouldn’t call it a hefeweizen so much as an American Wheat Ale. GLAD that they didn’t serve it with any kind of citrus wedge (I have a particular disdain for that tradition...). Definite hints of apple and other bright fruit in the nose. Goes down smooth and refreshingly. I’d have another.

name: Southend Carolina Light Blonde
review: Draft at brewer. Kinda like the blonder only weaker. A clear straw color. Scent not there. Taste is sweet malt and thin.

name: Southend Carolina Light Blonde
review: Draught at the brewpub. You know it’s gonna be good when the bartender jokingly says "Tell me how close to water we got it" when serving it to me. Pours a very light straw greenish yellow with small white head. The aroma is kind of mildewy with some grain and wet shoes. The flavor is weird graininess, shoes again, and a hint of lemon. Bland, but fair enough for what it is.

name: Southend Carolina Light Blonde
review: The taste is almost stale upfront, but the aftertaste is reminiscent of Coors Light.

name: Southend Carolina Light Blonde
review: Light yellow. Medium yeasty and metallic aroma. Light on palate with a metallic taste and weird creamy finish. Not great.

name: Southend Carolina Light Blonde
review: Not much head, but there was good lace on the glass. Straw color and hazy. The aroma is off; it reminds me of a Sam Adams Cranberry Lambic--like a malty Sweettart. There must be a high percentage of adjuncts in this beer. It tastes grainy with absolutely no hop to the tongue. Lots of carbonation and quite watery. Overall, a definite miss.

name: Southend Carolina Light Blonde
review: Tasted at the Southend Brewery & Smokehouse - pale yellow pour, no head - grassy, wheat aroma - taste of corn and dirty socks. Not a very good beer.

name: Southend Carolina Light Blonde
review: Pours light gold with no head. Clean draw. Musty aroma. Good hoppy bite, kinda an apple taste n the backend. Very musty.

name: Southend Carolina Light Blonde
review: This is by far the palest of the beers offered. The flavor has a light straw malt and a slight citrus note, but this is definitely on the watery side.

name: Southend Carolina Light Blonde
review: Draft. Light yellow, big bubbles. Lemons and a hint of bitterness in the aroma. Refreshing enough finish with nearly no body. A very boring, but not terrible micro-light.

name: Southend Carolina Light Blonde
review: Tap. Sweet orange and malt aroma. Medium yellow with small head. Sweet malt flavor with a light hops finish. A very nice light beer.

name: Watson Brothers Abigails Amber
review: On Tap. At the Cin Airport. Pours out a light amber. Malt and Caramel flaver Great.

name: Watson Brothers Abigails Amber
review: [on tap in Cincinnati airport] Flat, clear amber. Raisin, dark malts, sweet cherries, port, lifesavers candy = aroma. Raisin, fruity toffee = flavour. Significant bitterness. Medium body, low carbonation and a sweet finish. Almost an altbier.

name: Watson Brothers Abigails Amber
review: Light toasted malt nose - really light, amber color, low clingy head. Weak roasted malt body with a sugary sweetness in the middle. Oaky finish, some hop character. Thin and vapid, really, with a quick profile. Not very good.

name: Watson Brothers Abigails Amber
review: It was served by a waiter so it had no head. It was much darker and stronger than would expect from an amber. Nice malt flavor and a good hop finish.

name: Watson Brothers Abigails Amber
review: Draft at Watson Bros. Brewery. Dark amber hue with a medium white head that diminished quickly. Medium aroma of malt and caramel. Medium body with creamy texture. Well balanced flavor of malt and caramel with small bite at finish. Earlier Rating: 5/13/2005 Total Score: 3 Draft in sampler set in Blue Ash. Poured a dark brown with a medium rocky off-white head. Aroma and flavor was a small malt with short sweet finish. Below average for style.

name: Watson Brothers Abigails Amber
review: pours brown with no head. Slight caramel taste, not much after that. bland and undesirable.

name: Watson Brothers Abigails Amber
review: At the Cincinnati airport Watson Brother’s outlet. Roasty with a lightly nutty caramel tone. Tingly on the tongue. Lightly bittered finish.

name: Watson Brothers Abigails Amber
review: Had one of these on tap at Watson Bros Bistro & Brewery last night in Cincy prior to the Tool show. Nose of caramel, toasted malt and flowers. Medium ruddy brown with a creamy mostly diminishing white head and fair lacing. Low acidity, good balance with a medium finish. Medium creamy and smooth soft body with a slightly alcoholic feel to the finish. Very nice if you like 'em a bit on the sweet side.

name: Watson Brothers Abigails Amber
review: I believe this is the beer that is sold at Montgomery Inn in Cincy as Ted's Red. It has a light amber color and a soft hop nose. The flavor begins with a pleasant dose of hops but fades quickly with no real malt presence.

name: Watson Brothers Main Street Pale Ale
review: On Tap. At the Cincinnati airport Watson Brothers. Pours out a nice dark amber. With a nice white head. A very nice Hop to this one. Earlier Rating: 7/7/2006 Total Score: 3.8 On Tap. At the Cincinnati airport Watson Bros’ Pours out a nice dark amber. With a nice white head. A very nice Hop to this one. I was pumped.

name: Watson Brothers Main Street Pale Ale
review: [on tap in Cincinnati airport] Almost clear copper with a thin island and ring of head. Caramel and subtle diacetyl aroma with a touch of US hops. Average american pale ale for flavour: nice pine/citrus with subdued crystal malt and limited fruitiness. Medium to light body with moderate carbonation and a lingering bitterness.

name: Watson Brothers Main Street Pale Ale
review: Hop aroma is the best part of this beer. Unfortunately the rest is not so great. Over the past year the quality of EVERY WB ale has severly suffered. There’s a problem in every beer this brewpub offers. I had a sampler recently and every beer suffers from the same defect. It’s either an infection in dirty beer lines or their yeast is producing a powerful off-flavor: Diacetyl. It’s distinct in this and particularly their Amber. I dislike even writing this because the beer scene in Cincinnati suburbs is POOR at best. I want WB to survive. I hope they are reading these reviews. Recently closed down due to not paying taxes. Not sure if it will re-open or not.

name: Watson Brothers Main Street Pale Ale
review: Pale amber color, low tight head. Toasted malt, off taste that’s slightly veggie-like. Fairly big hop bitter across the whole mouth. Drying effect at the end with a lingering grassiness. Medium-thin body. Not very good, but probably the best one they offer.

name: Watson Brothers Main Street Pale Ale
review: Draft at Watson Bros Bistro. Dark amber color with a medium white head that diminshed slowly. Medium citrus and hop aroma. Medium body. Medium refreshing flavor with average bitter finish. Earlier Rating: 5/13/2005 Total Score: 2.9 Draft in sampler. Medium amber with a medium off-white rocky head. Hoppy aroma with a medium flavor with a light bitter finish. Average for style.

name: Watson Brothers Main Street Pale Ale
review: Pours weak brown, average hop taste at the start, followed by that Watson Bros famous buttery aftertaste

name: Watson Brothers Main Street Pale Ale
review: At the Cincinnati airport Watson Bros’ outlet. True amber with a light foam head. Puckering citric start and it stays with you. Decent hoppy ale for a Cincinnati layover.

name: Watson Brothers Main Street Pale Ale
review: Consumed at the Cincinnati airport on tap. What luck I thought in finding a Brew pub in the airport. This was a sad mistake. Red amber color with no head. Aroma is just a little skanky, sort of like Juliette Lewis. Thin bodied. Harsh hop bitterness. No balance. No good.

name: Watson Brothers Main Street Pale Ale
review: Light brown. Hoppy aroma. Very bitter almost unbalanced, but still drinkable. It kind of keeps me wanting more. Mildly hopped and pretty good.

name: Watson Brothers Main Street Pale Ale
review: Big thick head, good bitter bite. Nice finish – very refreshing.

name: Watson Brothers Tobys New Zealand Dark
review: On Tap. At the Cincinnati Watson Bros Pours out a nice dark brow almost a black.. With a nice tan head. Aroma of sweet and coffee. ok

name: Watson Brothers Tobys New Zealand Dark
review: Light toast-like nose, dark clear brown, low tight head. Roasted malt, tobacco, coffee-like bitter end that’s woody at times. Thin and unbalanced. Just roasted flavors with no body to support it or hop character either. Disappointing.

name: Watson Brothers Tobys New Zealand Dark
review: I’m surprised that this is a porter! I would rate it as a dunkel. LIght, roasted grain flavor with a slight chocolate overtone. No head (it was served by a waiter, they have a tendency to fill the pint glass to the rim at the expense of the head). It was flat. It had a nice hop finish. I wouldn’t go back for another one.

name: Watson Brothers Tobys New Zealand Dark
review: Draft at Watson Bros. under the same name. Dark brown with medium dark head. Aroma medium sweet with chocolat and roasted malt. Flavor same with coffee tone and medium finish. Medium body. Good brew but more like a English Strong Ale.

name: Watson Brothers Tobys New Zealand Dark
review: A little thin but the taste is not affected. Good robust flavor, strong coffee bean tones.

name: Watson Brothers Tobys New Zealand Dark
review: Tasted at the Barrelhouse Brewing Company Microbrew Fest on November 9. I was not very impressed with this beer, as it really didn''t come across as a Porter to me when I tried it. The beer poured a dark but bubbly clear brown. Roasted malty aroma and it actually tasted kind of like a Dunkel with a sweet malt finish. I think it needs to pack more punch.

name: Watson Brothers Tobys New Zealand Dark
review: Had one of these on tap at the Watson Bros Bistro & Brewery in Cincy Saturday night prior to the Tool show. Nose of chocolate, caramel, and a hint of coffee.
