Other than that, something definitely went wrong with this beer. It isn’t good at all and probably the worst of the Barrel House bottle offerings!

Sample(s) from 22 fl. oz. bottles (Alcohol 6.2% by Volume) shared at the September 2007 Jundale Beerklub Tasting. Thanks! Rating #29 for this beer.

name: Barrel House Oktoberfest
review: Bomber. Pours a pretty, dark golden/amber color with a small but well retained white head. Smell is sweet, toasty, malty, normal vienna/marzen aroma. Pleasant aroma, almost Great Lakes-esque. Taste is light, smooth, clean, slightly - very slightly sweet, pretty dry for the style. Highly drinkable. Don’t understand the low scores on this one. Granted it’s not fantastic or anything but it’s certainly a decent if not good example of the style.

name: Barrel House Oktoberfest
review: Pours dark amber with a nice cream colored head. Aroma is bready malt with a little caramel. Starts out somewhat sweet and bready, balanced well by the tartness from the hops. I think it’s a pretty good representation of an Oktoberfest, they must have addressed the sour/infection issue from last years batch as noted in previous ratings.

name: Barrel House Oktoberfest
review: Pours a dark amber in color. Only a slight frothy head forms on the pour. It quickly recedes to nothing. Smell is all malts. There are a good amoun of hops in the taste. Also some good toffee and spice as well. Decent mouthfeel and very easy drinking.

name: Barrel House Oktoberfest
review: I found this one quite enjoyable and am surprised by the recent negative reviews. I enjoy this style, and this one was a bit unique because it had a bit more hops, at least in some mouthfuls. The color was deep orange, aroma of molasses and cinammon. Apples in the palate along with graham crackers. Occasional hoppiness. This had wonderful complexity for an Okt.

name: Barrel House Oktoberfest
review: Date: 02/24/2008 Mode: Bottle Source: Tasting, Cellar Party Appearance: clear dark amber, wispy beige head, drippy Aroma: sweet bready malt aroma, Flavor: tart malt flavor, lots of earthy bitterness, Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 4/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 7/20 Rating: 2.2/5.0 Drinkability: 4/10 Score: */4

name: Barrel House Oktoberfest
review: Hazy amber body with a tiny white head. The nose is vienna, caramel, grapes and metal. The flavor is fairly dry, lightly tart and metallic with golden raisins and caramel. Medium/light body is a bit thin with light carbonation.

name: Barrel House Oktoberfest
review: Pours a transparent copper amber with a thin, wispy-lacing off-white head. Aroma of lightly sweet toasty earthy caramel malts and with a touch of noble hops and light fruity tartness. Body starts lightly sweet with a lot of unexpected citric tartness before a drier grainy earthy acidity. This is a bad infection issues going on here.

name: Barrel House Oktoberfest
review: Bottle courtesy of alexsdad06. Pours caramel copper with a white head. Smells of caramel, roses, biscuits, some sugary hints. Tastes like candy with a tarte finish.

name: Barrel House Oktoberfest
review: Bottle, slightly cloudy copper with an off-white head. Light corn, bread and light herbal hops in the nose. Flavor starts with some caramel/bread then a tart, somewhat sour yeasty flavor with some grassy/hay at the end. It’s lightly sour but not in an infected type of way. Thin, watery body with lively carbonation.

name: Barrel House Honeysuckle Blond
review: Draft at Beer Sellar in KY. Poured a straw amber color with a medium creamy white head that lasted. Soft citurs hoppy aroma. Light to medium body with soft carbonation. Light sweet hoppy flavor with a short smooth finish. Drinkable light brew.

name: Barrel House Honeysuckle Blond
review: Bland, boring and thin. Light gold color not enough hops!..................

name: Barrel House Honeysuckle Blond
review: Rerate 2/27/06: On draught at Barley’s Ale House #1. Clear golden color with a thin white head. Minimal lacing. Light hops and sweet honey aroma. The body is light and crisp with subtle malt and honey flavors. Touches of hops here and there too. The finish is clean and short. I can appreciate this beer a little more now, having had more exposure to the style, but it’s still pretty average. 11/13/02 (2.4)Tasted at the Barrelhouse Brewing Company Microbrew Fest on November 9. Light gold color with a thin head. Mild hops aroma. Really not much going on here, this is definitely a beer for the macro drinker who wants to support a local brewpub.

name: Barrel House Honeysuckle Blond
review: this beer is pretty good. deffinatly an easy drinker. the honey flavor is subltle and not overpowering.

name: Barrel House Honeysuckle Blond
review: Pretty average and meant for the macro drinker (this is what my dad drank while we were there). Very smooth with a hint of honey. Not a bad beer by any means, just on the boring side.

name: Barrel House Hocking Hills Hefeweizen
review: Pours mostly clear gold yellow with fuzzy white head. Tastes pretty thin, semi sweet grain, soft on the wheat. The is some apple and pear and light banana. There is a light spice in the finish. Alright but very light.

name: Barrel House Hocking Hills Hefeweizen
review: This was courtesy of Strykzone. Poured a hazy golden color with a fat white head that faded quickly and left decent lacing. .Nose is clove and banana Medium body and a smooth mouthfeel. Flavor is very pronounced, more than many hefes with again banana and clove. Very nice for its type.

name: Barrel House Hocking Hills Hefeweizen
review: Bomber from Network liquor in Roseville. Pour is golden orange with a soapy white head. Aroma is sour apples and fruit. Taste again more sour apples and fruit along with some malt and yeast. Palate is slick and fizzy with a sticky dry finish. I found thish quite enjoyable and would drink again!

name: Barrel House Hocking Hills Hefeweizen
review: Hazy amber with a thin white head. Aroma is very bready with the standard clove and banana with a hint of apricot. Taste is lemon right off the top with toasted bready malt and fruit behind it. Mild hints of clove and plenty of yeast on the finish. Goes down easy enough.

name: Barrel House Hocking Hills Hefeweizen
review: Bottle with many thanks to Phaleslu! Hazy straw, pours a very fizzy and quick lived white head, that leaves just a thin ring. Nose of clove, candy, some banana, bubblegum. Tastes immediately of sweet banana, cloves, thrills gum, peach. Medium bodied, a bit thin on the finish. Very sweet bubblegum aftertaste. Good. Thanke Peter!

name: Barrel House Hocking Hills Hefeweizen
review: 22 oz. bottle. One of our few local beers that I am finally getting around to rating. Pours a hazy yellow color with a larger fluffy white head. The nose is pretty standard wheat with a mild clove and a slight touch of banana and splashes of yeast. The flavor is much of the same; wheat, cloves, yeast, and banana. Medium bodied and smooth. A decent offering and the price was right.

name: Barrel House Hocking Hills Hefeweizen
review: Draft sample at a Barrel House tasting at Teller’s of Hyde Park. Pours a hazy mustard tan color, almost like a grapefruit juice without any reddish tint. Aroma of banana, clove, bread, wheat, vanilla, and a little apple and citrus. Flavor follows suit really well- fruity, bready, and mildly spiced. Medium-full bodied and smooth, with a bready mouthfeel. Very nice hefe.

name: Barrel House Hocking Hills Hefeweizen
review: Bottle. Pours an apple juice body with a wispy bubbly head that diminishes to nothing with haste. Paper, apple, citric aroma. Dusty banana and clove with a lingering apple and bread y finish. Decent at best.

name: Barrel House Hocking Hills Hefeweizen
review: A lightly hazed gold pour with creamy off white head and lace. Rotten banana peel aroma mixed with bread dough. A yeasty, fruitiness, with a bready after taste. Carbonation was just over the top for me. Drinkable but not special.

name: Barrel House Hocking Hills Hefeweizen
review: Sampled at Beerhawk’s Beer Gods in the Boro, aka 1000 Bottles of Beer on the Wall, By God Beer God Gathering, BG1K Tasting. Hazy mustard pour. Lemon zest, a little tartness. Some musty spicy pepper in the aroma. Moderate carbonation. Pretty good as far as hefes go.

name: Barrel House SternWheeler Stout
review: From the Barrelhouse Brewpub on East 12th street - Yeah, this is an old review of a mefiocre sweet stout, but I used to get growlers of the stuff from the pub.

name: Barrel House SternWheeler Stout
review: Nice one. This is my first experience and I like it. Nice aroma, it forces us to drink.

name: Barrel House SternWheeler Stout
review: Had this one on tap at the Barrelhouse as usual. It is a very good stout with all those lovely chocolate and coffee overtones in both the aroma and the flavor. The appearance is that of pitch with a slight head. The finish is nice without all the burnt lingerings of so many other stouts.

name: Barrel House SternWheeler Stout
review: On tap at Barrel House. Poured with a deep cocoa body, topped by a medium tan head. Fruit, caramel, and a touch of roast make up the aroma. Flavor is much in the same vein, with dry roasted malt, caramel, and somewhat sweet dark fruit. Very creamy, smooth palate. A solid, rich stout.

name: Barrel House SternWheeler Stout
review: Draft - Medium coffe and chocolate aroma. Black color with large tan frothy head. Medium coffee, roasted malt and touch of chocolate.

name: Barrel House SternWheeler Stout
review: Draft - very nice! Black as night with a light brown head of tiny, tiny bubbles. Very roasty, chocolatey nose. Big, rich, roasty flavor with loads of coffee.

name: Barrel House SternWheeler Stout
review: Opaque black color, no head. Roasted coffee, bittersweet chocolate, and sour lactose aroma. Sweet, sour and roasty with chocolate, lactose, smoked wood, and slightly vanilla flavors. Medium thick feel.

name: Barrel House SternWheeler Stout
review: Deep black color (opaque) with no head. The aroma was very strong with roasted coffee beans, slight smoked wood, slight black licorice, dark chocolate. The flavor was quite sweet with a prominant roasty character...coffee, chocolate, slight lactic sourness in the finish. Slightly watery feel...not thin though...with a semi-dry finish.

name: Barrel House SternWheeler Stout
review: thanks to hopsrus for this one's. It's a very easy drinking stout. Nice chocolate taste. very enjoyable

name: Barrel House SternWheeler Stout
review: Excellent stout. So smooth that it seems like a hybrid sweet stout and Irish dry stout. Rick, the brewer, does a fine job with all the B.H. beers and this one is no exception. Rich, coffee and chocolate flavors are evident. Just the right amount of bitterness. Very warming, firm and enjoyable.

name: Barrel House RedLegg Ale
review: 22oz bottle (another forgotten bottle. Poured a copper color with a larger sized head. I should have opened this when I got it v. forgot it ...

name: Barrel House RedLegg Ale
review: Bottle at Sander’s place, NYC. Ah, WTF! This beer is rancid, basically. Pours dark ruby with a big, off-white foam head. Tart fruits and toasty malts in the nose. Extremely sour flavor. In fact, if this was a lambic it wouldn’t be half bad. As it is, I’m concerned. Medium in body with big carbonation. Lasting pucker sour finish. Bummer, mostly.

name: Barrel House RedLegg Ale
review: It poured a copper color with a small white head. The aroma was of sweet malt and citrus. The taste was nutty with hints of butter, fruit, nuts and dough.

name: Barrel House RedLegg Ale
review: Red caramel pour with a rather foamy tan head. Aroma was caramel malt, some hops, a little spicy. Taste was a little sour apple with hops atr the end. It was ok.

name: Barrel House RedLegg Ale
review: 22. ounce bottle. Pour is copper with big frothy soapy head that dissipates to film on top. Aroma is sour red apples and malt. Taste is more sweet red apples and spice and malt. Palate is sticky and chaulky that finishes dry. I really enjoyed this one, has some nice characteristics.

name: Barrel House RedLegg Ale
review: The head on this beer can almost be described as nuclear. It jumps up from the pour. Light tan in color it is long lasting and quite fizzy. A pleasant aroma is sweet malt and complex fruit. The beer itself is clear and a soft copper color. Flavor offers gentle fruit notes, light cinnamon, and some grapefruit underneath. As the beer warms some dark fruit and chocolate develop. Things get a bit muddled here and nothing really works well together. Decent, though.

name: Barrel House RedLegg Ale
review: On Tap at "The Pub at Crestview Hills" on a trip to Northern KY - Pours a transparent copper amber with a thin, off-white head. Aroma of resiny grapefruity hops and some grainy malt. Body is somewhat thinner and grainy with a touch of toasted malt and earthy hops. Not a bad beer to eat some bar food with.

name: Barrel House RedLegg Ale
review: Bottle bonus thanks to phaleslu! Hazy apricot pour, little carbonation and a little citrus. Flavor is malt and sour apple and tasted slightly oxidied. Glad I got to try it, but will probably try to get another bottle along the way as I think this one has turned from the original flavor intended.

name: Barrel House RedLegg Ale
review: A nice red-copper color with a white head. Bright fruits, malty, a bit of roast, and some caramel in the aroma. Flavor is fruity and sour. Not much in the way of hops but full of caramel malts. Some lemon and cherry as well. I’m not a fan.

name: Barrel House RedLegg Ale
review: Overall pretty boring for a red. Not much flavor. Simple caramel malts with a touch of odd spice and rotten grain and old hops.

name: Barrel House Flying Pig Pilsner
review: Several glasses on tap at the Cincinnati Blues Fest, Summer 2005. This is quite clean overall with a real fresh, slighly herbal and definitely sweet aroma, but not corny at all. Some bitterness -- actually I thought this was quite good. Sweetness came on a bit stronger later but nowhere near sticky.

name: Barrel House Flying Pig Pilsner
review: Tap. Golden color with small white head. Low aroma of hops. Flavor and finish was medium of bitter hops. Drinkable bar brew.

name: Barrel House Flying Pig Pilsner
review: Another nice beer from B.H. This pilsner has a nice hoppy background but is light and refreshing.

name: Barrel House Flying Pig Pilsner
review: Better than average pils, slight wheaty aftertaste..........................

name: Barrel House Flying Pig Pilsner
review: Tasted at the Barrelhouse Brewing Company Microbrew Fest on November 9. Golden color with a thin head but decent lacing. Mildly hoppy aroma. This wasn''t so great but it was not skunky or flavorless like many Pilseners. Unfortunately it was pretty boring either way.

name: Barrel House Strawberry Blond
review: I was a little worred about this one cause i've had some bad experiences with fruit beer in the past, but I decided to try it anyway. Poured golden and cloudy with a slight pinkish hue. aroma was of fresh strawberries and the flavor was of the same with the essence of a blond ale. The thing that i liked the most about this beer is that the fruit is not overpowering or artificaial tasting. a very refreshing beer for a hot cincinnati day.

name: Barrel House Duveneck Dortmunder
review: briny aroma, like a can of black olives, with some citrus and caramel. old bottle? i agree it smells kinda belgian or something. taste is a bit sour, bright, some caramel and toast. medium body, lively carbonation. this is pretty weird but not bad.

name: Barrel House Duveneck Dortmunder
review: Poured from a bomber into a footed pilsner. Appearance is a translucent yellow with an enormous white head. Several inches of foam produced from a small amount of liquid. Aroma is sweet and grainy. Reminds me a lot of duvel in the aroma. Taste is sweet, fruity, grainy, and a touch of alcohol. This beer rocks.

name: Barrel House Duveneck Dortmunder
review: 22 oz Bottle -- Pours reddish-orange with a foamy off-white head. Smells more like a belgian than a dortmunder. Aromas of biscuits, malt, fig, raisins, sweet potato, brown sugar, and yeast. Sweet throughout the palate.

name: Barrel House Duveneck Dortmunder
review: Tap. Semi-hazy orange pour with a foamy white head. Aroma and taste of malt and biscuits. Just okay - nothing great.

name: Barrel House Duveneck Dortmunder
review: When this beer is virtually 100% off white head. Very slowly the foam drops and liquid appears. That beer is clear golden and is well carbonated. Some solids in the final pour. Aroma is malt, fruit, biscuit, and alcohol (even tho ABV is listed as 4.5%). Flavor is malt dominated with fruit, biscuit, and rye. Flavor warmed nicely and it became a pretty good beer. It started a bit rocky, but ended well.

name: Barrel House Duveneck Dortmunder
review: Bottle bonus thanks to phaleslu! Straw yellow poor, ongoing carbonation and an aroma of squash?? Flavor is better than the aroma, some white pepper, sugar, a little hops and finished vegetal on the aftertaste. Probably wouldn’t buy this one.

name: Barrel House Duveneck Dortmunder
review: I’m not sure what to do with this, smells like a triple? why is that? this can’t be a dortmunder. I saw other people saying they thought their bottles were old, i think mine was mixed up. Not sure, it’s good but not what i was expecting.

name: Barrel House Duveneck Dortmunder
review: I had this from a bottle. It could have been old. The color was very pale with a brown-yellow tint. Minimal carbonation. There were some honey flavors, but over all it was stale, however, did not taste skunked. This did not come close to a dortmunder style.

name: Barrel House Duveneck Dortmunder
review: 22 oz. bottle (notes). Pours a clear golden color with a larger off white head. The aroma is mildly sweet biscuity malt with a hint of lemon citrus and mild hop spiciness. The flavor is more biscuity malt with a touch of honey sweetness. Toward the finish the lemon citrus gets a touch sour which is strange. Slight hints of toasted bread come out. Light-medium bodied with a slightly dry finish.

name: Barrel House Duveneck Dortmunder
review: Draft sample at a Barrel House tasting at Teller’s of Hyde Park. Pours clear gold with a medium white head. Aroma of German hops, malts, straw, and honey. Flavor of honey, straw, hops, malts, grass, and spices. Light bodied, sharp, and crisp. Dry finish. Very nice Dortmunder.

name: Barrel House HardCore Hard Cider
review: i like it, it has a very good flavor, when i drink cider this is always the one i go for first

name: Barrel House HardCore Hard Cider
review: kind of like a dessert beer, goes well with ice cream oddly.................

name: Barrel House Belgian Winter Ale
review: Bottle from Phalesu. Thanks! Pours a deep walnut brown with a dissipating beige head. Aroma of fruity esters and dark Belgian malts. Medium bodied with somewhat soft carbonation, but a little thin in the middle. Flavor of mild chocolate, unripe berries, spice, and plums. Just a hint of acidity. Some phenols on the finish along with some yeast. Has somewhat of a homebrew quality to it.

name: Barrel House Belgian Winter Ale
review: Bottle sample at a Barrel House dinner at Teller’s of Hyde Park. Pours a dark, almost opaque ruby-brown color with a medium tan head. Aroma of berries, dried fruits, caramel, molasses, sweet grains, sweet malts, and biscuit. The flavor is sweet and tart, with notes of berries, caramel, molasses, sweet roasted malts, figs, biscuit, winter spices, and bread. Medium bodied, with a syrupy, oily, and chewy mouthfee. The tartness is not overpowering, and adds an unexpected element for the style. Some of the spices and milder flavors are overshadowed on the nose by the berries and sweeter elements, but these all come out more clearly on the palate. Alcohol becomes just a bit apparent as it warms. Really nice winter beer.

name: Barrel House Belgian Winter Ale
review: Draft. Brown color with a frothy head. Aroma has some spice and grain and some faint fruit. Flavor has plums, spice and yeast with some sweet and tart taste.

name: Barrel House Belgian Winter Ale
review: [2364-20090801] Bottle. Old chlorine characteristics hidden in the aroma. Dark brown body with a quick bubbly light tan head. Sweet tough malt flavour has a heavy ’tart’ finish and mild notes of fruit throughout. Full body. Drinkable, good. (w/ others @ BCTC; Cooperstown, NY)

name: Barrel House Belgian Winter Ale
review: 2009-08-01. Dark brown body with a good foamy beige head that fades. (3+) Mild aroma, light fruit and malt. (6+) Flavour is similar, tart fruit over malt, touch old? Sharp tart fruit in the finish. (6+) Average palate is lightly carbonated. Bottle at BCTC 2009, shared by DuctTape

name: Barrel House Belgian Winter Ale
review: Dark brown body with mahogany edges with some light and a light yellowish khaki head. The aroma has some perfume with sweet notes of pear and Belgian funk. There is also bubblegum and a little hint of melted plastic. The taste has some old leather and tart apples. There is also some paper and plastic hints. A heavy body, but smooth feeling. There is definitely something wrong here with the tart character. Too salty.

name: Barrel House Belgian Winter Ale
review: In the bomber bottle from Beertopia. At $3.49 a bottle, how can you go wrong for a 8.5% beer? The beer pours black with a purple highlight. The head, if agitated to do so, can produce a fine dark beige thick topping of limited durability. The initial aroma is a bit raisin-like, slightly vinous, but not large. The flavor occurs quick with roasted and raisin abbey ale features, but the beer then quickly release an unbalanced alcohol burn. <ild chalky finish that does not leave anything lingering but a slight tobacco essence. Again, good for the price, bad for the style.

name: Barrel House Belgian Winter Ale
review: i had a winter ale last night that was rated a 2.8. it was a thousand times better than this piece of shit. pours deep burgundy with some yeast opacity. 1/4 inch of mustard brown head. smells of alcohol and rotten apples. malty but unappealing. the flavor is thin and watery but pretty close to a shitty bock. slightly malty, slightly nutty, mostly shitty. nothing interesting about this bomb.

name: Barrel House Belgian Winter Ale
review: Dark brown with a quickly disappating head. Moderate carbonation. Malty nose with some raisons. Flavor is unique. Crystal and special b malt initially, possibly some candi sugar, a tart almost acidic flavor as well. A dry finish. Unique brew, kind of like a lesser version of rodenbach grand cru. Not too bad

name: Barrel House Belgian Winter Ale
review: This is well carbonated as a reasonably soft pour easily produces almost a four-finger thick, amber tinged, tan colored head in my 25cl tulip glass. The beer is an opaque, concentrated red-amber color as it sits on the table, but shows a clear, cranberry-red color when held up to the light. The aroma is sweet and fruity up front with a kick of toasty malt towards the finish. Aromatic notes evocative of caramelized fruit (prunes, raisins and even a touch of tart tamarind), toffee, a touch of rum-like character (light molasses perhaps) are found up front but seem to not have much staying power. When digging around for a bit some dry, malt driven character is noticeable with touches of toasted crackers, biscuit malt, and a crushed grain character are noticeable. The aroma is fairly appetizing, but somehow does note have a lot of presence after the initial surge of sweet grain / fermentation aromatics. Lightly sweet and definitely a bit tart in the finish; it is not so tart that this is necessarily attributable to an infection, instead it is quite light and certainly pleasant. Fairly light bodied & along with the light body is a bit nicer than suggested by the somewhat sweet aromatic intimations. A toasty malt backbone gets a hint of roastiness to it at times, but mostly reminds me of lightly toasted whole grain bread, and whole grain crackers. Since the sweetness is soft here the fruit flavors are not quite as prominent as suggested in the aroma; this causes the tamarind notes to play a slightly bigger role, but the raisin notes are still pretty noticeable. A nice prickly carbonation couples quite well with the soft mouthfeel & residual body to make this a chewy, yet easy drinking beer; the mix is just about perfect for a Belgian-Dubbel inspired beer. A pretty good beer, the flavor and aroma are nice, but the texture is just about perfect for a beer of this inclination. I do like the dimension that the light tartness adds to this brew, it adds a much needed complexity as I think this beer would be much to shallow without it.

name: Barrel House Vandermeers 00 Strong Ale
review: On tap at Barrel House. Poured deep red-brown, topped by a thin off-white head. Initially, the flavor was quite hoppy (pine) with candy-like sweet malts. Dark fruit, toast, caramel, and a woody aspect developed as I sipped. Rather tart. Needs more character, however. Also, this seemed to be more of an English Strong Ale, not a Belgian Strong Ale.

name: Barrel House Vandermeers 00 Strong Ale
review: rating this from memory, had it a few months back. reminded me alot of a barley wine. very strong and very flavourful. strong malt and hop presence.

name: Barrel House Vandermeers 00 Strong Ale
review: Thick with a nice dark amber appearance. Good strong flavor................

name: Barrel House Vandermeers 00 Strong Ale
review: Tasted at the Barrelhouse Brewing Company Microbrew Fest on November 9. Dark amber color and a potpourri aroma. Strong and complex flavor of raisins and hops. This beer was interesting to the end of my 3oz cup.

name: Barrel House Nut Brown Ale
review: A fine "beginner's" brown ale, I tend to think this brew is underhopped and light on body. Still, it is an enjoyable beer, and I wouldn't hesitate recommending it to friends.

name: Barrel House Helles Bock
review: Draft at Comet with Shigadeyo. Pours a translucent amber with a small off white head. Faint malty aroma. Medium carbonation. Nice toasted malt and bready malt base countered by spicy european hops, which provide a pleasant bite. I agree with Shigadeyo, that it had some mellow whisky or perhaps a mild boozy like charcter to it. Nice beer.

name: Barrel House Helles Bock
review: 3/06/2007 at The Comet with illinismitty... Bright, clear, light copper/honey color with a small, foamy beige head. Malt and light fruit to in the aroma. Substantial, but not overpowering malt flavor (slightly toasty) with hints of fruit and a whisky-like character. Supposedly the alcohol content approaches 8% for this beer, but one can’t tell since it’s so well hidden. Smooth on the palate, medium body. This is another impressive Barrel House offering and a really nice and enjoyable session bock beer! 16 oz draught.

name: Barrel House Helles Bock
review: Hazy golden pour with frothy head has a slight nose of straw, sweet caramel, and maple syrup. Palate is very nice with a creamy heft to it. Flavor is rich and deep with a caramel stickiness that is rounded nicely by a hop back. Easy to hoist a few, but a mature character as well.

name: Barrel House Helles Bock
review: On draft in Columbus near OSU campus. Gold, thin head, good lacing, low carbonation. Fruity nose, doughy palate, hoppy finish. Okay, I prefer the german bocks I guess.

name: Barrel House Helles Bock
review: Draft at Beer Sellar in KY. Poured a clear deep dark amber with a moderate frothy head that diminished slowly. Average caramel malt aroma. Medium body. Balanced caramel malt and small hop flavor with a smooth solid finish. Solid drinkable brew.

name: Barrel House Helles Bock
review: Caramelly taste and aroma with a slight musty aroma. Slight hop bite on the flavor and the finish. Pretty good bock.

name: Barrel House Doppelbock
review: Rating #7 for this beer. . . . . . . . . . . 3/12/2008: Barrel House Doppelbock looks very dark chocolate brown in color with ruby tones. It has an ample tan-colored head that lasts the entire time and leaves some lacing on the glass. The rich, deeply caramelized aroma is inviting. There is roasted malt in the front of the flavor alont with some slight coffee. The caramelized maltiness gives way to a dry and roasty finish. This beer has a medium to medium-bull body. Overall this beer is robust and quite good. Pint (draught) at Dilly Deli in Mariemont, Ohio. Rating: 7/4/7/3/13=3.7 . . . . . . . . . . 3/07/2009: The quality of Barrel House beer has definitely taken a hit lately. The Barrel House Helles bock that I had was at least a full point worse than it was previously. In addition, I was terribly disappointed with this beer as it didn’t even taste any better than the Hudepohl Bock. The alcohol content might haven a slightly higher, but other than that, the deep brown caramel color, dense beige head, bready malty flavor, and smooth creamy body were nearly identical. Barrel House Doppelbock seemed to have a slightly more chocolate-like flavor, but that’s really about it. It’s really hard to support a local brewery when they are brewing sub-par beer! Draught (pint) at Bockfest Hall during Bockfest 2009 in Over-the-Rhine, Cincinnati, Ohio. Rating: 5/3/5/3/11=2.7

name: Barrel House Doppelbock
review: Draft. Aroma: Toasty/bready with some nice caramel. Very light fruitiness (grapes) as it warms. Appearance: Dark brown in color with small ruby highlights. Off-white head was full and foamy with good retention. Fair lacing. Flavor: Nice maltiness with notes of bread, caramel, and light nuttiness. Some grapey fruitiness. Finishes fairly clean. Palate: Mouthfeel doesn’t feel as full as it should. Moderate carbonation. Light alcohol warming in back of mouth. Overall: This was pretty good. Light mouthfeel and a lack of flavor depth would be my only complaints.

name: Barrel House Doppelbock
review: Draft: Dark brown colored pour with light brown head. Sweet, caramely, malty aroma. Roasted malts, slightly sweet finish. Not bad.

name: Barrel House Doppelbock
review: Draft in growler from Party Town, KY. Poured dark reddish brown with a moderate light brown frothy head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Good caramel toasted tart fruit aroma. Medium body with a sticky texture. Good well balanced roasted bittersweet flavor with a moderate smooth balanced finish of moderate to long duration. Good doppelbock.

name: Barrel House Doppelbock
review: Draft from Fries Cafe. Retired? A thick dark malt body only makes this light caramel, wheat bready concochtion better. Not to bad.

name: Barrel House Doppelbock
review: Yes, this one is nice. Rich and high octane. They've brewed a variety of bock beers at Barrel House for the annual BockFest in Cincinnati. The alcohol laws in Ohio are making Barrel House's beers even more flavorful than before.

name: Barrel House Doppelbock
review: Only got one sip off a buddies glass. So I reserve the right to re-rate at a later date. They don't have this on tap for very long.

name: Barrel House Broadway Commons Cream Ale
review: Light and slight cigar after taste (or is that from the smokey bar?) A little too light tasting but better than typical American standard taste.

name: Barrel House Broadway Commons Cream Ale
review: Tasted at the Barrelhouse Brewing Company Microbrew Fest on November 9. Clear gold color with almost no head. This was a really sweet and creamy beer with a light clean finish. Not bad for lighter fare.

name: Barrel House Broadway Commons Cream Ale
review: Very good & tasty! Good red beer with a distinct full & creamy taste! Excellent with beef or pork! very good wth Barbeque! No heaviness or negative after taste! a real keeper!

name: Barrel House Powderhorn Porter
review: I like this one! Since I live in Cin. city, it's very easy to get down to the Barrelhouse brewpub to get some of this dark, full-flavored brew (although I find it just an iota lacking in body)... and easy access to the Barrelhouse is a good thing!

name: Barrel House Powderhorn Porter
review: I enjoye this porter. It is everything I expect from a porter and more. Rich, malty flavors. Slightly dry but slightly sweet. Very good effort on a better than average porter.

name: Barrel House Powderhorn Porter
review: Excellent beer. If you like porters, don't miss this one...................

name: Bend High Desert Hefeweizen
review: Pour is a clear gold with a large white head. Aroma is some wheat malt I guess. Pretty bland. Flavor is more on the bland side as well. Some wheat malt and pretty favor-less after that. This is more American wheat the a hefeweizen all day long.

name: Bend High Desert Hefeweizen
review: On Tap at the brewery. flicked the orange slice off immediately. Light hazy golden body with a skin of white head. Yet another wheat ale parading as a hefeweizen, Tried to capture the weizen characteristics, but they were so muted it didn’t make a difference. Kind of bland

name: Bend High Desert Hefeweizen
review: Had on tap at brew pub in Bend. Looks like pee in a doctor?s office cup.Dry metal aftertaste.Didn?t taste like much.

name: Bend High Desert Hefeweizen
review: Nose malt and a little honey. Fizzy palate, not much to taste. A drinkable session ale but nothing special.

name: Bend High Desert Hefeweizen
review: Draft at the brewery. Malty, doughy, sweet malts. The mouth feel is light. Light hop character. Nothing wrong with this beer, it is just a little bland.

name: Bend High Desert Hefeweizen
review: Draught at the Bend Brewing Co, Bend, OR. Hazy golden colour with a small white head. Weak citrusy aroma. Mild bitterness, rubber, mild yeast and mild citrus in the flavour.

name: Bend High Desert Hefeweizen
review: On tap at Bend. Pours a clear yellow color with a medium white head. A big fruity lemon nose. Sweet toast, lemons, zesty, light pepper. Light and clean.

name: Bend High Desert Hefeweizen
review: Meh. Really not impresses with this one. The giant lemon wedge was all you could smell. when removed, it was a very boring wheat beer. Squeezing in the lemon juice actually made it more interesting. That’s not good.

name: Bend High Desert Hefeweizen
review: Draft at Bend Brewing Co with Taylor. Pours piss yellow no head. Aroma is musky wheat hay. Taste is sticky light wheat, old socks.

name: Bend High Desert Hefeweizen
review: Hazygolden with a big white head. Grainy wheat aroma. Nice malty taste. Very good hefe. Satisfying. Great first bend beer.

name: Bend Metolius Golden Ale
review: Draft at brewery. Light golden body, hazy and milky, small ring of white head. Grainy aroma and taste, light and palateable. not too much here, but its a golden, so wasn’t expecting too much.

name: Bend Metolius Golden Ale
review: Had on tap at brew pub in Bend. Golden, cloudy. Not much smell. Easy to drink, not strong.

name: Bend Metolius Golden Ale
review: On draft at Bend Brewing. Nose is sweet malt and slight must. Flavor is thin, resembling a lager, but the palate is thick and less fizzy than would be expected.

name: Bend Metolius Golden Ale
review: Draft at the brewery. The aroma is subtle, the malts are all I can detect. The flavor is bready, there is a soft sweet maltiness. Very little hop character. Beer is clean.

name: Bend Metolius Golden Ale
review: Draught at the Bend Brewing Co, Bend, OR. Clear golden colour with small white head. A weak aroma of sweet malt. Mild hoppy flavour with some fruity notes. Unimaginative.

name: Bend Metolius Golden Ale
review: On tap at the brewery. Pours a clear copper orange color with a small white head. A light grainy nose. Smooth, biscuit, oranges. Dry earthy finish.

name: Bend Metolius Golden Ale
review: "It has a lot of hop flavor and aroma without being excessively bitter." Ummmm, no. I can’t see this as a pale ale, as it even underhopped and really boring...for a blonde/golden. Not understanding the hype I’d heard about this place. Color by numbers beers at best.

name: Bend Metolius Golden Ale
review: Draft at Bend Brewing Co with Taylor. Pours golden mustard, no head. Aroma is light pilsner malt, sweet citrus notes, hint if hops. Taste is grainy, hay, soft earthy bitterness, bready.

name: Bend Metolius Golden Ale
review: Golden like apple juice with no head. A little spicy and a little apple juice sweet aroma. Mild malt and bitterness with a little sweetness. Medium body.

name: Bend Metolius Golden Ale
review: Draught at the Bend Brewery Co. brewpub in Bend, OR. Very light grassy aroma. Pretty clear medium straw color. Mild sweet maltiness / a little bit buttery in mid (diacetyl?) / finish is smooth and minimally flavored. Thin body. Not bad, but not very inspired either.

name: Bend Elk Lake IPA
review: I try to drink a new beer at least once a week, I had to search a bit to find this beer but it was worth searching!

name: Bend Elk Lake IPA
review: Draft at brewery. Malts make themselves known in the aroma and taste, more so than usual for the style. Hops carry the back end through to a long lingering bitter finish. Hazy medium amber with small head. Not your typical big hoppy NW IPA.

name: Bend Elk Lake IPA
review: Draft Third of a Pint at GBBF 2011 (Day 1), Earl’s Court, London Aug 2011 - Hazy Copper Gold in colour. Hoppy; piney and grassy hops. Fruity; grapefruit citrus. and pineapple. Malty; biscuity malts, caramel. Nice hop/fruit/malt balance. Not extreme. Easy drinking for an IPA. (2011-08-02)

name: Bend Elk Lake IPA
review: Had on tap at brew pub in Bend. Golden orange color. Smells like strong orange. Tastes okay, aftertaste is strong. Almost liked it until the aftertaste got stronger & stronger.

name: Bend Elk Lake IPA
review: Nose is citrus, grapefruit. Light and sweet. Flavor is much more straightforward, hops all the way.

name: Bend Elk Lake IPA
review: Had on draft at the brewery. The aroma is citrusy, grapefruit rind, pine, hints of soap in the background. The flavor is grassy, pine, citrusy, balancing Bready malt character.

name: Bend Elk Lake IPA
review: Draught at the Bend Brewing Co, Bend, OR. Clear deep golden colour with a small white head. Sweet fruity hops, mild bitterness, resin and sweet malt in the aroma. The flavour is sweet fruity hops, moderate bitterness and sweet malt. A bit too sweet. Rich.

name: Bend Elk Lake IPA
review: On tap at the brewery. Pours a clear yellow color with a medium white head. A nise citrus nose. The flavor is big citrus, oranges, toffee. Very light and clean. Good.

name: Bend Elk Lake IPA
review: Hoppy grapefruit aroma. Clear orange with a rich lasting head. Grapefruit dominates all the way through along with a bitterness that doesn’t linger. Very crisp ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Bend Elk Lake IPA
review: a good complex hop profile stands this one out from most of their beers, which are more boring than not. Adequately bitter and flavorful. Not too shabby...

name: Bend Outback Old Ale
review: Had on tap at brew pub in Bend.Red like Anke.Bitter aftertaste (unexpected for red beer).

name: Bend Outback Old Ale
review: Nose is malt, must, and raisins. Flavor is virtually all malt, with a little hop character shining through.

name: Bend Outback Old Ale
review: On tap at the brewery’s brewpub in Bend. Look: clear dark copper body, nearly opaque, with a very good beige head and lots of sticky lacing. Aroma Dark roasted grain smells with a trace of sweet toffee. Flavor: Mild; lightly sweet. Mildy bitter.

name: Bend Outback Old Ale
review: Tap at the brewery. A: Dark red bordering on brow. Thin off-white head. N: Caramel, peppercorn, herbs, toffee, raisin, booze soaked cherry, marshmallow, burnt brown sugar. T: Quite bitter and sweet in proportion. M: Medium body, light burn, prickly carbonation. O: A nice old ale. Packed with flavor at a low ABV - I just wished it didn’t have so much roast/burn.

name: Bend Outback Old Ale
review: Had on draft at the brewery. This is a malty beer. Grainy, dry finish, light fruit notes.

name: Bend Outback Old Ale
review: Draught at the Bend Brewing Co, Bend, OR. Clear amber colour with a tiny off-white head. Mild sweet malt and mild hops (no bitterness) in the aroma. Sweet malt, mild bitterness... and all the things I don’t fancy in a red ale.

name: Bend Outback Old Ale
review: On tap at the brewery. Pours a clear reddish color with a small white head. A light toffee nose. The flavor is very light, caramel, pine. Soft. Ok. Unusual old ale.

name: Bend Outback Old Ale
review: as a stock ale this would be ok, but it’s just way too light in body and flavor for an old ale. Comes across as a nothing WRONG but ultimately very boring malty ale...and I like old ales quite a bit. This is an old ale lite.

name: Bend Outback Old Ale
review: Draft at Bend Brewing Co with Taylor. Pours amber with lacing. Aroma is hint of old caramel. Taste is amber malt, old caramel, astringent, hint of nut. Finish is amber caramel.

name: Bend Outback Old Ale
review: Nice dark and nutty ale, smooth, drinkable, nice example of the style. Worth exploring for the adventurous.t Resampled in Bend in 2017. Still holds up the original rating. Nice texture and feel.

name: Bend Pinnacle Porter
review: Extremely malt forward roasted, coffee and chocolate nose. Palate is superb, but slightly fizzier than expected for a dark porter.

name: Bend Pinnacle Porter
review: Had on tap at brew pub in Bend. Very dark brown but not black. Smells like coffee. Fairly thick. Tastes strong but very little aftertaste. Good for camping.

name: Blind Tiger County Seat Wheat
review: Draft at the source. Clear yellow color, white head. Aroma of lemon and light banana. Taste is mostly citrus. OK.

name: Blind Tiger County Seat Wheat
review: One of my least favorite staples at Blind Tiger. Watery and mild. A small amount of grass hops.

name: Blind Tiger County Seat Wheat
review: Tap at brewpub. Wheat malt, fresh lemon juice, floral hops. Palate is thin and slightly oily Finish is dry and slightly bitter with lemon and green apple notes. Not bad.

name: Blind Tiger County Seat Wheat
review: Tap @ Blind Tiger. Pours a clear light yellow appearance with a white head. Somewhat herbal, fairly dry wheat malty, vanilla aroma. Easy drinking, slightly grainy, light lemon, sweet malty flavor. Decent wheat.

name: Blind Tiger County Seat Wheat
review: Sampler on tap at Blind Tiger in Topeka. Pours a golden color with white head. Similar to Raw Wheat, but I enjoy Raw Wheat more.

name: Blind Tiger County Seat Wheat
review: Pours a lightly hazy golden with a medium creamy white head. Aroma of lemon, wheat and other cereal grains. Flavor of lemon, some cereal grain. Really dry although to the point of being watery. Claims a higher hop profile, but not high enough!

name: Blind Tiger County Seat Wheat
review: Pours hazy pale yellow with white head. Soft aroma of musty wheat grain. Rough wheat malt taste with a decent sweetness and a mild lightly spiced grainy finish. Not great, slightly better than most American macro brews.

name: Blind Tiger County Seat Wheat
review: On tap at the brewpub. Comes pale gold with a small white head. Mild aroma of wheat and citrus. Taste is wheat, citrus, and some sweet malt. Decent wheat beer.

name: Blind Tiger County Seat Wheat
review: On tap at the brewpub in August 2009. Reviewed from notes. Pours a very lift straw color with minimal head and no much lacig. Nose brngs grain tannins and hints of diacetyl. Taste brings a bunch of buttered popcorn and hints of dry grain. Feel is light with a good amount of carbonation. Drinkability is quite poor. Serving type: on-tap Reviewed on: 10-15-2010

name: Blind Tiger County Seat Wheat
review: Medium oily-looking amber-gold, smallish lasting head...grainy, lightly sour nose with hints of fruit...refreshing tart, crisp flavor profile, hints of toasty malt underneath and a touch of smokiness late...light-moderate body, tiny swirls of tart apple in nose and flavor as it warms...not bad at all

name: Blind Tiger Holy Grail Pale Ale
review: Draft at the source. Clear golden yellow color, white head, solid lacing. Aroma of herbal summer fruit. Taste is bittersweet apples, lemon, peach. Nice.

name: Blind Tiger Holy Grail Pale Ale
review: On tap. Off white-gold. A-soft pine, light malt. T-pine hops, sweet light malt.

name: Blind Tiger Holy Grail Pale Ale
review: A middling pale ale. Light a grassy with limited carbonation. Bready malts are mild.

name: Blind Tiger Holy Grail Pale Ale
review: 16oz on tap. Copper color, clear. Zilch on the aroma. I suspect that the keg or is old or something, because I definitely don’t taste the complexity that others are getting. In fact, it was a little bitter and nasty. It wasn’t fizzy, though. I’d like to try it again.

name: Blind Tiger Holy Grail Pale Ale
review: Sampler on tap at Blind Tiger in Topeka. Pours a copper color with white head. Earthy, hoppy, grassy flavors. Solid brewpub pale ale.

name: Blind Tiger Holy Grail Pale Ale
review: Pours a translucent golden amber with a creamy white lacing head. Aroma of citrus and piney hops with a touch of caramel malt. Flavor of tea, caramel, pine, mixed citrus and floral notes.

name: Blind Tiger Holy Grail Pale Ale
review: Pours golden with white foam. The smell is light caramely with a light hop presence. The taste us light and crisp, very nice. A nice fairly full flavored grain is complimented by soft herbal and orange citrus hops. well balanced and enjoyable.

name: Blind Tiger Holy Grail Pale Ale
review: Bottle 12fl.oz. Clear medium amber yellow colour with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, caramel, butter. Flavour is moderate sweet and light to moderate bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20120523]

name: Blind Tiger Holy Grail Pale Ale
review: Bottle at yespr. Cloudy orange coloured with a small white head. Sweet aroma of caramel, butterscotch and licorice with notes of spices. Sweet flavour of caramel and licorice with notes of hops and grapefruits. Dry hoppy finish.

name: Blind Tiger Holy Grail Pale Ale
review: Bottled. A hazy amber beer with a thin beige head. The aroma has notes of hops, caramel, and alcohol. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt, butter, straw, and caramel, leading to a stinging finish. Thanks pinball for sharing.

name: Blind Tiger Amber
review: Malty and light. Caramel sweetness. Mild grassy hops lend it a bit of balance. Tried for the first time back in 2009.

name: Blind Tiger Amber
review: On tap at the brewpub. Comes amber with a small beige head. Aroma of malt, citrus, and caramel. Taste is similar. Easy to drink, but nothing memorable.

name: Blind Tiger Amber
review: Pours a mostly translucent deep amber with a smaller creamy off white head. Aroma of nutty Munich malt, caramalr and light citrusy hop notes. Flavor of the same Munich malt however the hop profile comes through a bit more in the flavor profile. Mostly citrusy and lightly spicy hop notes.

name: Blind Tiger Amber
review: On tap at the brewpub in August 2009. Reviewed from notes. Pours a moderately deep amber color with an off white head and a good number of lace rings. Nose brings slightly sweet and toasted bred and a bit of earthy hops. Taste and feel come together to present a somewhat dry beer with moderate sweetness comic from caramel and toast. Drinks fairly well and is one of the better beers that we had at this location. Serving type: on-tap Reviewed on: 10-15-2010

name: Blind Tiger Amber
review: Draft at the brewpub. Pours an amber body with a white head. Malty nutty body with a light chewy salty fruit tone. Nerds and willy wonka candy sweetness. Bit of a mess.

name: Blind Tiger Amber
review: Date: February 24, 2009 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: clear amber, wispy off white head, bits of lace Aroma: light aroma Flavor: sweet malt flavor. touch of caramel sweetness, light earthyness Overall: not much character good or bad Aroma: 3/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 3/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 6/20 Rating: 1.8/5.0 Drinkability: 6/10 Score: 4

name: Blind Tiger Amber
review: Taster on tap at the brewpub. Pour is clear caramel brown and ruby. Not much of an off-white head. Aroma of biscuit malt and hazelnuts. Taste is nicely sweet and nutty, good full flavor with a lighter drinkable palate. Some nice lingering roastiness in the finish. Nice amber.

name: Blind Tiger Amber
review: On tap at brewpub. Light amber color, slight smell of chocolate, this was a very good beer.

name: Blind Tiger Amber
review: On tap at the brew pub. Amber orange with a smallish white head. Smells like butter and raspberries. Tastes buttery sweet and fruity. Medium body. Average carbonation. Sweet finish. Dull.

name: Blind Tiger Amber
review: Pours a clear copper with a ring of off-white bubbles clinging to the edge of the glass when it reached my table. The nose is caramel malt and faint fruity hops. Medium-bodied and grainy with a dry metallic finish. Roasted caramel malts with a fruity hop backing, concluding with a dry metallic note. I’m not sure if I’m just a glutton for punishment or I’m just hoping to find a diamond-in-the-rough, but almost all of the ambers that I’ve tried (with the exception of a few) finish off like I’m sucking on a penny. I just keep trying them, hoping the next one will be "the one" that helps me understand why so many brewers and brewpubs make this style.

name: Blind Tiger Tiger Paw Porter
review: Draft at the source. Dark maroon color, see pic please. Aroma of plums and roasty brown bread. Taste is sweet fruity plums. Nice.

name: Blind Tiger Tiger Paw Porter
review: On tap. Lt brown-dk brown. A-roasty/coffee/chocolate-dk malt, lactose. T-follows with some earthy hops.

name: Blind Tiger Tiger Paw Porter
review: A middling porter. Watery, thin on the palate. Has a nice roastiness, but this can’t compare to the java.

name: Blind Tiger Tiger Paw Porter
review: On tap at the brewpub. Pours a clear dark brown with a hint of amber and a light brown head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has roasted malts and dark grains with a touch of must. Flavor has a combination of dark grains and roasted malts.

name: Blind Tiger Tiger Paw Porter
review: Tap @ Blind Tiger. Pours a dark brown appearance with a tan head. Anise, dark chocolate, vanilla aroma. Fairly roasty malty, coffee, dark chocolate, anise, a touch smoky flavor. Ok.

name: Blind Tiger Tiger Paw Porter
review: Pours brown mahogany with off white head. The smell is light with some roasted grain. A lush medium chocolate malt covers most all the flavors with a moderate roast and semi sweet semi dry grainy palate.

name: Blind Tiger Tiger Paw Porter
review: Tap - small khaki colored foamy head, dark brown color, roasted malt aroma and flavor with mild coffee flavors, and a fair amount of chocolate flavor, especially as the beer warms up

name: Blind Tiger Tiger Paw Porter
review: On tap at brewery. Dark brown with a fizzy tan head. Roasted grain and coffee syrup aroma and taste with a sharp finish.

name: Blind Tiger Tiger Paw Porter
review: On tap at the brewpub. Comes dark brown with a tiny biege head. Aroma of roasted malt and chocolate. Taste is roast, chocolate, dark fruit, and molasses. Decent enough.

name: Blind Tiger Tiger Paw Porter
review: Creamy tan head on a deep brown body. Somewhat subdued aroma of roasted beans and dark chocolate. The body more than makes up for the soft aroma with heavy notes of smoke, tobacco, nut and chocolate. Smooth mouthfeel with a great nutty/sweet finish. Solid porter all around

name: Blind Tiger Hefe-Weizen
review: On tap at Blind Tiger. Pours a hazy dark gold with a small white head. Aroma is wheat, yeast, banana, and spices. Taste is sweet and malty. Very good

name: Blind Tiger Hefe-Weizen
review: Sampled at the 2009 Parkville microbrew festival. Pours a dark cloudy gold with a thick white head. Really robust. Very German smelling banana aroma. Intense and true hefe flavor. Great!

name: Blind Tiger Hefe-Weizen
review: Sample at the 2009 Parkville Microbrew Fest. Pour is a very cloudy yellow golden with a smallish white head. Aroma of big bubblegum, also quite sweet. Fruit strip gum, more or less. Behind the bright yeast is some decent wheat malt graininess, though it certainly in the far back seat. Taste is more of the bubble gum sweetness, along with some banana fruit and the wheat. Palate was medium to light, smooth and pretty drinkable. Overall, the over the top Hefe yeastiness of this was a bit too much for me, tone that down and there would be a pretty nice beer here.

name: Blind Tiger Raspberry Wheat
review: Draft at the source. Clear pale yellow color. Aroma of mixed forest berries. Taste is light tart berry. Easy drinking.

name: Blind Tiger Raspberry Wheat
review: This is a better beer than the ratings would indicate. Raspberry is subtle and tasty. Slightly tart.

name: Blind Tiger Raspberry Wheat
review: Tap @ Black Tiger. Pours a fairly clear yellow appearance with with a thin white head. Funky artificial berry, honey, floral aroma. Dull berry, sweet malty, wheat, a bit grainy flavor. Bleh.

name: Blind Tiger Raspberry Wheat
review: Pours a lightly hazy golden with a medium bubbly white head that laced. Aroma of fresh raspberries and Cheerios. Flavor of fresh raspberries, lemons and Cheerios.

name: Blind Tiger Raspberry Wheat
review: Sampler at the brewpub. Comes a cloudy pale yellow with a small white head. Aroma of raspberries only. Taste is raspberries with just a bit of malt and wheat. OK.

name: Blind Tiger Raspberry Wheat
review: On tap at the brewpub in August 2009. Reviewed from notes. Pours a very light blonde color with a thin white head. No hint of the raspberry in the color. Nose brings forward a bit of artificial raspberry along with a very hefty dose of diacetyl. Smells like buttered popcorn with raspberry snow cone syrup poured on it. Taste brings even more butter topped with some raspberry candy. Feel is light with a buttery creaminess and some thankful carbonation to wash the taste away. Drinkability is really, really poor. I don’t know what went wrong here but it was just a buttery mess; either way, it was at the brewpub so I have to fault them, wherever the problem may lie. Serving type: on-tap Reviewed on: 10-15-2010

name: Blind Tiger Raspberry Wheat
review: A wonderfully aromatic beer from what is becoming a favorite brewer. Pours a light crimson, translucent, looks somewhat dull. Aroma of ripe raspberries, very striking, reminds me of a raspberry lambic, however this doesn’t translate well in the flavor, somewhat flat raspberries are almost non-existant in the flavor, however has a crisp clean aftertaste

name: Blind Tiger Raspberry Wheat
review: Draft at the brewpub. Pours a pale golden body with a white head. Raz, mild berries, light citrus and lemon. Nice aroma, but not a beer drinkers beer.

name: Blind Tiger Raspberry Wheat
review: Date: February 24, 2009 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: hazy gold, scant head Aroma: sweet and tart raspberry aroma Flavor: sweet fruity flavor, raspberry kicks in first with a fruity sweetness before a short lived tartness appears to be replace back with the sweetness, clean finish Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 9/20 Rating: 2.5/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: *4

name: Blind Tiger Raspberry Wheat
review: Probably the third best beer on tap during my visit on 9/3/07, and for a raspberry wheat, that’s usually saying something. Pours a clear light yellow and was served with zero head. The aroma features a nice subtle raspberry with a wheat backing. Unlike many fruit beers, especially raspberry, this one lacks the soapy extract aroma that many exhibit. Light to medium-bodied, slick and clean, this beer highlights nicely balanced raspberry and wheat malt notes. It could probably use a bit more carbonation, but otherwise it’s pretty darn good. I’m not sure if the brewmaster has changed the recipe or if I just hit a better batch, but I thought this one was quite a bit better than many of my predecessor’s ratings would indicate.

name: Blind Tiger Prairie Dog Brown
review: Poured from a growler purchased on 12/14/2012 and enjoyed the next day. Poured a clear dark brown with some red highlights and a huge beige head. Aroma is sweet biscuit, caramel, toffee. Taste is bready sweet with caramel, toffee, and grains. Very good brown ale.

name: Blind Tiger Prairie Dog Brown
review: Pours a brown color with a huge tan head and almost a gushing bottle. Aroma of toffee and other lighter malts. Astringent malty flavor includes some chocolate and possibly some sweet hazelnut or vanilla. Light palate and very overcarbonated

name: Blind Tiger Prairie Dog Brown
review: On tap at the brewpub. Comes amber brown with a nice biege head. Aroma of malt, caramel, and dark fruit. Taste is malt, yeast, dark fruit, and a bit of cocoa. Enjoyable.

name: Blind Tiger Prairie Dog Brown
review: A great session brown ale. Nice chocolate aroma, that follows through into the flavor, with just a bit of raosty coffee acidity, and mild bit of dark fruitiness.

name: Blind Tiger Prairie Dog Brown
review: Ruby tinted dark brown. Sweetish caramel aroma and flavor. Hints of chocolate. Dry finish.

name: Blind Tiger Prairie Dog Brown
review: cask-conditioned: Hazy purplish ruby. Loose, foamy bubbles. Soft bed of fruity esters yield notes of blackberry and dried plums. Faintly malty and oxidized with dabs of unsweetened chocolate, cane sugar, yeast, and bushy/tangy hops. Loose carbonation. Slippery body. Twang of leather of plums merge with a brushing burst of earthy hops and underlying cocoa grit. Quickly loses body as it breathes. Light acidity accompanies bready malt textures, which bolster the body. Slightly sweet and yeasty finish with notes of pie crust, dried plums, and smoke. Could use more Crystal and hop coraseness to firm-up the slippery body and soggy maltiness, along with more pale malts to highlight the caramel/chocolate flavors. The nose could also stand to be a tad less unclean/yeasty. For a quick pint, though, this’ll do the trick.

name: Blind Tiger Prairie Dog Brown
review: On tap GABF '02: Light grain aroma, amber/orange color with a decent head. Watery mouthfeel and a short sweet aftertaste.

name: Blind Tiger Statehouse Stout
review: An okay stout and not as strong as their angry man. Lots of roastiness and some chocolate. Not as slick on the tongue as I wanted.

name: Blind Tiger Statehouse Stout
review: On tap at the brewpub. Comes a very dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma of malt and coffee. Taste is roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, and lactose. Very enjoyable.

name: Blind Tiger Statehouse Stout
review: Pours a deep brown, almost black, with ruby highlights and a thin, creamy, light tan head. The nose is of muted roasted malt. Medium-bodied and creamy/oily, the mouthfeel is quite nice. Roasted and chocolate malt with a light lactose-like note and a nice clean finish. This is a pretty tasty stout that I wouldn’t hesitate to order again.

name: Blind Tiger Statehouse Stout
review: On tap at the brewpub. Dark black, but not opaque. Very light brown head. I get oats, cream, and coffee in the aroma. Robust roasted coffe with some oats, and OLIVES? Medium body. Oil slick. Low carbonation. Semisweet finish. Very robust and easy to drink.

name: Blind Tiger Statehouse Stout
review: Black as night and by sight it looks thin; indeed, it’s very light-bodied with little flavor ... perhaps some light smoke, burnt malt. Most disappointing here.

name: Blind Tiger Statehouse Stout
review: cask conditioned, dry-hopped: Dark brown. Puffy mocha head with pasty lacework. Huge aroma of citric hops dusted with roasted malt. Caramel, moist prunes, soggy teabag, and cocoa whispers. Soft, silky, and chewy. Spicy orange rind assertions combine with a dried plum explosion and their tasty house character to momentarily muffle the malt richness. Leafy hop aspects reside beneath as sappy hop elements creep through to reinforce the beautifully-full body. Minerals and leathery deepen its undeniably unique character. Chalk and burnt cocoa notions add a drying effect to the decadent finish of tar, fudge, caramel, and mocha. Absolutely sublime rendition. Cask version reigns superior by far. (8,4,9,5,17) draft: Relentless, creamy, sticky, rich gray head. Mineral, roasted barley, and toasted cracker aroma. Mild hop fruitiness complements the hints of raisin, caramel, and chocolate cake. Creamy, fluffy body. Medium-bodied. Rich caramel flavors greet the subtle roastiness, which silences most of the acidity. Dried plums come through and balance some of the roastiness. Fluffy blend of caramel and chocolate. Firm mineral notes deter much of the flavorsome malts. Vague airiness retrieves some of the piny hop flavors. Prolonged finish of milk chocolate, cane sugar, cocoa, custard, and burnt malts. Overalll, a bit too acidic, but the rich malt abundance was superb. And thankfully, the nitro didn’t flaw the mouthfeel. Not bad at all. (7,3,7,4,13)

name: Blind Tiger Statehouse Stout
review: Deep brown with a creamy soft nitro brown head. Smell is a slightly creamy and sweet milk aroma... thick mouth feel with a little grit. Flavor is a heavy chocolate malt with oddly some cannibus and irish creme. Quite nice.

name: Blind Tiger Blarney Irish Red
review: Draft at the source. Clear amber color, see pic please. Aroma of lightly toasted caramel. Taste is sweet toffee and caramel. Decent.

name: Blind Tiger Blarney Irish Red
review: Pours a lightly hazy reddish amber with a medium creamy off White head. Aroma of caramel, nuts and toffee. Flavor of nuts, caramel and toffee:

name: Blind Tiger Blarney Irish Red
review: ruby. And an off-white head. Aroma and flavors of caramel and toast. Mostly, or should I say all, malt in this one. Must be an Irish red. Medium bodied.

name: Blind Tiger Blarney Irish Red
review: Sampler at the brewpub. Comes a dark clear amber with an average biege head. Aroma of malt, fruit and candy. Tastes of malt and fruit. Mild bitterness. Enjoyable.

name: Blind Tiger Blarney Irish Red
review: On tap at the brewpub. The body was dark copper with a khaki head. The aroma was sweet caramel apples. The taste was mild toffee with some Golden Delicious apples. There was a nice dry finish to complement the smooth carbonation.

name: Blind Tiger Blarney Irish Red
review: On Tap: It looked quite good. A ring of off whit ehead around the outsides above a mahogany, reddish, brown beer with a touch of carbonation. Aroma of sweet malts and nuttiness along with some hints of banana and fruitiness.

name: Blind Tiger Russian Imperial Stout
review: Pours a deep brown color with off white head. Chocolatey malty aroma. Big chewy chocolate flavor. Notes: on tap at the brewery, Spring break ‘18

name: Blind Tiger Russian Imperial Stout
review: Lovely imperial! Semi soft mouthfeel w/ an outstanding aroma! The body is smooth & the typical bitterness & chewiness you find in an imperial isn’t there but it’s oh so drinkable! Very nice!

name: Blind Tiger Russian Imperial Stout
review: On tap at the brewpub. Comes black with a decent tan head. Aroma of malt, chocolate, and coffee. Taste is roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, caramel, and a bit of molasses. Decent RIS.

name: Blind Tiger Russian Imperial Stout
review: Tap at brewpub. Deep black with a slight red hue when held to the light. Slight mocha cream head with a little lacing. Nose is molasses, maybe a hint of coffee. Taste is sweetened coffee, nutty notes, cocoa, maybe a hint of black licorice. Palate is a little thin. Finishes sweet and slightly bitter with cocoa notes.

name: Blind Tiger Russian Imperial Stout
review: Pours a deep almost black with a small bubbly tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, dark chocolate, molasses, toffee and caramel. Flavor of caramel, roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, vanilla and nuts.

name: Blind Tiger Russian Imperial Stout
review: The best of a flight of beers recently sampled at the brewery. Dark, tons of licorice and coffee. Thin head.

name: Blind Tiger Russian Imperial Stout
review: On tap 12/14/2012. This beer is black and opaque with a light brown head. Aroma is malty, dark chocolate, coffee, and a little booze. Taste is malty with coffee and dark bitter chocolate. Very good.

name: Blind Tiger Russian Imperial Stout
review: Growler shared thanks to Set. Black with medium body. Nice taste of coffee and roast. The lower ABV (9%) and sweetness, though, sets it off as not exactly a RIS. Good.

name: Blind Tiger Russian Imperial Stout
review: On tap at brewpub deep black color when poured Aroma begins surprisingly faint, with a touch of molasses . Flavor has a hint of syrup no lingering aftertaste mouthful was pleasent. Overall a beer I can drink on everydat basis.

name: Blind Tiger Russian Imperial Stout
review: This was not what I was expecting or hoping for, and despite the fact that I think this batch is "off", it was still interesting from the standpoint of flavor combinations. Served in a standard shaker, it pours jet black with a thin, creamy, tan head that reduces to a still, oily surface. The aroma is very different from any impy stout that I’ve ever tried: dark chocolate covered strawberries, plums, and faint alcohol blend into a fruity combination. No roast, no coffee. Medium to full-bodied with fine, lightly prickly carbonation coming through the oily texture. It finishes with a lightly dry woodiness. The flavor is of bright, fresh plums and dark, bittersweet chocolate with a fruity/tart, dry, almost woody finish and just a touch of roast at the end. After the first few sips, however, something undeniable and quite bold began to take hold of and dominate the flavor profile: green apple. What a shame. I think that this beer certainly has potential to be great, and from what others have written, other batches have been. I guess I’ll have to wait until next year to find out if I’m right.

name: Blind Tiger Maibock
review: Draf. Golden pour, very fruity yeasty maibock, but pretty traditional and pretty drinkable, nice smooth malt, spice.

name: Blind Tiger Maibock
review: Sampled at GABF 2015. In the tasting glass it was golden yellow. Small white head. Nose of caramel malts and some spice. Medium in body. The flavor is light mats and and finishes with some bite. Good drinking.

name: Blind Tiger Maibock
review: Sampled at gabf. Clear honey gold. Floral and honey flavors. Maltiness is soft. Very gentle fruit. Ok.

name: Blind Tiger Maibock
review: Draft at GTMW 2015. Clear golden yellow color, fluffy white head. Nice aroma of freshly cut haystacks doused with black pepper. Taste is fresh hay and peppery straw. Better than some of the maibocks I had in Germany last May.

name: Blind Tiger Maibock
review: First time out. It’s a heavy beer that doesn’t look like a heavy beer or taste like one.

name: Blind Tiger Maibock
review: A very nice maibock. Honey, fruit, citrus, and nice bready malt backbone. Crisp finish.

name: Blind Tiger Maibock
review: Clear medium yellow orange colour with virtually no head. Aroma is moderate malty, fruity, sugary, grass, malt, light caramel. Flavour is moderate to light light heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration, grass, sugary, light fruity. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is flat, finish feel is light alcoholic. [20131111]

name: Blind Tiger Maibock
review: Dark yellow with a small white head. Aroma of malt, grain, light citrusly hops. Flavor is malt, grain, sugar, little hoppy, alcohol. Medium body, soft carbonation, some alcohol in the finish. 111113

name: Blind Tiger Maibock
review: Frothy white fair mostly deminishing head. Yellow colour. Light malty and hoppy aroma. Moderate bitter flavor. Long moderate bitter nice complex finish. Maybe a little more ABV than 6.3? Oily palate.

name: Blind Tiger Maibock
review: Clear golden with a small white head. Aroma is sweet, malty and light hoppy - citrus. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and moderate bitter finish with a little warming alcohol. 111113

name: Bloomington Freestone Blonde Ale
review: Clear golden with a white head. Mild grainy pale malt aroma. Medium/light body. Semi dry flavor is bready pale malt grist, with a nicely bitter finish.

name: Bloomington Freestone Blonde Ale
review: I sampled BBC Freestone Blonde Ale on draft at Yogi’s in Bloomington. I was very dissapointed with this beer. No head, no aroma and very watery taste. The only positive is that this is brewed in Bloomington. Go Hoosiers!

name: Bloomington Freestone Blonde Ale
review: Pours golden, no head. Honey and apple sweetness. Little aroma. Tingley aftertaste. Light moderate mouth feel.

name: Bloomington Freestone Blonde Ale
review: Draught at the brewpub. Hardly any aroma, perhaps a touch of lemon cleaner. Clear golden pour, no head. Citric, lightly sour with bg grain notes, not very robust. No real hopping, light-medium body, and on the whole, another boring rendition of a boring style. [2.2] Re-rate over three years later. Bright yellow golden pour, clear, with a small cream-colored head. Sweet nose with light fruitiness and some lemon cleaner and faint yeast. Taste is moderately dry. Cleansing and refreshing despite the weak sauce, it’s plainness isn’t exactly calling me back for a third rate.... [2.7]

name: Bloomington Freestone Blonde Ale
review: Clear straw body, white head. Aroma is mild, medium sweet, light grassy, biscuit. Taste is medium sweet, grassy, light biscuit, mild/medium bitterness. Watery light body. Nice for what it is -- has legit bitterness, hopefully it can help the college kids move past the macros.

name: Bloomington Freestone Blonde Ale
review: The aroma smelled kind of woody. The body was a medium amber color. The palate was smooth and the flavor was slightly bitter.

name: Bloomington Freestone Blonde Ale
review: Dirty yellow hue with some head and lace. Faint aroma of standard hops and malts, nothing else. Smooth but so is water, bland and boring. Thin-bodied with a watery and fizzy mouthfeel. I'll pass on this, if given the chance.

name: Bloomington Freestone Blonde Ale
review: Poured no head and there was no lacing. There was no carbonation observed. It had a sweet aroma to it. It had a bitter taste and an aftertaste that lingered. This brew was watery and thin. I compared it as an American mass-produced beer; however, it was just bit better than a Bud.

name: Bloomington Freestone Blonde Ale
review: This brew poured a weak transparent yellow orange colored body with a very small head of fine white bubbles. IT has a mild malt-hop aroma and a smooth slightly fizzy bitter start with a lingering hop finish. It also had a weak watery mouth feel to it.

name: Bloomington Freestone Blonde Ale
review: This one is fairly light in flavor, and not as hoppy as other BBC offerings, though still a nice beer with dinner at their pub.

name: Bloomington Ruby Bloom Amber Ale
review: On tap at The Brick in South Bend. Pours very red. Flavor is very rich and smooth with a bit of creaminess. Very full bodied well rounded malt flavor - mostly fruity in character with some bready notes. Hopping is just enough to brighten up the finish. Very well crafted beer that I feel is being seriously underrated due to its style.

name: Bloomington Ruby Bloom Amber Ale
review: bottle. decent amber ale shared with 2 others. very mild beer overall, but good

name: Bloomington Ruby Bloom Amber Ale
review: Reddish/Brown Hue, lively carbonated with a sweet aroma on the nose. This was from a keg not bottle. Starts out with the caramel malt and munich malt as the main players in this beer. smooth taste follows with a slightly bitter finish that lingers until the next sip, Good Amber Ale overall, something I would go back to every now and then.

name: Bloomington Ruby Bloom Amber Ale
review: A decent amber. Malty and pretty well balanced. Pours darker red, smooth mouthfeel and a caramel body. Tried with Matt and Guy in 2016.

name: Bloomington Ruby Bloom Amber Ale
review: The problem is that the quality is massively variable in this beer. Sometimes it’s completely flat, sometimes it’s overly carbonated. Sometimes it’s a deep thick red, and sometimes it’s a light clear one. If you get a good batch, it’s amazing, but you really only have a 50/50 chance of that.

name: Bloomington Ruby Bloom Amber Ale
review: Aroma is malty, taste is mellow, malt, very light, not that crisp of a finish.

name: Bloomington Ruby Bloom Amber Ale
review: bottle @ Whitey’s / Lawrenceburg IN --- (btld 04/16/15) Clear rich brown color, off-white head that drops to a thin cover, hanging strands of lace. Taste is caramel malt that is mildly carbonated, then adds light hops in a medium length finish. The malt has a natural, full-bodied taste and chewy texture. Awfully dark for an Amber Ale, but also polite, inoffensive, and enjoyable.

name: Bloomington Ruby Bloom Amber Ale
review: Sampler pours amber with a off white head. Aroma of malts, grain and dried fruit. Taste is malty and yeast.

name: Bloomington Ruby Bloom Amber Ale
review: Tap...dark garnet pour with a fruity nose. Caramel malt body with ripe dark fruit. Finishes quite clean and somewhat dry. Pretty good.

name: Bloomington Ruby Bloom Amber Ale
review: Old notes - on tap at a restaurant while visiting Bloomington in May, 2014. Amber pour with a small khaki head. Light nuttiness in the aroma, doughy, some caramel and toffee, a little earthy. Plain flavor, I wouldn’t say offensive, some doughy notes, caramel, mild nuttiness. Not bad.

name: Bloomington Big Stone Stout
review: Sampler pours black with a brown head. Aroma of chocolate, grains, wood and a hint of burnt malts. Taste is coffee, chocolate and smoky.

name: Bloomington Big Stone Stout
review: Aroma of smoke, taste is smokey, lots of bitter coffee, woody, pretty different from what I am used to. Needs more balance.

name: Bloomington Big Stone Stout
review: A good basic stout not that great of head. Dark malty. Light smoke. More bitter than the creamy chocolate flavor I crave. Good thickness ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Bloomington Big Stone Stout
review: on tap-brown-black. A-roasty/anise/tobacco/chicory-dk malt. T-roasty/cocoa/anise/tobacco/chicory-dk malt, 2nd earthy hops.

name: Bloomington Big Stone Stout
review: Sampled at the Brewpub. It poured a dark brown color with a small tan head. The aroma was of smoked malts, some chocolate, hops and a touch of coffee. The taste was similar with a chocolate overtone with some bitterness and coffee hints. Good stuff.

name: Bloomington Big Stone Stout
review: Draft to taster at Lennies. Looks good; a dark cola with foamy tan head. Smells of dark malt, bitter chocolate, and roast. Tastes like it smells with a touch of smoke and a nice, dry finish. A decent example of the style.

name: Bloomington Big Stone Stout
review: Tap at source: Black with a strong, dark brown head. Scent is heavy..sweet chocolate and coffee. Taste is bold, sweet chocolate. Very smooth and creamy. A nice stout....good heavy feel to it...smoky towards the end. A pleasure.

name: Bloomington Big Stone Stout
review: tap at the brewpub - Pours very dark brown and has a roast malt and chocolate aroma. It tastes of that roast malt with some hints of coffee and chocolate. It’s medium bodied. Solid stout.

name: Bloomington Big Stone Stout
review: Tap. Smoky chocolate malt aroma. Dark brown color with moderate head. Lightly sweet and smoky chocolate malt and mildly bitter herbal hops flavor. Light body. Very nice.

name: Bloomington Big Stone Stout
review: On tap at brewpub My final beer of the afternoon was this decent stout. Much better than the porter it is at least worth a revisit when I am not in the mood to tick off something new. Especially at happy hour pricing this is probably one of the better local options without driving south to New Albany or up to Indianapolis. Aroma / Appearance - Reddish black with dark brown edges this beer has a mysterious glow. Loose and fluid it moves around the glass like the final drops of coffee from the bottom of the pot. Anise, plum, and pieces of bacon eat at the air. If you left malts to cool over a pile of cinders it might smell something like this. Flavor / Palate - Black coffee, anise, smoke, and a fluid texture are the hallmarks of this reasonably complex beer. Without trying to overwhelm the senses it throws wave after wave of depth at the senses. Bittersweet chocolate leads to a warm finish of smoky ash. If this is actually close to the 6% ABV on the board it is well done indeed.

name: Bloomington Java Porter
review: On draft at Max & Ermas in Eidenburg. The pour is a darker brown/black with a little garnet shining through. There is a thick light tan colored head and a fair bit of lace. The aroma is decent. There is a hefty coffee and roasted malt. The sweetness of a milk sugar and lighter chocolate does pretty well. The flavor is a bit more watery and single dimensioned. The coffee is present but watery with a light hint of chocolate and almost no malt present. The sweetness changes to bitter. The mouth feel is watery and hardly medium bodied with a sharpish carbonation and a lingeringly bitter roasted coffee on the back end. Not bad, but not terrible. 6 4 5 3 12

name: Bloomington Java Porter
review: Sampler pours black with a brown head. Aroma of coffee, chocolate and grains. Taste is coffee and nice malts.

name: Bloomington Java Porter
review: Draft: Pours black...with a short, tan head. Strong, roast coffee aroma. Creamy chocolate/coffee flavor. Roasty, smoky. Very solid.

name: Bloomington Java Porter
review: Draft to taster at Lennies. Looks good; a cloudy dark brown with beige head. Smells solid; lots of coffee with dark malt notes. Tastes like it smells with a good mouthfeel. Good beer.

name: Bloomington Java Porter
review: Aroma of bitter, chalky coffee, some chocolate. Appearance is garnet black with bone head. Flavor matches the nose; the coffee has a "spent" taste and is generally unpleasant. Palate is medium, chewy and soft. Needs work.

name: Bloomington Java Porter
review: Tap. Coffee and chocolate malt aroma. Dark brown color with small head. Slightly sweet chocolate malt and lightly bitter ash/herb flavor. Body a bit light. A nice drinkable beer.

name: Bloomington Java Porter
review: On tap at brewpub Moving on to the porters and stouts I was less impressed with what came at the end of the flight. While they weren’t terrible they just felt like they were lacking something that gave them an edge over any other beer brewed to a paint by numbers recipe. Even so it isn’t a bad fallback. Aroma / Appearance - Reddish black with spindly legs the beer slips down the sides slowly. Black coffee, ash, and a dry smoky malt bill nibble at the senses but never are strong enough to attract a bite. Flavor / Palate - Thin in the mouthfeel the texture is a bit watery. Like coffee left too long in the pot it has a strong bite. The taste of day old coffee proceeds to linger for a while before fading slowly. Average to slightly below average this is not the best example of a porter to use when trying to determine the good from the bad.

name: Bloomington Java Porter
review: Had this on tap at Lennies along with lunch. Not much head. Very dark porter. Aroma was coffee and maybe some chocolate in there. The flavor is similar to the aroma, although the roasted flavor comes through. Seemed pretty well balanced. Good, drinkable porter. The ABV is 5.0. Sumatran coffee beans are used.

name: Bloomington Java Porter
review: On tap at the brewpub. Wish this one had been on cask, but enjoyed it even so. Oily dark pour, with a thin but persistent head and nice lacing.
