Flavor is sweet and malty with the whisky notes appearing as well. Actually pretty complex. Body is medium to full. Nice bitterness on the swallow. This is good.

name: Coronado New Scots Ale
review: Deep brown color with a tan head. Nutty nose and taste. Not quite what I’d expect in a Scotch Ale, but still very enjoyable.

name: Coronado New Scots Ale
review: (Draft: Coronado Brewing Co. in San Diego, CA) At first, this has a moderate dark roasted malty flavor with a moderately bitter hoppiness for nice balance; But once again, like the Bay Bridge Bock, this Coronado beer is quite sugary and sweet -- too sweet in fact -- and it becomes a tad cloying after a few sips, masking the true character of the moderate dark roasted malt and hops; There's a slight alcohol flavor, but it's kept at bay; Medium to full bodied that coats the palate with a sticky sweetness after awhile; Lightly sweet and malty nose, but it's hard to tell since I'm sitting right next to a double station coffee machine; Ruddy mahogany color; Tannish head fades to nothing fairly quickly, so there's obviously no lacing; If it were less sweet, this would be a pretty solid Scottish Ale, but the excessive sweetness really is a pretty strong negative

name: Coronado New Scots Ale
review: draught: I assume that this is what I had, It was labeled as scotch ale... Brown as dirt with a khaki head, Whiskey or scotch aroma or cognac or something (don't ask me which, cuz i couldn't tell you) Very rich and malty, bitter finish, an interesting brew

name: Florida Brewing Dunks
review: I first experienced this beer in 1961, when it sold for .69 a six-pack. For reference Shlitz and Budweiser sold for $1.29, Busch (then called "Busch Bavarian") and Old Milwaukee were $1.09. I have no idea why this beer was (and still apparently is) brewed in Auburndale, FL - but the worst beer in America being brewed in area once exclusively associated with processing phosphorous makes some sort of sense.

name: Florida Brewing Dunks
review: only beer i have not been able to finish a 6 pack of, i wouldn't even give it to the taliban

name: Unibroue La Gaillarde
review: From old tasting notes. Hazy yellow gold color.mRocky white head. Yeasty sour malt nose. Tart lemony malt flavor with a spicy hop finish. Very wheat like. Decent flavor and mildly refreshing.

name: Unibroue Eau Bénite
review: 750ml bottle from IGA in Gatineau, QC. Pours a hazy deep golden colour with one finger of lasting white head and some lacing. Spicy aroma with some banana notes. Taste matches the aroma with some citrus notes. Creamy mouthfeel (similar to Tripel Karmeliet) with mid-high carbonation. Excellent tripel.

name: Unibroue Eau Bénite
review: Bottle. Pours hazy yellow with white head. Strong body. Sweet. Lots of belgian yeast and fruitiness. Orange.

name: Unibroue Eau Bénite
review: Bottle from beershop. Hazy orange color, white head. Yeast, fruits, peach, figue, booze. Good stuff

name: Unibroue Eau Bénite
review: Bottle, sampled in a large tulip glass, this ale had a orange-gold pour with hints of yellow at the sides of the glass, the pour started out clear and got hazy as the bottle emptied, the pour gave an initial two to three finger white head that receded to a thin cover and sticky ring, the glass had a center stream of bubbles of medium flow or a little less, there was a layer of medium to dark brown colored on the bottom of the bottle, the nose had yeast and fresh bread aromas, pear and apple fruit, some alcohol esters, malt and fruit sweetness, a little dough in the background, it had flavors of apple and pear, light malt and bread, and fruit sweetness, a little pepper at the finish but not much in dryness or citrus, the mouth feel was light to almost medium with a little creamy feel on the palate, I thought the carbonation was a little light, it could have used more carbonation, not a stand out in the world of tripel beers, the Unibroue La Fin du Monde was a much better example of a tripel, an ok drink.

name: Unibroue Eau Bénite
review: 750ml bottle at the RateBeer DC tasting. I believe I overheard that this was a 2 year old bottle. Poured a hazy yellow color with a small off-white head. Aroma was light herbal notes, some lemon notes. Light sweet grains, wheat. Light cardboard? Light fruity notes. Hay with a dry finish.

name: Unibroue Eau Bénite
review: Bottle at the RateBeer DC tasting. Slightly hazy yellow with off-white head. Aromas of malt, herbs, raisins. Tastes of malt, herbs, spice, candied fruit, raisins. Medium body with a dry finish.

name: Unibroue Eau Bénite
review: 750ml bottle pours a clear, dark gold with some cloudy, white head. Nose has yeast, grist, candy, candlewax, apricot. Flavor is sweet, honey, apricot, some pepper, yeast. Finishes sweet.

name: Unibroue Eau Bénite
review: From old tasting notes. Hazy honey gold color. Large rocky white head. Sweet fruity malt aroma. Zesty bittersweet citrus malt has a yeasty character. Intense fruity notes. Tasty.

name: Unibroue Quelque Chose
review: From a bottle with a 8/8/2002 bottled on date, and a 4/20/2018 drank on date-- 15 year old bottle from the cellar. Clear mahogany color with wispy white foam. Big dark cherry, cinnamon, sherry wine aromas. Medium bodied with soft carbonation. Nice spicy caramel, cherry fruit, cinnamon, port wine flavors with sweet spicy, herbal mint leaves--- smooth easy finish ___ fuck I wish I had more bottles of this

name: Unibroue Quelque Chose
review: 500ml bottle at Erik's. Corked. Vintage 2002. Appearance: a bit hazy copper Aroma: oxidized with sweet cherry notes Taste: similar Overall: ok

name: Unibroue Quelque Chose
review: From old tasting notes. Translucent brown color. Sour cherry aroma. Sweet and sour cherry malt flavor hints at spices. Although it is recommended to heat to 100 degrees, it is quite tasty served at 50 degrees. Very unique and flavorful.

name: Unibroue Trois Pistoles
review: Colore mogano scuro, versa un dito di schiuma poco persistente. Aroma tipico di una Quadrupel, con sentori di frutti scuri, spezie, frutta candita e caramello. In bocca risulta complessa e molto ben bilanciata, sentori di frutti scuri, caramello, liquirizia e malto tostato. Finale leggermente amarognolo e speziato. Corpo medio e gradazione alcolica ben nascosta. Ottima.

name: Unibroue Trois Pistoles
review: 12 oz. bottle. Pours a dull dark brown with a big off white head that dissipates after a few minutes. Big scents of raisins cinnamon, sherry and alcohol. Lots of carbonation with a sour acidic dry mouthfeel. Tastes of golden raisins, cinnamon and yeast that seem to fight somewhat. Warming alcohol burn comes in after a while. A christmassy brew.

name: Unibroue Trois Pistoles
review: Botella de 34,1 cl. Fecha de consumo 21/03/2022. Color caoba oscuro con dos dedos de espuma, carbonatación alta. Aroma a fruta madura, regaliz, anís, vino de oporto. El sabor sigue el mismo camino: uvas pasas, ciruelas, anís, cilantro, regaliz, oporto. Cuerpo medio/alto, dulce pero no en exceso. Una gran quadrupel de estilo belga, ya un clásico, excelente cerveza.

name: Unibroue Trois Pistoles
review: 2016 bottle, aged 3+ years in cellar. Ar: plum, raisins, sweet, honey, yeast, ripe fruits Ap: dark red, ruby, minimal head T: med sweetness, fruity, low bitterness P: med/full body

name: Unibroue Trois Pistoles
review: 750ml bottle in 2017. Dark brown with an offwhite head. Aroma of cloves, banana, dark malt, toffee and yeasty esters. Good body. Spicy, malty flavours with lots of fruity notes. Really on point for Belgian style.

name: Unibroue U Blonde
review: I live in Ontario and when I was in Quebec purchased Unibroue U Blonde and really like this beer. This beer is a very nice tasting beer and is not to Heavy.I would love to promote this beer in Ontario and have this here in Ontario.A very nice tasting beer that I really enjoy.

name: Unibroue U Blonde
review: Pours a foamy eggshell white head and has a dull pale golden appearance. Fairly weak lacing. Aromas are grainy with mild roasted malts. Not really much else. Has malty, bready and toasty flavours. Slightly sweet and mild citrus. Also has a light grainy lingering taste. Just a tad nutty with some honey in the finish. Faint carbonation. Slick mouthfeel. A bit watery with a drying sensation. A good Unibroue mass produced type beer.

name: Unibroue Sans Nom
review: 330. Thanks, Dany! Pours an opaque but bright strawberry blonde...until, well, this is probably a good time to remind everyone that I am a bit of an idiot. I just poured a 10-year-old BSA of unknown provenance straight down into a glass, just turned it over and glugged it. When the yeast cake burst through the mouth, it looked like I was firing a potato gun into a Duvel tulip. A potato gun that fires sweet, spicy, gooey potatoes of Quebecois love. I’ll let you just not think too much about some of the creepy gay overtones of what we just talked about, and move us right along to the beer. There’s not much head, even after I just poured the thing like a waiter at Applebee’s. Turns a tawny-looking caramel color if you’re stupid and careless enough to turn the yeast cake loose. Big caramel, toffee, and fig nose. Spicy sweet and delicious. Creamy medium body, surprisingly unsticky for all the sugars aboard. Very little carb. Caramel, toffee, figs, dates, and cookie dough on the mid palate. A wonderful combination of sweet and interesting notes that complement each other very well. Caramel sticky finish. Great beer, especially considering. Thanks so much, D.

name: Unibroue Sans Nom
review: Bottle [341ml] shared with HogTownHarry, GregClow & garthicus -- c/o HogTownHarry. 2000 vintage! 10 years old eh? Let’s do it! Pours a hazy golden-orange with a spare white head. Aroma: Not bad at all, it kind of reminds me of a UK Barley Wine. Quite fruity along with caramel malt, yeast and some maple syrup. Flavour is spicy in the finish, I didn’t expect that, dry, yeasty and fruity tasting -- much of the flavour is in the finish. Syrupy mouthfeel. Average bodied. This held up for a decade very well!

name: Unibroue Sans Nom
review: In short: A very old but surprisingly drinkable dusty, yeasty, rustic, tangy Belgian blonde ale. How: Bottle 341ml. Vintage 2000 (!!!). Consumed when too many years old. Bottle from Brasseurs Illimités personnal cellar, thanks René The look: Partly cloudy golden orange body topped by a small white head In long: Nose of burnt oranges, yeast spiciness, caramel, dust. Taste is has some kind of woody caramel upfront, dusty yeast. I know I haven’t had this beer since I started on ratebeer in 2005. And I don’t remember if I’ve had this local beer before. Maybe… 9 years ago? I don’t know (or remember) what it is supposed to taste like when fresh. But the bottle I drank had developed a rustic character with dusty and rusty notes. Unibroue sold it under the name “Without Name”, but that’s only because its real name was Renaldo.

name: Unibroue Sans Nom
review: 341ml bottle - shared with blankboy, garthicus and gregclow, via trade with JulienHuxley. Sure, it’s old - but I’ve wanted to try these long-retired Unibroues for years. D’oh - forgot to record the date!! Pours a flat-looking mostly clear gold, a touch oily-looking, with a small white head. Smells - actually, it doesn’t smell bad - peach, yeast, alcohol, a hint of paper - oxidized some, but not bad. Taste ... reminds me of Unibroue 10 - follows the nose right on with fruitiness, some alcohol, a bit dry and yeasty, overall sweet and a tad musty. Average body, mild carbonation, slick and again a bit must on the tongue, a hint of sourness in the finish - it’s held up some, thinning out, but "not poison"

name: Unibroue Sans Nom
review: Thanks to HogTownHarry. Appearance: Cloudy yellow with a small but persistent white head. Aroma: lots of caramel, maple, somewhat dusty, a little barleywine-esq with fruit in there too. Flavour: quite a lot of honey, malt, carbonated but not fizzy, tingling, a little spicy in the finish. Nice.

name: Unibroue Sans Nom
review: Bottle- Thanks so much Steve! Decants into my Unibroue snifter, a hazed burnt orange, with a thin white head that dissipates to a small ring. Interesting nose of wet basement, spices, oranges, brown sugar, and almost funky yeast. Tastes sweet, also slightly tart. Candied apricots, spice, and funky yeast leads to brown sugar. Thin, light medium body with an earthy finish. Still pretty good considering the age, and past its prime, but it is still drinking ok IMO. Glad I got to try it!

name: Unibroue Sans Nom
review: Bottle, vintage 2000. Thanks RH. Aroma is light brandy and cherries. Taste is cherries again, quite maderised. Light effervescence and thin palate. Not that bad despite his age.

name: Unibroue Sans Nom
review: Golden-orange in colour with a lasting but thin white coloured head, some light lacing and lots of visible carbonation. The aroma has some sugary sweetness still, some spice but the gingerbread is starting to take over. The flavour is also starting to go but there is still enough there for this to be enjoyable, the sweetness is light, ginger and some oxidization is starting to set in. Thin mouthfeel, meidum/light body, mild carbonation. Finishes lingering with a bit of spice. Well, it only took me 7 years to find this. Obviously nowhere near what this used to taste like, I give credit to the brewers because Unibroue beers have a crazy nack of holding up for years. Pretty much done now, drinking this is just for fun from here on out. Maybe one day I’ll come across another bottle. 341ml bottle obtained in a trade with Goldorak, thanks Martin. Opened on March 29, 2008. Vintage 2000.

name: Unibroue Sans Nom
review: Thanks to Jeff for sharing. The first beer of Saturday. Slightly hazy gold, thin head. Nose is honey & light toffee, malt, some astringent spiciness. Flavor is honey, yeasty spice, wishy washy toffee. Interesting but past it’s prime.

name: Boréale Blonde
review: Brownish, cloudy, with white head that dosnt last. Caramel, burned toffee in the aroma, Caramel, burned sugar, with mild hoppy aftertaste. a bit watery.

name: Boréale Blonde
review: Can. Clear golden body, medium white head with good retention and some lacing. Aroma of wet grains and diacetyl, hay and apricot jam. Taste of grains, rye bread, hay, herbs and some sulfurous compounds. Clean and fresh, with some minor defects.

name: Boréale Blonde
review: Can, 355 ml, bought at B & Y, Montreal. Pleasant golden ale, smooth and not too sweet. Moderate carbonation.

name: Boréale Blonde
review: Bottle at Banquise, Montreal. Golden pour with a modest head. Fairly neutral nose. Slightly bready with a bit of general fruit salad. Drinking experience defined by how effervescent it is. Fairly milquetoast, but ultimately inoffensive. Solid backyard BBQ sipper.

name: Boréale Blonde
review: The beer of the bear. Boreale is as commercial a microbrewery can be. It is really cheap and it reminds me of university. Still have one once a while. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Boréale Blonde
review: Good beer, surprisingly better than expected. A good backup when in doubt. Disappointing to see the Polar Edition to be the same as this.

name: Boréale Blonde
review: Bottle from local iga grocery A: light cereal, honeyed malt. App: clear pale sparring white head. T/p: med body with short bitter finish. Soft to moderate carbonation. O: A bit boring and watery. The beer geek in me would have enjoyed more malt support. Easy and refreshing.

name: Boréale Blonde
review: Slightly hazy golden color with low activity. A boring foamy white 2 finger head, lasting around 5 minutes, with poor lacing. Flavors of caramel, sweet roasted grains, coriander, lemon, herbal spices. Bready and sugary, slightly sharp on the herbal side. Slick medium body with soft prickly and crispy carbonation. Light to medium strength finish, fresh wheat and barley feel, toffee, and balanced leafy hops. Basic but refreshing, nice intensity with no adjunct feel. Good taste and a satisfying body. Overall good quality craft.

name: Boréale Blonde
review: 341ml bottle. Pour clear golden with a non lasting small white head. Aroma is shy, but it’s from light malt and pretty mainstream. Body is thin but in the style, very soft carbonation. Light bitterness from the discret hops. Medium finish. Refreshing and well done.

name: Boréale Blonde
review: Bottle, 341mL. Home. Kindly given by my parents ; bought during a trip at "Vendée Globe". Merci ! A clear golden beer with a big white head ; good retention ; ok lacing. Grain, light vegetable, herbal note. Light sweet, light dry bitter refreshing. Light body, watery texture, average to soft carbonation, dry short grainy finish. Overall, poor.

name: Boréale Cuivrée
review: 341ml bottle. Clear copper with a foamy white head. Flavors are caramel, barley sugar, alcohol and apricot with metallic notes. Medium to full body, moderate carbonation, oily texture.

name: Boréale Cuivrée
review: 341ml bottle. Pour dark reddish with a non lasting white foam. Aroma of caramel and notes of honey. Taste is of light roasted caramel malt and a bit metallic. Medium body and normal carbonation for the style. Medium bitterness and sweet finish. Well done but not complex enough to revisit.

name: Grays Autumn Ale-Nut Brown Ale
review: 12 oz bottle. Murky tarnished copper with a miniscule head...light caramel and smoke in the nose...pleasant, clean woody notes in the body, caramel and a bit of tar and licorice...medium carbonation, could be fuller at the finish.

name: Grays Autumn Ale-Nut Brown Ale
review: This beer was nothing special as far as the style. Solid, not impressive. A little thin and yeasty for a brown. Color and balance were well done, but the yeast came through and the mouthfeel was thin. Reading the other reviews, maybe I had a bottle that went a little awry, but maybe not. Same bitterness as described elsewhere.

name: Grays Autumn Ale-Nut Brown Ale
review: A deep brownish red beer with a coppery-tinged head (thin and fleeting). Strong scone or honey and biscuit aroma. Warm nuts and honey or honey and nuts. A fine brown ale, a bit on the thin side for body, but has a long, enduring finish. Very little up front though. Sweet for the style, but not bad overall.

name: Grays Autumn Ale-Nut Brown Ale
review: RERATE 10/8/04: After sampling three more bottles of this, I have to revise my rating upwards a little. I think the original bottle I tried was a litlle "funky". None of the three bottles I sampled later had the metallic taste I detected in the first one, and the "nuttiness" was more pronounced. Flavor was far superior so I've adjusted the rating accordingly. ORIGINAL RATING: I wanted to like this beer more. I really did. But let’s take it as it comes...From a bottle, this brew poured a dark brown with reddish tinges at the edge of the glass. Nice initial tan head that disappears quickly. Slight metallic hint in the aroma. Taste is mildly chocolate-y & somewhat nutty. Very slight metallic taste in the background. Reasonable hop presence towards the end. It certainly isn’t a bad brew for the money but it didn’t exactly wow me.

name: Grays Autumn Ale-Nut Brown Ale
review: Strange tea-like bitterness that I couldn''t get past. Nice brown-ale aroma with slight floral hop aroma. Very malty, but the weird hop flavors turned me off.

name: Grays Autumn Ale-Nut Brown Ale
review: Appearance is that of a glass of Coke, right down to the carbination. Nutty scent. Coffee taste, with a slight nuttiness. A little chocolate flavor as well. Too watery though.

name: Grays Autumn Ale-Nut Brown Ale
review: Nutty aroma, color is brownish red. Nicely hopped for a brown ale. Finish is chocolately.

name: Grays Autumn Ale-Nut Brown Ale
review: 10/6/02: Chestnut brown color with a small bubbled small tan head. Aroma of roasted grains and nuts. A faint solvent aroma distracts slightly. Quite thin in body. Flavors of hickory nuts and a mild hop bitterness. Finishes with a touch of astringency. Borders on a brown porter in flavor, but lacks body. A good beer none the less. 10/9/03: I pick this up every year. This may be the only brown ale I would buy on a regular(annual) basis. touch more body this year and a hint of chocolate. Still solid.

name: Grays Autumn Ale-Nut Brown Ale
review: Mmmm...smells nutty! Smooth, nice flavor. Damn, this stuff goes down easy! Add a 6 pack of this and "Jay & Silent Bob Strike Back" DVD, and you have a decent pre-bar evening!

name: Grays Black and Tan
review: Not so sure how i feel about this one. Poured a dark brown colour with a somewhat reddish tint, head was weak and and off white. Aroma was a little bland, mouthfeel was light. overall undercarbonated in my opinion, taste was a watery in the finish.

name: Grays Black and Tan
review: Had this beer on 9/15/1999. Color is a deep amber. Aroma a nice camel scent. Color is deep dark amber. Taste is a mild roasted malt flavor with a slight bitterness on the end.

name: Grays Black and Tan
review: 3/26/2007: Gray’s Black & Tan Ale is neither black nor tan, but more of an amber color with a small, fizzy, beige crown. (I know that the term "black and tan" doesn’t pertain to the color, but I couldn’t resist the urge to start my comments with that corny attempt at a joke...) The visible carbonation is moderate. Caramel and some light nuttiness are in the aroma. The flavor is similar with light hops and stale chocolate. There is a nice bitter bite and some roasted maltiness in the DRY, soapy finish. The body is seems a bir watered down feeling and there is some occasional fizziness as well. It seems like this bottle might be slightly old and/or oxidized. Not the best black and tan I’ve had... 12 oz bottle (34504GBC 0938 CT.05) from buckybeer (Dec 2006). Thanks for the bonus Mark! I appreciate it.

name: Grays Black and Tan
review: Bottle: Clear, dark copper color with a small tan head. Sweet aromas of cordovan leather and friendly grain. The taste is sweet and malty. It isn’t bad, but nothing great. This is definitely not a stout. Thanks BuckeyeBoy!

name: Grays Black and Tan
review: 12oz Bottle Pours out an amber not black or tan. Topped with a off white head. Arom is pretty good but not much on the tast. thanks Buckybeer for this extra.

name: Grays Black and Tan
review: Bottle pours a light mahogany with a small light tan head. Aroma is nice, woody, brown sugarand caamel. Very little hops in the aroma. Flavor is a bit cardboardy but soft and fairly sweet lightly toasted malts. Fine soft carbonation and a papery aftertaste. Very little hops here as well. This is a stout like Bud-Light.is a dopplebock. Seriously I think this is mislabled. A brown ale maybe. Meh...

name: Grays Black and Tan
review: Bottle: Pours a dirty orange with a medium, frothy white head. Nose of citrus hops and some malt. Creamy texture and taste of malt and hops, some floral notes. Tail has a little bitter kick. Thanks to Jeremy for sharing.

name: Grays Black and Tan
review: Dark clean amber pour with a small head. Aroma is a mild roasted nut along with light hops. Flavor is roasted nut and light bitter chocolate. I also found it a tad thin. Not too bad overall.

name: Grays Black and Tan
review: Without a doubt the best black and tan in a bottle...anywhere. Rich roasted , nutty malt predominates, the stout half being by far the most dominant flavor. But the EPA is represented by a lighter floral hopping that plays well against the heavier, more imposing stout. A little thin bodied, but not to the point of imposing demerits. All in all, very nicely done!

name: Grays Black and Tan
review: 12oz bottle. Poured a medium brown with an averaged sized off white head. Aromas of nuts, roasted & toasted malts, and light chocolate. Tastes of chocolate, toasted malts, and light chocolate. Semi-sweet.

name: Grays Cream Ale
review: Date: 08/07/2008 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: clear amber, fine dirty white head, drippy lace, Aroma: sweet candy caramel aroma, Body: slick creamy body, Flavor: sweet malt flavor, lots of dark caramel with a candy sweetness, balanced with a touch of earthyness, light cooked vegitable and heavy butterscotch character, Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 4/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 8/20 Rating: 2.4/5.0 Drinkability: 5/10 Score: *+/4

name: Grays Irish Ale
review: Draft pours amber with a white head. Aroma of bread, caramel and some floral notes. Taste is malty and grains.

name: Grays Irish Ale
review: 12oz bottle to tulip. Pours clear amber red, white soapy dissipating head. Aroma of caramel, butterscotch candy, toffee and sweet roasted grains. Taste of same with dark stone fruit and mild bitterness in finish.

name: Grays Irish Ale
review: Pours a copper with a white head. light lacing. Nose of caramel malts and nuts. Medium body. Flavor is mostly malts with a hint of floral hops. OK.

name: Grays Irish Ale
review: Bottle: Clear, deep red/amber with a small beige head. Toffee, berry aroma. Taste is slightly bready, fruity, toffee malt. A bit flat feeling, but a nice flavour.

name: Grays Irish Ale
review: On tap at the UW Memorial Union pours a clear Mber with some fading white head. Nose has malt, apple, pear, some raisin, caramel, yeast. Flavor is chewy grains, soggy bread, pear, carrot. Dry finish.

name: Grays Irish Ale
review: Bottle. Butterscotch candies/toffee malt and light straw aroma. Amber with small head. Mildly sweet buttery toffee malt and lightly bitter herbal hay flavor. Light body. Decent and easy drinking.

name: Grays Irish Ale
review: Draft at the source as Busted Knuckle, courtesy of nuplastikk, thanks. Clear golden amber color. Aroma of toasted fruity caramel. Taste is sweet malt and caramel. OK.

name: Grays Irish Ale
review: Pours light mahogany red with brief lacy head. Light , slightly sweet, malt aroma. Mildy sweet malt flavor with a hint of tempering hops. Palate light. Overall an easy drinking beer in the Celtic tradition... mostly malt wit a faint dry finish. Balanced and simple.

name: Grays Irish Ale
review: Brewed only in the spring, the Irish Style Ale is a special blend of four types of malted barley and three varities of hops. This ale is characterized by it’s sweet malty flavor and refreshing light scent. The rich red color is very distinctive to the origins of this style of ale. Available February 1 - May 30

name: Grays Irish Ale
review: Clear ruby colored with a very thin, fast disappearing head. Sweet nutty, toffee aroma. Caramel malt and lightly bitter taste. Very light carbonation and a short malty finish. This might not be the greatest red ale out there bu t after I sampled a series of clinkers this one was a welcome change.

name: Grays Winter Porter
review: Dark brown, small head. traditional porter smells and flavors - chocolate and coffee, plus a mildly spicy finish. Not bad. Thanks to Jewedekind for the trade!

name: Grays Winter Porter
review: Thanks to Jewedekind for this. Jeez, in 11 months on ratebeer I’ve never had a "make it or break it" 10th rating. Now I’ve had 3 in the last 3 days! This one pours deep ruby with medium off-white head. Aroma of malt, chocoff, cabernet, slight spice. Tastes roasty malty, with some chocoff, spices, and nuts. Standard mouthfeel (reminds me a little of Ravell), with more chocolate and spices as it warms.

name: Grays Winter Porter
review: This beer pours dark with little head. Thin, this beer is also bready in flavor and aroma. Still, lacks complexity in flavor and aroma.

name: Grays Winter Porter
review: Bottle: Pours a reddish brown with a small tan head and some lace. The aroma has notes of caramel and toasted malts, aromatic and grassy hops, coffee, and soem berry esters. The taste starts bland with just your basic malt sweetness before a dose of coffe and hop bitterness shows. Remains the same throughout the glass. The feel is watery and fizzy. An average to below average porter, not much going on here. Maybe too old?

name: Grays Winter Porter
review: Dark brown with a thin tan head. Nose is burnt and tobacco. Flavor is same. Not offensive, just not good.

name: Grays Winter Porter
review: black with thin brown head. Hoppy burnt nose with tobacco and nicotine in the flavour.

name: Grays Winter Porter
review: My contribution to the club's winter brew tasting. Bad choice. Well, it didn't suck but just wasn't anything remarkable. Dark brown with copper tinges, and a tan head. Coffee in the nose and the taste. Might try again sometime in the future.

name: Grays Winter Porter
review: Dark brown with hints of orange on the edges. Fluffy/wispy light tan head. Aromas of sweet grains and light brown sugar. Very grainy in flavor. Much like chewing on the grain/malt itself. Very dry finish with little linger. This seems thinner than I remember, although it has been a few years since I've had this one. Certainly drinkable, just not much to embrace.

name: Grays Winter Porter
review: At first sip, I thought this beer was just average. After a couple sips, I like it a lot more. More subtle then other porters, but still has a good taste.

name: Grays Winter Porter
review: color is a very very deep brown with a nice beige head sitting atop. mild coffee aroma with quite a bit of roastiness. flavor has similar qualities but with a sour finish and a fairly thin body and a kind of chalky aftertaste.

name: Grays Honey Ale
review: 12oz bottle to tulip. Pours clear gold, dissipating head. Aroma of honey, cereal, wheat, caramel apple and bubblegum. Taste of honey, grain and caramel. Pretty much just a lot of honey. Like I’m drinking chamomile tea.

name: Grays Honey Ale
review: I remember when this first came out and won a Gold along with their Oatmeal Stout in GABF in Denver at the same time. I rated this and the review got lost. Anyway, this beer is nothing like what it used to be, which was clean, crisp, subtle and a true pleasure. Now, it’s soft, thin, overstated and totally forgettable. A pity.

name: Grays Honey Ale
review: Bottle. Pours a clear mid golden color. Aroma, as you would expect, is honey and malt. Taste is very thin though, lacking any real depth or character. As advertised, honey and sweet malt. Barely average. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Grays Honey Ale
review: Poured a clear mid-gold with a light head and lacing. Aroma was sweet - honey, mallt, clover. Taste was light and slightly sweet with malts, honey and slight grassiness with very mild hop finish. Palate was OK. Overall, a decent but not a real great blonde ale.

name: Grays Honey Ale
review: This pours a clear, pale amber color with a slight, white head. There isn’t much to the scent other than some hints of grain and honey. The taste is fairly average but does have a decent honey taste that is better than Leinenkugel’s Honey Weiss. The texture is pretty watery with very little carbonation. Clean and refreshing, but nothing mind blowing.

name: Grays Honey Ale
review: The honey really comes alive as it warms, in both flavor and aroma. Crisp, clean, and very unoffensive. Very light body and not much to it past the honey. Would have again.

name: Grays Honey Ale
review: Bottle poured a clear golden amber with a lingering ring of ivory foam. Aromas of bread, graininess and light honey. Palate was light bodied and crisp. Flavors of bread, honey and light graininess with a crisp lingering honey finish.

name: Grays Honey Ale
review: Does not look like much, no head, just pale lager without any real visible co2. Smell is simply crisp and clean. Woo, there is a goodly amount of co2 in there on the tongue, fer sure. Taste is a little like slag. A fairly easy to get along with beer, not over the top in sweetness, never cloying. No real bitter attributes make this easy to drink. Finish has no ill effects that I can speak of. Overall just a decent beer that provides a good beer drinken experience. Would not hesitate to buy again, better than any of the cheaper pale lagers I drink.

name: Grays Honey Ale
review: Pours a clear pale yellow, highly carbonated, with a small white head sustained by said carbonation. Aroma is (surprise) honey. Taste has a yeasty, bready, slightly tart character with little hop flavor. Refreshing and well balanced, would be a great summertime session brew. It may not be your style, but it is what it is.

name: Grays Honey Ale
review: A clear, pale yellow pour with a white head. It has a cereal grain aroma with some mild hops. The light body is crisp and refreshing with lively carbonation. It has a neutral, balanced taste and a clean finish.

name: Grays Oatmeal Stout
review: 12 ounce bottle. Pours almost black with a small tan head. Aroma of chocolate, coffee, and malt. Taste is chocolate, coffee, roasted malt, and some ash. Mild bitterness. Pretty good.

name: Grays Oatmeal Stout
review: Draft pours black with a tan head. Aroma of grains, coffee and some toffee. Taste is coffee and toffee.

name: Grays Oatmeal Stout
review: 12oz bottle pours black minimal tan head slight roast aroma taste is oats and roasted barley

name: Grays Oatmeal Stout
review: Bottle from six pack picked up on way back from SD trip. Dark pour with a creamy light tan head. First whiff is of milk chocolate. Oatmeal is also noticeable on the nose. Some type of stale liquorice present in the taste along with oatmeal and coffee.

name: Grays Oatmeal Stout
review: This is my kind of sweet stout. Plenty of body, oily thick mouthfeel. Sweetness offset by other things going on.Chocolate nose with roasty notes. Thanks for the trade Ron.

name: Grays Oatmeal Stout
review: 12oz bottle to tulip. Pours black, tan ring head. Aroma of brown sugar, raisin, caramel, toasted oatmeal. Taste of same with sweet Dr. Pepper malty finish. Mouthfeel is mod-light.

name: Grays Oatmeal Stout
review: Bottle: Slightly rubied-black with a small tan head. Slightly smoky chocolate scent. Taste is creamy, chocolate malt, oatmeal. Nice....a very tasty little stout.

name: Grays Oatmeal Stout
review: Brings back memories of college days. Thin flat body, but excellent sweet chocolate and oat flavor.

name: Grays Oatmeal Stout
review: Bottle. Sweet chocolate oatmeal malt and light ash aroma. Dark brown with light tan head. Sweet chocolate oatmeal malt and lightly bitter dry hay flavor. Nice body. Very good.

name: Grays Oatmeal Stout
review: 12-Mar-14 (12-oz bottle) This beer pours a very dark brown body with a small, tan head that dissipates fairly quickly. Aromas of dark chocolate dominate, with some coffee, oatmeal, and damp earth in the background. On the palate, it’s fairly light and easy, with oatmeal and chocolate flavors being tempered by a gentle, but noticeable sourdough-like tartness. It’s medium in weight, medium-light in carbonation, fairly dry, and gently acidic. Overall, it’s okay, but I’d prefer a bit more richness and intensity without the light tartness.

name: Grays Wisconsin Weissbier
review: Draft pours hazy golden with a white head. Aroma of wheat, citrus and banana. Taste is grains and yeast

name: Grays Wisconsin Weissbier
review: Bottle poured a cloudy gold with a white head. Nose of wheat, citrus, and banana. Medium plus body. Flavor is light citrus. Finish is crisp almost like a Kolsch. Pretty good.

name: Grays Wisconsin Weissbier
review: 12 ounce bottle from a mixer bought at ShopNSave. I rolled this bottle and lots of sediment loosened. In the glass it looks like an unfiltered hefe. Fizzy noise when poured. I smell bananas and Belgian yeast. Those and cloves are tasted. A hint of cinnamon. Something lightly medicinal is not pleasant. This is not bad and actually tastes pretty good on a 98F degree day.

name: Grays Wisconsin Weissbier
review: Bottle poured ahazy gold with a lasting offwhite head. Aromas ofwheat, yeast, citrus and a hint of banana. Palate was light bodied and crisp. Flavors of wheat, bread and light citrus with a crisp finish.

name: Grays Wisconsin Weissbier
review: Really interesting. Tobacco cellar nose, with but a soft fruit. Plum? No, cherry. Light cherry aroma, too. Very light yellow, clear. Feels watery but a fizz keeps it going. Good and interesting, more than expected. (tap at Old Fashioned, Madison)

name: Grays Wisconsin Weissbier
review: Aroma is fruit/lemons, slightly subdued. The flavor is lemon, a hint of bubble gum and a mildly sweet finish.

name: Grays Wisconsin Weissbier
review: Bottle. Slightly hazy light orange pour with a large initial white head that fades. Nose is metallic grain. Lighter palate. Taste is a bit fizzy, grain, slight light fruit/sweetness, and a bit more metallic character. Not very good.

name: Grays Wisconsin Weissbier
review: Poured as Wisco Wheat out of a bottle from the mousehaus cheesehouse. Cloudy yellow with a thick white head. Aroma is nicer with the head. Without it’s just more alcohol. Flavor is flavorless.

name: Grays Wisconsin Weissbier
review: This beer is really pretty decent, but still nothing much to it. I like some more complexity.

name: Grays Wisconsin Weissbier
review: Garbage when you compare it to a real Hefeweissbier. Just utter garbage, a literal joke.

name: Gritty McDuffs Black Fly Stout
review: When I first starting drinking this sample, thought the final rating would be lower than what I'm giving....but in the end it all adds up to one solid beer. There are definitely other sweet/dry stouts that I would prefer, but still mostly better than expected. Grew on me towards the end of the glass. Appearance really can't get any better. Super dark black with mocha head.....looks thick but feel is rather thin. Was thinking and hoping would have more chocolate to the flavor, which seems to water it down a bit....but on the other hand gives it s thinner/more easy to drink lighter mouthfeel. Flavor almost an 8....has slight potential to be more. Either way I give props to my first sample from Gritty.

name: Gritty McDuffs Black Fly Stout
review: Refrigerated brown bomber poured into a cup. Dark brown with small beige head. Aroma is light coffee, medium body, low carbonation, and some lacing. Taste is dry toasty malt.

name: Gritty McDuffs Black Fly Stout
review: Draught @ the pub. Dark brown with creamy beige head, faint roasted malt aroma, low carbonation, bitter roasted malt taste, thin body, medium finish. A bit weak and watery for a stout.

name: Gritty McDuffs Black Fly Stout
review: Pours a near black from a tap. Aroma is mostly masked by the head. Why is everything brewed here so sweet? Okay beer. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Gritty McDuffs Black Fly Stout
review: On tap at the brewery. Pours a deep brown to black with a thin tan head. Big roast, cocoa, chocolate on the nose. On the thin side of medium bodied, cocoa, chocolate, a bit of sweetness. Slow roast into the finish, cocoa, roast, chocolate. Easy with a nice bitterness to balance, roast.

name: Gritty McDuffs Black Fly Stout
review: Pours black light coffee aroma taste of light coffee not much roast to it kinda weak stout not very impressed

name: Gritty McDuffs Black Fly Stout
review: This is the closest American Stout I’ve had to my Gold Standard(Guinness Draught:) Just wish I could get it in PA as I’ve only had this Maine brewed beer in the New England area.

name: Gritty McDuffs Black Fly Stout
review: This one is drinkable. Black with white head. Oatmeal and milk. Poured from draft at the Grittys taproom in Portland Maine.

name: Gritty McDuffs Black Fly Stout
review: LSAT Freedom Trip #48. Nitro at the Auburn location. Dark brown, large creamy tan head, good retention. Aroma of roasted malts, oats, chocolate. The taste is roasted malts, chocolate, oats, mild nuttiness. Thin-medium bodied, low carbonation, dry.

name: Gritty McDuffs Black Fly Stout
review: Sample at brewpub. Pours black with a khaki head. Slight roasted malt note on the nose. Fairly malty on the tongue with some roast notes. Could use some more hoppiness for balance. Kind of one note. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Gritty McDuffs Lions Pride Brown Ale (Best Brown Ale)
review: Very good brown ale. Big surprise to read the low alcohol amd calorie count. It is a very flavorful brown ale.

name: Gritty McDuffs Lions Pride Brown Ale (Best Brown Ale)
review: From old tasting notes. Reddish brown color. Big rocky being head. Earthy, toasted malt aroma. Spicy toasted malt flavor. Bittersweet chocolate maltiness throughout. Dry hop finish.

name: Gritty McDuffs Lions Pride Brown Ale (Best Brown Ale)
review: Draft at Gritty's Freeport. Pours brown with a thin head. Slight nutty note on the tongue. Has a bit of a copper metal thing on the tongue. Doesn't really remind me much of a brown ale. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Gritty McDuffs Lions Pride Brown Ale (Best Brown Ale)
review: Poured from draft at the Grittys taproom in Portland Maine. Brown sugar and asshole taste here. I must like asshole. Just kidding this sucks

name: Gritty McDuffs Lions Pride Brown Ale (Best Brown Ale)
review: LSAT Freedom Trip #47. Keg at the Auburn location. Clear dark red brown, thin fizzy off-white head, fair retention. Aroma of nuts, caramel and tinny hops. The taste is toffee, caramel, nuts. Medium bodied, low carbonation.

name: Gritty McDuffs Lions Pride Brown Ale (Best Brown Ale)
review: On tap at the brewpub. A deep amber colored beer, clear beer with a small off-white head. The aroma is quite cellar-ish, with dusty malts, bread and some caramel. The flavor is pretty much the same, but with a touch fruits. Medium body, very smooth on the palate, quite dry. Malty finish. Rather boring for a brown ale, easy drinkable though. 150609

name: Gritty McDuffs Lions Pride Brown Ale (Best Brown Ale)
review: Draught @ Gritty McDuff’s Brew Pub, Portland, ME Pours hazy amber with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, caramel, and floral. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter with along malty and caramel finish. Body is medium, texture is thin to oily, carbonation is soft to flat.

name: Gritty McDuffs Lions Pride Brown Ale (Best Brown Ale)
review: Thankfully I’ve reached the end of this pretty bad dirty dozen from gritty’s! Bad mouthfeel, week aroma, & semi metallic taste. This is not a good brown & I wouldn’t reccomend it!

name: Gritty McDuffs Lions Pride Brown Ale (Best Brown Ale)
review: Poured light brown with a thin head. Sweet, caramel malt aroma. Hop flavor is stale with a long dry finish. Definitively nutty. Not a big fan of this one.

name: Gritty McDuffs Lions Pride Brown Ale (Best Brown Ale)
review: Pours brown with an off white head. Sweet caramel malt aroma with some citrus hops.. Flavor starts off sweet caramel malt with brown sugar and some nuttiness followed with some fruity notes and a light citrus finish. Earlier Rating: 8/10/2013 Total Score: 3.3 Amber color with white head. Caramel nutty aroma. Caramel nutty flavor with roasted notes and slight hop finish.

name: Gritty McDuffs Best Bitter
review: Pours a rich reddish brown from a cask. Nice light malty aroma, slightly sweet. Good beer. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Gritty McDuffs Best Bitter
review: On tap at the brewery. Pours a clear copper amber with a thin white head. Soft floral notes, a bit of fruit on the nose. Medium bodied, soft sweetness, slow fruity malt. Toast, a bit of sweetness, crisp and fruity. Gentle fruit into the finish, a touch of bitterness.

name: Gritty McDuffs Best Bitter
review: From old tasting notes. Amber orange color. Big creamy beige head. Soft malty nose. Is peppery and toasty. Chewy toasted malt flavor is spicy with a citrus hop finish. Well balanced.

name: Gritty McDuffs Best Bitter
review: Cask at brewpub. Amber pour. Nose is faint caramel and cardboard. Tastes of caramel, earth, hops, floral, cardboard and sweet berry. mild palate.

name: Gritty McDuffs Best Bitter
review: On tap at the brewery. Pours copper with fluffy white head. Aroma is of caramel malt and red berries. Body is medium and smooth. Earthy hops, caramel malt and red fruit fill the mouth. Finish is long and peppery. Good overall.

name: Gritty McDuffs Best Bitter
review: Poured from draft at the Grittys taproom in Portland Maine. Orange with white head. Earthy and wheat. I guess it's cask and should be good. I am choking on it

name: Gritty McDuffs Best Bitter
review: Cask at GBBF ’15, day 3, 13/08/15. Had this juan at the brew pub in ’05 pre RB days! Golden copper with a decent egg shell white covering. Nose is nutty, toffee, biscuit malt, fruit peel. Taste comprises mellow fruit, caramel, light spice, airy malt base, biscuit crumble. Medium bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close with a bitter bite. Decent enough bitter.

name: Gritty McDuffs Best Bitter
review: LSAT Freedom Trip #46. Keg at the Auburn location. Clear copper, thin foamy white head, good retention. Aroma of toasted malts, berries, floral hops, grain. The taste is toasted malts, caramel, mild hoppy finish. Medium bodied, low carbonation, drinkable.

name: Gritty McDuffs Best Bitter
review: Sample at brewpub. Pours copper hued an with a thin white head. Not much on the nose. A bit malty on the tongue with a faint hop presence. Finished clean. Eh! ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Gritty McDuffs Best Bitter
review: Cask, gravity dispense at GBBF 2015. Dark orange, still, small foamy white head. Aroma is resinous, toffee, gluey. Body is medium, smooth, low carbonation. Taste is gluey, toffee, resin with some caramelised fruits. It’s a fairly accurate copy of a mediocre traditional British bitter. Not what American breweries have become famous for, but OK in its own right.

name: Gritty McDuffs Sebago Light Ale
review: LSAT Freedom Trip #75. Keg at the Freeport location. Clear pale golden, large foamy off-white head, good retention. Aroma of biscuity malt, butter. The taste is grainy and biscuit malt, herbal hops. Thin bodied and bland.

name: Gritty McDuffs Sebago Light Ale
review: On tap at Freeport location. Clear light golden color with white head. Light malt and citrus aroma. Crisp light malt flavor with lemon notes and crisp citrus finish.

name: Gritty McDuffs Sebago Light Ale
review: Nice light beer for summer - with low alcohol - especially on draft on a hot day.

name: Gritty McDuffs Summer Wheat Ale
review: Keg at the Portland branch. Pours clear, yellow-gold with a slight, filmy white head. Grainy pale malts in the nose, some yeast, white bread, hay. Medium sweet flavor with faint bitter hay, grainy cereal, pale bread. Light bodied with fine carbonation. Sweet finish, more grains, sugary white bread, hay. Very simplistic beer.

name: Gritty McDuffs Summer Wheat Ale
review: Very clean and smooth for a Hefeweizen. Very mild and refreshing. Sampled at the St. Pete Florida Craft Beer Fest.

name: Gritty McDuffs Summer Wheat Ale
review: Draft on vacation to Maine.Nice Golden color, seemed likesome hop finish with modest carbonation, almost like a Koelsch with light fruit flavors naturally derived.

name: Gritty McDuffs Summer Wheat Ale
review: Date: 04/29/1999 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub light amber, whispy head, slightly sweet malt aroma, light raspy wheat character, qood dose of bitterness in the finish, a touch of gritty’s house butterscotch in both the aroma and flavor Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.6/5.0 Score: **/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

name: Gritty McDuffs Summer Wheat Ale
review: Pale golden beer, whitish head. Aroma is quite light and lean as would be expected. A touch of citrus and light cotton candy over extra light malt. Light earthiness and a bit of bright citrus on the back. It’s simple and refreshing and quite a good summer ale.

name: Gritty McDuffs Summer Wheat Ale
review: (Draft@Freeport) Clear (not cloudy) yellow-gold with small white head. Aroma very faintly bready, yeasty. Mouthfeel light, kind of thin, a little prickly and dry. Nice lacing. Flavor very yeasty and bready, a bit sweet. A bit of bitterness on back end. I liked the freshness. Not bad but not something I’d really yearn to go back to.

name: Gritty McDuffs Summer Wheat Ale
review: Bottle. Light pale color, with medium white head. Slight citrus in aroma, little watery in finish. Typical summer wheat beer.

name: Gritty McDuffs Summer Wheat Ale
review: Not that great. Light lager like coloration with a white head and again lager like aroma. Flavor wasn't worth mentioning and nothing that I would try again.

name: Gritty McDuffs Summer Wheat Ale
review: (Draught) Sampled at Gritty McDuff's Brewpub in Freeport. Light golden colour with lasting, thin, white head. Little aroma. Light flavours of hops. Too thin!

name: Gritty McDuffs Summer Wheat Ale
review: This very clear crisp pale yellow beer is topped with a thick white head. the aroma is lsightly sweet and malty with a hint of hops and wheat. the flavor is slightly sweet and malty with wheaty undertones and a hoppy background.

name: Gritty McDuffs Halloween Ale
review: LSAT Freedom Trip #51. Keg at the Auburn location. Clear dark amber, medium sized fizzy off-white head, good retention. Aroma of toffee, caramel, spicy hops. The taste is toffee, caramel, dark fruit. Medium bodied, moderate carbonation.

name: Gritty McDuffs Halloween Ale
review: Sample at brewpub. Pours copper with a white head. Leaves trace lacing in glass. Not getting a lot on the nose. A bit fruity on the tongue which might be from its extra slight hoppiness. Finished clean. Eh! ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Gritty McDuffs Halloween Ale
review: Tap at Becky’s Diner. It pours clear deep red - brown with a small white head. The nose is toasty, bitter - sweet, caramel, pie and wood. The taste is bitter - sweet, woody, dark caramel, leather, soft pumpkin pie, toasty brown sugar and leather with a dry finish. Medium body and moderate carbonation. Quite a nice bitter - sweet balance. Not too shabby.

name: Gritty McDuffs Halloween Ale
review: Bottle from Harvest Market Pours a deep amber/copper color with a good sized off white head that persists for quite a while. Aromas of rich caramel malt with a bit of a mineral/sulfur edge, light earthy hop aroma. The flavor is rich caramelized malt sugars with lots of toffee. Light fruit, earthy hop, light mineral flavor. Medium body moderate carbonation. Decent brew.

name: Gritty McDuffs Halloween Ale
review: Pours Amber/brown with an off white head. Aroma of malt and spice. Flavor hints at malt with a bitter finish.

name: Gritty McDuffs Halloween Ale
review: 12oz bottle from Lacey Spirits. Pours a clear dark Amber color with a finger of frothy off white head. Aroma of caramel malt, hints of citrus skins, and cheese. Taste is better then the aroma. Toasted grain, roasted Amber malts, rotted citrus bitterness, and yeast.

name: Gritty McDuffs Halloween Ale
review: Pours dark brown with a frothy tan head that stays. Nose is malty with a hint of pumpkin and spice. Taste is balanced, nice hop bite in the aftertaste. Medium body. Lively carbonation. Tasty brew. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Gritty McDuffs Halloween Ale
review: Bottle. Pours dark amber with a thin tan head. Aroma of caramel and spices. Flavor was lightly sweet with caramel, bread, earth, mild spices and had a slightly bitter finish.

name: Gritty McDuffs Halloween Ale
review: Reviewed from notes. The appearance was a burnt brown colored body and gave a small off white/brown head. Some haunting lacing slowly slid down the glass as the beer went down. The smell had slight caramel and apples with a bit of a woody yeast and earthy hops to it too. The taste was sweet through caramel, light ginger, and apples, mainly an cooked apple aftertaste, hops once the beer warms a bit. On the palate, it sat at/about a medium, sessionable, yeasty finish with some light hops in that. Overall, full-flavored beer that I used to drink when I lived in Maine.

name: Gritty McDuffs Halloween Ale
review: Draft. Pours medium brown with white head that dissipates. Light carbonation mild caramel aroma. Caramel up front with mild spices and brown ale like flavors. Has mild hop flavor and very slight pumpkin taste. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Gritty McDuffs Christmas Ale
review: Pours brown/amber color with a cream colored head. Caramel malt and herbal hop aroma. Flavor is caramel malt with roasted notes and an earthy hop finish. I really like this one.

name: Gritty McDuffs Christmas Ale
review: Pours a reddish brown. Nose is ginger snaps and malt. Taste is somewhat sweet. Nice Christmas ale. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Gritty McDuffs Christmas Ale
review: You’ve heard of comfort food? Well this is comfort beer. A nice robust carmelly taste with a very crisp finish.

name: Gritty McDuffs Christmas Ale
review: * Old rating. 12 Fl.Oz. bottle, best before N 10. Dunkel-dickflüssiges Bier, Gewürze, brauner Zucker, aber nicht sonderlich tief. Nicht sonderlich aromatisch-bitter, echt enttäuschend...

name: Gritty McDuffs Christmas Ale
review: Bottle shared by a friend from notes. Pours a clear reddish brown color with a medium sized off white head. The aroma and flavor have caramel, brown sugar, nuts, some mild spices and earthy hops. Nothing great, but one of the better beers from these guys my friend was able to share.

name: Gritty McDuffs Christmas Ale
review: 355ml bottle. Amber colour. Bready and a little boozy. A solid strong ESB; maybe higher rating than it merits because is is so to my personal taste. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Gritty McDuffs Christmas Ale
review: Location: 12 oz bottle from Buy Rite, 5/20/14 Aroma: The aroma is rich and malty, fruity, some caramel, toffee, and brown sugar Appearance: It pours a clear amber color with a fizzy beige head and occasional lace Flavor: The flavor, like the nose, is rich and malty as well, pretty sweet, with a light bitterness Palate: The body is medium-full, it has a fairly thick texture, and a lively carbonation Overall Impression: This is some pretty solid stuff, and pretty sweet too. The carbonation hurts the drinkability here a bit. Overall, this is a solid example of the style, but not something I see myself seeking out.

name: Gritty McDuffs Christmas Ale
review: Reviewed from notes. The appearance had a chestnut/copper colored body, small white one finger head, lacing slid quickly into the body. The smell had a sweet subdued caramel, slightly bready. The taste was pretty much the same, but coming through in a bland sort of way. On the palate, it sat at/about a medium, slightly sessionable, creamy aftertaste, sweet bready finish. Overage average for the style, but acutally I liked it and went nicely with some Christmas cookies.

name: Gritty McDuffs Christmas Ale
review: Bottle. Pours coppery with off-white head. Nose is earthy, caramel malt, x-mas spice, with a spiced ESB flavor and medium palate.

name: Gritty McDuffs Christmas Ale
review: Poured caramel with a thick head. Nose like maple syrup? Not especially bitter, but nearly sweet, reminding me of other sweeter brown ales.

name: Gritty McDuffs Scottish Ale
review: Rather bitter for a Scottish ale. Clear garnet color with a thin head. Malt and bitterness seem to compete.

name: Gritty McDuffs Scottish Ale
review: Bottle, 12 oz, screw-top. Nose is very malty, sweet but not overdone, with wet grain and faint smoke, candyish elements and artificial sweetener, light citrus. Pours deep amber with a soapy tan head. In the mouth it’s airy, sweet but not too bad, very warming on the throat with light spikes of alcohol in the mouth, faint smoke with some gritty resin and lighter phenol/bubblegum/candy character. A bit grainy (as in husky), touch of toasting to the malt, earthy hops with a bit of wood. Dries out slightly, light body is pretty soft and actually somewhat interesting, but there are brewing flaws all over this and it’s pretty dirty on the whole.

name: Gritty McDuffs Scottish Ale
review: 12 ounce bottle. Dark copper color. Medium-sized foamy beige head. Subtle bready toasted malt aroma. Bittersweet toasted malt flavor upfront. Notes of roasted nuts and dark caramel. Slightly sour backdrop. Brief woody finish with a hint of dry hops.

name: Gritty McDuffs Scottish Ale
review: Drought at International Great Beer Expo (Meadowlands). Amber color, whitish foamy head, honey aroma, slightly bitter taste with strong honey flavor, low carbonation, long finish.

name: Gritty McDuffs Scottish Ale
review: Bottle. Poured a medium brown with big tan head. Strong malt with smooth crisp finish. Mediium body, one of my fav Scottish Ales.

name: Gritty McDuffs Scottish Ale
review: 355ml bottle. Medium brown with a tan head. Bready, scotch and peat aroma. Tastes of caramel, scotch, peat and earth. Medium body. Not bad, but it didn't go far enough. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Gritty McDuffs Scottish Ale
review: On tap at J’s resturaunt. Complex aroma of caramel malts and spicy hops. golden with off white head. complex malts were over powered by the floral hop flavors. good on palate. Very pleasent brew overall.

name: Gritty McDuffs Scottish Ale
review: Aroma of caramel, peat, and sweetbread. Medium copper color, relatively still. Biting, crisp start, long mellow semi-sweet finish. Body is a tad papery, otherwise very consumable. Decent Scottish style beer.

name: Gritty McDuffs Scottish Ale
review: The appearance is a deep golden brown color with a short white head that lingers a bit and leaves a good lacing along the sides of the glass. The smell contains caramelized malts, vanilla, butterscotch and touches of hops. The taste has a sweet but a sort of mildness of caramel and butterscotch within the malty character. Once again the hops are mild and balances superbly in this beer. There is a sligbhtly sweet aftertaste. The palatel is smooth and a little crisp, with a medium body, and medium carbonation. The finish is a bit dry. Overall, this is a good beer.

name: Gritty McDuffs Scottish Ale
review: 12 ounce bottle pours an amber color, with aromas of peat, malt, and biscuits. Flavors are teh same with some light floral hops added. Ok beer overall, would drink again if I had to.

name: Gritty McDuffs Maine's Best IPA
review: Poured into a pint glass from a 12oz bottle. Nice, clear light brown appearance, but the head dissipated quickly (and virtually no lacing is there). The nose was evident with malty bread and caramel notes. It has a bitter bite that matches the 60 IBUs, but the English and German malts dominate. Seems to be an "Extra Special Bitter Ale" and not an IPA at all. Cheers!

name: Gritty McDuffs Maine's Best IPA
review: Was in Maine recently and tried Gritty’s Maine’s Best IPA.... Very, very good beer. I’m disappointed it’s not distributed in CT, but will find a way to get my hands on more of this beer.....Awesome product!

name: Gritty McDuffs Maine's Best IPA
review: Definitely not the best IPA in the great state. Orange amber clear pour. Herbal resin caramel aroma. Taste is a bit shocking, overly sticky caramel earthy flavor. Modest bitterness.

name: Gritty McDuffs Maine's Best IPA
review: 12 oz. bottle. Color is a caramel maghony with weak lasting white head. Aroma weak earthy pine and herbal notes. Taste needs some help. Caramel toffee base with a slightly sticky texture. (WAY too much crystal malt) The hops are overly herbal and bold pine. The hops just come off astringent. Maybe I had an older bottle but… I doubt it. Sugar and astringent hops, no thanks.

name: Gritty McDuffs Maine's Best IPA
review: Interesting orange-red color, clear. Light tan head. Roasted grains, touch of pine resin. Bit of honey. Moderately bitter upfront. Nice sweetness balances it out. Medium body, decent amount of carbonation, some oiliness. Good. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Gritty McDuffs Maine's Best IPA
review: Bottle. It poured a clear golden color with a white head. The aroma was of citrus, grapes and some pine. The taste was similar to the aroma with more citrus, pine, hops and some sweetness. Not bad.

name: Gritty McDuffs Maine's Best IPA
review: Orange clear with white head. Poured from draft at the Grittys taproom in Portland Maine. Not good

name: Gritty McDuffs Maine's Best IPA
review: LSAT Freedom Trip #49. Keg at the Auburn location. Clear copper, thin foamy white head, fair retention. Aroma of citrus, lemon, pine, caramel. The taste is citrus, mild pine, caramel malt. Medium bodied, lingering bitterness. Decent, but no longer Maine’s Best IPA.

name: Gritty McDuffs Maine's Best IPA
review: Sample at brewpub. I'm probably not the first to say this but what a terrible fucking name for a beer especially if you don't deliver the goods. I wonder how many breweries started in Maine just to disprove this name. Anywho pours golden with a white head. Not much on the nose or tongue. Kind of dull for style. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Gritty McDuffs Maine's Best IPA
review: Copper poir with a quick head that leaves zero lacing.cminimal nose. Light bitterness, grassy funk and finish with pour lemons. Light to medium body. Instantly forgettable.

name: Gritty McDuffs Old Porter
review: Draught. One of my favorite beers by Gritty’s. If your in the Old Port in March grab one for sure.

name: Gritty McDuffs Old Porter
review: 2. 1. en gritty’s portland esta es la segunda del sampler de siete que tome en el brewery, un poco de humo y cafe en el sabor

name: Gritty McDuffs Old Porter
review: Date: 10/17/1997 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub dark ruby red, good tan head, light lace, slightly sweet chocolate malt aroma, rich chocolate malt flavor, like a melted hearshy’s bar in a glass, just a slight hint of sweetness in the finish that turns to malt bitterness as it warms Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 8/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 17/20 Rating: 3.7/5.0 Score: ****/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

name: Gritty McDuffs Old Porter
review: Holy crap, I finally found it! On tap in Portland...when the guy said they had a porter i was puzzled and i couldn’t remember ever having it. Turns out I hadn’t. This beer is actually really a yummy porter. Pours a dark brown with hints of red. Very smokey, malty, and just delicous. Nice full body and coffee flavors. Get this beer if you see it at grittys!

name: Gritty McDuffs Old Porter
review: [on tap at brewery] Dark red-brown with a tan ring and wisps. Sweet coffee aroma. Smokey and sour malt flavour with some dark malt bitterness combined to make a flavour that I really didn’t like that much. Medium body and medium carbonation.

name: Gritty McDuffs Old Porter
review: On cask NERAX ’04: Clear ruby color, roasted coffee and chocolate notes. Full bodied, starts off slightly sweet and ends a bit sweeter. Tasted a bit stale, but was good anyway.

name: Harbor City Mile Rock Amber Ale
review: Not bad for a style that isn’t known for being aggressive of dynamic. Has a grassy aroma with some light sweetness. Fruity, slightly acidic, with a caramel bready base.

name: Harbor City Mile Rock Amber Ale
review: Hazy light amber, abundant but loose beige head, decent lace. Aroma of pale malt with a bit of caramel. Bittersweet, malts have a bit of caramel, a bit of apple cider, no toffee or darker flavors. Some husky or crusty raw grain character, a bit oxidized on the finish. Bitter like orange peel. Carbonation plays a significant role in the flavor, though only a moderate one in the texture. Thin to medium body, somewhat spritzy.

name: Harbor City Mile Rock Amber Ale
review: 12oz bottle courtesy of mother in law. Lack luster aroma of malt. Amber body with white head. Flavor was sweet but bitter was more overpowering. Did belch after beer was finished and a caramel aftertaste was present. So the malt was there but didn’t show uo in aroma and flavor. Odd

name: Harbor City Mile Rock Amber Ale
review: 12 oz. bottle courtesy of Bockyhorsey - Pours a hazy amber color with a 1/2 finger thick light tan head. very light spotty lacing. Has a very light hop and carmel malt aroma. Flavor is hops, light esters, and a touch of malt. Light to medium body. A decent beer. Thanks Bill.

name: Harbor City Mile Rock Amber Ale
review: Big 20 beer tasting at Three Cellars Milwaukee. Good Hoppy ale. the carbonation is almost like champagne

name: Harbor City Mile Rock Amber Ale
review: Amber with thin white head. Aroma of light caramel, sweet malt and light fruit. Taste is more of the same wrapped up in a semi-thin body with a malty consistency. Finishes a little spicy.

name: Harbor City Mile Rock Amber Ale
review: 12oz bottle. Poured a clear medium orange color. Head was bubbly and off white. A bit of lace was left behind. Smelled of subdued cherry with a whiff of malt (ala chocolate and molasses). Light bodied and slightly sweet on the tongue. There was also a dash of salt. I tasted white paper, Ritz crackers, leather, and some milk chocolate. Carbonation was on the higher end of the spectrum. They must have forgotten to add the "assertive hops" to the boil, as there wasn’t much in the way of hop aroma or flavor. Not a good beer.

name: Harbor City Mile Rock Amber Ale
review: This beer poured nicely in a typical amber colour with a modest sized white head. Aroma was of light biscuity malts and subtle hops. Flavor was decent, soft caramel but finishes a little weak nonetheless.

name: Harbor City Mile Rock Amber Ale
review: Pours a thin amber color with a small head.Lots of malt and sweet caramel on the nose. Flavor was malty and semi sweet with a metallic tinge to it.The finish was kind of uninteresting. Nothing special here.

name: Harbor City Mile Rock Amber Ale
review: Had this beer on 9/18/2006. Aroma is a dry malt scent. Color is a nice golden with good carbonation and good tight head. Taste is bright and malty. Starting with a light medium body it goes down crisp with a mild sweet malt flavor coming on. The finish builds on this malt favor then end with just a faint bitterness. They lean to much on the malt and leave it a bit bland.

name: Harbor City Main Street Brown Ale
review: 12oz bottle. Toffee amber-brown color with a big foamy head. Sweet, nutty caramel aroma. Smooth and balanced, easy drinking. Medium bodied, light nutty malt tastes, mildly crisp. Middle of the road suits this style just fine. The hops display some great subtlety, but the malt is light and so-so. My type of session beer...I’ll be back.

name: Harbor City Main Street Brown Ale
review: Hazy amber, brownish color with a thin tan head and a lot of carbonation. Nutty aroma with a hint of maple. Slightly malty with a sweet flavor and hints of caramel, nuts and a bit of spice.

name: Harbor City Main Street Brown Ale
review: Large quickly dissipating tan head atop a brown clear liquid. Aroma of grainy yeast, maple and malt. Taste of maple, nuts and an over carbonated cola like candied taste. Semi-thin and not very good.

name: Harbor City Main Street Brown Ale
review: Mahogany is the best way to describe the colour of this beer. Like the colour of a walnut. touch of spice, otherwise plenty of caramel and nuts. well balanced, medium bodied, with a small head. Nice overall.

name: Harbor City Main Street Brown Ale
review: 12oz bottle. Poured a clear brown-orange color. the head was two fingers high and light tan with decent retention. A bit of lace was left behind. The aroma was subdued overall with whiffs of milk chocolate and roasted malt. Carbonation was on the higher end of the spectrum. Light to medium bodied and on the dry side. The flavors were as subtle as the aromas. I tasted a bit of adhesive tape and some thin papery malt, but that was it. Non-offensive to those who don’t care about beer, but a bit offensive to me. Eh.

name: Harbor City Main Street Brown Ale
review: I poured half the bottle and watched the head consume the top half of my glass. Once settled, the flavor was similar to other brown ales, like Newcastle.

name: Harbor City Main Street Brown Ale
review: 12oz bottle(5/01)-A dark ruby red body with w medium white head which dissipated rather quickly. Aroma of roasted malts and slight caramel. Taste of the same with some faint hops coming out. Not bad.

name: Harbor City Main Street Brown Ale
review: Picked up a single 12-oz bottle at Flanagan’s in Appleton, Wisconsin. Pours a clear reddish amber brew with a creamy thin white head that dissolves to a fine film and ring. Spotty lacing. Aroma of multi-grain malt, some flowery hops, roasted nuts and some caramel. Taste is lightly carbonated, medium bodied with flavors of roasted nuts, caramel malt and some citrus. Finish is slightly watery and dry with a sweet caramel aftertaste.

name: Harbor City Main Street Brown Ale
review: Seems many brown ales are criticized for being boring. This one is no exception. Brown, see-through color. Short, foamy head. Malty, sweet aroma with notes of caramel and some grain. Flavor starts sweet and stays sweet, though there is a slight tartness at the end. Lively carbonation for a clean finish.

name: Harbor City Main Street Brown Ale
review: Bottled. Poured clear iced tea brown with a short beige head. Aroma was airy and weak with mild chocolate notes and some grass.. other sweet malty notes, but nothing really did it for me. Flavor had semi-sweet chocolate and cola sweetness with mild grassy bitterness.. dry cola finish. Light-bodied and watery on the palate.. never felt good. Meh.

name: Harbor City Transcendental Wheat
review: Old notes. You really did need to be transcendental to get any of the matter in this one. Amber color with a somewhat fizzy head. Aromas of stomach acid, citrus, grass and old yeast. Flavors meld with the aromas, bringing together a matter that the mind and palate could not overcome. Acidic and sour, citric and oddly spiced. There was nothing refreshing about his one. Drain pour the last half of the bomber.

name: Huntington Beach Abbots Belgian Ale
review: Good, nice nose, great malt and hop balance. Found it a bit subdued, but quite good.

name: Huntington Beach Bolsa Chica Bitter
review: On tap @ HB Beer Co. Amber pour with a small off-white head. Grape juice and caramel on the nose. Grass, light herbs, and raisins. Flavor is very, very sweet. Grape juice, sugar, Kool Aid, and bubblegum. Raisin, some herbs, caramel, and bread. Meh.

name: Huntington Beach Bolsa Chica Bitter
review: Drinkable, I may have been off my feed that day as I remember and my notes say I getting a cold, but it was decent and a fair nose and a nice subdued hop bite.

name: Huntington Beach Brickshot Red
review: Tap at the brewpub. Pours dark amber with orange glints and a beige head. Aroma is pretty malty, but there’s a good deal of hop. There’s a chocolate aspect, but there’s enough old school hop to render it enjoyable. Malty, hoppy and bitter. Works nicely together.

name: Huntington Beach Brickshot Red
review: Draft. Subdued nose and carbonation. Medium red color. Rich malty flavor. Slightly bitter finish. Very smooth and drinkable, and goes well with food.

name: Huntington Beach Brickshot Red
review: 14th July 2014: large sample from the tap at the brewpub. I did not want any more. Looking at others thoughts on this site it would seem my offering was old or infected, needing taking off the bar because it was almost sour. Malty and red coloured yes, but not sweet or interesting, just ’iffy’ in everything. Only just managed to finish my sample it was that bad.

name: Huntington Beach Brickshot Red
review: Pours a clear amber red with nice head. Aroma is roasted malt with some hop bitterness on the back end of the sip. Medium mouth feel.

name: Huntington Beach Brickshot Red
review: Amber in color with an off-white head. Rather grassy aroma with some bread and toffee sweetness, a bit of caramel, and some floral hops. The flavor is mildly sweet with some caramel and toffee malt notes. Decent floral hop character, lots of grass, and a moderate bitterness, particularly on the finish.

name: Huntington Beach Brickshot Red
review: At the Brewhouse and sitting in the sun doesn’t help ther lack of carbonation.Definitely caramel malts shine through.Not terribly flavorful but a good session beer.Adequate,nothing special.

name: Huntington Beach Brickshot Red
review: Draught at the restaurant. Probably the better of the ales we tasted today. Not sure about the Irish Ale classification because it seemed more like a hoppier amber ale; good balance with the malt though.

name: Huntington Beach Brickshot Red
review: Clear copper color/ fleeting head. Leafy hop, caramel malt aromas. medium body. Same leafy hops in the flavor, along with rich spicy caramel. good

name: Huntington Beach Brickshot Red
review: ~Light caramel malt aroma. ~ Amber color with small white head. ~Rich caramel malty flavor with some chocolate and woody notes. ~Medium body, medium carbonation. Malty woodsy finish. ~Good amber. Very malty. Would be nice with more hops for better balance.

name: Huntington Beach Brickshot Red
review: A very solid irish ale. Smooth, nice body. Clean and crisp. Ruby pour, minimal head and lacing. Nice bitterness.

name: Huntington Beach California Lager
review: Golden pour with a white head. Bland aroma of grain, yeast, and grass. Maybe some floral hops, bread, and fruit. The flavor is kind of watery and sweet. Grain, bread, and very mild fruit. Grassy and floral hops, yeast, and a light bitterness on the finish.

name: Huntington Beach California Lager
review: Clean and very thirst queching with a decent nose and a nice bite, I liked it and I'm not normally into lagers.

name: Huntington Beach Main Street Wheat
review: Draught sample at the restaurant. From what I recall it was rather heavy on the banana and the malt. Rather cloudy pour too. Not bad just a little distance from being light and refreshing.

name: Huntington Beach Main Street Wheat
review: A little cloudy and yellow, with small head. Bready, citrus, a touch of banana. Rich and flavorful. I could drink another, but the 15th anniv. is on tap now also so that’s my next pint!!

name: Huntington Beach Main Street Wheat
review: I found it a bit weak?, not bad but a little off maybe. Malty and a little bit of bite, very disappointed.

name: Huntington Beach Pier Pale Ale
review: Shaker pint draft at Huntington Beer Company in Huntington Beach, California. The pour is a slight haze orange golden with a thin off white head. The aroma is soft floral with cereal malt. The taste is malt forward, cracker with a touch crystal, along with lemon and floral behind that. Solid, straight forward Pale Ale.

name: Huntington Beach Pier Pale Ale
review: Draft. Average nose and carbonation. Relatively weak flavor for an IPA. Clean finish. There are much better choices for an IPA.

name: Huntington Beach Pier Pale Ale
review: Draft at the Brewpub The APA poured a light amber with a small off white head. There was modest lacing. The aroma was lightly floral. The ale had a medium body and soft carbonation. This is great beer to watch the sun set on Walnut and Main. We were able to see the Huntington Beach pier from our seats in the outside section. In the back, hop bitterness takes hold, inducing a lasting swallow.

name: Huntington Beach Pier Pale Ale
review: A: The pour is a golden amber color with a thin white head topping it off. S: The hops are there, but like most of the other beers here, they’re grassy and rather unappealing. A bit of a citrus peel aroma does provide a bit of redemption. Unfortunately, there’s a weird, sweet fruitiness of grapes and some corn. T: Definitely a corn flavor to this, which really doesn’t belong in a pale ale. Bitter hops with more grass and a touch of pine. Some light breadiness and faint citrus peel flavors. M: Medium in body with a moderate carbonation. O: You’re not doing well if you can’t pull off a basic pale ale. And this one wasn’t executed well at all.

name: Huntington Beach Pier Pale Ale
review: This was a lighter version of the Indicator IPA. Pour is a light orange gold with a white head. Aroma is mostly flower hops with some malt character. Flavor is barely bitter. Finishes smooth.

name: Huntington Beach Pier Pale Ale
review: Fresh batch put on tap today. Brewer Greg says around 5%; not dry hopped. Centennial, Cascade, and Williamette hops. Gold color, significant white head of mixed size bubbles. Relatively light in the malt department with some bitter hops for flavor and in the finish.

name: Huntington Beach Pier Pale Ale
review: Tap @ Brewpub. Orange golden color with a laced white head. A pine hop aroma. Smooth with light malts and a touch of sweetness. Rating from 2005 notes.

name: Huntington Beach Pier Pale Ale
review: 22oz bottle poured a hazed amber color. The aroma had a bad Belgian yeast character that was definitely infected. Taste was the same with a very bad infection going on. Would have to try this again if it’s clean.

name: Huntington Beach Pier Pale Ale
review: Clear, light golden amber appearance, minimal foam. Lightly fragrant aroma. Palate is hoppy and biscuity, with slight tropical fruit tones in the middle and a mild bitterness in the finish.

name: Huntington Beach Pumpkin Head Ale 1
review: Ale 1 or Ale 2...not sure which but since no ratings on either, I’ll use Ale 1 and I assume they are the same beer, perhaps different batches. I’m not a fan of pumpkin beers but this one does a good job of balancing the pumpkin flavors and making it drinkable. Pour is a dark gold orange with an off white head. Flavor and aroma are all that you’d find in a pumpkin pie but they aren’t very strong, which is nice because if its strong, it doesn’t settle right for me.

name: Karl Strauss Endless Summer Gold
review: Heavier and sweeter than the light, not necessarily better. it was ok for what it is, but nothing to write home about :)

name: Karl Strauss Endless Summer Gold
review: Pours clear pale folden with a small white head. Aroma is weak malty hoppy as flavor too. Crisp and clean with subtile hoppy finish.

name: Karl Strauss Endless Summer Gold
review: 8 sept 2012, tap. Gold, clear, steady bubbles. Nose is dried straw malt. Thin/med body and fizzy. Tastes of straw and lager. Meh. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Karl Strauss Endless Summer Gold
review: bottle. premium lager?.....i guess. Nothing exciting here. pretty average golden lager. no real outstanding flavors or aromas. Pretty commercialized again Karl.

name: Karl Strauss Endless Summer Gold
review: Not a great beer at all, not terrible, I wouldnt buy it again. I was expecting substantially more. pretty bland but sessionable.

name: Karl Strauss Endless Summer Gold
review: cereal, grass, earthy, golden, clear, minimal head, light sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, light body, thin feel, average carbonation,

name: Karl Strauss Endless Summer Gold
review: On tap at the Costa Mesa, CA location. Poured a lighter to medium golden color with a small sized head. Aromas and tastes of light fruitiness with some citrus. Lighter and thinner aromas and tastes.

name: Karl Strauss Endless Summer Gold
review: Pale golden with a frothy white head. Salty celery and honey aroma. Light bodied. Taste is again light honey with celery. Crisp clean finish. Glad this summer is over.

name: Karl Strauss Endless Summer Gold
review: Sample at the Sorrento Valley location. The beer is a clear yellow-gold color with a thin white head that diminishes quickly. Spotty lacing. Light fruit and malt aroma. Light body with mild malt and hops flavors, along with a fruity undertone. The finish is lightly malty with a short hops aftertaste. Just average overall.

name: Karl Strauss Endless Summer Gold
