review: Very clean finish with a light hoppy aroma. Great beer for a day at the beach. Nice balance of sweet and sharp. Surprises me that they make this in a light!

name: Karl Strauss Light
review: Everything about this beer is light. Pours light gold with a foamy white head. Aroma is fruity and straw. Tastes pretty good. Light citrus and hops. Pretty good light beer.

name: Karl Strauss Light
review: Light is right. Pale golden color with a small foamy head. Slight fruity flavor. Very light.

name: Karl Strauss Light
review: Pale golden hue with a bubbly head. A light hoppy aroma and a touch fruity. A caramel flavor, a little grapefruit...refreshing.Decent for a light.

name: Karl Strauss Pilsener
review: Pours a nice gold with a generous white head. Aroma is grain and hop with slightly-detectable malt. Taste is grain with a crisp hop finish and barely-there sweetness. Remains crisp throughout, though nothing special.

name: Karl Strauss Pilsener
review: One of my personal Summer favorites. I believe they use to call it American Pilsner. ITs wonderful for parties. Very smooth and very crisp. Light and fulfilling. Women love it, saying, "Boy, this is Beer, This is really good"! I love its aroma, breadlike and with a very slight citrus hint.

name: Karl Strauss Pilsener
review: Cloudy golden appearance, moderate head formation. Malty sweet aroma. Malty sweet palate, pretty dry, mild peppery spice, slightly bitter/sour finish. Respectable pils.

name: Karl Strauss Pilsener
review: Light in color, light in flavor, easy to drink, nothing stands out about this brew.

name: Karl Strauss Pilsener
review: Must have not been that great, because I don't remember that well. Light gold color. Light in every way.

name: Karl Strauss Pilsener
review: Light bodied and colored. Sweet malty nose and a smooth semi-bitter finish. Not bad for a pilsener.

name: Karl Strauss Pilsener
review: Weak and bland. No real hops. The only real flavor is sweet malt which seemed badly misplaced here. A wreck of a beer.

name: Karl Strauss Pilsener
review: Very light golden color with a light head lacing on the surface. A little caramel and stale fruity aroma. A light caramel flavor...refreshing but, with an oily palate.

name: Karl Strauss Pilsener
review: Draught. Body is dark yellow. Aroma is lightly malty (grain, light bread), lightly hoppy (herbs). Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly bitter, lightly sweet. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. Too sweet and not much aroma.

name: Karl Strauss Pilsener
review: At Karl Strauss in Universal City, they had this named "America's Finest Pilsner". Yeah right. Light golden color, odorless, and tasteless.

name: Karl Strauss Red Trolley Ale
review: Clear bright amber under a thin ivory head. Light aroma with gentle biscuity malt and a touch of crystal. Crisp cool flavor that’s pale and crystal malty but pretty light and clean and delicate throughout.

name: Karl Strauss Red Trolley Ale
review: Purchased a six pack from Wal-Mart. Thick tan head on top of a clear amber body. It smells like sweet bread with a hint of toffy. It's very bubbly. The taste starts off sweet then becomes bitter on finish. Not an exceptional beer but a relief compared to all the IPAs I've had recently.

name: Karl Strauss Red Trolley Ale
review: Pours a clear light brown. Bready aroma. Taste is sweet but not overly. Brightly carbonated. Slightly toasted.

name: Karl Strauss Red Trolley Ale
review: Pours reddish-brown with a thin tan head. Aroma of sweet malt. Taste has rich malt notes and dark oak elements. Palate has a continuation of these woody elements along with slight hop notes. Earthy.

name: Karl Strauss Red Trolley Ale
review: Sample im Brewpub in San Diego. Rotes dunkles Bernstein, Klar. Aroma: Geröstetes Malz, Karamell, Honig Geschmack: Malz, Karamell, Rote Früchte, Rosinen. Keine Bitterkeit, Malzsüss

name: Karl Strauss Red Trolley Ale
review: Tap at a Restaurant near Old Town San Diego - clear amber color, white head. caramell, some toffee, some berries. nice.

name: Karl Strauss Red Trolley Ale
review: Looks better in a frosty glass than its actual taste. Not a lot to it but refreshing lunch beer.

name: Karl Strauss Red Trolley Ale
review: Very dissapointed with this IRA...poor character...better drink it cold....dull beer...

name: Karl Strauss Red Trolley Ale
review: Draft at the brewery in LA. Clear red with a minimal head. Aroma is nice, toffee, cherry. Flavor is sweet, red fruit. No bitterness. Medium body, smooth clean feel. Decent

name: Karl Strauss Red Trolley Ale
review: Sampled @ my one and only THT 2018. Nice reddish color, small white to off-white head. Smell and taste malts, caramel, caramelised sugars, honey, light piney, lightly sweet. Interesting.

name: Karl Strauss Minden Maibock
review: On tap; I think at PP. Poured an amber orange type color with an off white head. Aroma of sweet malt, caramel and maybe some fruit/caramel. Flavor was much of the same; and ok overall.

name: Karl Strauss Minden Maibock
review: Sample at the Universal City location. This beer pours a clear orange color with a medium thin off-white head that diminishes steadily to an outer ring. Top ring of lacing with spots underneath. Sweet malt aroma with some hops in the background. Light body with flavors of sweet caramel malt and lightly grassy hops. The finish is sweet malt with a short fruity finish. Slightly above average overall.

name: Karl Strauss Minden Maibock
review: A: The pour is a golden amber color with a short lived white head. S: A lightly sweet nose with plenty of bread. The hops are fairly grassy and "green". T: The flavor is somewhat light with bread, light molasses, and a bit of sweetness. Again, a very grassy and wild/green hop flavor. I just can’t quite find a better way to describe it, but it’s just odd. M: The body is medium with a low carbonation that I’m not sure is from the growler or just the way the beer is... D: Karl Strauss usually makes some good beers, but this is not one of them. Wouldn’t bother with this one.

name: Karl Strauss Minden Maibock
review: Draft. Amber beer with a cream colored head. Honey and malt aroma. Honey and malt flavor with light spice and light earth. Medium bodied. Honey and malt lingers with light spice.

name: Karl Strauss Minden Maibock
review: Clear golden with a medium white head. Malty aroma with hints of caramel and mild grassy hops. Flavour had malt, caramel and hints of grassy hops. Finished dry and slightly bitter.

name: Karl Strauss Minden Maibock
review: Taster@Sorrento Mesa Location: Light amber color with a wisp of off-white foam. Aroma is caramel sweet. Flavor starts caramel sweet followed by toffee and a soft bitterness in the finish. Medium body is kinda syrupy with moderate carbonation.

name: Karl Strauss Minden Maibock
review: Clear dark golden with a fizzy white head. Very sweet malty aroma and taste with grain vanilla and toffee finish.

name: Karl Strauss Minden Maibock
review: From the tap poured an amber color with a fair amount of head. Sweet malty flavor with a lingering aftertaste.

name: Karl Strauss Minden Maibock
review: On tap @ Karl Strauss. Pours medium gold with a small off white head. Nose was mostly baking spices with a light sweetness I couldn’t quite put my finger on. Flavor was much of the same, decent stuff.

name: Karl Strauss Minden Maibock
review: On tap at the brewery downtown San DIego. This was one of many on tap that I tasted and thought it was just ok.

name: Karl Strauss Cream Ale
review: the logo reminds me of the qauker oats guy,but he is your friend cuz he is handing you a beer.

name: Karl Strauss Eds Hoppy Birthday Brew
review: Backlog, from notes. On tap @ the brewpub (San Diego), 12 May 2001. A lager indeed, but doesn’t live up to its name: more malty than hoppy

name: Karl Strauss Eds Hoppy Birthday Brew
review: On tap of course. Clear golden color, some hops on the nose. Did not detect much in the way of spices as the description on the menu eluded to. Fairly light drinking but for the style I would say not too bad at all.

name: Karl Strauss Berliner Weiss
review: Draft. Clear pissy light yellow, white head. Mostly grain malt flavor, wheat, fairly dry, watery, very light tartness. Pretty weak sauce berliner weisse.

name: Karl Strauss Berliner Weiss
review: On tap at KS in La Jolla. Looks exactly like grapefruit juice even with the pulp. Slight grapefruit smell, seems like it can’t decide if it wants to be a sour, or something sweet (might be due to the raspberry artificial sweetener). Maybe the problem was that I was not given the choice to have the sweetener or keep it out since the server said it was part of the brew but honestly this was terrible. Avoid the sweetened version at all costs.

name: Karl Strauss Berliner Weiss
review: Draft. Amber beer with a whitish head. Tart and light citrus aroma. Sugary sweet flavor with tartness. Medium bodied. Sugary sweetness lingers with tartness.

name: Karl Strauss Berliner Weiss
review: Tap @ K&B. Pours a pale, cloudy straw yellow with a small white head. Slightly tart citrus nose with heavy wheat influence. Dry and crisp on the palate.

name: Karl Strauss Berliner Weiss
review: From the tap poured a straw color with a good amount of head. Malty flavor with a quick finish. Or with the raspberry syrup a slight raspberry flavor finish.

name: Karl Strauss La Jolla Hefeweiss
review: Tried at Disney’s California Adventureland, served in a transparent, flimsy YELLOW plastic tumbler. Wonder what the REAL colour of this might be? And, the server tossed in a slice of lime before I could stop her. However, this wasn’t half bad. Smallish white head, aroma of (mostly) the lime, but taste and mouthfeel were not objectionable. Next time, no lime and a proper glass, please.

name: Karl Strauss La Jolla Hefeweiss
review: Soapy, clouded, hazy wit-like body with a small bubbly white head. Clove-banana nose and strong coriander/orange peel flavor. Very assertive and fragrant. Nice!

name: Karl Strauss Marzen
review: On tap at the brewery. Pours a clear copper with small off white head. The aroma is toasted malt and biscuit. Thin body, spice, bread, raisin, light finish, decent.

name: Karl Strauss Marzen
review: Poured at Sac Beerfest. Really blah Marzen. How many characters can I get away with? ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Karl Strauss Marzen
review: On tap at beerfest. Color is golden copper. Has a popcorn taste. Sweet not very good..

name: Karl Strauss Marzen
review: @brewery on tap-pours gold/amber with a white head. Aroma is soft sweet light/medium malt-caramel. Taste is floral/spice hops, sweet light/medium malt-caramel.

name: Karl Strauss Extra Special Bitter
review: Good beer. Pours hazy, light copper with medium, white head that leaves rings of lace. Smells rich and caramelly malty with some underlying earthy hops. Tastes sweet and sugary, caramelly malty but not overly sweet with a strong earthy hop backbone, light bitterness. Medium body, vibrant carbonation.

name: Karl Strauss Extra Special Bitter
review: Taster from Sorrento Mesa location: Light haze copper color with an off-white head. Aroma is light grain and caramel. Flavor starts light caramel malt that is kinda nutty with a lingering lightly dry sort of citrus bitterness in the finish. Medium body is smooth with moderate carbonation.

name: Karl Strauss Extra Special Bitter
review: Appearance: Pours a yellow gold with a reddish tint. Leaves a 1/4 inch of foamy white head. Aroma: Faint sweet bread notes and Eurohops. Taste: Surprising big spicy bitterness finishing with sweet bready malt. Mouthfeel: Thin and fizzy. Overall: Really frickin good, great bitterness and easy drinking.

name: Karl Strauss Extra Special Bitter
review: Tap @ Hamilton’s. Pretty much your standard ESB. Pours a clear light amber color with a small off white head. Nose of light citrus, spice, and toasted malts. Crisp finish, not bad.

name: Karl Strauss Extra Special Bitter
review: Tap at Carlsbad. Pours a translucent golden amber with a medium creamy white head that laced. Aroma of nice floral and citrus notes, bready, caramel and nuts. Flavor of lemon, hops, caramel, bready and light toffee notes.

name: Karl Strauss Extra Special Bitter
review: Tap, downtown. Amber in color. Fairly malty flavored, with a bit of English hoppiness.

name: Karl Strauss Extra Special Bitter
review: draft - Pours orange/amber with a one finger head and a sweet malt aroma mixed with light hops. The flavor is heavy caramel malt with some fruity bitterness on the side. This medium bodied beer is a solid ESB.

name: Karl Strauss Extra Special Bitter
review: On tap at karl strauss San Diego. Poured amber with a good amount of head. Nice bitter flavor with a good finish.

name: Karl Strauss Extra Special Bitter
review: Mild sweet toffee aroma. Metallic somewhat, but not much else in terms of aroma. Pours burnt orange with a beige head. There are definitley hops prevalent in the flavor. Some grapefruit and tropical fruit. Caramel and toffee are there too. Finishes dry and resiny. It sweetens as it warms up, but still finishes dry. A nice hoppy ESB.

name: Karl Strauss Extra Special Bitter
review: On tap at Karl Strauss. Golden yellow with no head. Malt, candy, and citrus aroma. Candy sweet taste with a hint of ftruit, and a bitter/swet finish.

name: Karl Strauss Hortons Hootch
review: Tap - Karl Strauss has made a nice golden beer with a smooth, malty taste. The alcohol is just enough to be a bit warming and is fairly well masked. The flavor could stand to be a bit more aggressive, but it’s good.

name: Karl Strauss Hortons Hootch
review: Pours a gold color with a nice sized off-white head. Aroma is grainy and brewery-ish. Alcohol in the nose as well. Flavor is malty but little else to note. Alcohol is prevalant. Smooth body. Decent.

name: Karl Strauss Hortons Hootch
review: Best thing about this one is that it's high in alcohol. Good malty body for a copper beer. And I mean new copper like you see at Home Depot before the plumber gets his doped up hands all over it. Great yeast this brewery has, adds a griany/butterscotchy flavor that I love.

name: Karl Strauss Oktoberfest Beer
review: Taster On tap at The Brewpub, Downtown San Diego. Dark Golden with little white head. Malts, hops, yeast, grain, sweetness.

name: Karl Strauss Oktoberfest Beer
review: Draft at the brewery in LA. Clear bright copper with a lacy white head. Aroma is grainy, caramel, light. Flavor is sweet, caramel, grainy like a Vienna/Wiener lager. Medium light feel, average carbonation. Meh for style and beer in general.

name: Karl Strauss Oktoberfest Beer
review: 12oz bottle into a glass tankard at my daughters place in Orange County, California on 8th Dec 2017. Almost clear, deep amber body, the full white crown, sadly left the scene very quickly to leave a headless body. Malty front with a semi-sweetness throughout. A slight hop bitterness tries to balance out the malty molasses but they do not quite make it. My sweet tooth liked it very much, pity about the head!

name: Karl Strauss Oktoberfest Beer
review: Taster Brewpub. Sorry, didn't rate this at all. Soft appearance, soft aroma, soft taste. Just all round soft and lacking in anything distinguishing. Nope.

name: Karl Strauss Oktoberfest Beer
review: Draft. Pours orange with a white head. Bready malts, a little floral bitterness, and mild lingering sweetness. Pretty good.

name: Karl Strauss Oktoberfest Beer
review: Pours a clear golden brown from the bottle with fluffy white head that dissipates slowly to leave good lace. Aroma of mild caramel malts and earthy nuttiness. Taste is more mild than the nose, but pleasant and crushable for the style. Solid.

name: Karl Strauss Oktoberfest Beer
review: Pour is a hazy tan with a large white head. Aroma is a light sweet but toasted malt. Flavor is the same. A slight sweet malt with a little toasted bready malt. This beer has a horrible rating on here but other than being a bit light all around I could not find any fault with this.

name: Karl Strauss Oktoberfest Beer
review: Draft Pint in USA in Oct 2015 - Amber Gold in colour. Toasty bready malts, caramel, hint of nuts. Grassy spicy hops. Sweet malty and lightly spicy. Easy drinking. I liked it (enough to have a second). (2015-10)

name: Karl Strauss Oktoberfest Beer
review: Backlog entry: I had this one at the brewery. It’s a solid beer, nothing too unusual or stand-out.

name: Karl Strauss Oktoberfest Beer
review: Bottle. It pours a golden orange color with a small off white head. The aroma has solid toasted malt and hints of earthy, woody hops. Bready and toasted. The flavor is the same. Bready, toasted with hints of cooked squash. Very light hints of earthy hops and barely perceptible bitterness. Light bodied. Pretty standard, but well attenuated. A bit above average.

name: Karl Strauss Oatmeal Stout
review: Black pour with a khaki head. Roasted malt, soap, and water on the nose. Some char, hints of chocolate, and old coffee, too. The flavor is a little bitter, and also watery, soapy, and chalky. A bit acidic, some roasted malt, light chocolate, and coffee. Not terribly pleasant.

name: Karl Strauss Oatmeal Stout
review: Beer #2 in a flight. Dark poor, but rather thin still. Some toasted malt in the flavor, and smooth. Description says moderate bitterness, but this one must have gone to counseling, as it was rather calm, and even had a touch of sweetness at the end.

name: Karl Strauss Oatmeal Stout
review: Not a great beer at all, not terrible, I wouldnt buy it again. I was expecting substantially more. on tap at strauss sorento, pretty decent, no real aroma, decent body, but a tad thin and bland.

name: Karl Strauss Oatmeal Stout
review: On Tap at Karl Strauss Restaurant at Universal City. Served in a english pint glass ABV 5%. Opaque deep brown/black with nitro C02 mix allowed to settle into a rather attractive creamy head. Choc/Cocoa and sweet malt aromas on the nose. Roasty flavours then added on the palate post tasting. Carbonation is smooth and the mouthfeel is light and creamy with an excellent not so dry finish (for this dry stout). Quite a lovely beer on tap. Would enjoy again if the chance arose.

name: Karl Strauss Oatmeal Stout
review: On tap at the Brewery Gardens in Sorrento Mesa. Black as can be with a dense nitro head. This honestly tasted more like an oatmeal porter than an oatmeal stout. The body was much too thin for a stout, but this was still a really good beer. Of course I might be biased as porter is one of my favorite styles. Good roasty notes and flavor overall.

name: Karl Strauss Oatmeal Stout
review: Pours cloudy, dark brown with a creamy, resilient, offwhite head that leaves sheet lace. Smells of mellow, dark, roasted malts. Tastes lightly roasty and malty, watery. Some dishwater as well. Medium, watery body and smooth carbonation.

name: Karl Strauss Oatmeal Stout
review: On tap at Karl Strauss at the La Jolla location (San Diego, CA): Pours out dark brown and see through, topped with a thin head that lasted for maybe a minute. Nice aroma of toasted chocolate malts, caramel, and oatmeal. But then how is the overall taste so watery? Creamy texture with a smooth roasted flavor in the beginning, but that clearly didn’t last. Bittersweet finish. Drinkability: Overrated. Pairing: Meat pie. Rebuy: Needs a rerate. #314 on 01032010, DG.

name: Karl Strauss Oatmeal Stout
review: On tap at Karl Strauss Carlsbad. Creamy nitro tan head. Brown color. Very light watery flavor. Easy to drink, but bland. No aroma. Not bad though.

name: Karl Strauss Oatmeal Stout
review: From tap at Solana Beach. Pours dark brown to black with a small tan head. Aroma is dark roasted malt. Light liqourice note. Dark roasted and smooth malty flavoured. Bitter and dry roasted. Smooth and roasted malt flavoured finish, light roasted.

name: Karl Strauss Oatmeal Stout
review: On tap, opaque black with a small tan head. Aroma is coffee ‘n’ cream, browned oats. Flavor has a nutty, well-rounded sweetness, offset slightly by roasted flavors. Palate is slick, lightly carbonated. A bit subdued for the style, but still perfectly drinkable.

name: Karl Strauss StrausStout
review: Dark brown with a medium beige and creamy head. Sweet aroma with hard roasted malt, coffee and dark chocolate. Flavour had hard roasted and slightly burned malt, coffee, liquerice and hints of dark chocolate. Finished sweet.

name: Karl Strauss StrausStout
review: Draft. Black beer with a tan head. Coffee and roast aroma. Coffee and roast flavor with light chocolate. Medium bodied. Coffee and roast lingers with light chocolate. Big coffee presence.

name: Karl Strauss StrausStout
review: SD trip, Karl Strauss LaJolla, sampler, had these while having a larger DIPA, flavors and ratings may be rough: The description here says "Retired" but this is clearly what I was told was the special selection on the sampler; perhaps it has been brought out of retirement for another run. That said this dark brew has strong coffee and black malt nose; flavor is black burnt malts. Nothing too exciting.

name: Karl Strauss StrausStout
review: Taster@Sorrento Valley location: Jet black with a small tan head. Aroma is chocolaty with a hint of coffee. Flavor starts chocolaty sweet followed by a light coffee bitter finish. Light to medium body is smooth with moderate carbonation. Much improved over the sample I had a couple of years ago.

name: Karl Strauss StrausStout
review: Nitro at San Diego Brewing Company. Nice black pour with tight bubbled head. Aroams were some chocolate. Flavors were watery, but there was hints of roasted bitter coffee. Just OK

name: Karl Strauss StrausStout
review: Aroma of coffee and chocolate. Beer pours almost black. Flavor is more coffee, chocolate, and suprisingly crisp hops. This is a relatively lighter styled stout. It is also very carbonated and bitey on the palate. It is definitley a pleasant offering from this fine brewery.

name: Karl Strauss StrausStout
review: I had this on draft at Karl Strauss in Costa Mesa, CA. nice roasty aroma and slightly sweet flavor, this was a very drinkable stout. Not bad..

name: Karl Strauss StrausStout
review: Draught at Karl Strauss La Jolla: Dark black, nose of char and sweet licorice oatmeal. The flavor is almost sweet with some tart and astringent qualities. Finishes lightly hoppy with a harsh metallic note. Decent sweet stout.

name: Karl Strauss StrausStout
review: Black as night, smoky taste. My notes aren't very good for this one, just not a very memorable beer.

name: Karl Strauss StrausStout
review: After having th oatmeal stout, I thought this would be a bigger better brew, but it was one of the worst stouts i've had on tap. Do not get this if you are at the resturant. Not drinkable.

name: Ochakovo Premium Svetloe
review: "Very light golden appearance. Poured a thick foamy head but cleared up to leave a thin layer. Good carbonation, next to no lacing. Not very hoppy. has a bit of a sweet aftertaste. A bit on the watery side. Grainy aroma as well as flavour. Pretty average. Hardly premium."

name: Ochakovo Premium Svetloe
review: Ljusgul i färgen, vitt skum. Doftar malt gräs, hö, papper, typisk unken ton. Smakar lite unken malt, papper, gräs, lite citrus och liten bäska i avslutningen.

name: Ochakovo Premium Svetloe
review: pours yellow amber with slight carbonation. very mild corn, grass, hay nose. flavor is slightly malty with balanced hops. has a generally weak character but absolutely not offensive. mouthfeel is dry yet refreshing. i was expecting crap but found a very drinkable brew.

name: Ochakovo Premium Svetloe
review: bottle, pour a bright yellow, aroma is corny and flavour is so as well, the finish was fairly harsh and not terribily enjoyable

name: Ochakovo Premium Svetloe
review: Pretty plain and bland. Toasty and skunky hay is the aroma. the taste is simple, and mostly smooth and with a slight sharpness, but generally lacking substance.

name: Ochakovo Premium Svetloe
review: Bottle, at Christina and Camillo’s house-- Happy 72nd birthday Camillo! This was standard lager appearance, not much to describe there. The palate was clean, and I like that I found no stinky adjuncts here. I also like that the pale malts were not overly sweet. The hops could have been a little more prevalent, but coming from Russia, I’m pretty sure freshness was not helping the hop situation. Overall I preferred this lager over anything brewed in our macro market in Canada by a longshot.

name: Ochakovo Premium Svetloe
review: Aroma: Cereal, toast and bread. Light hoppy aroma of floral/herbs. Appearance: Pale, lightly golden clear with a minimal head. Taste: Sweet and lightly sour. Palate: light body, thin texture, average carbonation and a long sweet finish. Overall surprising, i was expecting a much worst taste.

name: Ochakovo Premium Svetloe
review: 0,5l bottle(5,3%). Very pale yellow color, bubbly. Small white head. Grain, malty aroma. Sweet, malty flavor.

name: Ochakovo Premium Svetloe
review: Pours a light golden color. Smell is of malts, slightly sweet. Taste is crisp, malts and grains, some sweetness. Overall a tasty and enjoyable lager.

name: Ochakovo Premium Svetloe
review: Bottle. Golden with quickly dissipating head. Malty and soapy aroma, watery taste.

name: EuroBrand
review: As common as the Euro and as aesthetically attractive. I remember the Guilder used to be such a colourful and cheerful style of currency. This one is now a dour uninspring and totally fake replica of whatever a beer is, just like the euro. Good thing that it cost something close to that denomination as it isn’t worth any more than that.

name: EuroBrand
review: I can't believe this has so few ratings, it seems like you can get it anywhere around here. A decent lager, smooth and the taste wasn't so bad.

name: EuroBrand
review: First off - cheap - generic looking TV studio label - were there no artists available in Holland? Were they on strike? Anyway - back to the beer. Bit of a wort-like aroma to it that I have witnessed in other beers such as Bavaria's NA. Medium golden appearance with little to no head. Malty flavor with a bit of a biscuity taste to it. The malty twang is what makes this beer stand above some of the other boring Euro lagers. Not bad.

name: EuroBrand
review: Malty brew, lightly sweet like graham crackers. Reminded me some of a Carribean or Eastern European lager. Terrible appearance marks for the green bottle, and the name, which is like some bad translation. The beer itself is unremarkable medium gold. A little tinny in the finish. I was in dire fear of something with such a generic name, but it actually turned out decently.

name: EuroBrand
review: An interesting Heineken taste-alike. Decent and non-skunked, thankfully! Crisp with a flavor remarkably reminiscent of..........Heineken.

name: Polander Beer
review: pours pale golden with a small white head, malty aroma and taste nothing special, its a little hoppy and bitter, id say its an average boring beer.

name: Polander Beer
review: I have a friend that goes to visit his mother who lives in Perth Amboy, NJ and he brings me all these weird foriegn beers. Thin white head and it was a light gold. I don’t know. I have had this beer a million times before it was just in various bottles. It tasted exactly like any other beer of its style from central or eastern Europe. Nothing new and exciting here. There’s no reason for me to really tell you what it’s like. Tastes like every other Polish or Russian beer. It’s not good and it’s not bad. It’ll work.

name: Polander Beer
review: Thin head which does not last long. Color is a medium gold and is slightly hazy. Aroma of hops and malt but nothing fancy. Taste is a little bland but not offensive with more malts. Finish is a little dry and bitter from the hops. You could do much worse than this.

name: Polander Beer
review: Smells of stale beer, corn syrup and pickles. Color is yellow with a slight haze. Taste is like a regular mass produced american beer, but not at all watery.

name: Polander Beer
review: Crisp is right-o on this one, but I'm glad...at least it's not sickly sweet or with obvious adjuncts. A fair lager. Nice little nose to it.

name: Polander Beer
review: Gold color with a very nice floral aroma, its a well balanced beer..........

name: Polander Beer
review: I'm not really into this beer, even if it's from Poland. Sort of pale and unassuming. It's probably better to drink in the summer, as it's crisp and very light bodied.

name: Polander Beer
review: Hmm, new beer from Poland (that first time in few months). Very weak head, pale lager. Aromas were not too special, some malt. Reminds me of those South American beers that I had few days ago, slightly more creamy.

name: Polander Beer
review: Hazy light gold; grainy, sour apple, raspberry on the nose; palate is light, maybe 25 IBUs, slightly herbal with a hint of grass.

name: Polander Beer
review: Simple, with a nice sharp dry flavor. Pale yellow and not very exciting. Another boring lager.

name: New Holland Paleooza
review: 355ml bottle at the House of Belgium, Xiamen. Pours hazy golden yellow with a white head. Aroma of pine with citrus. Malt pine taste. A little unpleasant. Bitter finish.

name: New Holland Paleooza
review: Bottle, Ann Arbor, MI. Gold, slight haze. Honey resin aroma. Some citrus. Bready. Citrus. Muted balanced finish.

name: New Holland Paleooza
review: Draft. Golden body with frothy white head. Aroma of toasted grain, floral hops, grapefruit, citrus, light grass. The flavor is moderately sweet and lightly bitter. It finishes lightly to moderately sweet and lightly to moderately bitter. Medium body, watery/sticky texture, lively carbonation. Taste of light grapefruit and citrus with a lingering bitterness. Easy drinking.

name: New Holland Paleooza
review: On tap at Hopcat. Crisp pale but not super hot you in the mouth bitter. Wish there was more. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: New Holland Paleooza
review: Hoppier smell, but lighter, taste is more hoppy than malt but smooth and not too bitter...fairly mellow...citrusy hops..very light orange, straightforward

name: New Holland Kourage
review: 12 ounce bottle into signature pint glass, bottled on 5/15/2017. Pours lightly hazy/cloudy deep reddish/copper/light brown color with a 1-2 finger dense and rocky cream colored head with fantastic retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lasts. Thick soapy lacing clings on the glass, with a fair amount of streaming carbonation. Fantastic appearance. Aromas of caramel, brown sugar, brown bread dough/crust, nuts, and toasted biscuit; with lighter notes of chocolate, cocoa, coffee, toffee, dark fruit, herbal, floral, grass, pepper, and yeast/roast/toasted earthiness. A bit too fruity/yeasty aromas, but not overwhelming. Nice aromas with good balance and complexity of dark/bready/light roasted malts, and light-moderate earthy hop/fruity yeast notes; with good strength. Taste of big caramel, brown sugar, brown bread dough/crust, nuts, and toasted biscuit; with lighter notes of chocolate, cocoa, coffee, toffee, dark fruit, herbal, floral, grass, pepper, and yeast/roast/toasted earthiness. Light herbal, floral, grassy, peppery hop; and roasted bitterness on the finish. Lingering notes of caramel, brown sugar, brown bread dough/crust, nuts, toasted biscuit, chocolate, cocoa, coffee, toffee, dark fruit, herbal, floral, grass, pepper, and yeast/roast/toasted earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Very nice complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/bready/light roasted malts, light-moderate earthy hops, and light fruity yeast flavors; with a great hop/roast bitter/sweet balance; and no cloying/astringent flavors after the finish. Lightly increasing dryness from lingering hop/roast bitterness. Medium carbonation and body; with a very smooth, moderately creamy/bready/grainy, and lightly sticky/chalky mouthfeel that is great. Zero warming alcohol for 6%. Overall this is a delicious American brown ale. All around nice complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/bready/light roasted malts, light-moderate earthy hops, and light fruity yeast flavors; very smooth and easy to drink with the mellowly bitter/drying finish. Not overly roasty. Nicely rich and well rounded malt complexity; nice earthy hop balance, and mild fruity yeast presence. A very enjoyable offering, and spot on style example. Glad I was able to try it from the anniversary pack.

name: New Holland Kourage
review: Sweet molasses smell. Dark translucent brown pour with thick foamy head. Sweet on the tongue, a little roasty. Thin, watery body.

name: New Holland Kourage
review: Draft sample at NH Brewpub. Poured a clear dark brown color with an average frothy light brown head that mostly lasted with excellent lacing. Moderate to heavy toasted nutty malt aroma. Medium to full body with a smooth sticky texture and flat carbonation. Medium to heavy toasted sweet flavor with a medium to heavy sweet finish of moderate to long duration. Complex solid brew.

name: New Holland Kourage
review: On tap at New Holland Brewpub. Dark brown with a creamy tan crown and a ring of lace. Aroma of roasted malts, nuts, darker malts and some light cocoa. Taste is dark and tasty with roasted malt, nuts, chocolate and a semi-chalky and metallic finish. Decent but a bit too metallic as it warmed.

name: New Holland Kourage
review: Sample at New Holland. Clear brown pour with a medium beige head. Caramel malt nose with a bit of hop and a hint of cognac. Caramel malt flavor with a hint of smoke and pear before a hoppy finish. Pretty solid.

name: New Holland Kourage
review: Very dark colored beer. Thin head and a aroma of malt and nuts. The flavor was good with a hint of sweet malt and nuts, maybe a touch of chocolate, and nice hoppy finish. Really ingulfs the mouth when drinking this semi thick brew.

name: New Holland Kourage
review: really not that good. Ive had much better. like......miller high life to be exact.

name: New Holland Kourage
review: On tap at New Holland. Deep sanguine red-brown body (probably the darkest brown ale I’ve tried), thin off-white head. Light aroma (I hate it when brewpubs serve their beers too cold), grainy and toasty/nutty. Flavor was very chocolatey and nutty with some raosted toasty aspects, kind of winey/grapey and woody. Has a tannin-heavy mouthfeel that coats the mouth. Just a touch of dark fruits before the long, roasted bitter finish.

name: New Holland Kourage
review: Dark pint, from brewpub tapper. Light nutty nose and some bitterness. First taste is faint with coffee, hazlenut and cream. Fluffy body,and taste is decent enough to enjoy a full pint of.

name: New Holland Kourage
review: Dark brown,with a decent,khaki head. Good retention and lace.Little nutty,coffee,hops in aroma.Aroma seems pretty empty.Mouthfeel is creamy.Pretty big body.Plenty of nutty,roasty,light coffee flavors.Finish lingers not overly done with hops.Not bad,worth a try.

name: New Holland The Poet
review: Thick creamy light brown head stayed on a black still body. Berry, aniseed, lactose & malt aroma. Medium bodied, soft, oily & creamy on the tongue with a clean back. Demerara, roasted, chocolate, liquorice, bonfire toffee, malt & nutty tastes with a tangy, slightly citrus finish.

name: New Holland The Poet
review: 12 oz bottle. Pours a red brown with a pencil thin fast dissipating tan head. Sweet scents of malt and chocolate. Sweet and malty with a fizzy mouthfeel and astringent finish. Doesn’t all work together as well as you would like.

name: New Holland The Poet
review: Aardige oatmeal stout van New Holland brewing uit Michigan. 5,8% alcohol. Net iets te flauw.

name: New Holland The Poet
review: From the bottle. No head. Barely any aroma. But delicious. Roast malt. Sweet but not too much. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: New Holland The Poet
review: Bottle. Color: Black, beige head. Aroma: Sweetish roasted malt. Taste: Smooth, roasted malt, notes of coffee, mocha and light hints of chocolate. Creamy mouthfeel. Long lasting roasted malt finish with moderrate bittery palate. Medium sweet, light bitterness. Medium body, below average carbonation. Nice oatmeal stout.

name: New Holland The Poet
review: Botella de 355 ml adquirida en Gastrópolis, Zaragoza. Color negro, espuma marrón clara que se disipa rápidamente, poca retención. Aromas a frutos secos, café y chocolate. Textura oleosa, densa. En boca, suave, demasiado. Notas a avellanas y nueces, café, cereal tostado y caramelo.

name: New Holland The Poet
review: Bottle poured into a globe glass on 11/23/18. Black color and a fizzy brown head. Aroma of chocolate liquor, roasted malt, a hint of coffee. Initial taste is roasted malt, oats, and a hint of chocolate. Aftertaste continues that theme and is well-balanced. Carbonation is a little high with a smooth, medium-heavy body. Nicely done!

name: New Holland The Poet
review: Bottle from De Drankenmarkt. Aroma is roasty malts with notes of chocolate and hints of coffee. Rich malt profile, mild bittersweet flavour. Body is medium. Good stuff.

name: New Holland The Poet
review: Nothing really doing it for me with this stout. About average. Carbonation a little high for the style, which messed up the feel a bit. Sweet chocolate malt was ok. Balance towards the sweet side. Might be better on tap or perhaps sitting in bottle too long. Not a bad beer, just sort of forgettable.

name: New Holland The Poet
review: pretty burnt and roasty for an oatmeal stout. not really what i was expecting. its still really good either way

name: New Holland Mad Hatter Ale (-2015)
review: Bottle Orangish color, white head, some retention and lacework. Aroma with notes of resin hops and grapefruit. Flavor with a decent bitterness, grapefruit and orange zest. Bittery final with dry mouthfeel.

name: New Holland Mad Hatter Ale (-2015)
review: From the bottle. Solid malt back bone. Yeasty apricots on the nose. Amber hue. Solid

name: New Holland Mad Hatter Ale (-2015)
review: From Apr 2008 My first New Holland beer, thanks to joe1510. Thanks Joe! This one pours a slightly hazy orange gold with a 1 finger head of foam and some decent lacing. Head retention is average...just a fine broken layer after a few minutes. The smell is fairly light to me. Some citrus, some caramel malt. The taste has notes of caramel malt, citrus, pine, and earthy hops, and finishes with a bitter bite. Mouthfeel seems to be medium, carbonation is also medium. Interesting flavours here but I don't feel a real harmony going on with the malt and hops. It just seems a bit rough for my tastes but I'm glad I got a chance to try it.

name: New Holland Mad Hatter Ale (-2015)
review: Very good India pale ale. Nice malt level. Slight oxidation may be due to age of sample? Good beer. EnJoinable. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: New Holland Mad Hatter Ale (-2015)
review: Backlog, 12 oz bottle with an orange appearance and cloudy white head. Smell and flavor of bitter centennial hop, pine, honey, malt, and resinous oranges. Medium in body and mouthfeel. Some grass as it warms. Not bad for off the shelf.

name: New Holland Mad Hatter Ale (-2015)
review: Solid IPA; great logo and packaging. Nothing overwhelming about the taste. Hoppy and bold but a bit too much aftertaste imo.

name: New Holland Mad Hatter Ale (-2015)
review: Backlog from old phone notes. Orange to amber in appearance with a white head. Aroma and flavor of pine, citrus fruits and light resinous hops. Decent IPA overall.

name: New Holland Mad Hatter Ale (-2015)
review: Hazy orange brown color, citrus and melon aroma. Grassy and orange flavor with a cantaloupe finish. Full body with almost chewy texture ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: New Holland Mad Hatter Ale (-2015)
review: Pours orange with white head. Not much on the nose. Pine, grapefruit to taste with a bitter finish. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: New Holland Mad Hatter Ale (-2015)
review: Nice amber/orange color; Medium body; Aroma of yeast, nice floral hops, & citrus; Flavor of caramel malt, floral hops, grain, and citrus; Finish is fairly bitter; Nicely balanced; Different - pretty good IPA.

name: New Holland Jubilee
review: 12 ounce bottle into tulip glass, bottled on 5/12/2017. Pours lightly hazy/cloudy golden orange/amber color with a 1 finger fairly dense off white head with good retention, that reduces to a thin spotty lace cap that lingers. Nice spotty soapy lacing clings on the glass, with a light amount of streaming carbonation. Aromas of big juicy/tart/tangy cherries, fruit skin/pits, peach, pear, plum, apricot, lemon, orange, melon, red apple, red grape/wine, peppercorn, honey, candi sugar, lightly toasted bread, herbal, floral, grass, and yeast earthiness. Damn nice aromas with great balance and complexity of fruity/spicy yeast, cherries, candi sugar, pale malt, and light earthy hop notes; with great strength. Taste of big juicy/tart/tangy cherries, fruit skin/pits, peach, pear, plum, apricot, lemon, orange, melon, red apple, red grape/wine, peppercorn, honey, candi sugar, lightly toasted bread, herbal, floral, grass, and yeast earthiness. Light-moderate peppery yeast spiciness, fruit tang/tartness; and light herbal/grassy bitterness on the finish. Lingering notes of tart/tangy cherries, fruit skin/pits, peach, pear, plum, apricot, lemon, orange, melon, red apple, red grape/wine, peppercorn, honey, candi sugar, lightly toasted bread, herbal, floral, grass, and yeast earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Awesome complexity, robustness, and balance of fruity/spicy yeast, cherries, candi sugar, pale malt, and light earthy hop flavors; with a great malt/bitterness and tart/tangy fruit balance; with no cloying/puckering flavors after the finish. Light-moderate increasing dryness from spiciness and tart/tangy fruit. Medium carbonation and medium-plus body; with a very smooth, moderately creamy/bready/grainy, acidic/tangy fruit, and lightly sticky balanced mouthfeel that is great. Mildly increasing warmth of 9.8% after the finish. Overall this is an awesome fruited Belgian strong pale ale. All around great complexity, robustness, and balance of fruity/spicy yeast, cherries, candi sugar, pale malt, and light earthy hop flavors; very smooth and dangerously easy to sip with the mellowly spicy/acidic/tangy/drying finish. Very juicy/jammy cherries and balanced Belgian yeast complexity; with a great candi sugar/pils malt backbone. Well attenuated, not overly sweet/heavy for the ABV from lingering dryness. A really enjoyable offering, and spot on style example.

name: New Holland Jubilee
review: Part of a throwback variety 6-pack. Clear red-ish pour, showing off the cherry. light bubbly head.mild cherry whet aroma. Big tart cherry taste. Not necessarily great, but big. I'm not a fan of this one.

name: New Holland Zoomer Wit
review: 12 ounce bottle into signature pint glass, bottled on 5/15/2017. Pours fairly hazy medium golden yellow color with a 2 finger fairly dense and rocky off white head with fantastic retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lasts. Thick soapy lacing clings on the glass, with a fair amount of streaming carbonation. Fantastic appearance. Aromas of lemon, orange peel, peach, pear, red apple, peppercorn, clove, light banana/bubblegum, wheat, cracker, white bread, herbal, floral, grass, and yeast earthiness. Nice and pleasant aromas with good balance and complexity of fruity/spicy yeast, orange peel, and pale/wheat malt notes; with solid strength. Taste of lemon, orange peel, peach, pear, red apple, peppercorn, clove, light banana/bubblegum, wheat, cracker, white bread, herbal, floral, grass, and yeast earthiness. Mild herbal, floral, grassy bitterness; peppery yeast spiciness; and wheat tang/tartness on the finish. Lingering notes of emon, orange peel, peach, pear, red apple, peppercorn, clove, light banana/bubblegum, wheat, cracker, white bread, herbal, floral, grass, and yeast earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Very nice complexity, robustness, and balance of fruity/spicy yeast, orange peel, and pale/wheat malt flavors; with a nice malt/bitter/spiciness balance, and no cloying/astringent flavors after the finish. Lightly increasing dryness from lingering bitter/spiciness. Medium carbonation and light-medium body; with a very smooth, moderately creamy/bready/grainy, and lightly sticky mouthfeel that is great. Zero warming alcohol as expected of 4.7%. Overall this is a delicious witbier. All around nice complexity, robustness, and balance of fruity/spicy yeast, orange peel, and pale/wheat malt flavors; very smooth and refreshing to drink with the mildly bitter/spicy/drying finish. Very flavorful and not watery for the ABV. Perfectly balanced Wit yeast, orange peel, and pale/wheat malts; with mild earthy hop presence. A very enjoyable offering, and spot on style example.

name: New Holland Zoomer Wit
review: Straw yellow with a stark white pillowy head. Mild wheat aroma. Flavor is more bold than expected. Reminds me of a New Belgium Fat Tire, actually. It's not offensive in any way, but on the flip side not memorable either.

name: New Holland Zoomer Wit
review: On tap at New Holland on our way to RBSG. Pours a milky yellow with a thin white head. Grainy, light yeast. Medium bodied, faint wheat. More grain than wheat. Looked promising, fell short.

name: New Holland Zoomer Wit
review: Hazey golden color w/ a slight head. This beer had a stale scent which put me on guard prior to tasting. The slice of lemon (in the beer) helped masquerade the bad taste. I drank it at the brewery from the tap.

name: New Holland Zoomer Wit
review: Not so great. Yellow but relatively clear and not that hazy. Somewhat limp palate. Some interesting flavors, banana and bubblegum, but not enough texture to satisfy. Bottle.

name: New Holland Zoomer Wit
review: Poured to a hazy light yellow with little head or lacing. Aroma was faintly spices and wheat, but I had to work hard to get that. Mouthfeel was a little on the thin side, though I did notice a slight tingle. Taste was more of the muted spice of the nose, and the finish was short and non-descript. Not much to this one

name: New Holland Zoomer Wit
review: 12-25-08. 12 oz bottle. Poured hazy straw yellow with a frothy head. Smelled of wheat and some spice. Tasted of slightly stale wheat, clove, coriander, and stagnant water. Mild spice and yeast flavor. Needs more citrus flavor to mask the bad water flavor.

name: New Holland Zoomer Wit
review: Definitely not a witbier, but a pretty easy drinking wheat ale. Flavor is all wheat, with only a hint of anything else. Not really any spice at all. Lightly sweet taste of wheat.. Light bodied and on the watery side. Very boring beer, but refreshing. Subtle aroma of wheat.

name: New Holland Zoomer Wit
review: Hazy straw color w/ an average sized white head and some lacing. Smells of good spice, also hoppy with a little bit of wheat and yeast. Palate is citrus, a good amount of carbonation and an ok mouth feel. Flavor is wheaty with a hint of spice and yeast and a touch of lemon rind. I got one of the last 6 packs at the Blue Goat. I had it with a great big Salmon filet with dill and lemon…a perfect match.

name: New Holland Zoomer Wit
review: Hazy, orangish-yellow pour. Nose is wheaty, citrusy. Flavor is a bit off, really fakely sweet and citrus. I wouldn’t really call this a wit. I wouldnt have this again.

name: New Holland Ichabod
review: Spice and nutty aroma. Brown and amber in color. Kind of dirty looking. Taste is nutty, nutmeg, bland spice, not really any pumpkin to it. Maybe pumpkin seeds? Not a fan.

name: New Holland Ichabod
review: Orangish brown pour with white head. Aroma of solid pumpkin spice - nutmeg, cinnamon. Tastes of metallic tinny malt and pumpkin spice. Not very good.

name: New Holland Ichabod
review: It's actually a pretty enjoyable pumpkin beer all thing considered. It is perhaps a little overwhelming on a cinnamon/nutmeg type spice and not as much on the pumpkin.

name: New Holland Ichabod
review: It is what you expect when it comes to the pumpkin spice world. Malty aroma with the pumpkin spice coming through. Nice orange color with a small amount of white foam and a little lacing. Refreshing spicy flavor with a strong pumpkin spice aftertaste.

name: New Holland Ichabod
review: One of the worst pumpkins I've tried in awhile! Pours Orange with a thin tan head and decent lacing. The aroma softly filled of fall spices. The taste is quite dry without many of the described flavors coming forward. It almost feels like a pale ale. There's a hint of cinnamon in nutmeg somewhere in the middle but the abrupt dry nearly rye like finish is rather off putting! Not recommended!

name: New Holland Ichabod
review: 12 oz bottle. Aroma is packed with pumpkin spice--nutmeg, cinnamon, clove, vanilla, raisin. Pours hazy orange with a one finger bone white head with decent retention. Taste is sweet and roasty, some light acidity. Not bad for style.

name: New Holland Ichabod
review: Pours a dark Golden with a thin white head. Tastes of pumpkin and nutmeg. A little bit hoppier than the typical pumpkin ale. This is basically a textbook pumpkin ale, maybe a little more refreshing though.

name: New Holland Ichabod
review: Tap, ADT. Clear golden orange with a small white head. Pumpkin pie spice, white pepper, grassy hops, bread. Light bodied, mild malt finish. OK.

name: New Holland Ichabod
review: Good taste up front but an earthy aftertaste I'm not a fan of. Great aroma. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: New Holland Ichabod
review: Very noticeable pumpkin and cinnamon aroma, refreshing and sweet, tad of spice at the end. Good autumn beer! ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Ayinger Altbairisch Dunkel
review: 500 ml bottle. Clear brown reddish, foamy head. Roasted malt, nuts, lemon, a bit metal. Malty sweetness, dry metallic bitterness. Medium bodied, oily watery texture, soft carbonated, dry metallic finish. Rather average.

name: Ayinger Altbairisch Dunkel
review: 500ml bottle brewed at 5% in Germany. Dark amber to nut-brown in colour. Medium, short-lasting head. Faint roasted, burnt sugar aroma. Moderate carbonation. Toffee malt, roast malt (with associated bitterness), bready malt, all make themselves known in a balanced way. This is a malt-lover's delight, and eminently sessionable for such. The hops are doing work keeping it relatively light and airy in the background, but can't really be picked out beyond perhaps a slight grassiness. The overall impression is a bit like a dark mild/best bitter fused with a lager, and although it's noticeably got its lager heritage, none of the pitfalls of the style remain. I've yet to have an Ayinger beer I didn't enjoy, and this is no exception.

name: Ayinger Altbairisch Dunkel
review: Feinporige, langanhaltende, große Schaumkrone eines dunkelbraunen, fast schwarzen Dunkelbiers mit Rotschimmer. Süßlich-malzig im Geruch. Vollmundiger Antrunk mit Bitterschokoladennoten, Körper mit röstmalzigem, minimal herben Noten. Langer, süß-malziger aber etwas wässriger Nachhall, der leicht an ein Stout erinnert. Schnell wieder vergessen.

name: Ayinger Altbairisch Dunkel
review: Ciemnobursztynowe wchodz¹ce w brunatny kolor, klarowne piwo z obfit¹ pian¹ która ³adnie zdobi szk³o. Aromat karmelu, przypieczonej skórki chleba. W smaku lekko wytrawne, pra¿ony s³od, karmel. Bdb dunkel

name: Ayinger Altbairisch Dunkel
review: Chestnut pour tan head taste honey cereal malty and comforting.bottle from booths

name: Ayinger Altbairisch Dunkel
review: 500 ml bottle, bought in Munich. Cereall, chocolate, honey smell. Color is redish brownish medium head. Toasted taste, coffe.

name: Ayinger Altbairisch Dunkel
review: Very malt oriented; bready; almost a malt vinegar aroma, though not the acidity. Very low hops. Good, though a bit simple/one dimensional.

name: Ayinger Altbairisch Dunkel
review: On tap at Ayinger in Munich. Toasty and bready smell with some caramel. Similar taste. Well made.

name: Ayinger Altbairisch Dunkel
review: Tap at the Olbaren. Pours dark amber-brown. Aroma and flavor are sweet, caramel, malt, grains. Overall: very good.

name: Ayinger Altbairisch Dunkel
review: Bottle 50cl. @home poured into a footed pilsner glass. Brilliant deep amber, tall frothy beige head, good retention, fair lacing; aroma light roasted malt, grain, caramel, brown sugar; taste light heavy to medium sweet and light bitter, roasted malt, caramel, hint cocoa, spicy notes; malty sweetbitter aftertaste, nutty notes; medium body, oily texture, soft carbonation; well-balanced, good.

name: North East Brewing Boston Blonde
review: Better than good, above par ... a good American Blonde Ale..................

name: North East Brewing Black Sow Stout
review: What a great stout, one of the best in the Boston area......................

name: Old Saddleback Half Stock Ale
review: This beer is gross could not finish it. I can’t under stand why it had such high ratings.

name: Old Saddleback Half Stock Ale
review: Didn't know they had closed, and don't know how long my bottle was sitting at Table and Vine in Northampton, but there sure was a damn big beige head on the pour, eventually revealing a clear copper body. Aroma is fairly sweet, berry, spicy, roasty/burnt. Taste is medium sweet, caramel, berry, spicy, light floral. Finishing roasty, even slightly burnt, caramel. Highly carbonated medium body.

name: Old Saddleback Half Stock Ale
review: Well, I know this beer is friggin old, cuz I spent some of my adolesence in Pittsfield, and these guys closed there doors a while a go. But I have a few of their bottles kickin around my refridge, and theyve been there too long, so here we go. Big frothy whip cream orangey head. Fruity malt nose. Orange reddish amber. Pale biscuity malts, sweet, light to medium bodied, fruity, big carbonation, finishing rather sweet with faint hops.

name: Old Saddleback Half Stock Ale
review: Pours a dark ambery brown, with a light whitish head. Aroma is malty and a bit estery, with a decent hop presence. Flavor is well balanced, with enough hops to balance out the sweetness, but without taking over. Estery fruitiness in the middle, and finishing with a hint of breadiness. Good body on this beer, and carbonation is moderate, but lacking in that special something to make it memorable.

name: Old Saddleback Half Stock Ale
review: A very nice aroma, rich and fruity, much like a belgian ale, the look is similar too. However the taste falls short, has hints of a realy good beer, but its just not quite all there. There is a strange slightly biter aftertaste that isnt too pleasing. Still not bad, and worth the 4 bucks I payed for the 6 pack.

name: Old Saddleback Half Stock Ale
review: Bottled. The best of the Old Saddleback offerings I had tonight, but not enough to get me to seek out their other products. Nice-looking ruby appearance with more head than I expected on this Irish red ale; flavor has decent balance and body, with some floral notes and caramel but really isn't very distinctive or memorable. Drinkable, but not worth any effort.

name: Old Saddleback Half Stock Ale
review: Well balanced and hearty. Crisp taste that is refreshing...................

name: Growlers Powells Blueberry Wheat
review: It appears a little ugly & weak. A little too pink for my visual pleasure. There is little to no head and no carbonation at all. The aroma is minimal to say the least. The flavor was heavy on the grassy/wheat lineup but not much else, including a very faint berry profile.

name: Growlers Powells Blueberry Wheat
review: On tap at the MBF. Poured a moderate golden color with a thick head. The tatse does remind me of blueberries. Very carbonated. I’m not a big fan of fruity flavored beers, but this wasn’t bad. Not sure I could drink a lot of these because the 4 oz. sample I got was more than enough for me.

name: Growlers Powells Blueberry Wheat
review: Draught at brewpub: Cloudy pink-hued amber body with a small white frothy head that fades to a ring but lasts. Aroma is medium sweet fresh blueberries, wheat, and light yeast. Taste is sweet, but not overly so, with flavors of blueberries, tart wheat, light lemon, peppery yeast, and raspberry seeds. Light bodied, medium-lively carbonation that tingles the tongue until just after the swallow.

name: Growlers Powells Blueberry Wheat
review: Amazing fresh blueberry aroma, balanced with malt and wheat. A great fresh summery beer, but unfortunately the season for this one if too short. Excellent fruit beer!

name: Growlers Powells Blueberry Wheat
review: Golden purple, fizzy white head. Fresh blueberry juice aroma with light wheat overtones. Straight up balanced flavors of blueberry, malt and wheat. Not much more to say here. Light bodied, soft carbonation and drinkable by the growler. A perfect summer thirst quencher...

name: Growlers Powells Blueberry Wheat
review: A murky, medium brown color with a small off-white head. Smells like blueberries and wheat. Tastes initially like a normal pale ale with the blueberries joining in to take over the aftertaste. Perfectly balanaced and great for summer weather.

name: Growlers Powells Blueberry Wheat
review: Hazy peach snapple body topped by a light-purple-tinged white head. Aroma is sweet, fresh blueberry (good stuff, not artificial). Taste is mild sweet, some earthy, blueberry (present but not dominant, thank goodness), light earthy bitterness in the finish. Light-medium body, very drinkable.

name: Growlers Powells Blueberry Wheat
review: Draft... The color is a hazy copper with a pink/purple head. It smells fruity and sweet, like blueberries. The flavor is light and refreshing. Blueberries abound. Although very lightly carbonated, it has a smooth, crisp finish. Excellent summer brew!

name: Growlers Hardings IPA
review: Decent IPA, has all the right characteristics, but needs a little more hop kick. very refreshing though. More like a strong pale ale than an IPA...lots of malt, darker color. Nose isn’t really there and hops fade from the palate a little quickly. Still, tastes good, if a little weak.

name: Growlers Hardings IPA
review: Overall Impression: I haven’t had this one in a while, but I remember it being just OK, and not much more then that.

name: Growlers Hardings IPA
review: On tap-Maryland Brewer’s Oktoberfest. Clear golden color w/a slight white head. Bitter hop flavor with not much to back it up. Seemed stale although the keg was very fresh, considering how they were rolling thru them @ this event. No wonder this Brewery always had the shortest line. Very average, wouldn’t buy it again.

name: Growlers Hardings IPA
review: Very much subpar for an IPA. If its an IPA, wheres all the hop flavors. Not impressed. Lost my notes on this beer, so will have to rerate for certain. JKust remember being very disappointed.

name: Growlers Hardings IPA
review: Clear dark amber color with a still tan head. Warm, high carbonation, means the keg was just put on. Slightly metallic tasting, with some waffle flavors too though, which is weird, has a decent flowery hop aroma, fruity and ripe, fresh smelling but at the same time you can still smell a mild diacetyl infection in this one, not nearly as potent as their other beers.

name: Growlers Hardings IPA
review: Draft - Light amberish gold, creamy off white head. Nice English IPA nose of floral hoppiness that’s balanced with soft notes of butterscotch and caramel. Well bittered flavors of citrus and florals that again are nicely balanced with a soft sweet caramel malt backbone. Medium bodied, soft carbonation, bittersweet finish. Good stuff...

name: Growlers Hardings IPA
review: Draft... Clear, golden ale with a mid-sized, creamy, khaki head. Excellent retention. Malty nose and palate. Fuzzy fruit esters and toffee notes with just a whisper of grapefruit in the aroma. Excellent balance. Great hopping prevents any real sweetness from tipping forward from its sturdy malt foundation. Full-bodied and oily with light carbonation. Lengthy, medium-bitter finish. Very nice English-style IPA. Earlier Rating: 3/20/2003 Total Score: 3.6 Draft... Crystal clear deep golden hue. Small, creamy white head with very interesting lacework. Mostly lasting. the aroma is very citrisy and floral. Lemon, grapefruit, black pepper, dandelion and clove. Very well balanced brew. Very malty and rich up front. Moderately bitter on the backside. Medium-bodied with a silky mouthfeel and lively carbonation. Lengthy, moderately bitter finish.

name: Growlers Hardings IPA
review: Draught at brewpub: Clear pale amber with a small white head that quickly fades. Aroma is very mild hops, fruit, and light grains - not what you would expect from an IPA. This one is seriously lacking hops. Taste is berry seeds, mild grass, sweet syrupy light malts, sweet hop syrup. Light-medium bodied, medium amounts of carbonation.

name: Growlers Hardings IPA
review: Average. Nice copper color with white head, but it fades fast. Slight copper/penny flavor at first then some hop flavor. Palate feels like high carbonation, but doesn’t show in head. Not bad, but probably wouldn’t buy it again.

name: Growlers Hardings IPA
review: bottle. Just your run of the mill average (at best) IPA. A little more malt than I care for but I suppose it just goes along with the East Coast philosophy of IPA. Not my cup ’o tea.

name: Growlers Nut Brown Ale
review: Pours dark brown/black. Tan brown head that retains well. Well carbonated. Nut and molasses flavors with the chocolate flavours and aromas of a dark ale. Medium bodied. Has a very sweet aroma and taste due to early ceasing of fermentation

name: Growlers Nut Brown Ale
review: Dark, syrupy, and sweet. The malt is very up-front in this beer, and tastes nuttier than most nut browns. It’s sweeter than it needs to be (toffee-like), as if the fermentation was stopped too early. Overall, one of the better Growlers brews.

name: Growlers Nut Brown Ale
review: Sampler on tap @ Balt Octoberfest : Deep mahogany brown color, with a very typical nutty ’brow ale flavor’. So my vocab isnt amazing, but a brown ale is a brown ale thus far in my beer-expirience. Minimal to zero hops, heavily malted.

name: Growlers Nut Brown Ale
review: Rusty brown, light tan creamy head. Rich nose of buttermilk and cashews, with lesser notes of milk chocolate. Good balance between the soft nuttiness, chocolate, and the light hop bitterness. Light bodied, medium carbonation, dry, bittersweet finish. Compared with Hopscotch’s review, this one seems worked out to me now. A nice session brew...

name: Growlers Nut Brown Ale
review: (Re-Rate as Growlers Nut Brown Ale on 8/7/2006) Draft... Clear copper ale with a mid-sized, creamy, beige head. Good retention. Nutty, chocolaty aroma and flavor, however there is definitely a trace of DMS in the beer... either that or someone washed my pint glass in the same sink as a plate full of mussels or shrimp. Just beneath all the hearty, chocolaty, nutty maltiness this beer promises to be, there’s a hint of shellfish. Talk about raining all over a beer guy’s parade? Anyway, once the joint gets that problem solved, you’ll run into a medium-bodied brown ale with a creamy mouthfeel, mild carbonation and a lengthy, astringent, chocolaty finish. Every brew I sampled on opening day impressed me except this. (Original Rating as Summit Station Nut Brown Ale on 3/18/2003) Draft... Crystal clear mohogany hue. Medium-sized, creamy, antique-white head. Patially lasting with very good lacing. The aroma is of milk chocolate, toasted cashews and Jamaican Blue Mountain coffee. Nice, moderately malty flavor. Milk chocolate and coffee up front. Well-balanced with mildly bitter hops and more milk chocolate on the backside. A touch earthy as well. Medium-bodied with a dry mouthfeel and lively carbonation. Short, dry finish with a hint of Kentucky bluegrass at the far end. Very enjoyable beer. Session beer. Original Score = 3.4

name: Growlers Nut Brown Ale
review: On Tap, Summit Station Dark pour, with frothy beige head. Aroma malty, and nutty. First sip brings forth the nut and malt flavors. Nice mix together, little sweet toward the middle, and a slight hop kick in the finish. Nicely balanced, smooth, easy to drink.

name: Growlers Nut Brown Ale
review: Sampled on draught at the brewpub, and a 2 liter growler to go. The nose on this beer has some nice nutty malt aroma paired with some "grainy" malt aroma. The palate is soft, with some good nutty and pale malt flavors. This beer finishes malty and nutty up front, then ends slightly cloying, and with a mild hop bite to balance. Pretty straight foward Nut Brown Ale. Good drinking beer. Made for a nice pint at the bar, and would work well with dishes on Summits menu.

name: Growlers Nut Brown Ale
review: Hazy mahogany body with beige head. Aroma is medium sweet, nutty, caramel, some chocolate, light nutmeg. Taste is moderately sweet, nutty, caramel, some chocolate, light earthy. Medium body, light sticky.

name: Growlers Nut Brown Ale
review: Draught at brewpub: Clear dark amber/brown with a medium beige head that lasts. Aroma is toffee-covered chocolate, caramel, mild chocolate syrup. Taste is burnt toffee, nuts, chocolate, grains, and chaulk. Light-medium bodied, moderate carbonatoin. This was a nice brown, and well done in all aspects though the body was a touch watery.

name: Growlers Nut Brown Ale
review: Surprisingly good. In the Sammy Smith's vein, but not league. Crazy malts lend a light porter view of toffee and caramel. Looks like a classic NBA. No complaints about the finish.

name: Summit Station Alt
review: I wasn't looking to try this beer, but when a neighbor has a growler of it and offered up a glass, who was I to refuse? Red-black body topped by medium beige head. Aroma is medium sweet, roasty, caramel. Taste is fairly rich, medium sweet, roasty, some coffee, caramel, earthy, finish is roasty bitter with light earthiness. Medium body.

name: Summit Station Alt
review: Draft... Sparkling clear mohogany hue with a small, off-white creamy head. Mostly diminishing with decent lacing. The aroma is of caramel, brown sugar and cola. Another perfectly balanced brew from Summit Station. Very malty and rich up front. Very lightly bitter and acetic on the backside. Light to medium-bodied. with a watery mouthfeel and almost non existant carbonation. Short, lightly pungent finish.

name: Growlers Diamond Stout
review: Draft - Dense brown, creamy tan head. Rich nose of light roasted coffee, cream, milk chocolate, and oatmeal, with soft tones of vanilla. Well balanced flavors of all the above. Medium bodied, soft carbonation, roasty, bittersweet finish. Nice session stout...

name: Growlers Diamond Stout
review: Nitro... This beer rocks! ... Pitch black ale with a mid-sized, creamy, beige head. Terrific retention. Chocolaty nose with a layer of vanilla and a whisper of acetaldehyde. Well-balanced, very chocolaty flavor with a touch of toffee. Smooth, toasted, gently burnt notes… not at all harsh. Almost full-bodied and very creamy with soft carbonation. Chocolaty, bitter, dry finish. More like a stout than a dry stout. World class brew! Earlier Rating: 3/18/2003 Total Score: 3.8 Draft... Very dark, clear ruby ale with a small, frothy, khaki head. The aroma has notes of dark chocolate, vanilla and deeply roasted cashews. The flavor is decently balanced with toasty to burnt notes of cocoa and charcoal. Full-bodied with a heavy, creamy mouthfeel and lively carbonation. Burnt, moderately bitter finish. Very imperialesque.

name: Growlers Diamond Stout
review: On Tap @ Summit Station Poured very dark with some ruby highlights, with small brownish head. Aroma of mild coffee, chocolate, and roasted nuts. Flavor of chocolate, caramel, and roasted/toasted nuts and malts. Full bodied, thick mouthfeel. Nice carbonation. Bitter finish as it warmed. Overall not bad

name: Growlers Diamond Stout
review: Draught at brewpub: Clear dark brown with a small beige head that doesn’t last. Aroma: mild chocolate, unsweetened cocoa powder, and a light coffee scent. Flavor: toffee and chocolate, roasted grains, plum, light retronasal hops, vinous dark malts. Medium bodied, moderate carbonation. Bitter finish. This one gets points for the carbonation which is near perfect.

name: Growlers Diamond Stout
review: Reddish black with nice espresso head. Roasty, coffee aroma. Flavor is the same, though it's as strong a roasty coffee flavor as I can ever recall tasting. Malty bitter with healthy hops balance. Bitter aftertaste is relatively mild.

name: Growlers Diamond Stout
review: Is definitely very dry, singificant coffee in the roasts. Very roasty. Were this a bit stronger, it'd seem like an imperial to me.

name: Palm Springs Red Feather/Old Prospector Amber Ale
review: I remember dudes hunting down this beer in college (early-mid 90's) and proclaiming it was something special. I remember thinking it was extremely overrated. I distinctly recall a very dry finish and vague floral undertones.

name: Palm Springs Red Feather/Old Prospector Amber Ale
review: They are no longer brewing beer. They got a big ($$$)contract to brew their root beer and gave up beer. Reddish brown color – medium head. Again a kind of mild beer. Yet, there is a hint of roasted malts, nearly no hoppyness

name: Palm Springs Red Feather/Old Prospector Amber Ale
review: A good beer, not great. Nicely malted and fair hop bite, very clean and refreshing.

name: Palm Springs Golden Wheat
review: Very light and quite a refreshing beer. Wheat and malts evident in the nose. Not at all bitter as some wheats can be, even the non-wheaty lovers will like this beer.

name: Palm Springs Palm Canyon Porter
review: Porters and stouts are my favorite styles of beer, this one will rate high on my master list. Dark, coffee, chocolate and a beautiful subtle hop finish that's lip smacking good.

name: Charlevoix Bonté Divine
review: Acid/sour taste that is perfect for this beer. Totally refreshing in the summer. Usually seems to have a chill hase.

name: Charlevoix Bonté Divine
review: Slightly sour, spicy, alcoholic apple cider aroma with notes of bitter orange. Golden amber coloured body with thin but dense white head that lasts nicely. Oranges carry through to the sweet, biscuity flavour more-so than apples. Some citrusy lemon also notable. Creamy medium body with slightly prickly mouthfeel. Restrained but exciting. This is a mild yet enticing Belgian Strong. Very easy to drink... Enjoyed it cold - as it warms up, diacetyl becomes very noticeable in both the aroma and flavour. I would bump down aroma by two, flavour by four points,palate by two and overall by four because of this. Score as rated splits the difference - originally - 6,4,7,4,13=3.4. Drink it cold - at warmer temperatures, not so good - 4,4,3,2,9=2.2. Bottle.

name: Charlevoix Bonté Divine
review: The nose was interesting with green apples, chocolate, earthy notes and just a hint of cotton candy. The taste is of green apples, sour malt and an astringent finish. To me it seemed like a brown ale, but maybe I am out of it.

name: Charlevoix Bonté Divine
review: (66o ml bottle) Pours a medium, creamy, quick dissipating, almond head and a cloudy copper body. Aroma of sweet malt, strong whiskey and oranges. Somewhat contrast thin body and tart flavour to the aroma. Light, biting alcohol, mid-palate of a sour port and bouncing market fruit - oranges and apples. Finish of a sour apple cider...

name: Charlevoix Bonté Divine
review: Poured, this beer is dark brown with a thin head with no legs (doesn''t last). It has a good strong malt backbone, with some strange spicing rising to the palate. Certainly sweet orange peels, but others, perhaps some cinamin, and some cloves but everything is at the edge of perception, more like a suggestion...

name: Charlevoix Bonté Divine
review: A good bottle is a thick and luscious apple cider…Spring spices on a bed of sugary fruit… A bad bottle is cloying metal and rotten fruit…The brewer of this tiny and far microbrewery is known though to travel many miles to take some old bottles of his off of shelves which do not treat them well…Worth a try…

name: Charlevoix Bonté Divine
review: Stange brew.Nose has a bit of smoke and spices.Dry and crisp mouthfeel but also pretty short.Has lots of yeast and ends with a vinegar/white pepper finish.Nothing more than a curiosity

name: Charlevoix Bonté Divine
review: It is back on the market. Dark hazy amber with a head that won't last. Lemon, yeast, spices, apricot and a bit of bubble gum aroma. This beer isn't sure if it wants to be sweet, acid or anything else as a matter of fact. It didn't impress me.

name: Charlevoix Bonté Divine
review: I guess it is back on the market now. Dark amber, yeasty, medicinal Belgian session ale. Bov is right about it not being one of the finer examples.

name: Charlevoix Bonté Divine
review: nothing to do with "divin" ! this one does not deserve to be a belgian ale.

name: Charlevoix Maillard Pils
review: A predominant hop dirt in the end is preceded by a lingering yeast and dry wheat...A light lemon breeze blows and brings over pure water from above...The faint aftertaste is admitted in their description, as this is obviously the house blond offering...

name: Charlevoix Maillard Pils
review: As far as I know, this is the light lager they serve at the ski lodge of Le Massif. It is a typical american/canadian innofensive micro lager.

name: Lindens Sax-a-Pale Ale
review: Some bitterness but overall lack of a nice floral character. Lacking in well done malt/hop balancing. Neat brewery though.

name: Lindens Sax-a-Pale Ale
review: On tap: creamy white head. Hoppy aroma. Copper, amber color, hazy. Pacific North West haziness/hoppiness. Lingering hoppiness.

name: Lindens Sax-a-Pale Ale
review: Draught. Body is light amber. Aroma is lightly malty (toasted light bread), moderately hoppy (grapefruit, resin), lightly yeasty (dough). Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is moderately acidic, moderately bitter. Medium body, creamy texture, lively carbonation, moderately astringent.

name: Lindens Sax-a-Pale Ale
review: GABF 2002: Sparkling dark golden colour. Caramel aroma. Weak flavour. Uninspiring.

name: Lindens Sax-a-Pale Ale
review: Nice lace with a bright golden hue. Cool and refreshing. Flowery aroma hops seemed a little undeveloped, and didn't seem to reach their full potential. Mouthfeel was a bit watery. While I liked the earthy malt flavors, I would've liked to see a little more malt backbone... and maybe hops with more hairs on their chests. Decent bitterness builds though.

name: Lindens Sax-a-Pale Ale
review: I just don't get the malt that theoretically rounds out this rather limpid hop juice.

name: Lindens Percussion Porter
review: A dark ruby brown with an aspiring lacy head--nice looking. Aroma is yeasty, burnt, black patent malt, soy sauce, and a sort of whiskey sour smell. Flavor is very bitter and astringent but dry and very stark. I didn't get much hop flavor, but what I did get was grapefruit/flower petals.

name: Lindens Percussion Porter
review: Cask-conditioned, hand pulled: They added extra hops to this one when they cask conditioned it. Creamy, body and head. Head stuck around for the whole pint. The coffee and chocolate were present but subdued. Also, acidic. A lot more hoppy than most porters. Fair amount of carbonation. I need to try the regular version of this porter for comparison.

name: Lindens Percussion Porter
review: Draught. Body is dark brown to black. Aroma is moderately malty (roasted grain, dark chocolate), moderately hoppy (grapefruit). Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is moderately acidic, moderately bitter. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation, moderately astringent. Too citric-hoppy/acidic for my liking.

name: Lindens Percussion Porter
review: Very nice and dark, deep-red hue with a frothy head. Aroma was nice: coffee, roasted and sweet. Very atypical porter though, stylistically speaking. Hops were very sweet and grapefruity, and they masked the malts, if you can believe it. Me being a hophead, I was torn. I loved the grapefruit/citric flavors, but not necessarily in a porter.

name: Lindens Percussion Porter
review: Best aroma in the brewpub and a fine roastiness, but this is balanced by a sour grassiness that doesn't endear me to it. The thing gets more roasty-sweet and less sour as you go.

name: Lindens Percussion Porter
review: Not a typical porter. Very Hoppy/Stemmy. Tastes quite fresh and strong, Almost like over stepped tea, although it works for this beer. I really enjoyed it.

name: Tied House Alpine Gold
review: Draft at Tied House. Don’t be hating folks, this actually a pretty tasty golden. Clear and bright, small head, big, bold grainy aroma and taste. Bready and sweet. Tasty to a fault, minor bite, leaves the palate clean.

name: Tied House Alpine Gold
review: On tap @ Tied House. Clear golden beer with a white head. Aroma and flavor are both really quite sweet. Get some honey, grains, and corn flakes. A light baked apple ester aroma. There is sort of a grainy and chalky bitterness to the flavor that I could do without. Also very sugary tasting and intensely sweet. Some caramel to go along with all the cereal. Meh.

name: Tied House Alpine Gold
review: Draft at Tied House in Mountain View. Pale good. Light. Grains, bread, and some spice. Bit of lemon. It is pretty sweet but also, finishes fairly dry for the style. Solid.

name: Tied House Alpine Gold
review: Sample at the brewpub. Clear yellow color with a thin white head that dissipates quickly to an outer ring. Spotty lacing on the glass. Aroma of malt, yeast and mild hops. Light-bodied with flavors of bready malt, herbal yeast and slight hops. The finish is mildly bitter with a short grassy hops aftertaste. Barely average overall.

name: Tied House Alpine Gold
review: Yellow. Frothy white head. Not much nose. Maybe a little 7-up smell. Taste is lightly bitter; mostly grainy; hints of corn. Medium body. Lively carbonation. Decent. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Tied House Alpine Gold
review: Tap at hermitage. Pours clear golden yellow, medium creamy white head, nice lacing. Aroma is lightly floral, grain, honey. Flavor follows, medium sweet, little bitterness. Light body.

name: Tied House Alpine Gold
review: On tap, sampler. Pours a clear yellow with minimal head. Not much of a nose, some malt, some grassiness. Very thin on the tongue. Easy drinking but nothing special.

name: Tied House Alpine Gold
review: Clear golden color with lingering white head. Honey biscuit, mild floral aromas. Light smooth mouthfeel. Dry biscuit, stale honey flavors with a polycarbonate burp to finish--

name: Tied House Alpine Gold
review: Light coloured, almost lager-like, but still fairly nice. Not the boldest of flavours.

name: Tied House Alpine Gold
review: Ok. Nothing special. Pours a nice golden color. Smells a little sweet. Doesn't taste like much though. Had in bottle. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Tied House Cascade Amber
review: Draft at brewpub. Amber body, clear, silky head, solid lacing coats the glass. Caramel malts in there, more so in taste than aroma. Aroma is weak. Taste is mildly sweet, but has an overall nice mouthfeel. Aside from the aroma, another winner.

name: Tied House Cascade Amber
review: On tap @ Tied House. Clear caramel colored beer with a finger of off-white foam. Pretty much your typical caramel apple amber ale here. There’s a whole lot of acidity, too, which I don’t like. Some grassy, herbal, and earthy hops. Tastes kind of bland and flat. Some berry, apple, and lemon. Scroll past.
