name: Tied House Cascade Amber
review: Draft at Tied House in Mountain View. Balanced, leaning malty. Pretty typical of the style, with a really solid mouthfeel.

name: Tied House Cascade Amber
review: Sample at the brewpub. Slightly cloudy copper color with a thin off-white head that recedes quickly to a film. Spotty lacing. Aroma of roast malt, fruit and subtle hops. Light body with flavors of caramel malt, earthy hops and fruit. The finish is sweet with a grainy malt aftertaste. Average overall.

name: Tied House Cascade Amber
review: Reddish-amber color. Thin white head; good lacing. Nose is faint malt and a note of hops. Taste is well-balanced; slightly dry finish. Medium body. Soft carbonation. Good brew. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Tied House Cascade Amber
review: Bottle from Bevmo: Created a soft and thin layer of foamed head while the liquid was a tea brown meets golden honey color. The aroma was rather fruity with scents of dried fruit such as apricot and plums. Flavors are tangy with a fruity yet soapy taste. There is a sweet finish and also allows for some notice of caramel malts, but I wouldn’t buy this again and only think of this amber as below par.

name: Tied House Cascade Amber
review: On tap, sampler. Pours a very light amber, almost yellow. No real nose to speak of. Crisp attack, malty but very light. Finishes clean. Can drink a lot of them I guess, but nothing amazing.

name: Tied House Cascade Amber
review: An ok amber. Pours a really nice brown-orange. Smells slightly roasted. Tastes a little refreshing, with some cream. A little bit of a weird vinegar aftertaste. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Tied House Cascade Amber
review: Backlog purge. On tap at the inaugural Hop N Barley festival in Scotts Valley. Awful crystal malt bomb, iced tea with generic C hops.

name: Tied House Cascade Amber
review: A clear amber beer with a long lasting white head. Aroma is caramel and hoppy, citrus, flowery. Taste is malty and caramel, some citrusy (orange). Medium body

name: Tied House Ironwood Dark
review: Draft at brewpub. So far Ive been pleasantly surprised. This one leaves unimpressed, very much so. Dark amber, small skin of head. Faint malty aroma, barely there. Taste doesn’t improve things much, more cola than beer. Mildly sweet and nutty, but not enough to save this.

name: Tied House Ironwood Dark
review: On tap @ Tied House. Darker amber colored beer with a thin layer of khaki foam. Pretty much a nutty brown ale here. There’s a nice toasted hazelnut and walnut thing going on. Some sweet caramel malts and a little bit of chocolate. Hints of coffee bitterness and earthy hops to balance the sweetness. Pretty decent, actually. Probably my favorite of their house beers.

name: Tied House Ironwood Dark
review: Draft at Tied House in Mountain View. Clear amber. Nuts, roast, and caramel. Bit of toffee as well. Spice and earth. Balanced, though land sweet. Easy drinking. Very clean.

name: Tied House Ironwood Dark
review: On tap at Tied House. Sweet nutty aroma. Sweet nutty taste. Sticky sweet. This isn’t too bad.

name: Tied House Ironwood Dark
review: Shared with gmellison. Reddish orange appearance with a thin tan head. Caramel, apple, dusty toasted malty nose. Twangy, caramel, sweet, red apple flavor. Pass.

name: Tied House Ironwood Dark
review: Sample at the brewpub. Clear brownish-amber color with a medium light beige head that diminishes quickly to a film. Short strings of lacing. Aroma of roasted malt and nuts. Light-bodied with flavors of roast malt, fruit and slight earthy hops. The finish is sweet with a short malty aftertaste. Average overall.

name: Tied House Ironwood Dark
review: Dark amber pour. Thin white head. Sparse lacing. Nose is malty. Taste - sweet. Nearly full body. Lively carbonation. Standard brown ale. Good brew. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Tied House Ironwood Dark
review: On tap, sampler. Light brown, not much head. Mild nose, malt and yeast. A bit thin on the attack, but overall pleasant if unremarkable. Might be good on a hot afternoon.

name: Tied House Ironwood Dark
review: Draft. A decent brown with plenty of body. Brown, cloudy, light head. Smooth without offtones. A very enjoyable brown.

name: Tied House Ironwood Dark
review: Claims to be English style, but it’s much fizzier than most British ales. Not bad though.

name: Tied House New World Wheat
review: Draft at brewpub. This one too is a bit underwhelming. Faint aroma, grains pick up in taste, very cracker and biscuits. Kind of dry, a little honey sweetness. This one could go either way, but I didn’t like it as much as the first two.

name: Tied House New World Wheat
review: On tap @ Tied House. Slightly hazed straw colored beer with a thin, short lived, white head. There’s a fairly bland aroma to this. The flavor isn’t much more intense. Slight applesauce thing going on. There is a bit of tang and lemon character to this, too. Maybe just a bit on the doughy side. Tastes kind of...raw overall.

name: Tied House New World Wheat
review: Draft at Tied House in Mountain View. Clear golden color with a small head. Pale wheat and spice. Light fruit. Thin, fizzy. Not too exciting.

name: Tied House New World Wheat
review: Sample at the brewpub. Pours a slightly hazy pale golden color with a thin white head that recedes quickly to a film. Spotty lacing. Aroma of wheat, spice and malt. Light-bodied with flavors of herbal wheat, mild fruit and slight hops. The finish is clean and wheaty with a short fruity aftertaste. Average overall.

name: Tied House New World Wheat
review: Bottle from Bevmo: Created a thick layer of foamy head while the liquid was a glowing dirty blonde hue that was near opaque. The aroma was a sweet scent of malt, lemon, and bubblegum. Flavor was funky and had a wheat grain taste with a strange mutant yeast that has a fruity flavor but also an artificial sweetener taste. This wasn’t a wheat beer that could even remotely quench my thirst for beer on a hot summer day in the beginning of autumn.

name: Tied House New World Wheat
review: On tap, sampler. Cloudy gold, big head. Nose is malt and yeast, but weak. Tastes like a very lite heffy. Clean finish. Drinkable in large quantities. Kinda the them of the lighter beers at this place.

name: Tied House New World Wheat
review: Draft. Dark amber, cloudy, light head. Not much aroma, nice easy taste without too much strength. Decent all around if not looking for anything out of the ordinary.

name: Tied House New World Wheat
review: Bomber from Bevmo Salinas. Nose is lightly spicy with hints of caramel and banana. Hazy yellow with a big pale yellow head. Flavor is white pepper, light bitterness, and caramel.

name: Tied House New World Wheat
review: Hazy, murky, orange-wheat colored body. Thin white head. Soapy lacing. Orange peel and wheat -- simple and pleasant. Flavor follows suit. Relatively clean profile, minimal spicyness from the yeast. Nice orange presence. Medium to light bodied. Fairly refreshing.

name: Tied House New World Wheat
review: Aroma of lemon peel and baguette. Pale golden amber, hazy, thin white head. Medium sweet flavor, light bitter, strong lemon, salty, a hint of almonds and vanilla. Light body, soft carbonation, finish short, clean, and citrusy. Drank this with grilled halibut, portobellos, and spinach. This beer is an excellent complement to light fish.

name: Tied House Porter
review: Barrel Aged Version. Tasted at the 6th Annual Triple Rock Firkin Fest on 4/4/2009. The porter pours a dark black color from the firkin. Small sized beige foamy head. The aroma is bourbon, sweet and chocolate. A medium body porter. The malts are chocolate and coffee, slightly roasty. The hops are earthy. A touch of bourbon and oak, the flavors are more noticeable in the nose than in the taste. Nice soft carbonation. Good balance. Mouthfeel is full. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.

name: Tied House Porter
review: On cask at Firkin Fest. Dark brown, roasted malts, little coffee, slight chocolate, very dry.

name: Tied House Porter
review: Date: 08/17/1998 Source: Brewpub deep ruby red, thin tan head, light sweet malt aroma, rich roasted malt flavor, slight sweetness, hint of bitterness, no big whoop Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.7/5.0 Score: **/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

name: Tied House Porter
review: This is an oddbut pleasing mix of strengths and weaknesses. It''s lighter in color and a bit thinner than many Porters. Still, it had a pronounced Porter nose and solid if thin Porter taste. The finish hung in longer than expected, a pleasantt surprise. It is more of a drinking porter than many.

name: Tied House Oatmeal Stout
review: Draft at brewpub. Immediate chocolate on the nose, rich and sweet. Hints of coffee too. Taste follows with more of the same, really well crafted. Only knock is it could use a bit more body. This is really, really good.

name: Tied House Oatmeal Stout
review: On tap @ Tied House. Black in color with a tan head. Smells mostly like roasted malt, but there’s some coffee, chocolate, and ash to it as well. The flavor is a little much for me. A whole lot of ash, burnt marshmallow, and some smoke. It’s also certainly quite thin and not terribly pleasant to me. Has some grassy and almost vegetal bitterness. Sort of metallic as well. No thanks.

name: Tied House Oatmeal Stout
review: Draft at Tied House in Mountain View. Medium brown with a thin head and drippy lace. Roasted and trusted malt aroma. Bit of coffee. Not much sweetness mostly roasty, and a bit bitter. Medium bodied. Soft carbonation. Clean, light dry close. Not too shabby.

name: Tied House Oatmeal Stout
review: Sample at the brewpub. Brownish-black pour with a medium thin foamy tan head that recedes quickly to a film. Short strings of lacing. Aroma of roasted malt and dark chocolate. Light-bodied with flavors of mild coffee, toasted malt and slight chocolate. The finish is semi-sweet with a chocolate malt aftertaste. Average overall.

name: Tied House Oatmeal Stout
review: Nearly black pour. Creamy tan head. Slightly malty nose. Taste is creamy with a dry finish. This is a Guinness clone. Not bad. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Tied House Oatmeal Stout
review: On tap In visalia. Very dark brown, almost black color with a thin beige head. Roasted nose. Aroma is roasted malt and dark chocolate. It continues this way but it is medium bodied only. Malty bitterness remains.

name: Tied House Oatmeal Stout
review: On tap, sampler. Light black color with a thin tan head. Nose is the best part, a bit of roast and malt, very pleasant. Taste is think and finish is a bit sweet.

name: Tied House Oatmeal Stout
review: Admittedly I’m not a big stout drinker, but this isn’t one of the best. It’s a bit low on flavour for me.

name: Tied House Oatmeal Stout
review: A - Served a dark black with a touch of brown with a finger of creamy chocolate head. Fades slowly with good lacing. S - Roasted chocolate malts with a touch of burnt, with some lactose sweetness. T - Roasted chocolate malts with a bit of milk sweetness and a touch of vanilla. Touch of more heavily roasted chocolate and a bit of burnt malt. Finish is chocolaty with a lactose sweetness alongside. M - Medium bodied with moderate carbonation. Smooth creamy mouthfeel from the nitro with a roasty finish. D - Very drinkable. Nice roasted flavors and sweetness but could have used a bit more body and kick.

name: Tied House Oatmeal Stout
review: On tap at the brewpub in Mountain View Appearance: Dark brown with a nice frothy tan head and some lacing Aroma: Toasted malts, coffee and chocolate Taste:Thin mouthfeel of roasted malts, ashy, grainy and coffee. Dry finish Decent

name: Tied House Shark Bite ESB
review: Not the one who entered this beer, merely the first one to rate it. Presuming this is the same thng as "the English Bitter". Bready aromas. Some minor fruitiness in the nose. A hint of sourIN milk. Orange. Thin, white head. Caramel notes in the taste. Fruity. Medium bodied Some lactic background.

name: Tied House Kitchen Sink India Pale Ale
review: Name: India Pale Ale Date: 08/17/1998 Source: Brewpub clear amber, scant head, light sweet floral hop aroma, light body, mild hop flavor, this is an ipa? not even by uk standards, Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.6/5.0 Score: **/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

name: Tied House Kitchen Sink India Pale Ale
review: Pours golden with thick lasting head. Aroma is potent with notes of citrus and flowers. Flavor is fruity and slightly sweet. Finish is nice and bitter. One of their better brews.

name: Tied House Kitchen Sink India Pale Ale
review: Tap @ Bistro 6th Annual IPA Festival (August 9, 2003). Amber color with a tan foamy head. Rich malts with chocolate notes. The hops spring forth gently at first and finish aggressively with a bitter finish.

name: Tied House Kitchen Sink India Pale Ale
review: Medium orange gold color. Large white foamy head. Aroma is minimumal, but is a touch floral. A medium bodied IPA. Malts are nutty, fruity and a touch sweet. Hops are grapefruity and spicy. Balanced towards the hops. The taste is a touch harsh and is a little rough tasting. Mouthfeel is full. Finish is crisp. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.

name: Tied House Oktoberfest
review: Overall: Flat, mediocre. Note: Bottle 750 ml at home. Reviewed 2015-04-04.

name: Tied House Oktoberfest
review: A - Clear copper brown color with a thin layer of white head. Heads fades quickly leaving behind a bit of lace. S - Sweet caramel and bready malts, bit of spice in the background. T - Rich sweet caramel malts and some lager yeast in the background. Through the middle, some bready malts come through with a bit of spice. Finish is a mix of sweet caramel malts and some bready yeast flavor. M - Medium bodies with moderate carbonation. Smooth with a fairly sweet finish. D - Very drinkable. Standard Oktoberfest flavors with a bit more yeasty flavor and the finish could be a bit crisper.

name: Tied House Oktoberfest
review: Sampled in at Brewhouse in Mountain View. Had a nice lacey white head and a very hoppy aroma. Pour was a very nice hue of light brown and served cold. Flavor is packed with hops and has a little bit of an aftertaste.

name: Tied House Oktoberfest
review: Tap. I am usually not afan of their beers but this one is quite good. Itpours with an copper amber color. Aromas are dominated by malts and toffee. The flavors are also mainly malts, there is a subtle hoppy bitterness in the finish. One could argue that it is quite one dimensional, but compared to most of their offerings it is quite well done.

name: Tied House Oktoberfest
review: on tap. Amber color. Malt nose. Creamy malt taste throughout with slight tartness

name: Tied House Oktoberfest
review: Tap. Full on amber color. Focus is on bland malts rather than spice. Good body and a smooth rich feel. A little tangy/sour with a fruit flavor.

name: Tied House California Pale Ale
review: On tap. Pale body with small white head. Not much aroma. Not much flavor here either, quite similar to a macro lager. Not so much more to say really, I could add the word dry.

name: Tied House Amber Light
review: Bottle from Sac Bevmo. Pours reddish copper with a modest beige head and a light floral aroma. Wow, this has almost no taste.A little pale malt and a slight hop bitterness.

name: Tied House Amber Light
review: Draught at the brewpub. Clear dark red-amber color with a lasting beige head. One whiff and I almost couldn’t even take a sip. Massive diacetyl overload; an almost sickening amount of rancid butter. The beer is buttery and slick in the mouth. There is some caramel malt flavor and a touch of hops, but the diacetyl makes it pretty much moot. There is just no excuse to serve a beer like this. I get that they are probably using a house English yeast strain, but why is there so much trouble with diacetyl? This was by far the worst example, but the wheat and brown ale were also plagued by it.

name: Tied House Amber Light
review: On tap. Clear pale amber with an off-white head. Lightly nutty aroma. Thin and watery, lightly sweet malt and caramel. Absolutely no bitterness. 250709

name: Tied House Amber Light
review: From tap at the brewpub. Pours clear and light golden orange to amber with a small white head. Aroma is pinewood hoppy and vague malty. Flat malty flavoured, rather vague hops flavour. Dry, light toasted and flat malty flavoured into a mild finish with no bitterness.

name: Tied House Amber Light
review: Draft at the brewpub. An amber beer with lazing beige head. The aroma has notes of malt and caramel. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt and caramel, leading to a lightly bitter and lightly nutty finish.

name: Tied House Amber Light
review: On tap at the Tied House in Mountain View. Not a terrible light beer. Color is a light amber with a white head. Can definitely notice the presence of some Cascade hops one the aroma. Flavor is sweet malt (somewhat subdued) and more Cascade hops that redeem this beer somewhat. The absence of the usual hint of fresh piss that you expect in light beers is also a plus. Flavor is a little weak and it’s watery, but hey, it’s a light beer, and those don’t get too much better than this.

name: Tied House Amber Light
review: I am getting "dirty" smells - maybe this comes from the hop choice. Or, possibly the enzymes used break down the residual sugars? In either case, this aroma follows through to the pallete. Not very enjoyable

name: Tied House Amber Light
review: Date: August 17, 1998 Source: Brewpub Appearance: golden, frothy off-white head Aroma: light sweet malt aroma Flavor: light sweet malt flavor with a quick finish, just the slightest hint of bitterness. Overall: best light style I’ve ever had Date: July 12, 2009 Mode: draft Source: brewpub mtn view Appearance: clear gold, fine beige head Aroma: sweet malt aroma, light floral hops Flavor: sweet malt flavor, unfermented wort character, light floral hops, light bitterness Overall: no longer the best light style example, but that was 11 years ago Aroma: 4/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 4/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 8/20 Rating: 2.3/5.0 Drinkability: 6/10 Score: *+/4

name: Tied House Amber Light
review: An amber light... hmmm. Overall the aroma and the appearance are entirely like that of Cascade amber. After that, the flavor is incredibly weak and os disappointing. Stick to the normal amber.

name: Tied House Amber Light
review: On tap. Appearance, aroma and taste much similar to a average pilsner with an exception for a little hint of cascade hop in both aroma and taste. Not bad, but not very interesting either.

name: Tied House Raspberry Wheat
review: Sample at the brewpub. Reddish-orange color with a thin white head that evaporates quickly to an outer ring. Spotty lacing. Aroma of wheat and raspberries. Light body with flavors of artificial raspberries and wheat. The finish is fruity with a mild berry aftertaste. Slightly above average overall.

name: Tied House Raspberry Wheat
review: A nice beer. Has a nice raspberry aroma, but it could be stronger. As it seems to be with most of their beers, they could make them a lot better but most of them seem a little watered down. Flavor of raspberyry is a nice change but kind of weak

name: Tied House Raspberry Wheat
review: Draft at the San Jose brewery. Pours fizzy yellow with a disappearing white head. Vacant nose, attack, palate, and finish, other than a cloying raspberry syrup additive. I think they need to cut the extract by about 40% and the water by about 20% and maybe they’ll be onto something. They wouldn’t be on to anything to write home about, but as it is this is a sticky mess.

name: Tied House Raspberry Wheat
review: Pours hazy golden with thin white head. Aroma is of raspberries and not much else. Just imagine one of those raspberry smirnoff ice things and thats exactly what this beer tastes like, smells like, body, etc.

name: Tied House Passion Pale
review: On tap, sampler. Clear yellow gold with minimal head. Nose is malt and fruit. The fruit in the beer is very mild and seems to work, still its an odd combo and finishes a bit wet and muddy for me. Won’t be trying it again.

name: Tied House Passion Pale
review: A - Clear golden-yellow color with a thin covering of white head with a bit of red in it. Fades quickly leaving behind some lacing. S - Aroma is a mix of wheat and some grains with some sugary sweet passion fruit smell and other fruit. Touch of citrus. T - Starts off with some wheat and other grain flavor withe a touch of fruity sweetness in the background. Through the middle, some stronger sweet passion fruit flavor come through with a bit of citrus. Finish is a mix of sweet fruity flavor and wheat. M - Medium-light bodied with moderate lively carbonation. Smooth and crisp but a bit watery and empty. D - Very drinkable. The beer feels a bit empty and the fruit flavor is a bit too sugary overall.

name: Tied House Passion Pale
review: Draught at the brewpub. The waitress said that they serve a rotating fruit beer that is the same base blond ale with a different fruit mixed in the serving tank. I lucked out and got passion fruit. Clear light gold in color with a lasting white head. Lots of sweet and lightly tangy passion fruit in the aroma. The flavor is an overload os sweet passion-syrup. There is a light touch of malt flavor and maybe a suggestion of hops, but this is all-passion, all the time. Sticky and cloying in the mouth. Much like the gold, this is way too sweet and hardly drinkable.

name: Tied House Passion Pale
review: On tap at the Tied House in Mountain View. Didn’t really inspire any "passion" in me. Golden color, white head. Aroma was sweet malts and passion fruit, maybe a little citrus. Tastes like a mediocre American pale ale with subdued hops and with a weird flavor thrown in that I’m guessing is the passion fruit. Not very balanced. Average palate.

name: Tied House Passion Pale
review: Name: Passion Pale Ale Date: 08/17/1998 Source: Brewpub clear light yellow, whispy white head, sweet fruity aroma, light body with strong fruit flavor, somewhite sweet, Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.7/5.0 Score: **/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

name: Tied House Passion Pale
review: On tap. Quite pale body with a small disappearing head. Not much aroma. Flavor is mild with a little harsh bitterness, maybe a hint of passion as well somewhere. Short aftertaste. Not bad, but a little bit more of everything could not hurt.

name: Tied House Passion Pale
review: on tap.Deep gold with lasting head.. Herbal fruity nose. Sweet passionfruit fore and mid taste with creamy malt finish

name: Tied House Passion Pale
review: Tap. Golden yellow with minimal head. Passion fruit flavor but less noticeable in the aroma. Favorably not an overwhelming fruit flavor, but it is too noticeable to make it a hint and not enough to just enjoy the fruit. A failure by landing in the middle.

name: Rio Grande Outlaw Lager
review: On tap at the Airport Location. Poured an amber color with a thin sized off white head. Caramel and toasted grains.

name: Rio Grande Outlaw Lager
review: Draft at Nob Hill. Clear amber color medium white head. Caramel aroma, subtle pepper. Taste is very lightly toasted caramel.

name: Rio Grande Outlaw Lager
review: Pours clear amber from the bottle. The frothy white head soon fades. Mild caramel, white bread aroma. Taste is sweet, a touch nutty, with a very mild bitterness at the finish. Body light to medium. Okay, but forgettable.

name: Rio Grande Outlaw Lager
review: Nothing about this screams common - just a nondeScript step above a macro generic lager. Lightly malty, little hops...meh.

name: Rio Grande Outlaw Lager
review: Seems I may like this more than others but to me it had nice flavor and hops and no bitter aftertaste. Consumed directly from the bottle. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Rio Grande Outlaw Lager
review: Pours a gold-amber with a small white head and lacing. The aroma is faint sweet malt with a flavor that is sweet up front and a sweet, slightly crisp finish over a medium-light body. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Rio Grande Outlaw Lager
review: This is not a good lager. There’s way too much kilned and caramel malt in this lager. Almost tastes like a brown ale. Overall, I wish brewers would stop falling in love with crystal malt.

name: Rio Grande Outlaw Lager
review: Malty and slightly sour lager, overall body is on the watery side. Dark amber with small foamy head, initial sourness in the aroma can be off-putting. Finish is mix of sour and bitter. This one may be a matter of personal taste.

name: Rio Grande Outlaw Lager
review: Bottle:   Amberish, small sudsy white head, little lacing.   Sweaty stale bready aroma.   Touch nutty, touch biscuity.   Really nutty up front, no real sweat to speak of.   Slightly bready as well.   Moderate body and mouthfeel, however leaning thin.   Finishes quick, very soft nutty notes linger.   Pretty boring overall.   Develops a mealy background after the finish that ain’t all that pleasant.   Meh...

name: Rio Grande Outlaw Lager
review: ruby .. bottle .. mild caramel and baked beans .. actually quite nice, a freakin surprise .. . I signed up for a combination Retirement home and Cemetary. Its quite convenient.

name: Rio Grande Desert Pils
review: On tap at the Airport Location. Poured a lightly hazy yellow color with a thin sized head. Watery pilsner ... some grass and sweet , but not much there.

name: Rio Grande Desert Pils
review: Bottle: Pale, lightly hazed yellow-gold with a puffy white head. Milk, grains aroma. Taste is nicely bitter and creamy pils malt. Really quite good....a little surprised at the low ratings on this one.

name: Rio Grande Desert Pils
review: As Sierra Blanca Desert Pilsner. Clear yellow, white head. Corn, grains, light malt. Some metallic notes. Somewhat bitter finish.

name: Rio Grande Desert Pils
review: A-. Pours a clear golden color with white head. High drink-ability, as promised.

name: Rio Grande Desert Pils
review: Had as Desert Pilsner. Pours wan yellow with a thick, snow-white head. Aroma provides zesty malt and a mixture of pomme and tropical fruit. Flavor is even bolder, fruity - tropical and pomme, a hint of citrus - plus tangy malt, a little sweet. Texture features firm, smooth body and perky fizz. Enjoy your just desert(s).

name: Rio Grande Desert Pils
review: Bottle. Creamy barley malt and hay aroma. Golden yellow with giant white head. Moderately sweet milky barley malt, and moderately bitter quinine/tin and hay flavor. Good body. A solid German pilsner.

name: Rio Grande Desert Pils
review: From notes, tasted at Great American Beer Festival 2017. Will add more notes if I get to try this again. This was miss.

name: Rio Grande Desert Pils
review: Sampled at GABF 2017 in Denver, CO. Numerical rating only - did not take detailed notes. Listed in the GABF program as "Sierra Blanca Desert Pilsner".

name: Rio Grande Desert Pils
review: Tap at the ABQ airport. Light pour, modest white lacing. Thin but crisp, slightly sweet, not a huge amount going on here but not particularly flawed either. Does the job for an airport bar beer.

name: Rio Grande Desert Pils
review: Sampled at GABF 2016 with Paul and Larry. Pours a clear golden body with white lace. Light body and plain mouthfeel with generic grainy/corn notes. Very plain overall, not much else to say.

name: Rio Grande Elfego Bock
review: it’s fun to go out on the road and pick up new beers, but the truth is, too often we find dwarfish little underachievers that scarcely rate three lines of commentary. this one is as brown as bran flakes, and about as interesting. a reasonable head puffed for show and then staked out a modest stronghold around the edge of the glass. besides some oxidation i gathered olfactory evidence of dunkel-like sweet and well-browned malts, which could generously be likened to a whole wheat pancake with a bit of maple, and a bit of baked carrot. indeed it is sweet tasting, with dates and toast, watery feel, and a not quite a medium body fullness of flavor. very negligible hops allow the sugar water effect to linger which is not the best way to finish. could be considered a reasonable quencher down in arizona, particularly given that hellacious summer climate they endure. if you’re a gila monster toasting in that desert inferno, you’d probably love a cool dish of elfego "bock". any gila monsters listening out there? i got a half bottle of elfego right here with your name on it!

name: Rio Grande Elfego Bock
review: I too was disappointed by this one. I don’t know if it was the bock title or not, but this wasn’t anything German. Somewhat of a burnt and yeasty aroma and flavor. Hops were noticeable and didn’t seem to match the beer.

name: Rio Grande Elfego Bock
review: Redddish copper brown with a creamy off-white head. Rather bizarre aroma of cocoa, berries and olive juice. In mouth, rather thin beer with sweet malt, light acidic points, and no hops. Rather boring. Cant remember where I got this bottle, maybe from Degarth?

name: Rio Grande Elfego Bock
review: This beer produces an aroma tha resembles burnt semi-sweet chocolate and raisins. As far as looks go, this beer could pass for a glass of tea. It is flat and watery and only produces a taste of crackers in the aftertaste.

name: Rio Grande Elfego Bock
review: Bought this bottle on a trip to New Mexico. Pours with a spare tan head adn a clear mahogany body. Aroma is light but has wet cardboard and malt. This is thin and watery with very little carbonation. Not a bad beer at all. I’m too hungover to type anymore than that.

name: Rio Grande Elfego Bock
review: Pours a small tan head that settles down quickly. Brown color, light red hue, clarity is very good. Faint malt nose, grainy notes. Body is light, lightly carbonated, watery. Lightly sweet malt flavors, caramel and buttery notes with a bit of chalkiness in the finish. Finish is almost dry. Degarth Delivered this bottle, Thanks man!

name: Rio Grande Elfego Bock
review: Thanks Tim. Toffee/caramel nose - slightly earthy with a hint of hops. Copper body, fluffy off white head that fades quickly. Flavor is sweet caramel malt - more of a brown ale than a bock. A bit of maple in the finish.

name: Rio Grande Elfego Bock
review: If these beer selections don’t get better I am gonna rethink the whole beer of the month thing. Bleck.

name: Rio Grande Elfego Bock
review: Botted beer of the month. Ok beer. Nothing special. Had a sweet malt taste going but that was it.

name: Rio Grande Elfego Bock
review: Not very good. Dark amber with thin white head. Faint aroma of sweet malt. Thin and watery and carbonated. Little or no flavor beyond what you could get from a BMC.

name: Rio Grande Pancho Verde Chile Cerveza
review: On tap at the Airport Location. Poured a golden color with a thin sized head. Green pepper with a maltiness. Not hot (good).

name: Rio Grande Pancho Verde Chile Cerveza
review: Bottle: Clear gold with a short white head. Grain, green pepper aroma. Taste is sweet barley malt with a low level chile heat. Overall.....pretty bland.

name: Rio Grande Pancho Verde Chile Cerveza
review: Bottle. Roasted Hatch chiles, light malt, and straw aroma. Golden yellow with small head. Lightly sweet Hatch chile, light malt, and mildly bitter straw flavor. Okay body. Really nice Hatch chile aroma and flavor in a light bodied beer - I really like it (but roasted Hatch chiles are one of my favorite things on earth).

name: Rio Grande Pancho Verde Chile Cerveza
review: C+. Pours a clear golden color with white head. The description is absolutely right. I was skeptical of the pepper because I've had one before and it was awful, but this one wasn't bad

name: Rio Grande Pancho Verde Chile Cerveza
review: 12 ounce bottle from wchesser. The beer is a clear gold with a white head of foam. Strong roasted chile pepper aroma. Fairly vegetal. Medium body and medium carbonation. Kind of gross, but also exactly what I expected. Would be a good cooking beer.

name: Rio Grande Pancho Verde Chile Cerveza
review: From notes, tasted at Great American Beer Festival 2017 (listed as "Sierra Blanca Green Chile Cerveza"). Will add more notes if I get to try this again. This was surprisingly good.

name: Rio Grande Pancho Verde Chile Cerveza
review: Sampled at GABF 2017 in Denver, CO. Numerical rating only - did not take detailed notes. Listed in the GABF program as "Sierra Blanca Green Chile Cerveza".

name: Rio Grande Pancho Verde Chile Cerveza
review: Pours gold from the bottle. The white fizzy head fades fast. Aroma has a soft malty base with noticeable chili. Taste is very sweet, with a strong chili inflection. Finishes sweet and spicy. Feels contrived, and lacks all nuance. Quickly wears out its welcome.

name: Rio Grande Pancho Verde Chile Cerveza
review: Head literally runs away, sickly yellow appearance. Nose/taste of corn, peppers, mildly spicy, palate finish of a soda. Not really even like a beer.

name: Rio Grande Pancho Verde Chile Cerveza
review: APPEARANCE- looks like a lager. Head is fizzy, and short lived. NOSE- um, none. FLAVOR- tastes like super cheap lager And hardly any Chile flavor.

name: Rio Grande Bock Holiday
review: Loose soapy white head and golden-amber body with flaky suspended particles. Munich malts dominate in the nose with elements of well-toasted bread crusts, a note of toffee, and iced tea. Toasty malt flavor with a twangy extract quality. Some warm spicy properties and a mild hop presence. Body is flat and a little watery, especially for a doppelbock. Not bad overall.

name: Snake River Pale Ale
review: Of all the groovy things of the 70s (moon landings, shag carpet, psychedelic drugs, macrame, bell bottoms & watergate) this beer does not belong on this list. Blatz does. Snake River Pale Ale? Do you think Evel Knevel was drinking this junk when he tried (on September 8, 1974) jumping the Snake River....and failed, oh-so miserably? Hell to the no. That wily fuck was loaded on Blatz, inspiring the kids of the 70s to look up to him like the demi-god that he was. Sure he may have crashed and burned, and failed miserably in his idiotic stunt, but when you are as full of Blatz as he undoubtedly was no one could care less.....himself, the spectators, the worldwide TV audience...... Blatz? Why not?

name: Snake River Pale Ale
review: Deep yellow color, light citrus nose. Light tinny flavor with mild bitterness. Not sure if can is old or not

name: Snake River Pale Ale
review: Draft at the brewery in Jackson, WY. Drinkable American pale ale with moderate bitterness

name: Snake River Pale Ale
review: Draft at the Snake River Brewing, Jackson, WY. Clear deep golden color with a small creamy white head. The flavor is citrusy and resiny hops, moderate bitterness, dryness and malt. Quite okay. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Snake River Pale Ale
review: Nice citrussy and bitter pale ale. Light yellow beer and very drinkable. Nice!

name: Snake River Pale Ale
review: Tap. Pours clear golden, small creamy white head, great lacing. Aroma is super light, oranges, pine, caramel. Flavor is light plus sweet, light bitter. Medium body. Meh.

name: Snake River Pale Ale
review: Blind tasted with 3 other pale ales. Beers were: 1. McMenamins Hammerhead Ale 2. Moab Brewery Pale Ale (6%) 3. Blue Island Tile Setter 4. Snake River Pale Ale. Rater 1 rated the beers: 1234, Rater 2 (ME): 1234, Rater 3: 1324, Rater 4:1423. 473ml can. Golden pour. Aroma is very soft, some haylike malt, herbs, grass. Flavor is sweet, not much else going on, hint metallic, not great. Post tasting thoughts: My guess is this was old, typically this brewer is better than this with the pales.

name: Snake River Pale Ale
review: Can. Golden color. Aroma of biscuity malt, citrus, herbal pine and caramel. Taste has herbal grassy pine, biscuity malt, bitter citrus and crisp. Typical cascade beer, nice.

name: Snake River Pale Ale
review: From old tasting notes. Bright copper color topped by a rocky beige head. Soft nutty malt aroma. Wonderfully smooth toaste malt flavor with a buttery character. Long dry hoppy finish.

name: Snake River Pale Ale
review: Pours gold into the cup. The head is porous, white and fluffy. Aroma is melon, spruce. Taste is lightly bitter with dry finish. Body is light. Rating by memory: drank in back country under steady onslaught of mosquitoes.

name: Snake River Jenny Lake Lager
review: Can. Caramel malt aroma with notes of bread, nuts and some toffee. Pours clear amber colored with a half a finger of off white head that has excellent retention and lacing. Starts with sweet caramel and bready malt flavors. Finishes smooth with nutty malt and toffee malt flavors. Solid Vienna lager.

name: Snake River Jenny Lake Lager
review: (Draught) Pours a clear copper body with a medium off-white head. Aroma of grain, caramel, and light citrus. Flavor of grain, caramel, nuts, earth, and biscuit.

name: Snake River Jenny Lake Lager
review: Draft at the brewery in Jackson, WY. Pleasant dark amber lager beer with a malty taste

name: Snake River Jenny Lake Lager
review: Draft. Amber beer with a cream head. Malt and light spice aroma. Malt and spice flavor. Medium bodied Malt and spice linger with light grass.

name: Snake River Jenny Lake Lager
review: From 12oz can to lager glass. Pour os a cloudy brown/orange, thin white head. Nose is malty, caramel, toasty, nutty. Taste is light medium bodied, sweet. Finish is long and carbonated.

name: Snake River Jenny Lake Lager
review: On tap at Sanfords Grub and Pub. Golden pour. Sweet grainy malts. Taste is pretty blah, some grains but not much else.

name: Snake River Jenny Lake Lager
review: Tap at Sanfords. Clear orange pour with a white head. Malty and sweet. Hint of metal. Meh.

name: Snake River Alpine Fest Lager
review: On draft at the brewpub during Oktoberfest. Pours a clear amber with an off white head. Aromas are of hay and hazelnut. Flavors are sweet malts with very little hoppiness. Smooth finish.

name: Snake River Alpine Fest Lager
review: Pint at the brewery. Has a nice deep copper color to it with a decent white head. The taste is of roasted malts, bread, caramel and some hops. Similar aroma. Has a full body with a bit of bitterness. An excellent brew. Made my trip up to Idaho and back worth it.

name: Snake River Alpine Fest Lager
review: On draught at the local Old Chicago. It poured a gorgeous red colour with about a half inch of foam. There would probably have been more but the bartender is pretty meticulous about beer vs foam and I appreciated that. The smell was malty, toasty, and there was a smidgeon of some hop action going on. The taste was damn good. What I expected from a well made sample of the style. Caramel malt with a good but not overdone side order of bread, a bit of a graininess, and a light sprinkling of hop bitterness. Well done brew and I found it very easy to drink; very good tasting and very good mouthfeel. I’ll be drinking more during OC’s Oktoberfest mini tour!

name: Snake River Alpine Fest Lager
review: On tap. Amber to copper with an off white top. Light scent of malts and caramel. Taste is mild, notes of caramel and yeast.

name: Snake River Alpine Fest Lager
review: Also at the Brewery, tastes a whole lot like the Vienna Lager, with the only difference being in the amount of bitterness.

name: Snake River Alpine Fest Lager
review: on tap-pours a foamy off white head and gold color. There is no aroma. Taste is medium malt-caramel/some smoky, secondary hops. Nice, mild. OK carbonation.

name: Snake River Alpine Fest Lager
review: Head is initially average sized, frothy, off-white, mostly diminishing. Body is dark amber. Aroma is moderately malty (toasted bread, cookie, caramel), lightly hoppy (flowers). Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter. Medium body, watery/velvety texture, lively carbonation. It’s a bit too by-the-numbers and plain for the style, but it’s clean, quaffable, and pleasant.

name: Snake River Alpine Fest Lager
review: A very nice malty lager, its a very neutral lager overall and good if your trying to jsut start drinking lager beers.

name: Snake River Alpine Fest Lager
review: Nice copper color. Nice malty aroma. A great Vienna lager. Good balance, not too overpowering in any one way. A very drinkable, nice beer. I think this style in general is a good option for novice drinkers...and this particular beer would be toward the top of the pack.

name: Spaten Optimator
review: Well reputed as one of the best doppelbocks. Lots of complex taste that supports the maltiness, quite drinkable despite its high ABV.

name: Spaten Optimator
review: Bottle 33cl. @home poured into a teku glass. Clear deep ruby brown, small fizzy beige head, mostly diminishing. Aroma roasted malt, caramel, candy sugar, sugar syrup. Flavour light heavy sweet and medium bitter, roasted malt, caramel, raisin, candy sugar. Medium body, oily to sticky texture, soft carbonation, malty sweetbitter finish, light roast and caramelized sugar, much better than expected and also less boozy, good doppelbock.

name: Spaten Optimator
review: Botella de 33 cl @ Saveur Biere online. Color marrón oscuro, oro viejo. Espuma beige abundante que se disipa rápidamente. Baja retención. Aroma a pasas, higos secos, malta tostada. En boca no es muy dulce, algo licorosa, fruta seca.

name: Spaten Optimator
review: The darkest one of the variety. Lots of malt. Reminds me how much better American beer is than European. They beat us on tradition but their beer has been outdone by American microbrews.

name: Spaten Optimator
review: Draught. Pours dark brown with a small beige head. Aroma is molasses, toffee, raisin, bread, brow sugar, and slight coffee. Taste is molasses, raisin, coffee, brown sugar, and a little chocolate. Medium+ body. Medium carbonation. Creamy-ish mouthfeel. Need to retry - I remember this being better/less sweet.

name: Spaten Optimator
review: Nice aroma, small head, good malt taste. Pours a nice dark brown in color. Nice full body, but doesn't feel heavy. very easy drinking.

name: Spaten Optimator
review: Wonderful full flavoured, complex, strong. Beautiful beer, my style. online saveaur bier

name: Spaten Optimator
review: 330 ml bottle from Beer Hawk's mystery case, bb 07/2019 so ok. Red/brown, clear, pale beige head. Nose - raisins, dried figs, malts. Taste - bittersweet, follows the nose.

name: Spaten Optimator
review: 12 oz bottle, pours reddish brown clear. Medium body, aroma of dark fruits and malt. Bready raisin taste with slightly bitter finish.

name: Spaten Optimator
review: Appearance of coca cola and some of the sweetness too. Figs and licorice in the flavour with heavy malt backbone. Morello cherry tartness stops it being over the top in my opinion. I like this style anyway and thought this was an interesting and worthy example.

name: Twenty Tank Moodys Hi-Top IPA
review: Name: Moody’s Hi-Top IPA Date: 03/21/1997 Mode: Firkin Source: Brewpub cloudy light amber, frothy head (cask), strong pnw hop (cascade?) aroma, light body, strong and lasting citrus hop flavor, mild bitter finish, much like an esb -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Name: Moody’s Hi-Top IPA Date: 08/15/1998 Mode: nitro fine white head, thick lace, delicate citrus hop aroma, very smooth body (nitro), solid bitternes from start to finish, Aroma: 8/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 8/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 17/20 Rating: 3.9/5.0 Score: ****/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

name: Twenty Tank Moodys Hi-Top IPA
review: Big floral west coast IPA was big then it would probably be average now. Good malt body a touch of sweetness and good bitterness.

name: Twenty Tank Moodys Hi-Top IPA
review: Opaque amber.Bitter throughout but green aromatic hops not flavoring ones...

name: Twenty Tank Red Top Ale
review: Date: 09/08/1997 Source: Brewpub Appearance: dark opaque amber, Aroma: light aroma, Flavor: flavor starts malty then the strong hops kick in just before a bitter finish Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 16/20 Rating: 3.4/5.0 Score: ***/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

name: Twenty Tank Red Top Ale
review: Very much a true amber with aslight touch of roasted malt. Cramel and crytal malt forward with good floral dry hooped nose.

name: Twenty Tank Red Top Ale
review: Brown. Carmel nose. Carmel malt flavor with lingering dry hop finish.......

name: Twenty Tank Red Top Ale
review: Alas, Twenty Tank is no more. A victim to the rising rents in a neighborhood the Tank made trendy. But the beers were good if not amazing. The Red Top was a moderatly hopped red ale with a distinctive creamy texture. The recipe called for torified barley to obtain that nice smooth mouth feel.

name: Twenty Tank Bowsers Brown Ale
review: Clean amber ale taste of crytal malt witha touch of roast. nice but basic brown ale.

name: Twenty Tank Bowsers Brown Ale
review: Clear brown with tan head. Good malt nose. Clean malt profile throughout....

name: Twenty Tank Pollywanna Porter
review: This was last consumed exactly one year to the day after they closed. Great porter Big vinous chewy roasted brew of great depth. Espresso and cocoa beans nice finish.

name: Twenty Tank Pollywanna Porter
review: This was my favorite porter on tap for a long time, but then the brewery closed down. This was a coffee-heavy brew with some hints of chocolate and possibly brown sugar. It was impossible to taste a cup of coffee after drinking this beer as the coffee essence of the beer was THAT strong. Great stuff, shame about the brewery.

name: Twenty Tank Pollywanna Porter
review: Black with lasting tan head. Great roasted nose. Good roasted malt profile. Great lace

name: Twenty Tank Kinnikinick Old Scout Stout
review: Date: 09/08/1997 Source: Brewpub black, thin tan head, sweet roasted coffee aroma, rich roasted flavor with a dose of chocolate malt and espresso beans, just enough bittering hops to keep it balanced without being hoppy Aroma: 8/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 8/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 17/20 Rating: 3.9/5.0 Score: ****/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

name: Twenty Tank Kinnikinick Old Scout Stout
review: Coffee and roated amlts in abundance, dry and balanced with good mouthfeel and low carbonation.

name: Twenty Tank Kinnikinick Old Scout Stout
review: Black,brown head. Roasted coffee nose. Great roasted espresso taste. Chewy with great body.

name: Unibroue Seigneuriale
review: 750ml bottle: This one pours a murky, oxidized copper color. There was a wisp of an off-white head that left no lacing. Good nose. Yeasty and bready. Some grains, biscuit, faint spice and fruits. The taste is very good. Bready and yeasty, some spiciness, fruits, malts, grains, biscuit. A lot in there with nothing really on top of anything else. Just an excellent blend of flavors. I would definitely buy this one again.

name: Seigneuriale Triple
review: 750ml bottle pours a golden orangeish color with a huge white head that leaves a healthy lacing on the glass. Aroma is llight fruits and spices with some yeast and alcohol. Taste is fruity and malty sweetness with spices and yeast and a light hop bitterness. Medium to heavy body and an abundance of carbonation leave a nice tingle on the palate. A very complex and tasty ale.

name: Seigneuriale Blonde
review: 500ml bottle pours a pale cloudy golden color with 2 fingers of white head which settles quickly leaving only a few spots of lacing on the glass. Aroma is bananas and yeast with some clove. Taste is fruity sweet with some yeast and light malts and hop bitterness. A very appealing blonde ale which was quite enjoyable.

name: Seigneuriale Blonde
review: Pours a hazy, straw-like blonde with a tall soapy head. Powerful aroma of yeast, banana, apple... Taste is sweet with the fruits more powerful than the yeast. Dry finish. Great summer beer! Too bad it’s retired.

name: Seigneuriale Réserve
review: 500ml bottle pours a pale amber color with a huge white head that settles to leave some nice lacing on the glass. Aroma is fruity with some malts and yeast with some hints of spices. Taste is fruity and malty sweet with some yeast and light hop bitterness and hints of spices. Medium body and lots of carbonation. This is a truly outstanding beer.

name: JW Dundees Honey Light Brown
brewery: Dundee Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
review: On tap at Valhalla. Not too outstanding. Very sweet, almost syrupy. Too much for my taste, but drinkable.

name: JW Dundees Honey Light Brown
brewery: Dundee Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
review: Amber with a small white head. Weak malt aroma. Thin and dry flavour with honey notes.

name: JW Dundees Honey Light Brown
brewery: Dundee Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
review: A lighter version of the JW Dundee’s honey brown is not a bad idea, in my opinion. I don’t mind the regular, and I could see drinking this as a Yuengling lagel or Sam Adams light substitute on a hot summer day.

name: JW Dundees Honey Light Brown
brewery: Dundee Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
review: this is the most digusting foul beer that i have had the displeasure of tasting in a long while,why does anyone even buy this crap?

name: JW Dundees Honey Light Brown
brewery: Dundee Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
review: This is ABSOLUTE shit!!! I hate honey brown, they somehow took shit and found a way to make it shittier!

name: JW Dundees Honey Light Brown
brewery: Dundee Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
review: As far as im concerned there's no reason to water down a honey brown, its weak enough as it is. Damn that Hillsdale Kroger for selling this, damn them

name: JW Dundees Honey Light Brown
brewery: Dundee Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
review: even worse than the original. For those who actually like this crap, I hope one day you will be able to appreciate a real beer.

name: JW Dundees Honey Light Brown
brewery: Dundee Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
review: has an slighly off smell and a rather sour taste. oddly popular for an unpleasant beer

name: JW Dundees Honey Light Brown
brewery: Dundee Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
review: This beer's popularity is waning. I remember the big Honey Brown craze a few years ago. What was up with that?

name: JW Dundees Honey Light Brown
brewery: Dundee Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
review: My ex used to love this stuff. I never stole any from her, if that says anything. Seems like everything that might have given it decent flavor was fermented, leaving a funny smelling, neutral tasting brew.

name: Speakeasy Big Daddy IPA
review: White weak creamy head. Cloudy pale yellow colour. Aroma is hoppy with citrus pera Apple and milky notes. Flavor is hoppy too with citrus apple and milky tones, ending in an hoppy finish. Medium bodied.

name: Speakeasy Big Daddy IPA
review: On tap. Pours a clear gold with a yellow hue and a white head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has a nice citrus and pine combination with a hint of grass and a light grain backbone. Flavor is more grass and pine, a bit of citrus rind and light grains underlying.

name: Speakeasy Big Daddy IPA
review: Vycap 100 pív. Vôòa alkoholova medova. Farba medova. Chu vodova medova alkoholova.

name: Speakeasy Satchmo Stout
review: so after tromping around san francisco for 20+ blocks we all had to piss real bad, i said ’the next bar we find were going into’, so we end up at this little hole in the wall bar that didn’t even have a sign (somewhat speak easy-esque) and as we all order out drinks we all find out that we all received free drinks, we had free drinks all night!! it was the first night this place opened and they were giving out free drinks all night as some sort of a promotional deal. my friends took full advantage, drinking top shelf liqour, i however stuck to this beer all night, i wasn;t able to fir as many in me as they were with the grey goose, but i’m not about to complain. black body wth a frothy brown head, Rich mocha nose and flavor, sweet chocolate malts, extremely roasty and warming, thick and divine. This is a very good stout, and thats coming from a former michigander and bell’s nerd. ou must try this stout.

name: Speakeasy Satchmo Stout
review: some malt derived bitterness with a very roasted body and an almost burnt wood touch to it. Cigar and tobacco nose with some hop presence. Good dry lightly acidic finish.

name: Speakeasy Satchmo Stout
review: on tap at the toronado - very hoppy for a stout i thought, which was good in a sense it wasnt like drinking a cold glass of folgers it was spicy and chocolatey, very different, and very easy to drink

name: Speakeasy Satchmo Stout
review: Tap. Roasted coffee and chocolate aroma. Big roasted flavor with a light body.

name: Speakeasy Satchmo Stout
review: Lots of particulate, floral and vine nose which may be related. Folgers coffee flavors. Leaves an unfined coat on the glass you can taste.

name: Speakeasy Satchmo Stout
review: Flavorful and very hoppy for a stout, making it a nice session beer despite the surprisingly high abv (6.5%). Body is too watery, though.

name: Speakeasy Satchmo Stout
review: Rich and creamy, chocolate and toasted grains, with a bit of hops to boot, really a top notch brew, and the bottles are beautiful, and the beer is even better from a nice pint glass, along with the Tornado, my heart belongs San Francisco's breweries!

name: Marin Harvest Ale
review: Sampled as part of a sampler pack. Aroma was mild hops and sweet malts. Appearance was light brown with a thin lacey head. Mouthfeel was a little harsh and flavor lacked any kick of hops you expect from a harvest ale.

name: Marin Harvest Ale
review: 1998 vintage, thx to herbjones for this taste. Orange-amber color, smallish head, sweet malty aroma. Malt dominate; honey, toffee roasted just a bit. Real good if you’re in the malty mood.

name: Marin Harvest Ale
review: 1998 vintage. Was expecting a hop monster ala Sierra Nevadas Harvest only to get a barleywine light. Deep orange color with a thin head. Sweet malty nose that carries through into the flavor along with some toffee notes.

name: Marin Harvest Ale
review: 1998 hoppage thx to herbjones for sharing Hazy copper color, very syrupy sweet smell, lots of malt everywhere. very little hops. thx to herbjones for sharing, a bit thin, but nice.

name: Marin Harvest Ale
review: Bottle of the 2000 vintage. A dark golden brown with a slight haze and a tan head. A rich complex malt, slightly toasted, caramel, and honey aroma. The flavor is all malt and honey with interesting layers. A solid beer.

name: Marin Harvest Ale
review: 2001 vintage. Medium brown-orange color, small head. Medium bodied ale. Complex malt flavor, somewhat Belgian is style. Intense hop flavor as well. Nice complex balance. Complex flavor combination, yet well finished/balanced taste. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is very smooth and clean. Aftertaste is slightly bitter. Very interesting beer. Etched beer bottle.

name: Marin Harvest Ale
review: Balanced, soft and small bubbled. Near headless. Scant aroma. Oily. Extended bitter. Blunt instead of punctuated flavors.

name: Carlton Sheaf Stout
review: Aroma is almost whiskey-like, then smoky, roasted, but still alcohol. Black - opaque, with bubbles visible just at the glass. Tall tan head, thick and creamy. The head recedes moderately, leaving bubbly lacing. Feel is thin to moderate. Initial taste is dark fruit and roasted malts, transitioning to a slightly astringent bitterness in the middle and finish. Aftertaste is dry and somewhat bitter. The middle and finish also has an odd earthiness that is hard to describe; not unpleasant, just unusual. Overall, seems to be a bit of a cross between an English Stout and a Dry Irish Stout. Good enough to buy again (but, I probably won't).

name: Carlton Sheaf Stout
review: Bottle from convenient store in Santa Cruz, CA (near Westerhold house). Aroma is burnt sugar, bark. Taste is roasted malts, burnt sugars, charred caramel. A bit rough around the edges but some interesting burnt sugar notes.

name: Carlton Sheaf Stout
review: A nice Australian stout. The Guinness of Australia. Cheers from Cannery Row Beer Club. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Carlton Sheaf Stout
review: From old tasting notes. Deep dark brown color with a brownish tan head. Roasted chocolatey malt nose. Sweet roasted malt flavor is coffee-like and bitter. Good body. Burnt caramel finish is long and pleasing. Tasty and drinkable.

name: Carlton Sheaf Stout
review: Bottle, Blacktown, Australia. Pours very dark brown with a tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, dark chocolate, cocoa. Flavor is light sweet, light bitter, roast malt, bread, coffee, chocolate, cocoa, little licorice. Medium body, average carbonation, fairly dry finish. Surprisingly good. 090317

name: Carlton Sheaf Stout
review: bottle @ Keg Liquors / Clarksville IN --- Aroma of roasted malt. Opaque brown / black color, brown head that is slow to recede, lace cobwebs. Taste is smooth roasted malt in a creamy base. Mild carbonation, and more of the same through a medium length finish. Simple, yet effective as a common stout.

name: Carlton Sheaf Stout
review: Big tan head dark pour soft medium carbonation aromas milky touch roast coffee liquorice chocolate mild fruit the flavours coffee a roast note milky chocolate an oily taste cocoa nut smooth note of prune bitter taste is there quality stuff the finish best notes some fine tastes sweetness of malts cocoa taste superb roast bitter lasting taste very enjoyable stout

name: Carlton Sheaf Stout
review: Bottle @ RBSG 2015. Thanks, Ferris. Black in color with a big khaki head. Smells like a mix of cardboard and chocolate syrup. Sort of metallic and grassy as well. Hints of coffee grounds, roasted malt, and toasted bread. Doesn’t really taste much better, either. Sort of oxidized and cardboardy. Sweet, sugary chocolate sauce and caramel. Bitter metallic, roast, and coffee grounds finish.

name: Carlton Sheaf Stout
review: Bottle - Roast and some cocoa notes. Jet black with a decent light brown head. Light dark malts and a little toast.

name: Carlton Sheaf Stout
review: Bottle on the RBSG party bus Clear dark brown with a medium sized tan head, good lacing. Aroma of dark malts and chocolate. Taste of dark malts, chocolate with a dry finish Ok

name: Deschutes Black Butte Porter
review: Malty chocolatey aroma. Dark brown body, light brown head. Weak taste. Weak palate. So-so overall.

name: Deschutes Black Butte Porter
review: Tap @ Deschutes taproom, Bend. Pours clear deep brown, small off-white head. Aroma has liquorice nods, dark malt. Taste is liquorice-forward, distant chocolate, fairly light bodied, easy-drinking, gentle coffee hints. Nice flavourful, light porter.

name: Deschutes Black Butte Porter
review: Bottle. Dark brown body, small beige head with average retention and no lacing. Aroma of dark chocolate, fig jam, oak, leather, burned caramel and toffee. Taste of burned caramel, lava chocolate cake, herbs, rye toast and vanilla beans. Flavorful!

name: Hacker-Pschorr Münchner Dunkel (Alt Munich Dark)
review: 500ml bottle brewed in Germany at 5%. Opaque dark, a very bright light reveals some toffee brown at the edges. Good-sized reasonable duration foamy head. Moderate carbonation. Somewhat burnt sweet malt aroma. Very slight grassy/earthy hops, relatively thick texture but still has that dunkel thinness in comparison to its stout lookalikes, star of the show is the toffee sweet slightly burnt sugar toasty malt. Very straightforward, knows exactly what it wants to do and does it. Has only enough lager characteristics to stop it being something else entirely. Splendid dunkel. Augustiner's might be better-made, Ayinger's definitely shows off more brewing skill and ingredients, but this just plain hits the spot. I'm keen to compare Ayinger's unfiltered dunkel to this, to see if it's the naturtrueb nature that makes this go down such a treat.

name: Hacker-Pschorr Münchner Dunkel (Alt Munich Dark)
review: Ciemnobursztynowe klarowne piwo z niez³¹ pian¹. Aromat g³ównie karmelowy, trochê toffi. W smaku kawa zbo¿owa, karmel trochê czekolady deserowej.

name: Hacker-Pschorr Münchner Dunkel (Alt Munich Dark)
review: Clear brown, orange when exposed to light. Creamy brownish white head, three fingers, good retention. Lots of carbonation visually. Texture is watery, with little fizz and some density. Aroma is malty, caramel, chocolate, nuts, bread, butterscotch. Taste follows the aroma. Really malty, caramelly, in a positive way. Almost sweet. Bittersweet ending with notes of nuts and caramel. Alcohol well integrated. Good representation of a Dunkel, I suppose.

name: Hacker-Pschorr Münchner Dunkel (Alt Munich Dark)
review: Draft. A- Malty, caramel, mild cocoa, subtle roast. A- Dark brown color, dark liquid, off white head. T- Caramel, biscuit, cocoa, subtle roast. P- Medium body, average texture, average carbonation, balanced finish. O- Pain in the ass finding this beer. Brewed by Paulaner when I was busy searching for Hacker Pschorr. Menu listed it simply as Hacker Pschorr dark bier. I do not like German beer menus I've learned. Makes for tough rating.

name: Hacker-Pschorr Münchner Dunkel (Alt Munich Dark)
review: Tawny brown pour, thin tan head. Nose is roasted malt. Middle is light toffee, dark kilned malt, herbal bitterness. Finish is malty. Nice dunkel.

name: Hacker-Pschorr Münchner Dunkel (Alt Munich Dark)
review: Dark amber to brown color with beige head. Aroma has toasted malt, brown sugar and some burnt caramel notes. Taste is grainy with dark bread crust notes, toasted malts and some bitterness on the finish to balance out the flavors. Medium body and carbonation. Overall it's a decent dark lager with no obvious flaws but it really lacks personality.

name: Hacker-Pschorr Münchner Dunkel (Alt Munich Dark)
review: 500ml bottle bought from the Offie, Leicester. Reddish brown with a creamy beige/tan head. Smells of creamy chocolate, Ovaltine and vanilla. Sweet taste with a touch of black grape. Velvety smooth finish. Light to medium carbonation. A lovely traditional Dunkel.

name: Hacker-Pschorr Münchner Dunkel (Alt Munich Dark)
review: Pours chestnut brown, clear, topped with a larger tan coloured head, but not so lasting. Medium caramel and biscuity nose, quite sweet feel. Medium caramel sweetness and medium bitterness in the finish. Short aftertaste. Medium body. Good, but nothing amazing. Decently drinkable.

name: Hacker-Pschorr Münchner Dunkel (Alt Munich Dark)
review: Bottle at the 'Back to the Roots Classic German Beer Tasting' session. I only took numerical notes while having this.

name: Hacker-Pschorr Münchner Dunkel (Alt Munich Dark)
review: Pours a rich copper with off white head. Sweet honey and dark bread aroma and taste. Notes: bottle at L’Arcade Mainz, Aug ‘17

name: Hale's Wee Heavy
review: Bottle. Orange amber, golden head. Bready toffee aroma and flavour, a touch of orange peel, a bit boozy.

name: Hale's Wee Heavy
review: [3/3/15] Draught at Hales Ales Brewery & Pub in Seattle. Clear amber. Aroma of malt, caramel and toffee. Sweet malty flavor with caramel, toffee and a drier finish. Medium-bodied.

name: Hale's Wee Heavy
review: I love the way this all comes together, some savory winter spices blending perfectly with the peaty character of the Scotch ale. Nice fluffy head on a cloudy dark copper body. Earthy, malty aroma. Taste brings more winter spice, which lingers afterward. All around a great winter warmer.

name: Hale's Wee Heavy
review: First sip was funky. Decided to let it open up and the flavors started to coincide with each other quite nicely.

name: Hale's Wee Heavy
review: On tap at Stateside, pours a hazy amber orange with a small white head. Aroma brings out caramel, brown sugar, and bready malt. Flavour is less sweet than expected, with notes of caramel, bready malt, and a fairly prominent spiciness in there that cuts down the sweetness. Balanced and drinkable, yet nothing overly provocative. Decent.

name: Hale's Wee Heavy
review: Bottle (12oz $1.80): Golden brown with 1-2 finger white head. This was different than other Wee Heavys I have had. Its sweet and bitter. medium plus body.. syrupy.

name: Hale's Wee Heavy
review: 12oz bottle poured into Gordon’s thistle glass. Surprisingly there is some particles, floaties in this beer despite the clear bottom of the bottle. A dark amber-brown color. A glow o the beer with low clarity. A medium sized head that leaves a surface covering lacing. Aroma is slightly grassy with a slightly syrupy malt character. Its not hoppy, its not too sweet (yet there is a faint barley syrup candy aspect). In the flavor there is also a bit of toffee and slightly fruity. But this is pretty damn good for a six pack Scotch Ale. Medium body with an aftertaste of light fruit-syrup.

name: Hale's Wee Heavy
review: Draught at Hales Ales Brewery and Pub Cloudy dark amber color with creamy head. Light aroma. Smooth mouthfeel, quite round, with moderate residual sweetness; good Scottish malt flavor, lightly smokey, lean, lightly fruity; correct bitterness. Pleasant drink.

name: Hale's Wee Heavy
review: Bottle. Pours a hazy brown color with a smallish off-white head on it. Nose has a little bit of toast and nuts in there, with just a hint of some spices in there. Taste is also pretty spicy, with a hint of some sweetness up front. Meh.

name: Hale's Wee Heavy
review: Bottle from the Wine and Beer Haus, Seaside, OR. Caramel malt aroma with some hoppiness. Pours a deep caramel color with a thin beige head and very little lacing. Caramel malt flavor though a little watery. Finishes dry with some hops as well as some metallic flavors which is unfavorable. Ok scotch ale but the finish isn't good. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Chapeau Exotic
review: Amber clear with a thin head. Smell of pineapple. Sour, sweet, almost no bitterness and the taste of pineapple. A good alternative to pineapple juice.

name: Chapeau Exotic
review: Helder donkergeel beier zonder schuim. Smaak is zoet met een vreemde wat muffe bijsmaak. Ik vind het geen fijne combinatie en herken de ananas ook totaal niet.

name: Dieu du Ciel! Fumisterie
review: 341ml bottle. Clear dark orange with a frothy beige head. Flavors are toasted cereals, caramel, molasses, herbs and berries with smoky and spicy notes. Medium body, moderate to good carbonation, oily texture.

name: Dieu du Ciel! Fumisterie
review: Draft - Light wood and twig. Clear copper with a decent white head. Sweet caramel and bitter with a nice twig note.

name: Belle Gueule Originale
review: 2014 rating. Pours an average size foamy off white head and has a pale golden, light amber appearance. Very bubbly. Ok lacing. Aromas of light malts, grains, corn and a bit of barley. Flavours are mainly sweet malts, mild grains and wheats. Some notes of herbal hops. Pretty excessive carbonation. Medium retention. Tingling and somewhat astringent mouthfeel. An ok beer.

name: Belle Gueule Originale
review: Can from local iga grocery A: corn, light caramel, light cereal App: brilliantly clear copper lasting smallish white head. T/p: thin to med body with sweet finish of short duration. Med carbonation. O: Macro like. a little too sweet perhaps, still easy to drink. Won’t probably buy it again.

name: Belle Gueule Originale
review: Bright straw color with weak activity. White 1 finger head, lasts 5 minutes, with poor legs. Aromas and flavors of corn, sweet roasted malts, a little herbal spices. High on the sugar with a syrupy feel, and bit bready. Slick light body with moderate carbonation. Faint finish ending with a roasted malt feel, slightly bitter dry. Overall a dull craft having faint watery adjunct flavors. Too sugary and thin, but still fresh. Even from tap it doesn’t help.

name: Deschutes Bachelor ESB
review: From May 2007 . Purchased at Poplar Wine and Spirits in Casper. This pours from 12oz bottle(best by 04-06-07) a clear amber with a good head of foam that shrinks fairly slowly to a fin layer and it has some good lacing. The smell has a nice hoppy nose with notes of caramel and biscuit. The taste has big notes of floral hops up front with biscuit and caramel malt following in the background. That's a pretty bitter start to this session but it all balances out nicely with the ample malt presence. Further sips in and I'm getting some grapefruit mixed in with the floral hops and it kind of makes my mouth pucker a little but the malt *never* lets the hops get out of hand and *that's* working for me because it makes me want to take more sips and that's always a good thing. ;^) The finish is very dry and the mouthfeel, for me, is spot on for the style. This is a very good ESB and I'm glad that it's back in town after being absent for many years. I'm just hoping that I can get some fresher samples so I can compare and perhaps update this review.

name: Deschutes Bachelor ESB
review: Bottle. Copper-Orange in colour. Malty; sweet toasted malts, toffee, caramel. Hoppy; floral and spicy hops. Fruity; citrus-orange. Nice malt/hop balance. Sweet malty throughout leading a dry bitter hoppy finish. Tasty. Very drinkable. (2009-08)

name: Deschutes Bachelor ESB
review: nice sticky head.. good lacing... hazy amber brews. grassy floral hops are very well balanced with fruity yeasty notes and lite toffee and toasted malts. Flavor is very similar to the aroma.. but slightly lending itself more toward the hops... more toasted/biscuit malts.. earthy hop flavor... good bitterness and ultimately very well balanced. medium body with just enough low carbonation to keep things interesting... very drinkable.

name: Deschutes Bachelor ESB
review: Brigh amber beer with a lasting white head. Aroma is roasted caramel and malt. Flavor is sweet malt with caramel. Low carbonation and average body.

name: Deschutes Bachelor ESB
review: "along with anderson valley and goose island, one of the better ESBs out there. pretty close to the traitional style, but with a little more fresh smelling hop complexity going on."

name: Deschutes Bachelor ESB
review: Reviewed from notes. This was poured into a pint glass. The appearance was a hazy orange to glossed over brown color. Bar pour yielded barely a head. Barely any lacing was around the glass. The smell had a toasted caramel nuttiness over and underneath. The taste was somewhat sweet nutty maltiness. There’s a dry sweet roasted nutty aftertaste and finish. On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium in body with a slight sessionability about it. The carbonation finishes slightly smooth. Overall, good ESB. Too bad, it’s been retired.

name: Deschutes Bachelor ESB
review: Best by: 05JUL11 A: Pours a toasted caramel ale with a single finger of yellow soapy head which falls in a few minutes to a broken sheet of the same. Excellent clarity. Rings of lace. S: Creamy and sweet with good earthy bitterness. Slightest hint of oxidation (but this is expired, so I can’t dock for that). T: Extra bitter, and earthy. Definitely english in nature, with earthy and soily hops and the yeast is bready. M: This is medium bodied, but lacks a certain ’bounce’ I feel with most ESB’s. Carb is low end of moderate. O: Good, but not great. Pretty decent. And likely a bit of Homer in my grading as Deschutes is one of my favorites. Serving type: bottle 07-27-2011

name: Deschutes Bachelor ESB
review: 9th November 2009 Hazy amber beer. Semi soft palate but with a carbonated sting. Lightly creamy malt. Blooming sharp bitter marmaladey hops. The bitterness lasts well in to the aftertaste.

name: Deschutes Bachelor ESB
review: Thank you Fran! Nice looking brew, dark honey brown good cap. Nice west coast hop aroma, some soap. Taste has a massive bitter. I like this brew. Fruity body with a soapy bitter finish. Pine, leather, other stuff. Did i mention this is making me salivate. This is more like an IPA then a English ESB but even though it crosses styles I’m digging it. not sure hoe to score it........my marks might be a touch high.

name: Deschutes Bachelor ESB
review: I like this one better than their pale ale--more hops but not enough to make it a bitter. Tastes more like a pale ale.

name: Deschutes Obsidian Stout
review: Black, small head, aroma is malt, coffee, roast, choco. Taste is the same, bitter, creamy, dry, nice.

name: Deschutes Obsidian Stout
review: Cask at GBBF 2016, Kensington Olympia. Black with a tan head. Aroma of dark malt, coffee and mild fishy notes. Good body and a nice Rising bitterness.

name: Deschutes Bond Street Brown Ale
review: "never had it in a bottle, only on tap at the Bend pub. pretty good stuff for a brown ale. obviously, nothing overpowering, but a nice, roasted , malty, and well balanced beer. Buzzsaw (bottles as of 2008) is good as well."

name: Deschutes Bond Street Brown Ale
review: Deschutes Brewery & Public House--Bond Street Brown Ale--Bond Street Series--An Original Public House Ale--2005 Release--22 oz. Bottle--4.80% ABV--25 IBU’s. (4.0 / 5.0) Brown Ale-- Foamy mild lace head. Clear thin bright walnut red brown color. Bottle Conditioned sediment. Malty mild cocao hop front. Smooth creamy malty toffee cocao nut body. Clean smooth easy mild hop end. Minimal fruit. Tasty mellow Brown. Sampled 8/26/2005.

name: Deschutes Bond Street Brown Ale
review: On-tap, Public House, Bend OR - Nutty, light toasted bready malt character with a creamy mouthfeel. Dry with some light chocolate notes.

name: Deschutes Bond Street Brown Ale
review: A great brown ale, definitely one of the best that I have had in a long time. Rich and well-layered on the palate, with some creamy chocolate, a bit of roastiness, with some sweet toffee and a somewhat salty nuttiness. Hops are approachable, giving a welcome bitterness in the finish.

name: Deschutes Bond Street Brown Ale
review: Pours a nice dark brown color. Aromas of nuts/chocolate/caramel. Flavor is nutty with a nice sweet honey chocolate taste and a little coffee bitterness. This is a great beer.

name: Deschutes Bond Street Brown Ale
review: Aroma is caramel, coffee, hint of chocolate. Body is brown with a cream colored head. Taste is kinda roasty with light caramel, and mollases. Body is average.

name: Deschutes Bond Street Brown Ale
review: Beer pours ruby red-brown with lasting light-brown head. Body is clear and lacing is spare. Nice malt backbone with toasted grain, toffee, and nutty aromas. Citrus hops. Mouthfeel is a little on the thick side for my preference with this style. Smooth and easy to drink, though, and not too strong. Have another.

name: Deschutes Bond Street Brown Ale
review: Bottle. Amber brown beer with a big beige head. Nice roasty-caramel malt aroma. Balanced caramel malt, butty, and slight chocolate flavor with some hops. Clean and refreshing and easy to drink.

name: Deschutes Bond Street Brown Ale
review: (Bottle) Pours a mahogany body with a large rocky beige head and good lacing. Aroma of toasted malt, nuts, mild citrus, and a hint of cocoa. Flavor of malt, chocolate, and mild hops.

name: Deschutes Bond Street Brown Ale
review: 15-Dec-05 (22 oz bottle: $3.49 at Bottleworks in Seattle, WA) Since I also have a bottle of this beer, I thought it should get a more thorough rating, or at least be rated in a more "rating friendly" and controlled environment like my living room in front of my computer rather than a bar. This is definitely a mild brown ale, with very light roast in the flavor and nose. Mild sweetness, a fair amount of chocolate, and a bit o’ nuttiness in the flavor, and likewise in the nose, except that the beer does not have a very sweet aroma. Chocolate increases slightly as the beer warms up. Body is medium, with fairly mild carbonation. Light-medium brown, but with nearly perfect clarity. Light tan head pours to an inch in height, settling to a ring in a pretty normal fashion. True to the brewing style of Deschutes, this is an understated brown ale that has a nice flavor without trying to knock you over the head showing it.07-Aug-05 (Draft: Deschutes Brewery in Bend, OR) Ooh, this smells nice! Malty, very chocolaty, lightly roasty, the nose has me looking forward to tasting this beer. It’s not as chocolaty, but the roast almost takes on a sesame character. It’s fairly sweet, but the roast helps to keep the palate pretty clean and dry. Moderately bitter, but not especially hoppy. Light brown in color, with a light tan head that shows solid retention and a dense crochetwork of lace. Definitely the best of the seasonals I’ve tried today. (7, 4, 7, 4, 14, total 3.6)

name: Deschutes Broken Top Bock
review: "pretty solid as Bocks go. there was a little more to it than i was expecting. not as much bite as sierra nevadas, but great flavor and aroma. i’d recommend."

name: Deschutes Broken Top Bock
review: An all right beer. I personally was expecting a little more umph from this one. Still not bad.

name: Deschutes Broken Top Bock
review: Deschutes Brewery--Broken Top Bock--Bond Street Series--2006 Release--22 oz. Bottle--6.50% ABV--26 IBU’s. (4.25 / 5.0) Bock--Bitter Truth 4/10/06. Mild lacy head. Clear thin dark mahogeny red color. Toasted mild hop front. Dry sweet burnt black cherry toffee tangy rich smooth body. Roasted hot hop spice end. Tangy Dark Bock. Sampled 4/19/2006

name: Deschutes Broken Top Bock
review: This was pretty standard fare, some roasted toffee maltiness, some dried fruit flavors, some herbal buttery hoppiness.

name: Deschutes Broken Top Bock
review: Bottle: Pours brown with a light tan head. Aroma, caramel, light roasted malts, toasted notes, some fruits. Flavor, caramel, fruits, toasted notes, some roast, herbal hops.

name: Deschutes Broken Top Bock
review: 2007 Release Sampled December 2007 Pours with an initially, almost three-finger thick, lightly browned, tan colored head that sits atop a dark, weathered amber-brown colored brew. When held up to the light the beer shows a brilliantly clear, bright, yet concentrated, ruby red color. Quite malt focused, with an almost berry like, malt aroma. Concentrated, somewhat rich, malt notes of toffee, lightly browned, toasty malt, browned bread crust, a touch of brown sugar. This also has some nice, subtle hop aromatics that contribute to the light berry like fruitiness as well as provide a hint of an herbal edge. A nice and inviting aroma, not as rich and powerful as a Doppelbock for sure, but still nice and malt focused. Chewy, yet not too thick, this has lots of rich malt flavor to it without being overly sweet.
