The sweetness has a certain savory quality to it, what with the concentrated toffee notes and richly caramelized malt sugars. Towards the finish the malt character leans towards a touch of dusty cocoa, toasty, drying dark malt notes as well as a clean, almost concentrated dark fruit note. The hop character, while not huge here, is definitely noticeable; flavors of soft herbs is noticeable from the get go and even picks up a bit of steam towards the middle with notes of menthol and grassy pine flavors. This finishes with a soft, yet noticeable bitterness that I would not quite characterize as biting. Like a good, regular strength, Bock should be, this beer has a chewy heft to it without being thick; it is still fairly quaffable and would be a perfect beer to pair with dinner (it is not a sipping beer). I really like the depth of malt character that this achieves, yet it is not too thick, and it has a nice backdrop of hop character too. Quite the tasty Bock!

name: Deschutes Broken Top Bock
review: This brew had a good reception at a Deschutes featured event at Bardenay last year in Boise. I guess I’d have to like the bock style which I don’t but if I did...

name: Deschutes Broken Top Bock
review: 22oz bottle shared courtesy of TomDecapolis. Poured a deeper brownish color with a small sized off white head. Aromas of chocolate, roast, nutty, toffee and caramel. Tastes of toasted nuts, roast, chocolate, and caramel.

name: Deschutes Broken Top Bock
review: Thanks to kenb for the trade. Pours a deep brown with lots of ruby red highlights. Aroma of sweet malty grains, dark fruits, candy sweetness, toast malts, some nuts. Flavor of toasted malts, grains, sweet maltiness, vanilla, nuts, dark fruits. Very nice bock.

name: Deschutes Broken Top Bock
review: 3/25/2007: After a long day of working on the landscaping around the front of the house, it’s finally time to relax and have a beer... Broken Top Bock pours a clear chesnut color. It has a large, foamy, dark beige head that leaves some lacing. Malt, fruit, caramel, and apple are in the aroma. The flavor is a nice blend of malts and caramelized fruit with a darker malt flavor (chocolate) in the roasty finish. This beer has a medium-full body and is smooth. Even the wife enjoyed this one, so it must be pretty good! 22 oz bottle from kenb (Oct 2006). Thanks for the bonus beer Ken. I really appreciate it!

name: Deschutes Jubelale
review: 330ml bottle in 2013. Deep brown with a beige head. Very nice roasty and herbal aroma with some good coffee and bready malt flavours.

name: Deschutes Jubelale
review: Woody, slightly herbal, notes of treacle, orange, ginger, and molasses. A bit sharp in places.

name: Deschutes Jubelale
review: Draft. Pours amber with a beige head. Toasted malts, a little fruitiness, and mild-moderate sweetness. Pretty good.

name: Deschutes Jubelale
review: I have appreciated Deschutes as a brewery as long as I have got serious about rating beers. A picked up a single bottle at the nearby craft beer shop late last fall. This one is going into my ABGB tulip glass in which I determine a dark mahogany body completed by a heathy top of finely-bubbled, medium tan foam. The scent is dark fruit, grain and forest. Yeah, really. And now a sip, woody, a bit of cherry, malt, fairly bitter. Decent, a sipper for sure, not inspirational.

name: Deschutes Jubelale
review: Bottle at home. Pours hazy amber brown. Aroma is sweet and bread-y. Flavor opens with slightly sharp bite of winter spice, developing into some sweet malt, finishing with a little harsh, resin-y hop bitterness. Medium body. Somewhat warming. A pleasing beer, but the finish is somewhat discordant and takes away from the overall experience.

name: Deschutes Jubelale
review: Elongated, Brit-style longneck. Artsy label. Immense, peachy-khaki spray insulation head over a deep ruby-black pour. Sweet, yeasty, aley, pruney, je ne sais quois aroma. Fairly acidic, aley, parboiled plums, toasted sugars, tannic. Fence line, volunteer plums (sloes but not blackthorn) overtones. Quite tasty. Harris Teeter, Boone, NC. New Year's Trip, 2019.

name: Deschutes Jubelale
review: Nice winter beer... A brown beer with some seasonal spice and toffee. Not complicated but enjoyable.

name: Deschutes Jubelale
review: Malty spiced aroma, pours brown with a tan head. Tastes malty up front with a strong hop bite and a brown ale like finish. Palate is nice and smooth. Good, I bet it would be really good aged.

name: Deschutes Jubelale
review: 12 oz. bottle. Pours a deep ruby red color with an off white, finger thick head that gradually settles to a film leaving some lacing. Aroma is of sweet malt, toasted malt, a little dried fruit and some toffee. Flavor is of toasted malt with some bittering hops coming through after the swallow. Not bad.

name: Deschutes Jubelale
review: Dark amber with a big beige head. Aroma of sweet malts, toffee and a little hops.Long dry and hoppy finish.

name: Edelweiss Weissbier Hefetrüb
review: 0.5 l bottle. Hazy yellow color beer with small white head. Light fruit aroma. The taste is fruit with lightly fried cereals and herbs.

name: Edelweiss Weissbier Hefetrüb
review: On bottle. Pours hazy yellow with a thick white head. Nice weissbier with all the expected aromas of yeast, banana and hops. Good and refreshing!

name: Bills Clearcut Lager
review: A very nice looking and light beer. I don't usually enjoy lighter beers but this one had a great taste.

name: Bills Blackberry Beauty
review: Bills Tavern, Cannon Beach. Soapy foam, rich cloudy red. Hazy juice. Cloudy wheat ale or strong blonde with a heavy addition of butter blackberry purée. Thick base, creamy, fruit comes up flat at the finish. Flat like a blackberry Italian soda. Not fantastic.

name: Bills Blackberry Beauty
review: We can’t much taste the blackberry but its good. We both think we can throw a few back.

name: Bills Blackberry Beauty
review: On tap at Bill’s Tavern, pours a cloudy reddish orange with a small white head. Aroma brings out loads of blackberries upfront. Flavour is similar, with faded blackberries and a little wheat. Clean and drinkable, without any rough edges - just nothing over special.

name: Bills Blackberry Beauty
review: On tap at the brewpub Hazy red grapefruit color with a small pink head and some lacing. Mild aroma of blackberries and wheat. Taste is blackberries and plastic Decent

name: Bills Blackberry Beauty
review: Pours a bit purple. Aroma has some berries but there’s not much in the taste. Better than being cloyingly sweet but not something I need to try again.

name: Bills Blackberry Beauty
review: Pint – Bill’s Tavern & Brewhouse – Cannon Beach, OR Aroma – Light aroma very light fruit also in the nose. Appearance – Reddish amber in color, Super hazy, with a thin head. Flavor – Light malt flavor with a light fruit flavoring . Not much to this beer just very light. Palate – Dry finish with a decent Mouthfeel. Overall – I was hoping for more in the fruit flavor dept. Not much there.

name: Bills Blackberry Beauty
review: Looks like muddy water. Opaque tan, turning darker as the bottom of the glass. Thin aroma of berries. Very sweet, almost like a soft drink. Fizzy mouth feel. This doesn’t taste/feel like a beer.

name: Bills Blackberry Beauty
review: Had this on tap at Bill’s Tavern in Cannon Beach, OR. Colour... cloudy peach colour with no head. Nose... smells like a fruit snack mixed berry pack! Palate... mildly berry-like with scarcely any C02, vague hops and a rather grainy finish.

name: Bills Blackberry Beauty
review: Draught @ the brewpub. Pours a hazy pale golden color with a small white head. Has a sweetish fruity blackberry aroma. Sweetish malty and fruity blackberry flavor. Has a sweetish fruity blackberry finish.

name: Bills Blackberry Beauty
review: Purplish amber colour. The aroma is blackberry. On the palate, a two-step of tart wheat and sweet blackberry syrup. Quick, refreshing, not bad for what it is.

name: Bills Duck Dive Pale Ale
review: Bill’s Tavern, Cannon Beach. Pale orange gold, nice haze. Soft, vegetal pepper pale malt base. Odd flavor. Clean pale, low bitterness, and low hop flavor for that matter. Wet and cool. Ok.

name: Bills Duck Dive Pale Ale
review: Pours a clear amber-gold with smallish head. Aroma has some hop pine/spruce, but rather muted. Flavor is kind of weird, like there’s something floral in there other than the hops. Almost flowery. Some malt sweetness. Kind of a metallic finish/aftertaste. Not all that great.

name: Bills Duck Dive Pale Ale
review: On tap at Bill’s Tavern, pours a hazy golden with a tiny white head. Aroma of harsh floral hops and earthy notes. Flavour is rather off-putting, with skunky herbal notes and BO. Not pleasing to this hophead’s palate. Needs refinement.

name: Bills Duck Dive Pale Ale
review: On tap at the brewpub Clear golden with a medium sized white head and lots of lacing. Aroma is floral and dusty. Flavors are floral, dusty and citrus Decent

name: Bills Duck Dive Pale Ale
review: On tap at the brewery on Cannon Beach. Pours a clear copper color with a medium white head. A nice aroma of pine and light citrus. The flavor is balanced with biscuit, smooth pine and a bit of low bitterness around the edges. Quite quaffable and nice.

name: Bills Duck Dive Pale Ale
review: Pint – Bill’s Tavern & Brewhouse – Cannon Beach, OR Aroma – Nice hoppy aroma good malt nose this had some life. Appearance – Dark golden in color, Clear, with a thin head. Flavor – Good malt build with a awesome hops this was flavorful. Palate – Dry finish with a Good Mouthfeel. Overall – Very tasty beer. I knew they could do it. Great flavors this was the best for me today.

name: Bills Duck Dive Pale Ale
review: Had this on tap at Bill’s Tavern in Cannon Beach, OR. Colour... cloudy golden. Nose... slightly piney hop nose. Palate... lightly piney hops, nice C02 up front, some hope bite on the soft palate and throat. Rather one dimensional, but decent for a pale.

name: Bills Duck Dive Pale Ale
review: Excellent beer for a small brew pub. Citrus and grapefruit tasting and lightly bitter. Mild hops. Cloudy and creamy with an exceptionally smooth taste. Full bodied without the watery taste that comes in a good many brew pub beers. Highly drinkable.

name: Bills Duck Dive Pale Ale
review: Draught @ the brewpub. Pours a hazy orange color with a small off-white head. Has a malty hoppy aroma with some hints of citrus. Sweetish malty hoppy bitter flavor with hints of citrus. Has a malty hoppy finish with a hoppy bitter aftertertaste.

name: Bills Duck Dive Pale Ale
review: On tap at the brewpub in Cannon Beach, OR--Yum! Poured a cloudy copper-amber with a medium white head. Nose of bright tropical fruits. Great full mouth feel. Finished tangy, bitter, and fruity. Quite good!

name: Bills Curiously Strong
review: Moderately deep amber colored ale with nice carbonation. Pleasant prickliness develops in the mouth working synergistically with the candi malts. Hoppiness continues to develop as well as some green complexity. A nicely balanced strong ale.

name: Bills Curiously Strong
review: On Tap At Bills Tavern and Brewhouse Cannon Beach OR. Pours out a Dark red with a off white head. a nice spice and caramel.

name: Bills Curiously Strong
review: on tap at bill’s. dark red pour with an inch of lacing, frothy off-white head. aroma is hops, spices. flavor is a pretty balanced sweet/spicy base, with a good flowery hoppy finish. pretty full mouthfeel. a very solid brew.

name: Bills Curiously Strong
review: Mahogany with a beige head and strong lacing. Big toffee and a hint of spice in the nose. Bitter hops with some all spice or nutmeg maybe. Some brown sugar. Big caramel malts in the flavor along with more brown sugar. Bitter hops and alcohol accompany dark fruits. Sticky palate with a sweet malty finish.

name: Bills Curiously Strong
review: Sampled draught at Bill’s Tavern, Cannon BeachAmber color, light lacing. Nose of tart cherries and buttered popcorn, some fig & persimmons too. The flavor is lightly salty & the alcohol is up there, reminds me of a fishy smell.

name: Bills Curiously Strong
review: True to its name.... Definitely a worthy brew, very rich looking, darker than I expected and yes very strong. Don't know if I could handle more than one at a time.

name: Bills 2 x 4 Stout
review: A serviceable if uninspired stout. Pours dark with little head. Aroma is light roasted malt. Slightly bitter finish makes it a bit more interesting.

name: Bills 2 x 4 Stout
review: Roasty aroma. Brownish in color. Flavor is roasty with a bit of apple notes. Notes: On cask

name: Bills 2 x 4 Stout
review: Cask at GBBF 2010. An opaque brown beer with a thin brown head. The aroma has light notes of vegetables and roasted malt. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt, caramel, and citrusy hops as well as lighter notes of roasted malt. Not much of a stout, but a decent brown ale.

name: Bills 2 x 4 Stout
review: Cask (gravity) @ GBBF 2010, Great British Beer Festival, Earls Court Exhibition Centre, London, England. Unclear dark brown color with virtually none head. Aroma is moderate malty, roasted, woody, tobacco, wood. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration, tobacco,woody, dark roasted, alcohol. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is flat, finish feel is light alcoholic. [20100805]

name: Bills 2 x 4 Stout
review: Cask at GBBF 2010, 5th Aug 2010. Flat murky brown. Tired taste with just some very average malt flavours. Looks like I got the bottom of the barrel, given the other rates for this from that day.

name: Bills 2 x 4 Stout
review: Cask Stillage at the GBBF, Earl’s Court 05/08/2010 Fruit and hop aromas. Dark coloured and a little rich on the palate with some alcohol present. A hint of dryness and bitterness in a coffee roast finish.

name: Bills 2 x 4 Stout
review: 5th August 2010. GBBF. Cloudy dark brown beer. Light dry palate. Sweetish malt. Nice touch of chocolate.Good underpinning dark fruit - tangy plum and some generic fruits. Finishes fairly dry with a pinch of spice. Some grassy spice in the aftertaste. Nicely joined up.

name: Bills 2 x 4 Stout
review: CaskGBBF2010. Murku ambery brown colour, not much head. Aroma is alcohol, fruits, earth and some mild liquorice. Flavour is fruits, liquorice, alcohol and some quite plummy notes.

name: Bills 2 x 4 Stout
review: From cask. Pours dark brown to black with a fully gone head. Aroma is dark malty and roasted. Sweet malty, dark breadish and hardroasted malt flavoured. Bitter and dry into the finish. Rather dry and mild acidic.

name: Bills 2 x 4 Stout
review: I think this beer is clear, but it’s too dark to tell. Strong roast malt aroma. Heavy body with a sour finish that spoils an otherwise nice stout.

name: Hale's Nut Brown Ale
review: Dark cherry wood brown color with a moderate taupe head. Initial DMS scents slowly fade to reveal some light roasted malt, hints of herbal hops and hint of coffee. Lightly sweet flavors. I somehow get a musty roasted flavor. I think I understand what they were going for, enjoy it for what it is, but I don’t think it quite works for me. An Irish red/brown. Ok. 2/10

name: Hale's Nut Brown Ale
review: 12 oz bottle. Pours a nice hazy mahogany color. Aroma is floral hops up front with faint toasted caramel notes. Flavor is well-balanced between bitter hops and malt backside. Palate is a bit thin, but it makes it very drinkable. Overall a decent, drinkable beer. Surprised it’s a seasonal, actually.

name: Hale's Nut Brown Ale
review: Nitro draft pour featured at the brewery. Swirling amber color pour with the huge creamy head and lace. Aroma has light hops, and rich malt. Rich caramel malt flavor with a toasty finish. Interested in trying this on regular draft, but this nitro is very nice. Creamy, cinnamon like, spice finish. Nicely done.

name: Hale's Nut Brown Ale
review: Bottle. Pours a mostly clear dark amber color with a smallish off-white head on there that disappears quickly. Nose is pretty nutty with hints of toast to it. Taste is a little sweet and bready, with quite a bit of nuttiness coming through. OK, but just seems a bit off for me.

name: Hale's Nut Brown Ale
review: 12oz bottle poured into an Affligem wide mouth goblet. Beer Date: " Exp: 05.14.15. This just came out recently, so maybe 4 month best by date. So, lets see we have 4 ratings in 2011, 4 in 2012, 1 n 2013, 0 in 2014... well the rating scene in Seattle is growing old. Brown colored beer, not much head. Aroma smells of industrial plastic, metallic, and bug spray. Flavor is similar. Maybe I understand why no one is rating this beer. Its close to being macro level, un-nuanced, industrial flavored waste of fermented malted beverage. Low, even for Hale’s.

name: Hale's Nut Brown Ale
review: Sample at the brewpub. Deep amber color with a medium off-white head that dissipates steadily. Partial rings of lacing. Aroma of roasted malt and nuts. Light-bodied with a roasty character and flavors of sweet malt, nuts and fruit. The finish is sweet with a short nutty aftertaste. Slightly above average overall.

name: Hale's Nut Brown Ale
review: Pleasant nuttiness, not too sweet, A LOT of diacetyl. Very round. Had it more body, would be a great beer.

name: Hale's Nut Brown Ale
review: Surprisingly strong nut aroma. Flavor is decent, nutty and sweet. Palate is weak. Watery.

name: Hale's Nut Brown Ale
review: Nice amber gold brown color, big thick head. Malty, doughy nose. Malt and sugar taste, clean lingering finish. Not bad.

name: Hale's Nut Brown Ale
review: From tap at the brewpub. Pours clear and golden deep amber with a small off-white head. Aroma is roasted dark malty and caramelish. Mild bitterness, dark roasted malty, light nutty and mild fruity. Ends bitter and dry.

name: Hale's Drawbridge Blonde
review: Somewhat fruity zesty aroma. This is nice. A good light flavor with some fruit in the middle. Surprisingly refreshing and would make a great session beer.

name: Hale's Drawbridge Blonde
review: Bottle. This one was a gusher. Pours murky amber with some floaters and a 4 finger foamy beige head that leaves delicate lacing. The nose is fruity and grainy. The taste is caramel and fruit with a grainy finish. Medium mouthfeel. Not that great, but I think it’s an older bottle.

name: Hale's Drawbridge Blonde
review: Draught @ the brewpub. Pours a slightly hazy golden color with a small white head. Has a fruity malty aroma with some grainy hints. Fruity malty slightly hoppy flavor with some grainy hints. Also some hints of citrus. Has a fruity malty hoppy finish.

name: Hale's Drawbridge Blonde
review: From a 12oz bottle purchased at Belmont Station in PDX--Poured a clear copper-amber body with a medium whitish head. Fruity, creamy, sweet with a hint of caramel and nuts. Malty thin body and weak finish. Very drinkable but dull.

name: Hale's Drawbridge Blonde
review: clearish light amber with thin head. no aroma, light fruit notes and malty taste very thin body

name: Hale's Drawbridge Blonde
review: 1999 12 oz. Bottle. 4.85% ABV. (4.25 / 5.0) Clear pale bright amber color. Floral hop front introduces rich balanced pale ale crystal malt body with light spicy caramel fruit flavor. Hops spice up cloying finish. Sampled 5/14/1999. 2000--12 oz. Bottle. 4.85% ABV. (4.0 / 5.0) Clear rich golden color hazes at end. Mild light floral hop front. Nice bouquet. Crisp smooth mild pale malt body. Mild balanced floral sweetness. Clean mild hop end. Hints of biscuit. Nice lace in head. Sampled 11/6/2000. 2001--12 oz. Bottle. 4.85% ABV. (3.75 / 5.0) Slightly cloudy rich golden color. Malty light fruit floral hop front. Crisp mildly citrus light biscuit body with good texture and flavor. Balanced sweet hop end with clean refreshing citrus notes. Sampled 5/15/2001. 2002--12 oz. Bottle. 4.85% ABV. (3.75 / 5.0) Bottle Conditioned. Clear light golden color. Mild floral hop front. Crisp mild sweet creamy caramel butter body. Dough hints. Mild clean balanced light hop spice end. True light tasty balanced Blonde Ale. Sampled 10/19/2002. 2003--12 oz. Bottle. 4.85% ABV. (4.0 / 5.0) Bottle conditioned. Clear rich bright golden color. Thin mild lace head. Tasty mild floral hop front. Mild creamy doughy butterscotch and light sweet citrus fruit caramel body. Clean mild hop end. Nice. Sampled 8/12/2003. 2004--12 oz. Bottle. 4.70% ABV. 25 IBU’s? (4.0 / 5.0) Mild lacy head. Slightly hazy bottle conditioned sediment rich golden color. Floral mild hop fruit front. Smooth creamy buttery mild sweet bread banana fruit body. Clean mild hop citrus end. Residual malt sugars. Mild. Tasty. Sampled 9/14/2004. 2005--12 oz. 4.90% ABV. 25 IBU’s? (4.0 / 5.0) Tight lacy head. Clear bright golden color. Mild floral hop malt fruit front. Smooth tasty butterscotch caramel bottle conditioned mild sweet ester fruit doughy body. Creamy mild sweet hop citrus smooth refreshing end. Sampled 7/18/2005. 2006--12 oz. Bottle. 4.90% ABV. 25 IBU’s? (4.0 / 5.0) Mild lace head. Bottle conditioned sediment. Clear bright rich gold color. Mild hop front. Refreshing clean smooth mellow butter caramel banana ester mild sweet body. Clean smooth malt tang mild CO2 hop end. Tasty Blonde! Sampled 10/26/2006. 2007--12 oz. Bottle. 4.90% ABV. 25 IBU’s? (4.0 / 5.0) Mild head. Bottle conditioned hazy bright golden color. Mild floral hop front. Semi sweet mellow caramel butter fruit ester no biscuit Blonde body. Mild fruit hop fresh clean easy refreshing mild end. Nice Blonde. Sampled 5/26/2007. 2008--12 oz. Bottle. 4.90% ABV. 25 IBU’s? (4.0 / 5.0) Bottle Conditioned. Mild lacy light white head. No sediment. Clear thin bright light gold color. Mellow floral hop flowery front. Crisp mild caramel butter delicate tasty fruit ester mild zesty body. Refreshing smooth mild hop clean satisfying end. Brainy Blonde. Sampled 7/3/2008. 6-Pack $7.99.

name: Hale's Drawbridge Blonde
review: Amber with small white head, few lacings. Aroma is floral hops. Taste is mild with slight hop bitterness, some decent malts. Very quaffable summer blonde. Drink, repeat, etc.

name: Hale's Drawbridge Blonde
review: Bottle: Deep blonde with a golden hue. Smallish white head. Aroma is light, but floral and bits of grass. Flavor is maltier than expected, some light florals and again grassy. Not bad. One of the better blondes that I choose to remember.

name: Hale's Drawbridge Blonde
review: Pours a nice golden color with a medium fizzy white head. Slightly sweet malty grain and citrus aroma. Good flavor. Slightly hoppy and bitter finish. Above average.

name: Hale's Drawbridge Blonde
review: Pours cloudy light caramel with a decent head. Aroma of wet dishrag, corn and spice. Flavor is watery corn, spice with a bitter finish. Sucks.

name: Hale's O'Brien's Harvest Ale
review: Rating #1997 2015.09.27 #CraftTakesSeattle Day 4, Beer 99 – Draught at taproom/brewpub.Dark brown pour with a white/tan head. Earthy, roasted malt tempered with a punch of hoppy bitterness. Character of almonds, chestnuts, chocolate, toffee, citrus.

name: Hale's O'Brien's Harvest Ale
review: dark amber slowly poured to leave quite a bit of yeast and other stuff in the bottle. Little lite tan head and no lacing. This is a big nose hoppy brew. Citrus and pine hop aromas with earthy and appropriate garden dirt. Wow... actually very complex for a simple APA. Floral notes mix perfectly with toasty bready malts. Flavor is the same, but with a bracing/balanced and lingering bitterness.. I am really liking this one. Oily hoppiness sticks to the inside of my mouth.

name: Hale's O'Brien's Harvest Ale
review: Hazy to nearly cloudy dark copper color. A few chunks of yeast float about. Initial moderate head that settles to a small lid of tight, tiny, taupe tinted bubbles. Scents of caramel coated pine cones, along with toasted grain bread, and mild herbs. Fairly sweet and caramel-like in the front. Some marzipan and hint of alcohol as well. Touch of toffee as well just before the hops really start to kick in. Citric and pine flavors, and bitterness take the lead into the finish and linger. Acidity amps up in the late finish and linger. This is not your ordinary amber. 7/10

name: Hale's O'Brien's Harvest Ale
review: 12 ounce bottle from Whole Paycheck. Pours a dark copper color with a large white head. A light toast and caramel nose. The flavor is caramel, Crystal malts, some citrus. Hmm. Very sweet like a Oktoberfest. OK. Drinkable for sure.

name: Hale's O'Brien's Harvest Ale
review: Bottle from Brewers Haven. Picking up some Belgian notes right away, yeasty, musty aroma. Would not put this in as an amber, although lots of caramelly malt late on the palate. Cloudy dark amber body with small soapy head. Lingering bitter finish and minor warmth.

name: Hale's O'Brien's Harvest Ale
review: Bottle: Poured a copper off white head. Very veggie harvest aroma. Taste is hops and malts little veggie.

name: Hale's O'Brien's Harvest Ale
review: 12 oz bottle. Pours a nice amber brown color. Slight white head, a bit of lacing. Aroma is caramel malt. Flavor is sweet, with a bitter hops aftertaste. Overall I wasn’t immediately blown away, but then I realized how easily drinkable it is. Definitely worth checking out.

name: Hale's O'Brien's Harvest Ale
review: On tap at Hale’s, pours a clear copper with a small beige head. Aroma brings out a mix of different hop varietals, with notes of citrus, pine and resin, some bready caramel malt as well. Flavour is both hop and malt heavy, with lots of resinous hops, which then transition to sweet caramel malt. After a while, the malt bill overtakes and leaves a rather high amount of sweetness. Okay, but nothing special.

name: Hale's O'Brien's Harvest Ale
review: 2015 version. Deep Amber with a firm white head. Nice pine and light citrus hops with a good portion of toasted caramel malts. Full bodied. Full flavored Amber with a good malt and hop balance. Highly enjoyable.

name: Hale's O'Brien's Harvest Ale
review: 12oz bottle from Total Wine in Spokane Slightly cloudy amber with a medium sized beige head, good lacing. Aroma of toasted malts and dark fruit. Taste of toasted malts, sweet caramel, bready and spices Decent

name: Hale's Pale (American) Ale
review: From Aug 2007 Purchased as part of a mixed 6Pack at Wilbur's in Ft Collins. It pours from 12oz bottle(some numbers etched on the bottom of the bottle: 258-0-2 0724) a deep gold with a small head of foam and...a lot of floaties. I hope that doesn't mean that I have a bottle that is *well* past it's best by date. Anywho, the foam lasts right through the session and it has lots of lacing. It'll be hard to score on appearance. :^( The smell is very hoppy by way of grapefruit and....it smells like how a dry hopped ale would taste. The taste is nicely balanced between some semi sweet malt and not too bitter hop character. The hops are more floral than anything else. I can't taste any grass and as far as citrus goes, there's just a touch of maybe, lemon. Overall, the flavour works for me. Now the malt kicks in again and I note some earthiness. The finish is slightly bitter and the mouthfeel is medium. I like it despite seeing those damn floaties when I raise my glass. Next time I see a bottle, I'm gonna check it out more thoroughly because if this bottle *is* past it's prime, a fresher sample would "probably" impress me even more.

name: Hale's Pale (American) Ale
review: Aus der Retrodose, optisch erste Sahne, stabiler Schaum. In der Nase Zitrus, leicht grasig, hopfig. Im Trunk hopfig, süffig, mittig bitterer werdend, crispy. Hinten lange bitter. Passt.

name: Hale's Pale (American) Ale
review: 355ml can. Well this one is kinda embarrassing, honestly tastes like a homebrew, chlorine, tasted it blind and it did not impress in a poor pack.

name: Hale's Pale (American) Ale
review: Can, Brewklopedia, Leicester. Golden with a white foam. Cereal grain with toasted malts. Plenty of citrus with a pithy bitterness. Light pine. Dusty palate. Peppery with traces of glue. This is OK.

name: Hale's Pale (American) Ale
review: Can. Hazy orange color. Thin white head. Medium bitterness. Light sweetness. Medium body. Aroma and flavour is orange, tangerine, peach, citrus, hops.

name: Hale's Pale (American) Ale
review: 355ml can. Cloudy, orangey golden colour with average, thick, frothy, half-way lasting, minimally lacing, white head. Piney and fruity, hoppy aroma, notes of orange, mandarine, caramel malty background. Taste is moderately bitter hoppy, piney and slightly fruity, hints of mandarine, orange, zesty bitterness, caramel malty basis, a light jelly bear touch; slightly water finish.

name: Hale's Pale (American) Ale
review: 12 ounce can poured to wine glass light amber, hazy small light tan foam that slowly disappears and lingers fragrant slightly hoppy hint of grains medium bitterness ok finish, bitter aftertaste lingers very good beer-pale ale, can be repeat, look forward to, excellent value drank: 11/4/2016 6:32 PM

name: Hale's Pale (American) Ale
review: 12 oz can, gift by luttonm. Not sure if he thought the gift was him giving the can, or me taking the can off his hands. Either way, I got a beer in my hand, I’m happy. A golden, hazy pour with a full foam cloud cover head. Juicy and hoppy, bright aroma. Flavor is creamy, a bit juicy, solid hop profile. No real bitterness noticeable througout. Drinks easy. Always nice to see a beer that’s been around since years before I was, and still on the shelves today. A good beer to keep a few ice cold, and enjoy, while taking in some ball games. Seems fitting anyway.

name: Hale's Pale (American) Ale
review: Can at home. Aroma is earthy hops, malt, some caramel, citrus, orange, mild fruity, touch of toffee. Flavour is light sweet and moderate bitter. Body is medium. Nice and easy old school APA with tasty citrussy hops and a caramel malt backbone.

name: Hale's Pale (American) Ale
review: Rating #1999 2015.09.27 #CraftTakesSeattle Day 4, Beer 101 – Draught at taproom/brewpub. Golden amber pour with a creamy white head that bubbles away quickly. Hops very fragrant with mild citrus in the aroma. Mouthfeel is creamy, medium carbonation, and bitter hops on the finish - but not overpowering, very balanced. Delicious.

name: Hale's Cream Ale
review: I've said it before and I'll say it again, one of my faves to just drink. I don't have to think about it. It's great, and easy to drink!

name: Hale's Cream Ale
review: On tap at Seattle Beer Company on 1st Street downtown Seattle. Pours clear pale yellow with tiny soap bubble white head or lacing (from nitrogen). Aroma: sweet biscuit, lemon, cereal. Flavor: honey, biscuit, Corn Flakes, lactose. Mouthfeel: light-bodied with a lingering creaminess. Super drinkable in large quantities.

name: Hale's Cream Ale
review: Rating #1996 2015.09.27 #CraftTakesSeattle Day 4, Beer 98 – Draught at taproom/brewpub - Pale, clear yellow, with a decent white head.Aroma is sweet grassy, mild vegetal. Has a light sweetness, light body, creamy, average carbonation. Snooze.

name: Hale's Cream Ale
review: On tap. Pours a nice white straw gradually turning to golden straw with thick white head, really cool appearance. Smells of bread and citrus. Tastes of bread and honey, a hair sour after sitting. Little flavor, little aftertaste, but overall enjoyable.

name: Hale's Cream Ale
review: On nitro tap at the brewery. Pours a clear gold with a thin white head. Sweet grain and a touch of toast on the nose, milk sweet. Medium bodied, soft and sweet, grainy with a light creamy note. Grain into the finish, crisp, almost a grapenut quality. Gets a touch fruity into the finish, raisins and dried apricots.

name: Hale's Cream Ale
review: Tap at the brewpub. Pour sight glad with a white head. Aroma is lightly bready malt. Med body or so. Flavor is bready, possibly with a hint of citrus. Rather bland, lightly bitter, but an easy drink for lunch.

name: Hale's Cream Ale
review: On tap at Parilla Grill. Looks like nitro without being on nitro. Velvety smooth and creamy, then goes down hill from there. Faint grainy aroma, taste is crackers and white bread. Nice mouth feel and texture to go with the look, but kind of bland overall.

name: Hale's Cream Ale
review: [3/3/15] Draught at Hales Ales Brewery & Pub in Seattle. Clear pale golden. Grainy aroma with a bit of corn. Sweetish flavor, grainy, a bit corny, with a faint fruity hint and a slightly bitterish finish. Quite light-bodied.

name: Hale's Cream Ale
review: 5oz at brewpub. Beautiful nitro head from the nitro tap. Clear macro yellow color. The nitro head sticks to me lip. Really need to work past it to figure out what the beer tastes like. Very corny, macro tasting. Tastes like minerals and not malts (rice or corn or whatever). Long cheap malt liquor aftertaste. Sticky flavors won’t leave my palate. Really good for blending with the BA lmpy Stout.

name: Hale's Cream Ale
review: On nitro at ABV Pub in Hillsboro, OR. Faint aroma of grass. Creamy head with huge amounts of lacing. Taste is subdued, grass, just a hint of something resembling a German hefeweisen, but only a hint. Easy to drink but too easy, really. Not my beer.

name: Hale's Special Bitter (Cream HSB)
review: On nitro draft at Next Door Gastropub in Port Angeles. Pours a clear copper with a creamy ecru head. Aroma of biscuit and caraeml. Flavor is moderately sweet caramel with some hop bitterness. Creamy mouthfeel. Smooth finish.

name: Hale's Special Bitter (Cream HSB)
review: Rating #1998 2015.09.27 #CraftTakesSeattle Day 4, Beer 100 – Draught at taproom/brewpub. Pours a dark crimson/brown with a foamy tan head that dissipates slowly, medium-strong retention. Aroma is roasted malt, hint of coffee and chocolate. Taste is bold with noble, earthy hoppy bitterness, but has a strong caramel malty sweetness, hint of soft fruits in the finish. Well balanced, medium bodied ale.

name: Hale's Special Bitter (Cream HSB)
review: On nitro tap at the brewery. Pours a clear brown with a medium sized white to tan head. Toast on the nose, softly nutty malt. Medium bodied, sweet, soft malt and grain. Crisp, softly bitter, a touch of crisp malt into the finish, lightly bitter.

name: Hale's Special Bitter (Cream HSB)
review: On June 24, 2015. At Hales Ales Brewery and Pub in Seattle, Washington. Clear copper to amber color, off-white head. Malty, herbal taste. Herbal aftertaste. Medium mouthfeel, medium bitterness. Malty, cream, herbal scent.

name: Hale's Special Bitter (Cream HSB)
review: Tap at Beveridge Place, Seattle. Colour is clear orange with small creamy white hear. Aromas and flavours: Fruits, dryness, some caramel, hints of hops and malts. Quite good session beer.

name: Hale's Special Bitter (Cream HSB)
review: 5oz at brewpub. Pretty nitro head from the nitro pour. Amber-copper clear beer. This tasted more like an English Pale than bitter to me. Aroma has hops present, despite the nitro. Nice English bright and clear minerally and earthy hops. Dusty, earthy malts below that. Low bitterness in both nose and flavor, which is nicely clean. Again, slightly dusty but clean malts with an apparent English hoppiness. Finishes clean. Soft nitro body. Good stuff.

name: Hale's Special Bitter (Cream HSB)
review: The server warned us about this one. But we just had to have the sampler - and this was the price we paid for that decision. Almost colorless, almost flavorless, with subtle hints of metal and cardboard. No. 2.

name: Hale's Special Bitter (Cream HSB)
review: Draught at Hales Ales Brewery and Pub, nitro Hazy amber color with creamy nitro head. Almost no aroma. Light caramel flavor, dry mouthfeel, a bit of toasted nuts, ordinary bitterness, and some metallic aftertaste. Stop nitro!

name: Hale's Special Bitter (Cream HSB)
review: This has a pungent taste and aroma to it. Reddish pour. Vinegar taste. Gross. Had on draft at hales brewery in Seattle.

name: Hale's Special Bitter (Cream HSB)
review: Nitro @ Hales... Poured dark reddish with a thick, floating, white head with constant retention. Super mild, very drinkable. Thin, soft mouthfeel. Some light doughy malt tones and just enough hops to balance the sweetness. Don’t expect much from this one, but when you need a session pint, it does the job.

name: Hale's Celebration Porter
review: Dark nut brown in appearance with a thin off-white head. Nice chocolatey aroma with a hint of cotton candy and molasses. Fruit comes out on the semi-sweet taste that finishes a little bitter. The bitterness almost seems as if it could be coming from the malts, but with some thought I am sure it is a hop bitterness. A good porter.

name: Hale's Celebration Porter
review: dark rum colored appearance with super fine carbonation bubbles, very small head and minimal lace, goor rich coffe/carmel aroma, with smooth chocolate taste and pleasant hop/carmalized sugar finish

name: Hale's Celebration Porter
review: Tan head. Smoky burnt nose. Dry roasted malt flavor. Good body.............

name: Hale's Celebration Porter
review: Black bodied with a ring of head and a twinge of amber. The atmospher, unfortunately was quite smokey. However, the aroma itself was undeniably smoky with a burnt attribute. The flavor was deep, dry coffee and by most accounts, this beer seemed akin to a lower a/c imperial stout. Need to sample again.

name: Hale's Celebration Porter
review: Had this on a hand-engine...Aroma is malty--both sweet and roasty, and also a bit estery..very nice indeed. This is what a porter should look like: darkest brown with a creamy wheat-hued head that coats the glass as it is drawn down. The flavor is rich and complex: mellow roastiness introduces itself, followed by a bloom of flavors ranging from a modest fruity tang to subtle sweet caramel to the mild/dry hop/coffee finish. This brew is smooth and has a fine creamy feel to it--substantial body as well, but not "heavy." This is an outstanding example of the brewer's art in evidence: complex, well-balanced, attractive to behold...Mike Hale's dedicated team impresses once again...

name: Hale's Celebration Porter
review: lucky for me that I have a friend who drives down here from their hometown about 3 or 4 times a year. He just last week brought me a case of hales ales, a mixed bag, Now I have sampled them all. Dark and rich, nice nose and a great semisweet finish.

name: Hale's India Pale Ale
review: Tap at brewpub, Crystal nose citrus/ pine. Hazy reddish orange color, Small to no head. Sweet bitter flavors Grapefruit and orange creamcicle. Thin bodied, bitter finish. Tasty, englishy ipa

name: Hale's India Pale Ale
review: This IPA was quite a suprise! cloudy orange color. Mild hop, carmel malt flavor. balanced and enjoyable.

name: Hale's India Pale Ale
review: Comments Cloudy light amber with good lace. Long citrus hop finish. Underhopped for IPA

name: Hale's India Pale Ale
review: Brass appearance with a creamy head which yielded to an initially creamy mouthfeel. The hops in this beer are quite reserved for a Northwest IPA. A decent introduction to the style--the hops never get out of hand. Well balanced and a good beer to have in your hand--just not an exceptional or unique offering.

name: Hale's India Pale Ale
review: The head on my Imperial pint of this stuff was a bit thin--otherwise, this is an outstanding offering. Aroma is fruity/floral/hoppy and with plenty of it. As for flavor, malt comes through nicely to balance very prominent hop profile--excellent bitterness without strident harshness. Finishes pleasantly dry with subtle fruity accompaniment...as fine an IPA as will be found in the Northwest.

name: Hale's India Pale Ale
review: The best English (style) IPA I've ever had. Toasty, fruity flavors (Hale's house character) are married perfectly with an understated, but very bitter, hoppiness. The thinking man's India Pale Ale. This might actually be better than the phenomenal pale ale. Brewer Mike Hale might just be God incarnate.

name: Hale's India Pale Ale
review: A relatively underrated beer (and brewery for that matter) by afficionados, but I think this is a wonderfully aromatic and easy going West Coast IPA, well worth seeking out, especially on cask.

name: Hale's Amber Ale
review: Very good beer. Nice smooth taste and finish. Decent head too. Nutty flavor was enjoyable and clean.

name: Hale's Amber Ale
review: Amber Ale--1998 12 oz. Bottle. 5.20% ABV. (3.0 / 5.0) Ist Released March 1998. Nice caramel malt start. Pretty amber color. Starts strong, but peters out at end. Sampled 9/11/1998. Amber Ale--2003 12 oz. 5.20% ABV. (4.0 / 5.0) Clear rich bright amber red color. Mild lace head. Light bottle conditioned sediment. Sweet malty mild floral fruit hop front. Crisp toasted sweet doughy biscuit caramel fruit body. Earthy citrus clean malty mild hop end. Sampled 11/3/2003.

name: Hale's Amber Ale
review: Bottle. Multiple tastings (Previous tastings from memory). Drank these occasionaly when I lived in Seattle. Godd but nothing spectacular.

name: Hale's Amber Ale
review: It smells good but has a bitter taste that makes you want to set it aside quickly.

name: Hale's Amber Ale
review: I really like this beer. Great hop and malt flavors and a nice head give this a higher score in my book. Nice deep color and pleasent aroma. Taste is rich and long lasting. Lace is good all the way to the bottom of glass

name: Hale's Amber Ale
review: Bottle Pours a deep mahogany that is hazy and with a snall light tan head that dissipates quickly. Mellow toasted grain aromas that is malty and only faintly of hops. Flavors are similay somewhat sweet malts with a little toasted slant and still quite easy on bittering hops. Fairly soft carbonation and a woody chalky trailer.

name: Hale's Amber Ale
review: Yes, this one is amber in color with an off white head that soon disappears. Caramel and malt aroma. The commercial description claims "a big malt body". It's anything but big. Yes malt flavors with a slight crispy/fizzy feel lurking in the background. However also found it to be quite watery and weak bodied. Drinkable but not very exciting.

name: Hale's Amber Ale
review: Probably the crispest amber I've ever had. Don't get me wrong, this is noticeably malty and definitely packs the trademark amber-ness but the "various hop influences" are very noticeable. I'm not bitching either, I thought this was a very nice aspect to the beer, which overall is very bready and caramelly, except for the hops keeping it in check. Not my favorite Hales beer, or my favorite amber, but tasty and satisfactory nonetheless.

name: Hale's Amber Ale
review: malty/slightly nutty aroma, medium amber hue with a nonexistent head, round maltiness with slight roasted notes and an unpleasant bitter finish

name: Hale's Amber Ale
review: draft.nice amber color with very thin head and lace, unexpected full aroma, clean taste and hoppy finish. didn't stand out other than appearance

name: Hale's Moss Bay Extra
review: On tap at the brewery. Came across thin and weak for an ESB. Watery mouthfeel.

name: Hale's Moss Bay Extra
review: Moss Bay Extra Ale--1998 12 oz. Bottle. 5.75% ABV. (3.75 / 5.0) ESB. 1st Released March 1998. Rich amber Color. Hoppier balance to fruit flavor commonly found in amber ales. Medium body. Light easy finish. Sampled 9/1/1998. Moss Bay Extra Ale--2003 22 oz. Bottle. 5.75% ABV? (4.5 / 5.0) Amber ESB Ale? Lightly hazy rich bright amber color. Nice head with rich lace. Malty very floral hop front. Crisp spicy light toasted sweet caramel biscuit fruit hop body. Rich clean balanced hop citrus spice end. 8/10/2003. Moss Bay Extra Ale--2003 12 oz. Bottle. 5.75% ABV? (4.25 / 5.0) ESB? Clear bright thin amber red color. Light lacy head. Toasted malty floral hop front. Sweet earthy doughy biscuit toasted crisp dry caramel fruit ester BC body. Clean dry citrus hop spice earthy end. Sampled 11/5/2003. Moss Bay Extra Ale--2007--12 oz. Bottle. 5.80% ABV. 35 IBU’s? (4.0 / 5.0) Devolved O’Brien’s Hop Harvest Recipe without fresh hops. ESB? 6- Pack $6.49. Light tight bottle conditioned sediment. Mild lace light head. Cloudy dark amber red brown color. Toasted floral bottle conditioned fruit ester hop front. Mild sweet toasted caramel biscuit fruit creamy earthy hint body. Cloying bottle conditioned ester mild hop spice clean smooth end. Malty Amber ESB. Sampled 7/1/2008.

name: Hale's Moss Bay Extra
review: Bottle. Pours a hazy iced tea color with a half finger beige head. Nose is caramel malt for the most part with very light hops. Taste is caramel, ripe dark fruits and earthy hops with some bitters in the finish. Medium mouth feel. Not a bad representation of the style.

name: Hale's Moss Bay Extra
review: 12 oz. bottle from Plaza Liquors - Pours a hazy deep amber color with a 1/2 finger thick light tan head. Very light spotty lacing. Aroma is esters and caramel malt with a hint of perfume. Flavor is toasted malt and fruity esters. Medium body. A pretty nice beer.

name: Hale's Moss Bay Extra
review: Pours a deep amber mahogany color with a tall lasting head. Hops on the aroma with a bit of caramel. Full nectar with mellow residual effers creating a soft round mouthfeel. A juicy malt backbone supported by a defined hop bittering component. Flavors of citrus, caramel, leather, and biscuits. The finish is long with lingering caramel and hop bittering.

name: Hale's Moss Bay Extra
review: Sweet aroma on top a clear, amber body - zilch head. Cloying fruit sweetness with a bit tart component. Sweet caramel malt backbone that it altogether too thin and boring.

name: Hale's Moss Bay Extra
review: sweet caramel malt aroma. Pours a copper brown, minimal head. Burnt fruit, light hop finish.

name: Hale's Moss Bay Extra
review: 12oz bottle-pours a dissipating light tan head and amber/mahogany color. Aroma is medium malt-caramel/sweet molasses, dark fruit, faint hops. Taste is medium malt-caramel/molasses/a bit of chocolate comes through, some fruit, faint hops. On the thin side. Comes across like a light English mild or Dunkel Bitter. Mild carbonation.

name: Hale's Moss Bay Extra
review: (12oz bottle) Sampled at the Post-Great Canadian Beer Festival 2007 in Victoria on September 8th, 2007. Mild butter. Smooth malt. Boring.

name: Hale's Moss Bay Extra
review: Vibrant dark amber. Bright and beautiful. Caramel/chocolate aroma with minty, grassy notes. Moderate bitterness. More herbal hop notes and similar malts.

name: Hale's Cream Stout
review: @ Hales. Black color/ tan head. Nice coffee, tobacco, dark chocolate, dark roast malt aromas. smooth, rich mouthfeel. Dry chocolate, dusty dark malt, coffee flavors. Nicely bitter dark roast malt finish- good.

name: Hale's Cream Stout
review: On Tap at the brewery on 8-4-10. Jet black with a creamy nitro head on top. Roasted aromas in the nose. Flavors of coffee, dark chocolate and just a touch of sweetness round out this beer. More like a dry stout just a little bigger and fuller. Easy drinking with a smooth mouthfeel from the nitrogen conditioning. Not bad at all.

name: Hale's Cream Stout
review: 2010-07-03. Black body, small creamy tan head. 4+ Mild dusty roast aroma. 5+ Flavour is watery, mild roast, very mild cocoa touches, dilute sweet malt. Very light bitterness and lingering muted roast. Thin palate. Bland. It certainly delivers the creamy head it promised, but little else. Seriously? On tap at Hales, Seattle

name: Hale's Cream Stout
review: [3097-20100703] Nitro. Roasty smoky malt aroma has mild fruit notes. Brown black body with a long-lasting creamy mocha head. Rich alcoholic roast malt flavour has an odd strong aftertaste. Full body. Not inspiring nor as smooth as I was hoping, a little too alcoholic. Nice shamrock. (@ brewpub, Seattle, WA)

name: Hale's Cream Stout
review: Date: September 08, 2009 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: black with ruby edges, creamy tan head, drippy lace Aroma: roasted and dark chocolate aroma, touch of sweet dark caramel Body: creamy body Flavor: sweet roasted and dark chocolate flavor, light bitterness follows the dark chocolate Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 11/20 Rating: 3/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: ** /4

name: Hale's Cream Stout
review: tap at beveridge place. Frothy, from nitro. Smooth choclate flavor, a little nutty.

name: Hale's Cream Stout
review: Roasty creamy aroma. Flavor is not as intense as the aroma. Roasty creamy and sweet in the finish. Pretty good.

name: Hale's Cream Stout
review: On nitro at Hale’s. Pours dark brown with a nice creamy tan head. Roasty malts and coffee with a nice swelling bitter smoky coffee finish.

name: Hale's Cream Stout
review: Dark brown with medium light tan head. Aroma like a Starbucks. Tastes of bitter chocolate and roasted coffee, but very thin body. No finish to speak of.

name: Hale's Cream Stout
review: Nitro at TFD Boise. Dark brown pour with a thick, creamy brown head. Light aroma of roast and a faint sweetness. Tastes more roasty than anything, a little chocolate and some bittersweetness. Not bad.

name: Alpine Lager
review: 341ml butelka, kolor z³oty, klarowny, piana wystêpuje ale zbyt szybko znika zostawiaj¹c œlady na szkle. Aromat zbo¿owy trochê metaliczny. W smaku trochê gotowanych warzyw ale w sumie mo¿na spo¿yæ chocia¿ brak rewelacji.

name: Alpine Lager
review: Not bad for a Lager. Golden, white head that dilapidates quickly. Some sweet, grainy taste. But then, it‘s a Lager, thus very mild in taste, not too special. Drinkable.

name: Alpine Lager
review: One of the best Lagers out there, classic taste. In my opinion this is the ideal Lager

name: Alpine Lager
review: 473ml can 5.0% ABV Milton LCBO Outlet #1 (Milton, Ontario, Canada) June 18, 2015 $2.15 The beer pours a translucent pale gold colour with a snow white foamy cap and a little bit of effervescence. The aroma is cereal malt, grass, and weak floral hops. The mouthfeel is medium bodied with average carbonation. The flavour is grainy malt, with some soapy bitter notes. The lack of phenolic and metallic notes puts this above most Canadian pale lagers.

name: Alpine Lager
review: Unspektakuläres Lager mit leicht süßlichen Malzaromen. Kaum getrunken schon vergessen...

name: Alpine Lager
review: Pours amber with a small white head. Aroma is a little malty. Taste is a little sweet with a little malt. Medium bodied with medium carbonation. It's a mild and inoffensive lager but it does have some flavour.

name: Alpine Lager
review: A mainstream lager with a wee bit of a flavour boost. Definitely a step up in the macro department. Pours a clear straw colour with a big bubbly head. Some malt aroma.

name: Alpine Lager
review: 355ml bottle. Clear golden with a white head. Grainy, malty and corny aroma. Taste is watery sweet. Overall, another lager.

name: Alpine Lager
review: On tap at a lobster place in Alma NB. A plain and simple mass-market lager. Straw in colour with a white head; thin with a corn syrup taste; and the minimum of hops. Cool and refreshing, but nothing more.

name: Alpine Lager
review: Pours clear gold with a white head. Aroma is corn and grain. Taste is clean and refreshing but a little on the watery side. It’s what I expect in a canadian lager.

name: Alpine Light
review: 355ml can. This basically had no colour or taste, at least until it got warm. Still better than Coors Light.

name: Alpine Light
review: slightly more taste than typical macro-brewed lagers. a tiny bit of hop character in the finish. Otherwise, this stuff is as forgettable as most light beers.

name: Alpine Light
review: [1842-20081102] 341mL bottle. Vegetable straw bale and mild fruit aroma. Clear, yellow body with quick white bubbles. More vegetable watery straw in the flavour. Light body. Poor.

name: Alpine Light
review: Probably the worst Maritime beer I’ve ever had. I grew up drinking them so have a high tolerance, but this was just bad.

name: Alpine Light
review: Can thanks to my friend jay, thanks Jay- This one is pale pale yellow with a short lived white foam. Sewage aroma , like really, with corn wet paper, wet dog, and piss n shit. Tastes like the leftovers of a steelback product. Plasticy, fake, corny, ass-ey. See ya! Thanks Jay!

name: Alpine Light
review: They were serving this at a down-home Christmas party. Pale golden yellow, moderate white head. Pretty clean nose actually(maybe because it’s so cold), faintly grainy. Decent pale lager palate (i.e. no big adjunct taste or dirty finish), just a little watery. For a light beer, not bad among its peers. But it’s still a light beer.

name: Iron Hill Anvil Ale
review: Cask at the source. Hazy golden amber color, small fluffy white head. Aroma of lightly burnt caramel. Taste is slightly sour toffee. Very light body.

name: Iron Hill Anvil Ale
review: w/ Uncle mark @ iron hill in Jersey. Stylistically it seems off of the classic English bitters. Not a bad brew though.

name: Iron Hill Anvil Ale
review: On tap at Iron Hill Maple Shade. Appearance: Clear amber body, foamy light tan head. Aroma: Light fruitiness, some floral hops, and light malts. Taste: Light fruity flavors, light malts. Palate: Creamy body. Overall: Solid bitter. Nothing standout though.

name: Iron Hill Anvil Ale
review: 4 oz sample at Iron Hill Maple Shade, New Jersey. The pour is clear golden with a small white head. The aroma is cracker and crystal malt, touch of dry floral hops. The taste is the cracker toasty malt, with crystal iced tea flavors. The floral aspect gives some bitterness to the finish. The palate is light to medium bodied, fine carbonation, and a mineral iced tea finish. Easy drinking, solid ESB.

name: Iron Hill Anvil Ale
review: On tap at the lancaster pub. Clear orange in colot. Slightly fruity on the onset, enjotable effect. Yes, a tad bitter but has all the good mild mannered attributes of a well behaved english bitter. Not bad overall. that fruityness really adds a friendly aspect to this brew. Nearly flat on the palate. Medium lenght bitter finish. Its anem makes you think it would be harder hitting than it really is. Not as dark as pictured here.

name: Iron Hill Anvil Ale
review: Backlog...late 2011/early 2012...probably @ WC Iron Hill...Pours clear copper with a medium white head. Aroma has earthy bitterness, caramel, and bread. Flavor has caramel/toffee, biscuity notes, and earthy bitterness. Mouthfeel is light/medium with a dry finish.

name: Iron Hill Anvil Ale
review: Good sized frothy white head of fine bubbles that settles slowly. Dusty malt aroma with some fruity hops and a hint of grainyness. Color is a bright copper orange. Thin body of biscuity malts up front followed by a strong floral hops presence and bitterness. Bready malts show up lae swallow again. Finishes with some crusty bread, and a lingering dry bitterness. Easy drinking with a nice hoppy bitter profile.

name: Iron Hill Anvil Ale
review: Nice yeasty aroma with some floral and corn. Pours with a nice bubbly head. Taste is a little grain heavy with floral notes. Finishes with the yeast. It’s ok.

name: Iron Hill Anvil Ale
review: Pours copper with wispy white head. Aroma is caramel and grass. Taste is slight bitters with more sweetness then expected.

name: Iron Hill Anvil Ale
review: Tap at Wilmington. transparent amber-gold, thin white ring surrounds oily top, lacing all over. Watery nose of grain, light crust, and bubblegum. Flavor is similar, more bubblegum, apple, and corn sweetness through finish following light butter and biscuit that makes an oily glide across mid-palate.

name: Alpine Genuine Draft
review: I found this beer very sweet. It was once a local favorite for "tying one on" due to the fact that it is so smooth. definitely different that most.

name: Alpine Genuine Draft
review: A good little number from the brewers at Moosehead. Pours out a deeper shade of pale yellow. It has a rocky, white head that fades to a ring around the glass. The hops dance around in your mouth when you drink it. It's much better than the typical American macro brews. I recommend seeking it out if you're ever in Canada, because it's really a good, well balanced beer to have.

name: Alpine Genuine Draft
review: I don't have a whole lot to say about this one it was better then I thought it would be.

name: Alpine Genuine Draft
review: Its ok, but the old Alpine Genuine Draft was a lot better...................

name: Alpine Genuine Draft
review: i'm not a big fan of alpine but i found this beer not bad...................

name: Alpine Genuine Draft
review: Not too bad, comes in a cool clear bottle, a la mexican beer, yellow, tinny, flavorless.

name: Alpine Genuine Draft
review: I remember one time I had a bottle of this at a bar that tasted good. Once in a while you get this with Moosehead. They spoil a batch by putting hops in it, and foist it off on students as part of some promotion or another.

name: Iron Hill Maibock
review: On tap at Iron Hill Maple Shade. Pours a crystal clear amber color with a small head of white foam. Aroma of rotted oranges, caramel, alcohol, and as hint of bail polish remover. Taste of grapefruit zest, rotted oranges, caramel malt, and a sweet graininess.

name: Iron Hill Maibock
review: 20140602 5 oz pour at Newark. Well this one is sweeter than I’d hope for a maibock, but after the doppel I had earlier in Wmton, I guess its not surprising. The plus is that it comes across as relatively fresh and the sweetness isn’t palate wrecking.

name: Iron Hill Maibock
review: Draft at iron Hill. Pours clear copper with minimal white head. The aroma has caramel, light toast. The taste is lightly bitter with a thick caramel sweetness. A bit boozy.

name: Iron Hill Maibock
review: A nice bit of a sweet malty aroma. Taste is a fairly strong sweetish malt kick, good body, good finush

name: Iron Hill Maibock
review: Draft. Pours gold with a white head. Grainy malty base, light sweet malty notes, and hints of earthy hops. Not bad.

name: Iron Hill Maibock
review: Light amber minimal head. Faint nose. Thin palate. Light hoppy bite light malt profile. Easy drinking and not distracting.

name: Iron Hill Maibock
review: Aroma of typical caramel malt and skunky lager. Pours bronze with light brewpub film. Taste is nice and sweet with notes of honey, barley and caramel. Goes down easy.

name: Iron Hill Maibock
review: At Maple Shade. Light amber with rimming white head; aroma slightly sweet berries; Flava is sweet and malty with notes honey; feels medium test fizzy; finishes sweet and sugary

name: Iron Hill Maibock
review: Pours a clear golden/amber with a medium white head. Aroma has a light toasty toffee note. Flavor has toasty toffee up front and quickly balances with nice crisp bitterness. Mouthfeel is medium and the finish has a grassy dryness that lingers to spice.

name: Iron Hill Maibock
review: Deep gold with creamy white head and lace. Sweet caramel malt aroma. Peppery and caramel and a light bitter finish. Medium bodied and a tad fizzy. Nice beer.

name: True North Light
review: Bottle- GOlden body with a frothy white cap. Distinct hops aroma for a light, with mild fruit, and malt in the nose. Taste is actually pretty good. Both hops biotterness and sweet malt are present. No real finish, except it is notably bland.

name: True North Light
review: Draft. My first impression was that the body was surprisingly nice for a light beer, better than many macro lagers. Pale yellow body with a good white head. Flavour is fairly bland, but has enough malt and hint of hops to make it one of the better light beers out there.

name: True North Light
review: (Bottle) Pours a large white head and a clear yellow body. Light malt nose. Nice complexity for the style and ABV. Very surprising actually. Good malt flavour. I am truly impressed with this brewery...

name: True North Light
review: Hoppy/malty nose, amber, small white head. Fruit, malt taste, good body for a light, pleasantly bitter, average.

name: True North Light
review: this is a light? it's surprisingly good. not that it's great, but I'd guess it as a good macro lager before a light. malt and buttery aroma. canned peach sweetness and even a bit of bitterness in the finish.

name: True North Light
review: Clear, bright yellow. White head. Extremely faint aroma. Light body. Inoffensive but very bland flavour. No aftertaste to speak of.

name: True North Light
review: A micro that tries to compete with the macros (why?). It is relatively bland beer with no flaws but no qualities to speak of.

name: True North Light
review: As befits a microbrewed light lager, it is bland according to style, but a fair bit fuller than the big brewery fare.

name: True North Cream Ale
review: Taste: crisp filling, caramel malt, slight sweet cornbread notes. Grainy nose. Light Gold hue, with a white foam head with some delicate webbed lace. Medium to med/light body. A little toothy feel then some cream ales.

name: True North Cream Ale
review: Pours clear golden/copper colour with minimal white thin head that dissapears quickly, which is big no no for cream ale. Aroma is light malt, light bready yeast, and faint hop. Body is not creamy at all, or even close to being oily. Love cream ale, but this falls short.

name: True North Cream Ale
review: Clear pour with copper amber colour. No head. Corn mash, sweet malts and a bit of funk. Some tartness on the palate. Sweet and kind of metallic. Not good.

name: True North Cream Ale
review: Bottle - Light sweet bread and honey notes. Clear pale yellow with almost no head. Light grains and sweetness with a bit of richness in the body. Meh.

name: True North Cream Ale
review: 341 ml bottle from the factory. Pours gold with orange tinges. White head that doesn’t last. Smells mildly of apple juice. This one has a nice mild phenolic bitterness to it. Pleasantly surprised. Some earthiness to the taste, bread malt. Not bad.

name: True North Cream Ale
review: 341ml bottle. Pours a crystal clear golden/copper with a white, one finger head that fades to a film quickly. Aroma has notes of bread, grain, and caramel. Taste is mild but balanced. Slight grains blended with biscuit and caramel. Medium body and carbonation. Clean in the mouth with a smooth finish. Overall not bad. Easy drinking but could use more of an aroma and taste. Not offensive but too faint to stand out. Cheers.

name: True North Cream Ale
review: Tastes like a rusty lager. Not even any real sense of cream here. Pours orange with no head or lacing. Some crisp barley finish. Fizzy texture. Bottle from brewery.

name: True North Cream Ale
review: Originally rated May 2004. True North Cream Ale is golden coloured (almost amber), has a good amount of carbonation, and a head that doesn’t last long. I can taste hints of rasberries, with a slight bitter aftertaste. I prefer this cream ale to Sleeman’s.

name: True North Cream Ale
review: 341 ml bottle from The Beer Store. Pours a clear golden orange with small white head. Bread, fruit and floral notes in the aroma with a hint of spiciness. Flavour is grainy and slightly fruity malt with a modest floral hoppiness. Light bitterness in finish. Alright.

name: True North Cream Ale
review: Pale straw coloured pour. The aroma is of pale malt, light corn and a touch of leafy/spicy hops. Surprised to see it listed as all-malt but maybe they were going for the DMS that adds that component. Medium-bodied and a little bit more hoppy than I was expecting which adds a bit of interest to it. Soft lingering bitterness. It’s not great but it’s not terrible either.

name: True North Strong Ale
review: 341 ml bottle from The Beer Store. Pours a very dark brown colour with modest-sized light tan head. Aroma is caramel, toast and some dark fruit. Flavour is toasty bread, caramel, whiskey and fruit. Body on the thinner side. Decent.

name: True North Strong Ale
review: Clear coppery colour. Muted aroma, over filtered, some biscuit and toast and some serious cereal notes in this one. Medium bodied to light brew with a light sweet touch and some cereal and grain. Meh, boring.

name: True North Strong Ale
review: [7014-20141229] 341mL bottle. Mild whisky barrel grains aroma. Clear, amber orange body with a quick foamy white head. Sweet grainy barrel wood flavour. Medium body. Poor. (6/3/5/3/9) 2.7-

name: True North Strong Ale
review: Bottle - Light fruit esters and caramel malts. Clear gold with a thin white head. Light malts and grains, but really not much else.

name: True North Strong Ale
review: 341 ml bottle from brewery. clear copper colour, minimal head on an easy pour. Smells malty, caramel, sweet. Taste has some fruity flavours to it, plus candied sugar, sweet bread, caramel with a bit of booze on the finish. Decent ale.

name: True North Strong Ale
review: 341ml bottle. Pours a crystal clear golden copper with a one finger, off-white head that thins out. Aroma is faint with notes of caramel and bread mixed with a slight fruitiness. Taste is a balanced bitter with a touch of bready caramel with a slight fruity finish and aftertaste. Medium body and carbonation. Fairly clean and refreshing in the mouth with a slightly fuller feel than the other True North beers I’ve tried. Overall not bad. A bit more flavourful than the other True North brews I’ve already tried but still a but underdone. The aroma could be more enticing and the taste more complex. Not offensive but a bit simple. Cheers!

name: True North Strong Ale
review: Not quite what I envision a strong ale is. Pours reddish clear with ok head and lacing. Mostly caramelized, sweet malt in aroma with a little woodenness and some booze. Finishes sweet and boozy. Bottle from their store.

name: True North Strong Ale
review: Amber golden pour. The aroma is light nutty and toasty. Some sweet malt and a bit of toffee. Assertive hopping but not a lot of hop aroma or flavour. A little bit of woodiness and some fruit as well. Some fusely yeast character and a bit of an odd underattenuated malt flavour. Sort of chewy and almost cloying with a bit of some lingering dusty yeast notes. Pretty poor.

name: True North Strong Ale
review: Originally rated May 2004. A copper-red colour with a beige bubbly head. I don’t know if it’s a bad batch, but I see hardly any carbonation. It has a sweet smell going on the bitter side. I know it is blasphemy, but this beer is actually much better drank from the bottle.

name: True North Strong Ale
review: A hazed amber ale with a thin white head. In aroma, a nice caramel malt with nice British hops, light treacle, some vinous and burned caramel notes. In mouth, a smooth caramel malt with light British hops, some nice effect from maderization, a bit thin in finale (bottle is about a year old).

name: Mogollon White Mountain Wheat
review: Medium gold color. Medium head. Aroma is floral and citrusy. A medium bodied wheat. Malts are mild and fruity. Hops are floral. Flavorful and very smooth. Light and refreshing. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.

name: Mort Subite Framboise
review: The lambic has got a deep purple color with an airy head and thin body. Aroma of raspberries and acid. Taste of fresh raspberries, leaves and acid. Fruity finish.

name: Mort Subite Framboise
review: 2014 rating. Pours a thick foamy pinkish head and has a burgundy hue with red highlights. Leaves dirty patchy lacing. Very nice huge raspberry aromas right out of the gate. Flavours are mainly raspberries with some subtle notes of herbal hops and some other dark berries like cherry and elderberries. Nice tarty and mildly sour mouthfeel. Has some very lively carbonation and lots of fizzyness on the palate. Pretty good stuff.

name: Mort Subite Framboise
review: 375 ml bottle into tulip glass, best before 2/20/2015. Pours slightly hazy/cloudy ruby red/orange color with a 1-2 finger dense and rocky light pink head with amazing retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lasts. Dense soapy lacing clings down the glass, with a fair amount of streaming carbonation retaining the cap. Fantastic appearance. Aromas of big lightly tart/tangy raspberry jam, fruit skin/seeds, peach, plum, strawberry, lemon, red apple, hay, straw, grass, oak, candi sugar, lightly toasted bread, light musty funk, and yeast/oak earthiness. Damn nice aromas with great balance and complexity of raspberries, fruity/light funk yeast, oak, candi sugar, and pale malt notes; with great strength. Taste of big tart/tangy raspberry jam, fruit skin/seeds, peach, plum, strawberry, lemon, red apple, hay, straw, grass, oak, candi sugar, lightly toasted bread, light musty funk, and yeast/oak earthiness. Light fruity/lactic tartness, fruit tang, and yeast/oak spiciness on the finish. Lingering notes of tart/tangy raspberry jam, fruit skin/seeds, peach, plum, strawberry, lemon, red apple, hay, straw, grass, oak, candi sugar, lightly toasted bread, light musty funk, and yeast/oak earthiness on the finish for a while. Awesome complexity, robustness, and balance of raspberries, fruity/light funk yeast, oak, candi sugar, and pale malt flavors; with a great malt/tartness balance, and zero cloying sweetness after the finish. Slightly increasing dryness from fruit tang/tartness. Medium carbonation and medium-plus body; with a very smooth, moderately bready/grainy, and lightly slick/syrupy/acidic/tangy/tannic balanced mouthfeel that is great. Zero warming alcohol as expected of 4.5%. Overall this is an awesome sweetened fruit lambic! All around great complexity, robustness, and balance of raspberries, fruity/light funk yeast, oak, candi sugar, and pale malt flavors; very smooth and refreshing to drink with the mellowly tart/tangy/drying finish. Super jammy fruit with great yeast complexity; balanced sweetness with nice oak presence. A really enjoyable offering, and spot on style example.

name: Mort Subite Framboise
review: 6 4 6 3 13 Draft at A La Mort Subite, Brussels. Hazy red with a big pink head. Aroma of sweet raspberry, raspberry syrup and jam. Flavour is above moderate sweet with a light sourness behind. Light medium bodied with light carbonation.

name: Molson OV Old Vienna
review: 473ml can. Clear pale gold, effervescent and a thin foamy white head. Flavors are corn syrup, old newspapers, citrus and grass with stale notes. Light to medium body, moderate to good carbonation, syrupy texture.

name: Molson OV Old Vienna
review: Pale straw with a white head. Nose of corn and industrial malts. There's a fairly pronounced green apple and metallic aroma. Slightly sweet again with a lot of metallic flavour. This is not a good beer.

name: Molson OV Old Vienna
review: Quite possibly the best beer you can buy for the price if your main objective is to get pissed with out shitting your pants. Smells looks and tastes like heaven. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Molson OV Old Vienna
review: Okay OV is pretty simple stuff. smoother than Budwesier, kind of crisp, not too much. The least pretentious of the Molson line. It doesn’t try to be what it isn’t and it good at that. They used to sponsor five pin bowling, and is currently about as common.

name: Molson OV Old Vienna
review: Bottled. The body is clear with an uneven white head. The aroma is like corn, the taste is surprisingly hoppy.

name: Molson OV Old Vienna
review: Old Vienna is listed as a pale lager with the ingredients being only water, barley malt, hops, and yeast. It has a thin, white head, a clear, bubbly, golden straw appearance, with some bits of lacing left behind. The aroma is of sweet malt, white bread, and clean water. Taste is the same, with a mild, rounding hop bite at the end. Mouthfeel is high-light, and Old Vienna finishes crisp, refreshing, and it seems to be a bit higher quality than others of its ilk. RJT

name: Molson OV Old Vienna
review: 473ml can. Its a shitty pale lager but its somewhat drinkable, does not get as poor as it warms.

name: Molson OV Old Vienna
review: One of the best Molson products available. It is a light tasting old school lager.

name: Molson OV Old Vienna
review: Suitcase Of Cans - Basic budget brew, tastes better than most in that age bracket

name: Molson OV Old Vienna
review: 341ml brown bottle. Pours out a light yellow colour, crystal clear. White foam settles quickly and leaves some thin lacing. Some grains and bready aromas. Taste has thin bready malts, a little sweetness with a light finishing hop note. Old school swillin’.

name: Alexander Keiths Light
brewery: Alexander Keith's Nova Scotia Brewery / Oland Brewery (AB InBev)
review: Bottle, Halifax NS. Pours pale yellow, gassy froth that disappears quickly. No particular aroma. Tastes of sour-hay, ok with a meal with strong flavours, but not great on its own. Like one of the American lite beers, surprised it has 4% alcohol

name: Alexander Keiths Light
brewery: Alexander Keith's Nova Scotia Brewery / Oland Brewery (AB InBev)
review: checl out this rar north of the border white whale. at the Hilton Garden just outside the halifax airport with some fish and chips. I would venture to guess most american folk dont know that they dont need to travel all the way to england to eat shitty british food, all they have to do is visit an Canadian Province that is not named Quebec. Any way, this critter pours light straw yellow, minimal head, translucent. Light pale malt, balanced sweetness, thin body, abrupt finish. Nothing much to this one.

name: Alexander Keiths Light
brewery: Alexander Keith's Nova Scotia Brewery / Oland Brewery (AB InBev)
review: Pale golden pour with very little head. Weak scent, watery and a touch grassy. Easy to drink. Watery with very little taste. A touch of bitterness and hops. Pretty much goes down like nothing. It’s all in the aftertaste. The aftertaste really reminds me of regular Keith’s IPA. It’s like drinking a slightly beer tasting glass of water then getting the aftertaste like you just downed some Keith’s IPA. Odd. I would probably enjoy it more if I enjoyed Keith’s IPA more. For a light beer it’s very drinkable and better then most.

name: Alexander Keiths Light
brewery: Alexander Keith's Nova Scotia Brewery / Oland Brewery (AB InBev)
review: Draft in a sampler at the Red Stag Tavern. Pours a pale yellow color with a small white head that leaves some lace in the glass. Faint aroma. Very dry. Corn, pale malts, paper, and a hint of citrus. Light-bodied, with medium-high carbonation. Boring.

name: Alexander Keiths Light
brewery: Alexander Keith's Nova Scotia Brewery / Oland Brewery (AB InBev)
review: Draft at Saint John Ale House. Some sweetness and maltiness from the ale come through, but not really a blonde ale much like Keith’s IPA isn’t really an IPA either. Still, being kind of a blonde ale made it better than the majority of light macro lagers. If you have to drink a light beer in Atlantic Canada you could do much worse.

name: Alexander Keiths Light
brewery: Alexander Keith's Nova Scotia Brewery / Oland Brewery (AB InBev)
review: light yellow color with average head. light wheat nose with not much else going on. Taste is way watery and it tastes exactly like other light macros. Exactly what I expected

name: Alexander Keiths Light
brewery: Alexander Keith's Nova Scotia Brewery / Oland Brewery (AB InBev)
review: Bouteille 341 ml. 4%. Couleur jaune pâle, mousse blanche. Arôme discrets. En bouche, une light macro typique, pas trop de gout, pas d’amertume.

name: Alexander Keiths Light
brewery: Alexander Keith's Nova Scotia Brewery / Oland Brewery (AB InBev)
review: Draught. Pours light yellow with average white head. Weak aromas of grassy hops and malts. Taste is similar and weak/watery. It’s about what you would expect from a light beer. On par with other macro light beers.

name: Alexander Keiths Light
brewery: Alexander Keith's Nova Scotia Brewery / Oland Brewery (AB InBev)
review: Bottle: Poured a super light yellow color lager with a small bubbly head with no retention. Aroma of lightly sweet malt with typical adjunct notes. Taste is also dominated by lightly sweet adjunct and not much else. Body is extremely light with not much else noticeable. Bad boring and bland like most other light beer.

name: Alexander Keiths Light
brewery: Alexander Keith's Nova Scotia Brewery / Oland Brewery (AB InBev)
review: Pours a very pale wellow color with a small white head that disappears quickly. Smells skunky with a tiny bit of spice in the aroma. Tastes light and crisp wwith the skunkyness present in the aftertaste. Slightly spicy in the beginning.

name: H.C. Berger Whistlepin Wheat Ale
review: Rated from old notes taken in the late 90s. Lightly fruity, tart, reminded me of the old Celis White brew out of Texas, but more drier, and slightly more bitter. Turned watery at the end, but not bad overall.

name: H.C. Berger Whistlepin Wheat Ale
review: 12oz bottle-A nice tasting American wheat with no overpowering flavors. Not trying to be something it wasn’t.

name: H.C. Berger Whistlepin Wheat Ale
review: Nice full wheat beer with good malt. Not any frills. Very solid if not terribly special beer. Atypical of the style. I guess that is why I like it.

name: H.C. Berger Whistlepin Wheat Ale
review: Soft, sweet, and caramely. Finishes light, although a little cloying. You'll have to add your own lemon wedge too - no lemon, orange, or coriander was very detectable.

name: H.C. Berger Indego Pale Ale
review: From old tasting notes. Hazy orange copper color. Big bubbly beige head. Sweet earthy toasted malt aroma. Smooth sweet toasted malt flavor hints at chocolate and brown sugar.ncrisp citrus hop finish.

name: H.C. Berger Indego Pale Ale
review: Had this beer on 1/11/1998. Color is a medium golden brown, head and carbonation are light. Aroma is is a mild malt scent with very little hop fragrance. The taste is a little to sweet and hop flavor and bitterness is not the way it should be for a Pale Ale. It starts off with a sweet malt flavor, goes down smooth and finishes with a mild hop bitterness.

name: H.C. Berger Indego Pale Ale
review: 12oz bottle-A slightly hazy amber with a nice off white head and an aroma of malt and hops. Taste of malt more than hops. Not impressed.

name: H.C. Berger Indego Pale Ale
review: Date: 07/13/2002 Mode: Bottle Source: Brewfest, Athens Amber with a slight chill haze, scant off-white head, slight carmel malt aroma with earthy floral hops, light malt flavor and body, light bitterncss in the finish, boring Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 3/10; Flavor: 2/10; Palate: 4/10; Overall: 5/20 Rating: 1.7/5.0 Score: */4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

name: H.C. Berger Indego Pale Ale
review: Old notes. Very clean maltiness with a touch of dark fruit in the aroma. Creamy, solid medium body with lots of malt and dark fruit. Aroma also contains a graininess from the use of German malts. A plummy earthiness and a dried biscuit flavor also prevails with an underlying caramel/toffee taste. One of their best beers. I always thought of this one as an Alt beer gone crazy than an American pale.

name: H.C. Berger Indego Pale Ale
review: Completely not what I expected. This one pours a light brown color with a very light creamy head. The aroma is complex and does not smell like a pale and I think this should really be labeled as something else. Flavor is balanced but only slightly, there is a battle going on for flavor dominance in this ale. Creamy and full in the mouthfeel, with a taste that is slightly musty and sweaty sort of like a california common. It is well worth a try though if you can find it. I happened to find this one while driving across Wyoming of all places.

name: H.C. Berger Indego Pale Ale
