review: I absolutely love this beer. I used to drink it all the time. Now I can’t find it anymore. I’m sure it’s still around. Man I miss this stuff. Great raspberry flavor mixed in with wheat. Nice stuff! Hard to believe it’s actually brewed by Coors. They certainly got this one right!

name: Blue Moon Raspberry Cream Ale
review: This rating is from memory, but i remember i time when i drank plenty of it from the tap at Fitgers Brew House. Like a raspberry cream of wheat.... or something. It was a damn good beer.

name: Blue Moon Nut Brown Ale
review: Bottle poured to pint glass cold beer Appearance: Light yellow, head, a lot of lacing Aroma: scent smell of malt, slight fruity smell nothing else Taste: still ok Mouth feel: carbonated Overall: good beer nothing special just got it to taste it, not to do it again

name: Blue Moon Nut Brown Ale
review: 12oz bottle (Old Notes)-Pours a light brown with a small head. Aroma of malt, caramel, nutty, and toffee. Taste of the same with some added sweetness. This medium bodied brew is not a bad brew from Coors.

name: Blue Moon Nut Brown Ale
review: Bottle (2000?)... Found this baby in an old box of golf balls along with a Sam Adams Longshot Hazelnut Brown (1997?) (my favorite beer before before many of my favorites of today were even a gleam in their respective brew masters’ eyes). I used to really like this beer as well, let’s see how it held up... Clear, dark mahogany ale with a small, fizzy, off-white head. Restrained aroma of caramel and toffee with a hint of earthiness and a whisper of milk chocolate. Flavor wise, no real oxidation. Not much else either. Well-balanced, although it leans a touch on the sweet side and is pretty thin. Unoffensive. Light to medium-bodied with a watery mouthfeel and lively carbonation. Short, crisp, clean finish... too crisp and clean for the style. In this bottle’s case, thank God for pasteurization. Oh well, not as much going on as I remember. Can’t wait to drink the Sam Adams Hazelnut Brown... loved it twelve years ago and probably still will, but I’m certain it’s not in the database. They only brewed it for one year and that was well before RateBeer!

name: Blue Moon Nut Brown Ale
review: Name: Nut Brown Ale Date: 01/01/1994 Mode: Draft Source: Taco Mac, Sandy Springs smooth finish Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.6/5.0 Score: **/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

name: Blue Moon Nut Brown Ale
review: Bottle. A very tasty brew indeed! Smooth and very rich. Roasted malt and caramel. Pure joy. Sad that it is no longer brewed.

name: Blue Moon Nut Brown Ale
review: I haven’t had this in about 11 years, but I remember it being somewhat flavorful. It might have gotten a higher rating from me, but I am not a big fan of the style.

name: Blue Moon Nut Brown Ale
review: The name tells you everything you need to know about this brew: an uninteresting brown brew with a faint nose of cocoa, earth, and malt. The flavors are ok, slightly common of the style without much character - a little roasted chocolate and malt, a bit smooth, but overall unimpressive. I will gladly pay extra for Samuel Smith’s nutbrown.

name: Blue Moon Nut Brown Ale
review: This is a perfect example of what not to brew. We want to drink a refreshing beer not a bottle of trail-mix! Pour me something else PLEASE!

name: Blue Moon Nut Brown Ale
review: Pours deep brown, with aroma of malt, slight toffee, and caramel. Tastes malty and nutty, with some caramel, almond, and malt flavor at the finish. Pretty good.

name: Blue Moon Nut Brown Ale
review: not bad, middle of the road flavor and finish was an ok trial beer but wouldn''t buy again there are better out there in this style

name: Bittings Coal Train Porter
review: I had it on tap. It pours black with a small tan head and some lacing. The aroma is coffee, chocolate, and bitter hops. The taste is coffee, roastiness, bitter hops, chocolate, and coffee liqueur. It had a smooth and creamy palate with some carbonation. This was a good one.

name: Bittings Coal Train Porter
review: Tap. Pours clear black with a small, frothy light tan head, short retention with good lacing. Aroma is leathery roast malt and prunes, figs with earthy hops. Flavor is bitter dark malt, light hops and bitterness with a dry finish. Medium body and carbonation.

name: Bittings Coal Train Porter
review: Draft at the source. Very dark brown color, beige edge head. Aroma of dark cocoa. Taste is smooth cocoa and light coffee grounds.

name: Bittings Coal Train Porter
review: Very malty, almost chocolatey in both aroma and taste, Black in color . Pretty good, but some buttery (diacetyl?) qualities.

name: Bittings Coal Train Porter
review: Dark and smooth. Thanks Eric for sharing at Eds. Little bitterness and some roast.

name: Bittings Coal Train Porter
review: pours ddep brown with a thin off white head. Smoky aroma, roasted malt with a hint of coffee. Flavor starts strong smoke with a faint hint of chocolate caramel and hops. Very thin for a porter, almost watered down. Medium palate, kind of tingly. Decent overall.

name: Bittings Coal Train Porter
review: An almost black pour with creamy tan head and lace. Aroma of chocolate and medium coffee. Flavor mirrors the aroma with a slight bitter finish. Mouthfeel and carbonation are solid. A very ncie porter.

name: Bittings Coal Train Porter
review: on tap-pours a tan head that laces and black color. Aroma is dark malt-roasty. Taste is dark malt-roasty/chocolate/slight coffee, faint hops. OK carbonation.

name: Bittings Coal Train Porter
review: Poured a dark brown color with a medium sized, tan head that left nice lacing on the glass. Aroma of roasted malt, some smoke, and sweet chocolate. Taste of smoked malts, with light bitterness from the roasted malts, and some hoppiness as well.

name: Bittings Coal Train Porter
review: Deep brown with a nice lasting head. Nice roasty flavors. Good beer. Sweet.

name: Dock Street Illuminator
review: From old tasting notes. Deep Amber orange color. Bubbly tan head. Spicy aromatic malt nose. Tangy toasted malt flavor. With hints of orange peel and cinnamon. Delicious spicy hop character. Long spicy floral hop finish. Quite good.

name: Dock Street Illuminator
review: @ 50-55 degrees. Pours a very nice looking deep amber with thick beige head....aroma of caramel, berry an lavender. Flavor is nutty, berries, hint of medicinal, off-dry. Somewhat thin body with medium-high carbonation. Overall, not a fan and I am hoping this was just a bad bottle, came from beer trade.

name: Dock Street Illuminator
review: 12 oz bottle. Most ratings for Dock Street! Mahogany with a beige head. Nose is raisin and toffee with hints of mocha. Medium body with a tang and a lingering buzz. Taste is grape-ade, tobacco and lightly burnt sugar. Solid representation of the style.

name: Dock Street Illuminator
review: Capone’s draft. Ok for the style, so-so drinkability. A sour, rye edge, after a malt job. Lacy.

name: Dock Street Illuminator
review: Brown pour with red hues. Aromas of yeast, caramel malt, and toffee. A mild hop presence in the taste that is overwhelmed by the raison, caramel malt and yeast flavor. Good brew.

name: Dock Street Illuminator
review: Bottle. Clearer dark amber orange with very light tan head. Prunes, some slight cane sugar, and toffee in the aroma. Definitely not as sweet as suggested in the aroma, and has some nice dark fruits and toffee and a dryish finish. Medium body and a bit sticky.

name: Dock Street Illuminator
review: Clearish dulled down mahogany pour covered by a quickly fading head despite the active carbonation. Clean malty nose where toasted malts are the common denominator, but a fair array of intricacies is developed under our nostrils. For instance, there is a fair amount of fruity, almost juicy component that reminds of plums and raisins - cookie like, it also features chocolatey notions. There is pehaps a bit more hops than your average doppelbock, adding a spicy, leafy, minty undertone that fits the soft roastiness nicely. Makes me think, has there ever been a chocolate mint stout? Anyways, this illuminator follows on with an appropriate nutty (dry hazelnuts) complement on its bready toastiness. The finish is cerealic, toasty, spicy and relatively long. Impressive how it manages not too feel heavier, nor too sweet for all the malt showcase it offers. Not a show-stopper, but very good and not surprisingly from the other beers I’ve tried from lovely Dock Street Brewpub.

name: Dock Street Illuminator
review: On tap at World Cafe Live beer fest in February. Boy, was I ready for a nice big doppelbock, and this was the perfect start to the Spring drinking season. The beer is as close to drinking freshly cooled mash as you can get - totally malty, almost complete lack of hop presence, in a nutshell - liquid bread. Notes of vanilla, clove. Big body, very sweet finish, and overall refreshing and daringly easy to drink, considering it is nearly 8% ABV. This beer is listed in Michael Jackson’s infamous "500 Beers to Try" book. He has quite a point.

name: Dock Street Illuminator
review: Enjoyed from a 12oz bottle in a pub glass. The beer pours a deep brown color, with a small just off-white to possibly ivory head. The nose is malt in its purest and most unadulterated indulation. Munich malt sets the tone, and is backed up by a splendid chorus of crystal and continental character malts. I think that I get a little bit of Special "B," as well as some aromatic and perhaps Vienna. The palate is also unabashedly malty, giving notes that are very similar to what is advertised in the aroma. No hops are detectable, other than perhaps a bit of balancing. A very nicely done bock, and a steal for the price.

name: Dock Street Illuminator
review: Sampled from a12 oz brown bottle this beer poured a mahogany color with a small brown head. The aroma was strongly malty with notes of chocolate, caramel, and fruit. The flavor was tangy, very richly malty and had notes of nut, caramel, chocolate, apricot and apple. The finish was long, tangy, malty and fruity. The mouthfeel was thick and smooth. Well done.

name: Poor Henrys Bohemian Pils
review: A very nice pils. This one is also seasonally available as the same recipe at Ortleibs in Pottstown.

name: Ortliebs Select 69 Lager
brewery: Ortliebs Brewery & Grille at Sunnybrook Ballroom
review: From old tasting notes. Pale gold color. Lots of big bubbles do rocky white head. Sweet soda pop aroma. Sour malt flavor upfront. Effervescent light dry hop finish. Little or no aftertaste. Thin bodied and bland.

name: Ortliebs Select 69 Lager
brewery: Ortliebs Brewery & Grille at Sunnybrook Ballroom
review: 6/6/04 at Ortlieb’s Brewery. I haven’t had many good lagers, or many lagers at all for that matter. No, the standard American megabrews don’t count as real beer, either. That said, being a microbrew, this beer is quite good as far as lagers go. Not much head, but the aroma was on the sweet side with a very mild hop presence. Initial taste is sweet and citrusy. Finish wasn’t fantastic, but I did like it. This beer is still worlds above Bud, Coors, Miller, etc. It’s not very complex, but it is refreshing.

name: Ortliebs Select 69 Lager
brewery: Ortliebs Brewery & Grille at Sunnybrook Ballroom
review: Pours pale yellow, with medium head. TAstes crisp, smooth, refreshing, with some malt, citrus, and hop flavors.

name: Ortliebs Select 69 Lager
brewery: Ortliebs Brewery & Grille at Sunnybrook Ballroom
review: 04.04.04 Tap at Citizen's Bank Park, Philly, PA. Are the Phillies resurrecting old brews? First the Dock Street, now this. Pours a lighter yellow with ample, fizzy, disappearing head in a plastic cup. Not much aroma other than light graininess. Lots of bready malts in flavor; simple, unpretentious, and quite tasty for a ballpark beer. Cheaper than BMC, too! Refreshing (not that I needed that on a cold, wet, day) and could use a touch of dry bitterness at the end. Unassuming and forgettable.

name: Ortliebs Select 69 Lager
brewery: Ortliebs Brewery & Grille at Sunnybrook Ballroom
review: Maize-colored with a grain husk aroma. Standard US lager with a sturdy malt character. OK.

name: Ortliebs Select 69 Lager
brewery: Ortliebs Brewery & Grille at Sunnybrook Ballroom
review: decent lager. fizzy yelloe stuff but hasa nice malt body with a tangy hop finish.

name: Ortliebs Select 69 Lager
brewery: Ortliebs Brewery & Grille at Sunnybrook Ballroom
review: real shit! taste like drinking warm budweiser from a shaved monkeys belly button.

name: Ortliebs Select 69 Lager
brewery: Ortliebs Brewery & Grille at Sunnybrook Ballroom
review: Very average lager, a bit of a darker tint to the golden color, very little head, not a whole lot going on with this brew

name: Ortliebs Select 69 Lager
brewery: Ortliebs Brewery & Grille at Sunnybrook Ballroom
review: This is a fine lager. I enjoyed it very much. Great appearance, good aroma and a balanced, very enjoyable lager. The label is awesome too. Can't go wrong here.

name: Ortliebs Select 69 Lager
brewery: Ortliebs Brewery & Grille at Sunnybrook Ballroom
review: I believe dirty dishwater tastes better.....................................

name: Poor Henrys Abbey Trippel
review: Sharp and yeasty - a bit too harsh. Clearly a derivative of Duvel, but missing the smoothness and great easy drinking body, and Duvel's big firm head. Very malty - hard to finish.

name: Poor Henrys Doppelbock
review: Nice deep amber appearance...somewhat rich malty flavor with Belgian tint to ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Poor Henrys Doppelbock
review: Firmly malty and strong, yet easy drinking, pairing well with many foods. Very dark brown color, not the opaque black of Celebrator.

name: Greene King IPA Smooth
review: Can 44cl, a copper beer with creamy head. Nose is more like a pale ale, touch of resin and honey, grass. Aroma is on hop resin, medium bitterness, typical english profile, caramel, hay. Texture is creamy and the beer nice for the alcohol level.

name: Chang Beer 6.4%
region: Phra Nakhon Sri Ayutthaya Province, Thailand
review: Light lager. The one you get in Thailand is slightly stronger than the version you get here.

name: Chang Beer 6.4%
region: Phra Nakhon Sri Ayutthaya Province, Thailand
review: absolutely gutted to find out that this thai-domestic beer has been discontinued, yet at the same time glad to see that the poor chang export has also gone the way of the dodo. i will have to try the "new" chang classic. anyways, chang 6.4% is/was a phenomenal, malt-heavy brewery with a slightly overpowering alcoholic kick. chilled down to ridiculous proportions and imbibed in the thai heat however, you could go through it like water. very tasty, for a.) a lager and b.) for its strength. RIP.

name: Chang Beer 6.4%
region: Phra Nakhon Sri Ayutthaya Province, Thailand
review: Tämä versio suoraan Thaimaasta, 6.4%. Vaaleankeltainen olut kohtalaisella valkoisella vaahdolla, joka jättää aavistuksen pitsiä. Maltainen ja viljainen, aika pitkälle peruslagermainen ja hieman makea tuoksu. Maku maltainen, viljainen, asteen verran normilageria vahvempi. Oiva janojuoma ja varmasti hyvä tulinen ruoan kaveri.

name: Chang Beer 6.4%
region: Phra Nakhon Sri Ayutthaya Province, Thailand
review: Dorata pallida, schiuma bianca non molto persistente. Aroma di malti chiari, fieno, metallico ed erbaceo. Al palato stesse componenti, corpo medio-leggero, mediamente carbonata.

name: Chang Beer 6.4%
region: Phra Nakhon Sri Ayutthaya Province, Thailand
review: From 330ml bottle. Clean, clear yellow lager. A bit high on the abv for my taste. Not my first choice for a pale lager

name: Chang Beer 6.4%
region: Phra Nakhon Sri Ayutthaya Province, Thailand
review: Very pale yellow and clear. White foam. Lager aroma. Very light and sweet. No bitterness at all. Fair carbonation. Bad.

name: Chang Beer 6.4%
region: Phra Nakhon Sri Ayutthaya Province, Thailand
review: Pours clear yellow. Head dissipates immediately. Aroma of wet grain and dried corn. Tastes like silage with a sweet backbone. Finish is dry. Medium light mouthfeel. Similar to any light domestic, nothing worthy of note.

name: Chang Beer 6.4%
region: Phra Nakhon Sri Ayutthaya Province, Thailand
review: Clear pale yellow body and minimal head. Nose has malts and hay-like aromas. Taste is sweetish with a mildly dry finish and a metallic note. Carbonation and mouthfeel are medium. Basic light lager,, nothing special.

name: Chang Beer 6.4%
region: Phra Nakhon Sri Ayutthaya Province, Thailand
review: Eines der besseren Thaibiere und mit 6% auch geschmacklich etwas erwachsener und weniger wässrig. Malzig-bitter im Geschmack, leichter Reis-Nachgeschmack (aber immerhin überhaupt mal einer).

name: Chang Beer 6.4%
region: Phra Nakhon Sri Ayutthaya Province, Thailand
review: Can, 6.0%. The good old sour grain aroma. Clear golden colour. Small frothy chalk white head. The flavour is surprisingly malty and does not have much of the graininess of the aroma. Also has a little alcohol punch, but no more than expected for the ABV. Decent for the style.

name: Lobkowicz Knize (Knight) 12°
review: Dieser Ritter (cz. knize = dt.:Ritter) ist ein helles Lagerbier, das einfach nur billig produziert wurde. Inzwischen wurde es eingestellt -kein großer Verlust.

name: Lobkowicz Knize (Knight) 12°
review: Bottle @ Havsnära, Ystad 20180726. Malty and malty, grassy, medium body with a watery texture. The finish is dry, bitter and malty.

name: Lobkowicz Knize (Knight) 12°
review: Gyllengul öl med vitt skum. Doft och smak av malt, säd och mycket lätta smörkolatoner.

name: Lobkowicz Knize (Knight) 12°
review: Flaska. Klar guldfärgad med ett givmilt vitt skum. Enkel och drickbar pilsner, med inslag av säd, bröd, citrus och i avslutningen en lätt mineralton.

name: Lobkowicz Knize (Knight) 12°
review: To tap pub Kamelot in Prievidza,malt aroma ,sweetish,honeyis,light to medium body,blond to golden color.

name: Lobkowicz Knize (Knight) 12°
review: Quite disgusting and barely drinkable. Metallic taste and a sour aftertaste that was not pleasant.

name: Mudshark Full Moon Belgian White Ale
region: Lake Havasu City, Arizona, United States
review: On tap at Taphouse Kitchen Scottsdale. Medium bodied very standard wit. Finish is very lightly floral. Watery mouthfeel.

name: Mudshark Full Moon Belgian White Ale
region: Lake Havasu City, Arizona, United States
review: Radiant hazy orange color with a thin head of white foam. Sweet citrus, coriander, yeast, and floral hops. Hides the high alcohol very well considering the style.

name: Mudshark Full Moon Belgian White Ale
region: Lake Havasu City, Arizona, United States
review: Sampled at Tucson fest. Rich golden and hazd. This is sweet and fruity. Oranges. Dangerous with the abv.

name: Mudshark Full Moon Belgian White Ale
region: Lake Havasu City, Arizona, United States
review: Draft at the source. Murky bronze color, white head. Aroma of orange and spice. Taste is orange, orange zest. More orange. Spice. Alcohol. Not a fan.

name: Mudshark Full Moon Belgian White Ale
region: Lake Havasu City, Arizona, United States
review: Bottle at home. Pours cloudy orange with a small, frothy white head, short retention with spare lacing. Aroma is earthy wheat malt, alcohol, perfumey coriander, light orange peel and bubble gum. Flavor is earthy and spicy wheat malt, peppery and perfumey alcohol, light orange peel and coriander with some tartness and a sweet, boozy finish. Medium body and light carbonation. This beer seems a little "dirty" and possibly infected.

name: Mudshark Full Moon Belgian White Ale
region: Lake Havasu City, Arizona, United States
review: [ bottle ][ 1oz ][ @Tasting ][ $ ? ][ snifter ][ 12.06.15 ] tepid gold honey, thin large bubbled white ring. Heavy banana fusel nose, plenty of plastic with light Belgian candi. Thick body is sweet, hot, plenty of candi.. "That’s a tinder profile, I hope" - B3playr.

name: Mudshark Full Moon Belgian White Ale
region: Lake Havasu City, Arizona, United States
review: 12oz bottle pours a murky gold with some cloudy, white head. Nose has yeast and fruit, a little perfume. Flavor is sweet, white grape, banana milkshake, mild spice. Muddled finish.

name: Mudshark Full Moon Belgian White Ale
region: Lake Havasu City, Arizona, United States
review: Some citrus and some light florals. Pours amber. Finishes tangy. Bottle shared at tasting.

name: Mudshark Full Moon Belgian White Ale
region: Lake Havasu City, Arizona, United States
review: Bottle courtesy of iphonephan, thanks! Cloudy golden yellow color, big white head. Light straw aroma. Taste is light lemon.

name: Mudshark Full Moon Belgian White Ale
region: Lake Havasu City, Arizona, United States
review: From a bottle shared at the DC mini tasting in December 2015. Pours a hazy gold with an off white head. Light coriander aroma. Flavors of caramel and orange.

name: Odell Cutthroat Pale Ale
review: "Nice balance between bready malts and floral herbal hops, with a very slight citrus aspect to the aftertaste. Light to medium body and feel. Especially seeing as how I’ve had this for a while, this is pretty nice."

name: Odell Cutthroat Pale Ale
review: Bottle. Pours dark brown with tan head. Smells chocolatey, sweet. Tastes smooth, bitter, grassy, roasty, great bitterness. Really good.

name: Odell Cutthroat Pale Ale
review: Poured a medium amber color with a bit of off-white head. Aromas of light hops and light malt. On the palate, this one is rather light bodied, with mild hops and a little malt.

name: Odell Cutthroat Pale Ale
review: Clear golden with a tiny off white head. Grainy aroma with hints of malt. Grainy flavour with vague caramel and grassy hops. Finished sweet and grainy.

name: Odell Cutthroat Pale Ale
review: Tap straight from the Brewery on Ft. Collins’ Oktoberfest- Surprising for a pale ale; not overpoweringly bitter, yet plenty of hoppiness. Finished very clean.

name: Odell Cutthroat Pale Ale
review: Poured a clear golden bronze color with a slightly off-white finger of head. The nose was of earthy and herbal hops, biscut and caramel malts. The flavor started malty and thin with a strange metalic copper taste. Next flowery hops try to exert themselves but the copper taste keeps the the balance off. The finish had citrusy hop notes. The feel was very thin. This Pale Ale was well below average and unimpressive.

name: Odell Cutthroat Pale Ale
review: I love this brewery! When I found out that they were discontinuing this beer, I ordered the remaining cases from the distribtor. Now, I finally get a chance to rate this beer next to its succesor. 12z, bottled 031605. Light amber hue with finger width head. Good bubble size on remaining head. A lot of grainy maltiness in the nose, with a supporting sweet, slight hop note. Malty kick as it hits the mouth followed by a dry hop note as it rolls over the back of the tongue. I guess that this means a malt/hop balance, but its more of a one/two combo. Good amount of maltiness that, apparently, is typical of the style. But it is followed up by a drying bitterness in the mouth. Am I being redundant? I just wanna be sure that I am good and thorough since this is going into extinction! There are many slight notes in the flavor...cirtus, caramel, and a light roasted note. Well, bottle is empty but the beer was clean! Now for the 5BBL...

name: Odell Cutthroat Pale Ale
review: Bottle. Bottled on 2/22/05. I believe I picked this up in Kansas City. Somewhat doughy in the aroma with a hint of hops and some fruit. Attractive, hazy amber with an off-white head that is mostly diminishing. Slow, widely spread visible carbonation. If I had a dollar for every beer I’ve had that tastes like this...is this from a kit? It tastes a fair amount like Kona Fire Rock Pale. Has some pine to it. Reasonably well balanced, but malt and hops somehow just don’t synchronize very well. Some caramel notes. I have concerns that at 6 months of age, this brew is past its prime. However, it seems to have enough hops for preservative quality. Improves as it warms, however, there really isn’t anything in here that blows me away.

name: Odell Cutthroat Pale Ale
review: Draught. Pours amber with a rocky off-white film and blotchy spotty lacing. Fruit hop floral aroma with nutty caramel malt and a pine nose. Bitter acidic hop and caramel malt (meal) flavor. Medium bodied and creamy palate.

name: Odell Cutthroat Pale Ale
review: Poured clear yellow with white mostly lasting head. Aroma is malty, leather, yeast. Taste is lightly bitter, some sweet, with a nice dry finish. Palate is between watery and oily.

name: Odell Easy Street Wheat
review: Hazy gold. Nose is wheat malt, citrus hops. Decent malt flavor, wheat biscuit, American hops accent. Crisp.

name: Odell Easy Street Wheat
review: Translucent pale gold on tap. Slight hoppy aroma, pine lemon grass - with a nice crisp wheat flavor and body. Nice for the style.

name: Odell Easy Street Wheat
review: This reminds me of a hefe with light hoppiness and citrus at the end. Easy to drink and has a good collection of flavors. Sunny afternoon kind of beer.

name: Odell Easy Street Wheat
review: 355ml can from Binnys Kenwood. Pours a hazed blonde color, fluffy white head. Aroma is light and non-descript. some creamy wheat and slight herb, musty, oatmeal. Flavor is grainy and doughy, some herbal character, sweetness. I’m not into this at all, like drinking dough, not pleasant.

name: Odell Easy Street Wheat
review: Can from Boise Co-op. Very subtle what beer, as in, barely there. Light golden body, skin of head. Faint grainy aroma, white bread. Taste too is bready, wheat. It does have a nice texture though, not enough to salvage this.

name: Odell Easy Street Wheat
review: These days, I expect wheat ales to basically be APAs but this is in the old school American craft style and quite refreshing. It’s cloudy orange in the glass w/ an ton of thick patches of lace after the first few sips. There is a bit of soft fruitiness to this and quite a solid malt presence once you taste it. It’s quite full and creamy on the palate but a good prickle of carbonation keeps it from feeling sluggish. Some sweetness brings out a hint of lemon hops in the finish. This is a really well done beer overall, not aggressive but subtly spicy and flavorful.

name: Odell Easy Street Wheat
review: Can, hazy light yellow. Typical light wheat beer aromas. A bit more sharp hop flavors that I expected. Bold flavors, soft wheat bready trailer. Not Bad

name: Odell Easy Street Wheat
review: Cloudy yellow with small fast fading head. Smells of grain and tropical fruit but the taste is grain with a strong tartness that is not very good at all. Two more bottles of this in the sampler so maybe after drinking the other nine beers these will taste better.

name: Odell Easy Street Wheat
review: From 12oz bottle to snifter. Pour is a hazy orange/yellow, thin white head. Nose is sugary, sight malt, wheat, nutty. Taste is light bodied, sweet. Finishes crisp, simple easy drinking beer which is definitely the intent.

name: Odell Easy Street Wheat
review: Out of the new cans from liquor store. Pours cloudy with nice big white head. Excellent flavor and palate. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Odell Levity Amber Ale
review: Aroma is spices and malts/caramel malts. The flavor is citrus, fruit/berries, malts/earthy and a hoppy/bitter finish.

name: Odell Levity Amber Ale
review: 12 oz. bottle. Poured light amber, lasting white head. Aroma was sweet floral, light hops, biscuit. Taste was mild sweet, spicy, grass, citrus.

name: Odell Levity Amber Ale
review: On tap at the brewery. Pours a clear orange with medium off white head leaving sticky lacing. The aroma is caramel and resin. Medium body, earthy hop, caramel, light bitter finish, good.

name: Odell Levity Amber Ale
review: Looks deep gold. Barely amber. Has a faint sweerness like an amber but significant enough hop bitterness not to suck.

name: Odell Levity Amber Ale
review: Looks decent...nice amber colour with a silky head. Smells like a lager and taste is quite bland. Still refreshing though... ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Odell Levity Amber Ale
review: this has an interesting, fruity/citrus aroma and a more golden appearance than most amber ales. the taste is nice and fruity, hoppy without being overly bitter, and refreshing. i like this one pretty well. im not a huge pale ale person because lately it seems to be a contest to see how bitter a pale ale can be. but this one is just bitter enough. most hoppy beers are not that refreshing to me, but this one is.

name: Odell Levity Amber Ale
review: Draft at Jack Quinn’s. Pours clear bright copper with a fizzy beige head. Tastes like light fruit, very malty, toffee, dry toast, grassy. Light/medium body and low carbonation. Smells like light fruit, toasted malt, grassy.

name: Odell Levity Amber Ale
review: Notes from my recent Denver trip: Light amber pour, no head. Nose is vague grain. Bittersweet. Middle is more roasted grain. Finish is lightly sweet. OK.

name: Odell Levity Amber Ale
review: Bottle from McHughs. Pours opaque amber with white thin foam head. Fairly bread, molasses, maple syrup, a little metallic. Sweet doughy flavour with dry bark finish

name: Odell Levity Amber Ale
review: Poured from a bottle. Golden brown with a thin white head. Sweet, caramel and brown sugar aromas. Sweet with apple flavor with some nuttiness. Medium body, but light tasting and refreshing.

name: Odell Curmudgeons Nip
review: Courtesy of markwise, now I can pull yet another very long time ‘want’ off my list, thanks. This 1997 vintage pours clear copper with thin off white head. The aroma is musty malts, smooth blunted pine hops, some caramel candy, a bit of oxidation and thick and tacky summer pavement burned malt syrup. The taste is smooth and yummy goodness with caramel candy, sticky malt sweetness and smooth blunted rolling waving pine hops. Into the finish a bit of dark fruity esters come to the surface and sort of seem like aged pine hop infused brown sugar coated prunes. I think the word “yum” is required here.

name: Odell Curmudgeons Nip
review: Thanks to markwise for the share. I cant say too much more than mark says below, it was really good and wish I had more.

name: Odell Curmudgeons Nip
review: Thanks to the man for this one in trade. Pours caramel brown with a white head. The sticker that he put on top says "1997 bottle." Holy hell, for a 14 year-old beer, this one has aged beautifully. Pours caramel brown with a white head. Nose is caramel, brandy, booze, raisins, and slight fruit. A twinge of oxidation, but not really. Flavor has brandy and caramel with slight cardboard that is quickly snuffed out by brandy and caramel. Medium-bodied and enjoyable.

name: Odell Curmudgeons Nip
review: Pours a nice reddish brown color. Aromas of dark fruits, hops, and a touch of wood. Flavor is smooth caramel malt, wood, and a nice hop.

name: Odell Curmudgeons Nip
review: 2003 bottle shared by Matt. Darker reddish brown with a thin light tan film for a head. Alcohol pops out a bit stronger (surprising once I see the ABV!) in the nose with some molasses and lighter dark malt and caramel. Medium body, lower carbonation. Sweet medium malt. Dark fruit, alcohol. A bit astringent, but very smooth otherwise. Brown sugar. Lingering sweetness, not bad.

name: Odell Curmudgeons Nip
review: 2006 bottle. Pours amber with a thin white head. Smells of caramel, molasses, some dark fruit. Tastes caramelly and sweet with a syruppy finis.

name: Odell Curmudgeons Nip
review: 12oz., bottled on 03/2006, with another thank you to John (jjpm74) for this great selection from the Christmas cheer trade forum box he sent my way! Pours a clear orange amber with a fizzy and quickly dissipating off-white head that settles into a thin ring and center whisp, no lacing. Aroma is dark fruits, toffee, caramel, and sweet malts. Flavor is a little more one dimensional, with sweet caramel malts and toffee. A bit thin bodied and middle of the road for the style. Thanks again John!

name: Odell Curmudgeons Nip
review: Tasted 5/11/08. Apparently a 2005 vintage. Hazy orange golden honey hue. Slight layer of bone white head. Aromas of raisins and wood. Caramel and spices. Citrus and toffee. Big nose. Full bodied and with a nice tingling effervescence. Rather dry finish with a lot of citrus qualities. Peppery and sticky. Bitter hop finish. Piney dry hop palate. Moderate burn. Almost a touch bitter rye malts. Tangy citrus flavor. The bitter hops and the sweet malts have a nice juxtaposition on the palate. Rolls roughly but nicely.

name: Odell Curmudgeons Nip
review: Bottle 2003 vintage poured a clear mahogany with a small disapating amber head. Aromas of dates, fig, carmel, toffee, pepper and a hint of mocha. Palate was medium to full bodied smooth and warming. Flavors of carmel, toffee, dark fruit, pepper and light spice with a smooth warming lingering bittersweet finish. One of the best beers I’ve had from Odells but I’m sure the ageing helped.

name: Odell Curmudgeons Nip
review: Has this beer on 1/13/1999. Color is a medium orange brown with average carbonation and head. Aroma has a lightly sweet malt scent. Taste smooth and lightly sweet. It starts off with a medium body that goes down smooth with a sweet malt feel. Finish is a some what rich sweet malt flavor with a light bitterness. It’s a little lighter than I like a Barley Wine to be.

name: Ruby Mountain Bristlecone Brown Porter
review: Got this on draft at the Whispering Elms Bar in Baker, Nevada st the foot of Great Basin National Park. Pours brown in color with a light tan head. Nose of roasted malts, chocolate, and coffee. Medium body. Kind of a thin mouthfeel Flavor is a bit earthy along with the roasted malts. The finish is earthy and bitter. Decent.

name: Ruby Mountain Bristlecone Brown Porter
review: 0.355l bottle shared with The Tasting Crew. This is a deep dark ruby red colored one, it also has a small softly lacing dark beige top. Strange nose. Some old sun damaged chocolate and old brownie cake glazing. Sour cocoa butter with yeast and traces of phenol. Not a super aroma, but I think this is quite a old bottle. It has a just above average carbonation level, the small prickling kind and it feels thin oily in the mouth. Doesn’t taste all that bad really. Softly roasted with a gentle nice sweetness. Dry cocoa powder, nugatti and it’s rounded off with traces of burned sour thin coffee. Quite strange, but actually not bad. Just old. Older than it should be. 15.01.2014

name: Ruby Mountain Bristlecone Brown Porter
review: Rated while watching the 2014 Las Vegas Bowl: Toasted malt, coffee nose. Cola brown, thin head. Coffee and beechwood flavor, low astringency. Medium body, soft carbonation. Solid porter.

name: Ruby Mountain Bristlecone Brown Porter
review: On Tap at the original Brewforia Beer Market, Meridian, ID Deep dark brown with redish edges, Full thick lasting light tan head. Nutty light toasted malt aroma. Sweet woody brown malt flavors. Some sweetness and a little of that sourness that some browns and porters have. Nice finish. Papery trailer.

name: Ruby Mountain Bristlecone Brown Porter
review: "i was hoping northern Nevada would be represented better than this, especially being that their Angel Creek Amber is so good...but this beer is weak & boring, even if it were classified as a brown. worst porter i’ve ever had."

name: Ruby Mountain Bristlecone Brown Porter
review: Dark, dark brown, near black pour with small tight beige head. Slightly smoky, nutty aroma and taste, medium weight and creamy mouth feel. not too bad.

name: Ruby Mountain Bristlecone Brown Porter
review: Draft. Pours dark brown in color with a small off white head. The aroma and flavor have roasted malt, chocolate, mild coffee, some earthy bitterness to the finish. Standard porter.

name: Ruby Mountain Bristlecone Brown Porter
review: Draft pour dark brown. Nose light roast, coffee some sweet malt. Taste light roast, similar to nose. Light bitter from mid pale to end. Light mouth and a little watery, but not to bad.

name: Ruby Mountain Bristlecone Brown Porter
review: 15.01.2014, 0,33l bottle sampled @ BBGTC tasting: Small creamy mediumlasting head. Aroma is strange fruity, tangerine, unripe banana, grapefruit, grass. Taste is caramel malts, nuts, hay, grain, grass, chocolate, hints of cardboard. Medium bitterness, very thin body. Boring.

name: Ruby Mountain Bristlecone Brown Porter
review: Brown murky pour with a fast subsiding tan head. Aroma is somewhat sweet and estery like overripe banana. Taste is very moderate roasty, bready maltyness and a bit too faint all around. Slightly watery.

name: Sierra Nevada Krombacher Pils
review: 500ml bottle enjoyed @ Oktoberfest, Munich, 27.09.2012. A: Cristal clear yellow color forming a big bubbled white head. Medium to low retention with a thin layer that lasts forever on the top S: Sweet grains and flowery hops. Very Lager yeasts in the nose. Bready. Hops are very citrus T: Sweet grains upfront with strong notes of white bread, Lager yeasts and flowery hops. Metallic and a bit ashy. In overall, a dry taste with a stingy hop bitterness in the end M: Light body and medium carbonation. Sweet grains, stingy and quite crispy bitter aftertaste O: Good drinkability. An authentic Bavarian Lager. Good session beer [ BA Review @ 9/28/2012 ]

name: Sierra Nevada Krombacher Pils
review: rather unremarkable in any way, although it was crisp and refreshing at the time

name: Sonoran Top Down Classic Red Ale
review: 12oz bottle. Poured a deep copper color with a reddish tint and thick tan head. Plain toasted malt aroma. Flavor is sweet roasted malts, nuttiness and slight mild hops. Very mild and plain.

name: Sonoran Top Down Classic Red Ale
review: Re-Rate 09/1/02: Deep garnet in color, the head is generous and beige, lots of lace. Nose is malt, nut sweet, as is the start. The middle of the beer is light, the finish is acidic, dry, lightly hopped and a decent but not great beer. Ranks #913 on my master beer list.

name: Sonoran Top Down Classic Red Ale
review: Red-brown. Lightly malty, low bitterness....................................

name: Sonoran Top Down Classic Red Ale
review: Malty taste. Low hops. Was a little bit to thin...........................

name: Sonoran Top Down Classic Red Ale
review: reddish colour, no head, plastic aroma with a hint of cherry, far too much carbonation, sour, long plastic aftertaste - boaaark !

name: Sonoran Top Down Classic Red Ale
review: buttery, malty aroma; orangey-amber colour; thin body with rank flavours of sour hop, and empty maltiness (like spent grains). It's not bottle-conditioned, so what's gone wrong here?

name: Sonoran Robust Porter
review: A Porter lovers Porter, very robust flavor, big roasted malt nose, hints of Chocolate, and a deep dry hop finish and decent malts. High on my list of Porters.

name: Blue Moon Harvest Pumpkin Wheat
review: Bottle. Pours orange brown. Cinnamon, nutmeg, lemon, pepper, little sweaty, little floral. Medium body. Really not too bad.

name: Blue Moon Harvest Pumpkin Wheat
review: Pours clear amber with a thin white head. Aroma of pumpkin spice. Taste has slightly herbal elements, nutmeg. Palate has butternut squash. Typical pumpkin beer.

name: Blue Moon Harvest Pumpkin Wheat
review: good beer has in bottle would buy again had cold poured into glass good taste nice appearence

name: Blue Moon Harvest Pumpkin Wheat
review: 35,5cl Bottle @ Drinks of The World, Geneva, Switzerland. Reddish amber colour with a thin white head. Aroma is malt, sweet, pumpkin, spices. Taste is malt, caramel, pumpkin, cloves, slightly yeasty. Medium body, average carbonation.

name: Blue Moon Harvest Pumpkin Wheat
review: Taste the squash flavor of the pumpkin plus the traditional flavors of Thanksgiving. One of the best pumpkin beers I’ve had

name: Blue Moon Harvest Pumpkin Wheat
review: Pours from the bottle clear dark amber not much head, sweet gum on the noze, sweet body and bitter neck, the pumpkin very present

name: Blue Moon Harvest Pumpkin Wheat
review: Pours medium amber with a thin white head. Heavy pumpkin spice flavor, with a little pumpkin/rind tang. Slight sugar candy sweet flavor as well. All and all a drinkable if not a little too sweet pumpkin beer.

name: Blue Moon Harvest Pumpkin Wheat
review: 330ml bottle served in a pint glass. Pours a clear copper amber color that forms a medium to small thin bubbled creamy light yellow head. Medium retention with only very few spotty lacings formed and left in the glass. Sweet and spicy nose. Strong notes of toffee, caramel, pumpkin pie, cinnamon, honey, chestnut, vanilla and caramel malts. Toffee caramel candy. Sweet upfront taste too. Strong notes of toffee, caramel, pumpkin pie, cinnamon, honey, vanilla, chestnut, caramel malts, roasted malts and flowery hops. Too sweet. Not bitter enough. Medium creamy and smooth body. Medium carbonation. Toffee, pumpkin pie and cinnamon in the afteraste. Medium drinkability. Too sweet and not enough bitter.

name: Blue Moon Harvest Pumpkin Wheat
review: Solid flavors, but it really doesn’t taste like pumpkin anything. I honestly would have no idea there were pumpkin flavors if I didn’t read it on the label, so definitely disappointing if I was looking for heavy pumpkin flavors.

name: Blue Moon Harvest Pumpkin Wheat
review: From backlog. Bottle from Total Wine Bocca Park, Las Vegas, Nv. Golden /orange with white head. Malts, hops, spices and some bitterness.

name: Stoudts Pils
review: 12 oz bottle, clear pale gold. Medium body. Mild malt aroma, grassy taste and light malt finish.

name: Stoudts Pils
review: Gyllengul öl med ett större vitt skum. Doft och smak av malt, lättare citrustoner och tysk humle. Trogen till stilen.

name: Stoudts Pils
review: on tap at the brewery; clear gold color; ligt, earthy malt aroma; clean, crisp, earthy malt flavor with light hop notes

name: Stoudts Pils
review: 12 oz bottle from NC. Pours with a clear, pale golden body that is topped with a reasonably durable white head. Aroma: Hop forward Herbal-fruity, hop forward flavor. Light body and medium+ carbonation; dry.

name: Stoudts Pils
review: From old tasting notes. Yellow gold color with a huge white head. Nice small bubbles. Light malt aroma . Sweet malt flavor upfront dissipating to a spicy hoppy entanglement of flavor. Light clinging hop aftertaste. Though lacking in complexity, it entices and pleases with a robust character.m

name: Stoudts Pils
review: Bottle. Pours clear gold with a white head. Aromas of sweet malt, a touch of honey and German hops. Definitely sweet malt flavor with hints of butter, a touch of herbs and cut grass. Clean mouthfeel. Nice, overall.

name: Stoudts Pils
review: Draft -pours yellow white head - nose/taste of peppercorn, spicy malt, citrus - medium body

name: Stoudts Pils
review: Draft - Nice grains. Clear gold with a nice white head. Grainy and bitter, a solid pils.

name: Stoudts Pils
review: On tap at Kutztown Folk Festival. A bitter and hoppy Pilsner. Very crisp mouthfeel with lingering bitter.

name: Stoudts Pils
review: Pours a golden yellow with a white head. Aromas of bread/malts/hops. Crisp hop flavor with hints of fruit/malt.

name: Stoudts Gold Lager
review: From old tasting notes. Lovely orange amber color. Huge bubbly beige head. Tiny small bubbles. Light sour hop aroma with metallic overtones. Dry roasted malt flavor with a mild hop backdrop. Dry finish and aftertaste.

name: Stoudts Gold Lager
review: Straw yellow pour with fairly quick white foam. Malty nose with touches of yeast and a little fruity hops. The taste is sweet and familiar. There is a little bitterness at the end. Medium body and active fizz. It is a little sharper than a conventional lager.

name: Stoudts Gold Lager
review: This is one of the best Lagers in America and can easily compete with the best European Lagers. It is a clean and simple beer that is easily quaffed and is quite refreshing. I believe the ratings for the beer are lower than they should be because Lagers normally have very little aroma and have only subtle flavors.

name: Stoudts Gold Lager
review: Bottle pour. Straw color with a finger of head. Toasted malt taste. I really enjoyed this one. Will buy another six pack before I leave Atlanta.

name: Stoudts Gold Lager
review: Draft. Clear golden yellow color, medium white head. Aroma of white pepper and fresh hay. Taste is peppery straw. Easy drinking.

name: Stoudts Gold Lager
review: This is one of my favorites, especially from draught. Last time I tried was at Gingerman, NY. Really good helles.

name: Stoudts Gold Lager
review: Draught @ Ginger Ma. Bright and clear yellow with large off-white creamy head, honey aroma, high carbonation, delicious honey taste, abrupt finish. Very good Helles!

name: Stoudts Gold Lager
review: From tap. Pours cloudy orange with a small white head. Aroma is grainy and light fruity. Toasted, flat malty and light bitter. Grassy and grainy. Toasted malty finish.

name: Stoudts Gold Lager
review: Rated on 12-22-2010. This beer pours a small frothy, fizzy mostly diminishing white head, hazy yellow body, fizzy carbonation, and one ring of lacing. The aroma is malty, yeasty, hoppy, sweet, and fruity. The taste is sweet, lightly biter, malty, yeasty, citrus hops, and fruity. This beer has a semi-harsh finish. The mouth feel is clean, lively and this beer is medium bodies. This is a session beer. The flavor is a bit of a turn-off for me as it taste somewhat harsh.

name: Stoudts Gold Lager
review: 12 oz. bottle. Pours a clear but slightly hazy gold color with a thin white head that disappears rather quickly. Aroma of corn and a touch of hops. Thin bodied, balanced between malt and hops. Finishes the same as the taste. Makes me think of a pre-prohibition lager. Not awful, but certainly not the best.

name: Dominion Lager
review: From old tasting notes. Amber gold color. Bubbly white head. Light fragrant hop nose. Zesty toasted malt flavor. Some spicy hop flavor in middle. Dry bitter hop finish.

name: Dominion Lager
review: Draft. Clear golden color with a white head. Light malt aroma with caramel notes. Slight bitterness.

name: Dominion Lager
review: Appearance: Clear brown, some light tan head. Aroma: Malt, caramel. Taste: Malt, caramel? Sweet. Smooth, nice. Bought: Old Dominion (Dulles Airport), 414 ml, $7.50 Info: 18/9-2015

name: Dominion Lager
review: A gift from a really good friend whom is part of a beer of the month club, I tasted pear and apple, I didn’t taste any alcohol.

name: Dominion Lager
review: Gran aroma. Clear yellow, some arty hops but that s about it. Very mellow not too much but drinkable cold. Ok.

name: Dominion Lager
review: Malty with burnt caramel. No nose to speak of. Decent enough but not worth revisiting. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Dominion Lager
review: Bottle with bottling date July 23rd, 2007. Very syrupy smell. Muddy yellow colour, some black residue on the bottom. Mostly tastes like butter. Some hoppy notes to be noticed, but this one was rather clearly spoiled. Giving an average rating for now.

name: Dominion Lager
review: Keg at Jake’s place. Pours clear golden yellow, taste is cold, dry, light toffee malt.

name: Dominion Lager
review: Actually a strong, good lager with good malt and some nice hops. Pours amber with good head and lacing. Finishes with a little bitterness, good balance. Finishes with light bitterness. Comes together with good balance. Pleasantly surprised here. On tap at DC Summerfest.

name: Dominion Lager
review: Tap. Clear deep nice golden yellow with a fluffy white head. Light grassy hops, dough, and a hint of malty sweetness. Flavor is very similar. Mostly clean with crackers and light grassy hops. Lighter to medium body. Not bad, but far from a great lager.

name: Stoudts Blonde Double Mai-bock
review: Poured into a sample glass. Nose is very faint (sweetness). Expert appearance of filtered, golden brew. Very smooth, honey and malt overtones. Smooth and clean. Nose prevents a much higher score. Cheers!

name: Stoudts Blonde Double Mai-bock
review: Bottle - from sampler pack. Dark golden color - clear. Clean, malty aroma. Sweet and malty. Doesnt taste like a 7% beer.

name: Stoudts Blonde Double Mai-bock
review: Sampled from a 22 oz brown bottle this beer poured a cloudy orange color with a bunch of chunks and a huge foamy orange-white head that left good lacing. The aroma was sweet and yeasty with sugar and golden fruit. The flavor was sweet, tangy and yeasty with strong golden fruits. Long finish. Moderately full bodied. Excellent.

name: Stoudts Blonde Double Mai-bock
review: strong malt aroma. golden in color with nice head. flavor is malty, slight roastyness, finishes with slight hoppyness

name: Stoudts Blonde Double Mai-bock
review: Bottle shared thanks to jdb288! Pours a hazy golden orange with thin bubbly white head that leaves light lace. Aroma of of grapefruit overt bready pale malt and fruity yeast. Taste is more toward the malt, bready and easy for the alcohol. Better than I was expecting.

name: Stoudts Blonde Double Mai-bock
review: Poured from bottle into a pint glass Appearance – The beer pours a nice clear amber color with a one finger head of just off-white foam. The head has a good level of retention, slowly fading to leave a moderate level of lace on the sides of the glass. Smell – The aroma of the beer is quite heavy of a sweet and malty smell with lots of fruit of peach and apricot as well as a bit of toffee and some biscuit and bready malt smells. Along with these aromas are some lighter citrus and earthy hop mixed with just a hint of lemon. Taste – The taste begins with a quite bready and sweet flavor with the sweet being a mix of the lighter fruits that were detected in the nose (peach and apricot). A little bit of orange and grape work their way onto the tongue more toward the middle of the taste, with them being joined by a somewhat grainy flavor. Toward the end, the apricot and peach really intensify and mix with a little amount of an earthy hop flavor and some light hay, leaving a nice fruity sweet and bready flavor to linger on the tongue. Mouthfeel – The body of the beer is on the average to slightly lower side for a maibock of 7.0 % abv. with a carbonation level that is average. Overall a little thicker body may have been better for the heavy sweet and malty flavors of the brew, but overall the feel was alright. Overall – A very easy drinking maibock at 7.0 % abv. with a nice big sweet and bready taste. Well worth a try.

name: Stoudts Blonde Double Mai-bock
review: Bomber. Nose is clean, golden sunshine with a little cracker and caramel, noble hops, sunny citrus. Pours orange with above-avg carb and a dense, rocky beige head. Taste is pleasantly sweet with caramel, crackery, and a nice sugary doughy cookie character, just really well-developed malt all around. Hops are juicy lemony citrus with floral nobility, and only somewhat subordinate, and very lightly spicy. Fresh, clean medium-full body, a lot of interest in the mouthfeel (very ’swishable’). No alcohol, refreshing and not too heavy, and free of the boozy-type flaws that plague almost all American attempts at this style. I’ve missed you, Stoudt’s, you do things right. [3.9] Even better at volume! Just perfect. Wow! [4.2]

name: Stoudts Blonde Double Mai-bock
review: Bottle at home from backlog notes 07. Pours a clear golden color with a medium sized white head. The aroma and flavor have sweeter cookie like malts, light caramel, grass, honey, a mild citrus, nose was lighter and more difficult to discern.

name: Stoudts Blonde Double Mai-bock
review: rich malt flavor. a alcohol note. beautiful clear rich amber/gold color. quite bitter in the finish. slight sweetness underneath. brewed with honey, but i didn’t detect and appreciable honey flavor. this is really good, but a little too bitter for my taste for a maibock. then again, if it weren’t so bitter it might appear to be too sweet, so, i’ll opt for too bitter over too sweet every time.

name: Stoudts Blonde Double Mai-bock
review: Nose is honey, doughy malt, some rich dark fruits. Almost barleywine esque. Flavor is doughy malt, honey, light crackery malt, some root/herbal qualities.

name: Stoudts Scarlet Lady Ale ESB
review: Had this one several times over the years. Malty nose and a good, mahogany color and thin head. Decent lacing, too. Malt is the dominant flavor, but a bitter bite is well balanced at the end. Quality brew. Cheers!

name: Stoudts Scarlet Lady Ale ESB
review: From old tasting notes. Bright amber orange color. Bubbly beige head. Fruity toasted malt nose is complex and spicy. Bittersweet toasted malt flavor. Complex and spicy with hints of peppercorns and allspice. Dry hop finish.

name: Stoudts Scarlet Lady Ale ESB
review: Reddish amber pour, clear with white foam. The hops and malt are both light and slightly grassy. The body is light as is the fizz. Slightly sharp notes, but easy to drink. July 2008

name: Stoudts Scarlet Lady Ale ESB
review: backlog, Tap, copper color with a medium beige head. Notes are malt, dry fruit, nuts, and light toffee. Finish has some pine and roast. Light to medium bodied ESB from Stoudts.

name: Stoudts Scarlet Lady Ale ESB
review: Poured from a 12 OZ bottle into a pint glass. Appearance- the color is a reddish amber with a medium sized white head. Aroma- full of malt and bread. Taste- malt and a mild hop finish. Overall, a real good ESB

name: Stoudts Scarlet Lady Ale ESB
review: Appearance: Ruby Brown. Aroma: Tart bitter malt. Caramel. Taste: Bitter malt. Tart sour notes. Mild caramel. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Stoudts Scarlet Lady Ale ESB
review: As far as English Style Bitter’s go, this beer isn’t bad. It is just sweet enough and has just a tad of hop bitter to it; so basically it is easily quaffable and would be welcome any time I need a refreshing beer. There is no unpleasant aftertaste. There is nothing wrong with this beer, it is a decent ESB. But of course if I wanted to drink an interesting beer this would not be my choice as it just doesn’t hold up to the stronger styles.

name: Stoudts Scarlet Lady Ale ESB
review: More sour than bitter. Pales in comparison to today’s hoppy offerings. Not for me.

name: Stoudts Scarlet Lady Ale ESB
review: Deep Amber brown with foamy tan head; aroma is malt forward sweet; flava us rich blend if sweet malt with hoppy and spicy herbal notes units of cinnamon and caramel ; feels medium smooth (on cask) finishes slightly tangy and dry hop spice notes

name: Stoudts Scarlet Lady Ale ESB
review: This wasn’t one of my favorites from Stoudts, but I am not the biggest fans of extra bitters. The hops are the main theme going on, with of course, an extra bitter aftertaste. It is still a smooth, crisp beer....on the lighter side overall. Dark orange-light copper color. Better than average, but pretty much an across the board 7.

name: Stoudts Fat Dog Stout (Vintages through 2003)
review: From old tasting notes. Opaque black brown color. Small tan head. Soft roasty malt nose. Bittersweet roasted malt flavor hints at espresso and bittersweet chocolate. Dry hop finish. Long bitter aftertaste.

name: Stoudts Fat Dog Stout (Vintages through 2003)
review: Nice black pour in glass. Nose and taste is roasted malt, creams, molasses, beet sugars. Rated 6/17/02

name: Stoudts Fat Dog Stout (Vintages through 2003)
review: 2002 Bottle. Wow, great flavors and no oxidation. Held up so well for the age and abv. Nice roasted malts, light cream. Nice body with little lacing. Aroma is sweet and balanced with roasted malts and a little sweetness, molasses. Flavor is smooth and very drinkable. I may even prefer this one over the newer batches.

name: Stoudts Fat Dog Stout (Vintages through 2003)
review: 750ml bottle from 10-23-03. Pours a dark coffee brown with a small tan head. Lots of chocolate on the nose with light oxidation present. Flavor and palate were both quite light and thin for this beer, mostly chocolate with light toasted malts.

name: Stoudts Fat Dog Stout (Vintages through 2003)
review: bottled 10/23/03 - drank on 7/5/09. Nose was dominated by chocolate. A rough poor left a dark brown beer with a thin tan head. Taste was bog on dark chocolate, some dark fruits, and finishes surprisingly boozy with nice bourbon warmth.

name: Stoudts Fat Dog Stout (Vintages through 2003)
review: Bottle shared by Trevor, thanks man, Vintage 2002. Pours a deep black body with a tan head. Rich and subtle but dry roasty chocolate. Licorice. Pretty much no oxidation and this held up dam well for a 6% brew!

name: Dominion Stout
review: From old tasting notes. Translucent brown color. Brief tan head. Soft chocolate malt aroma. Roasted malt flavor is on the light side and hints at cocoa and cinnamon. On the light side, this is more like a porter than a stout.

name: Dominion Stout
review: At the Dominion Taproom at Dulles airport 9/12/2012. Near black in colour with a hint of red and slight, off-white head. Light, roasted malt aroma with some milk chocolate. Flavours of powdered chocolate, prunes and caramel with a dryish finish. Fine.

name: Dominion Stout
review: pretty decent stout very dark and decently sweet, pours an off white creamy head.

name: Dominion Stout
review: Dominion Stout--2000 12 oz. Bottle. 4.70% ABV. 22 IBU’s. (3.75 / 5.0) Clear rich dark red black color. Richly roasted malty front with light espresso toffee chocolate flavor and burnt taste. Light body is easy to savor and compliments rich flavor. Sipping brew. Sampled 7/3/2000. Dominion Stout--2003 12 oz. Bottle. 4.70% ABV. 40 IBU’s. (4.0 / 5.0) Malt of the Earth Beer of the Month Club Selection. Clear thin dark black red color. Light head & lace. Mild cocoa espresso hop front. Thin creamy cocoa caramel mild sweet fruit body. Crusty doughy toasted notes. Clean chalky mild hop spice end. Sampled 4/17/2003.

name: Dominion Stout
review: Date: 10/01/1995 Mode: Draft Source: Capitol City, DC black, whispy head, rich sweet chocolate aroma, rich chocolate flavor with lots of sweetness and a slight amount of roasted flavor, ever so slight bitter aftertaste strong coffee aroma/flavor Aroma: 8/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 16/20 Rating: 3.7/5.0 Score: ***/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

name: Dominion Stout
review: Once bottled, draught only product now found on tap at the brewpub. The recipe has been tweaked over the years, and this is the base beer for Oak Barrel Stout. Five malts are used in the brewing of this beer, including two row pale, carapils, chocolate, caramel, malted wheat, and an addition of roasted barley which is not malted. This beer is hopped with two varieties, Perle and Willamette. That is an awful lot of flavor packed into a 4.7% abv brew, and makes for a truly fantastic stout to drink on any number of occasions. Dominion Stout pours to an opaque ink black color with a thick and creamy tan head, and a soft carbonation. The nose is very inviting on this beer. Very robust aromas of dark chocolate, coffee, sweet malt, and slight grassy hop aroma floods the nose. The palate is very soft and full with lots of big malt flavors. Sweet malt, chocolate, caramel, and coffee flavors marry with a slight bit of roast. Dominion Stout finishes with a delicious creamy, silky chocolate/coffee flavor up front, and ends with just a touch of roasty flavor, and enough hop bitterness as to make this beer not too cloying.

name: Dominion Stout
review: Thanks to Argo. 2003 bottled. Nasty nasty stuff. Completely skunked. I hope this isn’t what it’s supposed to taste like.

name: Dominion Stout
review: A pleasant if only mild stout. Very creamy with some pleasant vanilla overtones.

name: Dominion Stout
review: Appearance: deep and dark, practically black, under a short filmy brownish head. Aroma: espresso bitterness marks the olfactory aura, joined by pitch and tar and a bit of anise, but mildly. Taste: full-bodied, rich, malty, a bit sweet, but also with sufficient bitterness, a tiny touch of hops. Dark, complex and tasty, yes, but never quitting with the bitter, roasty feel. Could’ve done with some more in the mouthfeel, though, some power on the palate, a fling with creamy texture, or a dalliance with lush malt. This stout unfortunately falls short, in terms of what I’m yearning for with this style, more fruity, too, would be nice, but a greater cocoa feel is greatly missing. I’ve got to say I’m a bit disappointed in this stout, and I’m glad I’ve got some preferable versions handy in the fridge.

name: Dominion Stout
review: Pours black with a light brown head. Taste is of coffee and chocolate malt. Mouthfeel is a bit watery. Considering how good Dominion’s other brews are, this one is very boring and non-distinctive. Not bad, but not recommended either.

name: Dominion Black & Tan
review: Very dark maroon, 6 bubble head, yet very effervescent. Aroma of roasted coffee. Very thin. Not complex. I had to taste it 3 times before I could remember it enough to write down my impression.

name: Dominion Black & Tan
review: Pours deep chocolate brown. Medium creamy coffe colored head. Slight lacing. Smells of coffee, flowery hops and carmelized malts. First sip, mild chocolate, leading into a bland middle with a finish reminiscent of the oak barrell stout. A touch of hops, choclate and coffee with a side of allchohol. The feeling is light and very watery, not much texture and the carbonation seems to overpower a bit. If the excellent finish was brought forward this could be a much better black and tan.

name: Dominion Black & Tan
review: Draft at Dulles. This to me seemd like a watered down version of the stout; which I really enjoy. The Ale just did not add much and in fact detracted. Definitely have the stout over this.

name: Dominion Black & Tan
review: On tap at the brewpub on 7/16/06: Pours a clear dark mahogany with a nicely-lacing off-white head. Aroma has a nice light toasty caramel sweetness with a touch of piny hoppiness. Body starts with a pleasant earthy sweet caramel maltiness, nicely-balanced with an earthy, mildly bitter hoppiness and toasty cookie dough flavor.

name: Dominion Black & Tan
review: A deep red beer with a thin beige head. The aroma is sweet malty with light notes of caramel. The flavor is sweet with notes of roasted malt, and oatmeal, leading to a dry roasted end.

name: Dominion Black & Tan
review: Just an average black and tan, had this a few times both on tap and in bottles. Dark body, cream head. Smells of chocolate and coffe, taste is same, but rather non-descript. In many ways could be considered old-school with no dynamics.

name: Dominion Black & Tan
review: 22oz draft at Dulles airport during layover. No head, burnt notes on the nose, grassy then licorice on the tongue. Forgettable.

name: Dominion Black & Tan
review: Draught at Old Dominion for breakfast - RBSG DC 06 Brown/black, light head and lacing. Nose of light hop, plenty of roast and sweet malt. Not too exciting. Light vanilla and grass maybe. The finish is moderate.

name: Dominion Black & Tan
review: Deep red body with a large off-white head. Light roasted malt aroma. Sweet heavy chocolate flavor with some roasted malt hints.

name: Dominion Black & Tan
review: On tap at OD Brewpub. Dark clear reddish brown with a small beige head. Roastiness, chocolate and a hint of grass in the nose. Feels like a porter. Roasted malt, caramel, chocolate and plenty of hop bitterness. Well rounded. Medium body, moderate to light carbonation. I was never a big fan of black and tans but this one was pretty solid.

name: Dominion Ale
review: Draft pour at the Hyattsville location. The beer is a clear amber color with a beige head of foam. The aroma is moderately sweet and malty. The finish has a bit of a bitter aspect to it. Medium body and medium carbonation.

name: Dominion Ale
review: Flasche in einer Bar am Flughafen DC Dulles. Bernstein Farbe, Strich fester Schaum. Klar. Aroma wie Geschmack nicht sonderlich ausgeprägt: Malz, Karamell. Wässrig

name: Dominion Ale
review: Draft at IAD. Pours clear amber with a fizzy off white head. Tastes like citrus hops, grapefruit, bready malt, grassy. Light/medium body and carbonation. Smells malty, like caramel, citrus hops, some grapefruit and resin.

name: Dominion Ale
review: Gentle all around ale with a good balance between malt and hops. Clean and without strong aromas or flavors.

name: Dominion Ale
review: Daughter in pentagon city. Poured moderate amber brown. Strong malty notes, medium bodied. Not a bad session amber.

name: Dominion Ale
review: Draft at BonChon Chicken in Centreville, VA as Bonchon Ale. Pours an amber/copper brown color with half a finger of off-white head. Light lacing. Aromas of sweet fruit, light citrus. Tasting notes of sweet malt, bitter piney hops, toast, citrus. Medium body with a dry finish. Medium carbonation.

name: Dominion Ale
review: Bottle->SA. Medium copper with small creamy white head. A: roasted and sweet malt, hint of hops. T: sweet malts, grains. Plain, dull.

name: Dominion Ale
review: Appearance: Brown, cloudy, some off-tan head. Aroma: Hops, some malt and roasted. Taste: More hops than malt. Roasted. Info: 473ml draught, 30/8-2013

name: Dominion Ale
review: Bottle. Light amber color with a white head. Malty aromas with sweet caramel, fruit, nuts and hops. Easy to drink with you want something light.

name: Dominion Ale
review: On tap at Harry’s Dulles as Harry’s Amber Ale. Bold amber body with thick head. Nose is roasty, hoppy and sweet. Taste is roast with malts and some happier notes too. Quite nice.

name: Stoudts Scotch Style Ale
review: Very good, smooth, but not quite as smooth as I would hope/expect for this style and from Stoudt’s. I really like this, just not quite as much as a couple other Scotch Ales. And, the large bottle is pretty pricey for not being phenomenal.

name: Stoudts Scotch Style Ale
review: Bottle aged for more than five years. Big malt, malty aroma, peat in the finish. Very smooth and drinkable.

name: Stoudts Scotch Style Ale
review: 650 ml bottle thanks to someone at the tasting 1/23/10 at Eric’s. Pours a dark brown color with a medium white head. A rich malty scotch ale nose, earthy and light chocolates. A smooth flavor; a well-done scotch ale, smooth rich malts, earthy, lots of sweet chocolates and fruity musty malts. Very easygoing and tasty. Nice.

name: Stoudts Scotch Style Ale
review: Skyview Tasting 2.5. Dark red color with a large head. Roasty and chocolatey aroma. Slightly sweet, syrupy taste along with malt. A bit of the ocean &#40salt&#41.

name: Stoudts Abbey Double
review: From old tasting notes. Labeled as "Cuvée NotreDame Belgian Style Abbey Double". Hazy reddish brown color. Creamy beige head. Soft fruity candy-like malt nose. Tangy fruity malt flavor hints at prunes and currants. There’s an underlying yeastiness that imparts a uniqueness to this ale. Very good indeed. Nice Belgian lace.

name: Stoudts Abbey Double
review: Pours a deep dark brown with a nice tan foamy head. Aroma of dark fruits, plums raisins. Taste is nicely carbonated, spicy, malty. Full body. A nice Belgian abbey style ale.

name: Stoudts Abbey Double
review: Tap from just a small sampler (2oz?). The most obvious quality to me was how much this reminded me of a tripel; plum and raisin, sure, but general maltiness with honey on top and much more in the way of phenolic overtones. Mahogany pour, medium body, nice and a touch spicy.

name: Stoudts Abbey Double
review: 12 oz glass off of tap...Large light brown head that dies quickly. Hazy brown with a red hue. Malty somewhat buttery nose that was originally sour, as it warmed it made for some pleasent changes. Medium body, good mouthfeel, creamy texture. Good malt flavor, Fruity, yeasty , spiceyness all work well together. a "multi-colored " beer , appearing lighter in color towards the bottom of the glass. Mid hops, with a fizzy carbonation. Had a "home brewish" taste to it.

name: Stoudts Abbey Double
review: shared @jtc’s-750 bottle-pours dark brown with a tan head. Aroma is medium malt-toffee/cocoa, some spice. Taste is medium malt-toffee/cocoa, 2nd spice hops.

name: Stoudts Abbey Double
review: Bottle shared by Jcwattsrugger. Pours dark brown with tan head. Nose/taste of toffee, caramel, plum, raisin, dark fruit and bready malts. Medium body.

name: Stoudts Abbey Double
review: 7050. Pours an amber brune body with a tan head. Dark fruit, plum and raisins, malty tawny caramel and a light woodiness. Dried fruit and a lush malty warming body. Nice brew.

name: Stoudts Abbey Double
review: 750 ml bottle that I have had for several years - I’m not sure of the age of the bottle. Pours a crystal clear deep red with a moderate, sudsy off-white head that is initially more reminiscent of the head on a glass of Coca Cola than anything else. The head quickly settles into an incomplete film and leaves a partial coating on the glass. Pleasant aroma of malt and brown sugar. The flavor is malty and a bit richer than the aroma suggests, but with none of the brown sugar sweetness. Fairly smooth with just a hint of alcohol at the very end. One of the better offerings I have had from this brewer.

name: Stoudts Abbey Double
review: An ’01 vintage bottle. Vinous. Possibly from its superannuation? Rather sour. But the other flavors poked through.

name: Stoudts Abbey Double
review: Very nice authentic Dubbel. Primarily a malty flavor but dubbel fruit tones come make their presence known in the aroma. Sampled at Stoudts 17th Annual Microfest: June 2008

name: Stoudts Triple
review: This Belgian Abbey-Style Ale is very smooth wirh a great pallet. Make sure when you pour it in a glass that you leave the last inch of liquid in the bottle. The reason for this is so you can get all the full flavor from the un filtered sediment. When about an inch is left roll the bottle on it's side rhen swirl in the bottle and top your glass with all the great flavor many leave behind.

name: Stoudts Triple
review: 12oz bottle pours a golden color with a bit of head. Alcohol hotness. Mild Belgian yeast fruitiness.

name: Stoudts Triple
review: Cloudy, dark amber with quick white foam. Sweet nose with touches of pepper and coriander. Medium body. The taste balances the sweet and spice initially, but as it warms the malts become more pronounced as does the ABV. The finish is a little heavily sweet. tongue.

name: Stoudts Triple
review: Backlog, Hazy orange gold color with a small to medium white head. Nose is apples, plums, belgian yeast, and molasses. Flavor is clove, wood, dark fruit, and orange skins. Very sticky and sweet for the most part. Not my favorite.

name: Stoudts Triple
review: Pours a pale hazy golden yellow color. Aromas of yeast, some hops and spice. Taste is yeasty and hops.

name: West Virginia Blackwater Stout
review: Enjoyed at the brewpub in Morgantown, it’s 4.8% abv. This sessionable stout is fine, it’s a dark brown with some head. Coffee in the nose. In the taste, I get more chocolate than coffee. On the malty side.

name: West Virginia Blackwater Stout
review: Last and best of the beers I tried 5/10/08. Black with creamy tan head. Aroma is sweet and medium malty. Flavor is sweet, with a hint of roasted malt. Medium-bodied, and very smooth and creamy. Enjoyable

name: West Virginia Blackwater Stout
review: My first impression is that someone collected the water used to put the campfire out and served it up in a stout glass. Very smoky and I love it. Nothing wishy washy about this brew it comes straight at you.

name: West Virginia Blackwater Stout
review: Sample at the brewpub. This brew pours a flat black color with a medium beige head that burns away steadily. Rings of lacing on the glass. Roasty aroma of coffee and milk chocolate with hops and malt in the background. Medium-bodied and smooth with a roasted coffee character, along with some chocolate and burnt malt. The finish is toasty with a mild coffee aftertaste that lingers a bit. Above average overall.

name: West Virginia Blackwater Stout
review: 11/1/07 - Sample at brewpub. Dark black w/ red tones. Roasted malt. Smooth. A bit of raisin and plum. Crisp finish. Normal stout, which isn’t bad. It’s done well. Good stuff.

name: West Virginia Blackwater Stout
review: Universally a good example of this style. Pitch black. Very little head, just a girdle around the inside edge of the glass. Can’t smell much, the aroma is well behaved. Flat like a nitro beer on the palate. Not like imp stout in any fashion. Lighter than an Irish Dry. Fine lacing and legs on this beast. Building back of throat bitterness like I just ate some charred grill meat.

name: West Virginia Blackwater Stout
review: Date: 07/24/2006 Mode: Growler Source: Tasting black, thin fine tan head, touch of lace, roasted malt aroma, creamy body, roasted and chocolate flavor, Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 11/20 Rating: 3.1/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **/4

name: West Virginia Blackwater Stout
review: Sampled in mid-July 2006 from a growler courtesy of hopscotch, left over from the RBSG: Pours an opaque black with a frothy, wispy-lacing light tan head. Sweet sugary dark caramel malty aroma has some roasted smoky notes and hints of salty black olives. Starts with some sugary dark malty sweetness and a touch of dark fruits with a lingering roasty smokiness in the finish. A decent stout and quite drinkable.

name: West Virginia Blackwater Stout
review: Big thanks to hopscotch for sending me a Growler from a new state for me! Poured a deep black with an averaged sized (first pour was huge) light brown head. Nice looking. Aromas of roast, chocolate, vanilla, and coffee. I liked the aroma. Tastes of chocolate, vanilla, and roast. Tastes a bit of a let down compared to the aroma. Thin and creamy body. Nice lacing left on the glass.

name: West Virginia Blackwater Stout
review: Semi-opaque coffee color, lacy camel head. Milky, coal tar and coffee aroma. Creosote and char, medium light sweetness, a certain dustiness. Green nuts towards the finish. Finishes with light astringency and acidity, but doesn’t cling. Pretty good.

name: West Virginia Appalachian Ale
review: some sweetness with a nutty flavor and a hoppy citrus and pine presence tempered with a substantial fresh from the farm malt character. vibrant carbonation makes it great for whenever you want to cool off. deep amber color adds intrigue.

name: West Virginia Appalachian Ale
review: My friend Big D turned me onto this brewery about a year ago. I had to drink another before rating the beer, and I saw this bottle at vintage Estates, I had to pick one up. The last time I tasted this beer it was flat and skunked. But this bottle was fresh, and this was a decent beer. I liked the hoppy flavor, surprised from a small brewery and this style, and balanced with a nutty slight bitter finish. Decent CO2, I guess I am going to have to try a few more from this brewery. Are you in Dennis?

name: West Virginia Appalachian Ale
review: Sample at the brewpub. This brew is a dark amber color with a thin light beige head that recedes quickly. Spotty lace from top to bottom. Light malty aroma with touches of fruit and hops. Medium, smooth body with flavors of malt and caramel predominantly. Bits of citrus and hops here and there as well. The finish is sweet and malty with a sweet aftertaste. Slightly above average overall.

name: West Virginia Appalachian Ale
review: On tap. Brown with a decent size tan head. Aroma is light, caramel, a bit nutty. Solid flavor.

name: West Virginia Appalachian Ale
review: On tap at Bar 101 in Charleston. Seems much more like a very malty pale ale, or IPA than a "Brown Ale". It poured a nice reddish brown with a slightly hoppy aroma. Flavor was strongly hops, with a bit of a sweet malty finish. Overall, not bad. For WV brews, I’ll take just about anything from Mountaineer over this though.

name: West Virginia Appalachian Ale
review: Enjoyed on tap at the brewpub. Like a red, only maltier like a brown. Pink reddish colour with some head and lace. Hops there as well as malt. Above average carbonation that was higher than needed. 5.2% abv. The one I liked the most for drinkability and balance.

name: West Virginia Appalachian Ale
review: Pretty good amber, but not great. Nutty as you might expect, slightly hoppy. Not terribly strong flavor.

name: West Virginia Appalachian Ale
review: 2nd one on tap night before we moved Kara from WVU. Dark amber beer. Some sweetness up front then a bitter bite at the end. Not as refreshing.

name: West Virginia Appalachian Ale
review: 11/107 - Sample at brewpub. Dark amber color. Nose is a bit of hops. Nice malt backbone, touch of roasted malt, carmel. Good hop prescence, floral and citrus. . A touch of earthy bitter aftertaste. This is a very good flagship beer. Let’s go, Mountaineers! Could definately have a bunch on a gameday.

name: West Virginia Appalachian Ale
review: I don’t beleive this to be a brown ale, way too many hops for that, but it was a decent beer nonetheless from a very small brewpub.

name: West Virginia Grist Mill Wheat
review: Sample at the brewpub. Pours a cloudy yellowish color with a thin and wispy off-white head that disappears quickly. Spotty lacing on the glass. Fruity aroma with notes of wheat. Thin-bodied with a fruity character and flavors of mild wheat and spices. The finish is wheat and banana and does not have much of an aftertaste. Slightly below average overall.

name: West Virginia Grist Mill Wheat
review: Enjoyed on-tap at the Morgantown brewpub, this is an American wheat and not a hefeweizen. 5.4% abv. A wheaty fruty aroma. Grapefruit coloured with near zero head. Its sourness malted down for drinkability. It has above average carbonation, and some odd water as if warning me the water is safe to drink but not tasty.

name: West Virginia Grist Mill Wheat
review: My 800th rating! Go me!... Murky pear juice color. Quickly diminishing white head. The nose is of yeast, clove and lemon. Well-balanced flavor. Spicy, but too thin. Light-bodied with a slightly creamy mouthfeel and soft carbonation. Short, crisp, clean finish.

name: West Virginia Grist Mill Wheat
review: Light fruity aroma, nice cloudy color, fair citrus and banana flavor. Refreshing. I'd drink it again, yep.

name: West Virginia Cheat Mountain Gold
review: Enjoyed this beer many of times at C.J. Maggies in Elkins, WV. Worked at a research forest in Cassity, WV. Beautiful gold color with a sweet and light taste of hops.

name: West Virginia Cheat Mountain Gold
review: Pint at the Brewpub. Poured a transparent golden color. Very light, very clear. Aroma was pretty much non-existant. Flavor.....very light. Lightly sweet, but not in a malty way. No hop flavor at all. Absolutely no bitterness. Crisp though. Overall....not great. Probably the worst WV Brewed beer that I’ve had. Not to say it was BAD. Just not something I’d try again.

name: West Virginia Cheat Mountain Gold
review: Sample at the brewpub. This beer is a pale yellow-gold color with a thin and fizzy white head that diminishes quickly. Spotty lacing. Weak hops and bready malt in the nose. Light-bodied with flavors of grain, malt and light hops. The finish is lightly hopped and short. Typical half-assed gateway beer for macro drinkers, barely average.

name: West Virginia Cheat Mountain Gold
