review: After a night of packing up Kara’s things to bring her home from WVU we stopped over for a few beers and this was the 1st one I tried. It was a light crisp golden ale as they say. Had a touch of honey sweetness and a tiny bit of hops. Very refreshing.

name: West Virginia Cheat Mountain Gold
review: 11/1/07 - Light yellow color. No discernable nose. Nice light lager. Not much to write home about. A touch of skunky mustiness. Crisp hop finish. Corn and malt, a bit of bitter finish. Good overall.

name: West Virginia Cheat Mountain Gold
review: Nothing special at all. Very sweet cream ale with a hint of hops kicked in at the end.

name: West Virginia Cheat Mountain Gold
review: Lighter than normal clear yellow color. Mild hay or sour grass aroma. Very Clean. Good carbonation. No detectable bitterness. Almost has the consistency of west Virginia spring water. Very enjoyable and easy to drink. A great session brew. Has some interesting mild erthy tones in the background. Finish is well mannered and un assuming. Nice.

name: West Virginia Cheat Mountain Gold
review: Very malty, *beer* aroma with light whiskey notes. Tangy, cereal, nicely hopped. Lightly sweet, but mostly crisp and crackery. Good CO2. Good light brewpub offering. The pub has changed hands recently, and the lite offering is often the bellweather for the brews to follow, so this appears to be a good sign, given the style.

name: West Virginia Cheat Mountain Gold
review: West Virginians are VERY lucky to have this little low-hopped gem in their midst. Cheat Mountain breaks the often over-hopped microbrew mold with a bold maltiness and light carbonation and only the lightest of hop touches. Very similar to Belgium’s Primus. I’d consider it one of the top 10 lager-type beers I have ever had, "and I’ve had them all over the woild" (apologies to Irving Woltz of the Godfather).

name: West Virginia Cheat Mountain Gold
review: Looks and tastes like all the other "freebie" swill lagers I drank throughout the day while attending a couple tailgates before the WVU football game. Not good. Hard to believe it’s an ale as it has all the characteristics of a pale lager. This brewery is going downhill fast.

name: West Virginia Neds Pale Ale
review: just a nice american pale ale. good body and mouthfeel substantial as it is in flavors of pine flower and citrus hops combined with a good sweet and earth like malt that is caramel like in character. nicely bitter and refreshingly so. nice ipa like aroma of hops with just a certain german like spiciness to it. american traditional yet demonstrative. GOOD.

name: West Virginia Neds Pale Ale
review: On Tap at the Brew Pub. Pour was a nice copper amber. Aroma was nice and hoppy. As was the flavor. Good, bittersweet malt flavor. This is how you make a pale ale. Although more like an IPA. Still, delicious. My face lit up at first taste because some of what I’ve had from WVBC has been mediocre. This is not. This is top shelf. Nice.

name: West Virginia Neds Pale Ale
review: Enjoyed on-tap at the Morgantown brewpub. Good C-hop aroma, its 5.8% abv. Good bitterness, some would and used to call this an IPA. Drinkable and satisfying although nothing out of the ordinary.

name: West Virginia Neds Pale Ale
review: 3rd beer had night before bringing Kara home from WVU. Plenty of hops in the aroma. Starts off semi sweet and hoppy. Ends very hoppy.

name: West Virginia Neds Pale Ale
review: Pours a dark copper color. Aroma is a bit bland with some hops. Flavor is a bit fruity with a nice hop punch, almost an IPA.

name: West Virginia Neds Pale Ale
review: Sample at the brewpub. This beer pours a clear amber color with a minimal white head that evaporates pretty quickly. Thin top ring of lacing with spots underneath. Hops and citrus in the nose. Medium-bodied and moderately hoppy with just a bit of bready malt and caramel for balance. The finish is citrus and hops and leaves a lightly bitter aftertaste. A little unbalanced but decent.

name: West Virginia Neds Pale Ale
review: 11/1/07 - Sample at brewpub. Light amber color. Solid carmal and raisin/plum malt backbone with cascade/chinook hops. Fruit and floral popping in the mouth. Crisp finish. If not the best by WV, only the Appy ale comes close. Good beer.

name: West Virginia Neds Pale Ale
review: Floral hops aroma but not pine. Smells like IPA and looks like IPA. Rather clear. Somewhat like a lighter IPA impact but that is only on the beginning. Starts off fruity then it takes a while to morph into an offensive IPA blast. Perhaps a little lighter than many IPA. Not quite as mediciny as I expected. Lingering bitter finish that hangs for a while.

name: West Virginia Neds Pale Ale
review: Name: Ned’s Pale Ale Date: 07/15/2006 Mode: Growler Source: Tasting, RBSG, 2006 clear amber, headless, sweet citrus aroma, unbalanced with just abit of dry carmel malt flavor to go with lots of lingering bitterness in the finish, Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.9/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **/4

name: West Virginia Neds Pale Ale
review: Another thanks to eagle for stopping on his way through WV for this one. Poured an orange color with small head and almost no lacing. Aroma was very grassy and earthy. Flavor was of dirt some malts and a little lemon/citrus. Not a bad beer at all.

name: West Virginia Pillow Rock Pilsner
review: 11/1/07 - Sample at brewpub. Gold color. Good, solid malt character. Nice hoppiness, crisp, floral and earthy. Finish is clean. Good beer.

name: West Virginia Pillow Rock Pilsner
review: Very pale, straw-colored lager. Nice lacing. Lightly floral with butterscotch and honey in the aroma. Well-balanced and well-bittered flavor. Butterscotch, black pepper and woodsy notes. Light-bodied with a watery mouthfeel and lively carbonation. Short, crisp, bitter finish.

name: West Virginia Pillow Rock Pilsner
review: (Sampled at the Armory Tavern, Harpers Ferry, WV) This was very nice. Big saaz nose mixed with pils malt. The body was firm and malty with just enough hops to keep you thirsty. Good long malty/hoppy finish. A baby Tuppers Pils.

name: West Virginia Bowden Bitter
review: I had a bitter by this brewing company at the Penn Brewery festival on June 4. I can only assume that this was the beer as it’s the only Bitter they brew. It sucked. Maybe those good old boys grow their own hops down there and tweak them a little. The flavor was overwhelming alright, if it was hops, but I’d never tasted anything like it. You could’nt call it a good flavor either. It was the only beer I poured out that day.

name: West Virginia Oktoberfest
review: 11/1/07 - sample at brewpub. Carmel with a very little roast. Muddled hop finihsh. Soapy - tannic finish w/ the hops. Ok, not bad.

name: West Virginia Oktoberfest
review: Rating #300... Pretty good lager. It was quite smokey in the taproom and the beer was about 15 degrees too cold, but hey, it’s a lager sooo... The aroma was moderately malty, but due to the temperature of the beer and especially the cigarette smoke in my face, that’s about all I could get out of the nose. Probably not fair to the beer, but it gets low marks for aroma. Sparkling clear Copper. The color of a freshly minted penny. Large, frothy white head. Quickly and entirely diminishing. Malty flavor. Nicely hopped. Perfectly balanced. Not sweet at all. Light to medium-bodied. Fizzy. Watery mouthfeel. Crisp, dry finish. Not a bad beer, but I’ve had better Octoberfests.

name: West Virginia Hoppy Hippie
review: Damned if I know where they came up with this name, but it's a huge misnomer. Cloudy red/brown, with medium beige head. Aroma is moderately sweet and malty. Taste is along the lines of a Scottish Ale -- it's a bit on the sweet side, but not too bad. What bitterness there is is limited to the back of the throat into the swallow. Unimpressive beer.

name: West Virginia Hoppy Hippie
review: This beer rocks. Don''t let the name fool you. This is not an acutely hopped beer. Very rich and Malty, but not sweet. Lightly carbonated (very much like a cask-conditioned beer). Oily mouthfeel. Well balanced. Dry finish. Excellent brown ale. First unfiltered brown ale for me. Great beer drinking experience.

name: West Virginia Dunkel Bock
review: Sample at the brewpub. Pours a hazy amber color with a medium thin off-white head that dissipates quickly. Spotty lacing on the glass. Aroma of pale malt and fruit with a bit of caramel. Medium body with roasted malt and caramel flavors plus some mild fruit in the background. The finish is clean and fruity with a short and sweet malt aftertaste. Decent overall.

name: Ruby Mountain Elevation Pale Ale
review: Draft. Pours a clear amber/copper color with a small off white head. The aroma and flavor have caramel, mild fruit, light dank and earthy hops. Pretty standard for the style without standing out.

name: Ruby Mountain Elevation Pale Ale
review: Draft pours light copper. Nose fruit hop, sweet malt, slight dank. Taste light bitter, followed by fruit hop, but subdued. Light bitter finish. Nothing of putting, but nothing stands out.

name: Ruby Mountain Elevation Pale Ale
review: Draft. Amber beer with a cream head. Malt and light grapefruit aroma. Grapefruit and pine flavor. Medium bodied. Grapefruit and pine linger with light malt.

name: Ruby Mountain Elevation Pale Ale
review: I had this on tap as the "Elevation Ale" at Elevation 486 in Twin Falls, Idaho. It has an amber/orange color with a slightly off-white head and lacing. The aroma is largely pine with some grapefruit and a small amount of pale malt in it. The flavor is medium hops up front with a malty middle, leading to a slightly spicy finish. A refreshing pale ale good on a warm day.

name: Ruby Mountain Elevation Pale Ale
review: Well, I’m not totally sure where to put this ranking. The bottle said Buckaroo Pale Ale, and it definitely tasted more like a pale ale than a golden ale. In fact, it tasted just about what you could call a proto-typical pale ale. Nothing outstanding, but nothing detrimental either.

name: Ruby Mountain Elevation Pale Ale
review: Draft at Red Lion in Elko, NV: Light copper pour with a small white head. Very nice lacing. Nose is light hops, both floral and citrus with just a touch of malt. Taste is well hopped and consistent of the floral and citrus from the aroma. Hints of caramel malt. Similar in characteristics to their amber ale, but with a drier hop finish.

name: Sonoran Desert Amber
review: At this Very nice place in Williams Arizona With a great feeling I had the Very best Amber!

name: Sonoran Desert Amber
review: Amber pour, off white head. Nice caramel malt, toffee, light sugar cookie notes and some mild hops. Overall a pretty good beer for the style.

name: Sonoran Desert Amber
review: Draft. Rich amber beer witha cream colored head. Toasty aroma with malt. Toasted malt flavor with backing citrus hops. Medium bodied. Toasty malts and citrus hops linger. Well balanced.

name: Sonoran Desert Amber
review: On tap at Pinnacle Peak Patio, it pours a nice deep amber color but with little to no head. Good flavor of mild hops, malts and even caramel but far from original. That’s not to say it was bad, far from it, it just didn’t blow my mind. Nice, somewhat bitter finish.

name: Sonoran Desert Amber
review: On cask at brewery: Though I’m not a huge fan of the style, this is one of the best ambers I’ve ever had: nice caramel character without being too sweet; earthy malt notes, balanced hop profile, and smooth palate made this a pleasant surprise.

name: Sonoran Desert Amber
review: Small tan head thats short lived, minimal lace. Clear light amber brew. Malty nose somewhat musty, no hops detected. Med/light body. Medium sweet malt flavors, toffeeish with light caramel notes. Medium dry finish.

name: Sonoran Desert Amber
review: Light amber color with an okay head... the hopping makes this drink. It’s present, but not overbearing. "Clean." The aroma promised a better bitter hop taste than the flavor delivered, but it remains a pleasurable brew that one can enjoy all night long. Beer of the Month Club

name: Sonoran Desert Amber
review: nice easy drinking beer with a nice amber color and a decent head. nice malty taste and finish. this would be a great beer to drink a lot of one after the other

name: Sonoran Desert Amber
review: This beer falls under the "Amber Ale" category...nothing challenging or offensive, yet nothing interesting either. Pours a lighter amber color with a caramel aroma. Flavor is caramel malt and some light hop bitterness. Why do all amber ale's taste the same?

name: Sonoran Desert Amber
review: Nice amber color with a tan head, sweet malty aroma. Taste was a mix of hops and caramel notes. Light on the palate.

name: Sonoran IPA
review: Fair aroma, not much there for an IPA...decent if it were a pale, kind of cloudy with thin head, very lean watery, not a bad beer per se, just on light side of hops etc.

name: Sonoran IPA
review: Backlog, from notes. On tap @ Timberwolf, Tempe, 27 May 2001. Aroma’s: notably caramel and some fruit. Flavor is light sweet, with only a mild bitter finish.

name: Sonoran IPA
review: Enjoyed on tap at the brewery showcase restaurant. Hoppy aroma, cloudy grapefruit colour with white head and lacey. High carbonation. A bitter that is more than a regular IPA although not at a double IPA level.

name: Sonoran IPA
review: Solid representation of the style but nothing that separates it. Glimmers of copper, gold and brass when held to the light. Aroma is grapefruit, lemon peel, pine, and malt. Flavor is quite earthy/grassy...medium mouthfeel and highly drinkable.

name: Sonoran IPA
review: Pours ordinary pale ale/IPA amber with contrasting head. Nose is mixed citrus with an herbal grassy quality. Black tea flavors are present on the palate. THe herbal grassy components carry through to the flavor, and the finish is medium. Carbonation is good and this IPA is quite drinkable.

name: Sonoran IPA
review: Pours from the growler a brilliant copper-amber color. It is topped by a frothy tan colored head that is initially two-fingers thick. The aroma is sharp and pungent a mix of pine, menthol and perhaps a hint of sweet citrus fruits. The taste of the beer is sharp and pungent as well. There is a nice maltiness here that is lightly sweet, with a touch of caramel and a dry toasted malt note in the finish with a bit of biscuit-like notes thrown into the mix. The beer is light enough on the palate to be quite drinkable, but still has a richness and fullness to it that accentuates the hop character. There is a solid bitterness throughout this beer as well; starting with a gripping raw hoppy bitterness, moving through to a long herbal bitterness in the finish. The really striking thing about this beer is that there is a striking mintiness to this beer. It is quite noticeable and really dominates the flavor profile. While this does not have the typical flavor profile of an IPA, the mix it does have is striking, and atypical enough to make this a really enjoyable beer. I was pleasantly surprised by this beer and definitely recommend it heartily.

name: Sonoran IPA
review: Sonora IPA pours to a bright amber color with a tight white head, and a moderate amount of carbonation. The nose is somewhat fragrant with some cirtic and piney hop aroma, but they do not smell as vibrant and zesty as a good AIPA should. If this beer is dry hopped, I could not tell. The palate was a bit on the lean side, with some good caramel and pale malty flavors, and some light touches of fruit. Sonora IPA finishes with a dry, slightly citric and piney bitter tang that slightly lingers. Hummm. This is a good beer, but hardly earth shaking, and the hops didn’t get my teeth buzzing. In all fairness to the brewery, I believe my bottle sample that I had was old and stale, and really this beer is better than the example I tasted. I visited the brewpub in Pheonix after this bottle sample, and had some fantastic, fresh, and delicious beers there. I need another crack at this one, and will have to re-rate, because having sampled their other products fresh, I know this beer is better. Its a nice beer with some nice hop character, but not an IPA that most hop heads would get excited about. That being said, I would enjoy this beer as a nice one to have as a before dinner drink, or a thirst quencher after some yard work. If you see this beer in your market, and the price is right, I say go for it if you can get fresh product. But if you are a hop head, and the bottle looks old, and you are looking for a hop buzz, you might want to think twice before you shell out some cash for this one.

name: Sonoran IPA
review: On tap at brewery: This actually has less hop charactor, but certainly more bitterness than Burning Bird; rather simple, but nice round maltiness.. OK.

name: Sonoran IPA
review: tap-scottsdale beer fest-pours a clear orange hue with a small white head. citric/pine aroma with some good malt base, more like an english IPA. flavors are piney hops, earthy hops and good malt backbone. not overly bitter, but there is some pine coming through in the finish. well rounded body! I would love to have this again!

name: Sonoran IPA
review: this is your typical average- above average IPA...nice pine floral hops that makes it easy to drink and quaff. had 3 back to back to back. quite good for a lower alcohol ipa. go!

name: Sonoran Top Down Golden Pale Ale
review: I am rating this one a little higher than normal due to the fact that my girlfriend loved this one. A very light golden pale ale, but I think the alaskan Golden pale, is a better buy.

name: Sonoran Top Down Golden Pale Ale
review: Clear gold in color, decent white head, fair lace. Nose is malt, slightly floral. Start sweet, the top light, the finish is acidic, dry, lightly hopped, and quite uninteresting.

name: Sonoran Top Down Golden Pale Ale
Sonoran Heartland Hefe
review: Sampled at the Arizona Craft Brewers Guild 2008 Strong Beer Fest, on February 17, at the Mesa Amphitheatre. A hazy golden color with a small foamy white head. Aroma of grain and citrus. Pretty standard tasting American Wheat. Refreshing, but not spectacular.

name: Sonoran Heartland Hefe
review: pours a hazy yellow with brown/orange edges and a white ring for a head. faint aroma consists of light graininess, lemon and vanilla. the flavor is strange... pineapple, light wheat and grain all hidden under a huge dose of sour freshly squeezed lemon juice. ( i got a second sample to make sure that a lemon was not put in the glass. but, sure enough.) medium body but the sour lemon makes it seem like a thin mouth feel. it’s not terrible but it’s not good either. tastes like watery unsweetened lemonade...

name: Sonoran Heartland Hefe
review: The Hefe that I had must have been different from others. I very much so enjoyed this Hefe. It was full of flavor, had a wonderful palate and looked, smelled, and had a Hefe consistency. This is the best Hefe that I have had out of a microbrewery...took a bottle home with me.

name: Sonoran Heartland Hefe
review: On Tap at Brewery: This is actually quite a clean for a hefe; smooth and drinkable without alot of phenelics; light banana and lemon notes; a hefe I practically enjoyed.

name: Sonoran Heartland Hefe
review: Bottle: I just don't like heffe, I try but i don't like it. Poured like Dawn dish detergent. Aroma of Lemon, Bananna, and Pinapple. Tasted like Pinapple weird shit. Doesn't taste like beer. Then again i don't like Heffe.

name: Sonoran Heartland Hefe
review: Hazy golden color. Fruity hoppy aroma. Sweet, bountiful berry flavor. Not a true hefe. Hard to make what of this beer. Not terrible, just not one of their best.

name: Sonoran Heartland Hefe
review: This wheat beer is a gold color with a bit of chill haze to it (note I did not pour in the yeast at the bottom of the bottle). It pours with a thin white head that fades quickly. There is a slightly catty hoppy aroma. Smells grainy, and has an aroma that I usually associate with an American lager. Quite clean tasting overall, has a hint of fruity sweetness to it. Has a bit of hop bitterness at the end, and is well carbonated.

name: Sonoran Heartland Hefe
review: Very lemony, as if I was drinking a Saxer Lemon Lager by mistake. Thin and watery, too. I wonder if this has gone bad or it just is supposed to taste this bad? Thin and one-dimensionally sourish. TERRIBLE, and an inexcusible embarrassment to Sonora!

name: Sonoran Heartland Hefe
review: Yellow, slightly cloudy, with a good head. Pretty weak beer. Not much aroma at all. A bit of hops, but not much. Arizona Lawnmower beer.

name: Sonoran Heartland Hefe
review: Medium gold color, slightly hazy. Large foamy head. Aroma is malty and a touch floral. A medium bodied weizen. Malts are mild and slightly sweet. Not very hoppy. Very smooth taste. Well balanced. That said it also doesn’t have much flavor. It also a little lemony tasting and funky. Not one of Sonoras better efforts. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is very slightly bitter.

name: Sonoran Old Saguaro Barleywine
review: Bottle, aged sample. Clear copper color. Aroma is caramel malts, faint papery notes of oxidation. Flavor matches. Sort of light in body for the style, and still a bit hot despite the time in the bottle. Hurt by a bit of a papery note. This did not stand up well to aging, which is a bit of a disappointment in a barleywine, but it was just a bit too light for that treatment in my opinion.

name: Sonoran Old Saguaro Barleywine
review: 355mL. Clear amber, low carbonation with no head. Nose is maple, peanut brittle, toffee, mint, lemon iced tea. Taste is lemon, coffee, dusty, paper. Neutral sugar, tannic. Not my style.

name: Sonoran Old Saguaro Barleywine
review: Awesome super strong barley wine thanks yo friends of GT2, caramel, intense

name: Sonoran Old Saguaro Barleywine
review: Orange-amber with a white head. Aroma is brown sugar, caramel and pine. Flavor is brown sugar, maple, pine and a light amount of tartness. I also get some alcohol. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

name: Sonoran Old Saguaro Barleywine
review: 12 oz bottle from bhensonb (maybe a 2004 since that is what he rated and because of the general characteristics of the beer?) Nose is light toffee, prunes, and an overall oxidized aroma. Murky lighter brown with a very slight bit of carbonation. Flavor is somewhat oxidized, toffee, and a bit of candi sugar. Body is somewhat watery. To be savored like a fine cognac?

name: Sonoran Old Saguaro Barleywine
review: 1999 Bottle from Kevin Wilk at CAH. pours flat with no head. nose is vanilla and sherry. first taste is caramel, sherry, and cider. finish smooth.

name: Sonoran Old Saguaro Barleywine
review: Rusty with the bottle. Brown pour. Sherry, light caramel, cardboard, infection. Flavor is sour and quite over the hill.

name: Sonoran Old Saguaro Barleywine
review: An average BW at best. To be fair I am not sure of the vintage I ran across, it is possible that it was an older vintage and this is a BW that doesn’t stand the test of time well. I didn’t find it to be particularly well balance. No boosiness, the odor seemed muted and a bit musty, malty, a touch of dark fruits on the nose. The color and carbonation were proper. I would like to give this brew another shot, if I knew what vintage I had so I could make a fairer assessment. I wouldn’t seek this beer out again, but if I were to run across it, it was reasonably priced and I would give it another try. Not a drain pour by any means, but the one I had was nothing special either.

name: Sonoran Old Saguaro Barleywine
review: Bottle:   1999 vintage from brewandbbq.   Intense deep caramel, minimal sudsy head, dies on the spot, no lacing.   Pretty much what I expected.   Strong musty caramel nose... oh, and HUGE oxidation.   Surprisingly caramel sweet, brown sugar, very musty and basement like on the tongue.   Despite the oxidation, its not half bad.   Sweetness dies quickly.   Not much body is left on this one.   Lingering caramel sweetness, strong but dull in flavor.   Otherwise strong and dank basement mustiness.   Held up fairly well for 12 years despite the oxidation.

name: Sonoran Old Saguaro Barleywine
review: Bottle. Pours an amber toned body with an off whtie head. Herbal hopped body light pine, herbal, and a plant tone i’m unfamiliar with. Lighter fruit note s citrus and peach. A bit warming with tart finish. Odd ball.

name: New Amsterdam Amber Beer
review: From old tasting notes. Orange amber color. Small bubble carbonation. Beige head is ample. Toasted malt nose is fruity and sweet. Flavor is hoppy with a semisweet toasted maltiness. Medium bodied with good balance.

name: New Amsterdam Amber Beer
review: 12oz bottle in a shaker. Pours deep rubyish/amber with a lacy, off-white head. Aroma strong of bread and cereal malts with a little toastiness and some light hops. Not that hoppy on the finish. Average texture. Decent, but not great.

name: New Amsterdam Amber Beer
review: Malty apple aroma. Clear dark orange color with a small white head. Sweet beginning with a light amount of bitterness. Bitterness fades in the finish leaving a light palate and mild sweetness.

name: New Amsterdam Amber Beer
review: Bottle: Finally scrounged one of these Utica-made NA beers. I’m revisiting this after tasting the original in the distant misty past. One of the first US micro beers I tasted. Pours a clear orange-amber ale in the glass. ! finger rocky cap, goes to a ring but laces the glass. Caramel maltiness, some fruits and dried grass in the nose Moderate body, thinnish mouth feel. Caramel malts in front are balanced with piney hop and fruity esters, finish dries out with a decent hop bite. My memory is foggy but this seems a tad thin compared to the AN amber of yore, nothing outstanding but it’s a decent enough amber ale for sessions.

name: New Amsterdam Amber Beer
review: Brewed in Saratoga Springs, but by who? New Amsterdam was one of the pioneers of the craft beer movement in New York in the 1980s. It disappeared for a while, and I suppose the brand has been picked up or restarted by someone else. Nice label. Brown pour. A bit of citrus tang and honey in the aroma. Pretty dry, medium-bodied ale, with a touch of esters and some honey in the aftertaste. It is still a good brew.

name: New Amsterdam Amber Beer
review: 12 oz bottle. I remember drinking this back when I first got into craft beer, or microbrews as they were called, back in the early 90’s. After cracking this one open and drinking it I must admit it’s pretty much the way I remebered it.....decent looking amber body with a smaller slightly bubbly off white head, sweet aroma with notes of caramel and toffee and a similar taste with a medium mouthfeel but lots of carbonation. Nothing special by any means other then the nostalgia for me but boy does this one take me back.

name: New Amsterdam Amber Beer
review: 12 oz bottle, pours an opaque dark brown color with little head. Aroma at first is sharply hoppy and dry but later becomes sweeter and maltier. Flavor is bitter with a bit of sweetness, kind of roasty. Palate is average, kind of rough, but somewhat full body. Not a bad beer, but nothing special.

name: New Amsterdam Amber Beer
review: Bottled. This says it was brewed in Saratoga Springs, not Utica, which makes me wonder if Olde Saratoga/Mendocino is doing the brewing/owns this now. Pours with pretty much no head, darkish brown-gold-amber. Aroma is syrupy, malty, sweet, bitter. Not much to the flavor, just a vegetal malty bitterness with a spoiled milk finish. Blech. Not really worth drinking at all.

name: New Amsterdam Amber Beer
review: From a 12 fl. oz. bottle no. 4123114080148. The pour is definitely amber with just about no head and light lacing. The aroma is fresh malts and slightly hopped. The mouthfeel is adequate. The flavor is about a 50-50 balance of malts and fresh hops. Slight aftertaste. It was not as good as I remembed it when I first had it in the late ’80’s but it was still OK.

name: New Amsterdam Amber Beer
review: this brew was okay. I tried it at a beerfest because I’d never seen it before. It was very ....forgettable. Nothing really stood out. It wasn’t good and it wasn’t that bad. If your looking for run-of-the-mill beer. This is it.

name: Backcountry Switchback Amber
review: On tap at Backcountry. Pours amber with high white head. Extreme lacing. Aroma is of malt, some fruits. Taste is of malt (roasted), sugar, some slight bitterness. Palate: Medium-full bodied. High carbonation. Overall: Fair. A tad sweet. Somewhat straight-forward (but then again, it’s somewhat normal).

name: Backcountry Switchback Amber
review: On tap at the brewery. Dark gold and clear appearance with an average white head. Malty, smooth and creamy with an average body. Mild sweetness, minimal bitterness. OK

name: Backcountry Switchback Amber
review: Bottle. Slightly hazy orange amber pour. Bready malts, a bit of caramel, but plenty of cardboard and stale notes as well. Not great.

name: Backcountry Switchback Amber
review: On draft at the brewpub in Frisco CO. Pours a clear reddish copper with an off white head. Nutty nose. Sweet malty flavor. Lingering toasty finish.

name: Backcountry Switchback Amber
review: Tap at brewpub. Pours clear golden amber with creamy off-white head. Aroma is caramel and toasted malts, light toffee, light woody notes, light floral notes, and faint spice. Flavor is dry malt base, light toast, light caramel sweetness, and faint woody notes; semisweet finish. Medium body and carbonation.

name: Backcountry Switchback Amber
review: Draft at the brewery. Pours very clear copper brown with a very frothy beige head. Tastes creamy, mellow, like light malt, nuttiness, and sweet hops. Medium body and low carbonation. Smells like light musk, breadiness, and malt.

name: Backcountry Switchback Amber
review: Poured at backcountry taproom. Copper in color with light amount of white head. Large amount of lacing is present. Smells slightly spicy and hoppy. Has nice amber characteristics but not super flavorful.

name: Backcountry Switchback Amber
review: Draft at Backcountry. Pours bronze with thin lumpy head. Aroma is dirty, amber Munich malt, mold. Taste is light, mold bite, amber malt bites quick cleanish finish.

name: Backcountry Switchback Amber
review: On tap at the brewpub. Comes reddish gold with a nice white head. Aroma of malt, caramel, and florals. Taste is similar. Nice, pleasant Amber Ale.

name: Backcountry Switchback Amber
review: Clear brilliant amber with a medium foamy off white head. Nice nose with malty caramel and dry hopped leafy bitterness and a touch of biscuit. Big biscuity caramalt flavors with a mediumish body ands touch of nutty toffee and a kiss of bitterness.

name: Backcountry Pale Ale (Telemark IPA)
review: drank at the dallas gingerman .. . copper gold .. strong foam head .. grass, fresh leaves, citrus dryness .. . mouth is on the level, good easy finish .. . fond of this one .. . . who calls them franks? they’re hotdogs you kraut.

name: Backcountry Pale Ale (Telemark IPA)
review: Gold pour lots of bubbles. Aroma simcoe, honey, malt. Tastes balanced, pine. mild hop in flavor but sturdy bitterness. biscuity bready malt takes up much of the flavor here.

name: Backcountry Pale Ale (Telemark IPA)
review: On tap on the premise. Pours golden with medium white head. Good lacing. Aroma is of strawberries, pine, citrus. Taste is of peaches, strawberries, citrus, bitterness, some resin aftertaste. Palate: Medium body. High carbonation. Good balance. Overall: Good hop use. Well balanced, clean.

name: Backcountry Pale Ale (Telemark IPA)
review: Clear light copper goldenish with a thin foamy white head. Lovely nose thats a bit tropical and leafy and floral and juicy--lots of guava and melon and pine and passionfruit bitterness buttressed with some sweet juiciness and a bit of pale malt caramelliness. Full crisp flavor with some bready pale malt backbone, built upon with some crisp juicy tropical bitterness, leafy, piney, with some citrus tones and a little passionfruit and melon.

name: Backcountry Pale Ale (Telemark IPA)
review: Slightly hoppy, crisp ale, wonderful light aromas, Great pale, darker golden in color, light foam head

name: Backcountry Pale Ale (Telemark IPA)
review: 12 oz. bottle from Wilbur’s. Appearance: finger khaki head, orange/copper yellow color, clear, ok lacing. Aroma: floral, caramel, light lemon/orange. heavy pine. Palate: light body, less than average carbonation, light bitter finish, slightly sticky texture. Taste: light sweet floral taste, into sweet pine and finally light bitter pine. Overall, not very hoppy, pine really is heavy, but not unpleasant. Balance is just so so and nothing special.

name: Backcountry Pale Ale (Telemark IPA)
review: On tap at The WoodCellar, served in a shaker pint. Light amber and clear appearance with a thin, lingering, frothy white head. Thick lacing and active carbonation. Aroma of fresh hops, pine, grass, herbs, citrus zest, light tropical fruits and toasted malts. Similar flavor, mild bitterness, mild sweetness, light notes of toffee and caramel. Average body, crisp and easy to drink. I like this one, probably the best beer I’ve tried from the brewery.

name: Backcountry Pale Ale (Telemark IPA)
review: Clear gold with fading white head. Aroma is medium hops. Taste starts sweet, a little sour bitterness in the middle, but it works out OK. Medium bodied, watery palate.

name: Backcountry Pale Ale (Telemark IPA)
review: On tap poured a clear golden hue w/ a medium mostly diminishing white head. Moderate hop aroma. Initial flavor is faint sweet w/ a bold bitter finish. Tastes are grass, herbal hop, and straw. Medium bodied, watery mouthfeel and lasting bitter finish. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Backcountry Pale Ale (Telemark IPA)
review: On tap at the brewpub it is a clear light amber color with a slight head. The aroma is citrus and the taste is a strong grapefruit flavor that lingers bitter on the palate

name: Backcountry Porter (Peak One)
review: Bottle. Black with a small beige head that has fair retention. The aroma is medium with chocolate, grains and some dark fruits. The taste is more of the same, chocolates, mocha, figs and anise. The palate is a bit light than I prefer and the carbonation is soft. Overall: Decent

name: Backcountry Porter (Peak One)
review: Tap at brewery. Pours dark brown with tan head. Aroma is very chocolatey, a hint of roasty, breast, cerealy. Taste is sweet upfront with a dry finish, med bodied. Overall, men.

name: Backcountry Porter (Peak One)
review: On tap on the premise. Pours black with low-medium light-beige head. Aroma is of chocolate, roasted malt. Taste is of chocolate, coffee, roasted malt, some acidity. Palate: Full bodied. Medium-high carbonation (strangely high). Overall: Good. Straight-forward. Enjoyable.

name: Backcountry Porter (Peak One)
review: Dark deep brown pour with a thin light tan head. Smooth nose of cocoa and a touch of graham, gentle roast and black malt. Smooth and balanced flavor with some mild dark cocoa, breads toast, roast, gentle whispers of coffee, and finishes with a dry roastiness. Fairly standard run of the mill Porter. As it warms the chocolatiness comes through a bit more, but..eh.

name: Backcountry Porter (Peak One)
review: Bottle. Very dark pour with a small off white head. Nice aroma of coffee and roast. Taste is a little disappointing compared to the aroma - something seems off.

name: Backcountry Porter (Peak One)
review: On tap at the brewery. Almost black appearance with a tan head. Aroma and flavor of coffee, chocolate and roasted malts. Medium body with a creamy feel. Nice.

name: Backcountry Porter (Peak One)
review: Very dark brown color with a small head. Aroma of coffee, cocoa, and caramelized sugar. Light roast character, heavy vanilla sweetness. Full body. Mostly sweet finish.

name: Backcountry Porter (Peak One)
review: On draft at the brewpub in Frisco CO. Pours a clear dark cola with a tan head. Aroma of roasted malt. Flavors of coffee and licorice. Medium bodied, moderate carbonation, toasty finish.

name: Backcountry Porter (Peak One)
review: Tap at brewpub. Pours clear brown with creamy beige head. Aroma is chocolate and lightly roasted malts, earth and woody notes, and light raisins. Flavor is dry roast malts forward, light chocolate bitterness, and light ash; dry finish. Medium body and carbonation.

name: Backcountry Porter (Peak One)
review: Draft at the brewery. Pours very dark brown with a thin, creamy beige head. Tastes very malty, nutty, lightly roasted, like burnt toast, with mild bitterness. Light/medium body and carbonation. Smells like burnt toast, coffee, and light cocoa.

name: Backcountry Pilsner (Ptarmigan)
review: From May 2007 This one pours from 22oz bottle a clear straw gold with a large head of foam that settles down but stays for the entire session and has good lacing. The smell is of malt and it's very sweet on the nose. The taste on first sip is strong on the sweet malt with some earthiness and a touch of bitterness near and through the finish. I think that it's similar to a lot of American Pilsners I've had in the past(New Belgium Blue Paddle comes to mind) but it lacks a certain oomph that would make it stand out. A few more sips in and I'm getting a "salty" flavour that I'm not really enjoying all that much. Hmm....pretty ordinary; I note that the best by date has March notched and a pen mark where 2007 would be so maybe I'll have to try again with a fresher bottle if I can find one. As is, it's pretty ordinary.

name: Backcountry Pilsner (Ptarmigan)
review: (Draught at brewery) clear bright gold, creamy white bubbles. Nose of very earthy hops, grainy, boring. Taste is super earthy and lagery, spoiled cream, rotten trash, just not my thing

name: Backcountry Pilsner (Ptarmigan)
review: On tap at the brewery. Pours a clear gold with frothy white head that lasts. The aroma is grass, wheat, citrus. Medium body, honey, grass, lemon zest, light bitterness, decent.

name: Backcountry Pilsner (Ptarmigan)
review: On tap at Backcountry. Pours light golden with low white head. Good lacing. Aroma is of pilsner malt, lagering action. Taste is of pils malt, some nice bitterness, slight metal. Palate: Good balance, high carbonation. Overall: Surprisingly good pils. Nothing off. nice one. I don’t really get why the ratings here are so low. Lots of them are old so I’m gonna guess there have been major improvements. Nice!

name: Backcountry Pilsner (Ptarmigan)
review: Bottle - clear gold - minimal, soapy lace - overall weak and messy - aroma is highly acidic and a little starchy, with slightly sourish malt character - flavor is sweet, but with a sharp acidity, bland malt character, moderate but kind of dull hoppiness - a bit of chalk, starch, corn - moderately sour finish - lame.

name: Backcountry Pilsner (Ptarmigan)
review: 12oz bottle pours a clear pale yellow with a medium white head. Aroma of honey, caramel malt, corn, light yeast and noble hops. Sweet taste of caramel and honey, malt, mild corn, mild hop bitterness on the finish. Decent pils, prefer this one straight from the bottle though.

name: Backcountry Pilsner (Ptarmigan)
review: Bottle. Awful. Pale slightly hazy pour. Musky corn stalk and bug spray. Thinner palate. Total drain pour.

name: Backcountry Pilsner (Ptarmigan)
review: On draft at the brewpub it is clear golden with a slight head. The aroma is citrus and the taste is a funky flavor whivh slightly resembles grapefruit

name: Backcountry Pilsner (Ptarmigan)
review: On draft at the brewpub in Frisco CO. Pours a clear gold with an off white head. Light biscuit nose and flavor. Light bodied, Moderate carbonation. Short crisp finish.

name: Backcountry Pilsner (Ptarmigan)
review: 12 oz bottle from Evergreen Discount. Gold and clear with a lasting white head and light lacing. Aroma of pilsner malts, mild sweetness, noble hops, mild bitterness and a touch of citrusy fruits. Light to medium body with a crisp feel and a smooth finish.

name: Backcountry Breakfast Stout
review: Tap at First Draft, Denver. Near black. Small golden head. Really nice coffee aroma. Very creamy too. Taste is more sweet but with coffee bitterness. Doesn’t taste so strong, but good on the whole.

name: Backcountry Breakfast Stout
review: Faint malty aromas. Dark and smooth-looking. Flavors of chocolate, toast and coffee. Medium weight on the palate.

name: Backcountry Breakfast Stout
review: Bottle. Black with a small tan head that has fair retention. The aroma is faint with some chocolate malts. The taste is chocolate, mocha, vanilla earth and minerals. Palate is medium and uneven. Finished short and sweet. Overall: OK, but not great.

name: Backcountry Breakfast Stout
review: Picked up single 12-oz bottle from Heritage Liquors in Maplewood,, MN. Pours an opaque dark brown colored brew with a thin creamy beige head that quickly dissipates. Aroma of mostly mild coffee, a hint of vanilla with toasted dark malts. Taste is medium bodied with more toasted malt flavors with dark chocolate, and a hint of roasted coffee. Finish is semi-sweet, has a short coffee aftertaste that quickly disappears and leaves behind a toasted chocoalte malt and light vanilla aftertate.

name: Backcountry Breakfast Stout
review: On tap at Wapiti Restaurant & Pub. Comes almost black with a small tan head. Aroma of coffee, chocolate, and malt. Taste is coffee, chocolate, and roasted malt. Thin bodied. Pretty good stuff.

name: Backcountry Breakfast Stout
review: On tap at the brewery. Pours black with small beige head that lasts. The aroma is olive and cracker. Medium body, olive, roast, light finish, ok.

name: Backcountry Breakfast Stout
review: (Draught at brewery) deep black, creamy tan head. Nose of olive brine, old coffee, and roast. Taste of olives, salty, old coffee, touch of roast, soft carbonation, stale coffee finish and cardboard.

name: Backcountry Breakfast Stout
review: Nice stout. Medium dark roast aroma. Coffee and light chocolate notes. Dark brown, almost opaque. Nice creamy tan head with good retention. Slightly sweet. Dark roast with chocolate and light coffee. Medium bitterness. Very little hop flavor. Finishes moderately dry. Medium full bodied. Smooth. Light astringency in finish. Overall good stout but lacking a little in coffee aroma/flavor for a "coffee stout" ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Backcountry Breakfast Stout
review: (Draught) Pours a dark brown body with a spare beige head. Aroma of roasted/burnt grain, chocolate, graham cracker, and coffee. Flavor of chocolate, roasted malt, coffee, and caramel.

name: Backcountry Breakfast Stout
review: Tap at the brewery. Pours very dark brown, foamy tan head. Aroma is dark malt, roast and coffee. Some notes of cocoa. Medium-full body with slick chocolate malt. Roast on the finish. Lovely. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Backcountry Expedition ESB
review: No aroma detected. Nice light copper color and a medium palate. Flavors were more pronounced with bready malt and slight bitter finish.

name: Backcountry Expedition ESB
review: On tap at Hops and Pie poured a clear amber with a small lingering amber head. Aromas of carmel, earthiness and light fuittiness. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of carmel, earthiness and light fruittiness with a smooth moderatly bitter lingering earthy finish.

name: Backcountry Expedition ESB
review: Tap at the brewery. Dark red orange appearance with a frothy cream orange head. Slightly hoppy aroma with amber malts. Body has a floral hoppy taste with a medium deep amber maltiness. A little hoppier than a typical ESB with an amber malty and slightly hoppy aftertaste. A little off but not bad.

name: Backcountry Expedition ESB
review: GABF 2010. Pours clear orange with a large, creamy beige head, high retention with excellent lacing. Aroma is average malt (caramel, grainy, toasted), average hops (herbal, woody), and average esters (fruity). Flavor is average malt (bread, caramel, toasted), heavy hops (earthy, herbal, spicy), and light esters (fruity). Medium body, low warmth and creaminess, high carbonation and a dry finish.

name: Backcountry Expedition ESB
review: Hazed amber. Peachy/apricot hops, good fruitiness. Nice maltiness. Great ESB.

name: Backcountry Expedition ESB
review: On tap at the Backcountry Brew Pub. Poured a medium orange color with a small sized off white head. Aromas of floral, nutty, and lightly earthy. Tastes follow the same with some caramel mixed in. Light lacing left on the glass.

name: Backcountry Expedition ESB
review: tap. copper pour with large head. earthy hop aroma. very mild. Light body. touch musky. disappointing hops and weak bitterness.

name: Backcountry Expedition ESB
review: Draft 6 oz’er at the brewpub: Nicely carbonated with a rubbery head. Big, big aroma ... but it’s musty and dirty-sockish. This drinks with a tepid, earthy mossiness that made it the most disappointing of Backcountry’s beers.

name: Backcountry Maibock
review: On tap on the premise. Pours golden with medium white head. Aroma is of flowers, malt. Taste is of flowers, malt, sugar, some bitterness, over-ripe oranges. Palate: Medium-full bodied, soft-medium carbonation. Slightly sticky. Overall: OK. A tad sweet and heavy for a Maibock? Not their best beer.

name: Backcountry Maibock
review: On tap at the brewery. Gold and clear appearance. Malty lager flavor, mild sweetness, minimal bitterness. Smooth, crisp and easy to drink with a medium body.

name: Backcountry Maibock
review: Tap at the brewpub. Poured a golden color with a white head and good lacing. Aromas of biscuit, bread, and light hops, but very dominated by malt. Taste is very malt-forward as well, but somewhat fruity, ending moderately bitter. Medium mouthfeel with high carbonation. Meh.

name: Backcountry Maibock
review: Tap at Falling Rock - light copper - creamy mouthfeel - very mild flavor of cane sugar, watered down honey, light floral character - thin flavor let a lot of alcohol through - peppery hops in the finish - bland.

name: Backcountry Maibock
review: tap. golden amber pour with frothy white head. effervecant. lemon, hops and malt aroma. spicy, lemon wheat and a little sour. bitter finish.

name: Backcountry Maibock
review: Draught. Pours hazy pale yellow with a patchy white head that mostly fades, spotty lacing. Aroma is floral spiced and fruity hops, honey, mild citrus and faint malt. Honey malt, orange citrus flavor, medium bitterness and acidtity, sweet wheat finish. Light bodied and creamy palate.

name: New Belgium Frambozen
brewery: New Belgium Brewing Company (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
review: Crowler. Clear chestnut with a touch of maroon and a lasting film of creamy bubbles. Nose has raspberries, caramel, toasted walnut and cocoa. Tastes the same. Medium mouthfeel with medium fizz and an easy drinking balance. Mild astringency from the raspberry makes the finish pleasantly dry. Nice change-of-pace cold weather brew.

name: New Belgium Frambozen
brewery: New Belgium Brewing Company (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
review: From Nov 2005 Poured from bottle(room temp) a deep gold-brown with a good sized head that showed good lacing. The smell is all raspberry and that's just fine with me as I want as much infusion of the fruit in this ale as I can get! The taste is a wonderful mix of raspberry and malt and works so darn well, it's hard to put the glass down. I've enjoyed this brew for many years and will continue to as long as NB wants to brew it. ;^)

name: New Belgium Frambozen
brewery: New Belgium Brewing Company (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
review: Originally rated on 1/8/2009. Very nice aroma, raspberries of course, it wasnt in your face overwhelming, but very noticeable. The body was a deep dark brown that was almost black, with a reddish hue. Flavor was raspberries at first then a malty finish. Overall it was a pretty nice beer.

name: New Belgium Frambozen
brewery: New Belgium Brewing Company (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
review: thin tan head with a definite pinkish tinge. The brew is very clear walnut brown... just spots of lacing. Nose is distinctive "real raspberry".... also shows a nice clean brown malty character with deep toast and hints of lite cocoa. Flavor mirrors the nose and is actually pretty dry... just clean malts and sorta jammy raspberry essence.... pretty refreshing actually. Body is a bit on the light side, but plenty of smooth small bubble carbonation makes it seem a little creamy.

name: New Belgium Frambozen
brewery: New Belgium Brewing Company (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
review: Bottle to snifter. An immediate gawd awful aroma of rotten fruit and mustiness that makes me feel sick. a dark red pour with a medium sized light brown head. Taste is all papery thin and sugary sweetness like a lollipop. This is horrible.

name: New Belgium Frambozen
brewery: New Belgium Brewing Company (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
review: Rating #1392 - 15.12.2014 On tap @revolutionyeg. Pours a deep ruby Aroma is strong raspberry. Taste is more of the same, sweet berry juicyness, light tartness. Palate is heavy with sweetness, but it isn’t unwelcome in this instance.

name: New Belgium Frambozen
brewery: New Belgium Brewing Company (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
review: Draft at the brewery. Pours opaque bright red with a creamy, fizzy off white head. Tastes like cherry, dried fruit, earthy malt, and toffee. Light/medium body and low carbonation. Smells like cherry, dried fruit, earthy malt, and some toffee.

name: New Belgium Frambozen
brewery: New Belgium Brewing Company (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
review: Tap at New Belgium. Pours copper/ruby. Aroma is cherries, raspberries, toasted malts, and faint caramel. Flavor is dry with modest fruit flavor and a faint chocolate finish. Medium body.

name: New Belgium Frambozen
brewery: New Belgium Brewing Company (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
review: Bottle. Pours ruby red with a small off-white head. Aroma of toasted malts and raspberry fruitiness. Flavor of sweet raspberry, toasted malts, roasted grains and had a light tartness.

name: New Belgium Frambozen
brewery: New Belgium Brewing Company (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
review: Aroma is raspberry and sulphur. Taste is pale malts with faint caramel and mostly raspberry tones that are fairly well balanced and not consuming. Appearance is a clear amber with a thin pearl head that retains fairly well.

name: Weyerbacher ESB
review: From old tasting notes. Hazy amber orange color. Rocky beige head.maromatic spicy hop nose. Bittersweet toasted malt flavor hints at fruit and finishes with a complex hoppininess.

name: Weyerbacher ESB
review: Copper pour with an off white head. Grassy and earthy with some tea and spicy elements on the finish.

name: Weyerbacher ESB
review: Poured a light brown color with an off white head. Aroma was of plain malts, not too much outstanding here. Flavor was much the same, very bland and a bit watery

name: Weyerbacher ESB
review: Date: 04/06/2007 Mode: Bottle Source: Trade clear dark copper, dense beige head, drippy lace, sweet caramel malt aroma with light earthy hops, lots of rich caramel flavor, nice sweetness that eventually dries out and leads to a light bitter finish, Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 12/20 Rating: 3.1/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **/4

name: Weyerbacher ESB
review: Clear amber coloured body with a very thin white head. Aroma of cardboard, malt, and grass. Light-bodied; acidic taste of malt, metal, English hops, and limes. Aftertaste shows more acidity, metallic flavors, and little else. Overall, an alright beer but nothing outstanding. I sampled this 12 oz bottle purchased directly from Weyerbacher Brewery in Easton, PA on 21-April-2007 on the Eastern Shore in VA.

name: Weyerbacher ESB
review: Hazy copper body with amber overtones. Sizeable beige head, well retained. Fair lacing. Earthy hops dominate an aroma that also showcases caramel malts, brown sugar, dried flowers and must. Flavor is a touch better, with more malt accentuation and moderate bitterness and low acidity. Toffee and bready malts also noted in the flavor. Finishes medium dry and crisp, mellow. Palate is light bodied and balanced.

name: Weyerbacher ESB
review: (bottle - 12 oz) Amber color with a puffy white head. Aroma is bitter with some slight sweetness and caramel notes as well. Flavor begins with some floral hops and a nice bitterness in the middle, with a light touch of caramel and a bitter and clean finish.

name: Weyerbacher ESB
review: 12 oz. bottle. Pours a slightly hazy medium amber with a moderate off-white head that lasted through most of the glass. Pleasant caramel aroma with some floral notes as well. Somewhat sweet caramel and malt flavor well balanced against some hops bitterness. Somewhat creamy mouthfeel. Very easy to drink. Drank one today wth a Bubba Burger from the BBQ. Great combo.

name: Weyerbacher ESB
review: Thanks to Leopold Stoch for this one. Hazy amber body with a tall, long lasting head of off-white. Caramel aroma. The flavor starts sweet with some bitterness in the middle and a long caramel finish. Needs some hop dryness to balance out some of this sweetness. Smooth with plenty of body.

name: Weyerbacher ESB
review: Appearance: This beer pours a soft transparent copper color with a very creamy 2 finger off-white head with decent retention. Mediocre lacing. Smell: It has a good aroma but it is subtle and reserved. After some contemplation I came up with sweet bread and yeast, slight fruity tones and gentle hops. Taste: Like the smell the taste is gentle and approachable. It is not the most interesting ESB I have ever tasted but it is quite palatable. It seems to have a pretty straight forward bready malt and hop balance until the aftertaste. The aftertaste is a bit odd. There is very little of the bitter I was looking for up front it seems all the bitter is waiting for the finish. I’m not quite sure what to make of this...? Mouthfeel: This beer has a very light mouthfeel that seems to disappear into nothing through the middle. To its credit it is very smooth. Drinkability: Overall this is a decent beer but a bit lacking in luster. I would be too bored to have a second but it would be palatable if I was interested so the drinkability is what I’d call "Ho Hum." Hope this is helpful. Cheers!

name: Weyerbacher Hefeweizen
review: Bottle, must have gone bad. Pours a slightly hazed orange body with a white fizzy head. Acetone, and apples, some slight sour wheat and lemon. This is sour and went down the drain for the most part...

name: Weyerbacher Hefeweizen
review: Cloudy and orange with a nice white head. Pronounced citrus is present in both the nose and the taste.

name: Weyerbacher Hefeweizen
review: Bottle and draft - notes from 2006. Cloudy orange body. Aroma is light citrus and yeast. Flavor is yeasty/earthy, crisp citrus taste.

name: Weyerbacher Hefeweizen
review: Cloudy orange appearance with a large, white head. Aroma of wheat, banana and light spices. Medium bodied drink that was crisp and smooth. It was a good German style hefe. Refreshing.

name: Weyerbacher Hefeweizen
review: 22 oz. bottle. Pours a cloudy gold with a moderate white head that disappeared after a few minutes. Strong, unpleasant sour aroma. The flavor is a bit more palatable with the sourness more subdued and some cloves and citrus present as well. There were no banana flavors noted at all. There was a light metallic flavor in the aftertaste that I did not care for. Without question, this was the worst beer I have sampled from this brewer and I have a hard time believing they would put this stuff on the shelves tasting like this.

name: Weyerbacher Hefeweizen
review: Not good. Barely drinkable. Not much of an aroma and very sour taste. The aroma was like feet. Save your money.

name: Weyerbacher Hefeweizen
review: Hazy orangish yellow. Aroma is tart lemons and spices, light malts. Flavor is thin for the style, relatively bland and simple. Drinkable but boring.

name: Weyerbacher Hefeweizen
review: Orangish amber pour with little to no head. Citrus peel aroma, yeast, some banana. Funky, kind of sour, odd. None of the traditional hefe flavors that I would expect. This tastes nothing like it smells, very disappointing.

name: Weyerbacher Hefeweizen
review: 22 oz bottle. Golden in color, slightly hazy. Aroma: very sour, some barnyard. Taste: Sour, this one is obviously contaminated...

name: Weyerbacher Hefeweizen
review: Cold 22oz bottle: Pours a cloudy golden peach color with a small amount of alabaster bubbles around the edges of the glass. Aroma and taste: sour, acidic (possibly rotten fruit? vinegar? metallic?). Maybe it was past it’s time...the bottle has no date reference. Volgon did not add this to the garlic beer...it went down the drain instead! : )

name: Firestone Windsor Pale Ale
review: "a better aroma than their english pale attempt. a little better but still not the one i’d pick off the shelf. for their good stuff, go for the IIPA or the reserve Porter

name: Firestone Windsor Pale Ale
review: Firestone Walker Brewing Company--Windsor Pale Ale--2000 Release--12 oz. Bottle. 4.60% ABV--30 IBU’s. (3.0 / 5.0) Pale Ale--Clear rich golden color. Light hop front and light malt body backup. Mild caramel flavor with hint of biscuit doughiness. Minimally sweet fruit flavor. Mild Hops. English Pale Ale in Style. Sampled 8/15/2000. Firestone Walker Brewing Company--Firestone Pale Ale--2005 Release--12 oz. Bottle. 4.60% ABV--38 IBU’s. (3.75 / 5.0) Pale Ale--Beer of the Month Selection April 2005. Mild lace head. Clear bright rich gold color. Tangy floral hop front. Crisp thin mild caramel citrus body. Rich clean hop citrusy spice end. Hoppy, but weak malt backbone. Sampled 5/24/2005.

name: Firestone Windsor Pale Ale
review: Pours a nice cloudy golden straw color with no head. Slight hop aroma with some grass, floral..... Taste was citrus with floral and a mild hops finish.

name: Firestone Windsor Pale Ale
review: Herbal and grassy nose with wafts of bready malt. Mild citrus and biscuit notes on the palate. Clean and easy drinking session brew.

name: Firestone Windsor Pale Ale
review: The worst of the Firestone line in bottles. Nice golden colro but somewht skunky on the nose and palate. Hops blended with a mulching grass smell. Not rich enough to warrant a a world class Pale rating. Too young.

name: Firestone Windsor Pale Ale
review: Golden in color with a nice floral aroma. Hoppy taste present with malts to round up. Nice

name: Firestone Windsor Pale Ale
review: 12/4/2002 - Had on tap at Callahan's A dark yellow/gold color beer with a slight head, I found the aroma of this pale to be fruity, but a bit weak. Overall, I found the flavor lacking for a Pale Ale and while easy to drink, I was not overly impressed.

name: Firestone Windsor Pale Ale
review: Golden colour with a white head. Citrusy hop aroma. Dry bitter flavour with a hint of malt underneath. A good APA, but what keeps it from being great is the lack of complexityt in hop flavour.

name: Firestone Windsor Pale Ale
review: very fruity aroma, citrus with zest. Pale yellow, small to medium head. a good hop bitterness, but slightly straight forward. mild citrus

name: Firestone Windsor Pale Ale
review: The perfume is IPA all the way. very tart and complex. Tangy. It is an amber ale delightful to gaze at but better to drink. It has a variety of flavors right off the bat. Caramel with a hint of toffee. Huminee, huminee. Really pleasant tasting (I'mm embibing as I write this). Nice rich beer if just a tad young. Overall I enjoy this beer but would still choose a nice IPA over it but hey...I wouldn't turn her down either. Firestone Pale Ale is like an average looking chick with a lovely rack!!!

name: Weyerbacher AutumnFest Ale
review: Reddish, clear pour with a beige foam that fades quickly. Lots of toasted cereal malts in the nose with a little fruity hops in the background. The taste is a little more balanced, with a nice complex set of malt flavors and some hints of spice here and there. Medium, slightly watery body with slight fizz. Malt sourness at the end. A good, mild autumn beer.

name: Weyerbacher AutumnFest Ale
review: I poured it from the bottle into a pint glass. It pours a hazy orange color with a small white head and barely any lacing. The aroma is caramel malt, hay, and hops. The taste is malt, grass, dried fruit, and some alcohol with some hops on the back end. This tasted higher in alcohol than it actually is. As it warmed, it became smoother. This was pretty good.

name: Weyerbacher AutumnFest Ale
review: 12 ounce bottle. Pours a hazy copper color with a inch high creamy beige head. Faint toasted malt aroma. Sweet caramel malt flavor has notes of toffee and floral hops. Tangy fruity flavor with a silky mouthfeel. Smooth subtle hop finish is lightly bitter.

name: Weyerbacher AutumnFest Ale
review: Fresh bottle about two weeks old from Beach Liquor FWB. Nice clear copper color with a thin white head. Aroma is dusty, sweet malt with a hint of corn-like grain. Nice marzen overall with some light sweetness that lingers and just a hint of hops to balance it. Refreshing and pleasant.

name: Weyerbacher AutumnFest Ale
review: Bottle. Pours an orangish brown color with white head. Malty, bread, toast aromas. Sweet malty, syrupy, bread flavors. A bit sweet. Of the 10-15 oktoberfests I’ve had in the last month, this one is a little below average. Nothing bad about it, but it is a little bit more sweet than I’d like

name: Weyerbacher AutumnFest Ale
review: Pours a golden amber with no head. Sweet malt aromas that translate to sweet malt flavor, kinda watery. Meh...

name: Weyerbacher AutumnFest Ale
review: Poured from a 12 OZ bottle into a tulip glass. Aroma- a semi-sweet grain and hop aroma. Appearance- a very nice copper/burnt orange color with a small white head. Taste- A well balanced flavor of the hops and malt, no bitter aftertaste Palate- light bodied beer with mild carbonation, goes down well Overall- a very pleasant brew. I would definitely drink this again.

name: Weyerbacher AutumnFest Ale
review: Pours a nice amber color with minimal lacing and head retention. Tastes malty and of Autumn, but not much else worth noting here. Smells sweet, akin to a red style beer. Just alright.

name: Weyerbacher AutumnFest Ale
review: Bottle. Moderate cereal and caramel for the malt, light herbs and dough for the hops and yeast, with hints of dark dried fruit. Head is average size, off-white with some spots of lacing and is mostly diminishing. Color is medium to dark brown. Flavor starts lightly sweet and lightly to moderately acidic, then finishes slightly sweet and lightly acidic. Palate is medium, a little slick with a lively carbonation. Not completely Marzen-ish but still a tasty Autumn seasonal.

name: Weyerbacher AutumnFest Ale
review: DATE TASTED: September 21, 2014... GLASSWARE: Barley Creek pint...OCCASION: football watching with friends Mary and Rich... APPEARANCE: reasonably copper-amber body; strangely quiet in the way of bubbles; head mellows to a thin off-white head... AROMA: fragrant floral hops abound; nicely rounded caramel settles and balances the aroma--alluring... PALATE: crunchy and medium-bodied, with slick finish that lingers confidently; possesses the effervescence of cola.....TASTE: mellow, sweet caramel with a pitchy, sharp funk that provides a distinct profile... OVERALL: what makes this an autumnal brew? a darker body? a smoky scent? a heartier flavor? This beer really doesn’t have those attributes, but it does work well enough to compliment apps and football watching....

name: Weyerbacher Merry Monks Ale
review: Deep Amber and Carmel taste with a clean palate and honey notes. Mmmmmmm.... ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Weyerbacher Merry Monks Ale
review: Keg at Euston Tap, London. Wow. This basically tastes like a mouthful of peardrops... I'm not sure what else to say.

name: Weyerbacher Merry Monks Ale
review: Pours a very hazy good with a thin white head, mild lacing and is very fizzy. It has a very pleasant malty aromas. It has a medium to heavy sweetness and a very light, almost nonexistent body. I appreciate that this is a very mellow, even beer that is also somehow 9.3%. However, I wish it had a little more in each category.

name: Weyerbacher Merry Monks Ale
review: I have wanted to try this beer for a long time. Typical Belgian flavored beer with some nice Belgian hops that contribute to its flavor. Overall not bad.

name: Weyerbacher Merry Monks Ale
review: Bottle from BevMo. Sweet and yeasty up front. Huge banana and cloves. Some booze in the back end. By far the yeastiest tripel I've ever tried. Pretty enjoyable. It tastes more like an impy hefe than a tripel. Still quite good though.

name: Weyerbacher Merry Monks Ale
review: ALCOHOL evident. some Belgian beer spice the beer is velvety with some oil and a frothy creamy head. Some caramel and kick in the finish like a boost of flavor.

name: Weyerbacher Merry Monks Ale
review: Sampled at the January 2019 New England Craft Beer Pavilion in Boston. Pours slightly hazy yellow-gold with small creamy beige head and lacing. Aroma: barnyard, coriander, lemon. Flavor: honey, barnyard, coriander, lemon. Mouthfeel: medium-bodied, slightly creamy.

name: Weyerbacher Merry Monks Ale
review: Enjoyed this Abbey style ale, found it similar to Chimay Red. Decent head, yeasty with hints of raisin-like malt, yet enough bitter hops to round it out nicely.

name: Weyerbacher Merry Monks Ale
review: Poured from 12 oz bottle into tulip glass. A 2" white head drops slowly with plenty of lacing. Color is hazy orange, lots of streaming carbonation and yeast in suspension. Aroma is very yeasty with fruit and spice notes. Mouthfeel is medium and very similar to dry champagne. Flavors of banana, pear, spices, white bread, mild hops. Overall: nicely done tripel.

name: Weyerbacher Merry Monks Ale
review: Aroma Banana coriander clove Belgian yeast hay golden malts yeast funk white grapes Riesling Taste sweet white grapes grapefruit Riesling white wine yeast funk Belgian yeast barnyard bread honeydew lemon zest banana coriander golden malts fruity esters rose hips wheat sweet candi sugar melon apricot

name: Weyerbacher Old Heathen
review: De beergium. En copa Teku. Viendo The Society 1x09-10. Cuerpo ligero, notas herbales algo fuera de lugar y ligera acidez. Sin estar mala, se hecha en falta mas sabor y complejidad

name: Weyerbacher Old Heathen
review: Bitter malziger Beginn. Oxidation, keine Karbonisierung, wässriger Hintergrund. Mittellanger Abgang, Schokolade. 7/8/9/8/5/8

name: Weyerbacher Old Heathen
review: Solid good all around coffee chocolate flavored beer. Dark fruits linger in the background. Low carbonation. Very nice and smooth.

name: Weyerbacher Old Heathen
review: Piana drobna trwa³a, zdobi szk³o. Kolor czarny. Aromat ciemne s³ody czekolada, owocowa s³odycz suszonych owoców. Smak kawa, gorzka czekolada, palonosc, estry owocowe id¹ce w suszone owoce, karmel. Klasyczny RIS bez wynalazków, Bardzo Dobre.

name: Weyerbacher Old Heathen
review: Zakupione 10.2015 wypite 09.2017. czarne, piana br¹zowa, drobna i trwa³a. Czekoladowe g³ównie z nut¹ pralinek i kawy. Geste, mega czekoladowe w smaku z przewaga gorzkiej czekolady, plus praliny i nuta kawy na finiszu. Niskie nasycenie.

name: Weyerbacher Old Heathen
review: Bottle a black colored beer with a beige head aroma roasted malts laurel coffee spicy dark fruits and hops flavor roasted malts spicy laurel coffee chocolate dark fruits caramel and bitter hops

name: Weyerbacher India Pale Ale
review: Cloudy amber pour. Nose and taste of slight honey, spruce and maple. Rated 6/29/02

name: Weyerbacher India Pale Ale
review: Quite cloudy Honey colored with avery light head and a little lacing, Clearly this is about the bitter hops , clean finish

name: Weyerbacher India Pale Ale
review: Great IPA I had on draft, though it was listed as 7.2%. I asked if this was the Hops INfusion and was told FUCK OFF, this is NOT Hops Infusion my friend, you are trippin--so I punched the bartender in the dick with a $2 tip on my tab, bitches, and drank these things all night. It was sweet, because this beer has a high hop profile, medium grapefruit hip pine, all clean and intense and in your face. Very good IPA that is light coppper hazy. Nice brew, despite the bartending crew.

name: Weyerbacher India Pale Ale
review: Smells citrussy and sweet. Tastes citrussy and sweet with some tea elements. Pretty straight forward and basic.

name: Weyerbacher India Pale Ale
review: Bottle. I was hoping to find some fresh bottles but that looks like it won’t happen so I will rate on the bottle I’ve had. Hazy amber body with thin head. Aroma is faint citrus and spices. Flavor is caramel, spices and a little vegatable.

name: Weyerbacher India Pale Ale
review: Bottle->shaker: Pours a light brown head atop a dark amber body. Lots of frothy head, some carbonation Aroma is hoppy, bitter flavor, flavor is mostly hoppy, has a bitter+astringent aftertaste with not much body or aftertaste. Not a very good IPA interpretation IMO.

name: Weyerbacher India Pale Ale
review: Bottle. Pours cloudy amber with a thin head that disappears. Fruity aroma, grapefruit, flowers, touch of sweetness. Taste is flowers and bitter. Not much malt anywhere. Bitterness lingers. Drinkable, but unremarkable.

name: Weyerbacher India Pale Ale
review: bottle. hazy amber with thin off white head. musky aroma. week hops and malt. fruit smelled sour. thin. flovor matched the aroma. bitterness was big but unwelcome. Plain bad. I hope my drain enjoyed it more than me.

name: Weyerbacher India Pale Ale
review: Bottle. Copper, hazy color with head that overflowed upon opening. Classic IPA light hoppy scent with hints of melon and citrus. Drinkable but unremarkable in flavor or finish. OK.

name: Weyerbacher India Pale Ale
review: 12 ounce bottle from my SS winter 06. Light copper with a smallish white head. The aroma is of citrus hop tea. Not malt character to speak of. Kind of the same going on with the flavor. The malt just isn’t coming through. Medium body.

name: Weyerbacher Quad
review: 2015 bottle, thanks to Joe! Pours dark brown, with a small, fleeting, beige head. The aroma is plums, allspice, wet paper, sherry, and cocoa. Sweet and sugary, with a nice bitterness. Medium to heavy body, with a syrupy, spicy palate. Well aged. Has a lot of character and depth.

name: Weyerbacher Quad
review: DATE: July 19, 2018... OCCASION: another beautiful summer day in need of a nice drink.... GLASSWARE: La Fin du Monde tulip... pours a dark amber body, almost a brown tea consistency, holding a ring of thin white bubbles... thick, boozy red grapes, heavy plasticized ether, grapefruit, prune, plum, bourbon, caramel, cilantro, and roasted malts.... sips as a lab beaker might, drips at a time, warming and thick with a cough syrupy sweetness.... a slow burn lingers... somewhat dry and buttery... its strength is in its weighty plum and bourbon, smooth and satisfying, with caramel, toffee, and peat... this wins with its late nutty finish, its malty base, its caramel sweetness, and an overblown 11.9% ABV that slowly uncoils its wallup.... have had better, tastier, dark ales, but this is solid enough...

name: Weyerbacher Quad
review: Bottle poured into a snifter. Pours a clear reddish brown with a thin beige ring that fizzles out before you can set the bottle down. Sweet smelling aroma of candied fruits and brown sugar. Maybe a hint of chocolate. Flavor is sweet and follows the nose. Palate is full and warming. This is relaxation in liquid form. Delightful!

name: Weyerbacher Quad
review: Dark murkey brown pour with minimal head. Aroma is sweet; figs, dark fruit and yeast. Taste follows the nose, but with toasted caramel malts blending with the fruit flavors. Medium bodied with light carbonation.

name: Weyerbacher Quad
review: Bottle from Brewtopia. Reddish brown with no head. Burnt caramel cherry woody boozy aroma. Very sweet burnt caramel cherry with harsh herbal bitterness on sandpaper carbo bite. Full body. Sticky cloying. Totally missing the softness of a good Belgian quad. Gross.

name: Weyerbacher Quad
review: Strong plum and raisin aromas. Red and clear in color with nice long lasting head. Taste is malty with notes of plum, cherry, raisin

name: Weyerbacher Quad
review: Very nicely done. Smoke and raisin with prune and florals like a dried fruit amd cheese dish before dinner. Dark brown pour. Sweet finish. Great balance.

name: Weyerbacher Quad
review: Pours a hazy whiskey, amber color with a rich aroma of caramel & malt. Tastes of moderately bitter alcohol and malt, whiskey-like, with a semi-sweet finish of banana and a hint of clove. It’s medium bodied with moderate carbonation.

name: Weyerbacher Quad
review: 12 oz bottle from Liberty Beer in Pittsburgh. Strong and sweet, way too high on the perfume. I think the alcohol level was too high on purpose.

name: Weyerbacher Quad
review: Dark amber, clear, lasting tan head Sweet but refreshing nose. Full body, dense flavor, silky, sticky texture, very hot mouthfeel but well blended, average length. Very sweet but nicely balanced by bitterness and alcohol. Caramel sauce, overwhelmingly alcoholic, dried fruit, dates, prunes, hoppy in the background. Massive, great way to finish a meal. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Weyerbacher Raspberry Imperial Stout
review: love stout and love raspberry. And i like this stout a lot. full body cocoa and a touch of roast and ash. medium body some bitter from the cocoa. some vanilla and marshmallow.

name: Weyerbacher Raspberry Imperial Stout
review: Twelve ounce glass, on tap at the brewery. Pours a very dark brown, almost brown. Strong berry taste fades into the cocoa.

name: Weyerbacher Raspberry Imperial Stout
review: Pours fizzy and looks like a cherry cola, aroma of raspberries and bitter cocoa, taste to match, very tart bite at the end, medium mouthfeel, bottle.

name: Weyerbacher Raspberry Imperial Stout
review: Bottle sample courtesy of Kerry, thank you sir! Dark brown color beige head. Fruity coffee aroma. Taste is coffee and chocolate covered raspberry bonbons.

name: Weyerbacher Raspberry Imperial Stout
review: Pours a deep dark brown with a slight red tinged head which is gone in a flash......aroma of booze, fruit, fig.....taste is woody, booze, raspberry tartness. It's 5 degrees out, this is perfect.

name: Weyerbacher Raspberry Imperial Stout
review: Light aroma of berries and malt. Pours dark with nice head. Subtle raspberry taste and finish. No alcohol-ish taste for abv. Overall a great beer. Too good to have been retired.

name: Weyerbacher Raspberry Imperial Stout
review: Bottle at Paul’s tasting. Pours near black with a thin head. Roasted malts, light fruity raspberry, medium sweetness, and a hint of chocolate. I liked this must more than I expected I would.

name: Weyerbacher Raspberry Imperial Stout
review: Had two older vintages one with the label shown and one older with a pink label .... Black pour Tan head great looking beer ... aroma is very prominently raspberry with dark chocolate and light roast .... taste is a bit oxidized fruity, light raspberry with some roastedness and dark chocolate .. medium bodied ... abv hidden well ... aroma and appearance stood the test of time the flavor not so much ... finishes dry and lightly fruity/roasted

name: Weyerbacher Raspberry Imperial Stout
review: Originally reviewed: 4/29/09. Pours a very thick black with a small tan head on top. No retention and no lacing at all. Smells of dark chocolate, raspberries, strawberry, and dairy sweetness. Mouthfeel is decent. Some crisp carbonation, but overall pretty smooth. Flavor is full of fruity chocolate. The raspberry is there, but it’s not in your face. Hints of the fruit come through, but it is mostly cocoa and milky sweetness in this one. Decent. I liked this. Recommend.

name: Weyerbacher Raspberry Imperial Stout
review: The last bottle from ’05 or ’06 saved for Birthday week...Rich and dark, initially with a bit of licorice and Robitussin flavor but as it warmed and breathed the Raspberry still came through nicely. Quite warming. I miss this beer. sniff

name: Weyerbacher Winter Ale
review: This is what I prefer my winter ales to be like. On the darker side, not super spicy with some decent malt to it. Smooth mouthfeel. Flavor and overall almost an 8, but not quite. Only sampled a single to start, as was on clearance for a buck, but this is something I would seek next winter season.

name: Weyerbacher Winter Ale
review: Pours a dark cola brown with a thin off white ring. Medium carbonation with plenty of lacing. Light malts and some spices in the aroma. Fairly thin body. Taste is light spices with some cinnamon. Flavors aren’t very bold. Not bad, just not that great.

name: Weyerbacher Winter Ale
review: Quite good and thick. Very nice to drink and smells of fine brewed one. Great malty features and cloudiness.

name: Weyerbacher Winter Ale
review: Pours a medium brown color. Aromas of light chocolate, hops, and a touch of nut. Flavor has a smooth chocolate/coffee blend with a hint of nut, and a nice hop finish.

name: Weyerbacher Winter Ale
review: Deep amber pour almost brown with aromas of caramel, malt, light raisin and some light cherry. Flavors are the same nothing over the top just balanced theoughout.

name: Weyerbacher Winter Ale
review: Winter Weyerbacher. Very solid beer. Extremely well balanced, but possibly a tad boring because of it. Hints of cherry in the malt/booze, not too sweet, not too thick. Easy to consume for 7%. 3.6

name: Weyerbacher Winter Ale
review: 12 oz. bottle. Pours a rich, dark brown with very little head. Heavy malt on the nose and a thick caramel flavor. Not the best, not the worst. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Weyerbacher Winter Ale
review: Bottle. Pours dark brown with a fluffy head that dissipates to a thin beige head. Aromas of brown sugar and raisin. Flavors of brown sugar, dark fruits, spice and ginger. Finishes with a bit of breadiness. Creamy mouthfeel. Not bad.

name: Weyerbacher Winter Ale
review: Aroma - sweet malt Appearance - very dark brown body, good nucleation, unfiltered. Huge beige head over 2" and settles very slowly. Taste - sweet caramel malt, carmalized sugar, some adjunct spice. There is a bit of a molasses flavor as well. Palate - approaching full bodied, creamy texture, average carbonation, and short finish of some sweet malt.

name: Weyerbacher Winter Ale
review: A subdued aroma of a malt and fruit, pours a dark brown color without much of a head. Flat beer with a malt and fruit taste with a hint of bourbon. Watery feel and a malt finish.

name: Weyerbacher Light Irish Amber
review: Available only on tap at the now defunct brew pub... a "training" beer......

name: Aass Pilsner
review: For me this is my go to pilsner.Easy drinking, goes down well, and tasts good. I wouldn't go so far saying that it's some kind of masterpiece, but it does it's job.

name: Aass Pilsner
review: Clear gold, soapy white smattering of head. Grassy, hint of pepper. Typical pale pils, nothing special. Beer selection for Norway in EPCOT for #SnackCOT2019.

name: Aass Pilsner
review: 0,33l can. Pours ultra clean straw/pale golden with white head. Aroma of malt, grain, lemon peel, bitter hops. Taste is crisp, fresh, citrus peel, malty/grainy, watery, cardboard, hoppy bitterness in the finish.

name: Coors Extra Gold
