review: Walmart started selling this at 15 bucks a 30 pack. Who's gonna pass up a deal like that? Xtra gold is what it is. A decent lager best cold.

name: Coors Extra Gold
review: Really nice easy lager, when |I was 18 it was a very good beer, the women were cold but the beer was gold! Now I am 45 I lament on this old dear! The modern Coors Extra is rubbish and the pub has had become a Islamic furbish when I was 45 and the Masjid is a dive!

name: Coors Extra Gold
review: Pours a slightly darker yellow than Coors Banquet with a full white head that laces and stays. Nose slightly sweet cereal. Taste is Slightly sweet and smooth meaning the hop bitterness is slight. Body is fuller than CB and less crisp. Well baslancd beer. 12 oz can BBY 8/30/19

name: Coors Extra Gold
review: Found locally 16.99/30 pack. Coors best beer. Nothing fancy but nice full body. No headache

name: Coors Extra Gold
review: 12oz can poured into a Lager glass at 47°. Color is bright crystal clear gold with medium carbonation and a soft white head. Aroma is mild hop spice and a light corn like grain scent. It has a lighter body with a smooth yet crisp mouthfeel. Flavor is light, giving a nice pilsner malt base with a slight sweetness backed by a mild hop spice and ends with a light bitterness. Aftertaste is clean and the bitterness leaves it with a slightly dry feel. Overall it's not bad, I don't really like this type of brew but I would take it over most of them.

name: Coors Extra Gold
review: One of Coors True hidden gems when you can find it... pours a light golden color with a smooth and refreshing flavor..!! Supposedly a “blended beer” of Irish Red and Coors Light..?

name: Coors Extra Gold
review: Better than the standard coors because it has a hint of caramel sweetness. Tried at the brewery in 2007.

name: Coors Extra Gold
review: From old tasting notes. Light golden color has a greenish hue. Nice small bubbles support a medium white head. Light malty aroma of grain. Semi-sweet malt flavor with a wisp of hops. A small step up from Coors Banquet.

name: Coors Extra Gold
review: Poured from a 12 ounce can (identified as only Extra Gold Lager and no Coors about it) grabbed out from of a fairly chilled 30 pack into a 12 ounce thick glass mug. This is another 1 of ’dem ’dere beers I’ve been imbibing off and on for several years now. it works fine. Aroma: faint, far away grains and thin malts and hops but, acceptable enough to over see. It really does have a neato semi-darkish golden hue to it, from a clear glass mug, anyway. Jumping to overall: It doth good do to both pocket book and beer bud taste sensibilities. It’s a pretty simple brew, folks.

name: Coors Extra Gold
review: 12 oz. can. Pours a thin, well retained white head, over an effervescent yellow (SRM 4) body......nose is light malts, mild hops, slightly sweet, corn,balanced......taste is slightly sweet with pear, apple, corn tones, mild cereal, minimal hop bitterness......mouth feel, light body no alcohol, high carbonation, with mild acid. This is a mildly sweet version of this insipid style, and is very light and quenching. Rating below to style, above to enjoyment. BJCP 8/3/15/5/7

name: George Killian's Irish Red
review: Bottle at home just grabbed since didn’t want to go dateless this Monday. Another odd one to rate so late in game. Dusty amber. Nose is caramel and fruit punch. Tastes of cherry, caramel, herbal, slight paper. Odd aftertaste.

name: George Killian's Irish Red
review: Tried an 8oz sample at the Coors brewery in Golden, Colorado. Pours a pale red with a white head that disappeared quick. It has a light aroma and flavor. It's a nice easy drinking beer.

name: George Killian's Irish Red
review: A grown up Amber. Has a very full flavor. No bitter aftertaste. A very good Amber. Perhaps one of the best Ambers.

name: George Killian's Irish Red
review: I haven't seen this one in so long I thought they stopped making it. Pours a dark amber with a full linen head. The aroma is floral and a bit earthy, with nuts and bread. Sipping is faintly sweet. The overall flavors are lighter, which consist of toasted and floral elements, caramel, bread, and nuts. Slight floral aftertaste. Medium bodied and chewy in texture. I considered this a premium beer back in the day. Although nowhere near that status now, it still holds up pretty well.

name: George Killian's Irish Red
review: Twelve ounce bottle. Pours a copper-brown. Tastes a bit sweet like honey, with a touch of bread to give it a slightly thicker mouth feel. Slight lacing and just a little head.

name: George Killian's Irish Red
review: Taste great. 100% a step up from your other, readily available (Coors/Bud/Heineken etc) typical bar/restaurant beers. Its nothing that's gonna knock your socks off, but for a beer that's almost everywhere, its a solid "go to" when in doubt!

name: George Killian's Irish Red
review: 12 oz bottle. Pours a red brown gold with a thin persistent off-white head. Big malty biscuity scents. Taste has a vegetal overtone off the broad but flat malt character. Some balancing bitter in the the short dry fiz finish. Above average carbonation. I don’t think it works very well.

name: George Killian's Irish Red
review: Pours reddish amber with a thick white head. Aroma of sweet malt. Taste is malty with slight hop note punctuating throughout. Palate of earthy notes. Relatively plain and sweet brew.

name: George Killian's Irish Red
review: Nah, a little better than Coors Banquet, slightly more roasted malty flavor, but still a very watered-down industrial beer. Even from tap, it is very mediocre

name: George Killian's Irish Red
review: Found from bottle. Pours an inviting red-near copper color. The appearance is the best part. The taste is below average for the style but still enjoyable in mid-Fall from time to time.

name: Keystone Light
review: Alright listen up. Imma city boy and I had never even hear of this sh*t until my country ass roommate put me on. I won't sugar coat it. This is awful. overall one of the worst beers Ive ever tasted. HOWEVER. If you are A) locked up in a full day of yard work or B) just looking to shotgun some beers too pregame, Id say this is just about as good as your gonna do for a cheap light beer.

name: Keystone Light
review: 473ml can (TCrBF2018) (3:2:3:2:6=1.6) Just a corny lager, both aroma and taste. Not crazily offensive, in particular compared to some of the horrors at the fest, just crappy watery lager.

name: Keystone Light
review: My favorite light "water beer". Very refreshing on a hot day and you can pound them. Light grain and corn aroma and taste. Rated against other beers in the same class.

name: Keystone Light
review: Golden color with a white head. The light aroma is malty with grain and corn aroma. The taste is mildly sweet and thin/watery. Ok light lager.

name: Keystone Light
review: Cans and bottles when I was underage, Golden color with average non lasting head. Notes are skunked lager, corn, cereal grains, and awfulness. Thin and watery

name: Keystone Light
review: Have had many times before. Very bitter and only meant for consumption when looking for quantity. Still better than some of their competitors.

name: Keystone Light
review: Great easy drinking beer, light in colour and goes down well on a warm day.

name: Keystone Light
review: How: Large can. Where: From Target, had at the hotel room. Appearance: Pale yellow colour with a white head. Aroma: I suppose some sweet malt . Body: Watery body, medium carbonation. Flavour: Some malt and corn I suppose and a bit sweet, but there is something that is just not good. One sip was doable, two hard, the third had to be forced and I still had this huuuuuge can to go. Just couldn't do it. A few sips rest poured down the drain.

name: Keystone Light
review: Free can from Willows Liquor. Clear, pale golden appearance with a thin white head that quickly dissipates. Mild aroma of grains and corn. Similar flavor, adding mild sweetness and no bitterness. Light, thin and watery on the palate with a boring finish. Yikes.

name: Keystone Light
review: Aroma: Not very much of anything much but a near sweet smell and aluminum. Appearance: Light gold but with watery clarity. Taste: It's really ok, really. It won't kill you if this gets drunk. It's just ok, though. Palate: Inbetween nothing and something other. Overall: Ok.

name: Keystone Premium
review: Had this a couple times back in the day....when I drank swill in my delinquent years. I remember this much, that it could of been the worst beer I have ever had. For this reason, I am giving it the bottom of the barrel rating. Typical metallic, skunky, pee-looking grain-water. Would rather have a Busch, Old Milwaukee, or PBR.

name: Keystone Premium
review: Substandard beer. Thin and watery with more than a little stale maltiness, mostly isn’t he aftertaste.

name: Keystone Premium
review: Very similar to Coors Banquet, with the sweet malts/corn and hiccup causing finish. Only real difference is the alcohol is strangely more noticeable.

name: Keystone Premium
review: It is what it is. Really nothing special. Only good after working your butt off in the blazing summer heat. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Keystone Premium
review: 12 oz. can from grocery store. Pours clear. Very watered down taste. Not one I would buy again or take for free.

name: Keystone Premium
review: "carbonated pee-pee water. ummmmmm. you remember you’re mom telling you not to eat the yellow snow? well this is it, melted and fermented. take up a collection and buy good beer for cryin out loud!"

name: Keystone Premium
review: Hmmm...old notes, still worthy, here goes. When this was poured out, it was poured into a pint glass. The appearance was a light yellow color with a pretty good transparency about it. The head was white and quickly fading and it left no lacing. The smell had some cooked corn/roasty hay-like qualities, fairly grassy. The taste was semi-sweet and having a sort of off burnt corn quality about it. The palate sat extremely light and was very sessionable. Overall, this just another AAL to me.

name: Keystone Premium
review: Can (Old Notes)-Pours golden with a small head. Aroma of grains and corn. Taste is very similar. This light bodied brew is not bad as I was expecting worse.

name: Keystone Premium
review: 12 oz can pours golden with a white head. Aroma of malt and grain. Taste was pretty much the same. Average macro swill

name: Keystone Premium
review: Nastiest thing you could ever imagine outside Corona of course................

name: Keystone Ice
review: I use to be a budlight fan, but this stuff is SO MUCH better. I love it..its difficult to find because most local gas stations only carry 1 twelve pack, I guess because it's not popular. But I LOVE IT

name: Keystone Ice
review: It gets you drunk. It's cheap and does the job. As far as flavor it's shit and they should try a lot harder. Everyone is going to think it tastes different so a definite answer is up to you. In My opinion it isn't your high quality beer. This is Garbage beer for cheap drunks that don't care about quality. There after the buzz. This definitely puts out as far as a kick. Taste isn't on par.

name: Keystone Ice
review: Taste is harsh and tinny. I like Keystone Light okay but this tastes like a Keystone took a piss and somebody decided to can it.

name: Keystone Ice
review: Served from 24 oz can into pint glass. A 1" sudsy white head falls quickly with mild lacing. Clear pale straw with abundant streaming carbonation. Aroma of sweet malts and little else. Mouthfeel is light to medium, crisp and dry. Flavor is flat. Some malt sweet, a bit of cracker, maybe a hint of hops. Overall this beer just comes across as missing something in the flavor profile.

name: Keystone Ice
review: Gold color with a white head. Malty with an earthiness and a corn and a slight aftertaste.

name: Keystone Ice
review: Not the worst beer I’ve had but still this ain’t good it smells like apple juice with a hint of piss flavor wise it has a definite artificial apple juice taste overtire cheap I mean you can do worst than this but you can do a whole hell of a lot better but it’s cheap and it gets you drunk so that’s cool I guess

name: Keystone Ice
review: Found out of can. Slightly less bitter than the light version but subject to more of the aluminum taste when out of a can.

name: Keystone Ice
review: 24 oz. can. Hooray for 'full flavored' beer in grocery stores! Pours a clear, pale, urine color, with a big, fluffy, fizzy, white head. The nose is white bread, corn syrup, acrid pine, and wet grass. Sweet and syrupy, with a surprisingly unpleasant bitterness that I still can't get our of my mouth. Light body, with a slick, oily feel. Ugh *sigh* why did I pay actual money for this?

name: Keystone Ice
review: How: Large can. Where: From Target, had at the hotel room. Appearance: Light yellow colour with a white head. Aroma: Some malt, grain. Body: Watery body, medium carbonation. Flavour: Some malt and grain.

name: Keystone Ice
review: As a general fan of the post-Communist world's cheap, boozy, adjunct-laden lagers, it's a surprise to find that North America's can be soooooo much worse. Compared to the malty, boozy, bready goodness of say Saku Kange at a tenth higher, this alkaline, chalky, slightly banana-ish metallic vitamin-water base stuff is just terrible. Not again (24 oz can, Sayreville)

name: Moorhouses Pendle Witches Brew (Bottle)
review: Copper appearance. Aroma is nutty, malt, caramel and roasted. Flavour is malt, roasted, bitter, caramel and hops.

name: Moorhouses Pendle Witches Brew (Bottle)
review: Thanks dantomlinson for sharing! Clear copper body with a big foamy and persistent white head. Aroma is biscuits, malty caramel, berries. Taste is malty: caramel, toffee, a bit fruity. Nice mineral and malty finish. Medium body, soft natural carbonation, chewy texture.

name: Moorhouses Pendle Witches Brew (Bottle)
review: Spotty off white head left a blotchy cover on a finely carbonated copper coloured body. Malt & cream soda aroma. Medium bodied, chewy & sticky over the palate with a cloying finish. Bitter/Sweet tastes of berry, herbaceous, botanical, tea & hops with a bitter tangy finish.

name: Moorhouses Pendle Witches Brew (Bottle)
review: Taste: malty, some apricot fruit notes, some hops. Mild semi sweet fruit nose. Golden/orange hue, partly unfiltered, with an average head and lace. Medium body. Mellow.

name: Moorhouses Pendle Witches Brew (Bottle)
review: In my past life, I did not think that temperature matters. How wrong can a man be. It matters. A lot! This beer was not at all good when it was chilled. Really nice a room temperature. A fine deep (dark) golden beer with a fine head. Good intensity in the flavor. At right temperature. Balanced sweetness. Pleasant carbonation level. Easy to drink. Oily texture. Toffee, dried fruits and a bit bready flavor. Nice one. [Bottle from SPAR at Piccadilly Road (A6)in Manchester, England] Brewery #1899

name: Moorhouses Pendle Witches Brew (Bottle)
review: Soft foam and darker copper body. Soft aroma of tin and malt. Flavour is caramel ans soft wood hints. Medium finish. Rather boring.

name: Moorhouses Black Cat (Bottle)
review: Good considering the low abv, would have thought it was a porter if I hadn't known. Chocolate notes, rich.

name: Moorhouses Black Cat (Bottle)
review: From bottle in English pint. Pours dark brown with 1-finger frothy tan head and mild choc malt aroma. Smooth drinking with choc, smoke and a bit of spicy zest in the finish

name: Moorhouses Black Cat (Bottle)
review: From Jul 2008 I got this in a trade with getkrunkhoe. Thanks Carlos! This pours a dark brown with reddish hues and a very small head of foam that leaves the scene almost immediately. Just a ring around.. the glass left but it does have a little lacing. The smell is pretty darned nice! I get some dark chocolate, some fruit, some caramel, and some roasted malt. The taste is very nice as well! Good dark chocolate with some caramel brings a sort of ying yang with the sweetness/bitterness and there's some good dark fruity flavours with a touch of plum and some toffee. The more I sip, the more I notice the chocolate and that's making this son of a gun very tasty and very drinkable. Hell, 3.4%abv....I could drink quite a few of these, for sure. It's light bodied but not as light as I thought it would be. Carbonation is close to medium, and it finishes on a slightly sweetish note. This is my first real Mild Ale and I tell you what. I am now a fan! Great style and I envy the peeps in the UK for having a lot of them to choose from.

name: Moorhouses Black Cat (Bottle)
review: 500 ML bottle Black with hints of ruby, no head. Some spotty lacing. nose is dark and bitter chocolate, nuts and roasted grain. Taste is dark chocolate, subtle bitterness, toast and nuts. Some roasted grain. A bit thin and watery in the back and mid of palate but up front a nice beer. Solid for sipping.

name: Moorhouses Black Cat (Bottle)
review: No head, but some lacing. A lovely dark colur and a real hit of lightly bitter chocolate on the first sip. It was quite a surprise and very nice. The sweet and bitterness was nicely balanced and it had a very good low abv. I liked this a lot and I will seek it out again.

name: Moorhouses Black Cat (Bottle)
review: Bottle. Refreshing black mild ale with chocolate & roasted malt & bitter hop taste. (2008)

name: Moorhouses Black Cat (Bottle)
review: Butelka 500 ml. Ciemna ,brunatna barwa. Piana srednia ,bezowa. Aromat nikly,slodowy z karmelem i kawa. W smaku palone slody kawa karmel..dosc wytrawne.

name: Moorhouses Black Cat (Bottle)
review: Bottle sample at a tasting at the Beer & Beyond shop. Thanks kerenmk. Dark brown. Aroma of malt, caramel, nuts, toast, dark bread, minerals, vegetal notes. Sweetish flavor with malt, toast, nuts, caramel, minerals, bitter finish. Medium-bodied.

name: Moorhouses Black Cat (Bottle)
review: At the Beer and Beyond shop, Pours red to black with a beige head, aroma of toffee, caramel, roasted malt, flavor is slightly bitter and dry with chocolate and cocoa, medium bodied

name: Moorhouses Black Cat (Bottle)
review: Bottle. Thanks Danya F! Dark Brown. chocolate and toastiness, some dates and prunes in the nose, bitter and burnt toast in the mouth. light body, fizzy, a little burnt aftertaste. Pretty cool.

name: New Amsterdam IPA
review: Small white head, short lived, skimpy lace. Lightly hazy, amber colored brew. nose of malts, grains. Med/light bodied, lightly prickly carbonation. Lotsa grainy flavors, hops?? Dry, bready finish. East coast boring ass IPA. 12oz bottle from statelineliquors.

name: New Amsterdam IPA
review: Draught. Clear dark orange color with medium sized foamy off-white head, faint floral hops aroma, low carbonation, sweetish orange peel taste, medium hoppy finish. Very smooth and fruity.

name: New Amsterdam IPA
review: Looks can be deceiving. Very nice dark amber pour. Nose is floral. Taste is very watered down dry hops. Rated 11/15/2000

name: New Amsterdam IPA
review: Pours amber with a white head. Smells of citrus and caramel with some earthiness. Tastes earthy with some tea hints and a hint of spice on the finish.

name: New Amsterdam IPA
review: So, should the fact that no one has rated this beer since 9/03 worry me? Or maybe that the rating previous to that was in 5/03? Regardless here goes… Murky orange with a small off-white head. Aroma is almost non-existent. Flavor is flat semi-sweet Karo syrup. There are no hops to be found. This is not a good beer. Is this brewery is still in business? Next please.

name: New Amsterdam IPA
review: Medium copper color with some turbidity. Fruity, floral aroma. Tasty roasted malt flavor with a bit of sweetness. Hops become more pronounced as it warms, but not to the extent of many American style IPA's. Smooth, malty finish.

name: New Amsterdam IPA
review: Clear gold with a slightly grayish sticky head. Not much nose, but what's there has toffee notes. The description of the beer mentions Centennial and Cascade hops; don't get them at all. Very much a British-style IPA, with a toffee-butterscotch character. Finishes slightly sweet, which accents the toffee nicely. Pretty good stuff.

name: New Amsterdam IPA
review: copper color with a eggshell head, nice blends of sweet malt and floral hop gives this a honey character.

name: New Amsterdam IPA
review: Nice orange body with a medium eggshell-white head that dissipates fairly quickly. Floral aroma with some honey, relatively restrained. Flavor is tame, definitely not an American-styled IPA. The sweet maltiness is more noticeable than the hops. But the hops are there, floral and slightly citrusy. Slight bitter aftertaste. Good solid body, slightly chewy.

name: New Amsterdam IPA
review: I suppose an English style IPA since the hop profile was a bit restrained. A very good beer overall, however. Silky smooth going down; biscuit-like malty flavor; finishes with a crisp, subtle citrus hop flavor. Another strong New Amsterdam brew!

name: Paulaner Original Münchner Hell (Premium Lager)
review: Bottle. Aroma- bready and grainy maltiness, maybe with delicate herbal notes. Pale, clear, with a medium-high, creamy head. Taste- not bad, feels like a Dortmunder Export. Again bready notes play the main role. On the other hand, I'm missing some hoppiness, which could counter the malty side. No bitterness. Low bodied, with a low carbonation. Simple, correct, but quite dull Lager.

name: Paulaner Original Münchner Hell (Premium Lager)
review: Z³ociste klarowne piwo z z niez³¹ pian¹ która doœæ szybko opada. Aromat zbo¿owy, w smaku podobnie delikatne nuty zbo¿a i trawy. Niez³y monachijski hell

name: Paulaner Original Münchner Hell (Premium Lager)
review: Barwa z³ota, klarowna. Piana wysoka tylko przez chwilê, potem opada do zera. Goryczka prawie niewyczuwalna, lekki dms.

name: Paulaner Original Münchner Hell (Premium Lager)
review: Great beer,golden color but tastes more like darker beer with bready aroma. I liked it a lot.

name: Paulaner Original Münchner Hell (Premium Lager)
review: pretty alright industrial lager aroma, just a bit more hoppier than the typical industrial lager. looks like a typical lager. small white head. very nice taste, taste of hops. better than your average lager. a bit watery, not too big of a fan of that. 500ml can poured into a glass

name: Paulaner Original Münchner Hell (Premium Lager)
review: Butelka 0,5 litra, zakupiona w Auchan. Barwa z³ota, klarowna. Œrednia, bia³a piana, szybko opada. W smaku wyraŸna s³odowoœæ, goryczka œrednia.

name: Paulaner Original Münchner Hell (Premium Lager)
review: Shared pint can poured to snifters showing a clear & bright, golden hue, with a bubbly layer of soft white froth, and foamy spots of lacing. The nose was soft grain, Pils scent, with slight hints of spice & pear. Light to medium bodied, with lively carbonation, the taste was similar, adding a low but effective bitterness that was grainy, and subtly earthy. A very clean & drinkable Helles.

name: Paulaner Original Münchner Hell (Premium Lager)
review: 500ml bottle brewed in Germany at 4.9%. Pallid yellow-gold. Decent-sized, decent-lasting head. Grassy, malty, corny aromas. Moderate carbonation. Spicy, grassy, hop-dominated lager, which makes a change! Bitterness and sweetness well balanced, with the lager malt only really making itself known in the end of the mouthful, mostly just acting as a backbone to the hops and rounding the experience out quite well. One of the best Helles I've drunk. Unmistakably a lager, and unmistakably well-made.

name: Sierra Blanca Nut Brown Ale
review: On tap at the Airport Location. Poured a brown color with a thin sized head. Toasted nuts and some sweet chocolate.

name: Sierra Blanca Nut Brown Ale
review: Bottle.Earthy nutty chocolate malt aroma. Dark brown with a small tan head. Coffee, sweet chocolate, and light acidic flavor. Light body, moderate carbonation. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Sierra Blanca Nut Brown Ale
review: 12fl oz bottle poured into a shaker. Dark brown with half a finger tan head. Aroma is sweet malt. The flavor has a bit of chocolate but mostly earth. Not special but decent. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Sierra Blanca Nut Brown Ale
review: Draft sample on the Ruidoso restaurant balcony labeled as Bone Chiller; it is an alias based on their website. Dark chestnut color with a off-white head. Aroma is malty and milk chocolate. Bold taste with a hint of cherry fruitiness and coffee. Nice brown ale.

name: Sierra Blanca Nut Brown Ale
review: On tap at Rio Grande at the airport in Albuquerque, NM, where it was served at a ridiculously cold temperature. Clear, dark ruby brown with a small tan head and fair lacing. Aroma of chocolate, roasted malt, toffee, coffee and nuts. Taste of chocolate, roasted coffee, an interesting nutmeg spiciness, nuts, toffee and very mild roasted malt. Medium body and medium/high carbonization. Might be better if I had half an hour to let it warm to an appropriate temperature. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Sierra Blanca Nut Brown Ale
review: different label. $1.50 single at Total Wine. odd brew. middling feel, kinda generic. weird spice in the flavor. not really fitting the style, ok at best.

name: Sierra Blanca Nut Brown Ale
review: bottle shared with pals at club w, clear dark red pour with fruit, and malt aroma, taste is prune, and raisen, and some sweetness , not bad, not a huge fan of nut browns to begin with

name: Sierra Blanca Nut Brown Ale
review: Beer #79 of NM 100. On tap as Bone Chiller Brown. Nutty. Basic nut brown malt profile. Well balanced.

name: Sierra Blanca Nut Brown Ale
review: Poured from bottle into English pint glass. Pours a nice dark brown color, khaki head that goes from 1 finger to a couple mm thick but never completely dissipates. Aroma is very typical of an english-style nut brown - some chocolate notes, malt, typical fuggles hop nose present as well. I’m also getting something slightly earthy, almost funky, but not in a bad way - more mushroom/earth than barnyard. Taste is also typical english brown - lots of malt, chocolate, touch of coffee, mild hop - very nutty. Carbonation level is medium, but it’s nicely prickly on the palate. Mouthfeel is a bit thin, but given the style, not terribly out of whack.

name: Sierra Blanca Nut Brown Ale
review: Las Vegas, NV - Total Wine - Summerlin - 12 oz bottle. Dark brown pour, decently thick off-white head. Aroma of chocolate and chicory coffee. Flavor has some nice dark chocolate notes, some nuttiness, a bit of licorice in the back end. Nicely textured mouthfeel. Enjoyed this with a picnic lunch after hiking in Dead Horse State Park, Utah.

name: Youngs Dirty Dicks Ale
review: best before sept 03. Oh myyy. red brown pour some tan head. Aroma of booze out of control and whisky. Tastes super fruity. Bananas, cherries, crazy. This held up very well. Suprising.

name: Youngs Dirty Dicks Ale
review: "i’d prefer a good esb to this sweeter and slightly heavier version. not bad at all, the sweetness is nice if you’re in the mood, but i like a little more hops."

name: Youngs Dirty Dicks Ale
review: First tasted this in Gabriels, Paisley in October 1997. Cask, handpump dispense. Dark ruby red in colour with a thick white head. Strong fruit note of bramble in the short aroma. Thin mouthfeel and good lacing. Mixed malts give a fiery maltloaf base with strong overtones of tart redcurrant fruit. Spicy hop resins imparet a dry bitter aftertaste long in intensity. Finish is malty with dry vinous fruit still evident in the mouth. A decent session bitter.

name: Youngs Dirty Dicks Ale
review: From the aroma and color of this beer from is expecting a lot from the get go. Since the alcohol is a bit lower than usual for a premium beer the flavors have an opportunity to settle on the tongue longer. Reminds me of an Irish red ale but crafted a lot better and with better ingredients.

name: Youngs Dirty Dicks Ale
review: spruce, leaves, leather, clove, licorice, smoke, caramel, coffee, chocolate, red, sparkling, frothy, brown foam, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, lightly sour, medium body, sticky,

name: Youngs Dirty Dicks Ale
review: Bottle. Pours an amber body with an off white head. Malty body with caramel malts, light earth tones a hint of toffee and toast. Slight fruit tones appleish with a hint of paper and a lightly bitter toast finish. Eh alright.

name: Youngs Dirty Dicks Ale
review: Süßer Röstmalzgeruch, getreidige Töne nicht ausgeschlossen. Unerwarteter Antrunk, untertönig malzig, im Vordergrund steht ein vollmundig sauer-getreidiger Ton. Mit der Zeit entwickelt sich ein würziges Aroma, ebenfalls milder als erwartet. Dazu kommt eine malzige Note, die das erste Mal halbwegs die erdachte Stärke hat. Milder malzig-saurer Abgang, der zu später Stunde noch röstmalzern wird. Etwas entäuschend bei dem mehr versprechenden Geruch. Test vom 10.5.2007, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 10,10,8,9,11,9

name: Youngs Dirty Dicks Ale
review: Rather a shame this was retired. Nice dark colored bitter. Slightly caramely. Serving: Bottle

name: Youngs Dirty Dicks Ale
review: Originally rated September 2004. Poured an amber-orange colour with a fine head. The nose was fruity and hoppy. The taste, as well, was fruity (on the orange side). Could also taste the light caramel malts. Had a mild bitter finish. A pleasant english ale with a cool name, and a good story behind it (written on the label).

name: Youngs Dirty Dicks Ale
review: bottle-dirty water pour-aroma and taste of- sweet fruit-smooth bitter hop finish

name: Valley Forge Kings Gold
review: Part of the sampler at the brewery. Slight cream taste. Thas was about it. Nothing going on here.

name: Valley Forge Kings Gold
review: Clear gold ale with a very sticky white head. Light, sweet, refreshing. Not much special here. Not bad, but not great.

name: Valley Forge Kings Gold
review: ReRated to fix the typos in review: I honestly had more fun drinking my water than this beer. A bright yellow in the glass with zero head or aroma. The flavor was non existant in this beer. My gf actually said "Whats wrong?" when she saw me try it. It literally had nothing to it. Almost as if someone poured water into my beer and served it to me. AVOID unless you get a sampler.

name: Valley Forge Kings Gold
review: Cider gold, no head. Bits of hops and malt, nose restraned. Flavor is simply bad. Carbonation was screwed up and the flatness wasn’t intended, but the flavor itself was a mite sour and harsh.

name: Valley Forge Kings Gold
review: On tap. Poured a light yellow/gold. No notable aromas. Sweet with a vert light bitterness. This one didn’t do anything for me.

name: Valley Forge Kings Gold
review: Aroma: Low-level hop. Clean. Appearance: Crystal clear, good head retention. Gold colored beer with constant and quick rising bubbles. Flavor: Grainy malt, some steely flavor and slight chlorine/sanitizer notes. Some hops but very light. Sort of a musty flavor also that is off. Mouthfeel: Some astringency, otherwise OK. Overall: Not a bad beer, some odd flavors that would prevent me from drinking too many of these.

name: Valley Forge Kings Gold
review: A good gold ale, with an underlying sweetness and hop taste. Medium bodied, with a crisp, smooth finish. Not the best I've had, but not bad.

name: Valley Forge Kings Gold
review: Very clean light maize colored beer. Little to no aroma. Distinctly 'corny' flavor. Smooth, but pretty much uninteresting.

name: Valley Forge Kings Gold
review: Dry with a slightly sour aftertaste. Good body & good with food.............

name: Valley Forge Red Coat Ale
review: at the brewpub, wisps of white on top of a pale gold, aroma is pungent, as it almost makes my nose crinkle. flavor was weak and watery, little or no body and just not a very good example of the type.

name: Valley Forge Red Coat Ale
review: Part of the sampler at the brewery. Boring. Weak for an IPA. Alomost no hop flavor.

name: Valley Forge Red Coat Ale
review: Ligh amber/orange color. Definately taste and smell those cascades stronger than I expected. Pretty good ipa(but I still came for the imp. st.).

name: Valley Forge Red Coat Ale
review: Fairly decent IPA that when compared to the other offering of the brew pub truly stands out. Not a good thing. Mediocre hoppiness at the nose and on the palate was non existent. Just didn’t taste very fresh and I found this beer to be a little watery as well.

name: Valley Forge Red Coat Ale
review: Auburn. IPA nose, hoppy and citric. Hoppy and dry, not much citrus in the taste, just plain bitterness. Fizzy. Eh.

name: Valley Forge Red Coat Ale
review: On Tap. Poured a medium amber color with a white head. Citris and floral aromas and tastes. Some malts in the flavor but mostly hoppy bitterness. One of my favorite beers at the Brewpub tonight.

name: Valley Forge Red Coat Ale
review: Pours amber. with aromas of hops and flowers. Taste is dominated by bitter hops. It’s not balanced enough with the malt. Just an OK beer.

name: Valley Forge Red Coat Ale
review: Poured an amber color with a creamy white head and some lacing. Very fruity, citrus hop aroma. It had a sweet bubblegum and bitter hop taste with an average mouthfeel.

name: Valley Forge Red Coat Ale
review: This is a flagship brew for Valley Forge. A nice, heady reddish color with a malty, slightly floral odor. It goes down like a dream, with hints of grapefruit, caramel, watermelon, cherry, and cabernet (don't get me wrong...it is not sweet by any means). Very malty and hoppy on the finish, giving rise to the classic red ale taste going down. A rock solid red ale.

name: Valley Forge Red Coat Ale
review: Beautiful copper-red coloring. A mild start with hops present but not overwhelming. I had it on tap and it's definitely easy-drinking, but not exceptional.

name: Valley Forge Regiment Pale
review: From old tasting notes. Amber orange color. Thick, creamy, bubbly beige head. Soft, fruity malt nose. Spicy toasted malt flavor hints at toffee and grapefruit peel. Nicely balanced by a crisp spicy hop finish.

name: Valley Forge Regiment Pale
review: at the brewpub, sweet caramel aroma, deep golden color. nice balance in the flavor, blending from hop bitterness to sweet maltiness. not too bitter on the tail. very pleasant and drinkable.

name: Valley Forge Regiment Pale
review: Part of the sampler at the brewery. Tasted what is shoulf be. Nothing special. Very slight bitter taste.

name: Valley Forge Regiment Pale
review: Poued a copper colored body with a white head. A very tasty brew until I swallowed it. The aftertaste was just way too sweet.

name: Valley Forge Regiment Pale
review: A decent English pale that that will quench your thirst but won’t satisfy it . Malt was present throughout.

name: Valley Forge Regiment Pale
review: Copper. Nose quite British, malty with toffee and butterscotch. Very nice malts, caramel with a bit of peaty earthiness. Hops have a long, dry finish. Creamy as well, good palate. Really lovely stuff.

name: Valley Forge Regiment Pale
review: On Tap. Poured an amber color with a white head. Malty nose and flavor with a light bitterness to it. Not a bad beer.

name: Valley Forge Regiment Pale
review: Aroma: Relatively clean, low hop aroma. Flavor: Some malt, with low hop overtones. Not much flavor. A little steel-like off flavor. Appearance: Nice looking beer, good head retention, light amber. Mouthfeel: Relatively light body. Overall: Drinkable, not too full of flavor however.

name: Valley Forge Regiment Pale
review: A solid pale. Very hoppy, good, firm malt base, nice crisp finish. English styled, so it's not as sweet as other pales, and a tad maltier. Very smooth, drinkable pale ale.

name: Valley Forge Regiment Pale
review: A light copper beer with a frothy white head. Floral and peppery notes in the nose. Malty and rich flavor up front. Moderately hoppy with hints of straw and earth on the backside. Medium-bodied with a watery mouthfeel and fizzy carbonation. Short, crisp, clean finish.

name: Valley Forge Georges Porter
review: Cask. Pours dark brown with a medium head. Aroma coffee, nuts. Avery porter.

name: Valley Forge Georges Porter
review: at the brewpub, loads of chocolate malt coming off of a deep brown body with scarlet highlights and a nice cream colored head. the flavor was nice, a little oversweet with chocolate, but i personally liked that. the tail had a little more bitterness than i prefer, but the biggest complaint i had with this was it’s body, which was very thin and watery for a porter.

name: Valley Forge Georges Porter
review: Part of the sampler at the brewery. Slight roasty taste. Nothing special. A little weak.

name: Valley Forge Georges Porter
review: Medium dark brown body. Aroma is sweet carmel malts. Nice smooth carmel flavor with a little roasted malt in the finish. Pretty good.

name: Valley Forge Georges Porter
review: POured dark in the glass that when held up to the light burned red. No head whatsoever. Aroma was of roast and flavor followed suit with a discernable sweetnes throughout. Very watery beer for the style. Just wasn’t heavy enough.

name: Valley Forge Georges Porter
review: Poured a reddish, mahogany color with a thin to non-existant off white film for a head with very little lacing on the glass. Aroma of fudge, roast, chocolate, and sweet mollassas. Taste here was fairly bland as well, chocolate and roast, but a watery mouthfeel.

name: Valley Forge Georges Porter
review: Deep black-red, head lasted impressively. Light roasts in the nose, more assertive in the flavor, chocolate bitterness with some tartness and hoppiness.

name: Valley Forge Georges Porter
review: On tap. Poured a dark black with a tan head. Aroma of chocolate, coffee and roasted nuts. Coffee and chocolate flavors with a bitter finish. Watey body. Decent porter.

name: Valley Forge Georges Porter
review: Very full-bodied, malty porter with a subdued hop element. Very dark with medium sized head. Nice caramel, roasty, and chocolate overtones. Great with steaks or chocolate desserts.

name: Valley Forge Georges Porter
review: Very dark pour. Sparkling clear mohogany when held up to very bright light. Creamy, khaki-colored head. Mostly diminishing. The aroma is of roasted nuts, milk chocolate and coffee. Flavors of light chocolate and coffee up front. Fairly well balanced and moderately bitter, but a bit thin and watery on the backside. Barely medium-bodied with a watery mouthfeel and soft carbonation. Short and dry finish.

name: Valley Forge Peach Wheat
review: Pours a dirty, straw yellow body with a white head. Aroma is surprisingly that of a wheat ale with peaches. Flavor is a refreshing wheat taste with lots of peaches and a nice malt backbone. A little more body than most wheat beers. Very nice.

name: Valley Forge Peach Wheat
review: Part of the sampler at the brewery. I drank peach juice with fizz, what little there was, in this beer. No wheat or any other flavors.

name: Valley Forge Peach Wheat
review: Light, marginally hazy gold. Nose very peachy and sweet. Peachy, but not enough, finishes toasty and bready, an awkward transition.

name: Valley Forge Peach Wheat
review: On tap. Poured a hazy yellow with a white head. As the name implys, peach and wheat aroma and taste. Not much of a fruit beer fan but I enjoyed this one somewhat (although I would not drink too many of them in one sitting).

name: Valley Forge Peach Wheat
review: I tend to fill my growler with this one when it is available. A nice wheat beer with natural peach flavors and aroma. The peach is accompanied by a great malt base and subdued hoppiness. Be warned, though. This is not a "wimpy" peach ale. At 6% OH, it is rich and full bodied. I drink it as a dessert beer, or on hot summer days. Great with fruit trays and cheese.

name: Valley Forge Peach Wheat
review: Murky, creamy "almost blindingly" yellow. Sunshine in a glass! Small, almost fully lasting creamy white head. Thick lacing. The aroma is of a bucket of fuzzy, ripe peaches. The flavor? Peaches, Peaches, Peaches! Lightly malty up front. Well balanced with a mild hop presence on the backside. Very refreshing. Light-bodied with an oily mouthfeel and fizzy carbonation. Short, clean, dry finish. Great Summer fruit beer!

name: Valley Forge Peach Wheat
review: I'm not much for fruit beers, but this was pretty good. Peach flavor adds a nice little zing without overpowering the wheat malt. Not something that I could drink regularly though.

name: Valley Forge Peach Wheat
review: Fruity aroma & taste, had a zing to it like a Zinfendel wine, the more you have the more the peach tones come out, probably could only have one of these at a time

name: Valley Forge Peach Wheat
review: A very sweet fruity aroma. Cloudy yellow in color. Clean yet strong fruit flavor - the peachiness becomes more apparent as you keep drinking. An interesting concoction but not something to drink alot of.

name: Valley Forge Dortmunder
review: Dark gold in color. Lightly malty and clean. Highly drinkable. Nice lace.

name: Valley Forge Dry Stout
review: Very dark, almost black, but with a reddish tint when you hold it up to the light. Thin head lasts a long time. Crisp and bitter,with nice lace in the glass. Unfortunately, surprisingly thin and light bodied. Not good for a stout.

name: Richbrau Big Nasty Porter
review: Dark pour with thin tan head which quickly dissipates. Chocolate aroma with hint of coffee. Flavor was more coffee and kind of bitter, with milk stout hints at the end. Decent.

name: Richbrau Big Nasty Porter
review: Bottle sample at the Hopsnobbery Collective "From Russia With Suds" tasting on 1/2/10. Pours a clear light brown with a medium beige head. Aroma is roasty and a bit tart (infected?). Flavor is a bit roasty, but tastes more caramel than chocolate with some tartness in the finish.

name: Richbrau Big Nasty Porter
review: Sample at the "From Russia With Suds" tasting on 01/02/10: This brew pours brown with a medium beige head that recedes steadily. Stringy lacing. Roasted malt aroma with fruity notes. Medium, dry body with flavors of caramel malt, roasted coffee and tart fruits. The finish is roasty with a short malty aftertaste. Overall this Porter is neither Big nor particularly Nasty, especially not in the way the brewer implies on the label.

name: Richbrau Big Nasty Porter
review: On tap at Brewpub 6.4% Appearance: hazed brown with velvet grey , mid light top , fizzy centre. Nose: Roasty with sweet cocoa , slight milky feel. Clean burnt barley aroma. Very nice. 7+ Flavor/Palate : Mid bodied. Brown malts , smooth clear with feel of chocolate. Bitter finish. Good character shown.

name: Richbrau Big Nasty Porter
review: Dark brown with a thin white head. Aroma is chocolate, earthy and malt. Flavor is the same.

name: Richbrau Big Nasty Porter
review: Bottle courtesy of dkachur/ Pours brown with a thin white head. Smells earthy with some mellow chocolatey hints. Tastes tarte with some malty hints. Not very good.

name: Richbrau Big Nasty Porter
review: Bottle courtesy of Mike Miller, thanks Mike. Smooth going down with a choclate, cofee taste, then the hops kick in. Decent beer. If it was a little fuller it would get my attention more.

name: Richbrau Big Nasty Porter
review: Bottle, #388 Dark red pour, one of the lighter porters around, with a small head. Somewhat light aroma of chocolate and roasted malt. Same with flavor. Pretty enjoyable overall.

name: Richbrau Big Nasty Porter
review: Brown pour with small brown head from brewpub. Nutty, malty, with some caramel notes. Medium thin body, malty cloying finish. I do love the label though.

name: Richbrau Big Nasty Porter
review: On tap at the brewpub. Color reminded me of cranberry juice. Aroma of vanilla, caramel and hops. Taste of strong caramel, toffee and chocolate. Medium bodied, slightly bitter. Very nice. 7/4/7/3/15/3.6 Bottle from the brewpub opened 4/30/08. Ruby color with a small head. Aroma of coffee, chocolate and dirt. Taste is a bit metallic, with chocolate and mocha. 6/4/7/3/14 /3.4

name: Richbrau IPA
review: From Jun 2008 I got this bottle in a trade with jwc215. Thanks Joe! This English IPA pours a hazy orange gold with a 1 finger head of billowy foam. There's some lacing and the head retention is very good. It has a nice nose of pine and citrus hops, caramel, and some bready notes. The taste is hoppier than I'd hoped for, considering the style. Big piney notes with big doses of grapefruit give it a pretty bitter flavour. There's some nice fruitiness here(good) and a bit of caramel malt sweetness in the background but there's not enough of it(malt) to give a real balance and that's something I was looking for. Fairly light bodied and on the higher side of medium carbonated, it finishes very much on the bitter side with a long, lingering aftertaste. This is more of an American IPA in my book so in that respect, I'm somewhat disappointed but still, it's pretty drinkable and tasty. I'm certainly glad I got a chance to try it!

name: Richbrau IPA
review: Pours golden amber with medium white head. Big hops in the aroma. Bitterness in the aroma gives way to citrus lemon and hint of orange. Finish is actually not too strong, interesting flavor balance.

name: Richbrau IPA
review: On tap at Brewpub 6.2% Appearance: good amber , clear look , mid off tanned top. Some lace on sides.3+ Nose: clean , true fresh IPA in west coast style/ Citric – grapefruit with sweet malts.8- Flavor/Palate : Mid full bodied. Full out on high alpha hop , bitter leafy mid with slight metallic feel. Bold , bit one sided with more pronounced with time.

name: Richbrau IPA
review: Bottle at my refrigerator reduction tasting on 8/15/09. Bottle has a plain paper label that is less impressive than most homebrew labels I’ve seen. Starting to get worried. Pours cloudy orange with a medium beige head. Orangy hops aroma with some malt. Very orangy hop flavor (Centennial? Amarillo?) with a bit of sweet malt balance and a lasting bitter finish. Guess I won’t be judging a book by its cover again.

name: Richbrau IPA
review: 22oz bottle courtesy of Kevin. Pours a hazy amber with a decent sized white head. Some nice lacing. Very citrusy nose yet there is some hop earthiness as well. I am guessing Simcoe and Cascade in this one. Up front a spicy resiny bitterness with some strong grapefruit and orange peel. Finishes bitter and earthy. Very very good IPA.

name: Richbrau IPA
review: Pours golden amber with about an inch of head. Decent amount of hops in there as well. You can tell this is an east coast IPA. No floral aroma or much to speak thereof. Laces the glass nicely though. Medium bodied. More of an upfront bitter taste. What I hear from Maniac given the price of this stuff it’s not too bad.

name: Richbrau IPA
review: Growler filled by maniac. Clear orange amber with large big bubble offwhite head and decent lacing. Spicy floral hop aroma. Flavor is perfumy and floral citrus hops. Medium chewy body with moderately low carbontion, but that could easily be attributed to the growler. Bitter finish.

name: Richbrau IPA
review: Date: 11/2/2008 Source:Richbrau Brewery Keg from the brewery. Nice grassy citrus nose. Huge fluffy creamy head with long retention. Moderate grassy floral hops notes over pale and caramel malts to balance. Clean dry finish with moderate bitterness. Dead on for the style. Quite enjoyable.

name: Richbrau IPA
review: Bomber courtesy of dkachur. Pours copper with a nice white head. Smells of sage, oranges, dry malt, ginger. Tastes of pepper, spice, sweet pepper, resin, light bitterness. Excellent!

name: Richbrau IPA
review: Bottle from the brewery. Pours bronze colored with a small head and good lacing and retemtion. Bitter and floral hop aroma. Taste is hops (woody) with a hint of honey sweetness. Somewhat vegetal.

name: Kootenay Mountain Ale
review: 341ml bottle pours a light brownish color with a finger and a half of off-white head that leaves some spotty lacing on the glass. Aroma is caramel with hints of chocolate and some flowery hops. Taste is light caramel and chocolate malty sweetness with a modest hop bitterness in the finish. Light to medum body with adequate carbonation leaving a nice tingle on the palate. Quite a well done brown ale that I would recommend to others.

name: Kootenay Mountain Ale
review: Kootenay Mountain Ale--2001 12 oz. Bottle. 5.50% ABV. (3.5 / 5.0) ESB--Clear amber red color. Mild floral slightly toasted front. Slightly earth toasted bisquit body. Earthy almost ESB fruitiness. Ends mildly New hop spicy. Tasty but off to my taste. ESB or Amber? Sampled 8/6/2001.

name: Kootenay Mountain Ale
review: Ah, The Kooter. This brings me back. I don’t know where they get licorice and strawberry. I got creamed corn and grains. Slight metalliic taste, undoubtedly from the can. A bit bitter. I’d only drink this to be nostalgic of Spring Break 2003.

name: Kootenay Mountain Ale
review: ***review from May 5, 2007*** Nice deep crystal clear copper brew with minor effervesance and a quick fizz-up / quick death cap with no lacing. The aroma is on the mild side; at least it is not offensive. The dominant smell is of the sweet lightly toasted malts. as well as a touch of fruitiness and an initial short-lived weak rootbeer quality. Taste is pleasant with notable hops that leave some spicy bite but mainly the sweet light toasted malts with a faint caramel flavour . Don’t forget a touch of metallic flavour that actually isn’t terrible. I like the bitterness throughout - it does have a nice bite to it. Mouthfeel is smooth with fine carbonation and a lasting, pleasant bitter after taste. that surges mid-sip and then gradually fades. Light to medium bodied. Good easy drinking, smooth and mild beer that I would leave on the counter for awhile to max out the flavours.

name: Kootenay Mountain Ale
review: Bottle (6 pack bought at the brewery gift shop); Reddish amber, almost chestnut color, with a fizzy but kinda sticky head. Starchy to be sure and the tinny carbonation of a macro. Bit sugary. Liked it better when I tried it on tap at the brewery, but after all the fine beers I’ve been drinking for the past several hours, it’s a hard act to follow. This is a Canadian version of Shiner Bock -- a dark-colored macro lager -- sweet, adjuncty and almost corn-syrupy, but somehow still quaffable. Brown Ale? Not. (#2911, 5/17/2007)

name: Kootenay Mountain Ale
review: 341ml brown bottle. Deep amber colour, light tan head is fluffy and large. Aroma is caramel and just a bit flowery. Caramel malt flavours, a bit hoppy toward the finish, elements of citrus and trace metal with some toffee. Medium body and carbonation.

name: Kootenay Mountain Ale
review: Deep copper in color, clear and has a decent 2 finger off-white cap with moderate retention....good lacing on the glass..medium-high carbonation. Aroma gives off light berry tones over mild caramel malt and some citrus hopping. Medium to light body, slick mouth feel. Caramel malts up front with the unmistakable piney tang of Pacific NW Willamette and Nugget hops. Finish is wet where you can taste the licorice and toffee tastes which prevail over the metallic twang of the Yakima valley hops. Not really a brown ale but a NW variation. A very decent ale from a brewer most people write off as a Labatt maco brewer.

name: Kootenay Mountain Ale
review: Deep amber brown, thin tan head. Caramel and brown sugar aroma. Same on the palate, some malt, with a metallic tang in the finish. Not bad, but not great either.

name: Kootenay Mountain Ale
review: First found this beer in BAnnf, and was pleased to find it at home in Winnipeg. Was sad to drink one of my last two bottles, but it just winked at me when I opened the beer fridge.

name: Kootenay Mountain Ale
review: Clear copper colur with thin off white head. Mild malt nose. Flat mild malt taste with slight alcohol finish.

name: Kootenay Black Lager
review: 341ml bottle pours almost black in color with a small off-white head that leaves some specks of lacing on the glass. Aroma is roasted grains with hints of chocolate and some hops. Taste is chocolate malt sweetness with some roasted grain and mild hoppy bitterness in the finish. Light in body for the style and moderately carbonated. A decent brew, but could have been much better.

name: Kootenay Black Lager
review: Old Tasting Notes. Drunk in Creston, BC, Canada: Nose has coffee and mince meat. Taste is smokey bacon with coffee and chocolate. Nice mix and surprisingly well-balanced. Finish is long with smoke.

name: Kootenay Black Lager
review: Kootenay Black Lager--2001 12 oz. Bottle. 5.50% ABV. (4.25 / 5.0) Black Lager--Rich toasted front. Clear deep red black color. Spiciness starts in middle and dissolves to creamy end. Toasted flavor permeates brew. Spicy tangy toasted cherry fruit ale like body. Tangy creamy end. Rich. Sampled 8/6/2001.

name: Kootenay Black Lager
review: ( From tasting notes dated 3/6/03)....had one of these in the Fernie hotel trekking to Vancouver on the #3....I wish this one was more widely available as it gave the best representation of a Munich dunkel we could get in Calgary before the OSB Dark was available. Poured a deep cola color with red highlights. Modest off white cap...Aroma was nearly all caramel malt with light wisps of willamette hops. Medium- light body, wet, smooth mouth feel. Toasty caramel up front, some coffee and walnut tones balanced by the NW nobles finishes faster than I’d like with a light malty sweet aftertaste. This beer is still available occasionally in draft form made for specific events and customers who sell the draft under the house name.

name: Kootenay Black Lager
review: (Bottle) Probably the best beer thay don’t make anymore. Typical. Nice roasty flavor that is lighter than expected. Cleanly well brewed.

name: Kootenay Black Lager
review: Aroma of malt, with a slight undertones of coffee and chocolate. Pours a very dark brown with a nice head. Quick pouring results in cascading effect. Mouthfeel is slightly creamy. Alcohol seems stronger and shows up at the end. Hops are not really evident.

name: Kootenay Black Lager
review: Black, with tan head.Sweet malt nose. Sweet roasted chocolate malt flavor with noticeable alcohol heat. Slightly gassy

name: Kootenay Black Lager
review: This is a strange lager,great first taste,malted,slightly burnt yet still mild,,gets a little tiring after 3,drink in very small batches,or switch to something sour in between beers.

name: Kootenay Black Lager
review: This is an excellent dark beer. Exceptional flavour, don't know how it tastes after a few, but 1st was great.

name: Kootenay Black Lager
review: The flavour is not as dark as the colour. The initial taste disapears too quickly although the aftertaste is not unpleasant and does last a while making you want that next ounce. Not bad for Labatts.

name: Local Color Corporate Jims Pale Ale
review:
Sharp hop aroma of grapefruit-orange-citrus and floral character with a jolt of butterscotch over a tired malt base. Hazy golden body with low but lasting, fine-bubbled, white head. Grapefruit hop flavour is sharp with fairly assertive bitterness, strong butterscotch and very little malt character to note. Light
…

name: Local Color Corporate Jims Pale Ale
review: Purchased a bottle in Ann Arbor. Poured a hazy light gold with little head. The aroma is oranges with some flowers. The taste is taosted bread with some peanuts and a salty finish. There is also some grapefruit goodness here. Not as bad as the ratings would show.

name: Local Color Corporate Jims Pale Ale
review: This beer just flat out sucks. The label is cheesy!! Can you picture being seen holding a bottle of this? Something Donald Trump would be drinking...

name: Local Color Corporate Jims Pale Ale
review: This is a really poor pale ale. Like a poor homebrew or something. Grainy and harsh.

name: Local Color Corporate Jims Pale Ale
review: Bottle. Not much here, somewhat watery, little hops. Maybe just a bad bottle.

name: Local Color Corporate Jims Pale Ale
review: Aroma is slightly hoppy, somewhat similar to Molson Golden. Appearance is slightly cloudy with little head. As has been mentioned before, this tastes like "hop water" with next to no malt character to back it up. Corporate Jim tastes like a corporate product.

name: Local Color Corporate Jims Pale Ale
review: Watery, grainy and all around poor beer. The label may be the worst I've seen. No body to speak of, thin and gritty.

name: Local Color Corporate Jims Pale Ale
review: This one was just silly all the way around. Bad approach. Clean, miniscule hops some citrus. Poor.

name: Local Color Corporate Jims Pale Ale
review: I'm usually more forgiving than this, but this is hop pellet juice and water. Worse misfire than Dark Horse's Crooked Tree IPA.

name: Local Color Corporate Jims Pale Ale
Local Color No.VI Brown Ale
review: Okay, but not great. Weak head and typical aftertaste that lasts much too long on the back of the throat.

name: Local Color No.VI Brown Ale
review: This is better than the rest of their beers, it just has the same problems as the rest of their beers. It's uninspiring to begin with and then fizzles out way too quickly.

name: Local Color No.VI Brown Ale
review: This is the one Local Color brew that may be worth drinking. It does have some interesting roasty chocolate tones if you are patient enough to wait out the weak body.

name: Henry Weinhards Red
review: memory rating..fairly sweet beer...malt caramel and spices...light hop...was ok back in the day.

name: Henry Weinhards Red
review: "a pretty boring beer all around. another prime example of a macro-micro. a huge step up from other Miller products (as are the other HW brews) but still not worth the money."

name: Henry Weinhards Red
review: 12oz bottle (Old Notes)-Pours a lighter amber with a small head. Aroma of malt and slight caramel. Taste of the same with some sweetness. This light to medium bodied brew is not bad.

name: Henry Weinhards Red
review: Poured a medium orange, nose was tainted with mold and chalk. taste was thin and lacked any sweetness.

name: Henry Weinhards Red
review: Oh Blue Boar. Poured a light amber-golden. Clear and mildly spice/malty. Pretty boring, but drinkable.

name: Henry Weinhards Red
review: draught into pint glass years ago. I remember nothing good or awful about this beer. It was average across the board,

name: Henry Weinhards Red
review: Had this beer on 5/15/1999. Color is a deep brown with good carbonation but a thin head. Aroma is a sweet lightly roasted malt scent. Taste is sweet, light and clean. It starts with somewhat light body that goes down with a smooth malt flavor. The finish is a crisp lightly roasted malt flavor and light hop flavoring. It’s a bit lighter than I think good red should be.

name: Henry Weinhards Red
review: Bronze to copper in color with a wispy white head. Minimal nose with hints of biscuits and light caramel. LIght caramel and toasted grain flavors. HInts of herbal hops. I keep looking for more, but there is not a whole lot more in this one.

name: Henry Weinhards Red
review: Bottle. Didn’t know it was retired, still at the grocery store here. Pours amber in color with an off white head. Aroma of malt. For being so cheap it has a decent malty character, I used to think it was good which is why I tried it again with a more experienced palate. Taste very similar to the amber, and is also overly sweet. This could be old beer. I like the style of the bottle and we used to drink quite a bit of this stuff since it looked expensive but was very cheap in the thick cardboard 12 packs.

name: Henry Weinhards Red
review: Similar to Weinhard’s Dark, but red instead of brown. Similar light malt and hop character and mild sweetness.

name: Young's Winter Warmer (Bottle)
review: From old tasting notes. Splendid garnet red color with a creamy beige head. Small bubble carbonation. Toasted malt aroma reminiscent of baked bread. Sweet toasted malt flavor with a hint of treacle and brandy. Bittersweet finish where the hops come through. Long bitter aftertaste. Hearty to say the least. Good for the cold winter nights of London.

name: Young's Winter Warmer (Bottle)
review: Bottle. Dark Brown in colour. Malty; roasty malts, caramel, some chocolate notes. Hoppy; slight hops. Fruity; some fruit. Spicy. Sweet malty fruity with a slight bitter edge. Dry bitter malty finish. (2008)

name: Youngs Pilsner
review: brewed for purpose. Nothing to excite. Some flavour but generally a bit weak and watery with a bit of carbo

name: Youngs Pilsner
review: I coulda done w/ out this brew... overly thin and grainy... a kinda crappy flavor...

name: Youngs Pilsner
review: [i]Draught at Bishops Arms, Göteborg, some time ago[/i]. Pale golden, small head. Weak malt aroma but a fresh citric and floral hop profile. A bit watery, but quite soft mouthfeel. Good bitterness.

name: Youngs Pilsner
review: Tap. Very pale yellow with thin film head. Aroma is mildly hoppy. Taste is hoppy as well and not very sweet. Slightly watery mouthfeel.

name: Youngs Pilsner
review: Draught at the brewery. Clear golden with a rocky white head. Spicy hop aroma. Crisp malt and sticky hop flavor. Quite nice. Wow, either I got the one good batch ever made of this stuff or it ships extremely poorly.

name: Youngs Pilsner
review: Draught at Calthorpe Arms, London. Golden color with creamy head. Malty nose with hints of melon. The flavor is malty and moderately bitter with herbal hop and mineral notes. Minerals and bitterness in the finish. Single-minded pilsner.

name: Youngs Pilsner
review: Lgith musty lage nose, yellow color, bubbly low fizzy head. Grainy taste, some vegetable, light tingly hop bitter. Thin, pale. Not a good pils

name: Youngs Pilsner
review: Draught at the Lamb - not too bad. Golden wiht medium carbonation and a small fast diminishing head. Medium bitter nose - a bit weak fresh lemon taste, but still decent.

name: Youngs Pilsner
review: [At the Duke of Wellington, Notting Hill, London] A light yellow beer with a white head. The aroma is primarily of citrus, combined with light notes of malt. The flavor is of lemon and malt - on a thin body. Boring.

name: Youngs Pilsner
review: Draught. Golden coloured. Slightly hoppy aroma and flavour. Fresh and rather good.

name: Youngs Export
review: Complete crap. I’m a fan of British beers, but this is just crap. Taste like no lager I’ve ever tasted. Strange after taste. When in London avoid at all cost.

name: Youngs Export
review: Golden, small head. Aroma is floral and from toffee. Toffee comes back in the flavor together with some bread. Bitter finish, a good lager.

name: Youngs Export
review: Yellow/golden, smalle head. Aroma is clearly malty from toffee and butter. Flavor is malty with floral touches. Buttery palate and a somewhat bitter finish. This was a nice surprise to me...

name: Youngs Export
review: Young's Export Premium Lager, Keg Pale color. Undistinguishable aroma. Light taste, but with an original flowery note (elderflower). Dry.

name: Youngs Export
review: On Tap, The Courthouse, Dartford. Slightly fuller bodied than the Pilsner with a more prounced malt presence and a better balance with the hops. Remains good tasting for longer than the Pilsner. Salty finish.

name: Youngs Export
review: I had this side-by-side with the Young's Pilsner. This had just a wee bit more head than the pilsner, but not enough to discount the possibility of just two different glasses. Perhaps it is a faint shade darker (more orange) as well, but close enough to make no odds. You really wouldn't necessarily pick these two apart by appearance. Grassy, dusty aroma, with a pretty ugly similar flavor. At home this would have been a drain pour, but at the pub it was just the better part of a half-pint left on the table as I left. (on tap, Kings Arms, Oxford)

name: Youngs Export
review: Sampled on tap in London. Pale, glowing golden. Thin head but tons of lace. Malty nose with a hint of hops. Very flavorful--lightly fruity, prefect hop bitterness in the finish. A damn fine lager.

name: Youngs Export
review: Draught: I had this on tap at a pub called the Spread Eagle in London. The beer was a nice golden color. It had a little head, with not much carbonation to it. There was a slight hop aroma to it. There was also a similar mild hoppiness to the taste. This had a good bit more of a malty body than your typical lager. Very smooth. I'm guessing that it is very different in bottles than on tap, based on other reviews of this beer.

name: Youngs Export
review: tsandard lager,bland malt base with a light hop finish. expected better from Youngs.

name: Youngs Export
review: Complete crap. I'm a fan of British beers, but this is just crap. Taste like no lager I've ever tasted. Strange after taste. When in London avoid at all cost.

name: Bowes Special 7 Double Dry
review: Can 355ml. Many thanks to the best MC. Pours clear with low-medium white head. Some lacing. Aroma is of corn, sugar. Taste is of corn, sugar. Palate: Light-medium body. Somewhat thick. Medium carbonation. Overall: What do you expect?

name: Bowes Special 7 Double Dry
review: Sample from can at a tasting. Clear gold pour with thin bubbly white head. Aroma is grainy, lots of corn, sweet, light metallic. Taste is sweet, grainy, no hops. Palate is watery with med carbonation. It is what it is.

name: Bowes Special 7 Double Dry
review: Can, courtesy of myself, split 4-5 ways during a tasting. Pours a clear golden with a small white head that leaves nice lacing. Nose is of fruity corn, pretty standard cheap swill. Taste is pretty weak, maybe lightly sweet and offering more corn but that’s about it. Body is light, thin and watery, corn water if you please. Overall a pretty mediocre beer, we ended up drain pouring more than half of that 12 oz can...

name: Bowes Special 7 Double Dry
review: Can. Shared by mathieuc, thanks! Clear golden with a medium white head and little lacing. Aroma is of grains/corn, herbal presence, light sweetness and alcohol. Taste is less boozy, but it’s also sweet and corn forward with a little herbal presence. Light body. Medium carbonation. Bland finish. Not offensive. Somewhat drinkable. Bland and uninteresting.

name: Bowes Special 7 Double Dry
review: 355ml can. Clear golden yellow with a foamy white head. Flavors are cardboard, jelly sweets and corn syrup. Cloying sweet. Light body, fizzy carbonation, watery texture.

name: Bowes Special 7 Double Dry
review: can. pours clear bright golden with a small creamy white head, some retention and lacing. booze, sweet honeyed and caramel malts, but mostly malt extract, faint miscellaneous fruits - grapey, fusel, bland grassy herbal hops. moderate carbonation, light body - oily a bit sticky, semi-sweet and lightly astringent grassy finish. blah.

name: Bowes Special 7 Double Dry
review: Malt Likka don't quit, it's like zombie ODB all up in yo shit. Wu-tang 4 life.

name: Bowes Special 7 Double Dry
review: 7/13/13. Can thanks to mathieuc!!!!! Pale golden caramel with a small khaki head. Light pale malts, caramel, some fusels and fruitiness.

name: Bowes Special 7 Double Dry
review: Aluminum can share thanks to Tuba PhD. String adjunct, corn aroma. Moderate to high CO2. Slight aroma and flavor of sharpie markers. Phenols are best suited for weizens. Pepper gets stronger as it warms. ---Rated via ws; sp

name: Bowes Special 7 Double Dry
review: Thanks for this malt liquor, Shawn. Pale golden pour with a white head. A hint of bread, lots of sweet grain, grass, and corn. A bit of water, some metal, and grape juice. The flavor is sweet and grainy. The flavor is quite sweet. Grain, grape juice, and some corn. There’s a bit of water, metal, and grass.

name: The Three Stooges Beer
review: "a thin beer that smells of cereal with a little cheap beer too. Not skunky, so not horrible, but a pretty poor beer overall. tasted like cheap cereal. great name and bottle, though!"

name: The Three Stooges Beer
review: 355ml bottle pours straw in color with a finger of head which settles very quickly leaving no lacing. Aroma is light malts and hops. Taste is of a typical macro lager. Enough said.

name: The Three Stooges Beer
review: Bought it as a joke plus the single bottle was dirt cheap. You get what you pay for. Pale yellow lager. Funky malt nose and taste. Rated 2/3/2000

name: The Three Stooges Beer
review: This beer is getting some low ratings, however, I’m going to have to go against the grain a little on this. The beer I had is of unknown vintage, and unknown storage conditions. However, it was really not bad at all, the beer was very sweet showing almost all malt character and very nice caramel notes. There was very little hoppiness which could be due to being older. I also did not detect a whole lot of oxidation. Not bad at all, but not great either. Definately drinkable though and worthy of a fair rate.

name: The Three Stooges Beer
review: Unbeknown to me, this was sitting in a friend’s fridge for several years. Perhaps it was the age, but this tasted like a bock, having a strong malt presence and smooth finish. Would like to try a fresh sometime.

name: The Three Stooges Beer
review: (bottle - 12 oz) Had this one quite a while back but never rated it. Clear gold color with a very thin white head. Smells like a beer pretty much. Some dry hops and grass mixed with some malts. Flavor is pretty much the same. Dry hops mix with some hay and corn near the beginning and ends with a slightly dry and bitter malt and hop finish. Kudos to the awesome package though.

name: The Three Stooges Beer
review: Bought a case to frame for the bar. Bad beer but great pictures. Buy the case and keep the cardboard and bottle caps. Pour the beer in the sink.

name: The Three Stooges Beer
review: 12oz bottle. Just a plain american macro tasting pale lager, that is sold in a gimic six pack. Each cap has a different Stooge face, whoopie.

name: The Three Stooges Beer
review: Bought this for the label (see, marketing sometimes ropes us all in). Pours pale straw with some fizziness. Smells of creamed corn and skunky. Tastes watery with a stray hop or two. Basically Coors Light with a cool label.

name: The Three Stooges Beer
review: Oh man I hate to do this. This beer is VILE, second only to that Birra Morretti crap. I love the 3 Stooges, how could this be sold in their name. I had to pur it after one sip. I can’t possibly describe it in terms of beer, maybe isopropyl alcohol with some finger nail polish remover (acetone) thrown in. Never again, sorry Moe, Larry, Curly.

name: SLO Olde Highland Ale
region: San Luis Obispo, California, United States
review: Had this beer on 5/2/1998. Color is a medium golden brown with light carbonation and very little head. Aroma is a sweet fresh malt scent. Taste is like liquid ass. It starts off with a light creamy body that goes down cool and smooth. The finish is where this one kicks you’re ass with a heavy malt flavor that is full of some weird smoke flavoring. Its just bad.

name: SLO Olde Highland Ale
region: San Luis Obispo, California, United States
review: Amber color. Roasty, husky flavor and aroma. Bartender said it wsas like Guinness but was not close - more like a 80 Schilling with some roasted notes.

name: SLO Olde Highland Ale
region: San Luis Obispo, California, United States
review: a carmelly malty & smokey aroma lifted from the bronz..pretty solid smokiness and very malty w/ some carmel sugariness..pretty good for the style..whatever that may be..but doesnt do it for me...some sweetness in the very end with smoky carmel in the aftertaste

name: SLO Olde Highland Ale
region: San Luis Obispo, California, United States
review: Decent Scottish style ale, not as rich and complex as actual Scottish examples, such as Belhaven or Traquair House. Lighter in body and lighter in flavor. Still it had a clean malty flavor.

name: SLO Olde Highland Ale
region: San Luis Obispo, California, United States
review: Amber Ale, Slightly stronger than the Garden Amber. It has a spicy, smoky flavor- i.e. a scotch ale – finish is light

name: SLO Olde Highland Ale
region: San Luis Obispo, California, United States
review: Nice amber color and decent aroma but the body was lacking and the flavor was not altogether there for a Scottish ale, not enough smokiness or sweet chewiness. Guess they're not bottling this any longer?

name: SLO Olde Highland Ale
region: San Luis Obispo, California, United States
review: I can see how this can be a favorite for some. It's got some subtlety if you're patient. I found it had sweetness in the aroma that didn't carry through to the taste. For scottish ales, I'm looking for a bit of sweetness to taste balanced by peat, tobacco, and/or wood flavors. This had mild examples of both of these poles and though it had some texture and subtlety, it didn't have enough of what a Scottish ale means to me. Imagine Moylan's Kiltlifter on estrogen.

name: SLO Olde Highland Ale
region: San Luis Obispo, California, United States
review: Definetely one of my favorites. The hops are present, but not overstated. Good blend makes it a smooth yet engaging brew. whats slo stand for anyway.

name: SLO Olde Highland Ale
region: San Luis Obispo, California, United States
review: A decent beer, nice malt nose and a fair hop finish, quite clean tasting....

name: SLO Olde Highland Ale
region: San Luis Obispo, California, United States

name: Atlantic Coal Porter
review: Pours black with three finger, light tan head. Aroma is cocoa, roast and a hint of smoke. Taste is light caramel, warming to roast, coffee and a touch of hops. Finish is roast. A decent porter.

name: Atlantic Coal Porter
review: 12 oz bottle bought in Bar Harbor, Maine. Pitch black pour with a beige head and very good retention. Very good lacing. Has a nice, deep rich dark chocolate and dark roasted malt flavor. No coffee notes. Medium body. Smooth.

name: Atlantic Coal Porter
review: On one hand nice roasted toasted notes on other hand thin and acetic. Okay

name: Atlantic Coal Porter
review: Draft at Flatbread in Portland. Poured a very dark brown with a thin off-white head. Aroma is slightly fruity with some cherries. Some yeast notes with caramel and chocolate. The taste transitions to a roasted malty flavor with nuts. Aftertaste is a little astringent with some hoppy notes. Interesting!

name: Atlantic Coal Porter
review: Pours a dark brown from a bottle, big toasty aroma, sweet caramel taste with a cola aftertaste. A little fizzy. Good beer. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Atlantic Coal Porter
review: From a 12 oz. bottle. Pours a clear deep cola with a tan head. Aroma of cocoa. Flavors of leather. Roast finish.

name: Atlantic Coal Porter
review: This porter poured a deep black colour with a creamy, tan coloured head. A little lacing. Scents include roasted malts, wine and cocoa. First swig was delicious. Flavours of roasty malts and dark cocoa most prominent. Finish is burnt with minimal bitterness. Fantastic! ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Atlantic Coal Porter
review: Draft at Doubletree Portland. Pours black with an inch of khaki foam. Leaves trace lacing in the glass. Fairly roasty on the tongue but not a ton on the nose. Finished with a slight bitterness. Solid for style but not spectacular. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Atlantic Coal Porter
review: Not as bitter as a typical porter, but it is dark as any porter and tastes like a ’typical’ porter,

name: Atlantic Coal Porter
review: Pours basically black with a decent sized khaki head that settles to a thick fine-bubbled ring and film and leaves some walls and spots of lace. Nose involves some mild dark chocolate notes, whiffs of woody and floral hops, cream and sugar. Fairly sweet, somewhat bitter. Lighter bodied, active, a bit oily and slick, finishing somewhat dry with woody, earthy hops.

name: Hürlimann Samichlaus
review: 1987 Vintage bottle thanks to Dan. Congrats on the 10K! It pours clear deep rub - red with minimal head. The aroma is rich, oily, tangy fruits, musty oxidised aspect (as expected for a bottle this age), marmite, dark fruits, cake and vinous notes. The taste is slick, oily, juicy fruits, jammy, tangy, plenty of dark fruits, fruit cake, compote, bit of booze, wood and vinous character with a drying and chewy finish. Medium - full body, limited carbonation and oily mouth - feel. Really pretty great actually, especially given the age!

name: Hürlimann Samichlaus
review: Bottle split at the Osprey 10K tasting, CBC Islington, thanks to Danny Boyo 21/03/18. Rich murky mahogany brown with a decent beige cap. Nose is earthy, dusty fruits, soy sauce, ladies knickers on a warm day, toffee. Taste comprises fruit cake, sherry oak, toffee, vinous tones, dried fruits, light soy, modest oxidisation. Medium plus body, moderate carbonation, subdued boost at the curtain call. Fun to try and has aged gracefully.

name: Hürlimann Samichlaus
review: Bottle shared at Daniel Osprey 10K tasting. 21/03/2018. Many thanks! A hazed reddy brown coloured pour with an oily head. Aroma is sweet jammy tangy, hot alchol, red fruit, cranberry. Flavour is composed of brown malts, sticky, brown sugars, maple, earthy wood, tangy fruit, cake, earthy, umami, salty. Paalte is oily, sticky brown malts, tangy, oily, lowish carboantion.

name: Hürlimann Samichlaus
review: 24Mar2018 1987 vintage. Sweet, dark toasted malts, very sweet grain, bread, molasses, caramel, dark candied fruits, prunes. Hazy, very dark brown, tiny, creamy, beige head. Heavy sweet. Dark, candied fruits, prunes, more sweet, dark malts, soft carbonation, medium bodied. Outstanding, aged really well. Bottle shared at CBC Islington - thanks to The_Osprey!

name: Hürlimann Samichlaus
review: Bottle shared in London - big thanks to Daniel. Cheers on 10k. Vintage 1987. Pours unclear brown with no head. In excellent shape. Rich and jammy, hearty malts, burnt honey, toffee. Full bodied, soft and chewy. Warming finish, fruitcake, more toffee and brown sugar. Mellow oxidation. Outstanding, just like Danny.

name: Hürlimann Samichlaus
review: 21st March 2018 Craft Angel. Keg. Dan's 10K boostfest. Thanks to Dan. Hazy amber beer, small pale tan head. Smooth palate, modest fine carbonation. Rich caramel malts, mild salty bitterness. Little oxidised caramel. Good spicy fruits. Nice red berries. Tangy citric peel. Little brandy on the finish. Good stuff, aged well.

name: Hürlimann Samichlaus
review: Bottle at The Ospreys 10k tasting. Clear dark brown colour no head. Some soy sauce some oxidised. Some jammy fruit in mouth. Too oxidised aroma but rest is fine. Jammy fruit filling is fine. Thanks Dan . Higher score for interest.

name: Hürlimann Samichlaus
review: Beer #10000 on ratebeer. Bottle shared at CBC Islington as Hurlimann Samichlaus, 1987 vintage. Dark brown with a red hue, no head. Aroma is jammy, little marmite, plummy, dates prunes and raisins, nuts and raisins. Body is smooth with low carbonation. Taste is boozy , plummy , raisins, port, brandy, little oxidised sherry. Good for age. 3.6

name: Hürlimann Samichlaus
review: 1993. Poured from bottle into its proper glass at the Cerveceria Internacional, Sevilla, Espana.

name: St-Feuillien Blonde
review: Bottle picked up at M&S. Pours yellow/gold with thin foam head. Decent Belgian Ale; spruce spice, lemony soapy, fine carbonation, bit of sweetness to balance out the finish. Nice.

name: St-Feuillien Blonde
review: Sterke Belgische ale met prima balans tussen bitter en zoet. Goudgele kleur en prima schuimkraag.

name: St-Feuillien Blonde
