review: Kleinporige, beständige, große Schaumkrone. Schöne helle, trübe Bernsteinfarbe eines belgischen Strong Ales. Weicher Geruch nach Hopfen und etwas Hefe. Spritziger Antrunk mit hoher Rezens. Sehr vollmundiger, hefiger Körper mit Brotaromen. Im Abgang hopfig-herb mit langem hefigem Nachhall. Leckeres und weiches, sehr vollmundiges Ale. Etwas unterkomplex, aber gut.

name: Grisette Blanche
review: 330ml bottle in 2016. Hazy straw with a dense white head. Aroma of dry grain, esters, straw and coriander. Flavour and body quite thin.

name: Grisette Blanche
review: Aardig en niet bijzonder, weinig uitdagend maar redelijk vol in smaak. Typisch witbier, iets zuurder, maar naarmate je drinkt ontplooit het graan palet zich. Weinig substantiële kraag.

name: Grisette Blanche
review: Hazy, yellow colored, medium white head, nice lacing. Malty, wheat, coriander, perfumey, citrus-orange peel, medium sweet, light bitterness, dryish finish. Medium to light bodied, average carbonation, bit watery.

name: Grisette Blanche
review: Draft at Tria Taproom. Murky gold pour with watery white foam. Tastes of fresh grass and dried lemons. Earthy, herbal, and floral. Wildflower honey. Farro. Coriander. Has some weight but still feels light and refreshing.

name: Grisette Blanche
review: Can from Bruisin' Ales. Pours light, translucent gold with a large head that's foamy, but not at all frothy. Aroma of yeast and coriander. Med body, almost. Flavor is coriander, yeast, wheat; touch of citrus. Nice, but no strong yeast bite. Summer/lake/pool beer. Flavor is pleasing.

name: Grisette Blanche
review: 11.2 oz can received as day 3 of a 12 day advent mixed pack from my wife. The pour is a hazed golden white yellow with a well formed foamy one inch pure white head. The aroma is hay, spice, and lemon citrus. The taste is soft lemon citrus, followed by wheat grain, hay, and the general spice from the yeast. The palate is light bodied, with active carbonation and a clean citrus spice finish. Easy drinking beer.

name: Grisette Blanche
review: Flasche in Belgien. Helles gelb, trüb, wenig Schaum Aroma säuerlich, Zitrus, Orangenschale, Koriander, Geschmack säuerlich, Zitrus, Hefe, etwas Banane, wenig Koriander. Dünner Antrunk

name: Grisette Ambrée
review: An hazed dark amber ale with a thick big bubbled off white head. Aroma of caramel malt and oxidation. In mouth, a sweetish malt with light fruity esters, ripe apples, and surprinsing hoppyness, compared to other Grisette. Some lactic points developping. Medium bodied. BB 26-10-06. Bieropholie private order.

name: Grisette Ambrée
review: 25 cl. bottle. Amber colort with a small white head, Aroma of caramel, fruits and malt. Flavour is sweet and malty.

name: Grisette Ambrée
review: Bottle. Amber colour with a small white head. Fruity aroma and flavour of hops and very watery.

name: Grisette Ambrée
review: Hazy amber with a small white head. Sweet fruit and yeast aroma: really very nice. The taste is dull and watery. There’s a lot of fizz and some subdued sourness and bitterness.

name: Grisette Ambrée
review: Nicely lacing head which leaves large sheets of off-white foam around the glass sides. Otherwise, the pour is totally clear and of an earthy caramel color. Smelling, it does feel rather shy and unexpressive, leaving an impression of cerealic grains, some perhaps underfermented malts comprising a good dose of residual sugars, yet not managing to give anything resembling a caramelly suggestion. In mouth, it feels surprisingly hoppy compared to the other grisettes. A good slicing herbal/leafy aromatic combination does give the impression of increased dryness. The bitterness remains unagressive, imparting a slight lagery character, though the carbonation is obviously too creamy, if active for that. Slightly vegetal aspects, but I can’t say they don’t intermingle nicely with the bready and herbal notes. Simple and approachable beer, but you’re not gonna lift any hearts with that one.

name: Grisette Ambrée
review: Bottle. Nice cloudy amber body topped with a decent off-white foamy head. Fair malty/hoppy aroma with herbal notes. Taste is dominated by hoppiness. It also carries some oaky hints. Ends with a decent bitter finish. OK, but not impressive.

name: Grisette Ambrée
review: Bottle. Nice head but it fades right away. Color is amber. Decent aroma of caramel and malt. Taste is sweet and a bit acidic.

name: Grisette Ambrée
review: (25cl bottle) Purchased through the Bieropholie/SAQ importations. Pours a quick dissipating white head with a hazy, orange amber body. Nose of mild caramel malt and slight whiskey barrel. Flavour of a full palate of caramel malt and thin corn finish. Fairly plain by comparasion and overly malty. Could use some counter balance.

name: Grisette Ambrée
review: Bottled. Light amber coloured. Uncleaer. Dense beige head. Sweetness, yeast, fruity, light spice in the aroma. Flavour is fruity and pruny. Has some cocoanotes. Yeast detectable again. Is a bit thin and bland. In a way its quite perfumed. Is light citricc and fruity in the end. Decent ale.

name: Grisette Ambrée
review: 25 cl bottle. Yeast at the bottom. Amber colour with a weak head. Aroma og caramel, toffee and someway little nutty. Flavour of toffee, sweetness and hints of caramel. Not a beer for me.

name: Silly La Divine
review: The beer has a taste that matches its aroma, not right. It's easy to drink and finishes well. Surprisingly it doesn't leave an aftertaste equal to its initial flavor.

name: Silly La Divine
review: A: Deep amber with a medium, off-white head. N: Sweet caramel. Fruity. T: Quite sweet. Caramel with lots of fruit, particularly raisins. Nice zesty spiciness. P: Full O: Very nice!

name: Silly La Divine
review: Thursday, April 25, 2019. Bottle, 33cL. 9.5%. Purchase ("La Minute Blonde", St Jean-de-Thouars (79), FR). Home. A sparkling dark amber clear beer ; no bubble ; small white foamy head ; short retention ; good lacing. Burnt cereal, alcohol+ Medium sweet, heavy warming, medium dry ; light fresh wind ; suffocating heat. Medium body (lack of body!!), thin oily texture, soft gaseous to flat, sweet warming short finish. Overall, gross, sad. I will try another bottle...

name: Silly La Divine
review: Aroma 6. Appearance 4. Taste 7. Palate 4. Overall 14. Caramel, malt, and a hint of butter aroma. Caramel, candied fruits, alcohol taste.

name: Shipyard Summer Ale
review: Not too shabby, a 3.5... got it in the bargain bin @ Griffs in Watertown, NY. I noted Rochester listed on the label under the micro location, subbed out to Gennesse?

name: Shipyard Summer Ale
review: This is actually my least favorite of the Shipyards that I tried...close call between this and their Pumpkin. In the middle of my summer brew sampling phase, and this beer is one that I probably won't try again or miss. Thinkin I prefer more towards the Kolsch and Pilsner styles, or a golden ale even...over an American Wheat. The flavor seemed a little rustic and bitter, but not in a good hoppy way. Everything else is pretty much average.

name: Shipyard Summer Ale
review: Can at the cabin, NH. Pours mostly clear gold, effervescent, with a foamy white cap. Pretty inoffensive stuff, basic bready-doughy law malts, mild bitter straw, hints of citrus. Light bodied with average carbonation. Sweet finish, more pale bread, hay, lemon rind. Simple, enjoyable.

name: Shipyard Summer Ale
review: Pours a clear golden color with a head the disappears quickly. Aroma of wheat. Taste is watery, almost no flavor.

name: Shipyard Summer Ale
review: Floral aroma that comes off especially strong from the head. Taste and palate are similar to that of an IPA, the floral notes contained within the beer are its defining factor. A little harsh on the tongue for an ale but that’s ok.

name: Shipyard Summer Ale
review: Aroma is a bit weak. Taste is just your bland malty light beer. Overall just OK.

name: Olde English 800
review: Initial tasting notes: Rich, malty with notes of sewer rat. Quite similar to a Newcastle that had gone warm and had homeless bathe in it for a few weeks. Carbonation was apparent but did little to improve the drinkability of this thick drunk nectar. A few sips in the taste started to improve. No longer could taste the homeless who chose to cleanse themselves and get inebriated at the same time. By the time I finished the first, it reminded me much more of a crisp coors original. By this time the tape around both my hands was slowly cutting off circulation so drinking these rockets of awesomesauce helped ease the pain. The second was pure gold. 10/10 would recommend to a friend. This should not be drank without one being taped to each hand.

name: Olde English 800
review: Pours wan clear yellow with a white head. Weak aroma is malty, that's it. Malty flavor has a hint of apple. Texture yields so-so fizz and body. Well, had to try it.

name: Olde English 800
review: Can from Hell's Kitchen Brewtique, Manhattan, New York (July 2, 2019). Better than expected - no taste of alcohol. Similar to the basic US lagers. I see now why this might be an option if you want to get drunk. Well, I'm glad this the regular big can not the gigant size bottle.

name: Olde English 800
review: Backlog, decided to add all my gross macro beers i have had over the years. Golden color. Notes are cheap perfume, sweet malt, and ass cracks. Rough finish.

name: Olde English 800
review: Clear yellow color. Thick white head when pouring in a glass. Great for Edward 40 hands (well used to be before these plastic bottles they sell now). Anyways.. Has a bad metallic taste mixed with what I can assume eating straw would taste like but since I’m not a goat I can only assume that’s what it taste like. Overall it’s not terrible and let’s be honest, it does what it is designed for, cheap malt liquor that gets you drunk. Nuff said.

name: Olde English 800
review: As the great dave chapelle said when he was playing Samuel Jackson in a beer commercial, it'll get you drunk, you'll be f***ing fat girls in no time, you might even fight a ni**a or two, mhmm mm bi**h. Out of the cheap malt liquors its actually semi-tolerable, I'd rank it behind a Mickey's. Flavor is okay, doesnt have that bad of an aftertaste.

name: Olde English 800
review: 16 ounce can into lager glass, best before 5/2019. Pours fairly crystal clear medium golden yellow color with a 1 finger fairly dense and fluffy off white head with great retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Nice spotty foamy lacing clings on the glass, with a fair amount of streaming carbonation retaining the cap. Aromas of cracker, corn, white bread dough, lightly toasted biscuit, light honey, wood, pepper, and herbal/floral/grassy earthiness. Some fruity corn aromas, but not too overwhelming. Okay aromas with pale malt/grains and light-moderate earthy hop notes; with decent strength. Taste of cracker, corn, white bread dough, lightly toasted biscuit, light honey, wood, pepper, and herbal/floral/grassy earthiness. Light-moderate herbal, floral, woody, grassy, peppery bitterness on the finish. Lingering notes of cracker, corn, white bread dough, lightly toasted biscuit, light honey, wood, pepper, and herbal/floral/grassy earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Very nice robustness and balance of pale malt/grains and light-moderate earthy hop flavors; with a great malt/bitterness balance, and no cloying/astringent flavors after the finish. Moderately crisp/clean finishing. Very clean on lager flavors, with minimal fruity/yeasty notes. Light-moderate increasing dryness from lingering bitterness and carbonation. Medium-high carbonation and medium body; with a very smooth, moderately bready/grainy, and fairly sticky balanced mouthfeel that is great. Minimal warming alcohol for 5.9%. Overall this is a nice malt liquor. All around nice robustness and balance of pale malt/grains and light-moderate earthy hop flavors; very smooth, crisp, clean, and pretty refreshing to drink with the mellowly bitter/drying finish. Very clean and nicely rich pils malt/grain showcase, with nice earthy hop presence/balance for the style. Not too overwhelming on adjuncts. A nicely enjoyable offering, and impressive style example as expected of Miller.

name: Olde English 800
review: 42 oz. plastic bottle. Pours a medium, off white, well retained head, with slight lacing, over a clear gold (SRM 5) body.......nose is mild malts with corn tones, slight grassy hops, balanced......taste is mild malts with hints of corn sweetness, minimal hop tones, very slight hop bitterness on the finish, balance to the hops......mouth feel, light body, no alcohol, high carbonation. This is a very, very simple beer in both aroma and flavor and somehow comes toward the stated style. BJCP 5/2/5/4/5

name: Olde English 800
review: Gotten past the age where I will have this again. It's straw yellow and tastes awful. Certainly only for quantity drinking.

name: Olde English 800
review: 24 oz. can. Why do I keep doing this? Clear, pale, yellow color, with a big, frothy, white head. The nose is honey, straw, bread dough, and a bit of vanilla. Very sweet, with hardly any bitterness. Smooth and easy. I've certainly had worse.

name: Santa Fe Wheat
region: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
review: This is a light, weak tasting beer. It has that nice white, wheat appearance, with the internal bubbles, but it has a weak head and is overall lacking in taste and character.

name: Santa Fe Wheat
region: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
review: notes: Has the adequate banana clove aspect to the nose and flavor, but is a little too light on the palate to be that great. An ok sessionable brew, nothing more.

name: Santa Fe Wheat
region: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
review: Hazy gold pour with a fairly small white head. Not much happening beyond sweet, wheat and citrus but not bad at all.

name: Santa Fe Wheat
region: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
review: Pours deep gold with no head and very little lacing. Notes of wheat and citrus. Balanced taste with a slightly acrid finish. Crisp.

name: Santa Fe Wheat
region: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
review: In the bottle at the 2008 Crescent Moon Summer Beer Fest. Pours hazy gold with a large white head. Slightly sweet aroma. Nice clean wheat and lemon taste. If you search hard you can discern a slight banana ester but there’s not much of that. Pretty good on a hot day.

name: Santa Fe Wheat
region: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
review: Bottle. Pours hazy light orange with a one finger snow white head. The nose is sour wheat and light citrus. The taste is wheat, grain and light lemon zest. Medium, semi-prickly mouthfeel. Kinda boring, but nothing offensive about it. Refreshing yardwork beer.

name: Santa Fe Wheat
region: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
review: 12oz bottle. Clear golden yellow. Thin white head. Sweet wheat malt aroma. Heavenly floral hop aroma. Flavor is a bold wheat malt character. Dry and thirst quenching. Some lemon zest. Some banana. Just a touch of clove. Very well done. What I’d expect a Wheat Ale should build up to be. Very enjoyable. 23 may 09

name: Santa Fe Wheat
region: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
review: Appearance: Lightly hazy, yellow body with a frothy, white head. Smell: Very faint nose with only small notes of malted wheat, and even lesser touches of banana and spice. Taste: Lightly tangy malted wheat taste with a fair amount of sweetness gives way to flavors of banana cream pie filling, light lemon, and even lighter spice. Subtly spicy, lightly bitter hops. A few more hints of banana cream, though more cream than banana and a dull, earthy spice accent. Smooth, drying finish. Mouthfeel: Medium-thin body. Medium-low carbonation. Drinkability: Reasonably decent, but it comes up waaay short in the nose. I was going to say it’s a treat to beat the Santa Fe heat, but at 65°F it’s cooler there than it is in Georgia. So, I guess it’s a decent wheat to indulge in on a fairly pleasant, lightly breezy Wednesday afternoon.

name: Santa Fe Wheat
region: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
review: Basic wheat. Aroma of wheat with faint hints of citrus. Flavor is similar. Nothing to really distinguish it from other beers.

name: Santa Fe Wheat
region: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
review: Date: May 23, 2009 Mode: Bottle Source: Ticker Tasting Appearance: hazy pale orange, scant white head Aroma: light wheat aroma, touch of sweetness, touch of spicyness Flavor: light spicy wheat flavor, nice balancing sweetness to the spicyness, light floral hops, touch of citrus fruityness, well balanced all around Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 11/20 Rating: 2.8/5.0 Drinkability: 6/10 Score: *4

name: Santa Fe Pale Ale
region: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
review: 355ml Dose. Dunkelgolden und klar mit minimaler Schaumkrone. Malzig. Erfrischend. Süßlich im Antrunk. Gut trinkbar.

name: Santa Fe Pale Ale
region: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
review: From a 12 oz. can. Pours a hazy amber with an off white head. Malty aroma. Flavors are bitter grass.

name: Cabezon Stout
review: coffee like whoa. like i am chewing on folders grounds. muddy black color. harsh. tastes exactly like fuel cafe stout if you’ve had it. some acidic yet milky flavors with folders.

name: Cabezon Stout
review: Deep brown-black hue with an average-sized, tan, creamy head. Aromas of instant coffee, dried prunes, and baker’s chocolate. Moderately sweet, lightly acidic flavor. Lightly sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter finish. Slightly astringent. Medium-light body, watery texture, average carbonation.

name: Cabezon Stout
review: black, with very little tan head, has a very light plastic chocolate and weak coffee thing goin on in the aroma, and some wet grass/ Check that, it smells much like a pot of brewing coffee, like cheap ass instant coffee.

name: Cabezon Stout
review: Pours black w/ a tight off-white head. Notes of caramel and chocolate in the nose. Soft thin body w/ very little CO2. Flavors are bland and are enwrapped with diacetyl. I ended up using the rest of the sixer for baking bread. Worked pretty well for that.

name: Cabezon Stout
review: Dark reddish brown. Milky, latte aroma. All the regular players are here for a stout - chocolate, coffee, burnt toast. Rich and tasty. Later on a slightly smoky aroma emerges. The body is kind of thinnish, which actually seems to add to the appeal.

name: Cabezon Stout
review: Pours pitch black with a medium dark tan head. Starts off with a moderate aroma of roasted chocolate malt. The flavor is coffee with a touch of chocolate. The finish is salty and tastes like an Alka Seltzer. Not very good. Very disappointed in this one.

name: Cabezon Stout
review: Nice large head poured into my glass. A nice mixture of coffee and chocolate in the flavor. A very decent stout and a Guiness want to be

name: Cabezon Stout
review: Very dark brown color with a very small tan head. Roasted coffee bean and chocolate aroma. Lactose sourness, roasted coffee bean and chocolate flavors. Extremely thin and watery feel.

name: Cabezon Stout
review: Extremely dark brown (maybe black) with a small, sickly tan head. The aroma was very roasty and smokey...a lot of coffee and some cocoa. The flavor was full of coffee tones with a definite lactic sourness lurky in there. The feel was way too thin and watery...pretty much killed the experience.

name: Cabezon Stout
review: Pours a thick robust black with a thin tan head. Aroma is lightly burnt and kinda reminds me of mixed vegetables. Body is thin but has a nice mellow sweetness to it and is quite drinkable. Finishes faintly sweet with a lingering roasted coffee bean flavor. This could use a little more body and a nicer aroma, but pretty good for what I would consider a session stout. Thanks to whaleman for this one!

name: Cabezon Sunchaser Ale
review: Fairly flat pour. Lightly hazed copper color with a few lonely cream colored bubbles adrift on top. Earthy caramel aroma. Interesting brew. Rather dry malt flavors. Not much malt character and a buttery and herbal hops flavor. Long bitter finsih. Thanks for another state TannerTavernboys.

name: Cabezon Sunchaser Ale
review: 12oz bottle-pours a copper amber hue with minimal white head and mild carbonation. malty, fruty, earthy hop estery aroma-slightly buttery hops also. flavros are caramel/toffee malts, earthy hops. Some mild diacytl, but was covered up by the malts. slightly thin body, but a long malty, hoppy finish.

name: Cabezon Sunchaser Ale
review: Since when did English Pale mean something was very malty sweet with no hop aroma and even less hop flavor. This is another dissapointing American amber.

name: Cabezon Sunchaser Ale
review: This used to be my neighborhood brewery when I lived in ABQ; they’re no longer in the same location and I think they got absorbed by Rio Grande. But in any case, I made a point to pick up a 6-pack of this while passing thru NM. This is a nice light amber color. The aroma is rich -- malty and toasty. What follows is a nice caramel-sugar flavor, with a sense of New Mexican baked corn? It’s never as good as you remember, but this was better than most.

name: Cabezon Sunchaser Ale
review: Amber in color with a white head. Had a big malty aroma right off the bat. Medium malt taste with a little hops. Finishes a little thin. Pretty decent if you like English pales as I do.

name: Cabezon Sunchaser Ale
review: Unbalanced and really bland. Pours a rich copper color, with a small rocky head. The aroma is kind of musty, and I am beginning to think that this bottle is out of date, or perhaps a bad bottle altogether. Some flavors are still there, lots of caramel and toffee, with a finish that is like watered down cardboard.

name: Cabezon Sunchaser Ale
review: Brown-amber color. Aroma of spicy hops, sweet toasty malt, and mulling spices. Malty sweet and thin palate. Tastes like a watered-down American Amber.

name: Cabezon Sunchaser Ale
review: English-style pale ale. Richly malted with roasted caramel notes. Healthy bitterness dries the mouth. Very mild hop flavors. Well made and flows down the throat easy. Enjoyable flavors linger behind.

name: Silly Pils
review: The beer has got a clear golden color with a small head and crisp body. Aroma of hops and grass. Taste of hops, grass, citrus. Bitter metallic finish.

name: Silly Pils
review: Very strong yeast aroma and some grass & straw too. Taste better than a lot of other pilseners. Too bad I can only find it in 250 ml bottles. Sell it in 0.5 l please.

name: Silly Pils
review: Foggy gold. Weak white head. Aroma & taste: good ains, butterscotch, some vegetables. Dead hops. Rustic.

name: Silly Pils
review: Bottle taken from the Eurostar Lounge and consumed on the Eurostar, 1st August 18. Pours clear and straw coloured. Aroma is light citrus, yeast. Taste is sweet, not crisp enough, straw, caramel, malt. It's passable to pass the time on the Eurostar.

name: Silly Pils
review: F: huge, long lasting, white. C: pale gold, hazy. A: malty, sweet grassy, bit floral, toasted tones. T: malty, toasted tones, bit almost fruity, sweet grassy, bit slick mouthfeel, strange for the style, medium body and high disturbing carbonation, 25cl bottle from Rob The Gourmets' Market in Brussels.

name: Silly Pils
review: Flasche am Bahnhof in Brüssel Gold-Gelb klar, kaum Schaum, sprudelnd. Aroma: Zitrushopfen, etwas Malz. Geschmack: Voller Antrunk, etwas Malzsüsse, wenig bitter, wenig fruchtig.

name: Silly Pils
review: Pours clear golden with a minimal, foamy, white head. The aroma contains malt, faint grain and hops and some sugar. It tastes medium sweet and light bitter with a malty finish. Light body, watery/slick texture, soft carbonation. Rather sweet for a Pilsener. A bit strange.

name: Silly Pils
review: Clear golden. Bubbly. No head. Aroma is a little grassy. Taste is grainy and malty. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Silly Pils
review: Bottle @ Camping Piantelle, Lago de Garda. Pours hazy dark yellow with a white head. Aroma of malt, yeast, grain, hint of sourness, hay. Flavor is light sweet, malt, yeast, grainy, hay. Medium body, average carbonation, light sweet finish. 190717

name: Silly Super 64
review: The beer has got a golden color with a small head and medium body. Aroma of hops and yeast. Taste of Belgian yeast, flowers, bread, caramel. Mild finish.

name: Silly Saison
review: The beer has got a hazy light golden color with an airy head and thin body. Aroma of wheat and citrus. Taste of wheat, citrus, flowers, hops. Mild finish.

name: Silly Saison
review: Bottle from Beerwulf. Aroma is brown malt with caramel, sugar, dried fruits, hint of vegetables and red fruits. Flavour is sweet and syrupy, body is medium. Not what I want to experience when I open a bottle of "Saison"!

name: Silly Saison
review: This is a backlog rating from 2011 from a bottle shared by Tmoney99, from notes. When I had this beer it was average to below average for the style and not something I wanted to have again or I just didn't get back to my notes because of my technology at the time. Words to describe this beer are fruity, funky, sweet.

name: Silly Saison
review: Bottle. Pours amber with light off white head. Aroma is caramel, dog boo, some vegetables, sweet notes. Taste is dry, caramel, sweet, some syrup, grassy, some grapes, vegetables. Drinkable beer!

name: Silly Saison
review: Dark brown or red, small foam. Good aroma with notes of bread and flowers. Taste is fresh and light, balanced and drinkable.

name: Silly Saison
review: Aroma 7. Appearance 3. Taste 6. Palate 3. Overall 13. Caramel and spices aroma. Malt, sweet and a hint of red fruits taste.

name: Silly Saison
review: Bottle, 330 ml. Dark brown colour, moderate CO2. Smells caramel, apple, christmas spices on the nose. Sweet forest fruits soaked in carameln light biscuit, low IBU, kind of a dessert beer with low alcohol content. It's also citrusy on the palate, so the concept os like sweet notes on the nose and on the palate also, but undertoned with a citrus aromas. Man, i would be very confused on this one on blind. Great beer, big support!

name: Scotch Silly
review: Barwa br¹zowa z rubinowymi refleksami, klarowne. Piana œrednia, doœæ szybko siê redukuje. W aromacie toffi, suszone owoce - g³ównie daktyle, figi, brzoskwinie. W smaku s³odkie, s¹ przyprawy, owoce, karmel, s³ód, melanoidyny. Cia³o œrednie, wysycenie œrednio-wysokie. Ca³kiem dobre.

name: Scotch Silly
review: Bottle from Beers Of Europe. Hazy amber body with an off-white head. Lively carbonation. Faint lacing. Aroma of toffee and dried leaves. Flavour of caramel and brown sugar. Medium body with a slick mouthfeel. Soft fizz. Sweet and moreish. A treat.

name: Scotch Silly
review: 330ml bottle from belgiuminabox.com. Pours copper/black with a small beige head that quickly fades away. Very nice aromas of brandy, caramel, toffee and alcohol. Taste is sweet, candi sugar, caramel, dark fruit. Body is medium, carbonation soft. Very nice wee heavy that I think is wronged by the ratings.

name: Scotch Silly
review: Color marrón rojizo, sin turbiedad pero con levadura en suspensión que precipita rápidamente, translúcida. Espuma marfil, cremosa, de tres dedos de espesor y excelente retención. Aroma a frutos rojos, vinoso, debe atemperar para notar maltas ligeramente tostadas, notas a frutas pasas e higos. Sabor en esa línea, con un principio ligeramente ácido que se relaja enseguida para llegar a un final levemente amargo y seco, alcohol bien integrado. Textura acuosa y ligeramente oleosa. Carbonatación media baja

name: Scotch Silly
review: Bottle from Beerwulf. Aroma is dark malt with caramel, toffee, some molasses, dried fruits, dates, raisins, figs, brown sugar. Flavour is rather sweet with a light to moderate bitterness. Body is medium. Quite sweet, some rich malts, nice.

name: Scotch Silly
review: the aroma is caramel and fruity with hints of toffee, raisin, candy and dark fruits... the taste is caramel and fruity with notes of plum, toffee, raisin, lollipop, dark fruits and sweet berries... the aftertaste is sweet and dry...

name: Scotch Silly
review: 330ml bottle. Pours a slightly hazy red-brown with lots of yeast particles in suspension and a small, creamy, long lasting, tan head that laces. Sweet aroma of toasted caramel malt, toffee, fig, date, wood and light alcohol. Sweet flavour of toasted caramel malt, Belgian candy sugar, Belgian spicy yeast, fig, date, wood and light alcohol in a mild bitter finish. Medium body with an oily texture and soft carbonation. More of a Belgian Dark Ale, but still a good beer.

name: Scotch Silly
review: Bottle 0.33L. Brown body with a large, frothy, tan head, mostly lasting with some nice lacing. Moderate malty (caramel, toasted) and light yeasty aroma with notes of wood and some spices and alcohol. Moderate sweet flavour; long-lasting sweet finish with fruity and alcoholic notes. Medium body with oily texture; soft carbonation; light alcoholic feeling in the finish, very light astringency.

name: Scotch Silly
review: Warka: gdzieœ w 2018, pite 1.6.2019. W aromacie s³odowo, karmelowo ale doœæ przyjemnie o dziwo :) W smaku s³odko, karmelowe, z bakaliami, g³ównie z rodzynkami, skórk¹ od chleba i lekk¹ zio³ow¹ goryczk¹. Ca³kiem fajnie mi siê pi³o to piwo, a na do dadatek alkohol by³ fajnie ukryty. Trochê taka ubo¿sza wersja barley wine, ale nie taka ciê¿ka. W sumie nuda ale przyjemna.

name: Scotch Silly
review: Bottle. Ruby brown lots of sediment, some head. Sweet caramel toffee aroma. Sweet, very sweet, sugar cookies, thin body for a wee heavy. Dry black tea bitterness, cardboard finish. Well Ive been trying readily available Belgian beers lately, but this one is more disappointing.

name: Silly Double Enghien Brune
review: A: Deep dark brown with a medium tan head. N: Toasted malts and honey notes. T: Caramel, amber malts, honey, fruity. P: Medium-full O: Quite enjoyable.

name: Silly Double Enghien Brune
review: Bruin bier met voldoende koolzuur. Geur mout, muffig. Smaak mout, kandij, medium wat waterig mondgevoel. Nasmaak mout, kandij, beetje fruit, beetje hop. Vooral zoet

name: Silly Double Enghien Brune
review: (nez pas appétissant (fait un peu peur, comme une dlc de 30 ans), bouche idem, hop pas malin, last douleur)

name: Silly Double Enghien Brune
review: Bottle from crafty bottle Lincoln. Deep caramel amber colour with a medium tan head. Aroma dried fruit and lots of caramel. Taste overly sweet. Medium body heavy alcohol.

name: Silly Double Enghien Brune
review: Fles 33cl thuis. Zoet, rood fruit, honing, rozijn, caramel, alcohol. (2-2017).

name: Silly Double Enghien Brune
review: Pours hazy dark amber with thin white head. Nose is candi and toasted malts. Aromas are toasted malts, caramel, dark fruits, chocolate. Average carbonation, medium/full body. Long sweet finish. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Silly Double Enghien Blonde
review: Pilsener pour. A: sweetest malts, mushroom, some citrus. T: pretty standard Belgian blonde, sweet, peppery. Biscuits in finish. Not bad, not outstanding.

name: Silly Double Enghien Blonde
review: Backlog. Slightly hazy deep yellow with a big white head. Sweetness and orange peel galore. Very tasty.

name: Otter Creek Copper Ale
review: Backlog, bottle that pours a copper color with medium to larger white head. Notes are dark fruit, pine, brown sugar, earth, and pepper. Medium bodied with a smooth malty finish. Not my favorite style when it comes to the German beers

name: Otter Creek Copper Ale
review: Not a big fan of this copper ale. Bland and a little unbalanced. Has a decent hop character at the end. Tried for the first time in 2010.

name: Otter Creek Copper Ale
review: From old tasting notes. Hazy copper gold color. Small creamy beige head. Sweet Carmel malt aroma. Sweet toasted malt flavor has a silky soft mouthfeel and an underlying earthiness. Very good.

name: Otter Creek Copper Ale
review: Bottle 355ml @ Hotel room, La Quinta Inn & Suites, Portland, ME Pours hazy golden with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, caramel and grass. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter with a long malty, caramel and grassy finish. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

name: Otter Creek Copper Ale
review: Bottle. An unclear, dark amber to copper colored beer with a small, off-white head. The aroma is very bready, like Danish rye bread, with some caramel and a little fruity touch. It’s medium bodied and soft on the palate, rather dry, with flavors of bread, toffee and a generic fruityness. Some dried fruits and bitterness. Long caramel flavor with bread and some bitterness. Rather boring this one, and it needs a few sips to feel pleasant. 150608

name: Otter Creek Copper Ale
review: Bottle. Pours a copper color with a thin off white head and a bit of a haze. Sweet malty aroma. Malt comes through at the beginning with a some citrusy hop at the end. Balance seems quite good. Its okay, somewhat forgettable but a nice change from the hop bombs populating the scene.

name: Otter Creek Copper Ale
review: Aroma is a mix of caramel and mild nut. Deep brown body with a reddish hue. Mild haziness. Head is thin. Dry nut and malt taste. Has a hint of caramel. Seems kind of plain and straight forward although very drinkable.

name: Otter Creek Copper Ale
review: Poured into a pint glass. 3.25 A: Moderately hazed copper color. Not even one finger of head formed. 3.5 S: Big toastiness. Nuttiness to a lesser extent. Fairly dry, but sweet enough to be balanced. 3.75 T: Tastes like the nose. Toasty, nutty, grainy maltiness. Moderately dry with a touch of yeast. 4.0 M: Medium body. Good moderate carbonation. Nice creaminess in this. 3.75 D: Not a whole lot going on, but it is tasty.

name: Otter Creek Copper Ale
review: Bottle from Candia Road Convenience Store. Aroma is mix of bready malt and yeast. Appearance is gorgeous clear copper color (go figure) with beautiful sparkling, one finger frothy white head that dissipates to ring and foamy lacing. Taste is weak and has nothing up front but lightly sweet back end. Palate is light and thin with nice light carbonation on the tongue. Finish is inconsequential. Overall, I’m not sure you’re going to find a nicer beer to look at. But, it’s almost like OCB put all their eggs in this basket and forgot about the other attributes. Not much to recommend it otherwise.

name: Otter Creek Copper Ale
review: 12oz bottle, from variety pack, poured into 16oz tulip glass Aroma: Caramel, toffee, sweet, malty, floral hops Appearance: Amber color, hazy, off white head Taste: Sweet with a little bitterness Palate: Medium body, dry finish Overall: Slightly sweet with some bitterness. Very clean lager. Slight floral aroma. Nice balance with hops and malts. Nice dry finish. Same style and very, very similar taste to Long Trail Ale. Between this or LT Ale, I think I enjoy LT Ale by a little. I probably couldn’t pick out each beer from each other in a blind taste test. I think Altbiers like this and Long Trail Ale are great beer-beers. Nothing crazy, nothing too intense, good balance and great tasting. I don’t drink a lot of Altbiers, except for LT Ale and OC Copper, but these are solid beer.

name: Otter Creek Pale Ale
review: Backlog, bottle in 10-11. Pours a copper with massive white head and tons of carbonation. Thin bodied. Notes are dead hops, wood, caramel biscuits, and butter diacetyl. Quick finish and quick dump in the sink on this pale.

name: Otter Creek Pale Ale
review: "a crisp and clean beer, but one that lacked character in a recent apa tasting. average at best, but not something I’d turn down...or buy again. fairly thin."

name: Otter Creek Pale Ale
review: This was a light and refreshing brew. A hint of a citrus finish and to the overall dry taste. Loses a few points for low alcohol, but still a tasty beer.

name: Otter Creek Pale Ale
review: This pale ale is pretty good and uses my favorite hops from the northwest, but they could ramp it up a little. Like the northwest, the northeast is full of hop heads, but this beer seems to have been made to appeal more to tourists and college students at Middlebury. Has potential, but not there.

name: Otter Creek Pale Ale
review: Golden pour with medium sized head. Strong carbonation. Strong pine and pretty one dimensional pale ale. One of my first craft beers back in college. Mediocre at best.

name: Otter Creek Pale Ale
review: Pours a a cloudy light copper color slightly cloudy. Half inch head dissipated quickly. Good lacing and carbonation though. Pleasant Floral aroma but not overpowering. Slightly bitter at first but mellows. Smooth mouth-feel. Leaves a bit more of an aftertaste (almost metallic) for my liking. Not a bad beer at all. Would probably pair excellently with the typical bar food, wings, etc...

name: Otter Creek Pale Ale
review: Bottle clear golden color, thick white head. Aroma of subtle paint thinner. Taste is bitter straw.

name: Otter Creek Pale Ale
review: Pours a clear, dark copper with visible carbonation and a frothy, white head that stays with decent lacing. A bold, spicy, tantalizing aroma. Full and lightly effervescent mouthfeel. Taste is a bit flatter than the aroma suggests. Slightly sour finish. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Otter Creek Pale Ale
review: 355ml bottle pours a pale golden orange color with a finger of white head that retains decently and settles to a thin spotty lacing. Aroma is pleasing with some cereal grains and mild citrus and grassy hops. Taste is loaded with citrus and grassy hop bitterness balanced nicely with some light malty sweetness. Quite a refreshing and easy to drink pale ale that I would sample again if given the opportunity.

name: Otter Creek Pale Ale
review: Long Island, NY - 12 oz. bottle poured a hazy golden color. This is a run of the mill Pale Ale. It was good for what it's worth. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Otter Creek Stovepipe Porter
review: 2nd Sample of my New England run. A solid porter. Not top of the line, but decent and very well balanced. Nice roasty malty flavor with a good hop finish. I would get this again, but don't think I've seen it where I live.

name: Otter Creek Stovepipe Porter
review: dark brown, almost black; chocolaty aroma; an easy drinking, light bodied porter; fairly hoppy for the style; roasted malt base with a bitter aftertaste

name: Otter Creek Stovepipe Porter
review: From Aug 2006 oured from 12oz bottle a near pitch black with a small head of foam that dissipated quickly leaving just a fine ring and layer. The smell has good roastiness to it with strong chocolate notes. The taste is of roasted malt with a bit of chocolate up front and some hoppy bitterness comes through near the end but the finish is actually on the sweetish side. All of the flavours I mentioned are on the light side so this is one very smooth American Porter. I'd say, give it a try.

name: Otter Creek Stovepipe Porter
review: Bottle from backlog notes. Pours a dark cola brown color with a small off white head. The aroma and flavor have roasted malts, sour coffee, earthy, thin, a strange combination, I noted that I would never drink this again and I was right.

name: Otter Creek Stovepipe Porter
review: Originally rated on 12/10/08. "A slightly above average porter, stovepipe poured a very deep amber almost black body, plenty of carbontion but not much head or lace. Mouthfeel was a little thin and slightly bitter. Aroma and taste were standard with hints of toasted malts, some chocolate and coffee. O.k. but not great.

name: Otter Creek Stovepipe Porter
review: First experienced on tap at Mad Mountain Tavern, this porter convinced me, in a good way, that there was soot in the recipe. One of my all-time favorite porters, it’s with great sadness that I learn it is no longer being produced. For that matter, MMT is closed as well. So goes the impermanence of life I suppose.

name: Otter Creek Stovepipe Porter
review: "great balanced beer...not sure why this one is as low. it’s pretty stinkin good. definitely above average, but i guess there’s a lot of competition in this category."

name: Otter Creek Stovepipe Porter
review: Tap at Macgregors in Gates. Old notes. Sweet chocolate but well roasted to balance. Very chewy and rich. Fruit flavor come in well too. Sturdy and flavorful.

name: Otter Creek Stovepipe Porter
review: Bottle: Pours dark brown/burgundy with a short oatmeal coloured head. Chocolate malt, cream, light coffee scents. Taste is roast coffee, chocolate. Pleasantly mildly bitter.... Very well balanced...a nice one.

name: Otter Creek Stovepipe Porter
review: bottle. medium bodied black pour. notes of chocolate, light coffee & roasted malts in both aroma & flavor. decent porter

name: Otter Creek Mud Bock Spring Ale
review: Nice dark amber pour. Nose and taste has some fruits, citrus, malts and caramels. Rated 6/22/02

name: Otter Creek Mud Bock Spring Ale
review: $5 for 22oz bottle ----Otter Creek first got my attention with their jamaican-style stout appropiately called "Otter Mon." The sweet malts are given me chocolate, carmel, and some nut. The hops come through on the aroma, but I can’t really detect them on the tongue. My rating is not off the charts, but I do like the taste and lingering chocolate finish. This one is a maybe buy again.

name: Otter Creek Mud Bock Spring Ale
review: Pours a three finger light tan head that fades slowly to a thin layer leaving some lace. Brown/black color. Medium carbonation and medium bodied. Malty nose. Flavor is sweet and sour apple almost medicinal. Different bock. $3.99 for a 22oz bottle from Manchester Wine & Beer Manchester, CT. The bottle is actually part of the world tour series and is not the small Spring Ale.

name: Otter Creek Mud Bock Spring Ale
review: Bottle. Pours brown with a small light tan head. Aroma was malty and fruity with light caramel, roast and subtle chocolate. Malty sweet flavor with caramel, chocolate and some nuttiness.

name: Otter Creek Mud Bock Spring Ale
review: Bottle. Pours brown with light brown head. Aroma is dark fruits with nutty notes. Flavor is roasted malts, mildly nutty, sweet with a bitter twinge in the finish.

name: Otter Creek Mud Bock Spring Ale
review: $5 bomber into pint glass. Nice nut brown, almost amberish body. Creamy off-white head that fades to a thin layer and leaves some lace. Aroma is nutty, woods, some chocolate, some dark fruits like raisins and dates, a bit of vanilla. Flavor is a bit strange. Almost chalky, maybe even a bit oxidized &#40this is a spring release being consumed in the fall... thats not enough time to oxidize is it?&#41. A bit of chocolate and nuttyness, but the astringency seems to override most of the beers "character". Meidum body with medium carbonation. Overall: not horrible, but the aroma set a standard that the flavor simply didn’t follow through on.

name: Otter Creek Mud Bock Spring Ale
review: 22oz bottle, from the "World Tour" series. Pours dark brown with a ruby hue, capped with a medium sized tan head. Aroma is quite sweet, with notes of cereal grain, caramel, cocoa, and lucky charms marshmallows. Flavor is sweet as well, with chocolate, caramel, tea, and some roasted malt. Body is a bit thin. I first had this a while ago &#401998 I believe&#41 and I remember it being a lot more impressive.

name: Otter Creek Mud Bock Spring Ale
review: 12oz bottle from Hannaford. Pours a dark brown body with ruby-red highlights and about an inch of short-lived light tan head. Caramel, chocolate and a bit of nut characterize the aroma. Chocolate and coffee dominate the flavor, with a fair bit of caramel to support. Medium in body with moderate carbonation. A decent American brown, nothing to write home about, but pretty good.

name: Otter Creek Mud Bock Spring Ale
review: Bomber - Pours a dark copper brown in color with a medium light tan head that settles to a thick coat over the beer and produces some nice lacing on the glass. Aroma is slightly sour and fruity with plenty of roasted malts and a few hops. Flavor is much more sour than I would have expected. Little of the other flavors transcend the sourness. Quite disappointing...

name: Otter Creek Mud Bock Spring Ale
review: 22 oz. bottle shared by Tmoney99. Pours a deep caramel copper color with a small off white head. The aroma was semi sweet with fruit, some roast, caramel malt, and floral notes. The flavor opened with a sourness that was quite unexpected. Nothing from the nose really made it to the taste. It was thin and not something I would care to revisit.

name: Otter Creek Oktoberfest
review: Direct pour at the brewery. Comes out dark copper with a pure white head. Exactly what I expect from a good Oktoberfest. Feel like I got this too early in the season. Very young mouthfeel as it is July and the beer is new to tap. Perfect lacing.

name: Otter Creek Oktoberfest
review: 12-ounce can pours clear orange-gold with a small beige creamy head and residual lacing, along with lots of visible carbonation. Aroma: caramel, steamed cabbage. Flavor: caramel, butterscotch, shortbread, apricots. Mouthfeel: medium-bodied.

name: Otter Creek Oktoberfest
review: Pours up a amber copper color with a thin off white foamy head. Some nice lacing was left behind. The smell was malty with muted caramel tones and some light nuttiness. The taste was basically the same, malty and slight nut and dark fruit hints. The palate was a light to medium with nothing abrasive. Clean refreshing finish.

name: Otter Creek Oktoberfest
review: On tap at Otter Creek, pours a clear golden with a small white head. Aroma brings out bready malt, some cereal and light toasted caramel. Flavour is along the same lines, with sweet bready malt, caramel and some cereal notes. Sweet and bready. Solid stuff.

name: Otter Creek Oktoberfest
review: Draft at 10 Railroad St in Morrisville, VT. Not retired. Cloudy apple sauce colored pour with no head. High hop content for the style. Disappointing. Maybe it should stay retired.

name: Otter Creek Oktoberfest
review: Tried this at the Eastern States Exposition. Big E state fair. One of the best beers available at the fairgrounds. Vermont State building. Stop in, there are other Vermont beers available. Yummy. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Otter Creek Oktoberfest
review: Transfer from BA review on 10-13-13- Poured from bottle into a pint glass Appearance – The beer pours a crystal clear orange-amber color with a one finger pure white head. The head fades over about a three minute time period to leave a good level of foamy lace on the sides of the glass. Smell – The aroma was of a roasted malt smell with a light caramel and toffee sweetness. Along with these smells are some light earthy and herbal hop aromas. Taste – The taste begins with a roasted bready flavor with a bit of caramel sweetness. The sweetness increases toward the middle of the taste with the caramel growing stronger and some other light fruit flavors coming to the tongue. Flavors of a grassy and earthy nature come to the tongue at the end, and with the sweeter flavors increasing a bit, a moderately sweet and toasted malt flavor is left to linger on the tongue. Mouthfeel – The body of the beer is on the average side in terms of thickness and creaminess with a carbonation level that was on the averages side as well. Both were nice for making a rather refreshing and easy drinking brew overall. Overall – A nice drinking oKtoberfest. Nothing super exceptional, but good none the less.

name: Otter Creek Oktoberfest
review: It has a hazy appearance with a medium orange amber colored body. The head is just off white in color, small and fades quickly to a light ring of lace. There is a mild aroma of sweet bready malt with an odd ginger like spice and earthy dried leafy hops. It has interesting malty character with some caramel roasted flavors mixed with buttery sour dough bread notes and dry yeast. Hop flavor is in good balance and adds leafy and mildly spicy hop flavors which quickly fade off in the finish. It has a smooth texture, average carbonation and a good medium body.

name: Otter Creek Oktoberfest
review: Reviewed from notes. The appearance has a dark copper colored body and left a one finger white foamy head, some nice ringy lacing was left around the sides of the glass. No carbonation was seen rising. The smell seemed really off, bland and muted caramel tones with some light nuttiness to it. The taste was basically the same. The palate was a light to medium with nothing harsh on the tongue, sessionable. Overall, I’m not that impressed with this beer. I’ve had better Oktoberfests and this isn’t one of them. I won’t seek this out again.

name: Otter Creek Oktoberfest
review: Bottle at home. Pours clear amber with a small, frothy off-white head, short retention with spare lacing. Aroma is toast and nutty malt, earthy and spicy hops, and light notes of dates. Flavor is malt dominant with light hops and bitterness, somewhat dirty malt, almost endol in flavor with a sweet finish. Medium body and light carbonation.

name: Otter Creek Hickory Switch Smoked Amber Ale
review: Hickory Switch Smoked Amber Ale--1998 12 oz. Bottle. 4.40% ABV. 18 IBU’s. (3.0 / 5.0) Deep clear red brown color. Pleasant ester aroma followed by light smoky flavor in well balanced light amber fruit malt body. Very light, but quite flavorful. Sampled 11/21/1998.

name: Otter Creek Hickory Switch Smoked Amber Ale
review: bottle. Bottled 09/21/01. Aroma: BBQ potato chips, malt, and a bit of caramel. The aroma makes me a little apprehensive about how this is going to taste. Appearance: Very dark red, almost bordering on brown. No head to speak of. Flavor: There is a little hickory smokiness, but the main flavor is malt roastiness. A little bit of caramel flavor...and not much else. Flavors are weak. Palate: Medium-light bodied and watery. Carbonation seemed a little low, as well. Overall: Not good. I’m hoping the fact that this bottle is a couple years old has something to do with it. Weak, watery, and without distinction.

name: Otter Creek Hickory Switch Smoked Amber Ale
review: tap at RFD. more roast than smoke...very much not a rauchbier style, which is what i was expecting. black, slight head. medium body, malty flavors balanced mostly by acrid roast. pretty mediocre.

name: Otter Creek Hickory Switch Smoked Amber Ale
review: Dark redish brown hazy with a thin head. The aroma is malty with a bit of caramel and a smaller bit of smoked and an even smaller bit hickory, so small in fact, I dont smell it. The flavor of this is also just not good. It lacks anything consistent to make a taste interesting and has a funny aftertaste. The only other smoked ale Ive really has was Rouge’s....which was like 8 years out of date. And it wasnt much worse, it even smelled better.

name: Otter Creek Hickory Switch Smoked Amber Ale
review: The concept of a smoked american amber ale sounds good. Too bad this beer does not deliver what its name promises. Watery think weak and a little metallic. Not the best beer I've ever had. Flavor evaporates. which is good and bad.

name: Otter Creek Hickory Switch Smoked Amber Ale
review: Medium-brown, medium head, clear. Smoked sausage aroma is quite nice; flavor on the other hand is quite dull. Smoke present all the way through, but thin and bland and the smoky bitterness isn''t counterbalanced by much of anything. Fairly watery; not OCs worst, but I''m really glad I got just one bottle for under $1.50; I don''t feel TOO ripped off.

name: Otter Creek Hickory Switch Smoked Amber Ale
review: I don't get it. I keep trying this, keep hating it and yet keep trying it every fall. The smokiness is just unsettling, maybe because of the Hickory in lieu of say Beechwood. Just gives it too much "burnt kielbasa" flavor. The malts aren't bad they are hidden and only evident when really warm. I'll try it again next year.

name: Otter Creek Hickory Switch Smoked Amber Ale
review: Good Gawd, this stuff is awful! I have never had a respectable import like Kaiserdom, but I am sure it is better than this. Tastes like a bad bock beer with liquid smoke drops added to it. Regardless, the stuff is a good seller.

name: Otter Creek Hickory Switch Smoked Amber Ale
Otter Creek A Winter's Ale
review: The body has a dark appearance with good clarity and very deep brownish amber color. On top there is a huge light tan head that has great retention. It lasts all the way to the last sip slowly fading down to thin cap along the way. Also it makes for some cool splotchy lacing on the glass. The aroma has notes raspberries and rich lightly roasted malt. The base of the flavor is a sweet, lightly roasted malt with light buttery, bready and raspberry that adds a little tartness. Hop flavor is very light and understated. It has a solid medium body and its carbonation is light on the tongue with a smooth almost creamy feel.

name: Otter Creek A Winter's Ale
review: Draft. An average winter ale. The aroma was a pleasant malt scent with a bitter finish, and the appearance was a medium brown with a decent white head. The palate was a medium body with a bitter, crisp finishing texture, and the taste had a similar bitter finish to it. Malty caramel notes complimented by dry bitter and a touch of hops.

name: Otter Creek A Winter's Ale
review: Picked up the new winter seasonal from otter creek a raspberry brown, sounds interesting. Pours a dark reddish brown with a stingy beige head that dissipates quickly to form a cap. Smells of vanilla some brown sugar and a sweet fruitiness that I guess could be raspberries. Slight chocolate aroma as she warms. Taste is meh. I found the raspberry to be forward up front and a bit artificial. Think Sam Cherry Wheat but not as bad. There’s a tartness midway through each taste. There’s some brown sugar and sweet malts in the background of a beer that finishes quite dry. Medium body and carbonation with a syrupy/watery mouthfeel. This reminds me of a raspberry wine cooler and ex girlfriend used to drink. If you mixed it with Newcastle you would get this beer. I didn’t really enjoy this one much.

name: Otter Creek A Winter's Ale
review: Otter Creek Brewing Company--A Winter’s Ale--1999 12 oz. Bottle. 5.80% ABV. 24 IBU’s. (4.0 / 5.0) Pours a thick clear dark copper mahogany color. Light spicy front. Rich creamy sweet malty Scottish toasted caramel body. Excellent flavor. Spiciness reasserts itself in dry crusty finish. Sampled 1/3/2000.

name: Otter Creek A Winter's Ale
review: Lots of alcohol on the palate for such a low ABV. Dark reddish brown color. Okay. Rated 1/18/03

name: Otter Creek A Winter's Ale
review: Pours brown with a thin white head. Smells of caramel and dark fruit. Tastes vegetal and spicy with a sweet finish.

name: Otter Creek A Winter's Ale
review: Name: Winter’s Ale Date: 12/19/1998 Mode: Bottle Source: Chevy Chase, DC dark copper, whispy tan head, spicy malt aroma, rich malt flavor, low levels of spice and bitterness, slight belgian character Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.6/5.0 Score: **/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

name: Otter Creek A Winter's Ale
review: Malty, clear caramel aroma with some spice in it. Overall, a very good seasonal ale. The beer never goes skunky if you live in Vermont.

name: Otter Creek A Winter's Ale
review: bottled on 11/29/99.Batch 641. cellared. good good good good good good good will add as soon as i find the notes

name: Otter Creek A Winter's Ale
review: Malty, sweet caramel aroma. Clear amber-brown with low, off-white head that diminishes to ring. Liquorice and roasted malts with some notes of butter, peat and spices. Medium-light body with low carbonation. Bottle. Entered from notes.

name: Legend Lager
review: Another back of the fridge bottle. Poured a golden color with an averaged sized head. Toast, cardboard, citrus and some earth.

name: Legend Lager
review: Clear gold pour. Better than your standard swill for sure. Crisp and clean with a nice refreshing bite. Not a standout in the craft world, though.

name: Legend Lager
review: On tap. Pours a clear light orange with a thin white head. Aroma of pale malt and an odd scent I can’t put my finger on. Flavor of pale malt, lavender?, bready malt. Kind of off, not sure what it is. 5/4/5/3/11 (2.8/5)

name: Legend Lager
review: 12 oz single bottle from Total Wine & More - Springfield, VA. Clear golden appearance with a fizzy white head. Mild aroma of bread and grains. Similar flavor, adding mild sweetness and minimal bitterness. Light and a little bland, but easy to drink overall.

name: Legend Lager
review: Pours clear yellow, white head. Aroma is very bready, bread yeast. Taste is more harsh,more like an AAL, not sure what it is, maybe the hops, though doesn't taste like pilsner type hops. Light mouthfeel.

name: Legend Lager
review: Backlog, bottle with Pat, James, and Devon. Hazy yellow golden with average sized top and lacing. Notes of grain, corn, malt, hay sweet vanilla and lager stuff. Not into this one at all.

name: Legend Lager
review: Very enjoyable lager. Drinks easily, light to medium body. Crisp malt body, light touch of saaz hops. Very nice.

name: Legend Lager
review: Drank from a pint glass, poured from a twelve ounce bottle. Thank you Bjorn. A bit more creaminess than I am use to in a lager, but a welcomed flavor.

name: Legend Lager
review: (Bottle) Hazy orange body with a small orange-white head. Sweet malt aroma. Light body, lively carbonation. Bread, some orange; mildly sweet and clean.

name: Legend Lager
review: Bottle from Chevy Chase Wine and Liquors. Bold orange body with medium, white head. Nose is hoppy, floral and fruits. Taste is similar of hops, malts and citrus. Some wheat. A bit prickly in the texture. Dry, sweet finish. Decent beer.

name: Breckenridge Oatmeal Stout
review: I'm with the "this is a good but forgettable stout" crowd. Not sure to call it a sweet or dry, but I'd say more on the dry side. The chocolate malt and oat flavors are there, with a semi-creamy texture from the oatmeal. Roast coffee and burnt molasses/sugar give some bitterness. I certainly would not turn this down, but not seeking to buy again. Has potential though. Could see it being better fresh on tap.

name: Breckenridge Oatmeal Stout
review: 02-May-15 (12-oz bottle: Sample bottle from the distributor) This is an Oatmeal Stout that I last sampled in 1998 and I thought it was pretty bitter back then. It pours a dark-brown body with caramel edges. The tan head rises to half an inch before settling to a thin ring and patchy dusting. The nose is noticeably roasty and significantly burnt for an Oatmeal Stout. And on the palate, burnt, very dark-roasted malts dominate, but there's still quite a lot of oatmeal flavor, some dark chocolate, and grassy hops. It's not very sweet at all, and yeah, roasty and hoppy bitterness is readily apparent, so maybe I wasn't so far off back then. The beer is medium-plus in weight, medium in carbonation, and quite dry on the palate. Overall, this is more roasty that I like for this style, but it's still enjoyable for a dark, roasty stout.

name: Breckenridge Oatmeal Stout
review: 12 ounce bottle. Pours dark brown with an average tan head. Aroma of malt, coffee, and chocolate. Taste is roasted malt, dark chocolate, and coffee. Mild bitterness. Thin body. Ok.

name: Breckenridge Oatmeal Stout
review: Pours black, with full, tan head. Aroma is cocoa, coffee and roast. Taste is thin chocolate, moving to heavy roast and coffee. Finish is coffee. An OK stout.

name: Breckenridge Oatmeal Stout
review: Bottle from Village Beer Merchant. Brown coloured. Roasted malts, coffee, coffee grinds, quite dry. No oats whatsoever. Pretty poor all around.

name: Breckenridge Oatmeal Stout
review: 23 oz. bottle pours a translucent dark brown with creamy beige head that leaves some lacing. Aroma is all roasted barley, with mild coffee and mild chocolate. I couldn't detect the oatmeal. Taste is initially sweet and malty but the finish is bitter, Body is at most medium with soft carbonation and a creamy mouthfeel. OK, but not one I'll return to enthusiastically.

name: Breckenridge Oatmeal Stout
review: Good stout kinda sweet. Refreshing sipper. Would go good with a smoked meat.

name: Breckenridge Oatmeal Stout
review: Creamy flavor and creamy texture. Light body. Malty. Mild coffee (despite claim of boldness). This should be a sweet stout and not regular stout.

name: Breckenridge Oatmeal Stout
review: Roasted barley aroma, black color. Pretty standard. Taste is too dry for me, expected something sweeter from an oatmeal stout, haven’t found signs of oat here. Body is watery with quite acrid rough aftertaste coming from hops probably

name: Breckenridge Oatmeal Stout
review: Clear black with small light brown lacing foam head. Coffee and chocolate in aroma, same in taste. Good. (Galveston 201705)

name: Midnight Sun Kodiak Brown Ale
review: On tap at the brewery. Comes a mostly clear brown with a decent beige head. Aroma and taste of malt, grain, grass, and citrus. Pretty good.

name: Midnight Sun Kodiak Brown Ale
review: Brown colour with caramel flavours. Nice hit on palate. Taste a little dissapointing. Good strength. Hints of nuts and dark berries

name: Midnight Sun Kodiak Brown Ale
review: Brownish copper colour, smallish head on top left quite quickly. Aroma has caramel malts, some roasted malts and piney hop notes. Taste has slightly roasted and caramel malts with pine and grassy hops. Medium body and high carbonation.

name: Midnight Sun Kodiak Brown Ale
review: On tap pour brown, hazy, light khaki head. Decent amount of toasted malt and caramel malt. Slight sweetness. Light citrus. Medium body.

name: Midnight Sun Kodiak Brown Ale
review: 0.355l can. Definitely a brown one in color, little cloudy and a tall almost fluffy but somewhat fading beige head that leaves minimal of lacings. Smells mild chocolaty. Tones of nuts, dark berries and some darker types of malts. Nice and not too extreme aroma. It has a somewhat high carbonation level wrapped in a mild oily texture. Tastes quite good. Again it’s mild chocolaty with a nice dark caramel sweetness. The high carbonation is kinda disturbing the flavors a tad perhaps. There’s hints of truffles, marzipan and red berries in the finish. All in all its definitely a little dull, but drinks nice enough. 24.06.2015

name: Midnight Sun Kodiak Brown Ale
review: Shared with Wim at my home. Brown colored beer with small off-white head and no carbonation visible. Coffee malted aroma. Full sparkling palate. Finish is malty roasted hopped.

name: Midnight Sun Kodiak Brown Ale
review: Tap @ Pump House, Fairbanks. Dark auburn with thin head. Smells lightly sweet, almost chocolatey. Taste has some sourdough and a nice light bitter finish. It is a little cold, probably even better warmer.

name: Midnight Sun Kodiak Brown Ale
review: Along with Yves at his home can brown colored body with a off white head and a malt hops coffee caramel aroma a hops herby sweet caramel bitter taste with a bitter finish

name: Midnight Sun Kodiak Brown Ale
review: Last beer on my trip to Alaska. At Cheryl and Tanguy's place. 5.0% ABV. Good American brown. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Midnight Sun Kodiak Brown Ale
review: From a 12 oz can. Pours a clear cola brown with an ecru head. Sweet malty nose. Flavors of caramel and toast. Smooth finish. Tasty.

name: Midnight Sun Mammoth Extra Stout
review: 22oz bottle pours out dark brown topped with a small tan head. Nose is chalk chocolate roast coffee and a little ash. Taste is more of the nice chocolate roast coffee malts enjoyable.

name: Midnight Sun Mammoth Extra Stout
review: Bottle. Pours a cloudy brown with small beige head that lasts. The aroma is roasted malt, chocolate, and caramel. Thin mouth with sweet roast, dark chocolate, nutty malt, lingering dry finish, very good.

name: Midnight Sun Mammoth Extra Stout
review: Bottle: Pours a deep brown body topped with a thick brown head. Fizzy at first, but creamy and lots of thick lacing. Nose is an intense coffee, roast, and cocoa blend. Roasty and nutty flavors, light cocoa and some faint bitters. Lots of carbonation, more than desirable, imo. The good thing is a heavy finish of roast and chocolate that brings a seemingly creamy feel into play and helps get past the bubbles. Interesting.

name: Midnight Sun Mammoth Extra Stout
review: Based on notes from 2012. Looks black. Smells dry chocolate. Tastes smooth dry chocolate dry irish.

name: Midnight Sun Mammoth Extra Stout
review: This is at least a year old, as it has been retired. Bottle, opaque black body, walnut colored head, some lace. Aroma dark fruit (cherry and dried plum), molases, faint metal, roasted barley and coffee. Taste is roasty with coffee, dark chocolate, molases, and plum. Faint metal is still there in the flavor, finish is dry, bitter coffee. Palate is smooth, but not thick, carbonation moderate.

name: Midnight Sun Mammoth Extra Stout
review: "kinda halfway between an extra stout and an imperial. highly roasted aroma, with a nice balance op hops, chcoolate and coffee. nice brew, but overpriced for what it is, like most of MS bottles."

name: Midnight Sun Mammoth Extra Stout
review: Bottle served in a pint glass. Pours black with a good sized brown head. Good retention and nice lacing. Straight stout goodness. Not overly complex, but it is balanced and tasty. Light coffee, cocoa, roasted malts and resiny hops. Mid sweet, medium body and a long roasty and hop bitter finish. If they put this in a 6-pack it would rival the best stouts out there and become a commercial success.

name: Midnight Sun Mammoth Extra Stout
review: Bottle, age unknown. Pours black with a bit of yellow/tan head. Aroma is faint coffee, cheese rind. Taste is hard to describe. Some sweetness from the malt, though its’ more about the chewy texture than the flavor as far as the malt goes. A bit of the hops coming through. Weird interplay with the two. Undecided. Will update once I’ve had another go-round.

name: Midnight Sun Mammoth Extra Stout
review: Tap. Backlog of ratings. The look is black in color, dark, and has a tan head. The smell is roasty, chocolate, coffee, wood, and nice. The taste is toast, dark coffee, fruits, dessert, and chocolate.

name: Midnight Sun Mammoth Extra Stout
review: Pour out of 22 oz bottle, thick black pour with thiin tan head, aroma brought notes of slight caramel, oxidized fruit, more veggie notes, herbal, slight coffee and roast. Taste is a mix of veggie, earth, slight grass, grain, hints of roast, lots of veggies, finishing bitter, dry. Ugh.

name: Midnight Sun Old Whiskers Hefeweizen
review: Bottle. Bright clear golden color, scant white edge head. Aroma of banana bubblegum and heavy clove. Taste is up front clove, citrus. Average.

name: Midnight Sun Old Whiskers Hefeweizen
review: Gold in color with a large white head. Aroma is of wheat and fruit. Taste is of citrus, wheat and yeast.

name: Midnight Sun Old Whiskers Hefeweizen
review: Bottle:   Dirty golden, pale haze, moderate white head, frothy, fairly decent lacing.   Faint banana, clove, and bubblegum.   Not too shabby in the nose department.   Better than most American examples.   A little more mealy than wheaty on the tongue, but does retain some clove and banana.   Not too heavy, a little lighter.   At least not as filling or heavy as many German examples.   Seems fairly clean, exit is balance between wheatiness and a mealy sort of flavor.   Some dirty ice water like flavors linger tho after the finish.   You know, kinda like sucking on an icicle thats hanging off the roof, yeah that.   Its actually better than I expected though.

name: Midnight Sun Old Whiskers Hefeweizen
review: Golden color beer with a huge pillowy off white head. Light floral nose with some spice. Flavors of the traditional banana, clove and bitter orange peel flavors. It is an okay hefe.

name: Midnight Sun Old Whiskers Hefeweizen
review: Bomber. Poured a light yellow, slightly cloudy with a full thick white head. Peppery aroma. I can’t discern any banana or clove notes. Taste is straight up malt/wheat and pepperiness. Prickly mouthfeel with a crisp finish. Chucks of yeast. Decent.

name: Midnight Sun Old Whiskers Hefeweizen
review: Super hazy golden coloured body with orange highlights and a thick tan head - looks nice! Aroma of coriander seed, curacao, wheat, cardboard and a bit of sugars. Light-bodied; Sharp pungent wheatie flavour with some yeast, curacao, malt, sugar and citrus flavours coming through. Aftertaste is very mild, with only wheat tastes noticeable and a hint of citrus sugars. Overall, a decent beer, and a decent hef, but nothing special and really nothing to buy - especially when there are so many other better options from the brewery! I sampled this 65 cL bottle purchased on 23-June-2010 from Brown Jug in Anchorage, Alaska sampled in Seward, Alaska on 27-June-2010.

name: Midnight Sun Old Whiskers Hefeweizen
review: Old Whiskers Hefeweizen--2001 22 oz. Bottle. 5.00% ABV. (4.0 / 5.0) Light spicy Belgian wheat front. Hazy lemon golden color. Spicy crisp wheat favor. Spiciness mellows with sediment. Medium rich wheat citrus body. Clean end. Bavarian Belgian flavor. Medium maltiness. Nice. Sampled 3/16/2001.

name: Midnight Sun Old Whiskers Hefeweizen
review: Bomber; pours bright gold with faint haze and trace white head; stale lemons, mild wheat aromas; flavors of a little clove, banana and lemony stale wheat; grainy texture with faint sourness; pretty simple overall and quite light on the wheat; smooth and drinkable

name: Midnight Sun Old Whiskers Hefeweizen
review: 22 oz. bottle shared by shigadeyo. Pours a slightly hazy golden color with a small white head. The nose is crisp, fruity, grassy, yeasty with a small amount of clove. The flavor has a fresh fruity lemon zest upon a toasted bready malt base. The finish is dry with mild spices. Medium bodied and average at best.

name: Midnight Sun Old Whiskers Hefeweizen
review: (22oz bottle, courtesy of AmEricanBrew) Pours a lightly hazy yellow body with a moderate white head. Aroma of wheat, lemon, florals, and banana. Flavor of wheat, citrus, banana, and light clove.

name: Erdinger Pikantus
review: Bottle at home, brought at Waitrose. It's the best of the Erdinger range so far! Lovely look to the beer, massive amounts of carbonation rolling up the inside of the old Weissbier glass. Fantastic winter time warming colour. Taste is a bit fizzy, bounces around the palate but offers a ton of banana and dark treacle and white chocolate. Wonderful balance between the flavours. Very well done. Enjoy it! Just don't chill it down too much!

name: Erdinger Pikantus
review: Part of their Variety Pack from this Christmas with a glass. Pours a brown colour, clean with some copper-golden highlights. Beige head, fairly creamy, average retention with little lacing. Aromas of bananas and some hints of dark fruits. The taste is a blend of bananas and dark fruits as well. Alcohol is well-hidden, but still feel it. A caramel malt base. Not bad, but a little too rich overall without being refined.

name: Erdinger Pikantus
review: Sehr dunkles Braun. Feiner Schaum, zerfällt recht schnell. Süsser Duft. Honigbrot, Malz, leicht alkoholisch. Antrunk Bananenbrot, Honig. Recht süffig. Leichte Holznoten im Abgang. Leider recht schnell weg.

name: Erdinger Pikantus
review: Bottle at home from Waitrose. A chestnut brown light hazed pour with a fading beige head. Aroma is sweet toffee apple, caramel, burnt sugar, candy floss, nutty. Flavour is composed of brandy snap sugars, toffee, nutty malts, apple, raisin, light chalk. Palate is medium sweet, highish frothy carbonation, airy, sticky sugars. Brown sugars. cakey malts.

name: Erdinger Pikantus
review: Pours dark mahogany brown, big weizen-like head that soon reducing to small foamy layer on the beer surface. Aroma is sweet toffee and caramel, dark dried fruits, overripe plums, roasted, woody. Flavor is surprisingly quite bitter, caramel, ash, bit of plum, red fruits, mild spices.

name: Erdinger Pikantus
review: 50cl bottle from Waitrose. Pours a medium dark brown with a billowing tan head, tight foam and excellent lacing. Aroma is dark fruits and a rich, spicy taste with notes of dried fruit, chocolate, cloves and pepper. Not too sweet and with a long aftertaste. Medium, fruity bitterness. Excellent appearance and good carbonation. A very classy dark Weizen beer.

name: Erdinger Pikantus
review: Top notch in style beer. Great full flavour malty body. Everything is well rounded. Graeff hamburg

name: Erdinger Pikantus
review: Found out of bottle at erdinger restaurant in Berlin, Germany. Pours dark brown. Doesn't sit as heavy as expected. Simply enjoyable.

name: Erdinger Pikantus
review: Bottle at home from Waitrose, 12th September 19. Pours a chestnut brown, aroma is malt, caramel. Taste is caramel, malty, some bitterness, cocoa, sweet notes, fruit cake, dark fruit. Good

name: Erdinger Pikantus
review: Dark brown color. Well-carbonated. Mild roasted malt aroma, with the combination of wheat and little yeast. Malty drink, alcohol can be felt at the end of the gulp but not bad. It's just strange that malt has a stronger impact than wheat.

name: Midnight Sun Full Curl Scotch Style Ale
review: Growler, slightly cloudy, deep amber beer, dense cream colored head faded to a skiff. Aroma sweet malt, coffee and yeast. Taste is caramel malt, if ain’t hint of coffee or roast, touch of honey or baked apple, faint dried fruit. Palate is rich and smooth, carbonation subdued and fine. This is a bit sweet in the middle, but that roastiness comes through right at the end to tone it down. Great beer for a 15F night. Where’s my kilt?!

name: Midnight Sun Full Curl Scotch Style Ale
review: (Tap) clear bright Amber colour with a small tan head; aroma of toffee, hint of fruit compote; very nice balanced flavour with a long, very light bitter finish

name: Midnight Sun Full Curl Scotch Style Ale
review: Draft: Poured a brown with red edges and a light brown/tan head. Aroma is strong bubblegum malt. Taste is very rich with multiple malts that meld well together.

name: Midnight Sun Full Curl Scotch Style Ale
review: Full Curl Wee Heavy Scotch Style Ale--2000 22 oz. Bottle. 6.50% ABV. (4.5 / 5.0) Scottish Ale. Clear dark copper bronze color. Mild hop heather Scottish floral fruit malt front. Rich toasted malty body. Mild sweetness and medium texture. Spicy notes in malty finish. Balanced Scottish spice malt. Sampled 10/2/2000.

name: Midnight Sun Full Curl Scotch Style Ale
review: 2009 batch on tap @ MS. Clear brown with a medium tan head. The aroma is roasted malt, caramel and some mild peppery hops. Flavor is mostly sweet rich malt with a light amount of bitterness, which balances it out nicely. Medium body with medium carbonation and a long roasty/smokey finish. Wow has my palate changed, I remember when this came out in the mid 90’s and I thought it was really strong and intense. Still really good but almost a session beer for me now.

name: Midnight Sun Full Curl Scotch Style Ale
review: 2009 batch. Clear light brown color with a tan head. Mild smoky nutty malt aromas. Light/medium body. Nice nutty, medium roast malty flavors with a hint of smoke to finish. Draft@MSBC

name: Midnight Sun Full Curl Scotch Style Ale
review: This brew pours a nice reddish brown color, clear, with a frothy off white head. The aroma is slightly malty sweet and the flavor is hoppy. Nice brew.

name: Midnight Sun Full Curl Scotch Style Ale
review: This scotch ale pours a deep cover color from a 22oz bottle. Medium sized tan foamy head. Aroma is malty, caramel a touch bready and sweet. A medium bodied scotch ale. Malts are caramel and fruity, slightly sweet and a touch peaty. Hops are earthy and perhaps a touch floral. Mild carbonation. Nice balance. Lots of malts, a touch of peat and smoke. Nice beer. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.

name: Midnight Sun Full Curl Scotch Style Ale
review: Bottle sampled on 9/20/06: Pours a slightly hazy copper amber with a thin, wispy off-white head. Aroma of mildly sweet caramel malt with a hint of peat. Body starts with nice caramel sweetness with good toasty balance and some slightly earthy hops. A pretty good Scottish ale.

name: Midnight Sun Full Curl Scotch Style Ale
review: Bottle. Pours clear brown with spare rocky light brown head, diminishin, spare lacing. Aroma is heavy malt (bread, cookie, caramel, toffee, nutty), light hops (herbs), average yeast (dough, broth) with notes of butterscotch and brown sugar. Average duration, heavy sweetness, light acidity and bitterness, salty; creamy caramel malt flavor, brown sugar, doughy yeast. Medium bodied, creamy texture, flat carbonation and chalky finish.

name: Gordon Biersch Blonde Bock
review: I didn't know this was 7%. Felt light, but this is what I wanted actually. A nice, smooth, lighter, blond/golden ale. Finding all of Gordon's brews to be fairly solid. Decent hop finish. Semi-clear appearance...tiny bit of cloudiness. Sampling this brewer one beer at a time, but this is something I'd grab a 6-pack of.

name: Gordon Biersch Blonde Bock
review: Draft: Poured a golden with off-white head. Aroma is sweet grainy. Taste is sweet and grainy.

name: Gordon Biersch Blonde Bock
review: This is an okay Bock, but leaves a little to be desired. Could definitely be smoother to drink compared to similar beers. Overall, a decent value at most places you go

name: Gordon Biersch Blonde Bock
review: Dark gold with coppery tones and a small white head. Rich malt aroma, very much like a German bock. Sweet with a bit of an astringent bitterness fighting for dominance. Not a smooth balance. Too bitter of a finish for an otherwise well done bock.

name: Gordon Biersch Blonde Bock
review: 12 ounce bottle. Pours a somewhat hazy pale amber with a decent beige head. Aroma of malt, caramel, and fruit. Taste is malt, caramel, yeast, and some fruit. OK.

name: Gordon Biersch Blonde Bock
review: Bottle at Evernote in Redwood City, CA. Aroma is bready, malt syrup, some honey, floral and slightly metallic. Taste is sweet then medicinal / vegetal bitter like some ancient elixir, but not the kind that gives you immortality and thus worthy of the Ill-fated Eternal Drain Pour.

name: Gordon Biersch Blonde Bock
review: Draft at San Jose airport. Husky grainy aroma. Faint floral. Clear dark gold with head that quickly dissipated to a collar and dusting, but there is nice patterning down the sides. Tate is moderately astringent with moderate high bittering. Slight alcohol warmth is nice. Really a bit rough and lacking rich maltiness that this style demands.

name: Gordon Biersch Blonde Bock
review: [Dec 31 2015] Bottle at Gordon Biersch SLC airport. Golden body. Malty nose. Taste is malty, wheaty, sweet, some caramel. Dry in the finish. Okay.

name: Gordon Biersch Blonde Bock
review: Tap @ Gordon Biersch Taipei. Hazy yellow amber, reasonable head. Lemon yeast aroma. Black currant and malt flavour. Flowery perfumey aftertaste. Not one to get excited about.

name: Gordon Biersch Blonde Bock
review: On tap at Oakland airport. Light copper body, minimal head. Sweet malt aroma, taste follows with more sweet malt, honey. Body is fantastic, slick, slippery. Shame they serve it ice cold.

name: Gordon Biersch Märzen
review: Decent all around beer. Second sample from Gordon, and finding them both very drinkable. One of the better semi-economy brewers.
