Grabbed a few different varieties that I haven't tried on clearance for 1/2 off. One of them is the Festive Ale/Oktoberfest, so curious to see how it differs from this. Light amber color, clear appearance. Smooth mouthfeel. Flavor is mostly caramel malt, but good hop finish. The clearance was because these bottles are almost a year old....but still taste sort of fresh....definitely not spoiled. Liked their maibock, liked this....eager to try the blonde and festive ale next.

name: Gordon Biersch Märzen
review: Ehhh....nice pour, carmel with 2" white head, which looks great in glass, especially at an airport spot. Taste ok too but not the knockout it could be. Fine for a lager I guess.

name: Gordon Biersch Märzen
review: nice malty aroma. amber and clear in color with great long lasting head. taste is richly malty

name: Gordon Biersch Märzen
review: Drank over tap in restaurant Good oktoberfestbier with a beautiful amber color. Scent of malt is the first thing I noticed on this beer. Personally, I enjoyed this beer a lot. Not too much thinking in the drinking process, I just drank large chugs, muy bien.

name: Gordon Biersch Märzen
review: Clear with a dark reddish auburn color with brown chestnut highlights, served with a nice two fingers of solid white head that had a good retention to it. Light but malty nose with a faintly nutty hint to it. Flavor was nicely malt forward with a mild sweetness and caramel and biscuit flavor to it, as well as faint nutty, toffee hints, body feels medium/ light with an average amount of carbonation to it and a nice smooth mouthfeel to it, easy drinking and not to heavy. Finish is lightly bitter with a light balancing touch of faintly noble hop back-end that still leave a faintly lingering caramel sweetness on the aftertaste. Not a bad example of a Märzen

name: Gordon Biersch Märzen
review: Draft. It pours a caramel brown Cor with an off-white head. The aroma and flavor is caramel malt. The taste is rather sweet. Nice Oktoberfest.

name: Gordon Biersch Pilsner
review: Draft at DTW. Light gold clear, light body. Faint hops aroma, corn and grass taste. Mild bitter finish lingers.

name: Gordon Biersch Pilsner
review: This is for the Naptown pils in GB Annapolis. Nice low Saaz aroma with pils malt. The grassy astringent flavor overcomes the rest and make the experience underwhelming. Seems Jim the Brewer is blind to grassy flavors.

name: Gordon Biersch Dunkles
review: With Kris at Louisville KY at Gordon Biersch bewery. Amber colored beer with small white head and no carbonation. Malty caramel aroma. Finish is malty sweet bitter dry.

name: Gordon Biersch Dunkles
review: 750 ml. swing top from Safeway. It pours a deep reddish brown color, a bit hazy with a tall light tan head. The aroma is full with sweet cherries and red fruit. Light notes of raisin bread and malt. The flavor is a bit disappointing with some metal, light molasses and raisin bread. There’s some cherry cola sweetness as well that lacks depth. It ends on a dry, toasted note. The mouthfeel is pretty thin and fizzy. Could have used a richer mouthfeel and more flavor development.

name: Gordon Biersch Dunkles
review: 750ml bottle with a swingtop. Pours a slightly hazy roan brown color with a bif foamy beige head that has good retention. The aroma is soft with sweetened malts and grains. The taste is more sweetened grains, nuts and some cola notes. The palate is a bit lighter than I prefer and the carbonation is lively. Finished medium in duration and dry. Overall: Decent dunkel

name: Gordon Biersch Dunkles
review: ~Malty aroma, bready, light roast, sweet caramel, wood. ~Pours a brownish mahoghany hazy color with lasting creamy off white head. ~Sweet bready flavor with caramel and light roastiness. Well balanced. ~Light medium bodied with high CO2, lasting sweet bready roasty finish. ~Excellent balanced drinkable beer. Would have no problem drinking a few of these.

name: Gordon Biersch Dunkles
review: Sweet. Aromas of chocolate and caramel, very tasty but thin palate. Good session beer.

name: Gordon Biersch Dunkles
review: Bottle from Safeway in Los Altos, CA. Aroma is malted cola, roasted malts. Taste is a creamy cola which has been watered down by melted ice. Not incredibly complex but definitely one of the better GB beers I’ve had.

name: Gordon Biersch Dunkles
review: Bottle. 25th Anniversary. Copper beer with a tan head. Nutty and caramel aroma with light toffee and light roast. Caramel and light spice flavor. Medium bodied. Caramel and light spice lingers.

name: Gordon Biersch Dunkles
review: A decent beer, nothing too special, but smooth and tasty. Pours a beautiful ruby red with a thick white head. Smells malty, maybe a bit of marzipan. Taste is creamy, sort of empty upfront, with some coffee and toffee coming in, and a lingering sweetness on the tongue. Had in the bottle.

name: Gordon Biersch Dunkles
review: Poured from bottle into a pint glass Appearance – The beer pours a very light brown/dark copper color with an amazingly huge billowy off white head. The head has a great level of retention, slowly fading to leave a lighter level of foamy lace on the sides of the glass. Smell – A big caramel and brown sugar aroma are the bulk of the smell. These are mixed with some nice roasted malt and toasted aromas as well as a little bit of a nutty smell. Rounding out all these is a very light earthy and herbal hop as well, creating a very pleasant aroma overall. Taste – The taste begins with a sweet brown sugar and caramel flavor with a little bit of a toasted malt and a light grainy taste. The grain and malt are very light, largely being dominated by the sweeter flavors of the brew, which intensify even more after the initial taste with some other sweet flavors of a cola and molasses nature coming to the tongue. A little bit of a nut flavor develops right after the initial taste, with it then fading away toward the end due to the advent of the cola and molasses. Just a hint of herb is mixed into the taste leaving one with a very sweet, lightly roasted, and thin flavor to linger on the tongue. Mouthfeel – The body of the beer is quite thin with a carbonation level that is high. A thicker body would have certainly been better for accentuating the roasted and nut flavors of the brew and would have made it a bit less cloying. Overall – A little too sweet in darker sugar flavors with not quite enough malt and roast to really support the sweet. A bit sweetly unbalanced.

name: Gordon Biersch Dunkles
review: 750 Swingtop from Bine and Vine. Pours cola color with a beige head - though with lots of light behind it, it’s dark ruddy copper. Warm dark malt aroma. Med body, maybe. Flavor is lightly chocolate, a little darkly malty. Maybe a bit yeasty in the finish. Not much bitter in it. Enough flavor to make it an interesting beer.

name: Gordon Biersch Golden Export
review: Draught at Ethereal. A light yellow like pour with more sourness than I expected for style.

name: Gordon Biersch Golden Export
review: 1/31/18. On tap at Gordon Biersch DTW. Dark golden pour with a frothy white head that sticks. Doughy aroma, touches of floral and spice. Doughy flavor, malty, touches of spice, floral, honey. Not awful.

name: Gordon Biersch Golden Export
review: With Kris at Louisville KY at Gordon Biersch bewery. Clear blond colored beer with no head and no carbonation. Herby hopped aroma. Medium palate. Finish is sweet dry.

name: Gordon Biersch Golden Export
review: Clear rich golden with a thin white cap and a doughy crackery nose and a light grassy kiss. Nice grainy doughy flavor that’s clean and light and crisp with a nice herbal grassy hop nuance. Pretty doughy but tastes nice.

name: Gordon Biersch Golden Export
review: Clean Golden in color with a white head. Fresh malty aroma. Notes: On tap at the brewery during the Epic Vegas Brewery Tour of ’17

name: Gordon Biersch Golden Export
review: Draft: Poured a golden with a white head. Aroma/taste was nice refreshing grain.

name: Gordon Biersch Golden Export
review: Sample on tap @ the brew house restaurant in Baltimore, MD. Pours a clear bright yellow with a thin white ring. Grainy aroma. Crisp and refreshing but just a pretty simple light lager.

name: Gordon Biersch Golden Export
review: On tap at Gordon Biersch @ DTW Pours clear golden with a medium sized off-white head, good lacing. Aroma of sweet grains, honey and straw. Flavor is fruity, sweet grains, straw and herbal Good

name: Gordon Biersch Golden Export
review: [Dec 31 2015] Bottle at Gordon Biersch, SLC airport. Golden body with top white head. Nose is malty, grainy. and Buttery. Spicy. Thick texture. Not great.

name: Gordon Biersch Golden Export
review: Aroma of bread and yeast. Hops are grassy. Appearance very light yellow in color Minimal head, taste is doughy.Palate light body, thin feel, lively, with a long finish. Not a bad beer. Good on a hot day. Taster at Gordon Biersch in Bolingbrook Illinois.

name: Gordon Biersch Maibock
review: First sample from Gordon. Maybe a little better than expected. Was not sure if this is true craft or just restaurant brew gone commercial. Still not sure, but the beer is decent. Would not be upset if I got this on tap in Vegas or New Orleans at one of their restaurants. Been seeing 6-packs of Gordon Biersch distributed here, but wanted to sample one or two first. The price seems right, so based on the first sample I am sold. As far as this beer goes, on the lighter side for a bock...almost like an Oktoberfest. Good caramel flavors with a little hops at the end....just enough to notice. Not much aroma. Smooth feel. Nothing really special, but overall above average.

name: Gordon Biersch Maibock
review: 27/6/2018. Draught at the Gordon Biersch Brewery Restaurant, Las Vegas. Pours hazy amber colour with a small just off-white head. Aroma of malt, fruit, caramel and hint of spice. Medium sweetness and moderate bitterness. Medium to full body, oily texture, very soft carbonation. Quite decent.

name: Gordon Biersch Maibock
review: Color was a clear dark golden straw color approaching amber, served with a good two fingers of solid egg-shell colored head with a good amount of retention and lacing. Faintly nutty clean malt aroma. Mildly sweet malty forward with a grainy toast and caramel flavor to it. Light bodied and clean with a faintly slick mouth-feel to it as well as faint hints of oxidization. Finish is crisp and mildly hoppy with a faintly peppery noble hop bite to it and a fairly active carbonation to it.

name: Gordon Biersch Maibock
review: With Kris at Louisville KY at Gordon Biersch bewery. Amber colored beer with small white head and no carbonation and no carbonation. Malty aroma. Full sparkling palate. Finish is dry sweet malty caramel.

name: Gordon Biersch Hefeweizen
review: Draft to rocks glass at GB SFO. Looks good for the style; a cloudy/yeasty darker papaya with eggshell head that steadily dissipates into lacing. Smells yeasty with bigger notes of banana and clove alongside a moderately semi-sweet backbone. Tastes like it smells with a medium-bodied mouthfeel. A good example of the style.

name: Gordon Biersch Hefeweizen
review: 1/31/18. On tap at Gordon Biersch DTW. Lightly cloudy dark orange pour with a small off-white head that fades to a ring but sticks, mild lacing. Light banana and clove aroma, some dough. Doughy flavor, banana and clove, touches of citrus. Not terrible.

name: Gordon Biersch Hefeweizen
review: Very solid and true to style. Glowing hazy light orange. Bananas not cloves in this one.

name: Gordon Biersch Hefeweizen
review: 27/6/2018. Draught at the Gordon Biersch Brewery Restaurant, Las Vegas. Pours cloudy yellow gold with a small white head. Aroma of banana, clove, light bubble gum, lightly yeasty and wheaty. Medium sweetness and light bitterness with a hint of sour. Moderate body, slight oily texture, soft carbonation.

name: Gordon Biersch Festbier
review: These samples were from last season, thus the half off clearance sale. I didn't notice a difference really. Haven't tried this beer fresh yet, so would get this again based on curiosity. Found this to be one of the better domestic Oktoberfests out there. Was liking Sammy's, but wasn't that much into this year's version so sampling different brewers in this style. Found this beer smooth on the mouthfeel, flavor is decent and well balanced....maybe a tad on the sweet side but typical of this style. Light to medium orange appearance. Finding all of Gordon's beers to be decent so far.

name: Gordon Biersch Festbier
review: Mediocre, not bad, not great. I like all the German styles brewed here, vs. nothing but IPAs, this one was heavier on banana than clove.

name: Gordon Biersch Festbier
review: With Kris at Louisville KY at Gordon Biersch bewery. Amber colored beer with no head and no carbonation. Malty caramel aroma. Full palate. Finish is sweet caramel vanille.

name: Gordon Biersch Festbier
review: Draft: Poured a hazy straw with a white head. Aroma is light grain. Taste is sweet grain a light refreshing finish.

name: Gordon Biersch Festbier
review: Bottle at GB Salt Lake City. Nice amber body with thin head. Nose is malty and toasty. Taste of caramel, malts spices. Nice oktoberfestbier.

name: Gordon Biersch Festbier
review: On tap at the Atlanta brewpub. Served colder than ideal temperature. Look: amber body with excellent clarity and a creamy bone head. Aroma: mild mix of malts and hops, with a hint of citrus. Flavor: follows the aroma. Clean but a bit mild. Mouthfeel: light-medium body and medium carbonation. Nicely smooth. Overall: clean, refreshing, easy drinking,

name: Gordon Biersch Festbier
review: Sampler from the flight of beers at the Washington, D.C. location. Fresh and malty with an unfiltered taste throughout.

name: Gordon Biersch Festbier
review: On tap at Gordon Biersch in Taipei. Clear amber with a white head. On the sweet side with malt, caramel, some dried fruit. Low bitterness and with a medium body. An ok one

name: Gordon Biersch Festbier
review: Draft pours clear deep copper with a one finger white head. Looks nice. The aroma is standard caramel and grain. The flavor is mildly sweet with a touch of bitter on the finish and includes a hint of diacetyl. Medium body with an average festbier feel. Oh well, it’s a tick.

name: Gordon Biersch Festbier
review: Tap @ Gordon Biersch Tysons Corner - Malty, mild bitterness in a clear Amber package. Overall, drinkable.

name: Gordon Biersch Winter Bock
review: On tap poured into a pint glass. Very dark copper/light brown, beige head, which doesn't last long. Aroma of Munich malt, toast and toffee, some nutty notes. Flavor more Munich malt, bread crusts, toffee, raisins, light chocolate. A decent bock beer, would recommend to friends!

name: Gordon Biersch Winter Bock
review: Taste: baker's chocolate, toffee, roasted coffee, caramel, with creamy malt finish. Same with the nose. Dark brown, semi clear, average head and lace. Medium body. Would pair well with dessert.

name: Gordon Biersch Winter Bock
review: On tap in restaurant BUR. Appropriate aroma and body for style. Flavor was pretty rich, maybe on the low end for a dopplebock but still nice. I liked it.

name: Gordon Biersch Winter Bock
review: On tap at the Tysons location, pours a hazy amber with some thin, white head. Nose has grist, yeast, malt, some mild raisin. Flavor is the same, some soggy bread, yeast, a little caramel, some raisin. Watery finish.

name: Gentle Bens Red Cat Amber
review: Poured up at AZ Strong Ale Fest 2014 where they told me this was an imperial red ale but it very well might be the Red Cat Amber so I’ll put the rating there. It pours with a nice clear deep copper body that has some golden hues and supporting a light tan head of foam. The aroma offers up some pine hops mixing with some malts and a touch of citrus. The taste comes across a little thin and drinkable with tasty hops that run from flavor hops right into a decent level of hop bitterness. I’m getting mostly grapefruit as well as a little bit of pine and then a mixture of sweet fruity esters along with some sweet crystal malts. Pretty nice all-in-all with just enough going on to make it interesting amid the light drinkability.

name: Gentle Bens Red Cat Amber
review: Closer to brown in color, this was the last beer I had on the 4th of July and it didn’t work with all the others. It just felt too malty and little off.

name: Gentle Bens Red Cat Amber
review: Pint on tap at Barrio Brewery. Copper color, clear, small head burns off. Balanced taste, not too hoppy, which I appreciate. About as good as I’ve had for the style. I liked it quite a bit, especially fresh off the tap.

name: Gentle Bens Red Cat Amber
review: On draft at The Hungry Monk, light amber-reddish pour with thin off white head. Nose has a light caramel malt and grainy character and the taste is a little toasty. Not bad, but I’ve had much better reds before.

name: Gentle Bens Red Cat Amber
review: Light amber with a thin head. Light to medium amber/crystal grains make an olfactory appearance. Medium-bodied, a bit tannic and grainy. Bitter-sour finish.

name: Gentle Bens Red Cat Amber
review: Amber with creamy white head and lace. Light caramel with a hinto resiny hops. Caramel malt and light resiny flavor. Watery and fizzy, but an ok beer.

name: Gentle Bens Red Cat Amber
review: on tap-pours an off white head and gold color. Aroma issweet light malt, secondary citrus. Taste is citrus/spice-peppery hops, sweet light malt.

name: Gentle Bens Red Cat Amber
review: on tap as part of the sampler pours light amber with a thin off white head. Aroma is bread, toast, little else. Flavor is sweet corn and caramel, ends pretty clean. Eh.

name: Gentle Bens Red Cat Amber
review: Draft at pub. Quiet caramely malt nose. Wet malty flavor up front with a light spiced hop note amongst toastiness towards the finish.

name: Gentle Bens Red Cat Amber
review: [Tap] Pours a bright copper color with very little head, but decent lacing. Aroma of sweet caramel malts and astringent grains. Sweet and sugary taste is mostly caramel malt driven. Some citrus in the finish. Slightly cloying overall. Light/medium in body. This one was a little out of whack, in my opinion.

name: Gentle Bens Beer Down Nut Brown
review: Sampled at the brewery. Copper hue and a beige head. A nutty malty nose. Flavor is that with kind of amber malts. More nutty than brown. A hint os spice. Not a huge fan.

name: Gentle Bens Beer Down Nut Brown
review: It was fine. Nothing special. Nutty, but not super smooth. I probably wouldn’t order it again.

name: Gentle Bens Beer Down Nut Brown
review: Light bronzed amber, faced head. Pleasant nutty nose with a respectable brown malt backbone. Dusted nut and brown malt melds enjoyably together on the palate. Nice mouthfeel and just well put together

name: Gentle Bens Beer Down Nut Brown
review: (Draught) Pours a clear copper-brown body with a medium beige head. Aroma of chocolate, graham cracker, caramel, and nuts. Flavor of chocolate, nuts, light roasted malt, and caramel.

name: Gentle Bens Beer Down Nut Brown
review: Draft at the pub. Ok nut brown. Slight roast, slight almondy flavors. Mild caramely malts in the background. Kind of watery.

name: Gentle Bens Beer Down Nut Brown
review: [Tap] Pours a light brown color with a slight haze to it. Not much head. Aroma of cocoa powder and vanilla. The taste was mainly of milk chocolate, mild coffee and sweet toffee. Lingering roasted malt finish. Light in body and seemed a bit watered down. Not too bad, but not great either.

name: Gentle Bens Beer Down Nut Brown
review: Pours a deep brown color from the tap with an off-white head of foam. Smells of watered don coffee and tastes predominantly of dark cocoa and hazelnut. Not very balanced at all.

name: Gentle Bens Beer Down Nut Brown
review: This beer smelled of pencils and tasted like it as well. This was my least favorite beer of my Arizona vacation.

name: Gentle Bens Beer Down Nut Brown
review: Growler fill from Barrio Brewing Co. - Pours a clear brown color with a one finger thick light tan head. Light lacing. Aroma is caramel malt. Flavor is caramel malt and has a light nuttiness to it. Light to medium body. A good, typical Brown ale. Worth a try.

name: Gentle Bens Beer Down Nut Brown
review: Aroma of malty chocolate. Brown but amber when held to light. Head at first then disipated to thin layer on top of beer leaving lacing on the glass. Clean on the palate with a roasted flavor and aftertaste. Good beer wish Gentle Ben’s was closer to home.

name: Gentle Bens Copperhead Pale Ale
review: On draft at the brewery in Tucson. Pours a clear gold with an off white head. Aromas are light citrus. Flavors are moderately bitter pine.

name: Gentle Bens Copperhead Pale Ale
review: Pint on tap. Golden color, persistent head...light hay aroma. Bitter and piney for an "english pale ale" but I liked pretty well, I’d definitely order another on tap. Just an enjoyable afternoon beer.

name: Gentle Bens Copperhead Pale Ale
review: On tap at bar in Phoenix Airport (marketed as Barrio Copperhead Pale Ale). Pours a dark gold color. Moderate off-white head that dissipates fairly quickly. Mild grassy, earthy hop aroma. Flavor is similar, but muted. A little thin. Drinkable but nothing to write home about.

name: Gentle Bens Copperhead Pale Ale
review: Draft at BJs in Tucson. Clear and golden. A smallish head. This is gently hopped but they are somewhat complex. Malts are not bad. This is a nice pale ale with wrst coast influences but more, too.

name: Gentle Bens Copperhead Pale Ale
review: Growler from the brewery. Copper gold pour with thick white head. Very fresh citrus and pine hop aroma. Resiny hop bitterness with a nice crisp malt taste. Good session brew.

name: Gentle Bens Copperhead Pale Ale
review: Growler pour with deep clear gold body and copper hues supporting an off white head. The aroma offers up spicy hops, a bit of earthy hops as well as roasty malts, a bit of earthy malts and then a mild tropical fruit sensation off in the background. The taste has a mix of spicy hops, grapefruit hops and some roasty malts too. This is just a good tasty hop forward amber that I’m really enjoying.

name: Gentle Bens Copperhead Pale Ale
review: (Draught) Pours a clear golden body with a medium white head. Aroma of orange, grass, florals, and bread. Flavor of caramel, orange, light pine, florals, and peach.

name: Gentle Bens Copperhead Pale Ale
review: On tap at Barrio Brewing. Pours a clear light orange with a thin white head. Aroma of citrus and piney hops, tropical fruits, sweet caramel malt. Flavor is mostly sweet citrus hops, well blended with a caramel malt base. Very easy drinking. Great hoppy pale! 8/4/8/4/14 (3.8/5)

name: Gentle Bens Copperhead Pale Ale
review: Orange pour with creamy tan head and lace. Light resin and caramel malt aroma. Flavor mirrors aroma. Medium bodied but fizzy. Decent drinker.

name: Gentle Bens Copperhead Pale Ale
review: on tap-pours a disappearing off white head and gold/amber color. Aroma is pine, some light/medium malt. Taste is pine/resin/pineapple hops with some bite, secondary light/medium malt-caramel. Ok carbonation.

name: Gentle Bens Taylor Janes Raspberry Ale
review: Was concerned that this would be a radler. Thankfully, it’s not. Pretty good for a raspberry beer, which tend to be way to raspberry in flavor and too sweet. This is more slightly imbued. Good.

name: Gentle Bens Taylor Janes Raspberry Ale
review: Light bronzed body, silkened head. Wonderful, freshly juiced raspberry nose. Ok raspberry flavor, albeit sugary. Light bodied.

name: Gentle Bens Taylor Janes Raspberry Ale
review: (Draught) Pours a clear golden body with a medium white head. Aroma of raspberry syrup and wheat. Flavor of raspberry flavoring, minerals, wheat, caramel, and light spices.

name: Gentle Bens Taylor Janes Raspberry Ale
review: Gold pour with creamy white head and lace. Huge aroma of raspberry dominates. Sour raspberry start with a dry fruity finish. Thin and watery but very drinkable.

name: Gentle Bens Taylor Janes Raspberry Ale
review: on tap-pours an off white head and gold color. Aroma is raspberry-sweet grain. Taste is raspberry, sweet grain, secondary spice ops.

name: Gentle Bens Taylor Janes Raspberry Ale
review: On tap at the pub. Has a nice light brown with a purple haze coming through. Smells like fresh raspberries. Tastes like an ale that has been steeped with raspberries. It’s not overwhelming, but more a nice backbone that reminds you in the finish. Very nice.

name: Gentle Bens Taylor Janes Raspberry Ale
review: Draft at the pub years back. Best thing about this one by far was how extreme the raspberry nose was rocking. Decent enough for a fruit beer, but still fairly weak all around. Love the nose though!

name: Gentle Bens Taylor Janes Raspberry Ale
review: [Tap] Pours a light amber color with hints of lilac. No head. Strong aroma of raspberry and some wheat malts. Heavy raspberry flavor was sweet, but not cloying. Seemed a bit artificial at times though. Light body was balanced by cereal malts and honey. One dimensional flavor, but actually pretty drinkable.

name: Gentle Bens Taylor Janes Raspberry Ale
review: On tap at Barrio Appearance: Clear golden with a small white head and light lacing Aroma: Raspberry Taste: Raspberry, light malts and caramel OK, light body.

name: Gentle Bens Taylor Janes Raspberry Ale
review: Draft at Barrio. Pours clear pinkish-gold, medium white head; quite persistent, good lacing. Nose is big raspberry, some clean grain, some estery yeast notes. Flavours are big whole raspberries, some malt, slight sourness. I always appreciate it when a brewery does a really pleasant fruit beer, which is sadly all too rare. Good show Barrio!

name: Gentle Bens Nolan Porter
review: On draft at the brewery in Tucson. Pours a clear dark cola with a tan head. Aromas are of tobacco and leather. Flavors are bittersweet cocoa.

name: Gentle Bens Nolan Porter
review: Draft. Blackish beer with a tan head. Light malt and light roast aroma. Malt and light caramel flavor with light roast. Medium bodied. Caramel and light roast linger.

name: Gentle Bens Nolan Porter
review: Draft at Mooney’s in Sedona. Aroma is toasted malt and fruit. Sweet, coffee, red berries, acidic, char. Weird.

name: Gentle Bens Nolan Porter
review: Pours a reddish brown appearance with a tan head. Caramel, dark chocolate, slightly spicy aroma. Cardboard, dull hops, light pine, caramel, burnt sugar flavor. Ehhh, ok.

name: Gentle Bens Nolan Porter
review: Pour is dark reddish black pour with off white head, aroma brought notes of roast, sour fruit, grain, hints of grass, slight coffee, touch of ash, slight molasses. Taste is a mix of grass, caramel, toffee, hints of sour fruit, touch of grain, finishing slightly sour, slightly trashy.

name: Gentle Bens Nolan Porter
review: Pint at Barrio. Very good beer, taste is warm, rich, and balanced for the style. It’s not as strong as I thought it might be, but it has a very rich taste. Very complex, it’s right up my alley!

name: Gentle Bens Nolan Porter
review: Deep brown-black body with adequate head. Medium roasty nose with touches of ash.. Medium to full-bodied with moderate roastyness throughout with ash and molasses notes. A dry coal finish.

name: Gentle Bens Nolan Porter
review: Draft at the Tucson airport near B3 food court. A pleasant surprise and the only non-macro I saw. Dark brown with red hues. A smallish tan head soon becomes a ring. The nose is mostly nutty with a hint of cocoa. The flavor also features nuts, pecans maybe, and is nicely hopped. It is more balanced than expected. The hops seem to include Cascade but perhaps at least one other variety. The nut flavors made this a hybrid porter / brown. Regardless, it was nice if not great.

name: Gentle Bens Nolan Porter
review: (Draught) Pours an opaque black body with a medium tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, light coffee, and lactose. Flavor of roasted malt, dark chocolate, and some molasses.

name: Gentle Bens Nolan Porter
review: On tap at Barrio Brewing. Pours a dark brown with a thin light tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, light sweet malt. Flavor is roasted with lightly charred malt and mild sweetness. Lots of bitterness in the finish. Good porter, a little bland. 7/4/7/4/14 (3.6/5)

name: Gentle Bens MacBlanes Oatmeal Stout
review: Backlog, from notes. On tap @ the brewpub, 23 May 2001 (so probably still from their own kettles). Black color. Aroma’s: roasted malts, sweet coffee. Flavor is moderate sweet with starting bitterness that only becomes stronger in the finish. Good!

name: Gentle Bens MacBlanes Oatmeal Stout
review: Sampled at the Tucson Beer Fest. Clear but so black. Roasted notes that are not really coffee or chocolate. More earthy. Ligjt hops add bitterness and light fruit. Not great.

name: Gentle Bens MacBlanes Oatmeal Stout
review: (Draught) Pours an opaque black body with a medium brown head. Aroma of roasted malt, raisins, oatmeal, and chocolate. Flavor of chocolate, oatmeal, light coffee, and roasted malt.

name: Gentle Bens MacBlanes Oatmeal Stout
review: Black pour with tan head and lace. Huge aroma of burnt coffee dominates. Espresso and toasted malt flavor. Creamy bodied with good carbonation. A beer I liked.

name: Gentle Bens MacBlanes Oatmeal Stout
review: on tap-pours a tan head and black color. Aroma is dark malt-roasty. Taste is oat/dark malt-roasty/coffee, secondary earthy.

name: Gentle Bens MacBlanes Oatmeal Stout
review: on tap as part of the sampler pours black with a medium tan head. Aroma is roasted coffee and roast. Flavor is ashy with again light roast and semi-sweet coffee. Really nice blended with the porter!

name: Gentle Bens MacBlanes Oatmeal Stout
review: Draft at pub. Weak nose, hints of coffee and oats. Dark cocoa, light coffee, and slight oats in the finish. Could be a bit thicker, but is nice and smooth like the porter.

name: Gentle Bens MacBlanes Oatmeal Stout
review: [Tap] Dark brown pour without any head. Roasted malt aroma with more subtle vanilla and caramel notes in the nose. Similar taste of dry coffee, bittersweet chocolate, oatmeal and earth. Grainy and somewhat astringent finish. A bit light, but acceptable for an oatmeal stout. One of the better beers I had at the brewpub.

name: Gentle Bens MacBlanes Oatmeal Stout
review: On tap at Barrio Appearance: Dark brown with a small beige head and some light lacing Aroma: Roasted malts and chocolate Taste: Roasted malts, chocolate and grainy Nice and easy drinking

name: Gentle Bens MacBlanes Oatmeal Stout
review: Draft. Pours clear black, medium tan head, spotty lacing. Nose is oats, faint black licorice, big roast malt. Further nosing coaxes out the coffee and toasted oats lurking underneath. Flavours of oats, cream, very slightly boozy or astringent in the finish. Fairly classic stout.

name: Mickeys Fine Malt Liquor
review: From a can to a glass. Pours a crystal clear light amber color with a medium frothy creamy head. Aroma is barley, corn, slight earthy hops, slight bready yeast. Taste follows the aroma with a medium light mouthfeel.. Tasty Malt Liquor! Leaving excellent malt rings all down the glass!

name: Mickeys Fine Malt Liquor
review: Ohhh Mickey’s.. I can’t count how many darkened days and sunny nights you’ve gotten me through. You truly are the FINEST of malt liquors.

name: Mickeys Fine Malt Liquor
review: Ohhh Mickey’s.. I can’t count how many darkened days and sunny nights you’ve gotten me through. You truly are the FINEST of malt liquors.. only wish you were as cheap as your jailbound cousin (Old E).

name: Mickeys Fine Malt Liquor
review: It's some bad ass beer i remember getting trashed on this shit in high skool with my dad and uncle it waz there favorite beer

name: Mickeys Fine Malt Liquor
review: After all these reviews I noticed I never did a malt liquor. They didn’t have any 8 ball so I grabbed mickeys instead. Obviously it’s not good but I was able to slam it down. Only hints of funk. It will get you drunk! Pretty sure that’s why the style exists cheap and will get you bombed.

name: Mickeys Fine Malt Liquor
review: Smells very fruity and flowery, tastes kinda light and sweet. It tastes like a cheep beer with some corn syrup action going on. It's not bad as a malt liquor. After two I definitely felt it aswell which was nice.

name: Mickeys Fine Malt Liquor
review: From backlog. Bottle at Extended Stay America, Cypress, Ca. Yellow with white head. Malts, hops, corn, Sweet.

name: Mickeys Fine Malt Liquor
review: 24 oz can, Chicago. Much weaker and even hoppier than expected, its reputation is one thing, but the reality is more of a chalky, watery PL. To be avoided or at least not sought out, indeed, though for different reasons than expected

name: Mickeys Fine Malt Liquor
review: 24 oz. can. Very bubbly. A pale, sickly color, and a big, dense, frothy, white head. The nose is mostly corn syrup, with some indistinct hops, wet grass, and bread dough. Sweet and sugary, with a very light bitterness. Light to medium body, with a syrupy, sticky, and very effervescent mouthfeel. Pretty easy and smooth, but not exactly good. And I don't have anyone to blame for this but myself...

name: Mickeys Fine Malt Liquor
review: This is the type of bottle that you throw at a cop's head. Paper bag never required, always preferred.

name: St. Ides High Gravity Malt Liquor
review: This is a backlog rating from 2011 from a can, from notes. When I had this beer it was average to below average for the style and not something I wanted to have again or I just didn't get back to my notes because of my technology at the time. Words to describe this beer are sweet, grainy, corn, why?

name: St. Ides High Gravity Malt Liquor
review: Man, this one brings back memories. Remember those classic commercials? Taste wasn’t as good as Old Gold, but MAN did it have some kick! Haven’t seen it on the east in at least 15 years, but it’s a must try if they still make it. Tasted like a stronger PBR with an aftertaste. Not for everybody, but I enjoyed it.

name: St. Ides High Gravity Malt Liquor
review: Aroma and flavor is sweetish malts/corn and a mix of alcohol and nasty in the finish.

name: St. Ides High Gravity Malt Liquor
review: 16oz can thanks to crossovert Pours clear straw golden white a small white head that dissipates quickly, some lacing. Doesn’t smell offensive, sweet, corn and grains. Taste is sweet, malty, corn and grainy, alcohols No way in hell I could drink even 1 glass if this.

name: St. Ides High Gravity Malt Liquor
review: Can thanks to Yanick! Pours yellow white head - nose/taste of malt, corn, cream soda with a skunky creamed corn finish. Slightly metallic on the back end - medium body.

name: St. Ides High Gravity Malt Liquor
review: The dog on the label is also the one who lifted it’s leg over this can. Awful, awful stuff... would rather drink OE any day of the week.

name: St. Ides High Gravity Malt Liquor
review: Originally rated on 11/1/07. Ah memories.. quick cheap buzz beer. Taste is about what you expect, not the worst for H.G. malt liquiors.

name: St. Ides High Gravity Malt Liquor
review: Huge 24 oz can clear orange lots o bubbles. Alcohol and dry malts. Use this only to get drunk. No real flavor except wheat notes.

name: St. Ides High Gravity Malt Liquor
review: I love a good punishment beer; clear 40oz bottle into pils glass because I’m fancy yo. Bubbly clear pale golden color with ample white head. Aroma notes of grainy pale malt sweetness, corn flakes and faint grape soda; not offensive but not that great. Taste adds more corn bready sweetness almost and faint cardboard-like/grass bitterness. Light-medium body, heavy-moderate carbonation, crisp, tad sticky with light sugary-corny finish. Best drank very cold, best thing I can say is it doesn’t drink like 8.2% ABV. Overall a below average malt liquor.

name: St. Ides High Gravity Malt Liquor
review: Finally cracked my 40 of this the other day, after sticking it in the freezer for about 30 minutes. The initial swig is awesome, no damn corny sweetness, but a harsh, coughing bite of flavor. You can taste, smell, hear(?) the alcohol in this street malt. At first the taste was met with my disapproval but after I was 1/4 through this, I fell in love with it. I actually recommend not putting this one in the freezer, fridge temperature is more than adequate. I gave the palate 5 stars, allow me to explain: despite the initial "burn" this beer grew on me really fast, until I loved it. I instantly wanted more. And not just cause I was drunk.

name: Coors Winterfest
review: From Oct 2005 Poured from the bottle, it formed a decent head that lingered for a while then settled into a fine partial layer. The smell of this deep gold brew is pretty malty but not all that exciting. The taste is a decent balance of hops and malt with the malt lingering in the aftertaste quite well. Overall, a good product from Coors that doesn't exactly titilate the taste buds but *is* quite drinkable. PS: This is the first Winterfest I've seen for many years. If memory serves me well, the first editions of this product were much more complex.

name: Coors Winterfest
review: From old tasting notes. Brilliant Amber orange color. Foamy white head. Fragrant malt aroma with hints of grapefruit. Pleasant hoppy flavor. Excellent bittersweet finish. Dry aftertaste. Full bodied and robust.

name: Coors Winterfest
review: Bottle shared at a tasting at Guinn’s house thanks to Casey. Pours a copper dark amber with a thin off white head. Decent beer.

name: Coors Winterfest
review: Old rating...tastes like being back from college during Christmas break and playing foosball in a friends basement. Slightly sweeter, maltier, and less corny than coors. Still not good.

name: Coors Winterfest
review: The 30th Limited Edition of Winterfest; numbered 81596/263520 and as the label states "in celebration of the holidays" and "Sold only in Colorado". I recall when it initially came out. This one’s much, much, much better. I’d not tried any Winterfests for several years and thought WTF, give it go and recalling the 1st Winterfest batch had that "Colorado Kool-Aid" after taste. Recommended; nice light-brownish orange coloring; a refreshing taste. Looking forward to 2015’s batch now.

name: Coors Winterfest
review: (Actually A C Golden Winterfest, but made by Coors and has replaced Coors Winterfest) Poured from 12 oz bottle into pint glass. Appearance: pours a frothy 2" off white head that slowly falls with mild lacing. Color is a clear deep amber, lots of streaming carbonation. Aroma: malt is dominate with the smell of fresh bread dough, also some toffee and spice notes (cinnamon?). Nice floral hop aroma as well. Mouthfeel: light to medium bodied, quite sticky with a somewhat dry finish. Flavor: cracker, whole grain bread, toffee, some spice notes. Floral and herbal hops in the finish. Overall: extremely well done to the style.

name: Coors Winterfest
review: Clear rich copperish amber with s thin Rocky off white head. Faint aroma with a dark malt and earthy/herbal nose. Rich blonde toast and dark malt flavor, a touch of herbal noble hops and a little raisin. But overall with a lot of blonde malt and golden toast. Slight raisin undertone and toffee.

name: Coors Winterfest
review: December 21st, 2014 - With bottle 185153 out of 263520 I feel a little less special than most limited runs might, but good beer is good beer, whether stuck behind a scarcity gate or bursting off of grocery shelves. Winterfest, from Coor’s higher end brewing arm, is a healthy looking auburn brew with tines of carbonation running up my tulip glass, pushing a slightly sweet, honey-ish scent, with a background of malt. The palate is as active as it looks, so I leave it to settle, which reveals some light golden ale notes, but with a clean, clear lager finish. It’s a bit too light, and certainly doesn’t feel seasonal, but the delicate touch might work better for hotter days. March 1st, 2012 - I appreciate tradition, though as a student of history I often read how dangerous or ill-advised it can be. Nevertheless, pedigrees and homages to distant origins fogged and then burnished by marketers strikes a chord with me, which is why I couldn’t help but put a bottle of Coors’ Winterfest in my holiday sampler pack. It’s a Cocker Spaniel brown color, with a thin tan head. Notes of nuts and corn give the aroma most of its character. A powerful carbonation masks the foretaste, which then slowly advances towards a light flavor with pilsner malt and a faint nutty aftertaste. Overall the flavors are light and even a little wan. 6/3/6/2/12/2.9

name: Coors Winterfest
review: This was the first beer that I couldn’t finish. Tastes like a mixture of dirt, sawdust, and soggy bread. Horrible mouthfeel, leaves you wanted to get the stale taste out of your mouth.

name: Coors Winterfest
review: Bottle poured a clear redish-amber hue w/ a quickly diminishing fizzy white head and some lacing. Light aromas of malt and a fishiness. Flavor is malty, but finishes with hay. Has a long bitter aftertaste. Light to medium body, lively carbonation, metallic feel and watery texture.

name: Erdinger Weissbier
review: 500ml bottle brewed in Germany at 5.3%. Average-ish, so-so-lasting head, poured carefully mind! Light orange colour, but prevented from being genuinely pale by how murky it is - very. Citrus aroma with rusky wheat which develops in intensity. Moderate-medium carbonation. Initial spritz of orange-citrus hops, then monstrous thick-bodied wheat flavours. If you want wheat in your wheat beer, this delivers, with the hops, normally perhaps quite noticeable for a weissbier, here having their work cut out to shine a light through the thickness of body, and just about managing, cutting through every so often when needed. If you've had weissbiers and thought they didn't deliver the wheat, Erdinger has you covered here. Thick, almost frothy mouthfeel. Only hints of that classic banana yeast though, likewise for the other fruity flavours that a really good weissbier can show - they're there, just about, but this one's really wheat-focused. Lovely, thick, creamy and smooth, especially when the carbonation dies down a little. Perhaps not the most flavourful of weissbiers, but there's no duff flavours in here on the other hand, and it certainly delivers the wheat flavour and mouthfeel, while being decently hopped.

name: Erdinger Weissbier Dunkel
review:
Vistoso aspecto con color rubí y una gran espuma. Aroma suave a malta y notas del ligero tostado: crema, caramelo. Ligero olor metálico. En boca es también ligera para el estilo, con baja carbonatacion, cuerpo ligero y final muy corto.
…

name: Erdinger Weissbier Dunkel
review: Bottle pour with a brown color and light wet wood aroma. Notes of oak, toast and a very light body. Very basic on the flavors.

name: Erdinger Weissbier Dunkel
review:
Bottle from Waitrose. Decent. Love the look of the bottle and the look of the beer in the glass.
…

name: Erdinger Weissbier Dunkel
review: A 500ml bottle from Waitrose on offer in there Octoberfest range. A very good Dunkel Weizen.

name: Erdinger Weissbier Dunkel
review: Quite a good beer! Has a hint of faint chocolate. Nice dark color, and smooth taste.

name: Erdinger Weissbier Dunkel
review: Bottle at home. Dark color, middle foam size. Bread in aroma, good kvass taste. Good beer.

name: Erdinger Weissbier Dunkel
review: Pours dark brown/black with large foamy tan head. Sweet, malty wheat beer. Honey, banana, a little vanilla, a little bit creamy. Light texture, low carbonation. Enjoyed it

name: Erdinger Weissbier Dunkel
review: Good beer Two for one in Red Parrot Vung Tau Vietnam so drank 4 I think?. Half cut will fully be able to judge beer following hangover affects tomorrow. This is why I gave less the 5 rating.

name: Erdinger Weissbier Dunkel
review: Keg at brewdog Lothian road. Pours deep brown, nose is roasted, sugary, banana, taste is sweet, caramel, chewy. 6/4/6/3/13

name: Erdinger Weissbier Kristall
review: Part of their Variety Pack from this Christmas with a glass. Pours a clean golden colour with a big creamy warm cap, very long lasting with lots of lacing. Wheat aromas with some peach notes. The taste is malty with some pilsner hops hints in the finish. Clean tasting with a nice touch of dryness. A refreshing, easy-drinking well-brewed Krystalweizen.

name: Erdinger Weissbier Kristall
review: Bottle from Waitrose. It's a nice beer. But it's a wheat beer that has transitioned into a lager. It's ok, but a little boring. A little flat and uninspiring. Looks, aroma and taste are of a nice clean helles larger or pilsner. It's fine, really. But come on.....

name: Erdinger Weissbier Kristall
review: Zapach chmielowy, delikatny banan. Z³ociste, klarowne, wysoka piana. Piwo jest s³odowo s³odkawe, delikatna goryczka z ty³u. Wszystko co dobre w weizenie zosta³o wyfiltrowane. Piwo bez wad w sumie, ale ta goryczka z resztk¹ banana siê nie rymuje.

name: Erdinger Weissbier Kristall
review: Bottle. Aroma and flavor of clean yeast, malt, subtle wheat and bitters. Not very interesting really, these kristall beers lose a lot of their malt and yeast flavors and tend to be a bit boring I think.

name: Erdinger Weissbier Kristall
review: Nice light head of foam. Nice notes of lightly toasted Banana and light wheat. Clean finish.

name: Erdinger Weissbier Kristall
review: 500 ml bottle. Clear yellow color with small white head. Smells grains and some wheat. Taste are a bit dry water with some wheat notes and hidden citrus fruit. Not bad at all and refreshing. Short time aftertaste dry wheat and some little grain bitter.

name: Erdinger Weissbier Kristall
review: Clear golden with a frothy head. Citric smell of hops. Bittersweet taste. The sweetness reminds me of the taste of artificial sweeteners with a kiwi note. The bitterness is unpleasant and too harsh for a wheat beer.

name: Erdinger Weissbier Kristall
review: Hight whitehead. Creamy dark golden in color. Fruity aroma. High carbonated. Nothing special. Light taste of wheat bier.

name: Erdinger Weissbier Kristall
review: Bevuta in bottiglia da 50 in un bar market a Berlino. Aroma discreto ma un po'neutro. Fg

name: Erdinger Weissbier Kristall
review: Butelka 500ml. Klarowne o z³otej barwie. Piana bia³a ,obfita o drobnych pecherzach,opada powoli. Typowe nuty ziarna,lekkich bananów i zió³. W smaku podobnie: banany ,ziarno, trochê s³odu,guma balonowa. Lekko maœlana tekstura ,wysycenie srednie.

name: Erdinger Schneeweisse Winterbier
review: Erinnerte mich anfangs zunächst an die Kuchlbauer Turm Weisse. Mit 5,6 % ebenfalls recht hoher (allerdings nicht ganz so extremer) Alkoholgehalt. Recht fruchtige (insbesondere etwas Grapefruit und Limone), leicht getreidige, sämige Note. Der Hopfen kommt auch nicht zu kurz, auch wenn er erst hinten raus voll durchschlägt. Erfrischend und süffig (trotz reichlich Kohlensäure). Ein interessantes und wohlschmeckendes Bier. Man muss aber sagen, nach 2 Halben am Stück ist es auch gut und man macht sich dann lieber was anderes auf. Nur im Winter erhältlich (und dann auch nicht überall) - und dann hol ich mir auch wieder ein paar Flaschen davon.

name: Erdinger Schneeweisse Winterbier
review: 500ml bottle into a Franziskaner Weissbier glass at home on 13th Sep 2019. Hazy dull golden body, full white head with carbonation bubbles rising to replenish it. Not the pronounced banana and clove esters/flavours you usually get from German Hefewiezen, but it's a lovely, boozy version, very pleasant in deed and now one of my highest rated beers in this style.

name: Prescott Lodgepole Light
review: Pours a clear golden in color with a slight ring of white head. A light malty aroma. Light flavor with a bit of Belgian-like fruit spice hint. Notes: on tap at the brew pub, summer '12

name: Prescott Lodgepole Light
review: On tap at the brewpub. A straw coloured pour eith light carbonation and a ring of white head; grainy aroma; sweet grainy taste with a creamy body; and a light dry biscuity finish. Seems to be untroubled by hops.

name: Prescott Lodgepole Light
review: On tap at Prescott, pours a clear pale blonde with a small white head. Aroma brings out light toasted cereal. Flavour is light and clean, with toasted malt and some sweet cereals. Pointless beer.

name: Prescott Lodgepole Light
review: Draft @ the brewery. Pours clear golden color with white head. Aromas of cereal grain and bread. Grainy and grassy flavor. Medium body with average carbonation.

name: Prescott Lodgepole Light
review: On tap at the brewery. Pours a clear yellow gold with medium white head that lasts. The aroma is grass and wheat. Medium mouth, grass, cereal, wheat, light finish, decent.

name: Prescott Lodgepole Light
review: Pour on tap at the brewery, clear golden pour with white head, aroma brought notes of watery grain, cereal, touch of yeast into a bit of biscuit, touch of slight honey. Taste was a mix of honey, grass, some bread into some watery grain, cereal, finishing sweet.

name: Prescott Lodgepole Light
review: didn’t get much out of this one, either. Light crisp hopping isn’t boring, but overall the beer kinda is, as outside of that, it’s a bit bland and watery.

name: Prescott Lodgepole Light
review: On tap at the brewpub in Prescott where it pours with a clear gold body that supports a thin near white head of foam. The mild aroma offers up lightly sweet maltiness, a grainy wavy note here and there and just noticeable albeit vague hoppiness. The taste is sweet with clean malts flowing into some floral hops and then more and more sugary malt sweetness midway and into the finish. Not too bad but I would enjoy it more with less sweetness.

name: Prescott Lodgepole Light
review: Very light and drinkable. Not really my style of beer. But, would be a great gateway beer for a non craft beer drinker.

name: Prescott Lodgepole Light
review: On draught. Pours clear golden with a white head. Aroma is cracker and cereal. Taste is sweet. Not much going on. Meh.

name: Prescott Liquid Amber
review: Pours a copper color with slight ring of head. A light amber, a bit watery with light spikes of pine-hop notes and a light fruitiness. Bready aroma. Notes: on tap at the brew pub, summer '12

name: Prescott Liquid Amber
review: On tap at the brewery. A golden amber pour with a ring of white head; aroma of caramel malt; sweet malty caramel taste with a light bitterness; and a sweet biscuity finish. Drinkable, but nothing made this stand out.

name: Prescott Liquid Amber
review: 12 oz single can from Total Wine & More - Gilbert, AZ. Clear, light amber appearance with a small beige head and light lacing. Aroma of generic caramel malt, toffee, nuts, and light earthy hops. Similar flavor, rich and moderately sweet with a light hop bitterness. Light to medium body with a soft, creamy feel. OK.

name: Prescott Liquid Amber
review: On tap at Prescott, pours a clear copper with a small white head. Aroma brings out light toasted malt and a touch of caramel. Flavour is very mild, with toasted malt and light bready caramel. Restrained and clean, but very boring. Meh.

name: Prescott Liquid Amber
review: Draft @ the brewery. Pours clear amber color with off white head. Aromas of malt and dough. Similar flavors. Medium body with average carbonation.

name: Prescott Liquid Amber
review: Almost a schoolbook example on how to create an amber ale. A malty body with sweet and fruity caramel flavors balanced up by a crispy and hoppy finish. Excellent!

name: Prescott Liquid Amber
review: Can. Pours clear orange with a medium off-white head, decent lacing. Aroma is caramel, pine and perfume, hints of cardboard. Flavor is medium sweet, medium bitter, grass, pine, caramel. Medium body, light carbonation.

name: Prescott Liquid Amber
review: On tap at the brewery. Pours a clear copper with small white head. The aroma is molasses and honey. Thin mouthfeel, strong honey, wheat, molasses, sweet, good.

name: Prescott Liquid Amber
review: Pour on tap at the brewery, clear orange pour with white head, aroma brought notes of slight biscuit, bread, hints of slight toast into a bit of grain, pine, hints of earth. Taste was a mix of grain, biscuit, toast into a bit of pine, grass, slight red fruit, finishing slightly dry, sweet.

name: Prescott Liquid Amber
review: Draft, man this one is bad. Sweet malty and adjuncty. No hops at all, watery papery and thin mouthfeel.

name: Prescott Pale Ale
review: Pours a "dirty" golden in color with wisps of white head. A bit light, with some piney hop character. A pretty standard pale ale. Notes: on tap at the brew pub, summer '12

name: Prescott Pale Ale
review: On tap at Prescott, pours a clear pale golden yellow with a small white head. Aroma brings out light floral hops and crisp biscuity malt. Flavour is clean, with notes of floral hops and dry biscuity malt. Clean and well-balanced on the finish, with low astringency. Decent.

name: Prescott Pale Ale
review: Draft @ the brewery. Pours clear dark golden color with white head. Aromas of pine and caramel. Sweet caramel and pine flavors with moderate hop bitterness. medium body with average carbonation.

name: Prescott Pale Ale
review: Draft at the source. Clear golden color, medium white head. Aroma of light citrus. Taste has light stone fruit. OK.

name: Prescott Pale Ale
review: On tap at the brewery. Pours a clear gold with medium white head that lasts. The aroma is floral and wheat. Medium mouth, light honey malt, sweet hop, decent.

name: Prescott Pale Ale
review: Pour on tap at the brewery, clear golden pour with white head, aroma brought notes of cracker, biscuit, hints of orange peel into a pine, floral note with a hint of grass. Taste was a mix of lemon, grass, bread, hints of floral notes into a bit of orange, lemon in a bit of grapefruit, finishing bitter. Not bad.

name: Prescott Pale Ale
review: On tap at the brewpub in Prescott where it pours with a clear gold body that supports a dirty white head of foam. The aroma offers up largely grapefruit citrus like hops as well as faint maltiness. The taste starts nice and hoppy with citrusy grapefruit and tangelo hop bitterness and some hop flavor that only gives way slightly to a thin yet pleasing malty base. Nice Pale.

name: Prescott Pale Ale
review: Respectable pale ale, on draft at the brewery. Some hops and flavor but pretty smooth; somewhat grainy. Mild pine. OK, not great, but having it here,as the sun goes down, overlooking the courthouse, makes it better. Monday happy hour, $1 beer with meal.

name: Prescott Pale Ale
review: Pours copper color. Aroma is pine, resin, cracker. Semi sweet and light bitter. Ok.

name: Prescott Pale Ale
review: Light amber pour, quick head. Pine nose. Bitter. Middle is refreshing and bitter. Medium hop finish. Balanced.

name: Prescott Petrified Porter
review: notes from 2003; on tap at the brewery; smooth, chocolaty, slightly roasty porter

name: Prescott Petrified Porter
review: Pours a deep brown with no head. Roasty flavors that approach coffee, though a bit thin with some red apple notes. Bread crust aroma. Notes: on tap at the brew pub, summer '12

name: Prescott Petrified Porter
review: On tap at the brewpub. A cola coloured pour with a ring of white head; aroma of chocoalte malt; rather thin in the mouth with a sweet malted chocolate taste; and a caramel finish. Lakcing the bitterness to make this a true porter.

name: Prescott Petrified Porter
review: On tap at Prescott, pours a deep dark brown with a reddish tinge and a small tan head. Aroma brings out light roast and dry cocoa powder. Flavour brings out chocolate upfront, followed by medium roast and a little coffee. A little jagged and messy, but works okay.

name: Prescott Petrified Porter
review: Draft @ the brewery. Pours dark brown color with tan head. Aromas of roasted malt and chocolate. Roasted malt flavor with bittersweet dark chocolate. Medium to full body with moderate carbonation.

name: Prescott Petrified Porter
review: Dark brown pour at the brewpub. Tan head and some tan lacing. Roasted malt nose and taste. Pretty good.

name: Prescott Petrified Porter
review: On tap at the brewery. Pours a very dark brown with beige head that lasts. The aroma is roast and chocolate. Medium mouth, rich malt, roast, chocolate, light dry finish, very good.

name: Prescott Petrified Porter
review: Pour on tap at the brewery, brownish black pour with off white head, aroma brought notes of dark chocolate, roast, hints of earth into a bit of yeast, touch of coffee with a slight dark fruit note. Taste was a mix of cocoa, roast, coffee into some caramel, touch of earthy tones in a slight dark fruit, finishing sweet, slightly roasted.

name: Prescott Petrified Porter
review: Bottle @ home, thanks Pim & Amy! Aroma is roast, liquorice, lactose, kastanje, spices, caramel and more. Flavour is roasty caramel, nutty, chocolate, fruity notes and more. Nice.

name: Prescott Petrified Porter
review: Bottle. Clear reddish dark brown pour, thin off-white head. Aroma of caramel malts, chocolate, roasted and some coffee. Flavor is quite sweet, roasty malts and quite smooth. A bit thin and a bit too sweet.

name: Vinos 6 Bridges Cream Ale
review: 5/17/19 - Little Rock Ar - on tap at Vino's. Sparkling medium gold, nice bubble action, soft slight snow white head. Neutral aroma, hint of grain. Crisp flavor, some buttery notes, spent grain, touch of nuttiness. Crisp mouthfeel. Good companion to the calzone I had.

name: Vinos 6 Bridges Cream Ale
review: Pours a clear golden with soft white head. Light fruity aroma. Light fruit touch. Very clean and light bodied, a great porch rocker. Notes: on tap at the brewery, Jul ‘18

name: Vinos 6 Bridges Cream Ale
review: Sample at the brewpub. Hazy straw color with a thin white head that evaporates quickly to an outer ring. Short strings of lace. Malt, corn and mild hops in the nose. Light-bodied with flavors of bready malt, wheat, corn and slight hops. The finish is creamy with a malt aftertaste. Slightly above average overall.

name: Vinos 6 Bridges Cream Ale
review: Keg @ Vino’s. Deep gold pour with a small white head. Graham cracker and apple turnover. Pretty faint and neutral aroma. Flavor is pretty mild-mannered. Bread and a bit of graham cracker. Ribbon candy. Some apple. Light body, soft carbonation. Meh.

name: Vinos 6 Bridges Cream Ale
review: Draft at the source. Hazy pale yellow color. Aroma of light hay. Taste is peppery straw.

name: Vinos 6 Bridges Cream Ale
review: Draft - Light peach and pale malt. Clear gold with a decent white head. Light tropical fruit with a quick bitterness that fades nicely.

name: Vinos 6 Bridges Cream Ale
review: Hazy tangerine gold with a thin cap head. The nose is slightly wheaty and a little earthy green grassy. The taste is like a decent wheat beer, with mild biscuity doughiness, mixed with a decent amber ale, with chewy grainy pale toffee and crystal malts. A bit biscuity and chewy overall.

name: Vinos 6 Bridges Cream Ale
review: Into a U.S. pint glass. Half finger of head with a cloudy, medium straw colored body. The smell is mild grain. Taste is fizzy with mild bitterness balanced with a dose of malt. Simple and mild taste overall. Moderate carbonation with a nice fizzy. Light to medium body. Enjoyable and quite drinkable for the long-haul.

name: Vinos 6 Bridges Cream Ale
review: 04.08.2012. On tap at Vinos Brewpub, Little Rock, AR. Golden dark yellow colour with white head. Very soft beer with light malty aromas. Smooth and creamy. Nice, but rather flat malty flavour. low on bitterness and very easy drinkable ale.

name: Vinos 6 Bridges Cream Ale
review: Tap. Golden with small head. Smooth and light bodied, but not watery. Mild hops add some bite. Pretty good.

name: Vinos Firehouse Pale Ale
review: 3/22/19 - Little Rock Ar - on tap at Vino's. Dark Amber, frothy bone colored head. Hint of spice and toffee in the aroma. Chewy flavor, nutty, pomegranate, touch of toffee. Nice textured mouthfeel.

name: Vinos Firehouse Pale Ale
review: Pours a copper color with soft off white head. Clean light malty aroma and taste. Touch of red apple and toasted malt. Notes: on tap at the brewery, Jul ‘18

name: Vinos Firehouse Pale Ale
review: Sample at the brewpub. Clear amber color with a thin foamy off-white head that recedes quickly to a film. Short strings of lace. Malt, fruit and mild hops in the nose. Light-bodied with flavors of floral hops, fruit and malt. The finish is mildly bitter with a short fruity hop aftertaste. Average overall.

name: Vinos Firehouse Pale Ale
review: Keg @ Vino’s. Light amber pour with a small white head. Pretty malty nose. Definitely seems a bit tired and old. Some cardboard and caramel. The taste is similarly tired. Boiled grain and syrupy apple juice. Not much in the way of hops here. Medium body, soft carbonation. Meh.

name: Vinos Firehouse Pale Ale
review: Draft at the source. Hazy amber color, tan head. Aroma of fruity pine. taste is similar.

name: Vinos Firehouse Pale Ale
review: Draft - Light fruit and earthy hops. Cloudy gold with a thin white head. Earthy hops, and bitterness. Muddled flavours.

name: Vinos Firehouse Pale Ale
review: Clear amber with a thin white foamy head. The nose is a bit hard to detect but there’s a nice calm citrus hoppiness. The flavor is light and clean with a biscuity pale malt body and a clean and balanced/low bitterness with a little leafy tone. It’s a bit forgettable and light, perhaps made for the generic beer crowd without stooping to the pale lager level.

name: Vinos Firehouse Pale Ale
review: 04.08.2012. On tap at Vinos Brewpub, Little Rock, AR. Amber pale brown colour with off-white head. Aroma is malty with rather flat notes of malt. Nice smooth bitterness with notes of fruits and floral hops.

name: Vinos Firehouse Pale Ale
review: Tap. Amber with small head. Moderate hops and slightly malty. Pretty unexciting.

name: Vinos Firehouse Pale Ale
review: On tap at the brewpub in Little Rock, AR. Pours a hazed, orange-gold colored body with a finger-width, creamy and frothy, off-white head that dissipates slowly and leaves a moderate lacing. Aroma is on the lighter side with some medium sweet caramels, light floral citruses, and grain. Flavor is similar. Thin, medium sweet caramels and grain with a light floral citrus. Finishes pretty dry with a light, bland, papery and peppery bitterness. Medium length aftertaste following a thin body and a medium, slightly foamy carbonation. Overall, a pretty thin and boring pale ale. No off flavors or anything, just highly unremarkable.

name: Vinos Lazyboy Stout
review: 3/22/19 - Little Rock AR - on tap at Vino's. Sable black pour, creamy mocha head, nice lace. Organic coffee beans, creosote, topsoil in the aroma. Solid everyday brewpub stout, chocolate, black coffee, touch of licorice. Nice chalky dry mouthfeel.

name: Vinos Lazyboy Stout
review: Pours a deep brown color with a ring of off white head. Roast malt and coffee aroma and taste. Light bodied. Notes: on tap at the brewery, Jul ‘18

name: Vinos Lazyboy Stout
review: Sample at the brewpub. Dark brown color with a thin tan head that dissipates quickly to a film. Small patches of lace. Roast malt, coffee and chocolate aroma. Light to medium body with flavors of roasted malt, cocoa and coffee. The finish is roasty with a malt and coffee aftertaste. Decent overall.

name: Vinos Lazyboy Stout
review: Keg @ Vino’s. Deep brown pour with a small head. Chocolate, some ovaltine and cream. Taste has a weird mellow tartness. Root beer. More chocolate. Something seems slightly off. Medium body, soft carb. Not great.

name: Vinos Lazyboy Stout
review: Draft at the source. Brown color, beige head. Aroma of burnt coffee, cocoa. Taste is dark roasted coffee grounds. Light body.

name: Vinos Lazyboy Stout
review: Draft - Roast malts, molasses and dark chocolate. Jet black with a rich brown head. Dark roast, chocolate, light bitterness and a roasty finish. Very drinkable.

name: Vinos Lazyboy Stout
review: Deep black pour with a thin light beige head. The nose is of roasted black malts and a touch of smokey coffee. The taste is rich and deep with lots of chocolaty sweetness and a touch of smokey caramel, with some vanilla-ish coffee roastiness throughout. Nicely complex, even though it tastes like they were trying to be simple with it. A little light but nicely rounded.

name: Vinos Lazyboy Stout
review: Aroma is malt forward. Pours a thick black with a robust, mostly diminishing tan head and minimal lacing. The taste is caramel and dark roasted malt with a slight grainy bitter finish. Medium-full body with medium carbonation. Overall, a nice stout by any measure. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Vinos Lazyboy Stout
review: 04.08.2012. On tap at Vinos Brewpub, Little Rock, AR. Dark brown colour with off-white head. Malty aroma. Medium body with nice malty tones. Rather dry bitter mouthfeel. Dry bitter lasting aftertaste.

name: Vinos Lazyboy Stout
review: Tap. Dark brown with small head. Dry stout with chocolate malt. A little thin on flavor. Bordering on sour, it’s so dry.

name: Vinos Pinnacle IPA
review: 3/22/19 - Little Rock AR - on tap at Vino's. Dark copper pour, slight bubbly khaki colored head, nice lace. Piney aroma, toffee sweetness. Malt accented flavor, some caramel, allspice, a hint of citrus bitterness. Chewy mouthfeel. Old school brewpub IPA.

name: Vinos Pinnacle IPA
review: Pours a golden copper color with soft white head. Floral hop aroma and taste. Light bitterness, quite drinkable and tasty. Notes: on tap at the brewery, Jul ‘18

name: Vinos Pinnacle IPA
review: Sample at the brewpub. Cloudy copper color with a medium off-white head that recedes quickly to an outer ring. Spotty lace. Aroma of citrus, hops and malt. Medium body with flavors of grapefruit, earthy hop and malt. The finish is moderately bitter with a short fruity hop aftertaste. Decent overall.

name: Vinos Pinnacle IPA
review: Keg @ Vino’s. Deep amber pour with a small head. Somewhat still in appearance. Strong caramel malt, overripe cantaloupe. Brown sugary sweetness. Slight pine cone hoppiness that gets dominated by sticky sweet caramel. Heavy and ruddy on the palate. Needs some tweaks.

name: Vinos Pinnacle IPA
review: Draft at the source. Clear deep amber color. Aroma of tropical fruit. Taste is bitter but balanced fruit.

name: Vinos Pinnacle IPA
review: Draft - Light grapefruit and pine. Grapefruit and pine with a hit of bitterness that lingers. Little balance, but that is ok.

name: Vinos Pinnacle IPA
review: Clear copperish with a thin foamy/rocky white head. The nose has a ton of caramel but also a ton of pine resin and grapefruit rind zest. Smells a lot like weed too. Taste is nice and citrusy sweet at the start with a little piney/floral bitterness, leading into a chewy grainy caramalt tone. Finishes with a kiss of nutty toffee with, also, some grassiness.

name: Vinos Pinnacle IPA
review: 04.08.2012. On tap at Vinos Brewpub, Little Rock, AR. Rather dark amber golden colour with white head. Aroma dominated by tastefull and very fresh and crisp hops. Lots of flavours of both hops and malt. Refreshing and very nice IPA with lots of hops. Just as I like it.

name: Vinos Pinnacle IPA
review: Tap. Amber with small head. Nice IPA. Citrus hops and good flavor. Somewhat floral.

name: Vinos Pinnacle IPA
review: On tap at Vino’s. Dark copper color, excellent lacing, no aroma, really. Head fades to an irregular frisbee. Not my favorite IPA, but a passable attempt. It’s one-trick pony, not very complex. The taste profile that is there, however, is pretty good! It goes just fine with the pizza!

name: AleSmith Grand Cru
review: Proefglas van 75cl-fles. U: Wazig amber met een beige schuimkraag. G: Sinaasappel, karamel, esters en alcohol. S: Zoet met een lichte bitterheid. Esters, karamel en sinaasappel. M: Volmondig met matige carbonatie. Plakkerig.

name: AleSmith Grand Cru
review: Chocolate caramel malt spice aroma. Murky brown colour poor head and lacing. Malt caramel chocolate spice flavour. Smooth lingering palate.

name: AleSmith Grand Cru
review: Hazy dark amber with a little head. Malty, fruit in rum, raisins, brown sugarm fortunately only little sweetness, herbs, a bit boozy, good!

name: AleSmith Grand Cru
review: 750ml bottle aged for 5 years. Hazy brown appearance. Aroma is caramel and sweet. Flavour is sweet, caramel, dried fruit and cherry.

name: AleSmith Grand Cru
review: Bottled 750ml. -from Pivoteka Zagreb. Dark golden/amber coloured, small off-white head, malt and dried fruits in the nose. Sweet malty, dried fruits, notes of caramel, spices and wood with light touch of alcohol in the finish. Not bad at all but overrated in general.

name: AleSmith Grand Cru
review: 750ml bottle. Pours ruby red brown. Caramel, strawberry, biscuit, cherry, red grape, strong toffee, synthetic raspberry. Good body. Lovely.

name: AleSmith Grand Cru
review: Not a fan chocolate notes not satisfying. Never have been a fan of the Belgian yeasts. My exceptions for the Belgians are the Quadrupels, I tend to like them.

name: AleSmith Wee Heavy Scotch Ale
review: 0.75 l bottle from former 'Bierkompass', 2014 vintage, cellared for about four-and-a-half years. Clear, dark ruby with a thin, frothy, almost stable, beige head. Sweetish-malty, gently fruity aroma of caramel, molasses, raisins, prunes, dates and a touch of port. Fairly sweet, malty, slightly bitter, gently fruity taste of molasses, caramel, raisins, prunes, some gingerbread, a touch of vanilla and traces of port, followed by a medium long, moderately bitter, minimally roasty, a little herbal-smoky and a bit warming finish. Medium to full body, smooth and slightly effervescent mouthfeel, soft carbonation. Extremely well-balanced and moreish example of the style which held up so well over approximately five years. Would love to try the Bourbon BA version.

name: AleSmith Wee Heavy Scotch Ale
review: Bottle sampled at sbwf 2019. No head and a clear brown color. Very nice caramell malty taste and aroma. Lingering malt sweetness and medium bitterness.

name: AleSmith Wee Heavy Scotch Ale
review: Surprised I haven't rated this yet, Bottle that pours a reddish brown with medium sized head and lacing. Notes are raisin, smoked malt, fig, prunes, dark fruit, roasted malt, and spice. Medium to fuller body with a warming and slightly hot finish.

name: AleSmith Wee Heavy Scotch Ale
review: Cloudy brown,tan head. Malt nose. Huge bodied malt profile, light alcohol heat. Seems more like a barleywine than a scotch ale.

name: AleSmith Wee Heavy Scotch Ale
review: 75cl bottle @ monthly tasting, Chez Sophie, June 19. Aged by me for 4 years, and thankfully still holding up well. Pours hazed deep brown, frothy tan head. Aroma of caramel, moist fruitcake. Taste is deep flavoursome, smooth balanced caramel sweet malt, fruitcake with a bitter whisper. Lovely stuff.

name: AleSmith Wee Heavy Scotch Ale
review: 11th June 2019; Shrewsbury Beer Exchange meeting in Chez Sophie, cheers Mat for the 75cl bottle (Bottled in 2014). Beige head with lacing, dark brown body. Boozy chocolate brew with a light singed roastiness that gives a little bitterness late on. Glad I have eventually tried this famous brew.

name: AleSmith Wee Heavy Scotch Ale
review: Dark brown colour with nice beige coloured head. Aroma has licorice, caramel fudge, earthy notes, toffee sweetness. Taste has caramel fudge, toffee, smoky flavour, earthy notes too and ending with bitter and salty licorice. Full body and lowish carbonation. Damn good sipper.

name: AleSmith Wee Heavy Scotch Ale
review: Bottle, thanks G. Dark red body with a medium tan head. Marzipane, malts, berries, toffee, light ash. Medium sweetness, mineralic, tart-ish notes, nice. Creamy but slick body with natural carbonation. Nicely done, malty but also fruity with intense almond notes.

name: AleSmith Wee Heavy Scotch Ale
review: Telt mahagóni színe karamellás, dohányleveles, banános, aszalt gyümölcsös illatok visszafogott egyvelegét rejti, melyek egy füstös, fás színezetû, vajkaramellás, vadszószos, borókabogyós, vörös áfonyás, gyógynövényes jegyekbõl álló testben öltenek folyékony formát. Különösebben meghökkentõ, kirobbanó jelleget nem áraszt, egyszerûen csak a típus egyik mintapéldányaként lép fel, amely önmagában nem nyújt katartikus élményt, nagyszerûsége a stabilitásában, a kikezdhetetlen karakterében, a remekül összeforrott komponensek játékában keresendõ.

name: AleSmith Wee Heavy Scotch Ale
review: Really heavy. Trzeba lubiæ ten styl. Piwo jak gruba pierzyna w przegrzanym pokoju, wyciska siódme poty. Utlenienie chyba zamierzone. Ja tego nie umiem piæ.

name: AleSmith Old Numbskull
review: Bottle at RB share: bottle is quite ancient. pours brown with a small head. Aroma is caramel, toffee, malt. Taste is slightly sweet, boozy, smooth maltiness.

name: AleSmith Old Numbskull
review: Bottle. Color: Reddish copper, off-white to beige head. Aroma: Sweet, caramel, dark fruit, toffee. Taste: Sweet toffee, caramel, dark fruit and hints of red fruit, hints of vanilla. Medium to over medium sweet, moderate to over moderate bitter. On the sweet side, nice.

name: AleSmith Old Numbskull
review: Large bottle share at BrewDog Shoreditch in 2016. Deep amber pour. Aroma of honey comb, dried and stone fruits and burnt sugar. Very full bodied. Lots of rich, resinous, tinned fruit flavours.

name: AleSmith Old Numbskull
review: 750 ml bottle at home. Pours a hazy dark amber with a light beige head. The aroma is medium malty and lightly hoppy with toffee, bread, some honey, some raisins, dried fruits, quiet some pine and light herbal notes. Medium full body with a light to medium sweetness and a light to medium bitterness. The flavor is medium hoppy and medium malty, similar to the smell but with a more pronounced hop presence - sweet malt, honey, bread, toasted bread, toffee, raisins, hints of alcohol, pine, some resin. Finishes with a light to medium hoppy bitterness. Very balanced and with a good drinkability due to the nice hop presence which perfectly balances the sweetish malt. Aroma: 8 Appearance: 4 Taste: 8 Mouthfeel: 4 Overall: 15

name: AleSmith Old Numbskull
review: Hazy amber colour, nice ivory head. Nose: honey, caramel, toffee, dried fruit, esters. Full body. Soft carbonation. Taste: fine malts, dried fruit, honey, sufficient hops. Excellent balance. Perfect stuff.

name: AleSmith Old Numbskull
review: Bottle from the brewery - brown color, small head. okay, I wanted it. this is heavy stuff, goes directly in your head, esspecially the big bottle. malty, creamy, caramell. quite sweet. headache stuff. but a fine example of barley wine.

name: AleSmith Old Numbskull
review: I wanted it to have more fullness and mouthfeel, to go with that outstanding aroma and lovely looks. However the underlying alcohol tang made it less enjoyable, not hugely but. Did only that warmness though at the very end and back of the sup. I liked it the more it warmed up, which was in parallel with the amount I drank :-)

name: AleSmith Old Numbskull
review: 140419. Bottle at home (aged a few years). Pours clear mahogany with a small head. Aroma ripe fruit, raisins, some hops. Sweet with a hint of alcohol. Tears of joy drip into the glass. It's like suckling the tit of a fair maiden. Staring hard at the perfect figure of the female form. The farm party suffers a land slide loss and the beer gets even better. The Finnish Women's hockey team win the world championship (it was a goal) and it gets to orgasmic levels. Sadly I have to go to work tomorrow. Not Bad.

name: AleSmith Weizenbock
review: Bottle split at RB Best awards dinner, thanks to Bobby, 30/01/16. Orange golden with a minimal off white covering. Nose is papery, oxidised tones, grains, rich fruit. Taste comprises darker fruits, caramel, grains, corn. Medium bodied, moderate carbonation, semi drying close. Fun to try but past its best ... could have been worse though!

name: AleSmith Weizenbock
review: Bottle shared at Ratebeer awards show. 30/01/2016. 2001 vintage. Many thanks to Bobby. A light orange amber coloured pour with no head. Aroma is aged sweet malts, toffee, mint and apple cake. Flavour is composed of woody, aged, dusty, stale malts, toffee, mint and musty. Palate is sweet and viscoud, medium bodied, . Maybe a little too much age.

name: AleSmith Weizenbock
review: ’01 Bottle shared by torino at RBWG: Poured an orange with very little bubble head. Aroma was light soggy cardboard and malts. Obviously the taste had fallen way off but, even though it was light an oxidized the taste was malty to its core. I’m sure this one was amazing in its prime.

name: AleSmith Weizenbock
review: Bottle @ RBWG 2016. Thanks, Bobby, I’ve always wanted to try a 15 year old weizenbock... Dark amber beer with no real foam/head. Not surprisingly, quite oxidized. A lot of caramel, maple, and sweet sugars. The nose is pretty decent, actually. Unfortunately, this tastes like cardboard and celery. Some bitterness and a bit of caramel sauce. Oh well.

name: AleSmith Weizenbock
review: 750 ml bottle shared by t0rin0 at the RB Awards - thanks, Bobby! 2001 vintage. Holy smokes, that is some serious deep rotbox cred. From the days of green bottles at AleSmith. Pours a nearly clear golden orange with no head. Notes of cardboard, paper, honey, caramel, plastic, hay, and cereal. Light-bodied, with low carbonation and an oxidized, flat mouthfeel. Obviously much different than where it started, but it was fun to try.

name: AleSmith Weizenbock
review: [1/30/16] Bottle sample at the Encomium bottle share, after RateBeer Best awards ceremony at Hyatt Vineyard Creek Hotel in Santa Rosa. Thanks everyone who shared bottles! Hazy orange, flat. Aroma of malt, cookies, some fruits, caramel, oxidation. Sweet, a bit of cardboard, grapes.

name: AleSmith Weizenbock
review: Bottle thanks to torino. Pours a hazy copper with small beige head that diminishes to nothing. Lots of oxidation on the nose and wet cardboard. Medium mouth, oxidation, bready malt, boozy, didnt hold up well.

name: AleSmith Weizenbock
review: Bottle, thanks Bobby! Vintage 2001. Light hazy amber liquid with minimal white head. Aroma of raw sugar, raisins, port wine, dried fruit and oak. Taste is light to medium sweet and light bitter with notes of port wine, raisins, tobacco and raw sugar. Full bodied with low carbonation. Quite rotten.

name: AleSmith Weizenbock
review: 750 ml bottle to taster (thanks t0rin0). Looks solid; a mostly transparent caramelish orange with very thin lacing that dissipates quickly and completely. Smells malty and boozy with notes of caramel and oxidation. Tastes like it smells with a sticky medium full-bodied mouthfeel. Okay, but clearly past its prime.

name: AleSmith Weizenbock
review: 2001 bottle thanks to torino. Dark brown murky appearance with a thin tan head. Aroma has light banana, caramel, chocolate, and chocolate. Low carbonation. Pretty good drinking dessert beer. OK but well past its prime.

name: AleSmith X Extra Pale Ale
review: Z³ote, zmêtnione, piana niezbyt obfita. Aromat owocowy, grejpfrut, mango plus karmel, ¿ywica. Smak ca³kiem s³odki, karmel plus owoce tropikalne, ¿ywicznoœæ, mo¿e lekka kwiatowoœæ. Goryczka niska, bardzo przyjemna. Bardzo fajne pijalne piwo, bez wiêkszych wad.

name: AleSmith X Extra Pale Ale
review: Appearance is amber with a slight haze, a small foamy clingy white head. Aroma is lots of pithy stone fruit, orange, stewed fruit, mango, caramel hints. Taste- pineapple, mango, hops, grapefruit hints, stone fruit, toffee and caramel undertones with a trace of biscuity malt.

name: AleSmith X Extra Pale Ale
