Malt, fruit and slight hops in the nose. Light-body with flavors of sweet malt and honey, wheat and mild hops. The finish is sweet with an herbal honey aftertaste. Slightly above average overall.

name: Glenwood Canyon Hanging Lake Honey Ale
review: On tap at the brewery. Pours a clear orange gold with small frothy white head that lasts. The aroma is honey and wheat. Medium body, wheat, grass, light honey, crisp, good.

name: Glenwood Canyon Hanging Lake Honey Ale
review: Enjoyed on tap at Glenwood Canyon Brewpub in Glenwood Springs, CO after getting rejected by a full parking lot trying to go to Hanging Lake. I didn't tasting notes, but remember this being a solid, straight forward crisp honey ale, easy drinking. Its sessionable, good stuff.

name: Glenwood Canyon Hanging Lake Honey Ale
review: On tap at the brewery. Golden orange and clear appearance with a white ring of foam. Light honey and light bready malts in the aroma. Similar flavor, not much going on. Light body with a crisp feel. Pretty bland and boring overall.

name: Glenwood Canyon Hanging Lake Honey Ale
review: On tap at the brewpub. Pour is clear golden with a big white head and sticky lacing. Sweet honey, biscuit, caramel, tangy, and doughy aroma. Taste has cracker malt, some biscuit, light honey, lightly grassy, and doughy with a sweet finish. Light body with high carbonation. Nothing off, but pretty bland.

name: Glenwood Canyon Hanging Lake Honey Ale
review: Tap. Pours yellow with white head. Aroma is really nonexistent...quite disappointing. Taste is very honey, sweet, light, crisp, good body for such a light beer. Meh.

name: Glenwood Canyon Hanging Lake Honey Ale
review: Poured from tap to glass. Beautiful crystal clear straw hue with white head. Aroma is lager like, slight sulphur, honey, straw, floral. Mouthfeel is refreshing with a light body and crisp carbonation. Taste is clean dryness throughout with a sulphur following and clean finish. Overall this is a well executed brew.

name: Glenwood Canyon Hanging Lake Honey Ale
review: Tap @ brewery. Pours a clear yellow appearance with a thin white head. Light lemon, light straw, a touch sweet aroma. A touch grainy, honey, lightly carbonated, mildly fruity, bland but drinkable flavor.

name: Glenwood Canyon Hanging Lake Honey Ale
review: On tap at the brewpub. Comes a cloudy light gold with a small white head. Mild aroma of malt and grain. Taste is malt, wheat, honey, and florals. Very mild. Not too exciting, but refreshing.

name: Glenwood Canyon Hanging Lake Honey Ale
review: On tap at the brewpub it is a cloudy golden with a slight head a malty arms dome bitterness nit much indication of the flavors in the beer bitterness lingering on the palate

name: Glenwood Canyon Grizzly Creek Raspberry Wheat
review: Draft at the Glenwood Canyon Brewpub, Glenwood Springs. Definitely raspberry but a little thin in the finish

name: Glenwood Canyon Grizzly Creek Raspberry Wheat
review: At the brewery. This is simple but drinkable enough. Real, unsweetened rasperry in the aroma and the flavor, lightly sweet beer flavor as well. Not much here, but this is better than many beers of this sort.

name: Glenwood Canyon Grizzly Creek Raspberry Wheat
review: On tap at the brewery. Pours a hazy pink orange with small pinkish head leaving spotty lacing. The aroma is berry and wheat. Thin body, berry, wheat, medicine, light tartness, ok.

name: Glenwood Canyon Grizzly Creek Raspberry Wheat
review: On tap at the brewery. Clear amber appearance with a white ring of foam. Fresh raspberry flavor with light bready malts. Similar flavor, sweet and fruity with a light body.

name: Glenwood Canyon Grizzly Creek Raspberry Wheat
review: On tap at the brewpub. Pour is hazy salmon colored with a small white head and no lacing. Artificial raspberry, cough syrup, some fruit skins, bready, and doughy aroma. Taste is more artificial fruit flavors - raspberries and strawberry - biscuit, and tangy. Light body with high carbonation. Not good.

name: Glenwood Canyon Grizzly Creek Raspberry Wheat
review: Tap. Pours orange with a bit of pink and white head. Aroma is slightly fruity- not a whole lot of aroma. Taste is very raspberry, a touch bitter, good fruit flavor but nothing overbearing. A very good fruit beer.

name: Glenwood Canyon Grizzly Creek Raspberry Wheat
review: Tap @ brewery. Pours a pinkish orange appearance with a white head. Slightly spritzy, raspberry, lightly tart aroma. Somewhat tangy raspberry, slightly artificial, light flavor that isn’t necessarily very good but it’s not offensive.

name: Glenwood Canyon Grizzly Creek Raspberry Wheat
review: On tap at the brewpub it is a clear reddish color with s slight white head it has the aroma of raspberry bitter flavor with a hint of the raspberry

name: Glenwood Canyon Grizzly Creek Raspberry Wheat
review: On draft at the brewpub in Glenwood Springs CO. Pours a clear reddis amber with a white head. Light fruity nose. Flavors of raspberry soda. Refreshing brew for a hot day.

name: Glenwood Canyon Grizzly Creek Raspberry Wheat
review: ON tap at the brewpub. Pours copper with a long lasting white head and soda-like carbonation. Aroma is of raspberries and caramel and wheat malt. Body is light and smooth. Taste is sweet, mostly raspberries. Short sweet finish. Quite a drinkable brew.

name: Glenwood Canyon Red Mountain ESB
review: Tap. Pours orange with white head. Aroma is grainy, faint. Taste is very cereally, grains, a bit thin, easy. Fine.

name: Glenwood Canyon Red Mountain ESB
review: ON tap at the brewpub. Pours amber with a long lasting white head and lively carbonation. Aroma is of caramel, ripe fruit and earthy hops. Body is medium and smooth. Taste is similar to aroma. Medium, dry finish. On the whole it is nice brew.

name: Glenwood Canyon Red Mountain ESB
review: The name does not ring a bell, but the website says it is one of their 6 year round house brews. No doubt I had it, if not in a growler, than as a sampler, or sipped someone elses. Did not leave a lasting effect on me (on my memory (ok, that doesn’t help my point either)). Beer.

name: Glenwood Canyon Red Mountain ESB
review: The mountains of Colorado harbor many niches, nooks and crannies, within which lie a bounty of hidden mines, towns and even the occasional bakery (Silver Plume). Glenwood Springs is not what you’d call a quaint mountain town, exactly, but it’s not a global tourism destination either. Home to a therapeutic hot springs, it sees its fair share of visitors, and those who do go get a chance to visit the local brewpub: Glenwood Canyon Brewing Company. It is by no means an infamous brewery, or a landmark in craft beer, but it provides better beer to a town with one foot still in the past, and that makes it all the more charming. My family and I ordered a sampler to get a well rounded taste of the offerings, and I came away reasonably impressed, considering my expectations. The Red Mountain ESB took the third spot, in line with the chromatic scheme of light to dark, lucid to obscure. It is a very dark bronze color, rustic and burnt, a bit like Sicily, with a thread-thin head. The smell offered a great deal more, blasting the nose with a feast of caramel, sweetened-condensed milk, chocolate and the distinctive aroma of a temperate forest in the midst of a heavy rain. The taste is far less sweet, retaining the solid core of caramel, but replacing the sweet from the aroma with a metallic, cupric bitterness. In a broader perspective of the taste, it is still sugary and satisfying, overflowing with a shining caramel flavor profile, balanced with a less-than-ideal metallic contrast. It is refreshing, easy to drink, and relaxing – an excellent choice for a session beer, and a beer entirely matching with Glenwood Spring’s mountainous, pioneer feel. Slightly rugged, but comfortable and full of character: a beer befitting the town.

name: Glenwood Canyon Red Mountain ESB
review: on nitro-pours a light tan head that laces and copper color. Aroma is slight sweet medium malt. Taste is slight sweet medium malt, secondary hops with flat bite/bitterness. As much a standard Bitter than ESB. Mild carbonation.

name: Glenwood Canyon Red Mountain ESB
review: [GABF, Denver Co - 2006] A deep reddish copper color. Has a lightly roasted aroma with a great flavor and a good mix of hops to malts. This was a refreshing brew for the day.

name: Glenwood Canyon Red Mountain ESB
review: Draught. Pours copper-amber with a small off-white foamy head that lasts, good lacing. Aroma is lightly roasted caramel malt. lightly floral hops and hints of brown sugar. Medium sweet malt flavor, slightly sugary and notes of honey. Light bodied and clean, smooth palate.

name: Glenwood Canyon Red Mountain ESB
review: ESBs, if this is a normal one, don’t seem too bitter to me. actually sweet. Mostly this one just tastes like a thinned-out pale ale. A disappointing beer for sure.

name: Glenwood Canyon Red Mountain ESB
review: Caramel-colored; nice and creamy head. Soft, creamy texture with a nice carb. level. Notes of caramel and burnt toffee. Building bitterness, with notes of grassy and curious pine.

name: Glenwood Canyon Red Mountain ESB
review: Nice reddish amber with beautiful cascading waterfall head. Light aroma along the caramel lines. Woody-caramel flavors. Metallic finish. Not as good as I’d heard it was.

name: Glenwood Canyon No Name Nut Brown Ale
review: Smooth palate. Aromas and flavors of nut, chocolate and roasted malt. Light to medium weight.

name: Glenwood Canyon No Name Nut Brown Ale
review: On tap at the brewery. Pours a clear amber with medium frothy off white head that lasts. The aroma is cocoa and bread. Medium body, roast, cocoa, light dry finish, decent.

name: Glenwood Canyon No Name Nut Brown Ale
review: On tap at the brewery. Clear amber appearance with a diminishing white head. Roasted, toasted malt flavor with mild sweetness and a mild earthy bitterness. A decent brown overall.

name: Glenwood Canyon No Name Nut Brown Ale
review: On tap at the brewpub. Pour is deep amber-brown with a small eggshell colored head and good lacing. Big nutty, toffee, brown sugar, grapey and fake fruity aroma. Taste is cookie malt, dark fruits, tangy, some red licorice, brown sugar and caramel. Medium body with soft carbonation. Not really a brown but not bad either.

name: Glenwood Canyon No Name Nut Brown Ale
review: On tap at brewery. Pours a dark amber making a off white head. Medium lacing. Smells of malt and caramel. Tastes of caramel and toffee and light barley malt. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Glenwood Canyon No Name Nut Brown Ale
review: Tap. Pours clear brown with dark red hues and an off-white head. Aroma is sweet malts, not much aroma. Taste is subtle, easy, very session able. Really not too great.

name: Glenwood Canyon No Name Nut Brown Ale
review: Poured from tap to glass. Crystal clear amber brown hue with off white head. Aroma is honey, caramel, nutty, biscuit. Mouthfeel is nice with a medium body and soft carbonation. Taste is roasted sweetness initially with a dry nutty bitter following and finishes clean. Overall this is a decent brown but is light on the nuttiness.

name: Glenwood Canyon No Name Nut Brown Ale
review: Tap @ brewery. Pours a dark reddish orange appearance with a light brown head. Caramel toasted malty, light toffee, grassy/herbal aroma. Somewhat sweet, nutty, caramel, toasted flavor with slightly buttering, earthy hops. Average.

name: Glenwood Canyon No Name Nut Brown Ale
review: On tap at the brewpub. Comes a dark reddish brown with a small biege head. Aroma of malt, caramel, and a bit of hops. Taste is the same. Mild, but very drinkable.

name: Glenwood Canyon No Name Nut Brown Ale
review: on draft at the brewpub it is a dark amber color with a slight head aroma is fairly malty and the taste is malty with a hint of molasses does not linger long on the palate

name: Glenwood Canyon Trail Pale Ale
review: On tap at the brewery. Pours a medium gold color and makes a foamy white medium head. Smells of citrus and hops. Tastes medium hoppy and light. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Glenwood Canyon Trail Pale Ale
review: on tap-pours a retaining thin off white head an gold color. Aroma is citrus hops, secondary medium malt. Taste is citrus hops-some bitter, secondary sweet medium malt-caramel. Dry. OK/mild carbonation.

name: Glenwood Canyon Vapor Cave IPA
review: Draft at Glenwood Canyon Brewpub, Glenwood Springs. Pleasant hoppy IPA with a fruity edge

name: Glenwood Canyon Vapor Cave IPA
review: Average IPA with a moderate hop bite. Slight caramel base with a dirty yellow color and a big head.

name: Glenwood Canyon Vapor Cave IPA
review: On tap at the brewery. Pours a clear orange gold with medium frothy white head that lasts. The aroma is citrus and grass. Medium body, citrus, pine, light resin finish, good.

name: Glenwood Canyon Old Depot Porter
review: On tap at brewery. Pours a dark, black body and makes a thin light brown head. Smells of cocoa and roasted barley. Tastes full and mildly of chocolate. A good porter in the style. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Glenwood Canyon Old Depot Porter
review: Tap. Pours dark brown with off-white head. Aroma very chocolates and roasty. Has a very roasty flavor, dark chocolate, a bit hotter, slightly thin. Alright.

name: Glenwood Canyon Old Depot Porter
review: Poured from tap to glass. Dark hue with creamy tan head. Aroma is coffee, roasted malt, honey, cocoa. Mouthfeel is decent with a lighter body and soft carbonation. Taste is dry sweetness initially with a nice astringent malt bitterness in the following and finishes clean. Overall this is a lighter bodied Porter but quite nice.

name: Glenwood Canyon Old Depot Porter
review: On tap at the brewpub. Comes almost black with a small tan head. Aroma of malt, chocolate, and coffee. Taste is similar. Very easy to drink.

name: Glenwood Canyon Old Depot Porter
review: On draft at the brew pub it is a dark deep reddish brown with a slight head aroma of chocolate and roasted coffee that transfers to the taste it lingers on the palate

name: Glenwood Canyon Old Depot Porter
review: On draft at the brewpub in Glenwood Springs CO. Pours black with an ecru head. Flavors of coffee and chocolate. A decent porter.

name: Glenwood Canyon Old Depot Porter
review: on tap-pours a creamy light brown head and black color. Aroma is licorice-anise, dark malt. Taste is licorice-anise, dark malt. Medium body. Mild carbonation. Nice.

name: Glenwood Canyon Old Depot Porter
review: Robe brune foncée aux reflets rouges surmontée d’une mousse beige fugace. Arômes de noix et de malts rôtis. Saveurs de noix et de malts rôtis. Texture crémeuse.

name: Glenwood Canyon Old Depot Porter
review: Black, with very dark brown edges. Smooth, chewy texture. Sweet and roasty and very rich. Big notes of molasses and chocolate. A little toast and caramel, too. Nice and balancing bitterness. Pretty fine porter!

name: Glenwood Canyon Shoshone Stout
review: Pours a nice tan head, and has aroma of fresh coffee. Good malt notes with adequate English hops. Smooth mouthfeel, caramel coffee background, and no bitterness. Friend brought me a take home can and I really appreciate it, so I can’t wait to hit the west slopes of the Rockies and have Shoshone on tap! Thebrewdoc

name: Glenwood Canyon Shoshone Stout
review: Tap @ brewery. Pours a deep brown appearance with a dark brown head. Cocoa, a bit roasty, oaty, light espresso aroma. Slightly bitter, a touch fruity hoppy, light caramel, chocolate flavor. Eh.

name: Glenwood Canyon Shoshone Stout
review: Growler poured a clear dark reddish brown with a lingering ring of tan foam. Aromas of roastiness, coffee and dark chocolate. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of roastiness, dark chocolate, coffee and light carmel with a smooth lingering roasty finish.

name: Glenwood Canyon Shoshone Stout
review: I used to buy this stuff in growers. Big old gallon and a half (or maybe just half gallon, who knows?) and get it refilled for free whenever i took it back. Shoshone Stout was always my very favorite.

name: Glenwood Canyon Shoshone Stout
review: The mountains of Colorado harbor many niches, nooks and crannies, within which lie a bounty of hidden mines, towns and even the occasional bakery (Silver Plume). Glenwood Springs is not what you’d call a quaint mountain town, exactly, but it’s not a global tourism destination either. Home to a therapeutic hot springs, it sees its fair share of visitors, and those who do go get a chance to visit the local brewpub: Glenwood Canyon Brewing Company. It is by no means an infamous brewery, or a landmark in craft beer, but it provides better beer to a town with one foot still in the past, and that makes it all the more charming. My family and I ordered a sampler to get a well rounded taste of the offerings, and I came away reasonably impressed, considering my expectations. The Shashone occupied the very last spot, ostensibly as the thickest, darkest offering from the brewpub. They’re right – but the Shoshone Stout is not a big, heavy, burly stout by any means. It’s sweeter than most, lighter than most, and a fine way to top a meal in place of a dessert or coffee. By appearance it is dark and opal, much like Guinness, but the aroma immediately indicates something special. The sweeter side of oatmeal rushes into the nostril, reinforced in its dulcet breakfasted theme with a hefty spoonful of brown sugar, peat, rich roasted coffee and the distinct scent of a greenhouse. The texture is smooth as silk, or better yet, smooth and soft as velvet, but not as dense or as decadent. It’s actually sort of weak and watery following a motif through Glenwood Canyon’s brew line-up. But, like the contemporaneous Nut Brown Ale and ESB, it makes for a calm, effortless drink, and a fine conclusion to a good meal at the brewpub. I think there are dozens of stouts like this one out there, but it’s nice to see it offered in the context of a restaurant and available to a community should they so desire something sweetly drinkable to shake off the chilly spring mornings in the mountains.

name: Glenwood Canyon Shoshone Stout
review: nitrogen dispensed-pours a big creamy tan head and black color. Aroma is oatmeal, chocolate, dark malt. Taste is licorice, oatmeal, dark malt. Not my style but would enjoy occasionally. Creamy, full body. Mild carbonation.

name: Glenwood Canyon Shoshone Stout
review: Draught. Pours opaque with a tan frothy head, thick and edgy. Aroma is dark roasted coffee and chocolate malt, yeast (leather). Dark chocolate malt, mild bitterness, smooth chocolate flavor, finish is slightly hoppy. Dark and thin bodied, smooth palate.

name: Glenwood Canyon Shoshone Stout
review: This would be best described as a smoked stout, if you ask me. That’s the aroma and first flavors anyway. Being so smoky it’s actually pretty light. A decent stout, second or third on the list behind their barleywine.

name: Glenwood Canyon Shoshone Stout
review: Nice and black with a creamy tan head. Smooth, soft body with a very mild carbonation level. Rich and very sweet ... a little too sticky, actually. Rather roasted, with notes of coffee, a little sourness and some sweet milk. OK stout, but a little too sweet, slightly unbalanced, and a little cloying.

name: Glenwood Canyon Shoshone Stout
review: Solid black with a firm standing beige head. Medium coffee aroma but a sour/sweet burnt malt flavor that is off-key.

name: Pug Ryans MorningWood Wheat
review: On tap at the brewery. Hazy pale orange appearance. Mild aroma of wheat malts, lemon peel, light herbs and light oranges. Similar flavor, bland and a little boring. Light body, crisp and easy to drink.

name: Pug Ryans MorningWood Wheat
review: Tap at brewpub. Pours lightly hazy yellow/gold with fizzy white head. Aroma is biscuit malts, wheat, floral notes, and light herbs. Flavor is semisweet malts, light floral notes, and light grassy notes; dry finish. Light body and low carbonation.

name: Pug Ryans MorningWood Wheat
review: Draft at the brewery. Pours hazy gold with a thin, creamy white head and decent lacing. Tastes like creamy wheat, light lemon, some bubblegum. Light body and low carbonation. Smells like musk, wheat, and light citrus.

name: Pug Ryans MorningWood Wheat
review: On tap at brewpub. Pour is hazy orange with a big white head and good lacing. Wheaty, grassy, sonewht citrusy, bready, orang peel, and biscuity aroma. Taste is refreshing, wheaty - well-balanced - citrusy, grassy, spritzy, bready, and straw with a crisp bite on the backend. Light body with high carbonation. I really dig this wheat- super refreshing and well-balanced without being too malty.

name: Pug Ryans MorningWood Wheat
review: Can shared by Lunch. Thanks Paul. The beer is orange with a mild haze. Sediment in suspended animation. The head is nearly a half inch thick and coats the glass with copious lacing. The aroma offers some sweet fruit, malt, particularly oranges. The beer is mildly sweet, with some bread and citrus presence. Light bodied and fruity. Decent beer. Worth a try. Serving type: can Reviewed on: 01-06-2012

name: Pug Ryans MorningWood Wheat
review: Can. Yellow with white head. Smells...like nothing. Tastes flat, really has very little flavor, no finish, maybe a tad caramel. Really quite bad. Very bad.

name: Pug Ryans MorningWood Wheat
review: Pour on tap at the brewery is hazy yellow with white head, aroma brings notes of some white fruit, yeast, touch of grain. Taste is a mix of biscuit, some yeasty spice, touch of white fruit, finishing very fizzy.

name: Pug Ryans MorningWood Wheat
review: Clear light gold with a small fading white head. Off aroma of wheat and mildew. Tasted like a wheat and pilner combo, with a touch of light toffee sweetness. Not reccomended.

name: Pug Ryans MorningWood Wheat
review: Drank at A-Basin chalet after skiing all day. Cloudy yellow color with fruity/yeasty aroma. Flavors of coriander, wheat, yeast, orange and spice. Smooth and drinkable.

name: Pug Ryans MorningWood Wheat
review: On tap at the goat pours cloudy golden with small white head. Aroma is fruity, pineapple. Taste is a fruity candied citrus, sweet with a slightly bitter finish. Not much of a wheat fan but this is decent and drinkable.

name: Pug Ryans Pack Iron Pale Ale (Over the Rail)
review: This beer pours a clear copper color with a medium thin white head that recedes quickly to an outer ring. Spotty lacing. Aroma of hops, fruit and malt. Light to medium body with flavors of fruity hops and grainy malt. The finish is mild grassy hops up front with a malty aftertaste. Decent average overall.

name: SKA Pinstripe Red Ale
review: 12 oz can from Breckenridge, CO. Pours a clear light copper color with a white head and very good retention. Decent lacing. Fairly smooth mouthfeel. Light caramel flavor. Not bad.

name: SKA Pinstripe Red Ale
review: Excellent taste with just right hops. Very nice body and drinkable. Matches well with almost any food. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: SKA Pinstripe Red Ale
review: It’s lunch time so I decided to eat leftover curry which should pair well with a red ale. Ska Pinstripe Red Ale 5.2% Red-orange in color with a dense beige head. The aroma is caramel malt and pine, sweet but smells kind of past it’s best. Bitter hops, treacle caramel malt sweetness. Definitely on the old side. Paired with the curry the sweetness is cut back and the bitterness balanced out too. A winning pairing elevating a beer that has seen better days. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: SKA Pinstripe Red Ale
review: Backlog rating Tucson trip 2006: Golden, bamket head. Low body, low flavor, light grain.

name: SKA Pinstripe Red Ale
review: Draft from Criollo in Flagstaff. Light piney hops and loads of citrus. Very easy-drinking for the ABV. Enjoyable beer.

name: SKA Pinstripe Red Ale
review: Can. Pours orange with a white head. Sweet toffee malts, mild bitterness, and light bready malts. Fine.

name: SKA Pinstripe Red Ale
review: Draught. This is a run of the mill amber with some great branding a graphics which I enjoyed while at the brewery. Not my favorite Ska beer but maybe the most common out and about.

name: SKA Pinstripe Red Ale
review: Sample at SBWF 2016. Slightly hazy orange with a white head. Aroma of grain, some citrus and caramel. Similar taste. Kind of soft and easy to drink.

name: SKA Pinstripe Red Ale
review: Draft at Ridgway music festival. Copper-amber color with a lasting off white head. Aroma is good for a draft in an outdoor concert environment. I get fruits like pears,berries, and mangoes. The taste mirrors the aroma, lots of fruit in a neutral malt base. The palate is medium. Finishes a bit sticky.over all me like.

name: SKA Pinstripe Red Ale
review: Canned. Amber colour, mediumsized white head. Aroma is bready, grainy, some sweet malts as well as some toffee and mild herbal notes. Flavour is grass, grains, some toffee, mild crisp bready malts to it. Balanced and tasty.

name: SKA Ten Pin Porter
review: An average porter at best. Had side by side with the imperial. The impy was what this should have been and this one, while pleasant enough, was weak in body and flavor for the style. Meh.

name: SKA Ten Pin Porter
review: Dark pour with a beige head. Aroma is roasted malt and sweetness. Taste is creamy, black patent malt, roasted. Nice lacing.

name: SKA Ten Pin Porter
review: Shared 12 oz. bottle poured to rocks glasses, showing a black/brown hue, with a modest layer of brownish tan foam, and light, wavy lacing. The nose was roasted, with some char & smoke dryness. Medium bodied, with average carbonation, the taste presented a barley-like graininess, moderate, earthy & woody bitterness, more noticeable cocoa notes upon warming, and a hint of brine, reminiscent of an oyster Stout. A fairly tasty & robust Porter.

name: SKA Ten Pin Porter
review: I had this at Global Brew. Pours black with a brown head. Taste chocolate, roasted malt, coffee. I thought this was so so. I would skip this in the future. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: SKA Ten Pin Porter
review: Bottle @ home, picked up at Wilbur’s Fort Collins. Pours a dark brown appearance with a brown head. Roasty malty, coffee, light anise, fairly herbal, a touch fruity aroma. Slightly acidic, chocolate, coffee, slightly burnt flavor. Not a big fan of this one.

name: SKA Ten Pin Porter
review: Pitch Black Color, Huge Cappuccino Head, Lots Of Thin Lacing. Vanilla, Chocolate, Roasted Aroma. Taste About The Same: Vanilla, Roasted Malt, Light Chocolate. Rather Thin Body, Light ABV. Light bitter sour Finish. Decent, Although Too Thin. Retiring, Try While It Lasts...

name: SKA Ten Pin Porter
review: from BrewDog online shop - almost black beer with a moderate foam left; chocolate and cacao in the nose, walnuts; medium-bodied, light oily and umami; some tart earthy bitterness; aftertaste of chocolate ans ashes with light residual sweetness

name: SKA Ten Pin Porter
review: Poured from a bottle it is s dark brown with a flight head. The aroma is of roasted coffee and the taste is of coffee and milk chocolate that lingers bitter on the palate.

name: SKA Ten Pin Porter
review: From a 12 oz bottle shared in Avon NC. Pours a dark cola brown with an ecru head. Aroma of light coffee. Flavors of licorice. Medium bodied, high carbonation, slight bitter finish.

name: SKA Ten Pin Porter
review: from beerlicious iphone app: meh aroma black and clear minimal head light bittery notes short duration light slick body flat carbonation and abrupt finish.

name: SKA True Blonde Ale
review: Mild and Sweet Lemon Flavors. Thick head but dissipated quickly. Average drinking Blonde.

name: SKA Yeti Face Plant Ale
review: Bomber [2006] poured a clear copper with a small offwhite head. Aromas of apricot, peach, grassy, earthy and faint carmel. Palate was medium bodied and dry. Flavors of apricots, grassiness and a hint of carmel with a lingering bitter finish.

name: SKA Buster Nut Brown Ale
review: Draft. Clear dark amber color with a small beige head and good retention. Nice nutty aroma. The taste matches the nose. Nice, smooth nutty brown ale flavor, but the finish isn't really clean. Maybe slightly sour finish. Still pretty good.

name: SKA Buster Nut Brown Ale
review: This is a backlog rating from a bottle, from notes. When I had this beer it was average to below average for the style and not something I wanted to have again or I just didn't get back to my notes because of my technology at the time. Words to describe this beer are toasted malts, nutty, bland.

name: SKA Buster Nut Brown Ale
review: Can that Zac bought for the Purgatory condo. Relatively light brown color with no real head but lots of bubbles. Light dusty malty aroma. Flavor is lightly bitter malt with a hint of coffee. Meh.

name: SKA Buster Nut Brown Ale
review: Brown, almost opaque with a light beige head. Nutty aroma. Rich, malty backbone, smooth finish. Nice.

name: SKA Buster Nut Brown Ale
review: 12 oz. can. 5.3%. Pour was clear copper with a foamy off white head. Aroma was herbal, light nut, toasted. Taste was moderately sweet, watery, toasted grain.

name: SKA Buster Nut Brown Ale
review: Bottle from appellation wines comely bank. Pours cloudy brown. Aromas of toffee, malt loaf, berries, raisins, fruit. Taste is dry, earthy, orange peel.

name: SKA Buster Nut Brown Ale
review: Bottle from Appellation Wines Comely Bank. Appearance - deep brown with orange tints. Decent head. Nose - nuts and sweet malt. Taste - toffee and nuts. Palate - close to medium bodied with a creamy texture and a fairly good finish. Overall - decent example of the style.

name: SKA Buster Nut Brown Ale
review: Bottle from The Best in Hanwell, pours deep brown with a lasting crema, caramel-toffee and a little gingerbread on the nose, malty and dryish with a light bitterness. Hints of earthy bitter herbs, sultanas and toast. Good, but more muted than the label implies.

name: SKA Buster Nut Brown Ale
review: Sample at SBWF 2016. Malty smell with some caramel. Similar taste. Malt focused.

name: SKA Buster Nut Brown Ale
review: 355ml bottle from Brewdog Online Shop. Pours clear pale brown with a thin beige head. Aromas of chocolate and nuts, something creamy. Taste is sweet, sugary. Cold milky coffee. Thin finish.

name: SKA Special ESB Ale
review: This is a pretty solid, middle of the road ESB. A little bitter for my taste and a just a tad too alcoholic to be sessionable, but its got a great malty sweet body.

name: SKA Special ESB Ale
review: Really want to like this but there are just much better ESBs out there. A little too bitter.

name: SKA Special ESB Ale
review: 12 oz. can. Pour was clear light copper, off white head. Aroma was light malt. Taste was light bitter, pale malts, light fruit, hop finish.

name: SKA Special ESB Ale
review: This is a perfect session beer, equal malty with only a bit bitter. Clean looking with a steady, creamy head ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: SKA Special ESB Ale
review: I like this one. Probably the last ESB I drink with any kind of regularity. The SKa mix pack is a good one.

name: SKA Special ESB Ale
review: Poured from a can, substantial head and hearty aroma. As the head subsides malt comes through to dominate the aroma. Pleasing light malt flavors pair well with substantial hops. One of my favorites. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for Android

name: SKA Special ESB Ale
review: Can from Brewdog Online Shop. Pours clear golden orange with a thin white head. Aromas of nutty malt, citrus. Taste is cooked orange, nutty malt. Sweet finish.

name: SKA Special ESB Ale
review: Pretty generic golden ale. Sweet malt, some fruit, light to moderate bitterness. It’s OK.

name: SKA Special ESB Ale
review: Not much on the nose....some bread. Crystal clear dark orange, with a super thin white head. Sweet caramel up front. Bread/biscuit throughout. Bitterness balances sweetness pretty well. Bitterness has some spiciness, earthy tones. Average.

name: SKA Special ESB Ale
review: Origin: Can. Vessel: Can. Supplier: Gift (Romsey). Bitter caramel with high carbonation.

name: Smugglers Knuckledragger Extra Pale Ale
review: on tap in montrose 7/19/10. yellowy gold color with a slight haze and clingy white head. aroma and flavor of pale malt, spicy hops, citrus, caramel, grass and straw. crisp and refreshing. 6/3/6/3/13/3.1

name: Smugglers Knuckledragger Extra Pale Ale
review: Draft at SBR 7/11/09. Pours a white head over a clear golden (SRM 10) body....nose is spicy with hops, some light citrus....taste is very citrus with lingering grapefruit....mouth feel is medium as is carbonation. This is a pleasant, but somewhat light American Pale Ale.

name: Smugglers Knuckledragger Extra Pale Ale
review: The Knuckledragger is a light beer, and I found nothing really good about it. Bitter, watery, and a rank aftertaste. Disclosure: I generally like dark beers.

name: Smugglers Knuckledragger Extra Pale Ale
review: Draft at the brewpub during Telluride Blue and Brews Weekend 2006: Worst of their bunch, for sure. Very bright yellow-orange with a pillowy head. Watery ... big time. Not much here. Tastes like hoppy water. Bad.

name: Smugglers Knuckledragger Extra Pale Ale
review: A very light, uninteresting brew. Amberish color--not sure what this is supposed to be exactly, but I don’t like it. Highly carbonated, not much flavor, sort of tastes "off" to me. Nothing much here. Won’t have it again.

name: Smugglers Knuckledragger Extra Pale Ale
review: Light gold hue. Very smooth and easily quaffable. Surprisingly lager-like, even though it’s an ale. Clean grains. Hoppy (flowers, grass) with a little sourness. Grassy finish.

name: Smugglers Wildcat Wheat
review: on tap in montrose 7/19/10. clear. orange gold with a very clingy stained glass-like foamy head. dusty wet nose with faint notes of coriander and woody yeast. unfortunately, there’s not more in the flavor other than a bitter-ish finish. watery. flat mouth feel. blah. 5/2/4/2/11/2.4

name: Smugglers Wildcat Wheat
review: Draft at the brewpub during Telluride Blue and Brews Weekend 2006: Lightly cloudy yellow-gold with an invitingly wheaty nose. But the flavor is like bad imitation corn flakes you might find in some foreign marketplace. Bit flacid.

name: Smugglers Wildcat Wheat
review: Hazy yellow; mostly headless. Soft body; tingly, prickly carbonation. Grainy-sweet malts. Very mild bitterness. Lemon note, probably tainted by the wedge. Overall, light, bland and kind of boring.

name: Smugglers Shred Betty Raspberry Wheat
review: on tap in montrose 7/19/10. slightly pink hued pale gold with a pale white clingy head. buttery aroma...bam! redeeming aromas of caramel, dust, creamed raspberries, wood and florals. the flavor is the same with the addition of a little tartness from the berries. muddy, dead and meh in the mouth. flawed and oddly better than the wildcat? 5/3/5/2/10/2.5

name: Smugglers Shred Betty Raspberry Wheat
review: Hazy yellow-orange. Texture was mildly carbonated and kind of watery. Very light malts, and very mild -- almost nonexistent -- bitterness. Nice raspberry notes throughout, though -- both in the flavor and aroma. For the most part, it was a refreshing beer, albeit a little sticky in the finish, curiously enough.

name: Smugglers Road Rash Red
review: Draught. This is a pretty boring amber that is worth passing over for the coffee porter.

name: Smugglers Road Rash Red
review: on tap 7/19/10 in montrose. amber color with a creamy off white head and spotty lacing. grassy, citrus, caramel and grain in the nose. same for the flavor only a little bland. there’s a yeastiness left in the aftertaste. seems like it is aimed at the bl drinking locals. 6/3/5/3/12/2.9

name: Smugglers Road Rash Red
review: Draft at the brewpub during Telluride Blue and Brews Weekend 2006: More orange than red, this has one of those mashy "brewery" aromas. Almost a medicinal aspect in the flavor, like candied liquid nyquil or something.

name: Smugglers Road Rash Red
review: Hazy, rusty orange (my favorite color). Nice head and nice lace. Mild carbonation. Smooth, creamy and lightish. Chewy-light malts with nice flavors of caramel. Mild hops, but enough of them to complement the sweetness. Easy drinking ... but with some flavor. Hate to use it as comparison, but it was kind of like Fat Tire ... though, perhaps a little "heavier" on both fronts (hops and malts).

name: Smugglers Ingrams IPA
review: on tap in montrose 7/19/10. golden color with a white cap. faint bitter aroma mixes with orange, grass, mild spice, malt and a little skunk. the flavor is the same... citrusy sweet in the middle with dirty earthy hops on the end. crisp. medium body with a little slickness. not bad. 6/3/6/3/13/3.1

name: Smugglers Ingrams IPA
review: Draft. Mostly clear. Soft centennial nose, pine, some small amount of tropical fruit, light grassiness. Pale and weak flavor, needs depth and boldness. Body is unremarkable but there’s really no brewing flaws picked up, just a stale recipe that could benefit from more fresh/juicy/citrus hop character and more crispness.

name: Smugglers Ingrams IPA
review: Salida Brewers redevous 2008. Appropriate to the style, nice color, reasonable hopping, pleasant finish but nothing outstanding.

name: Smugglers Ingrams IPA
review: Draft at the brewpub during Telluride Blue and Brews Weekend 2006: Orange-red with a big grapefruity aroma. Chewy pine-cone hoppiness. Unfortunately there’s little body or base malt to back it up.

name: Smugglers Ingrams IPA
review: Slightly hazed; mostly orange color; nice head. Chewy malts, but with just a light sweetness. Quite a bit of flower juice. Big sourness, too. Moderate bitterness. Slight metal in the finish. Pretty good IPA, but kind of let me down, as I expected more.

name: Smugglers Strong Scottish Ale
review: on tap 7/19/10 in montrose. clear auburn/dark brown with an off white head which drips a lot. it smells like a rich, sweet, smokey mix of caramel and chocolate creme candies. combined with citrus and grass it tastes the same... nice and malty with lingering smoke and sourness. medium bodied. crisp though rich. highly quaffable. 7/4/7/3/15/3.6

name: Smugglers Strong Scottish Ale
review: poured at the 14th annual CO Brewers’ Rendezvous. deep brown with garnet highlights and a thin tan head that quickly faded. thick. lots of dark fruit in the background, as well as some smoke and a nice nutty presence. plenty of toffee and caramel with some roast and mild, sweet coffee. a good one.

name: Smugglers Strong Scottish Ale
review: Tap. Heavy malt aromas of toasted, strong coffee and molasses, light resin and earth for the hops and yeast, with cola, smoke, raisin and boiled root vegetables in the background. Head is small, bubbly, white with almost no lacing and is mostly diminishing. Color is clear dark brown with a deep red tint. Flavor starts moderately sweet, and has a moderately sweet and lightly acidic and bitter finish. Palate is medium to full, creamy almost syrupy in texture, has a soft carbonation and finishes sticky yet slightly dry. A very good, well rounded Scottish Ale.

name: Smugglers Strong Scottish Ale
review: Dark porter with an initially bitter taste, and a nutty aftertaste. Really great beer.

name: Smugglers Strong Scottish Ale
review: Draft at the brewpub during Telluride Blue and Brews Weekend 2006: Dark, almost brown/red. Big and sugary malt with a hint of smokiness but a sweet swirly finish.

name: Smugglers Strong Scottish Ale
review: Deep burgundy with a yellowish-tan head on my palette. Very smooth and creamy on my palate ... kind of chewy, even. Malts were nice, with roast, peat, chocolate and toast. Pinch of smoke, too. The aforementioned drifted into the aroma. Hops were in the background, nicely. Pretty good beer.

name: Smugglers Two Planker Porter
review: Draught. I got this in the brewpub. This was a pretty lack luster brew without too much going for it.

name: Smugglers Two Planker Porter
review: on tap in montrose 7/19/10. typical porter color along with drippy off white lace. the aroma is pretty spot on... toasted nuts, coffee, cream, damp wood, roast and a little ash. the flavor is the same though a bit watered down. there’s a nice tartness on the finish. the mouth feel is off... maybe low carbonation and flavor? it is however tart, crisp and dry. 7/3/6/2/13/3.1

name: Smugglers Two Planker Porter
review: Dark black porter with a light head that remains. Malty and pleasantly bitter taste with a slight chocolate aftertaste.

name: Smugglers Two Planker Porter
review: Draft at the brewpub during Telluride Blue and Brews Weekend 2006: They actually had two porters on and I got the wrong one. This is black, but it’s really thin. It’s very, very bitter, like chewing on carred wood. Should’ve had the espresso porter ... never remembered to correct the error.

name: Smugglers Two Planker Porter
review: Deep and dark brown. Very roasty and toasty. Sweet molasses base provided quite the anchor for this beer’s soul. Rich chocolate and some toffee gave it personality, with a little burntness to give it an edge. Very tasty, with decent aromas surfacing surprisingly often. Bitterness was mild, but surely there to try and balance things out. Pretty good porter.

name: Bank Street Safecracker Stout
review: Please note that on my older reviews I used a 100 point scale. To make up for any scoring discrepancies, all palate and apearance scored are assigned a neutralized 3/5. Undated 2001?: This looks just like guiness in the glass and has that cool bubble feature you see when a Guiness is poured. It tastes much more hearty than Guinness with a lot of sweet malty flavors and some bitterness.

name: Bank Street Safecracker Stout
review: Opaque with a creamy tan nitro induced head. Nice espresso and chocolate nose with strong hints of roasted barley. Oaty smooth body loaded with dry chocolate and roasted coffee. Lighter in body than I'd like, perhaps from the nitro, but solidly flavored none the less. Long aftertaste.

name: Bank Street Cove Porter
review: Please note that on my older reviews I used a 100 point scale. To make up for any scoring discrepancies, all palate and apearance scored are assigned a neutralized 3/5. Undated 2000?: This is a nice dark brown in the glass and smells like roasted chocolate and raisins. I like the flavor on this one. It is very hearty and layered. A definite in the winter.

name: Bank Street Cove Porter
review: A worthy porter from this fine brewpub. It's a toasty brew.................

name: Willimantic Certified Gold
review: Draught at brewpub. Light in color and in body with some crisp notes and a very accessible beer.

name: Willimantic Certified Gold
review: Poured a clear gold with a small lasting white head. Aromas of bread and yeast. Palate was light bodied and smooth with a dry finish. Flavors of bread, yeast and a hint of chalkiness with a smooth dry finish.

name: Willimantic Certified Gold
review: Draft sample at the source. The beer is a clear yellow with a white head of foam. The aroma has bready and grainy cereal. Doughy and crisp taste. A. It of a spice bite in the finish. Medium body and medium carbonation.

name: Willimantic Certified Gold
review: Tap at the brewery. Pours clear gold with a small, fizzy white head, short retention with spare lacing. Aroma is honey and biscuit malt with light earthy hops. Flavor is sweet malt dominant, light hops and bitterness with a sweet finish. Light body and medium carbonation.

name: Willimantic Certified Gold
review: On tap at the brewery: Pours clear golden with a decent white head. Aroma of bread, pils malt, and a little lemon. Taste is more of the same, a bit doughy, with some very light fruit notes. Light body, light flavor, it’s a decent beer that everyone can enjoy.

name: Willimantic Certified Gold
review: Draft at brewery. Pours clear yellow with white head. Nose/taste of cream, light malt, toast and lemon. Lighter medium body.

name: Willimantic Certified Gold
review: 10/11/2013. On tap at the brewery. Golden color with a while head. Aromas of malt, hops, yeast, hay. Good balance and medium carbonation. Nice hoppy finish.

name: Willimantic Certified Gold
review: Tap at the brewpub. Clear light orange pour with no head. Grain, sweet bready malts. Okay for a standard golden.

name: Willimantic Certified Gold
review: Sample at the brewpub. Slightly hazy yellow-gold color with a thin white head that dissipates gradually to a film. Spotty lacing on the glass. Aroma of grassy hops and malt. Light-bodied with flavors of grassy hops and grainy malt. The finish is mildly bitter with a short hoppy aftertaste. Slightly above average overall.

name: Willimantic Certified Gold
review: Nice pleasant golden with light flavors but nothing out of balance. Light sweetness, light spicy hops, and a solid doughy yeast presence. I like it.

name: Willimantic Air Mail Strong Ale
review: Growler. In the current world of beer-geekery, this beer is an imperial porter, no doubt about it. It just happened to be concocted without the existence of such a term, and since it’s a made up style anyway, there’s nothing concrete to warrant such characterization here. But it is what it is. In any case, chocolate, toffee, nougat, maybe some circus peanuts, and odd musty fruit sum up the beer. The first three, more traditional notes would be nice, but the weirdness creeps in too much for me here.

name: Willimantic Air Mail Strong Ale
review: Growler from the brewpub. Pours a dark brown with a small light tan head. Aroma of roasted nuts, oak, roasted malt, and a sweetness that is hard to describe. Flavor is also a bit difficult to describe -- roasted notes, sweet malt, and some citrusy hops. Definitely an interesting beer -- part brown ale, part ASA, part porter, part IPA. But certainly drinkable, enjoyable, and worth a try. 7/4/7/4/15 [3.7/5]

name: Willimantic Air Mail Strong Ale
review: Pours brown with a tan head. Smells of sage, spice pepper, caramel. Tastes of sweet malt, some nice spicy hints and a bitter finish.

name: Willimantic Air Mail Strong Ale
review: 3/10/08 notes: on tap, from Bram. This beer poured a deep red-brown, and thus was difficult to categorize by style. I thought it was kind of like a doppelbock, or a dark brown ale. Taste was full-bodied, creamy, smooth, nutty, with very slight hops and a nice malty-sweet undertone. Reminded me of offerings at Gordon Biersch (Winter Bock) and L’Amere (Bock). High Alchohol hidden very well, definitely a well-made beer.

name: Willimantic Air Mail Strong Ale
review: On tap at the brewery. Tan head with a dark brown body. Very delicious. My bartender described this as a stout/porter hybrid, and I kinda agree with this comparison despite the fact that its a strong ale.

name: Willimantic Air Mail Strong Ale
review: On tap at the brewpub. Very dark brown with a thick beige head - a beautiful beer! Sweet, chocolatey nose tinged with earthy hops, some toffee. Thick, silky mouthfeel. Big toffee and caramel flavors, earthy. Not a sharp bitterness, restrained but firm. Excellent.

name: Willimantic Air Mail Strong Ale
review: Served in a willibrew pint glass, pours a very dark brown with a thin tan head. Aroma is very sweet, chocolatey, sweet strong caramel, toffee, and figs. Mouthfeel is wonderfully full, thick, creamy and smooth, feels almost silky on the palate. Flavor is sweet all the way through, with some great complex malt flavors. Toffee, caramel, molasses soaked raisins, and strong surges of sweet chocolate. This is defintely worth a try, I’m sorry I passed up on it a week earlier when it was on cask. Damn.

name: Willimantic Air Mail Strong Ale
review: Low smokey note to the malty sweet aroma. Almost opaque dark brown with a decent tan head that recedes to cover with some nice lacing. Round, full, thick and malty flavour with some spicy hops and fair fruity esters. Medium body with medium-low carboantion provides for a smooth texture in the mouth. Sampled at the brewpub with MartinT, muzzlehatch and Rastacouere.

name: Willimantic Air Mail Strong Ale
review: New England Road Trip Easter ’05 with MartinT, tiggmtl and Rastacouere, beer #44. Small tap sample at the brewpub. Thick molasses with a lasting touch of creamy head...very slight malty nose, I just couldn’t get much out of it...sweet, malty thick body, molasses and nuts, vanilla and some stickiness...wish I could have smelled more.

name: Willimantic Air Mail Strong Ale
review: Coca-cola color, nice off-white head is foamy and sticky. Another highly aromatic beer from Willimantic, smoky, beany and earthy, yet salty, caramelic and leathery. It’s nice to see that the brewer can handle the malt interplays as well (or almost) as it can move the hops around like a scalpel. Fully malty palate, earthy and anise reminiscent at first, yet the second part of the taste gears toward a far fruitier and sweeter finish, very grape like. Smooth medium to full bodied, rounding low carbonation. Another great mouthfeel for Willy.

name: Willimantic Mail Carrier Maybock
review: Served in shaker golden, clear, no head. Medium bodied with mild hops flavor up front and a malty finish. Disappointing as Willibrew beers go, but not unpleasant.

name: Willimantic Mail Carrier Maybock
review: Draft at brewpub. Pours clear gold with white head. nose/taste of lemon, toasted grain, honey and touch of fruit. Medium body.

name: Willimantic Mail Carrier Maybock
review: Simple and too style. Cracker and doughy malts with a fair amount of sweetness. Hops are non existent really but still not too much out of balance. Decent stuff.

name: Willimantic Mail Carrier Maybock
review: on draft at the brewery, good malt flavors adn rich crisp bite. Very well made, I really liked it, simple and charming.

name: Willimantic Mail Carrier Maybock
review: On tap at the brewpub. Pours a clear brown/amber with a small tan head. Aroma of sweet malt (very malt dominated) and light hops. Flavor was more in the same vain...lots of malt and a sweet finish. Still, quite drinkable and nice to gulp down. 7/4/7/4/14 (3.6/5)

name: Willimantic Mail Carrier Maybock
review: Tap at the brewpub. Aroma of red fruits and big caramel malt sweetness. Flavor continues to feature huge malts with little hop balance. Very full bodied, seemingly tons of residuals. A malt bomb of a maibock.

name: Willimantic Autobahn Mail Alt
review: Draught at brewpub. Bit of a brown pour with some caramel notes and a bit of amber to it.

name: Willimantic Autobahn Mail Alt
review: On tap at the brewery: Pours redish brown with a thin white head. Aroma of caramel, nuts, earth, and slight pine. Taste is a little sweet with a lot of toasted malt, caramel, and a tiny amount of hops. Medium body, a little sticky mouth feel, this is a pretty nice alt beer.

name: Willimantic Postage Porter
review: Nice chocolatey lightly hoppy porter with a smooth lactose flavor. Soft and subtle and quite charming.

name: Willimantic Postage Porter
review: On tap at brewery, very rich and roasty, Chocolately, well made beer, good stuff

name: Willimantic Postage Porter
review: (drought at Main Street Cafe / Willibrew in Willimantic CT) med-body, roasty-complex-malt, balancing-hop-bitterness.

name: Willimantic Postage Porter
review: Growler. Aroma of solidly roasted malt, plenty of roasted coffee, chocolate notes behind. Flavor has tons of coffee for me, seemed they could even get away with calling it a coffee porter. Great roast throughout, never burnt, just well roasted. Nice porter.

name: Willimantic Postage Porter
review: Growler from the brewpub. Pours black with a small ring of tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, roasted nuts, chocolate, peanut butter. Flavor is equally nutty, with some charred roasted malt and bitter chocolate. Excellent porter with a nice blend of roasted malt, nuts, and chocolate. Very drinkable too. Well done! 8/4/8/4/17 [4.1/5]

name: Willimantic Postage Porter
review: sampled at the brewpub. Almost black in color with ruby highlights at the bottom of the glass. Tan lasting head. Aroma- alot of chocolate, some roast, dark fruit, chalk and molasses. Taste has alot of chocolate and some roast, some dark fruit, and medium bodied with a good caramel backbone. Excellent porter

name: Willimantic Postage Porter
review: Pours dark brown with a thin tan head. Smells of chocolate, lactic, some dark fruit. Tastes of bitter roasted malt, lots of sweetness to counteract the bitterness, some chocolate, some licorice hints. Nice!

name: Willimantic Postage Porter
review: At the pub. Yum yum yum. Even in a simple pint glass, this porter’s aroma is potent. A nicely textured beer, hints of dark chocolate, vanilla & coffee float around the palate. I don’t like to pick favorites, but this is one of the best Willi has offered.

name: Willimantic Postage Porter
review: on tap at brewpub. Pours a dark brown with no head. Aroma of toasted notes, wood and coffee. Palate was surprisingly light with little carbonation. However, this beer has delicious flavors of coffee, ash, hops, and semisweet chocolate. Maybe some dark fruit in there as well. Finishes fairly dry. Overall, very impressive.

name: Willimantic Postage Porter
review: On tap at the Brewpub. Pours pitch black in color with brown head. Aroma chocolate, coffee and sweet aroma. Taste of coffee and dark chocolate with bitter dark chocolate. Outstanding flavor.

name: Dogfish Head Shelter Pale Ale
review: From Aug 2007 I got this in a trade with Wasatch. Thanks, John! It pours from 12oz bottle a clear gold with a good head of foam that shrinks to a fine broken layer by the end of my session. The smell is rather delicate. I get a bit of floral hops but that's about it. The taste has some good malty graininess up front with a touch of bitterness that moves in about midway through and that's, pretty much, the highlight of this APA. I won't mention the "D" word but yeah, it gets overpowering for my taste buds and I'm having a rather tough time drinking this brew. In fact, I can't finish my glass. Dogfish Head makes some great brews so my not liking this one is neither here or there, if you catch my drift. ;^)

name: Dogfish Head Shelter Pale Ale
review: Bottle from Old Town. Pours a hazy gold with a finger of foam that lingers. Grassy hops with some faint citrus and light grain notes. Clean and crisp on the palate with a balanced, albeit slightly dry finish.

name: Dogfish Head Shelter Pale Ale
review: Tap at Dogfish Head, Milton. Colour is cloudy golden with small white head. Aromas and flavors: Fruits, some spices, hops and malts. Spicy apa.

name: Dogfish Head Shelter Pale Ale
review: on tap @ Vino Bellissimo / Lima OH --- Aroma of citrus and malt. Slightly hazy light-medium amber, white head that drops to a full cover, curtain of lace. Taste is malt with a heavy-handed bitter citrus in medium fizz, then all fades quickly in a short finish. Too much bitter. Poor balance, uneven performance.

name: Dogfish Head Shelter Pale Ale
review: Bottle in 2011, clear or lightly hazy gold color with average sized head. Lacing wasn’t much. Notes of lager skunk, toast, toasted hop, and grain. Nothing going on with this beer.

name: Dogfish Head Shelter Pale Ale
review: Draft pour. Clear copper with a big head of white foam. The aroma has grassy and herbal notes. Dry herbal notes in the taste. Medium body and medium carbonation.

name: Dogfish Head Shelter Pale Ale
review: DFH really bringing the heat to OBF. No insult intended but come on man! Pours a clear golden color with a medium white head. A nice toast, caramel and citrus nose. The flavor is more of the same, lemons, oranges, some toast earthy malt. Solid pale.

name: Dogfish Head Shelter Pale Ale
review: Tap at OBF Clear golden with a medium sized off-white head. Aroma and flavor is floral and grassy Ok

name: Dogfish Head Shelter Pale Ale
review: Bottled. Fondly remembered from back in the mid. 2000s when I thought 60 minute IPA was a really hoppy beer. Good times.

name: Dogfish Head Shelter Pale Ale
review: Pours a cloudy sparkling amber with an average size frothy tan head. Looks really good. Aroma of sweet malt and floral hops. Flavour of malt, hops and citrus isn’t hoppy enough -- in fact as it gets warmer it gets sweeter. Light bitter finish.

name: Dogfish Head Immort Ale
review: Süffiger, stark holziger Beginn. Nuancen von Vanille, moderate Bitterkeit, weich. Alkoholisch, dennoch angenehm. Steigend nach Vanille, mittellanger Abgang. Gut. 10/9/11/11/12/11

name: Dogfish Head Immort Ale
review: Pours cloudy mahogany with ultra-thin, light tan head. Aroma is maple, vanilla and molasses. Taste is light brown sugar and maple syrup (sweet, but not cloying), moving to wood and vanilla. Finish is smooth maltiness with a touch of an alcohol burn. A good barleywine.

name: Dogfish Head Immort Ale
review: Aroma is fruit/berries, medium sweetness and a hint of vanilla. The flavor is fruit/mild dark fruit, malts and a mild/medium sweet/alcoholic finish.

name: Dogfish Head Immort Ale
review: On tap at Farmhouse Tap and Grill in Burlington, Vermont. Pours clear amber-ruby with a spritz of off-white head and lacing. Aroma: peaches, cherries, smoke. Flavor: peat, Scotch, brown sugar, vanilla beans, maple candy, faint gin/juniper. Mouthfeel: medium- to full-bodied, slick.

name: Dogfish Head Immort Ale
review: Hazy dark amber color with beige head. Aroma has lots of dried fruits like figs, dates, raisins, plums but also dark sugar and light booze. Taste is sugary, bittersweet and fruity. The bitterness is woody, herbal. Medium body and carbonation. It's a quite nice strong ale / barleywine, slightly boozy but not difficult to drink.

name: Dogfish Head Immort Ale
review: light cherry, plum and malt aromas. dark amber in color with huge long lasting head. taste is malty, notes of plum, raisin, dark caramel, light pine

name: Dogfish Head Immort Ale
review: From Aug 2007 I got this one in a trade with Wasatch. Thanks, John! It pours from 12oz bottle a hazy deep amber with a very small head of foam with a bit of lacing. The smell is huge on the caramel malt...reminds me of taking a whiff of a JW Lees Harvest Ale or similar brews. The taste is as big on the caramel malt as the nose. Sweet? Yes it is. Too sweet? Not for my palate. There be big Oak flavours here as well and some vanilla.(says so on the label and it's true) There's also a good presence of dark fruit like fig and a touch of plum and it has just a wee bit of hop bitterness that shows up right before the finish. But as far as the style goes, I don't *want* much of a hop presence; the malt is king here and rightfully so. Great sipping brew and at 11%abv, that's the way to handle this baby though, I have to say, DFH has done a remarkable job of keeping the potent alcohol out of the taste and it doesn't really warm me at all as I swallow this nectar.The mouthfeel is thick and chewy and the carbo is light, just right for the style. I've had this one before, years ago, and I'm *still* enthralled with how well of a crafted brew this is. Ok, I'll go ahead and say it. It's one of my favourites. Thanks again, John!!

name: Dogfish Head Immort Ale
review: Not sure I'm on board with using juniper berries in a style as sweet as barleywine, especially one with the added touch of maple syrup. Starts with a nice, breakfast-like friendliness, the syrup and vanilla giving off a waffles-n-whipped cream vibe backed up by notes of apple and smoked tea. Bitterness on the back end shores up any cloy notes, but the juniper takes the brew in an odd herbal direction, like somebody stashed some pine needles in between your pancake stack. I'm a fan of hoppy-as-hell barleywines and juniper beers, but mixing the two ain't for me. Nose is caramel and toffee and juniper. Pour comes out a viscous, opaque brown with a modest off-white head and little lacing. Good texture; a year in the basement takes away any boozy heat. Too bad I can't reconcile the juniper and the sweetness.

name: Dogfish Head Immort Ale
review: Pours dark, orange/amber-whiskey color and nearly opaque with a 4 finger off white to tan head with an aroma of malt, vanilla and maple syrup. Tastes of malt, vanilla and maple syrup with an oak and Belgian yeast, clove finish with perhaps resin and bitter pine taste from the juniper berries. It has a sticky, viscous palate with little to no carbonation. It's full-bodied and exceptionally complex and a little smokey.

name: Dogfish Head Immort Ale
review: Deep brown with tan lacing head. Aroma is maple wood and berry. Taste is like a raisin liquor followed by some bitterness, ashy wood and alcohol burn. Like it.

name: Harrisons Black Diamond Stout
review: Dark brown color with an earthy, smokey/char aroma. Tan thin head that dissipated quickly. Flavor is burnt coffee, reminiscent of a fire that’s been out for awhile. Somewhat flat/low carbonation. Not at all one of my favorite stout samplings.

name: Harrisons Black Diamond Stout
review: dark brown, coffee with cream head. aroma is coffee and sweet roasted malt. flavor of coffee and chocolate, not as sweet as i feared. medium bodied with a slightly bitter finish. the bartender said it ’is like guinness’, but i didn’t find it half as sweet.

name: Harrisons Black Diamond Stout
review: On tap at Harrison’s. I think like most small brewpubs they want to appeal to the Guiness drinker. So here is their dry stout. Pours a dark brown with a frothy light brown head. Nose is surprisingly smoky and a touch of spice with all the roasted chocolate grains underneath. Mouthfeel is creamy. Chocolate roasted flavors are present but kinda weak and fading quick. Meh. Not good beers, but this huge place was full for a freezing thursday night. So I guess you don’t have to make good beers to survive sometimes.

name: Harrisons Black Diamond Stout
review: Had this one on draught at the brewpub in Orland Park, Illinois. Opaque, dark brown pour with a thick, medium brown head, soy sauce and smoky nose, bitter chocolate and more smoke throughout. Nice dry close. Outstanding example of the style!

name: Harrisons Black Diamond Stout
review: On tap at Goose Island Stoutfest. Poured a deep mahogany with almost no appreciable head. Nose was oddly soapy with lighter fruits, some roasted chocolate, and it had a grainy aspect to it. Some dark, roasty malts were muddled in the flavor (fruits and coffee primarily)... with oddly-placed bitters. Astringency was rather high, and alcohol made its presence known. Palate was lighter-bodied with sharp fruity notes around the edges. Carbonation was low, resulting in a flat cola feel. I really got nothing good out of this one.

name: Harrisons Black Diamond Stout
review: Draft sampler. Let’s see. Sufficiently black color with a thin tan head that’s lingered after 20 minutes in the sampler tray. Good roasty smell. Taste? Surprsiingly smooth low-carbonation stout pull. A bit of Guinnessy sourness and a kind of creamy mouthfeel that works with the carbonation. Not very complex, but a beer that seems to be improving since last time I tried it.

name: Harrisons Black Diamond Stout
review: Opaque and midnight brown in color with a creamy tan head. Medium, erring on the thinner side of, viscosity. Oatmeal, dark chocolate, medium roasted coffee bitterness and roasted malts give it a trademark nose. Hershey’s chocolate syrup overrides other flavor elements, with other accentuations of semi-sweet chocolate chips meeting dark chocolate morsels. Resonating qualities akin to a chocolate laden iced mocha on the underbelly. Smooth, denser palate feel and much better than expected.

name: Harrisons Black Diamond Stout
review: More a "sweet stout" than a dry sout, Black Diamond has a strong chocolate presence and a sweet finish that I didn’t find as cloying as others have stated. Dark, dark, dark with a medium-brown, oily head. Satisfying.

name: Harrisons Black Diamond Stout
review: Probably the best beers that Harrison’s has to offer. Black pour with a light brow colored head. Some chocolate and roasted grain in the nose and the body. Fairly easy to drink. A solid stout but nothing to rave about. Pretty good atmosphere in the bar on a weeknight which helps.

name: Harrisons Black Diamond Stout
review: Best of a sorry lot! But you gotta stand in line to get into this place, so they obviously don’t need my advice. Stand at the bar on a Friday night and you’ll see at least half of the patrons ordering bottled beers (Miller).

name: San Miguel
review: Bottle from friend. Almost no aroma. Gold body with almost no head. Light malty flavour with metallic finish. Bottle wasn't shipped properly.

name: San Miguel
review: Strong tasting lager with grotesque after taste that lingers. Looks good, smells of nothing, shocks your mouth.

name: San Miguel
review: The aroma is weak sweetish a little grass .. The taste is malt empty, the bitterness of hops is weak .. Euro lager

name: San Miguel
review: Gross if you're in the Philippines, light better, If you want to get trashed Red Horse

name: San Miguel
review: Fles thuis geprobeerd met LiekevdV. Het is een goudgeel bier met een dun laagje wit schuim. Het heeft een moutige geur en smaak. Beetje rijst achtig.

name: San Miguel
review: Zapach: chmiel, kwaskowy, delikatnie biszkopt Kolor: z³oty Smak: chmiel, kwaskowy, delikatnie biszkopt Wysycenie: œrednie S³aby, koncernowy lager. W zapachu i smaku to samo, tj. chmiel, kwaskowoœæ i delikatnie biszkopt. Sprawia wra¿enie rozwodnionego i nijakiego. Pijalnoœæ niska, poniewa¿ ma³o przyjemne w odbiorze. Ogó³em rzecz bior¹c po prostu s³aba masówka.

name: Caledonian Edinburgh Strong Ale (Cask)
review: Cask Pint at Wibbas Down (JDW), Wimbledon, London in Nov 2010 - Deep Amber in colour. Malty; sweet roasted malts, toffee, nutty. Fruity; citrus orange. Hoppy; fruity and floral hops. Sweet very fruity and malty ale throughout. OK. Drinkable. (2010-11)

name: Caledonian Edinburgh Strong Ale (Cask)
review: Notes found recently from a 2010 Wetherspoon Beer Festival. Not as strong a tasting bitter as expected.

name: Caledonian Edinburgh Strong Ale (Cask)
review: Tasted this in the Saltcot, Saltcoats (JDW) in November 2004. Cask, handpump dispense. Dark copper in colour with a thick creamy white head. Strong malty aroma of vinous fruits and caramel. Robust creamy mouthfeel and good lacing. Pale malt complex gives rich moist maltloaf with dollops of raisins, figs, banana and maple syrup. Slight note of dusty hop resins but short lived as the aftertaste becomes dry and vinous. Finish has an alcoholic brandy like warmth with hints of christmas spices to it. A Scottish strong ale in the tradition of Broughton’s Old Jock. Well recommended.

name: Caledonian Edinburgh Strong Ale (Cask)
review: From cask at Counting House as Edinburgh Strong Ale. Pours clear and golden brown with a small white head. Aroma is roasted malty, breadish and light hops fruity. Sweet malty to breadish flavoured. Distinct bitterhops note coming through giving the beer and overall bitter feel. Ends dry and bitter. Simple.

name: Caledonian Edinburgh Strong Ale (Cask)
review: Cask-conditioned at the Van Dyke Forum, Bristol 31/10/10. Copper coloured with a frothy white head. Big aroma of butterscotch, bananas and marmalade. Flavour was sweet and sticky, with chunky caramel, more fruit and a touch of diacetyl in the finish. A bit overpowering.

name: Caledonian Edinburgh Strong Ale (Cask)
review: Cask at the Claude du Vall (JDW), Camberley. Definitely in the "heavy" style. Reddish gold with a dense cream head; malty aroma; a sweet chewy malt body with some apricot fruit; that hides the finish, although there is a noticable alcoholic burn. Not something I’d try again.

name: Caledonian Edinburgh Strong Ale (Cask)
review: Cask at Bankers Draft (JDW), Bedford, in ’Spoons Beer Festival ’10. Amber brown with a small white head. Aroma is sweet, creamy, buttery toffee. Thick malty taste, doughy and near cloying, like a Bakewell Pudding doused in golden syrup. Any bitterness is concealed to the very last moment. Overwhelming.

name: Caledonian Edinburgh Strong Ale (Cask)
review: [Cask at the Monks Retreat (JDW), Reading] Deep copper with a small off-white head and a slight fizz. Inviting malt and toffee aroma. Sweet toffee taste with a bit of cough mixture, some peardrops and a hint of vanilla and herbs. Comforting, lasting buttery finish - I know some people here moan about "diacetyl" (what’s wrong with "butter...?"), but personally I think it works rather well in some of the stronger UK ales. Overall it’s a decent winter warmer.

name: Caledonian Edinburgh Strong Ale (Cask)
review: JDW Fest Autumn 2010 Cask @ Sir John Moore, JDW. Copper colour, white head. Aroma is caramel malts, bit fruity. Flavour is malty, some fruits, slightly sweet. Slightly dry finish. Not too special.

name: Caledonian Edinburgh Strong Ale (Cask)
review: Cask handpull at Society Rooms, JDW, Maidstone. Very deep brown/gold burnished I guess. Thick lasting cream head. It’s a strong fruity tasting ESB. Quite bitter on finish. It’s pretty good to be honest. I liked it.

name: RavenBeer The Raven Special Lager
review: 33 cl. bottle. A dark amber coloured beer with an off-white head. Aroma and flavour of malt, caramel, spice, hops and with a bitter finish.

name: Clipper City Chesapeake Lager
review: Chesapeake Gold Ale--1998 12 oz. Bottle. 5.20% ABV. (4.25 / 5.0) Golden Ale. Bright deep golden color. Rich caramel malt flavor in chalky body. Finish is intriguing with hop malt interplay. 2/10/1998

name: Clipper City Chesapeake Lager
review: good beer, fair head and lace. Well balanced, decent hops and a nice malt nose to start.

name: Dunedin Celtic Gold Ale
review: Pours a nice golden color with white head. Cereal grains, floral notes, and some citrus on the nose; follows onto the palate. Finishes clean.

name: Dunedin Celtic Gold Ale
review: Enjoyed a sample of this beer on tap at the brewpub. The beer had a cloudy deep gold color with a small foamy white head with short retention, but light cling and lacing. Its aroma had light floral notes along with some touches of citrus and grainy hops. The taste was a sweet and bitter blend with some floral and fruity tones and a grainy bitterness. It was a lighter, wetter beer, with low carbonation and fizz, and a refreshing, crisp mouthfeel.

name: Dunedin Celtic Gold Ale
review: This beer pours a nice straw like yellow with a bit of hops and grains in the aroma. Has a subtle honey flavor as well. Had it on tap at the brewery. A great time and a great place to visit, enjoy some beers, and talk to the brewers who are more than willing to lend an ear on all things beer.

name: Dunedin Celtic Gold Ale
review: Aroma of apple juice. Straight up Apple juice, little bit of earthy hop bitterness followed by slight cardboard but it quickly goes away.

name: Dunedin Celtic Gold Ale
review: Had on tap poured a clear yellow with a touch of hops and malts in the aromma. Not much flavor, some biscuits, honey and some sweet malts. nothing too special.

name: Dunedin Celtic Gold Ale
review: A: poured into a snifter. pours a straw yellow with slight amounts of sediment. pours a nice white head that recedes after a while. good amount of lacing. S: sweet aroma of grain. in some unusual way it reminds me of breakfast. T: some honey tones from the sweet malts. decent bitters from the hops, but nothing that reaches out and grabs you, which is hit and miss with the Kolsch style. slight metallic tones in this as well, which is turning me off. M: leaves the mouth a little dry, and the palate a little bitter. has somewhat of a chalky aftertaste. D: its a good session beer if you are into Kolsch beers. I am not a huge fan of the style, but I do respect it. There are other Kolsch beers that I prefer, but it isn’t a bad beer either.

name: Dunedin Celtic Gold Ale
review: Draft at redlight redlight. Pours yellow, but with a decent creamy head and fine translucency. Nice nose with aromas of golden malts and hints of honey and berries. Flavor is a little flat but it has a decent finish of hay and brite malts. pretty smooth. not great but decent session beer for sure.

name: Dunedin Celtic Gold Ale
review: Draught at the brewery on January 30, 2011 As part of a sampler plate Hazy yellow color, white head. Hoppy, herbal taste. Sweet and yeasty aftertaste. Moussy mouthfeel, medium high dry bitterness. Sweet and herbal scent.

name: Dunedin Celtic Gold Ale
review: Draft @ Brewpub: Light hazy yellow, thin head. Nose of light husk and nothing else. Thin. Meh. What?

name: Dunedin Celtic Gold Ale
review: Light golden beer. Drinkable but very light. A bit thin, descent carbonation and had some sweetness with a touch of extra light bitterness.

name: Dunedin Pipers Pale Ale
review: On tap at the brewery. Pours a hazy orange with small white head. The aroma is citrus and wheat. Medium body, grapefruit, wheat, bitter, decent.

name: Dunedin Pipers Pale Ale
review: on tap at Riverhawk 2017. This is a moderately bitter pale ale that otherwise had a deficiency in flavor.leans towards herbal and floral hops.

name: Dunedin Pipers Pale Ale
review: Pint pour of a really nice golden color with a full finger head that recedes and gives light lacing. Nose is plenty of citrus and bitter resin notes. Bright. Flavor is citrus forward, light tropical notes of maybe peach and light mango. Mild to medium bitterness without overpowering. Very clean and crisp, lighter finish. Really drinkable and enjoyable. 14052015

name: Dunedin Pipers Pale Ale
review: 4oz on tap at the brewpub. Labeled 6% ABV; simply "PALE ALE" on the board. Pleasant hoppiness to this, good american citrusy hop. Good subdued malt bill, none of the caramel you see in so many pale ales. just a mild clean breadiness... Some mild wort-type graininess, too though. Clear golden orange color. Little white head, leaves good thicker lace. Medium-plus body. Soft light to moderate strength carbonation. Very dry finish. Moderate sweet taste, light to moderate bitter. Sort of an average pale ale overall, in the end. The bigger hop is the best feature here.

name: Dunedin Pipers Pale Ale
review: This one poured an orange color with an off white head. Aroma was of caramel and earthy and citrusy hops. Flavor was lightly fruity and dirty hops and some caramel

name: Dunedin Pipers Pale Ale
review: Pours a clear copper color with off-white head. Citrus and pine are the most prevalent on the nose; following onto the palate. Finishes with more citrusy pine.

name: Dunedin Pipers Pale Ale
review: Enjoyed a pint of this beer on tap at the brewpub. The beer had a dark gold color with an average-sized foamy white head with average retention and lacing, but good cling. It had a pleasant blend of floral and fruity scents in the aroma with lighter notes of citrus and pine. The taste was mostly bitter with citrus hops, and a lighter floral and fruity sweetness blended in. The beer had good life, fizz, and carbonation, and was a bit dry and on the heavy, thicker side.

name: Dunedin Pipers Pale Ale
review: On tap at the brewery. Golden in color with small white head. Aroma is floral and hoppy. Bitter piney and grassy flavor. Light to medium bodied with bitter finish. Solid.

name: Dunedin Pipers Pale Ale
review: Tap at Dunedin. Low haze gold pour. Decent lacing. Big citrus hop nose. Taste is soapy, chemical, some zesty orange peel. More bitter grapefruit comes to the rescue. Not too bad.

name: Dunedin Pipers Pale Ale
review: Draft at the source. Hazy golden. Olor, thick white head, solid lacing. Aroma of grass. Taste is grass, hay, subtle licorice.

name: Dunedin Beach Tale Brown Ale
review: On tap at the brewery. Pours a dark amber with small beige head that lasts. The aroma is toasted malt and dark fruit. Medium body, caramel, toast, light finish, good.

name: Dunedin Beach Tale Brown Ale
review: on tap at Riverhawk 2017. This is s well crafted mainstream brown ale. Good strength, mild bitterness, and a lingering aftertaste of dark roasted grains with a touch of smoke.

name: Dunedin Beach Tale Brown Ale
review: 4oz on tap at the brewpub. Labeled simply "BROWN ALE"; 6% ABV. Mostly clear red, slight brown color. Thin off-white head. Leaves great thicker sheets of lace. Solid chocolate; nuttiness. Some earthy hop. Moderate sweet taste, light bitter. Bit dry. Lighter to medium body. Smooth, kind of soft, lighter carbonation. Decent, standard brewpub brown ale.

name: Dunedin Beach Tale Brown Ale
review: This one poured a brown color with a white head. Aroma was of toast and caramel, Flavor was the same with a dry finish Decent.t

name: Dunedin Beach Tale Brown Ale
review: Pours a brown color with off-white head. Roasted malt, some caramel, and a bit of hops on the nose; follows onto the palate. Finishes with a nice roasted character.

name: Dunedin Beach Tale Brown Ale
review: On tap. Opaque brown pour with a thin off white head. Aroma of earthy hops, caramel, brown sugar and roasted malt. Medium mouthfeel with a lasting hoppy yet malty finish.

name: Dunedin Beach Tale Brown Ale
review: On draft at Dunedin. Pours a hazy caramel color with a white head. Nose is tobacco, nuts, and light cocoa. Flavor is similar with tobacco and cocoa. Light to medium in body with a dry finish.

name: Dunedin Beach Tale Brown Ale
review: Tap at brewery near start of quite debacherous Dunedin day. Pours deep brown with nice head. Tastes toasty warm malts, coffee beans, caramel, walnuts, and light earth. Pretty decent brown

name: Dunedin Beach Tale Brown Ale
review: On draft, pours a deep brown color with a aramos of nuts, cocoa, and malt. Flavors follow the aroma, with a touch of hops.

name: Dunedin Beach Tale Brown Ale
review: Draught at the brewery on January 30, 2011 As part of a sampler plate Clear dark copper color, off-white head. Roasted, dry, coffee taste. Lingering roasted aftertaste. Moussy mouthfeel, medium high dry bitterness. Roasted, malty, slight bit fruity scent.

name: Dunedin Red Head Red Ale
review: On tap at the brewery. Pours a hazy dark amber with small beige head that lasts. The aroma is rye and caramel. Medium body, rye, caramel, light finish, good.

name: Dunedin Red Head Red Ale
review: a little fruity with some dryness near the finish. a light bit of roast to it. went well with what they had to eat. it was scratchy like an amber with a decent aroma.

name: Dunedin Red Head Red Ale
review: Draft at Yard of Ale in St Pete. Easily best dunedin beer I’ve had. Great amber. Smooth. Dark pour. No bitters. Surprisingly tasty.

name: Dunedin Red Head Red Ale
review: Appearance: Lightly hazed, tawny-hued amber body with a near-white head. Smell: A sweetish smell of toaster crisped bread slices, lightly caramelized sugars and soft fruity esters with minimal influences from herbal hops. Taste: As with the nose, it’s sweetish and toasty with a touch of scantly nutty caramel. There’s an apple-like fruitiness, but also some light citrus showing from the hops. Lightly bitter. Semi-dry, near-crisp finish. Mouthfeel: Medium-light body. Medium carbonation. Overall: A solid, simple red ale.

name: Dunedin Red Head Red Ale
review: 4oz on tap at the brewpub. Labeled 6% ABV. simply "RED ALE" on the board. Almost totally hazy red, slight amber color. Little off-white head. Few bits and ropes of lace, kind of loose. Medium body. Smooth, kind of soft lighter carbonation. Caramel malt, mild toastiness, light bit of tropical fruit. Kind of spicy. Light to moderate sweet, light bitter. OK, but not interesting at all... A wholly average red ale.

name: Dunedin Red Head Red Ale
review: This poured a light red with a white head. Aroma was of bread and caramel, flavor similar but lightly metallic.

name: Dunedin Red Head Red Ale
