name: Free State Populist Porter
review: This is an oddball beer: not really a porter at all. At first "sip," one tastes the maltiness expected in a porter. Then the hops hit you. This is, first off, definitely overhopped to be a "porter." This is not really a problem; I like dry, hoppy porters if they're done right. It just doesn't seem to come together in this beer. The aroma is GRAPEFRUIT, the flavor is GRAPEFRUIT. It seems like they used a lot of one kind of hop. Body and mouthfeel is a bit thin, although the appearance is quite satisfactory. It's an alright beer, but not nearly as good as Free State is capable of producing.

name: Free State Populist Porter
review: Very chocolatey aroma. Filtered; very dark red-brown. Somewhat minimal head and carbonation. Very nice roasty chocolatey, coffeeish flavors, with a somewhat chewy mouthfeel. Aftertaste is roasty as well, with the hop flavors being pushed way to the back. I kind of wish more hops were there to give it a more interesting character, but it's smooth. Good porter.

name: Free State Prairie Pale Ale
review: Thanks to hopdog for sharing this from a growler he got in a trade with mreusch. Pours a lightly hazy golden orange with a bubbly/creamy off white head that left some lacing. Aroma of cereal grains, floral and citrus hops, bready and hints of iced tea. Flavor of hop flavor, bready/cereal malts, some caramel and citrus.

name: Free State Prairie Pale Ale
review: Growler acquired in trade with mreusch (thanks!). Poured a medium and hazy orangish color with a smaller sized white head. Aromas of citrus, floral, tea, and lightly spicey. Tastes of citrus, orange peels, toasted caramel, and lightly earthy.

name: Free State Prairie Pale Ale
review: On tap at the brewpub. Suprised by the lack of aroma in this beer. The flavor was, for me, better balanced than the Copperhead I had just prior. Stong hop flavor with all the citrus, piney notes but strong mouthfeel and toasty malts as well. Quite good.

name: Free State Prairie Pale Ale
review: Tap @ FS, pours a clear golden with a slight amber tint, nice white head and good lacing. Hoppy aroma is pine/resin, grass, citrus, and slight lemon. Flavor is a nice bite that lingers, with more fresh hops, and a lively palate. Another well done IPA from FS; well received on a hot and muggy summer evening.

name: Free State Prairie Pale Ale
review: Draft (Styrian Goldings version): Light golden color. Sticky, finely layered bright white foam wisp. Toasted malt husk, peppery/minty hop aroma with apple hints. Silky carbonation. Moderately grainy. Brash hop textures clash with the buttery yeast. Overt huskiness wreaks havoc on the palate. Unbalanced with only a sparse amount of florally-juicy/honeysuckle Styrian traits. Ends dryly woody and coarsely earthy with dirty yeast flavors muddling the soft hop whispers. The mere trace of bright hop burps fails to offer any redemption. Good, but with Styrians being one of my favorite hops, this was a letdown.

name: Free State Prairie Pale Ale
review: O.G. 15.15/1061, 55IBU. On tap at the bar. Orange-gold color with a thin head. Nice lacing. Nice hoppy aroma. Citrus peels, some honey? notes. Taste is a nice, intially sweet malt base that get overtaken quickly by the hops. Resiny, piney hops flavor. Finish is dry, piney. Nice mouthfeel. Ths hops changed for this batch. They used Styrian Goldings along with another that I neglected to write down.

name: Free State Prairie Pale Ale
review: Good. Drink this when they don't have barleywine at the pub. Had this on tap. Strong hop character, both boiling and finishing, but not an over hopped beer. Good balance. Pleasing malt body.

name: Free State Prairie Pale Ale
review: Fruity, citrusy, hoppy aroma, with some light malt sweetness. Medium-dark golden color, hazy, with a lasting, creamy off-white head and plenty of lace. Flavor has some biscuity Pale malt flavor and a small amount of caramel sweetness, but overall the citrusy spicy, juicy hop flavors are most prominent, and features some pineapple and herbal tones underneath. Medium bodied, lightly creamy palate. Aftertaste also very hop-accented and satisfyingly bitter. Fresh and tasty.

name: Free State Prairie Pale Ale
review: I could taste the hops the way they smell right out of the package...aroma was conspicuously absent though. Initial bite strong but quickly and sadly diminished.

name: Free State Prairie Pale Ale
review: This beer seems unfinished somehow, and is not nearly as good as Free State''s Copperhead Pale Ale (also an IPA). Bitter and malty enough for the supposed style (English IPA), but the hop aromas and flavors are prominently absent; the bitterness is the only aspect that really shines through. Not bad, but I''ve had much more complex IPA''s, from Free State alone.

name: Free State Wakarusa Lager
review: On tap at Free State. Pours a copper color with white head. Clean, grainy, earthy, cereal aromas. Slightly bitter, grainy, earthy, slightly tangy flavors. Not bad lager.

name: Free State Wakarusa Lager
review: Pint at the brewpub. Comes a golden red with a nice off-white head. Aroma of malt and citrus. Taste is malt, lemon, and grass. Nice balance of sweetness and bitterness. Very nice.

name: Free State Wakarusa Lager
review: Shakers at the brewpub. Pours a clear pale copper with a small beige head. Clean, somewhat biscuity malt with a solidly balancing earthy/citrusy hop note. On medium side of light-bodied with a nice soft mouthfeel and a tight bitter finish. Biscuity malt dances with a significant earthy, grassy, and slightly critic hop note and finishing bitterness. This is a really nice beer. Free State makes some of my favorite lagers ever.

name: Free State Wakarusa Lager
review: Shaker @ the brewpub. The beer is a copper color with a strong sticky head. The head has good retention and rings are formed as I gulp the beer down, akin to the age rings on a tree stump. Aroma has a great bitter, herbal hop aroma. I love it. Its a clean lager with bitter herbal hops; awesome. The slight difference here is a bit of sweetness, just a bit coming off the malt. Flavor has a great bitter herbal hop flavor as well mixed with that light sweetness. Otherwise it is all clean, nothing else coming off the malt. Bottom line: Just a simple, clean beer with an herbal hop center and a light malt sweetness.

name: Free State Wakarusa Lager
review: On tap at Free State. Pours a crystal clear, golden-copper colored body with a finger-width, off-white, creamy head that dissipates quickly and leaves lots of lacing. Aroma is malty sweet with a light citrus hopping. Smooth caramels, lemon, earth, straw, and a faint spicing I can’t seem to put my finger on. Flavor has a much more pronounced hop character than the aroma. Sweeter caramels up front before an earthy, straw-like lemony hoppiness comes in. The hops grow into the finish where this dries with a moderate bitterness and a clean, caramel sweetness. Lengthy aftertaste of earthy lemons after a smooth, medium, very clean body. Overall, a solid beer. Fairly simple, but balanced with a good amount of hops and a sweeter, smooth malt body. Very clean and easy drinking.

name: Free State Wakarusa Lager
review: 10 oz draft pour at the brewpub. Pour is a clear golden amber with a smallish white head that falls with glass coating lacing. Aroma of not too much, some straw some hay, maybe a touch of earthiness behind that. Taste is mild sweet malt followed quickly by really drying straw mineral hops. Palate has light to medium body with lighter carbonation and the aforementioned dry finish. This was clean and easy to drink, nice, well made, straight forward beer.

name: Free State Wakarusa Lager
review: Fruity, hoppy aroma, some citrusy orange and caramel malt sweetness with lighter notes of of mint, spicy hop and apple skin. Medium-dark copper color, clear, with a slight, subsiding head. Fruity and sweet up front, becoming hoppier as the flavor progresses and with lightly spicy, lemony finish. Moderate amount of bitterness throughout. Medium bodied, palate is quite lively. A lager that drinks like an IPA.

name: Free State Wakarusa Lager
review: Grapefruit, grapefruit, grapefruit. The aroma and flavor practically hollared this to me. Beautiful deep amber shade, little head. It was "super clean", a little much for me though. The palate belied a slightly wheaty and complex malt character. But this was only after the grapefruit orgy faded to silence.

name: Free State Wheat State Golden
review: Bottle poured into a shaker on 7/3/18. Labeled only as "Golden". Gold color and a massive, thick, off white head. Aroma is wheat and citrus. Initial taste is rather bland... a little wheat and lemon. Aftertaste is much the same... very bready. Palate is medium and foamy with decent carbonation. Not sure what to make of this.

name: Free State Wheat State Golden
review: 12oz bottle as Golden..no mention of wheat. Medium bodied, straightforward, well made. Clean simple ingredients. Not a lot going on, but a pleasant enough session beer.

name: Free State Wheat State Golden
review: Sampler at brewpub. Pours golden with a thin head. Leaves some lacing in the glass. Not much on the nose. Maltier than expected on the tongue. Crisp and clean on the finish.

name: Free State Wheat State Golden
review: Free State’s Wheat State Golden is a light drinker, for sure. Golden shade and pure white suds. A clean, malty nose. Bread flavors with a hint of citrusy hops. Light-bodied and lively carbonation that’s just south of prickly. A nice brew for hot weather.

name: Free State Wheat State Golden
review: Nothing special here. The dryness stands out. Having this in the cold of winter, seems better suited to have outside on a hot summer night. Rating would be higher if the timing was right.

name: Free State Wheat State Golden
review: Golden beer with a foamy white head. Crisp cracker nose with hints of lemon. This is a light, easy drinking beer with some apple and orange notes over some cracker malts. A bit of lemon cookie in the finish. Good lawn mower beer.

name: Free State Wheat State Golden
review: Bottle: Clear medium gold with a small white head. Citrus aroma....apple-lemon-honey. Sweet flavour, lemon-aplle, straw, softly malted. Very good....a nice, light Kolsch.

name: Free State Wheat State Golden
review: Bottle. Orange-apple malt and straw aroma. Golden yellow with moderate head. Sweet lightly tangy lemon-apple, malt, and mildly bitter herbal hay flavor. Medium body. Nice.

name: Free State Wheat State Golden
review: 12 oz pour from bottle from fridge into mug. Little head. Straw color. Clear. Nice carbonation. Smells a little yeasty, but mostly clean. Tastes crisp, unassuming. A little bitterness. Not too bad, but not much going on.

name: Free State Wheat State Golden
review: Flight pour on tap at the brewery (Lawrence, KS). Pours a glowing rich orange amber hue, transparent hue is fiery sun and amber sap glow. Frothy whitish head atop stays as a decent layer, mellow lacing from the ringer atop. Aromas are a bit of flaked wheat, some dust and dry straw meeting a mellow earthy hop. A faint underlying fruitiness hits the nose. Touches of earth,,dryness and spice, grainy flaked wheat and cereal elements. Initial is lighter end of the fold in body but not without some substance to it. Gentle bready malts, a flinty kick of estery fruit shows some life with some decent hop bitterness, grainy malts, earthy hops and gentle straw. Backend is a touch fruity, gentle flashes of lemon with some earthiness, florals and a bit of spice. Smoothed out backend with a touch of dryness, earth, lingering bread and that subtle kick of lemon juice making it a bit refreshing. Lighter, pretty crushable with a coolness to it on the palate. Nice.

name: Bluegrass Altbier
review: (tap) clear, bright, orange amber colour with a small beige head; aroma of honey; light, balanced flavour with a long, light bitter finish

name: Bluegrass Altbier
review: Draft at the brewpub. Pours amber with light beige head. Bready malt aroma with floral notes. Biscuit malt with caramel notes.

name: Bluegrass Altbier
review: On tap at the brewery. Pours a hazy orange with small off white head. The aroma is grain and rye. Medium body, rye, bready malt, light finish, decent.

name: Bluegrass Altbier
review: Didn’t take tasting notes. Just wrote down the score so I’m typing just enough words.

name: Bluegrass Kolsch
review: Didn’t take tasting notes. Just wrote down the score so I’m typing just enough words.

name: Bluegrass Kolsch
review: Draft. Pours clear light brown/gold. Tastes like funk, woody, wheaty. Smells funky and fermented. Light body and carbonation.

name: Bluegrass Kolsch
review: On tap at brewery. Clear golden with a fizzy white head. Sweet bread aroma and taste with a vanilla malt and cereal grain finish.

name: Bluegrass Kolsch
review: On tap. I can only assume the ratings of this beer are coming from bad or old bottles/kegs, or from people who can;t appreciate the subtleties of this style. This was one of the better Kolsches I have ever had, and usually I am pretty skeptical and judgmental of BBC. It pour a very nice copper color. Crystal clear, nice white head and lace. It exhibited a very nice hop profile on the nose and flavor. The hops are most certainly there, but carried out with a nice subtlety, making them very on point with the style. Medium to light bodied with minimal carbonation. Nice and smooth. Overall: I could session on this beer all day.

name: Bluegrass Kolsch
review: Beautiful golden, grassy aroma and flavor, tinge of sour in the malt, mineral rocky taste. Medium body. Very refeshing.

name: Bluegrass Kolsch
review: Aroma of lemongrass, honey and light fruit. Appearance is gold with creamy head. Flavor matches the nose. Palate is creamy. Pretty ordinary, but drinkable.

name: Bluegrass Kolsch
review: Not too shabby. Very light flavored beer, but very pretty to look at. It’s got excellent body and head retention.

name: Bluegrass Kolsch
review: Billed as the Organic Kolsch Pours light golden iwth a thin foamy off-white head. Aroma is buttery, light malty notes of cookie and honey. Tastes of sweet malt, buttery grain and coarse graininess. Mouthfeel is light to medium bodied with lively carbonation. Ar 6 Ap 4 Fl 6 Mf 4 Ov 12 = 3.2 Billed as "Roo’s Kolsch" Pours bright amber with a fully receding tan head. Notes of crackery malt, bready, munich malt, with a bit of caramel. Medium bodied with some herbal dryness and lively carbonation. Ap 4 Ar 7 Ta 6 Mf 4 Ov 15

name: Bluegrass Kolsch
review: Draft at the brewpub (4th St location). Poured a clear golden color. Head was white and left some decent lace behind. Subtle, but pleasant aromas including buttery caramel, sweet cream, and cereal grain. Flavor was similar with the addition of minimal noble hops. Fresh cereal grain flavor in the finish was an added bonus. Surprisingly good kolsch.

name: Bluegrass Kolsch
review: Draft at brewpub. Straw color with an average frothy white head. Light hoppy aroma. Light body with a watery texture. Soft sweet hoppy flavor with a short finish.

name: Bluegrass American Pale Ale
review: (tap) slightly hazy, bright orange amber colour with a small beige head; aroma of honey, dry, mineral, unbalanced bitter flavour with a long, strong bitter finish

name: Bluegrass American Pale Ale
review: On tap at Bluegrass, pours a hazy copper golden with a small beige head. Aroma brings out metallic notes, piney hops and somewhat stale biscuity malt. Flavour is a bit stale, with metallic notes, stale biscuity malt and old hops. This just isn’t good.

name: Bluegrass American Pale Ale
review: On tap at the brewery. Pours a clear copper with small off white head that lasts. The aroma is floral and citrus. Medium body, pine, citrus, light bitter finish, good.

name: Bluegrass American Pale Ale
review: Didn’t take tasting notes. Just wrote down the score so I’m typing just enough words.

name: Bluegrass American Pale Ale
review: Crystal clear amber color topped by a nice frothy head that is punctured by hop pocks. Fruity and punchy hop nose. Flowery hop flavor with rose water notes that veer into baby powder on the finish. Bitter, baby powder finish.

name: Bluegrass American Pale Ale
review: Pours clear Amber with a nice buff head that leaves generous lacing. Aroma is not strong, but crisp and malty. Flavor is considerably bolder, malty with hoppy and subtle fruity notes, quite enjoyable. Mouthfeel has average body and fizz, but finish is delightfully hoppy and not at all bitter. Worth a fair shake!

name: Bluegrass American Pale Ale
review: Straw color to amber. Good citrus hop aroma. Mild malts. Breads. Lean. But overall pretty good.

name: Bluegrass American Pale Ale
review: Old rating. Bottle from Old Town. Nice aromas of floral hops, citrus and resin with some malt in there as well. Fairly well-balanced between caramel malt and bitter hops on the palate. Biscuity malt flavors appear is it comes to room temperature. Nice bitter finish.

name: Bluegrass American Pale Ale
review: 12oz bottle. It took more than 20 minutes, one foam-over, and four different attempts to pour this beer. The head never diminished, it just got chewed. Aroma is all hop resin and just enough malt sweetness to pull it together. The flavor is cloying hop resin. Absolutely no balance. Nothing I would drink again.

name: Bluegrass American Pale Ale
review: Draft sampler pours Amber with a off white head. Aroma of malts, citrus and pine. Taste is malts and grapefruit.

name: Bluegrass Dark Star Porter
review: Patty and I stopped in for dinner while passing thru town. Poured brown with an off white head. Aroma is chocolate and some coffee mostly with light caramel malt. Flavor is chocolate malt with a light roasty bitterness. Medium body with a slightly thin mouth feel.

name: Bluegrass Dark Star Porter
review: On tap at the Bluegrass Brewing Company on Main Street in downtown Louisville, Ky. Pours nearly opaque dark brown with ruby highlights with zero head and some residual tan lacing. Aroma: fragrant brown sugar and dark dried fruits. Flavor: brown bread, brown sugar, raisins, date bars, nuts, oatmeal. Mouthfeel: light- to medium-bodied, soft on palette, creamy finish.

name: Bluegrass Dark Star Porter
review: With Kris at Louisville KY at Bluegrass brewery. Brown colored beer with small white head and no carbonation. Chocolate malty granny aroma. Full sparkling palate. Finish is bitter malty roasted alcoholic.

name: Bluegrass Dark Star Porter
review: On tap at Bluegrass, pours a deep dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma brings out toasted malt, a bit of dark cocoa and earthy notes. Flavour is along the same lines, with stale earthy notes and dull bready malt. Stale and lifeless. Bad.

name: Bluegrass Dark Star Porter
review: i have to say only ok.i found all.their stuff to be lacking " backbone". reminded me of English beer. decent flavor, but i might be spoiled to the Gremlin Growler

name: Bluegrass Dark Star Porter
review: On tap at the brewery. Pours a dark brown ruby hue with small beige head that lasts. The aroma is roast and cocoa. Medium body, toasted malt, caramel, light dry finish, good.

name: Bluegrass Dark Star Porter
review: An ok porter with decent taste and body. Not amazing but not bad either. On top at the brewpub.

name: Bluegrass Dark Star Porter
review: (tap) clear very dark borwn colour with a tall brown head; aroma of roast, bitter chocolate; light, balanced flavour with a long, light sour finish

name: Bluegrass Dark Star Porter
review: Sampled at GABF 2015. In sample glass was dark brown with tan foam. Nose of chocolate. Medium body. Flavor is big on chocolate and the finish is bittersweet. To style and tasty.

name: Bluegrass Oatmeal Stout
review: Cask at the brewpub. Pours dark opaque reddish brown with large red-brown head. The aroma is bourbon, oak, vanilla, and soy sauce. The flavor is quite oaken, with a touch of bitter coffee, just a brief note of soy sauce, and an ashy finish. Some smoke comes out increasingly in the aftertaste. Satisfying.

name: Bluegrass Oatmeal Stout
review: on cask. Nice looking brownish-red brew with a very dense, lasting tan head. The aroma is like burboun and rich of sweet malts. The mouthfeel is wonderfully creamy. A tiny bit of coffee comes through and more sweet oak notes. The finish is like smoky, well done bacon.

name: Bluegrass Oatmeal Stout
review: Balanced chocolate/roast malt aroma and flavor. The head is outstanding and the finish is a complex blend of malt and hops.

name: Bluegrass Oatmeal Stout
review: Beautiful on cask. Cinnamony and bitter with gorgeous head that sticks til the end. They have really done it well this time! Stop in during the colder months for this hearty brew.

name: Bluegrass Ebenezer Spiced Ale
review: On tap at Bluegrass, pours a clear golden orange with a small off-white head. Nose is pure holiday spices, with lots of nutmeg upfront, and a little cinnamon. Flavour is the same, with lots of nutmeg and cinnamon, maybe a bit of clove too. Not very thrilling, but it’s done well for what it is.

name: Bluegrass Ebenezer Spiced Ale
review: 12/03/2010: BBC Ebenezer (through a Randall of dried fruits and cinnamon sticks)... Aroma: Dry clove, orange, cinnamon, nutmeg. Appearance: Amber color, frothy light beige crown. Flavor: Very much like the aroma along with some slightly sweet and bready maltiness underneath. Palate: Medium-light to medium body; smooth. Overall: Nice balance of flavors; easy to drink. Draught sample(s) during the BBC "Backroom Brawl" at Party Town in Florence, KY. Rating #15 for this beer.

name: Bluegrass Ebenezer Spiced Ale
review: Aroma of nutmeg, cinnamon; an overall eggnog feeling. Appearance is dark red/brown with tan head. Flavor matches the nose, but with an emphasis on nutmeg. Palate is bubbly. Another solid BBC brew, but not top notch.

name: Bluegrass Summer Wheat
review: (tap) slightly hay, bright yellow colour with a small white head; aroma of grain, balanced flavour with a long, very light bitter finish

name: Bluegrass Summer Wheat
review: With Kris at Louisville KY at Bluegrass brewery. Clear blond colored beer with small white head and no carbonation. Yeasty aroma. Medium sparkling palate. Finish is yeasty sweet slightly dry

name: Bluegrass Summer Wheat
review: On tap at Bluegrass, pours a cloudy orange with no head. Aroma brings out not much anything, maybe some light wheat. Flavour is dull and lifeless, with toasted biscuity malt. Not much to write about here.

name: Bluegrass Summer Wheat
review: Sampled at GABF. In the tasting glass cloudy gold. Nose of something. Stale. something. Light body. Flavor was citrus maybe. Not much wheat. Hard to rate this with just a sample but overall not very enjoyable for me.

name: Bluegrass Summer Wheat
review: Golden-hued with a decent head. Rather dank nose with perhaps a touch of wheat, Dank 20row grain and wheat tastes, a bit overripe on the palate. Sour, tannic finish,

name: Bluegrass Summer Wheat
review: Pours clear golden with a thin eggshell head. Crisp aroma is more malty than wheaty. Some wheat comes through in the flavor, but it is still mainly malt, like a typical lager. Mouthfeel has average body and not much fizz. OK, maybe not heir best batch of this.

name: Bluegrass Summer Wheat
review: Refreshing. Not the strongest aroma or taste but still a really good beer. Good not great.

name: Bluegrass Summer Wheat
review: Draft sampler pours golden with a white head. Aroma of wheat, malts, yeast and some floral. Taste is yeast, grain and hay

name: Bluegrass Summer Wheat
review: Tap @ Bluegrass: Pale straw color, cloudy & topped with a soapy, bright white collar. Bubbly. Grainy & wheat filled aroma with some cereal grains & faint pale malt sweetness. A little bit of hop leafiness in the flavor with more heaps of wheat & cereal grain. Slight flavor of buttered crackers in the finish. Very mild, light, & kind of vapid. Easy drinking but a little boring.

name: Bluegrass Summer Wheat
review: 10oz pour just to see what it was about. poured clear bright yellow with white head. minimal lacing on the glass...found it disturbing that I couldn’t get any type of nose on this one...nothing. flavor was mild to medium malt and wheat and there was almost a mid bitterness from the wheat. not much here to tell you the truth. not bad but not anything to write home about.

name: Stone Coast Sunsplash Golden Ale
review: Reviewed from old notes. This was poured into a pint glass. The appearance was a decent golden color with a film of thin white head. The smell had an ample amount of sweet corn lightly dosed with a slight caramel edge. The taste was pretty much the same adding a light biscuit-esque glaze over my taste buds. On the palate, this one sat about a light on the body with a decent sessionability about it. The carbonation seemed ok for the style and for me. There’s a nice carbonation about it. Overall, this was a decent golden/blonde ale I could do again.

name: Stone Coast Sunsplash Golden Ale
review: Pours gold with a white head. Smells of some fruit, floral hops, dry pilsner malt. Tastes of toasted malt, some crisp hoppy notes and a floral finish.

name: Stone Coast Sunsplash Golden Ale
review: 20061007 After Kennett. Clear and pale gold. Big white head. Aroma it tinny and bretty, mineral, touch of bandaid. Flavor is mostly bland, mucho dry, seemingly infected. Late metallic notes and funk. Very thin and dry. Something I oddly enjoy with the flavor.

name: Stone Coast Sunsplash Golden Ale
review: Can sampled. Pours a golden yellow with a off-white head. Aroma of lemon, grass, and some grain. Flavor follows the aroma and is malty with a hint of citrus.

name: Stone Coast Sunsplash Golden Ale
review: 12 oz Can - Poured a somewhat cloudy golden yellow in color with a big foamy white head that faded fairly quickly. Aroma was somewhat malty and skunked (from a can?). Flavor was not as malty as I anticipated and there was more hops than I expected too. Finish was mildly bitter and short... finished cleanly. Not real good...

name: Stone Coast Sunsplash Golden Ale
review: poured into tulip. pours a clear gold, with mild white head. a fresh golden malty aroma, not too much hidden. smooth and clean golden ale, light finish. not complex but serves its purpose, a good light sessionable quality.

name: Stone Coast Sunsplash Golden Ale
review: (draft) Clear straw body topped by white head. Aroma is medium sweet, lemon, biscuit. Taste is medium sweet, biscuit, light lemon. Light body.

name: Stone Coast Sunsplash Golden Ale
review: 12 ounce can from the Beverage Warehouse in Winooski, VT (July 2007) served at cellar temperature in a Samuel Smiths pint glass. Huge, creamy-foamy white head erupts from the can, slowly decaying about the very bright, lightly hazy golden body and leaving thin spidery lacing....honey-biscuity aroma, light floral-perfumy hops, a touch of jasmine and lavender and then on a second nosing, beautiful ripe apricots.....not nearly as entrancing upon tasting, however: very thin and watery, with pale malts barely distinguishable in the bitter, slightly burnt and somewhat chemical-adjuncty flavor profile; at the finish a fuesel plasticy quality dominates and the experience is basically ruined....light to moderate carbonation, some mineralic and metallic notes also evident at the finish. This brewery has been frustrating to me, a couple of very high quality beers and everything else quite mixed....this one I’ll try again based mostly on Clark’s rave, but for now it’s not worth it.

name: Stone Coast Sunsplash Golden Ale
review: Light and fruity. Citrus, but not in a hoppy way. Reminds me a lot of the rind of a citrus fruit. A little bubble gum. Actually more bitter than I would have expected. Has some sort of harsheness that I can’t place. Really a strange beer that I can’t make up my mind on. It’s light and refreshing, but somehow that harshness prevents it from being an easy drinker.

name: Stone Coast Sunsplash Golden Ale
review: On tap at David Copperfield’s in NYC. A minimum head on yellow body. Lace and creaminess, drinkable but a high carbonation. No aroma to speak of. Drop of cirus taste, more malt than hop.

name: Stone Coast 420 IPA
review: Fairly thin head with staying power, spotty lace. Light amber/dark golden in color, barely perceiptable haze in the liquid. Dark earthy hops is the predominant aroma, no real floral touch. Slightly yeasty, malt is present with a caramel sweetness. Overly hoppy even for an IPA--not that I’m complaining, my tastes lean this way. Very astringent aftertaste, really bitter, long lasting. Malt flavors are brief and fleeting. Full bodied with good carbonation. This would be a great beer to try last in a flight of IPA’s. Too bitter for regular consumption.

name: Stone Coast 420 IPA
review: Reviewed from old notes. This was poured into a pint glass at the brewpub. The appearance was a fairly nice looking glossy/hazy and somewhat golden to amber-ed orange color. There was a light foamy stringy lacing sticking and then sliding into the beer. The smell had a super nice aromatic citric/slightly piney aromas. The taste was there. It took the citrus with the pine to make a fairly nice bittersweet combination to taste. On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a fairly decent sessionability about it. The carbonation was somewhat there but honestly, nothing overbearing and nothing far out. Overall, I say this was a good IPA I could bang again.

name: Stone Coast 420 IPA
review: Poured into a snifter. 420 IPA pours a hazy, yellowish orange with a hint of red to it. Atop the brew is a nice off white head, with decent retention which leads to some light lacing. The aroma is a strong, sweet floral smell, with some hints of citrus, as well as some sweet grains. The beer tastes like tea with wet hops. Tastes dry-hopped eventhough the bottle didn’t say anything. The taste is a little light on the flavor compared to the aroma. Mouthfeel is smooth, yet a little dry. Mild to high on the carbonation level. At 6.9% some may not call this a session beer, but I beg to differ. It is smooth and has a different flavor than most IPAs, which makes the drinker take their time a little more, but not like a big beer.

name: Stone Coast 420 IPA
review: 2006: Orange-gold appearance. Nice full amount of head that isn’t going anywhere anytime soon. Cloudy and opaque. Overwhelming fruity scent. Overpowers any malt or hops that might be present. It’s a good smell, but doesn’t seem like it’s going to be an IPA. By smell alone, it seems like it would be an Apricot ale or some such madness. Malts and fruits dominate the bouquet. Has a very fruity, hoppy flavor. Unusual. Not quite anything I can remember having before. The fruit is actually much more prominent than the hops. I was expecting a bit more of a cannabis flavor given the name, but alas it is nowhere to be found. Tastes more like an apricot ale than an IPA. Or rather, an apricot ale with a heavy hop presence. A bit too fizzy and carbonated for my taste. I would prefer something a little smoother. The fizziness on the tongue makes it a bit of a tough sell. Harder to drink than many of the smoother IPAs. In fact, I would say that this beer is smooth as sandpaper. Not bad, just not one I crave.

name: Stone Coast 420 IPA
review: Pours gold with a nice white head. Smells of grass, hay, floral. Tastes perfumy and bitter with a caramelly finish.

name: Stone Coast 420 IPA
review: Nice hazy golden orange coloured body with a light amber tint and a frothy off-white head. Aroma of fresh hops, sweet sugars, oranges, grasses and green apples. Medium-bodied; Strong grassy hops with some floral hop quality and a plentiful potency of malt and caramel. Aftertaste shows more malt than hops and not a lot of hops at all. Overall, I thought this one would be more hoppy and well-rounded, but this one tasted like an APA. I sampled this 350 mL bottle purchased fresh from Oliver’s Beverage in Albany, New York on 08-October-2006.

name: Stone Coast 420 IPA
review: A very hazy appearance to it with a bit of fluffy white head. Lacing is minimal but present. The smell is of earthy hops and fruit. The most present taste is grapefruit with a bit of an additional bite form the hops. This is a pretty hefty IPA on the tongue with a grainy kind of texture. This is a highly drinkable brew. I probably couldn’t have too many due to its fuller body, but I’m good for a few. I’m usually more of a stout person but I enjoyed this brew and it was very different from other IPAs that I’ve had. I may become a hophead yet. Reviewed on: 05-23-2007

name: Stone Coast 420 IPA
review: Pours a murky rust orange with a sturdy, dense off-white head. Much of the hop aroma is muted, with light citrus, fruits and nothing else. The flavour is has a nice orange citrus flavor with peppery citrus and honey sweetness. This is a very straight forward, toasty and easy drinking IPA, but nothing worth buying again in my opinion. The aftertaste is bitter in a non-medicinal way, which is nice. The mouthfeel is medium-thin, sticky and mildly carbonated.

name: Stone Coast 420 IPA
review: 12oz. Bottle: Bottle exploded upon opening coating me half the beer. Lightly sweet aroma. Smells of fruity hops, peach, tangerine, apricot, pale malts, and slight citrus. Poured amber in color with a small, creamy, dense, off-white head that lasted throughout. Cloudy. Sparkling. Full of tiny and small particles. Very good lacing. Flavor is lightly sweet and medium bitter. Tastes of hops, fruit, grapefruit, resin, berries, and some other fruit I cannot identify. Medium body. Smooth, then chalky texture. Average to lively carbonation. Bitter, hoppy, resinous finish is medium dry.

name: Stone Coast 420 IPA
review: I was lucky enough to get one of the last kegs of this and had it on draft at my house. The head was massive and i had to wait a while for it to settle untill i could even drink it. The color is a bit cloudy with a redish amber color. The nose is full of light fruits and pepper spice. The flavor is nice and bitter leaving a tingle in your mouth after eash sip. There is some nice traces of caramilized malt with some toasted malt but overall it was a refreshing beer and it is a shame they will not be produceing it any more.

name: Sunday River Alt
review: Quart can via PUB'R. Pours hazy dark brown with fluffy head. Nose was corn flakey malt, earthy caramel. Tastes earthy, caramel malty, nutty, with a smooth finish and medium body.

name: Sunday River Alt
review: Poured from Crowler purchased at brewery. Pours amber with white head. Toasted malt aroma. Flavor is toasted malt with caramel and a bready yeast finish. Really nice lager.

name: Sunday River Alt
review: Draft. Crystal clear copper body with small beige head. Aroma is moderately sweet, caramel, some bread, milk chocolate, light spicy. Taste is moderately sweet, orange, bread, caramel, some spicy. Light-medium body, light stickiness, low carbonation.

name: Sunday River Black Bear Porter
review: Quart can via PUB'R. Pours hazy deep coppery toward brown with frothy, tan head. Nose is roasty dark malt, resiny hops, cacao. Tastes dark malty, with notes of dark chocolate syrup, hops, and a roasty finish. Like a black IPA/porter hybrid.

name: Sunday River Black Bear Porter
review: Pours dark brown with an amber tint and an off white head. Roasted malt aroma. Flavor is roasted malt and chocolate. Earthy hop finish.

name: Sunday River Black Bear Porter
review: Drunk straight from a quart can, now thats something you don’t get to say very often, while floating on a Maine pond so I may be projecting a little bias onto this beer but wow this is a good one, coffee but not overly so, tasty rich malty

name: Sunday River Black Bear Porter
review: Good flavor in a big (32oz.) can. Requisite dark coffee notes. Reliable roasting and a bit of bitterness makes for a fun drink.

name: Sunday River Black Bear Porter
review: Reviewed from old notes. At the brewery, this was poured into a pint glass. The appearance was a dark brown close to black color with a bar pour’s kind of slim white head. There wasn’t any lacing. The smell had a dark roasty coffee aroma with a robust quality to it. The taste was basically the same. On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a pretty good sessionability about it. Carbonation seemed somewhat subdued but mainly good for the style. I have to admit there does seem to be a fair amount wateriness about this. Overall, not a bad Porter, I’d have this again.

name: Sunday River Black Bear Porter
review: Watery porter, whose smell is deceving, it has the right smell and smokey taste but the mouth feel leaves you disappointed

name: Sunday River Black Bear Porter
review: Alpine Porter! Black Bear with the addition of juniper breweries. Aroma is a little funky - a bit like Lindburger cheese. Classic porter mouthfeel. Root beer coloring.

name: Sunday River Black Bear Porter
review: Draft at Sunday River Brewing. Pours black with a thick head. This is a very good traditional porter. The roasted barley comes through and there is a nice dry hop finish. The beer is dry overall and easy to drink.

name: Sunday River Black Bear Porter
review: Pitch black darkness. There are specks of yeast-sediment floating in the stagnant, tar-like body. Absolutely a black hole. Malty but with a surprising hop flourish. Fresh, flowery scent. Mild coffee flavor, but has an underlying sweetness. Has a nice hop kick that offers an excellent balance. Great balance of sweetness and hops. Nice thick flavor and fee. Has a nice, smooth feel afterward. A bit chalky but in a good way. Excellent, balanced porter. Has a nice, strong flavor,, but not overwhelming. A good combination of different flavors.

name: Sunday River Black Bear Porter
review: Pours dark brown with a thin tan head. Smells of sweet malt and mildly roasty. Tastes of roasted malt and chocolatey, but a bit thin on the mouthfeel.

name: Yellow Rose Wildcatters Crude Stout
review: This is to beer as oil is to beer. This is horrific crap, with hints of cauliflower and rotten roasted malt. Water, water, everywhere in this beer, and not a drop fit to drink.

name: Yellow Rose Wildcatters Crude Stout
review: Joe made me do it. I swear! I didn’t want to buy it, honest. Actually had this before and thought it was okay, but as I have no respect for the allowance of outdated bottles filling space that could be used for better product and the fact that unsuspecting souls may easily be lead to believe that this isn’t as rancid as it is, I will not mince words. Lactic, acidic - but not in a pleasant way nor is the oxidized matter that I almost made myself finish before I said the punishment was enough. Sad.

name: Yellow Rose Wildcatters Crude Stout
review: Still available...bottom of the coolers at S & K’s in Plano, among other places. And you know, I’ve had worse. This was especially palatable when it was relatively cold from the fridge. It poured a dark ruby-black with a bountiful dark beige head. The aroma, when cold, let out coffee, roasted essences with notes of grape, vinyl, and licorice. The flavor was similarly roasted and relatively pleasing--at first--although the palate is quite light. It is to stouts what something with Woodforde’s Norfolk Nip is to barleywines: you’re expecting thick, but you get an explosion in the mouth. That’s not bad, actually: not every stout has to be thick and oily, although with a name like "Crude Stout" I was expecting something more akin to a viscous fluid. Unfortunately, as it warmed, I started to get more sour notes from it, not exactly lactic, more just subtly vinegary, and then it got too much. So, I would say, keep it cold and drink it fast. But even with these problems, if you haven’t had it and you see it around, I would spring for it--at $2.50 for an unfiltered, unpasteurized beer, if it has been well kept it has the potential for having evolved a bit, and it isn’t terrible.

name: Yellow Rose Wildcatters Crude Stout
review: Not too bad, but not one of my favorites. The dark color is reminiscent of an oatmeal stout , but the flavor lacks the sweetness. It has hints of coffee and roasted chocolates in both the aroma and the taste. I’d give it a B+.

name: Yellow Rose Wildcatters Crude Stout
review: Had this from a pint bottle. This black beer came flowing out of the bottle with a ton of carbonation. Aroma was roasted and chocolatey; very pleasureable. The flavor had lots of deep rostedness and chocolate but the zing from the carbonation really detracted from the flavor. Some acidity in the aftertaste.

name: Yellow Rose Wildcatters Crude Stout
review: Appearance: deepest, darkest black, with significant speckles floating throughout, and a sturdy brown head above, similarly dotted, and heroically long-lived. Aroma: briskly bitter, distinctly espresso-ish, rich and roasted, velvety, divine. Taste: smooth deliverance on the tongue, and full of flavor, very sweet, chocolatey, caramelly... A bit lighter in body than I like my stouts, but otherwise, an excellent example. I enjoyed this all the way down the big, bad bottle!

name: Yellow Rose Wildcatters Crude Stout
review: Poured opaque black with a thin tan head and BIG floaties...by big I mean physically they were big....not a lot of little ones like some bottle conditioned Belgians, LARGE 1/16-1/8 of an inch stuff...some you could feel actually pass your lips...I am honestly not sure the age of this bottle...I know it is brewed by Great Grains now, but my bottle still says Yellow Rose and the phone number on the bottle was answered by a slightly irritated lady when I called to just see what would happen (since YR closed [also it was 1 AM, I guess I’m just rude])... Smell is roasty with some chocolate...taste is rather bland...there isn’t a whole lot going on at all...just roasted maltiness, some nuts, chocolate and coffee...finish is acidic and a little bitter...

name: Yellow Rose Wildcatters Crude Stout
review: dark almost black color with a fluffy tan head with yeasties or some other specks floating in it. roast chocolate aroma. taste is oil and low grade chocolate malts. doesn’t start well, and ends the same way/ best great grains product yet, but that is not saying much. this does not compare well with other stouts and finishes bitter and watery

name: Yellow Rose Wildcatters Crude Stout
review: Bottle. Oily pour with LOTS of yeasty floaties. Do you remember what it looked like out the window of the Milinieum Falcon when they went into light speed? That is what my glass looks like. Too many floaties. Slightly sour nose. Taste like a really good stout with paint thinner mixed in. The best Great Grains beer, but what is that worth?

name: Yellow Rose Wildcatters Crude Stout
review: On looks alone this brew should be a winner. When poured out of the bottle it errupted with a hugh head. But then I had to sip it and as they say in Texas "all hat and no cattle".

name: Portland Brewing WheatBerry Brew
brewery: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
review: Portland Brewing Company, Inc. Wheat Berry Brew--1997 12 oz. Bottle. 4.50% ABV. Fruit Ale--Wheat Ok Wheat but somewhat bland.

name: Portland Brewing WheatBerry Brew
brewery: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
review: Date: 10/04/1996 Mode: Bottle Source: Taco Mac, Sandy Springs cloudy light amber, scant head, pleasant light berry aroma, slight sweet marion berry flavor on top of a good wheat base, the berry disapates leaving behind a wheat character finish Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.6/5.0 Score: **/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

name: Portland Brewing WheatBerry Brew
brewery: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
review: Golden Color, berry aroma (Marion berry and other berry flavors). Slight berry taste, more bitter than sweet. A wheat beer flavored with berries but still has maltyness to it.

name: Portland Brewing WheatBerry Brew
brewery: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
review: Very strong fruity flavors, but not very sweet, which is a plus. On the other hand, I don't think I like marionberry. It tastes, well, funny. It's not a bad idea for a beer, just not my cup of tea (or, mug of beer, as the case may be). Looks and smells good, though, and easy drinking.

name: HardCore Black Cider
review: Tasty, but what ever happened to hard cores cranberry apple. Now that was a perfect brew

name: HardCore Black Cider
review: Pours a amber color. Aromas wine with tart apples. Flavor is oakish red wine and tart apples.

name: HardCore Black Cider
review: Pours a deep ruby/mahogany with a slight fizz, but no head whatsoever. Apple aroma with light vinegar notes. Flavor is crisp apple tartness with a kiss of cherry and a drop of honey. No "wooden" notes... the only evidence of barrel-aging is in its smoothness - it holds light astringence, but its sourness isn’t upsetting. Found in my sister’s fridge.

name: HardCore Black Cider
review: Golden in color with a small white head that quickly disapates. Aroma of applesw, slightl sweet finishes dry.

name: HardCore Black Cider
review: Why is this brew rated so low it great stuff.Nice amber color,nearly no head,strong apple aroma.Sweet/sour apple taste that is quite pleasant but i fear will lead to some hard core after effects as many of my fellow raters have posted.Over all i don't think this brew is rated very well i think it deserves a higher place.Hard to say what is the best cider since i'm not an aficciando(spelling problem) but i know what i like and this is a pretty decent cider and worth a decent rate.

name: HardCore Black Cider
review: as ciders go this is definitly one of the more palatable ones. Not too sweet for once!

name: HardCore Black Cider
review: Yikes! This stuff ranks right up there with Mad Dog 20/20. Just like drink cheap apple wine. Whew, I cannot describe the head ache pain I had the next morning after drinking this one night. Stay away from the Hard Core.

name: HardCore Black Cider
review: Re-rate 6/4/02: No, I wasn't foolish enough to drink this again, but I was reading through my ratings when I saw this and cringed. I was dismayed to see that I gave this a 0.8. This is on a short list of things that I will never drink again, unless I'm stuck on a desert island for life or in Hell. First rating: Holy shit! I'll be lucky if I'm alive in the morning, never-mind finishing this. Sweet and sour in a really bad way. No head. The dark color is the ONLY thing going for this.

name: HardCore Black Cider
review: If you are looking to get a little drunk on cider, hit this one up. It's cheap and it will do the job. Be weary of the apple flavored hangover.

name: Fischer Bitter
review: From old tasting notes. Labeled as "Fischer d’Alsace Bitter". Deep amber gold color. Thick creamy white head. Sweet perfumy bouquet, is fresh and aromatic. Initially, a sweet toasted malt flavor pervades. Flavor becomes nominally bitter with a hint of fruitiness. Light clean hop finish. Well balanced and flavorful.

name: Fischer Bitter
review: Schöne 500ml Bügelflasche. Hellgelbes Bier mut weissem Schaum. Herber Grasduft. Geschmack herb, grasig und metallisch.

name: Fischer Bitter
review: earthy, grass, cereal, butterscotch, golden, cloudy, frothy, medium sweetness, very bitter, lightly sour, medium body, slick feel, soft carbonation, bitter,

name: Fischer Bitter
review: 500mL swingtop bottle poured pale golden color with big white head settling quickly to some fine lacing. Aromas of hops and more hops. Taste is predominantly hoppy bitterness with a light malty sweetness in the background. Decently balanced for a bitter and has nice carbonation and mouthfeel.

name: Fischer Bitter
review: Beer no longer available for Fischer products, was sell in France in the typical Fischer bottle but with a green color. The smell was intense on hops and grass. Aroma was very bitter at the beginning followed by a very perfumed aftertaste. One of those beer we really miss.

name: Fischer Bitter
review: 16.6 oz swingtop bottle 9/01-Pours a medium golden with a decent white head. Aroma of caramel and fruits. Taste of dryness, sweetness, and bitterness. This light to medium bodied brew was different but OK to drink.

name: Fischer Bitter
review: This one was kinda too much at first, had a rough front and sorta dry and middle, and definatly hopppie at the close, no exactly my bag, but good for the fans and those who like british type of beers~

name: Fischer Bitter
review: 650 ml green swingtop. Pours a slightly hazy, orange-gold with a four-finger, creamy sticky head. Nice aroma of caramel, fruit, honey, and slight grass. Flavor is amazingly balanced between sweet and dry, having a big dry cereal flavor that is dried by some grassy-herb hops into a mildly sweet and tart caramel apple taste. Light-medium body is refreshing and dry. Nice caramel aftertaste. Seems more like a British style bitter ale than a pilsener, but gets high marks nonetheless.

name: Fischer Bitter
review: A very average beer. I was disappointed considering the cost. This is a transfer from an old account.

name: Fischer Bitter
review: Pours a slightly hazy deep gold with some off white head. Nose is heavy towards apple. Flavor is quite smooth with, yes, a bitter tone in the background, though not predominately so. At the start you get what seems like a bit of a sweetness. Feel is slightly watery with a slight carbonation to it. Very drinkable, though for some that "bitter" might detract. For it being this style, I am impressed. Worth a shot.

name: Grimbergen Cuvée Ambrée / Double (Dubbel)
review: Wygl¹d: Ciemna miedŸ, ju¿ tak podchodz¹ce pod czerwieñ. Takie rubinowe. Piana œrednia mikropêcherzykowa, delikatna. Aromat: S³odki, cukierkowy, mocno karmelkowy, toffi, trochê mlecznej czekolady. Smak: Taki lekki raczej, s³odkawy. Nuty karmelu, toffi, mo¿e miodu. Wysycenie œrednio niskie. Goryczki nie ma, raczej s³odki finisz. Ogólnie: Wygl¹d ³adny, zapach te¿ mo¿e byæ, ale trochê za s³odkie jak dla mnie, za du¿o karmelu.

name: Grimbergen Cuvée Ambrée / Double (Dubbel)
review: Really a very good "Dubbel" and general beer.. Very punchy with lot of carbonation and some bitter satisfying aftertaste.. The colour is dark brown and the taste is bittersweet with decent mouthfeel. Many caramel and chocolate notes here and also some dark fruits.. Overall i find it one excellent "Dubbel" beer to drink and really deserve better ratings.. And has the smallest amount of alcohol for the style. A big benefit..

name: Grimbergen Cuvée Ambrée / Double (Dubbel)
review: As much as i liked it in bottle, i disliked it on tap. Entirely different taste

name: Grimbergen Cuvée Ambrée / Double (Dubbel)
review: Miedziane piwo o doœæ obfitej pianie, która zdobi szk³o i pozostaje do koñca w formie warstewki na powierzchni. Aromat s³odowy, ciemne owoce, rodzynki. W smaku owoce, rodzynki. Goryczka œrednia. Ogólnie ca³kiem udany dubbel.

name: Grimbergen Cuvée Ambrée / Double (Dubbel)
review: Velice pøíjemné pivo. Pøimìøená lehèí hoøkost, lehké èokoládové tony a taky lehce ovoce. Dozvuk s lihovou stopou, což ovšem u tohohle piva není na závadu, spíše naopak.

name: Grimbergen Cuvée Ambrée / Double (Dubbel)
review: Bottle. Clear reddish brown colour with a medium foamy slightly tan head, nose is malty, yeasty, roasty, fruity and slightly boozy with notes of coffee, dark toffee and dried plums, taste is sweet, roasty and fruity with a tart and dry finish.

name: Grimbergen Cuvée Ambrée / Double (Dubbel)
review: Dark red-brown beer with a big heavy light brown long stable head, smell is autumn, autumn fruits, caramel, light sour, taste is fresh, light caramel and malty, bread, spices, herbs, very light sour, creamy texture, medium body, fizzy carbonation, (I drunk this on the Airport Faro in Portugal, on Carlsberg Sportsbar)

name: Grimbergen Cuvée Ambrée / Double (Dubbel)
review: Bottle, TWSP. Clear brown with a small beige head. Caramel, black cherry, toffee aroma. Flavor is black cherry, caramel, light chocolate, green leaf, toffee.

name: Grimbergen Cuvée Ambrée / Double (Dubbel)
review: Piwo lane, barwa miedziana, ³adna, doœæ trwa³a piana. Zostawia koronkê na szkle. W aromacie i smaku nuty s³odowe, karmelowe oraz lekka owocowoœæ (g³ównie czerwone owoce). Jest te¿ dobrze zarysowana goryczka. Solidny Dubbel.

name: Grimbergen Cuvée Ambrée / Double (Dubbel)
review: Found out of bottle from Al Capones in Tarnow, Poland. Pours a nice dark caramel brown with medium foam. Great chocolate notes throughout. Really great Fall option.

name: Fischer Amber
review: The beer has got a clear amber color with a steady head and medium body. Aroma of hops and malt. Taste of hops, caramel, bread, malt. Mild finish

name: Fischer Amber
review: Cerveza francesa flojita. Poquisima espuma. Lager vienna. Malta. No amarga. Gusto aceptable. Refrescante. Poco cuerpo.

name: Beer Works Beantown Nut Brown Ale
review: Reviewed from notes. The appearance was a dark brown color with a finger’s worth of eggshell white foamy head that fell off at a moderate pace. Light messy lace. The aroma had some strong notes of roast, chestnut/pecan, toast, cocoa powder, light coffee grinds and ends with a little bit of earthy hops. The flavor lent a hand to the sweetness initially and then mildly brings in the roast slightly. Some of which blended into the aftertaste and rubs the finish in the same sort of way. The feel was about medium bodied, perhaps just a tad under. Carbonation felt fine. ABV felt good too. Overall, good brown ale worthy of having again.

name: Beer Works Beantown Nut Brown Ale
review: Draft. A dark brown beer with an off-white head. The aroma has notes of roasted malt, caramel, and bread. The flavor is sweet with notes of roasted malt, caramel, and lighter notes of bread and fruits, leading to a dry finish.

name: Beer Works Beantown Nut Brown Ale
review: Boston Beer Works Nut Brown pours a chestnut brown color with a roasted nut aroma. Flavor is simple with a good mixture of roasted malt mixed with a mile sweetness. The sweetness is caramel and molasses. A refreshing and bubbly beer that was easy drinking and enjoyed near Fenway Park.

name: Beer Works Beantown Nut Brown Ale
review: Draft sampler pours brown with a off white head. Aroma of malts, spice and coffee. Taste is malty, nutty and some chocolate.

name: Beer Works Beantown Nut Brown Ale
review: Pours a nearly opaque dark chocolate brown with a fairly thick tan head. Aroma has a malty core with notes of caramel and cloves and a snippet of cinnamon added to it. Roast malt flavor trots cinnamon, caramel, clove and even slight molasses notes across the palate. Lively, fizzy texture is fairly firm, and leaves a tingly feeling on the palate and on the pipes as it heads downstairs. Beans, beans, the musical fruit...

name: Beer Works Beantown Nut Brown Ale
review: Beer had at beer works in boston airport. Beer enjoyable but average as a whole with no standouts. Food was ok, good for the airport the though. Tasting notes as follows: Hub light: clear, acidic, corn, short lasting boston garden golden: light, bready Patriot pilsner: warm, flat, sweet, light hop finish Fenway American Pale Ale: funky hop flavor, bitter start and finish Back Bay IPA: pleasant aroma and hop taste, simple, dry finish boston common: minimal aroma, minimal taste, flat, Beantown Brown: nutty nose, sweet candy taste, newcastle-like Buckeye oat atout: watery, light chocolate flavor

name: Beer Works Beantown Nut Brown Ale
review: 12 oz draft pour for about $5. Brown with almost no head. Aromas of malt and beer. Fairly interesting flavor, it has a fruity bittersweetness I associate with really dark chocolates. Maybe a bit overboard on the dark malt however, tastes almost burnt. This is a totally inoffensive and OK brown ale, nothing to seek out but nothing to avoid. If you’re at Beer Works and want a brown ale go for it.

name: Beer Works Beantown Nut Brown Ale
review: Draft at Logan. Fairly clean brown, bubbly beige head, and mild lace. Nose of not, roast, sweet caramel, chocolate. Medium to light body. Very roasty in the taste, mild bitterness.

name: Beer Works Beantown Nut Brown Ale
review: Draft at Logan Airport Nice looking ale with a dark brown color with a thin biege head. The aroma was mild and of raosted malt. The taste of burnt malt was present with chocolate. The body was light to medium with soft carbonation. Nice finish with roasted malt and nuts.

name: Beer Works Beantown Nut Brown Ale
review: Draught. This is a simple little brown ale that lacks character and feels very thin.

name: Fischer Kingston
review: cheese, spruce, citrus, herbs, cereal, toast, alcohol, rotten eggs, ginger, orange, cloudy, minimal head, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, sticky, soft carbonation, astringent,

name: Brew Moon Munich Gold
review: Sampled at Honolulu location. Light amber colour. Nice hint of hops in the aroma, good balance of malt and hops in the flavour. Crisp, dry finish. Good stuff.

name: Brew Moon Munich Gold
review: Sample pour in Honolulu. Nice head foamed on my lips. Hoppy aroma, dry finish. Good drink.

name: Brew Moon Munich Gold
review: Typical wanna-be German-style lager, but very smooth ......................

name: Brew Moon Munich Gold
review: (King of Prussia, PA) A decent Export style with some possible adjunct notes (but it was difficult to tell). Decent Noble hop aroma.

name: Brew Moon Munich Gold
review: No question as to why this was a gold medal winner. While dark, it's great for a summer time brew because it's light and full of flavor. Highly recommended.

name: Brew Moon Moonlight
review: On tap at the brew pub. Poured a clear yellow with a thin white head. Aroma and flavor of a light beer. I’m sure that this is designed for the light beer drinkers to have something to drink at a microbrewery. Not something I would try again.

name: Brew Moon Moonlight
review: Tap. Sour lemon malt aroma. Pale yellow color with small head. Slightly sour barley flavor with a moderate hops finish. Advertised as a light beer so compared to most light pale lagers, this is very good.

name: Brew Moon Moonlight
review: On tap, Brewpub. You know its bad when my friend smiles after drinking this and shouts, “wow this tastes like Heineken!” Flavor is too light, palate is weak and empty, and there is little finish. Only redeeming quality is that the flavors that are present are not offensive.

name: Brew Moon Moonlight
review: Taster - Brew Moon Brewery - Honolulu, Hawaii 2008 - Hawaiian Beer Run Aroma – Light pilsner aroma with a tad of hops in the nose. Appearance – Golden yellow color, clear with a nice head. Flavor – A light beer flavor this was very nice to finally find a good beer in Hawaii. Palate – Dry finish with a nice Mouthfeel. Overall – This was a very good Pilsner and to help my Hawaiian beer experience. The brewery was clean and the beer was very nice.

name: Brew Moon Moonlight
review: On tap at the Brew Moon located in the Ward Center. Poured a lighter yellow color with a very small sized head. Aromas and tastes of graininess and some sweet maltiness. Light yeast. Lacing left on the glass.

name: Brew Moon Moonlight
review: Sampled at the brewery with tastes of mild hops and carbonation in the throat. Lots of bubbles. A slight taste of yeast appeared in the ending.

name: Brew Moon Moonlight
review: Very pale. Thin in color and aroma and flavor. Some malty and yeasty bread in the flavor, but not very exciting.

name: Brew Moon Moonlight
review: Sampler - Light lemony aroma. Clear bright straw color w/ thin white ring of a head. Moderate flavor of bitters, lightly acidic with short finish. Medium bodied, but I thought it was pretty good. Lagers aren’t my favorite.

name: Brew Moon Moonlight
review: sampler. Very thin and light pale color and body. Good thin white head. Very weak and water. Better than a bud light though.

name: Brew Moon Moonlight
review: Slighty spicy nose with a clear, pale yellow body; snappy palate, though not in a pleasing way; weak

name: Brew Moon Lost Planet IPA
review: Light color, very hoppy, well balanced, very smooth .......................

name: Brew Moon Eclipse
review: Creamy black body with a thin brown head. Aroma of roasted malts. Nice coffee flavor with some sweetness. Best of Brew Moon’s offerings.

name: Brew Moon Eclipse
review: pours with a creamy, thin head; roast and malt in the nose; smooth maltiness and roasted, bitterish coffee and cocoa flavor; smooth, creamy palate, dry finish; best brew I had there, it’s quite good

name: Brew Moon Eclipse
review: Full body, very rich, coffee tones in the aftertaste........................

name: Woodchuck Amber Draft Cider
brewery: Vermont Hard Cider Company, LLC (C&C Group)
review: Bottle, 355 ml at The Beerhive, SLC. Clear amber, no head. Too sweet, low carbonation, sweet apples, light bodied. Pretty much sweet apple juice.

name: Woodchuck Amber Draft Cider
brewery: Vermont Hard Cider Company, LLC (C&C Group)
review: Dégustée le 2019-08-10. .

name: Woodchuck Amber Draft Cider
brewery: Vermont Hard Cider Company, LLC (C&C Group)
review: Woooahhh!! Way too sweet and sugary. If you like classic cider, this is it. This is also the most manly one to drink.

name: Woodchuck Amber Draft Cider
brewery: Vermont Hard Cider Company, LLC (C&C Group)
review: Been following the cider thread in forums and got all in mood, unfortunately no actual good cider was available to me today so grabbed some woodchuck from Publix. Clear amber pour. Nose is sugary apples and perfume. Tastes of caramel, flowers, apple pulp. Sugary but not terribly sweet thank heavens. Resorting to these measures makes me miss the northeast.

name: Woodchuck Amber Draft Cider
brewery: Vermont Hard Cider Company, LLC (C&C Group)
review: Excellent amber cider, sweet flavor with a satisfying aftertaste. It doesn’t leave you craving another one but leaves you refreshed. Not the best cider if I wanted to drink multiple but the ideal one and done drink.

name: Woodchuck Amber Draft Cider
brewery: Vermont Hard Cider Company, LLC (C&C Group)
review: Pours clear light amber. Aroma is bright apples, not unpleasant. Taste is similar, a bit of a vanilla note, quite sweet. Mouthfeel is light and refreshing. Not a bad thirst quencher, not complex.

name: Woodchuck Amber Draft Cider
brewery: Vermont Hard Cider Company, LLC (C&C Group)
review: Nice cider. Easy to drink, has mild aroma, flavor not too sweet or too tart, as many have noted. To me that makes it an excellent cider. I could drink 5 or 6 of these. No bloat feeling at all. I did not get other tastes other than just apple. No real aftertaste, just a pleasant cider flavor. Well done, Vermont Cider Co.

name: Woodchuck Amber Draft Cider
brewery: Vermont Hard Cider Company, LLC (C&C Group)
review: Have only had it out of the bottle. Not overly sweet like many ciders so I come back to it often.

name: Woodchuck Amber Draft Cider
brewery: Vermont Hard Cider Company, LLC (C&C Group)
review: Down the middle cider. Not too sweet or too tart. Not super great, but easy.

name: Woodchuck Amber Draft Cider
brewery: Vermont Hard Cider Company, LLC (C&C Group)
review: Sampled at Thunderbird hostel. No head. Clear light amber pour. Easy drinking. Not too sweet or tart

name: Brew Moon Nutcracker
review: Oh so malty, sweet in the mouth with caramel and bready cake like flavours.

name: Woodchuck Dark and Dry 802 Draft Cider
brewery: Vermont Hard Cider Company, LLC (C&C Group)
review: Backlog rating. Bottle from Old Town. Big apple-forward nose with some white wine notes and caramel. Fairly sweet on the palate, light cinnamon, caramel and wine notes. Some light dryness on the finish, but mostly sweet.

name: Woodchuck Dark and Dry 802 Draft Cider
brewery: Vermont Hard Cider Company, LLC (C&C Group)
review: Bottle. A- Apples. A- Amber color, clear liquid, minimal head. T- Apples, dry, slightly sweet. P- Light body, average texture, medium carbonation, dry finish. O- Dry and a bit skunky. Not my thing.

name: Woodchuck Dark and Dry 802 Draft Cider
brewery: Vermont Hard Cider Company, LLC (C&C Group)
review: Tap. Amber pour with no head. Apple, tart. A bit on a sweet side but nice and crisp

name: Woodchuck Dark and Dry 802 Draft Cider
brewery: Vermont Hard Cider Company, LLC (C&C Group)
review: This is way too sweet for my taste. Almost like apple juice. No tartness or dryness at all to speak of. Not my favorite.

name: Woodchuck Dark and Dry 802 Draft Cider
brewery: Vermont Hard Cider Company, LLC (C&C Group)
review: 12 Fl. Oz. Bottle. Poured dark amber, clear, small white head. Aroma of ripe red apple. Taste of apple and some yeast; tart and a bit dry. Crisp and refreshing. Not bad.

name: Woodchuck Dark and Dry 802 Draft Cider
brewery: Vermont Hard Cider Company, LLC (C&C Group)
review: Rated based on notes taken 14 July 2012 -- Not my favorite Woodchuck, very forgettable.

name: Woodchuck Dark and Dry 802 Draft Cider
brewery: Vermont Hard Cider Company, LLC (C&C Group)
review: Pour out of 12 oz bottle, dark orange pour with white head, aroma brought notes of caramel, toffee, some apple notes, vanilla into a bit of white wine, some grape, hints of spice. Taste was a mix of caramel, apple, vanilla into white wine, touch of white grape, finishing slightly sweet.

name: Woodchuck Dark and Dry 802 Draft Cider
brewery: Vermont Hard Cider Company, LLC (C&C Group)
review: Good carbonation and aroma seen upon pouring. Dry on palate that is balanced nicely with the sweetness. Overall very drinkable and enjoyable medium cider.

name: Woodchuck Dark and Dry 802 Draft Cider
brewery: Vermont Hard Cider Company, LLC (C&C Group)
review: 12oz bottle. a golden pour, not a lot going on. Very syrupy nose, faint pear, a lot of apple obviously. sweeter than most ciders, not a lot of mouthfeel. honey is prominent. lightly bitter older apple finish.

name: Woodchuck Dark and Dry 802 Draft Cider
brewery: Vermont Hard Cider Company, LLC (C&C Group)
review: 12 oz bottle at home. Pours a clear light amber color with no head. The aroma and flavor have sweet apples, mild spices, a light tang, barely more interesting than a basic cider.

name: Woodchuck Granny Smith Draft Cider
brewery: Vermont Hard Cider Company, LLC (C&C Group)
review: Tried this a couple years ago. Remember it being one of the better standard ciders that I had at the time, until recently I just tried the pear which seemed smoother. The green apple had that tart flavor whereas the pear was a little sweeter. Starting to get into ciders more, but this is something somebody else usually brings that I'll sample a single from. I would like to try them both again to compare, but I know there are better ones out there.

name: Woodchuck Granny Smith Draft Cider
brewery: Vermont Hard Cider Company, LLC (C&C Group)
review: Bottle at home just fishing the last of supermarket shelves unticked. Light cider pour. Nose is tart apple and perfume. Tastes of decent Granny Smith, light flowers, lime, residual sugar. Too much sugar but overall not terrible.

name: Woodchuck Granny Smith Draft Cider
brewery: Vermont Hard Cider Company, LLC (C&C Group)
review: I got this in Colorado. Pours light yellow with a white head. Taste tart, green apple. I thought was good. I would drink this again. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Woodchuck Granny Smith Draft Cider
brewery: Vermont Hard Cider Company, LLC (C&C Group)
review: Pours a very clear light lime color. Sort of like you took water and squeezed a lime into it. No head, no lacing. Aroma is light apple skin and tart. Taste is sweet tart. Perhaps a little too sweet. Tastes like Granny Smith apple skin. A little too watery. Mouthfeel is light. Tart. Sharp dryness, which may be the only thing that saves the cider. Overall, it’s not great. I guess it would beat NOT having a cider. But if I had to choose between this and another one; I would choose the other one.

name: Woodchuck Granny Smith Draft Cider
brewery: Vermont Hard Cider Company, LLC (C&C Group)
review: Pretty unappealing cider. Far too much sweetness. Granny Smith tartness understated. Tried for the first time in 2007.

name: Woodchuck Granny Smith Draft Cider
brewery: Vermont Hard Cider Company, LLC (C&C Group)
review: Bottle, 355 ml from State Liquor Store, St George, Utah. Pours pale golden, almost no head. Mostly apples, moderate tartness, sweet. Light bodied.

name: Woodchuck Granny Smith Draft Cider
brewery: Vermont Hard Cider Company, LLC (C&C Group)
review: Love this stuff. Dry yum yum. Refreshing. So enjoyable to drink. Lovely job here ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Woodchuck Granny Smith Draft Cider
brewery: Vermont Hard Cider Company, LLC (C&C Group)
review: 12 oz. bottle. Thanks Thomas! Pours clear, pale green, with no head. Distinct tart apples, vanilla, cloves, and light lemon. Sweet and fruity up front, with a good tart bite in the finish. Light body, with a crisp and acidic mouthfeel. Not a bad cider. The tart bite is pleasant and easy, and there’s a little more complexity here than most ciders.

name: Woodchuck Granny Smith Draft Cider
brewery: Vermont Hard Cider Company, LLC (C&C Group)
review: 355ml bottle. Clear pale white-golden with brief white head. Somewhat perfumy sweet apple aroma with only a light tart hint. Taste is mostly sweet concentrate based apple juice with only a light tart touch. Light mouthfeel, minimal carbonation and light perfumy aftertaste.

name: Woodchuck Granny Smith Draft Cider
brewery: Vermont Hard Cider Company, LLC (C&C Group)
review: This was ok for a cider, however was not the best cider that I have ever had.

name: Brew Moon Mayberry Wheat R.F.D.
review: Tap (listed as Moonberry Wheat). Raspberry wheat malt aroma. Pale yellow color with small head. Light raspberry wheat malt flavor. Nice frutiy flavor but very light.

name: Brew Moon Mayberry Wheat R.F.D.
review: On tap. Bad sign when even my girlfriend claims it is just too “weak” in flavor. Pours a cloudy light yellow with a cream-white head. Served with a lemon in a pint glass that is chilled in the fridge. Nice touch, but how much pizzazz do they need to throw in to mask a mediocre beer? Flavor is primarily wheat notes, light spice, and then a raspberry-sweet flavor. Not entirely bad, but where this beer really loses points is the finish. It seems like before the beer even goes down your throat, it has lost ALL of its earlier flavor and replaced it with strangely astringent cut-grass. Seems a bit gimmicky.

name: Brew Moon Mayberry Wheat R.F.D.
review: Taster - Brew Moon Brewery - Honolulu, Hawaii 2008 - Hawaiian Beer Run Aroma – Light ale aroma with the smattering of berry aroma also. Appearance – Golden yellow color, hazy with a nice head. Flavor – This had a good wheat flavor with the smallest amount of fruit that I could possibly taste. It was light but over all ot a bad beer. Palate – Nice wheat Mouthfeel with a nice easy dry finish. Overall – A very nice wheat beer this could use a tad more fruit. The bee would sell like hotcakes if the fruit was really more present. The ladies would go nuts.

name: Brew Moon Mayberry Wheat R.F.D.
review: On tap at the Brew Moon located in the Ward Center. Labeled as the ’Moon Berry Wheat’. Served with a slice of lemon. Poured a medium golden color with a small sized white head. Aromas of berries, wheat, and citrus. Tastes follow suit although on the weaker side. Light to medium berry tart finish. I liked the berry aroma.

name: Brew Moon Mayberry Wheat R.F.D.
review: Sampled at the brewery with tastes of wheat and some blueberries. I thought this one was rather interesting.

name: Brew Moon Mayberry Wheat R.F.D.
review: Draft at brewpub. Aromas were fruity as expected. Flavors were not as fruity with the wheat twang overpowering the fruit. American Wheats just don’t do it for me.

name: Brew Moon Mayberry Wheat R.F.D.
review: I don’t know if this is the Moonberry (raspberry) Wheat, but that’s what I had. I couldn’t detect the aroma. It had a clear lemon color, flavor of lemon rind (they went ahead and dropped the lemon in the glass.) Nice finish, even a bit syrupy. Pretty good but kind of mellow for the style.

name: Brew Moon Mayberry Wheat R.F.D.
review: sampler, was called a Moonberry wheat now. Pours with a little yellow gold haze to it. Has a nice malt flavor with a good balance of the blueberry flavor with lemon or something that blends very well. Lance was good just it finish with a slighty sour finish.

name: Brew Moon Mayberry Wheat R.F.D.
review: Always tastes lemony when that put a fat piece of lemon in a 4oz sample: other than that it has a berry fruitiness accomponying a less than smooth palate, esp for a wheat

name: Brew Moon Mayberry Wheat R.F.D.
review: Moon Berry Wheat: poured a cloudy banana yellow with a thin white head. Lightly fruity-raspberry-aroma and lightly floral. Light raspberry flavor. Not overwhelming. Sour finish. Pretty decent.

name: Brew Moon Grasshopper IPA
review: One of the better IPAs of my life. I just wish that the pub in Honolulu was a nicer place to drink.

name: Brew Moon Grasshopper IPA
review: Another outstanding brew from the folks at Brew Moon. Aggressively hopped is a great description, fills the mouth with hoppy flavor immediately and warms the back of the throat. This IPA has attained style perfection in my book.

name: Woodpecker Cider
review: 275 ml bottle at abv 3.5% bought at 517 Food Place in Tsuen Wan. Clear light golden colour with orange hue; Near zero head with residual soapy white foam which fades in 5 seconds; Poor sticky lacing with near zero carbonation; Quite fragrant aroma of light apple wine, with yoghurt, light mustiness, apple juice and sugar; Close to medium sweet taste of light apple juice, with alcohol, fair yoghurt, soda, sugar, and light tannin; Light body. Watery palate; Mouth feel is watered-down apple juice with pretty naked light booze, some apples, yoghurt and mustiness. White washed, very soda-ish with fair sweetness. Light tannin finish. Bad!... Slightly dry after taste. Very easy to mouth. Comments: Another macro cider nightmare, probably being cut from some the same cloth with Babycham - over-diluted fruit juice, too soda-ish, naked light booze - in this case there's at least a hint of apple juice and yoghurty characters, but not enough to write home about. I rather have apple juice than this!

name: Woodpecker Cider
review: Looks a lot like Lucozade in a glass. Very sweet and artificial, far sweeter than Strongbow, Blackthorn etc. Has a nasty saccharine aftertaste like sucking on a Canderel, with some apples, caramel and heap of barley sugar. Best Avoided. Tried on draught many years ago.

name: Woodpecker Cider
review: 275ml bottle. Pours pale yellow with no head. Aroma is apple juice. Taste is sweet apples. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Woodpecker Cider
review: Bottke on Malta. Weak light golden pour with lacings. Notes of apples, pears, lime, sweet and straw.

name: Woodpecker Cider
review: Clear golden-orange colour with a small white fading head. Aromas of sweet ripe apple develops mainly. Rather lively, bit slick texture and light-medium bodied. Clogging sweetness of candy-apple predominates. Medium finish.

name: Woodpecker Cider
review: Glass bottle. Clear gold. Thinest head. Low to medium sweetness. Thin body. Aroma is red apples.

name: Woodpecker Cider
review: @Liverpool, Italian restaurant, from the bottle. Clear amber/orange white head, apple aroma, flavor is slight sourish, sweet, apple, acidity overall not bad however not that great either. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Woodpecker Cider
review: Golden color with a small bubbly head. Mild acidic apple aroma. Medium body. Tad sweet and moderate acidic. Average carbonation. Nice fine apple flavor. Ok and easy drinkable cider. Maybe a bit to much on the sweet side. But overall ok 4% cider. [Bottle from an off license in Liverpool, England]

name: Woodpecker Cider
review: pale, clear, heavy cloying sweetness, light body, lively, long finish, had many cans of this in my younger days never lowered my standards to frosty jack and white lightning this was my pre night cheap and cheerfull booster wrong i know but we all did it

name: Woodpecker Cider
review: 33cl bottle at "all you can eat" Chinese in Shrewsbury. Appearance - golden orange with no head and loads of carbonation. Nose - sweet apples. Taste - fresh but again sweet apples. Palate - light to medium bodied with a tangy texture and a long dry finish. Overall - not the sour still style I prefer.
